children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The reader guesses beforehand whom the usher preceded in announcing the courier from Bretagne. This messenger was easily recognized. It was D'Artagnan, his clothes dusty, his face inflamed, his hair dripping with sweat, his legs stiff; he lifted his feet painfully at every step, on which resounded the clink of his bloodstained spurs. He perceived in the doorway he was passing through, the superintendent coming out. Fouquet bowed with a smile to him who, an hour before, was bringing him ruin and death. D'Artagnan found in his goodness of heart, and in his inexhaustible vigor of body, enough presence of mind to remember the kind reception of this man; he bowed then, also, much more from benevolence and compassion, than from respect. He felt upon his lips the word which had so many times been repeated to the Duc de Guise: Fly. But to pronounce that word would have been to betray his cause; to speak that word in the cabinet of the king, and before an usher, would have been to ruin himself gratuitously, and could save nobody. D'Artagnan then, contented himself with bowing to Fouquet and entered. At this moment the king floated between the joy the last words of Fouquet had given him, and his pleasure at the return of D'Artagnan. Without being a courtier, D'Artagnan had a glance as sure and as rapid as if he had been one. He read, on his entrance, devouring humiliation on the countenance of Colbert. He even heard the king say these words to him:

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Ah! Monsieur Colbert; you have then nine hundred thousand livres at the intendance? Colbert, suffocated, bowed but made no reply. All this scene entered into the mind of D'Artagnan, by the eyes and ears, at once.
children.prevalue: Ah Monsieur Colbert you have then nine hundred thousand livres at the intendance Colbert suffocated bowed but made no reply All this scene entered into the mind of D Artagnan by the eyes and ears at once

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The first word of Louis to his musketeer, as if he wished it to contrast with what he was saying at the moment, was a kind good day. His second was to send away Colbert. The latter left the king's cabinet, pallid and tottering, whilst D'Artagnan twisted up the ends of his mustache.
children.prevalue: The first word of Louis to his musketeer as if he wished it to contrast with what he was saying at the moment was a kind good day His second was to send away Colbert The latter left the king s cabinet pallid and tottering whilst D Artagnan twisted up the ends of his mustache

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: I love to see one of my servants in this disorder, said the king, admiring the martial stains upon the clothes of his envoy.
children.prevalue: I love to see one of my servants in this disorder said the king admiring the martial stains upon the clothes of his envoy

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: I thought, sire, my presence at the Louvre was sufficiently urgent to excuse my presenting myself thus before you.
children.prevalue: I thought sire my presence at the Louvre was sufficiently urgent to excuse my presenting myself thus before you

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: You bring me great news, then, monsieur?
children.prevalue: You bring me great news then monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Sire, the thing is this, in two words: BelleIsle is fortified, admirably fortified; BelleIsle has a double enceinte, a citadel, two detached forts; its ports contain three corsairs; and the side batteries only await their cannon.
children.prevalue: Sire the thing is this in two words BelleIsle is fortified admirably fortified BelleIsle has a double enceinte a citadel two detached forts its ports contain three corsairs and the side batteries only await their cannon

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: I know all that, monsieur, replied the king.
children.prevalue: I know all that monsieur replied the king

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: What! your majesty knows all that? replied the musketeer, stupefied.
children.prevalue: What your majesty knows all that replied the musketeer stupefied

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I have the plan of the fortifications of BelleIsle, said the king.
children.prevalue: I have the plan of the fortifications of BelleIsle said the king

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Your majesty has the plan?
children.prevalue: Your majesty has the plan

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Here it is.
children.prevalue: Here it is

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: It is really correct, sire: I saw a similar one on the spot.
children.prevalue: It is really correct sire I saw a similar one on the spot

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: D'Artagnan's brow became clouded.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan s brow became clouded

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Ah! I understand all. Your majesty did not trust to me alone, but sent some other person, said he in a reproachful tone.
children.prevalue: Ah I understand all Your majesty did not trust to me alone but sent some other person said he in a reproachful tone

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Of what importance is the manner, monsieur, in which I have learnt what I know, so that I know it?
children.prevalue: Of what importance is the manner monsieur in which I have learnt what I know so that I know it

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Sire, sire, said the musketeer, without seeking even to conceal his dissatisfaction; but I must be permitted to say to your majesty, that it is not worth while to make me use such speed, to risk twenty times the breaking of my neck, to salute me on my arrival with such intelligence. Sire, when people are not trusted, or are deemed insufficient, they should scarcely be employed. And D'Artagnan, with a movement perfectly military, stamped with his foot, and left upon the floor dust stained with blood. The king looked at him, inwardly enjoying his first triumph.
children.prevalue: Sire sire said the musketeer without seeking even to conceal his dissatisfaction but I must be permitted to say to your majesty that it is not worth while to make me use such speed to risk twenty times the breaking of my neck to salute me on my arrival with such intelligence Sire when people are not trusted or are deemed insufficient they should scarcely be employed And D Artagnan with a movement perfectly military stamped with his foot and left upon the floor dust stained with blood The king looked at him inwardly enjoying his first triumph

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Monsieur, said he, at the expiration of a minute, not only is BelleIsle known to me, but, still further, BelleIsle is mine.
children.prevalue: Monsieur said he at the expiration of a minute not only is BelleIsle known to me but still further BelleIsle is mine

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: That is well! that is well, sire, I ask but one thing more, replied D'Artagnan.My discharge.
children.prevalue: That is well that is well sire I ask but one thing more replied D Artagnan My discharge

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: What! your discharge?
children.prevalue: What your discharge

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Without doubt I am too proud to eat the bread of the king without earning it, or rather by gaining it badly.My discharge, sire!
children.prevalue: Without doubt I am too proud to eat the bread of the king without earning it or rather by gaining it badly My discharge sire

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Oh, oh!
children.prevalue: Oh oh

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: I ask for my discharge, or I will take it.
children.prevalue: I ask for my discharge or I will take it

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: You are angry, monsieur?
children.prevalue: You are angry monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I have reason, mordioux! Thirtytwo hours in the saddle, I ride day and night, I perform prodigies of speed, I arrive stiff as the corpse of a man who has been hungand another arrives before me! Come, sire, I am a fool!My discharge, sire!
children.prevalue: I have reason mordioux Thirtytwo hours in the saddle I ride day and night I perform prodigies of speed I arrive stiff as the corpse of a man who has been hungand another arrives before me Come sire I am a fool My discharge sire

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Monsieur d'Artagnan, said Louis, leaning his white hand upon the dusty arm of the musketeer, what I tell you will not at all affect that which I promised you. A king's word given must be kept. And the king going straight to his table, opened a drawer, and took out a folded paper. Here is your commission of captain of musketeers; you have won it, Monsieur d'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Monsieur d Artagnan said Louis leaning his white hand upon the dusty arm of the musketeer what I tell you will not at all affect that which I promised you A king s word given must be kept And the king going straight to his table opened a drawer and took out a folded paper Here is your commission of captain of musketeers you have won it Monsieur d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: D'Artagnan opened the paper eagerly, and scanned it twice. He could scarcely believe his eyes.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan opened the paper eagerly and scanned it twice He could scarcely believe his eyes

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: And this commission is given you, continued the king, not only on account of your journey to BelleIsle but, moreover, for your brave intervention at the Place de Greve. There, likewise, you served me valiantly.
children.prevalue: And this commission is given you continued the king not only on account of your journey to BelleIsle but moreover for your brave intervention at the Place de Greve There likewise you served me valiantly

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Ah, ah! said D'Artagnan, without his selfcommand being able to prevent a blush from mounting to his eyesyou know that also, sire?
children.prevalue: Ah ah said D Artagnan without his selfcommand being able to prevent a blush from mounting to his eyesyou know that also sire

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Yes, I know it.
children.prevalue: Yes I know it

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: The king possessed a piercing glance and an infallible judgment when it was his object to read men's minds. You have something to say, said he to the musketeer, something to say which you do not say. Come, speak freely, monsieur; you know that I told you, once and for all, that you are to be always quite frank with me.
children.prevalue: The king possessed a piercing glance and an infallible judgment when it was his object to read men s minds You have something to say said he to the musketeer something to say which you do not say Come speak freely monsieur you know that I told you once and for all that you are to be always quite frank with me

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Well, sire! what I have to say is this, that I would prefer being made captain of the musketeers for having charged a battery at the head of my company, or taken a city, than for causing two wretches to be hung.
children.prevalue: Well sire what I have to say is this that I would prefer being made captain of the musketeers for having charged a battery at the head of my company or taken a city than for causing two wretches to be hung

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Is this quite true you tell me?
children.prevalue: Is this quite true you tell me

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: And why should your majesty suspect me of dissimulation, I ask?
children.prevalue: And why should your majesty suspect me of dissimulation I ask

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Because I have known you well, monsieur; you cannot repent of having drawn your sword for me.
children.prevalue: Because I have known you well monsieur you cannot repent of having drawn your sword for me

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Well, in that your majesty is deceived, and greatly; yes, I do repent of having drawn my sword on account of the results that action produced; the poor men who were hung, sire, were neither your enemies nor mine; and they could not defend themselves.
children.prevalue: Well in that your majesty is deceived and greatly yes I do repent of having drawn my sword on account of the results that action produced the poor men who were hung sire were neither your enemies nor mine and they could not defend themselves

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The king preserved silence for a moment. And your companion, M. d'Artagnan, does he partake of your repentance?
children.prevalue: The king preserved silence for a moment And your companion M d Artagnan does he partake of your repentance

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: My companion?
children.prevalue: My companion

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Yes, you were not alone, I have been told.
children.prevalue: Yes you were not alone I have been told

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Alone, where?
children.prevalue: Alone where

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: At the Place de Greve.
children.prevalue: At the Place de Greve

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: No, sire, no, said D'Artagnan, blushing at the idea that the king might have a suspicion that he, D'Artagnan, had wished to engross to himself all the glory that belonged to Raoul; no, mordioux! and as your majesty says, I had a companion, and a good companion, too.
children.prevalue: No sire no said D Artagnan blushing at the idea that the king might have a suspicion that he D Artagnan had wished to engross to himself all the glory that belonged to Raoul no mordioux and as your majesty says I had a companion and a good companion too

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: A young man?
children.prevalue: A young man

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Yes, sire; a young man. Oh! your majesty must accept my compliments, you are as well informed of things out of doors as things within. It is M. Colbert who makes all these fine reports to the king.
children.prevalue: Yes sire a young man Oh your majesty must accept my compliments you are as well informed of things out of doors as things within It is M Colbert who makes all these fine reports to the king

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: M. Colbert has said nothing but good of you, M. d'Artagnan, and he would have met with a bad reception if he had come to tell me anything else.
children.prevalue: M Colbert has said nothing but good of you M d Artagnan and he would have met with a bad reception if he had come to tell me anything else

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: That is fortunate!
children.prevalue: That is fortunate

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: But he also said much good of that young man.
children.prevalue: But he also said much good of that young man

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: And with justice, said the musketeer.
children.prevalue: And with justice said the musketeer

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: In short, it appears that this young man is a fireeater, said Louis, in order to sharpen the sentiment which he mistook for envy.
children.prevalue: In short it appears that this young man is a fireeater said Louis in order to sharpen the sentiment which he mistook for envy

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: A fireeater! Yes, sire, repeated D'Artagnan, delighted on his part to direct the king's attention to Raoul.
children.prevalue: A fireeater Yes sire repeated D Artagnan delighted on his part to direct the king s attention to Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Do you not know his name?
children.prevalue: Do you not know his name

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Well, I think
children.prevalue: Well I think

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: You know him then?
children.prevalue: You know him then

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: I have known him nearly fiveandtwenty years, sire.
children.prevalue: I have known him nearly fiveandtwenty years sire

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Why, he is scarcely twentyfive years old! cried the king.
children.prevalue: Why he is scarcely twentyfive years old cried the king

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Well, sire! I have known him ever since he was born, that is all.
children.prevalue: Well sire I have known him ever since he was born that is all

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Do you affirm that?
children.prevalue: Do you affirm that

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Sire, said D'Artagnan, your majesty questions me with a mistrust in which I recognize another character than your own. M. Colbert, who has so well informed you, has he not forgotten to tell you that this young man is the son of my most intimate friend?
children.prevalue: Sire said D Artagnan your majesty questions me with a mistrust in which I recognize another character than your own M Colbert who has so well informed you has he not forgotten to tell you that this young man is the son of my most intimate friend

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: The Vicomte de Bragelonne?
children.prevalue: The Vicomte de Bragelonne

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Certainly, sire. The father of the Vicomte de Bragelonne is M. le Comte de la Fere, who so powerfully assisted in the restoration of King Charles II. Bragelonne comes of a valiant race, sire.
children.prevalue: Certainly sire The father of the Vicomte de Bragelonne is M le Comte de la Fere who so powerfully assisted in the restoration of King Charles II Bragelonne comes of a valiant race sire

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Then he is the son of that nobleman who came to me, or rather to M. Mazarin, on the part of King Charles II., to offer me his alliance?
children.prevalue: Then he is the son of that nobleman who came to me or rather to M Mazarin on the part of King Charles II to offer me his alliance

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Exactly, sire.
children.prevalue: Exactly sire

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: And the Comte de la Fere is a great soldier, say you?
children.prevalue: And the Comte de la Fere is a great soldier say you

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Sire, he is a man who has drawn his sword more times for the king, your father, than there are, at present, months in the happy life of your majesty.
children.prevalue: Sire he is a man who has drawn his sword more times for the king your father than there are at present months in the happy life of your majesty

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: It was Louis XIV. who now bit his lip.
children.prevalue: It was Louis XIV who now bit his lip

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: That is well, M. d'Artagnan, very well! And M. le Comte de la Fere is your friend, say you?
children.prevalue: That is well M d Artagnan very well And M le Comte de la Fere is your friend say you

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: For about forty years; yes, sire. Your majesty may see that I do not speak to you of yesterday.
children.prevalue: For about forty years yes sire Your majesty may see that I do not speak to you of yesterday

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Should you be glad to see this young man, M. d'Artagnan?
children.prevalue: Should you be glad to see this young man M d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Delighted, sire.
children.prevalue: Delighted sire

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: The king touched his bell, and an usher appeared. Call M. de Bragelonne, said the king.
children.prevalue: The king touched his bell and an usher appeared Call M de Bragelonne said the king

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Ah! ah! he is here? said D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Ah ah he is here said D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: He is on guard today, at the Louvre, with the company of the gentlemen of monsieur le prince.
children.prevalue: He is on guard today at the Louvre with the company of the gentlemen of monsieur le prince

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: The king had scarcely ceased speaking, when Raoul presented himself, and, on seeing D'Artagnan, smiled on him with that charming smile which is only found upon the lips of youth.
children.prevalue: The king had scarcely ceased speaking when Raoul presented himself and on seeing D Artagnan smiled on him with that charming smile which is only found upon the lips of youth

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Come, come, said D'Artagnan, familiarly, to Raoul, the king will allow you to embrace me; only tell his majesty you thank him.
children.prevalue: Come come said D Artagnan familiarly to Raoul the king will allow you to embrace me only tell his majesty you thank him

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Raoul bowed so gracefully, that Louis, to whom all superior qualities were pleasing when they did not overshadow his own, admired his beauty, strength, and modesty.
children.prevalue: Raoul bowed so gracefully that Louis to whom all superior qualities were pleasing when they did not overshadow his own admired his beauty strength and modesty

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Monsieur, said the king, addressing Raoul, I have asked monsieur le prince to be kind enough to give you up to me; I have received his reply, and you belong to me from this morning. Monsieur le prince was a good master, but I hope you will not lose by the exchange.
children.prevalue: Monsieur said the king addressing Raoul I have asked monsieur le prince to be kind enough to give you up to me I have received his reply and you belong to me from this morning Monsieur le prince was a good master but I hope you will not lose by the exchange

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Yes, yes, Raoul, be satisfied; the king has some good in him, said D'Artagnan, who had fathomed the character of Louis, and who played with his selflove, within certain limits; always observing, be it understood, the proprieties and flattering, even when he appeared to be bantering.
children.prevalue: Yes yes Raoul be satisfied the king has some good in him said D Artagnan who had fathomed the character of Louis and who played with his selflove within certain limits always observing be it understood the proprieties and flattering even when he appeared to be bantering

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Sire, said Bragelonne, with voice soft and musical, and with the natural and easy elocution he inherited from his father; Sire, it is not from today that I belong to your majesty.
children.prevalue: Sire said Bragelonne with voice soft and musical and with the natural and easy elocution he inherited from his father Sire it is not from today that I belong to your majesty

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Oh! no, I know, said the king, you mean your enterprise of the Greve. That day, you were truly mine, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Oh no I know said the king you mean your enterprise of the Greve That day you were truly mine monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Sire, it is not of that day I would speak; it would not become me to refer to so paltry a service in the presence of such a man as M. d'Artagnan. I would speak of a circumstance which created an epoch in my life, and which consecrated me, from the age of sixteen, to the devoted service of your majesty.
children.prevalue: Sire it is not of that day I would speak it would not become me to refer to so paltry a service in the presence of such a man as M d Artagnan I would speak of a circumstance which created an epoch in my life and which consecrated me from the age of sixteen to the devoted service of your majesty

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Ah! ah! said the king, what was that circumstance? Tell me, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Ah ah said the king what was that circumstance Tell me monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: This is it, sire.When I was setting out on my first campaign, that is to say, to join the army of monsieur le prince, M. le Comte de la Fere came to conduct me as far as SaintDenis, where the remains of King Louis XIII. wait, upon the lowest steps of the funeral basilique, a successor, whom God will not send him, I hope, for many years. Then he made me swear upon the ashes of our masters, to serve royalty, represented by youincarnate in you, sireto serve it in word, in thought, and in action. I swore, and God and the dead were witnesses to my oath. During ten years, sire, I have not so often as I desired had occasion to keep it. I am a soldier of your majesty, and nothing else; and, on calling me nearer to you, I do not change my master, I only change my garrison.
children.prevalue: This is it sire When I was setting out on my first campaign that is to say to join the army of monsieur le prince M le Comte de la Fere came to conduct me as far as SaintDenis where the remains of King Louis XIII wait upon the lowest steps of the funeral basilique a successor whom God will not send him I hope for many years Then he made me swear upon the ashes of our masters to serve royalty represented by youincarnate in you sireto serve it in word in thought and in action I swore and God and the dead were witnesses to my oath During ten years sire I have not so often as I desired had occasion to keep it I am a soldier of your majesty and nothing else and on calling me nearer to you I do not change my master I only change my garrison

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Raoul was silent and bowed. Louis still listened after he had done speaking.
children.prevalue: Raoul was silent and bowed Louis still listened after he had done speaking

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Mordioux! cried D'Artagnan, that was well spoken! was it not, your majesty? A good race! a noble race!
children.prevalue: Mordioux cried D Artagnan that was well spoken was it not your majesty A good race a noble race

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Yes, murmured the king, without, however daring to manifest his emotion, for it had no other cause than contact with a nature intrinsically noble. Yes, monsieur, you say truly:wherever you were, you were the king's. But in changing your garrison, believe me you will find an advancement of which you are worthy.
children.prevalue: Yes murmured the king without however daring to manifest his emotion for it had no other cause than contact with a nature intrinsically noble Yes monsieur you say truly wherever you were you were the king s But in changing your garrison believe me you will find an advancement of which you are worthy

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Raoul saw that this ended what the king had to say to him. And with the perfect tact which characterized his refined nature, he bowed and retired.
children.prevalue: Raoul saw that this ended what the king had to say to him And with the perfect tact which characterized his refined nature he bowed and retired

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Is there anything else, monsieur, of which you have to inform me? said the king, when he found himself again alone with D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Is there anything else monsieur of which you have to inform me said the king when he found himself again alone with D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Yes, sire, and I kept that news for the last, for it is sad, and will clothe European royalty in mourning.
children.prevalue: Yes sire and I kept that news for the last for it is sad and will clothe European royalty in mourning

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: What do you tell me?
children.prevalue: What do you tell me

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Sire, in passing through Blois, a word, a sad word, echoed from the palace, struck my ear.
children.prevalue: Sire in passing through Blois a word a sad word echoed from the palace struck my ear

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: In truth, you terrify me, M. d'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: In truth you terrify me M d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Sire, this word was pronounced to me by a piqueur, who wore crape on his arm.
children.prevalue: Sire this word was pronounced to me by a piqueur who wore crape on his arm

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: My uncle, Gaston of Orleans, perhaps.
children.prevalue: My uncle Gaston of Orleans perhaps

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Sire, he has rendered his last sigh.
children.prevalue: Sire he has rendered his last sigh

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: And I was not warned of it! cried the king, whose royal susceptibility saw an insult in the absence of this intelligence.
children.prevalue: And I was not warned of it cried the king whose royal susceptibility saw an insult in the absence of this intelligence

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Oh! do not be angry, sire, said D'Artagnan; neither the couriers of Paris, nor the couriers of the whole world, can travel with your servant; the courier from Blois will not be here these two hours, and he rides well, I assure you, seeing that I only passed him on the thither side of Orleans.
children.prevalue: Oh do not be angry sire said D Artagnan neither the couriers of Paris nor the couriers of the whole world can travel with your servant the courier from Blois will not be here these two hours and he rides well I assure you seeing that I only passed him on the thither side of Orleans

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: My uncle Gaston, murmured Louis, pressing his hand to his brow, and comprising in those three words all that his memory recalled of that symbol of opposing sentiments.
children.prevalue: My uncle Gaston murmured Louis pressing his hand to his brow and comprising in those three words all that his memory recalled of that symbol of opposing sentiments

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Eh! yes, sire, it is thus, said D'Artagnan, philosophically replying to the royal thought, it is thus the past flies away.
children.prevalue: Eh yes sire it is thus said D Artagnan philosophically replying to the royal thought it is thus the past flies away

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: That is true, monsieur, that is true; but there remains for us, thank God! the future; and we will try to make it not too dark.
children.prevalue: That is true monsieur that is true but there remains for us thank God the future and we will try to make it not too dark

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: I feel confidence in your majesty on that head, said D'Artagnan, bowing, and now
children.prevalue: I feel confidence in your majesty on that head said D Artagnan bowing and now

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: You are right, monsieur; I had forgotten the hundred leagues you have just ridden. Go, monsieur, take care of one of the best of soldiers, and when you have reposed a little, come and place yourself at my disposal.
children.prevalue: You are right monsieur I had forgotten the hundred leagues you have just ridden Go monsieur take care of one of the best of soldiers and when you have reposed a little come and place yourself at my disposal

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Sire, absent or present, I am always yours.
children.prevalue: Sire absent or present I am always yours

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: D'Artagnan bowed and retired. Then, as if he had only come from Fontainebleau, he quickly traversed the Louvre to rejoin Bragelonne.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan bowed and retired Then as if he had only come from Fontainebleau he quickly traversed the Louvre to rejoin Bragelonne

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Whilst the waxlights were burning in the castle of Blois, around the inanimate body of Gaston of Orleans, that last representative of the past; whilst the bourgeois of the city were thinking out his epitaph, which was far from being a panegyric; whilst madame the dowager, no longer remembering that in her young days she had loved that senseless corpse to such a degree as to fly the paternal palace for his sake, was making, within twenty paces of the funeral apartment, her little calculations of interest and her little sacrifices of pride; other interests and other prides were in agitation in all the parts of the castle into which a living soul could penetrate. Neither the lugubrious sounds of the bells, nor the voices of the chanters, nor the splendor of the waxlights through the windows, nor the preparations for the funeral, had power to divert the attention of two persons, placed at a window of the interior courta window that we are acquainted with, and which lighted a chamber forming part of what were called the little apartments. For the rest, a joyous beam of the sun, for the sun appeared to care little for the loss France had just suffered; a sunbeam, we say, descended upon them, drawing perfumes from the neighboring flowers, and animating the walls themselves. These two persons, so occupied, not by the death of the duke, but by the conversation which was the consequence of that death, were a young woman and a young man. The latter personage, a man of from twentyfive to twentysix years of age, with a mien sometimes lively and sometimes dull, making good use of two large eyes, shaded with long eyelashes, was short of stature and swart of skin; he smiled with an enormous, but wellfurnished mouth, and his pointed chin, which appeared to enjoy a mobility nature does not ordinarily grant to that portion of the countenance, leant from time to time very lovingly towards his interlocutrix, who, we must say, did not always draw back so rapidly as strict propriety had a right to require. The young girlwe know her, for we have already seen her, at that very same window, by the light of that same sunthe young girl presented a singular mixture of shyness and reflection; she was charming when she laughed, beautiful when she became serious; but, let us hasten to say, she was more frequently charming than beautiful. These two appeared to have attained the culminating point of a discussionhalfbantering, halfserious.
