children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Now, Monsieur Malicorne, said the young girl, does it, at length, please you that we should talk reasonably?
children.prevalue: Now Monsieur Malicorne said the young girl does it at length please you that we should talk reasonably

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: You believe that that is very easy, Mademoiselle Aure, replied the young man. To do what we like, when we can only do what we are able
children.prevalue: You believe that that is very easy Mademoiselle Aure replied the young man To do what we like when we can only do what we are able

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Good! there he is bewildered in his phrases.
children.prevalue: Good there he is bewildered in his phrases

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Who, I?
children.prevalue: Who I

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Yes, you; quit that lawyer's logic, my dear.
children.prevalue: Yes you quit that lawyer s logic my dear

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Another impossibility. Clerk I am, Mademoiselle de Montalais.
children.prevalue: Another impossibility Clerk I am Mademoiselle de Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Demoiselle I am, Monsieur Malicorne.
children.prevalue: Demoiselle I am Monsieur Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Alas, I know it well, and you overwhelm me by your rank; so I will say no more to you.
children.prevalue: Alas I know it well and you overwhelm me by your rank so I will say no more to you

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Well, no, I don't overwhelm you; say what you have to tell mesay it, I insist upon it.
children.prevalue: Well no I don t overwhelm you say what you have to tell mesay it I insist upon it

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Well, I obey you.
children.prevalue: Well I obey you

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: That is truly fortunate.
children.prevalue: That is truly fortunate

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Monsieur is dead.
children.prevalue: Monsieur is dead

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Ah, peste! that's news! And where do you come from, to be able to tell us that?
children.prevalue: Ah peste that s news And where do you come from to be able to tell us that

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I come from Orleans, mademoiselle.
children.prevalue: I come from Orleans mademoiselle

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: And is that all the news you bring?
children.prevalue: And is that all the news you bring

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Ah, no; I am come to tell you that Madame Henrietta of England is coming to marry the king's brother.
children.prevalue: Ah no I am come to tell you that Madame Henrietta of England is coming to marry the king s brother

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Indeed, Malicorne, you are insupportable with your news of the last century. Now, mind, if you persist in this bad habit of laughing at people, I will have you turned out.
children.prevalue: Indeed Malicorne you are insupportable with your news of the last century Now mind if you persist in this bad habit of laughing at people I will have you turned out

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Oh!
children.prevalue: Oh

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Yes, for really you exasperate me.
children.prevalue: Yes for really you exasperate me

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: There, there. Patience, mademoiselle.
children.prevalue: There there Patience mademoiselle

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: You want to make yourself of consequence; I know well enough why. Go!
children.prevalue: You want to make yourself of consequence I know well enough why Go

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Tell me, and I will answer you frankly, yes, if the thing be true.
children.prevalue: Tell me and I will answer you frankly yes if the thing be true

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: You know that I am anxious to have that commission of lady of honor, which I have been foolish enough to ask of you, and you do not use your credit.
children.prevalue: You know that I am anxious to have that commission of lady of honor which I have been foolish enough to ask of you and you do not use your credit

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Who, I? Malicorne cast down his eyes, joined his hands, and assumed his sullen air. And what credit can the poor clerk of a procurer have, pray?
children.prevalue: Who I Malicorne cast down his eyes joined his hands and assumed his sullen air And what credit can the poor clerk of a procurer have pray

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Your father has not twenty thousand livres a year for nothing, M. Malicorne.
children.prevalue: Your father has not twenty thousand livres a year for nothing M Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: A provincial fortune, Mademoiselle de Montalais.
children.prevalue: A provincial fortune Mademoiselle de Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Your father is not in the secrets of monsieur le prince for nothing.
children.prevalue: Your father is not in the secrets of monsieur le prince for nothing

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: An advantage which is confined to lending monseigneur money.
children.prevalue: An advantage which is confined to lending monseigneur money

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: In a word, you are not the most cunning young fellow in the province for nothing.
children.prevalue: In a word you are not the most cunning young fellow in the province for nothing

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: You flatter me!
children.prevalue: You flatter me

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Who, I?
children.prevalue: Who I

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Yes, you.
children.prevalue: Yes you

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: How so?
children.prevalue: How so

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Since I maintain that I have no credit, and you maintain I have.
children.prevalue: Since I maintain that I have no credit and you maintain I have

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Well, then,my commission?
children.prevalue: Well then my commission

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Well,your commission?
children.prevalue: Well your commission

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Shall I have it, or shall I not?
children.prevalue: Shall I have it or shall I not

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: You shall have it.
children.prevalue: You shall have it

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Ay, but when?
children.prevalue: Ay but when

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: When you like.
children.prevalue: When you like

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Where is it, then?
children.prevalue: Where is it then

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: In my pocket.
children.prevalue: In my pocket

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Howin your pocket?
children.prevalue: Howin your pocket

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: And, with a smile, Malicorne drew from his pocket a letter, upon which mademoiselle seized as a prey, and which she read eagerly. As she read, her face brightened.
children.prevalue: And with a smile Malicorne drew from his pocket a letter upon which mademoiselle seized as a prey and which she read eagerly As she read her face brightened

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Malicorne, cried she after having read it, In truth, you are a good lad.
children.prevalue: Malicorne cried she after having read it In truth you are a good lad

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: What for, mademoiselle?
children.prevalue: What for mademoiselle

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Because you might have been paid for this commission, and you have not. And she burst into a loud laugh, thinking to put the clerk out of countenance; but Malicorne sustained the attack bravely.
children.prevalue: Because you might have been paid for this commission and you have not And she burst into a loud laugh thinking to put the clerk out of countenance but Malicorne sustained the attack bravely

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: I do not understand you, said he. It was now Montalais who was disconcerted in her turn. I have declared my sentiments to you, continued Malicorne. You have told me three times, laughing all the while, that you did not love me; you have embraced me once without laughing, and that is all I want.
children.prevalue: I do not understand you said he It was now Montalais who was disconcerted in her turn I have declared my sentiments to you continued Malicorne You have told me three times laughing all the while that you did not love me you have embraced me once without laughing and that is all I want

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: All? said the proud and coquettish Montalais, in a tone through which the wounded pride was visible.
children.prevalue: All said the proud and coquettish Montalais in a tone through which the wounded pride was visible

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Absolutely all, mademoiselle, replied Malicorne.
children.prevalue: Absolutely all mademoiselle replied Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Ah!And this monosyllable indicated as much anger as the young man might have expected gratitude. He shook his head quietly.
children.prevalue: Ah And this monosyllable indicated as much anger as the young man might have expected gratitude He shook his head quietly

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Listen, Montalais, said he, without heeding whether that familiarity pleased his mistress or not; let us not dispute about it.
children.prevalue: Listen Montalais said he without heeding whether that familiarity pleased his mistress or not let us not dispute about it

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: And why not?
children.prevalue: And why not

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Because during the year which I have known you, you might have had me turned out of doors twenty times if I did not please you.
children.prevalue: Because during the year which I have known you you might have had me turned out of doors twenty times if I did not please you

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Indeed; and on what account should I have had you turned out?
children.prevalue: Indeed and on what account should I have had you turned out

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Because I have been sufficiently impertinent for that.
children.prevalue: Because I have been sufficiently impertinent for that

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Oh, that,yes, that's true.
children.prevalue: Oh that yes that s true

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: You see plainly that you are forced to avow it, said Malicorne.
children.prevalue: You see plainly that you are forced to avow it said Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Monsieur Malicorne!
children.prevalue: Monsieur Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Don't let us be angry; if you have retained me, then it has not been without cause.
children.prevalue: Don t let us be angry if you have retained me then it has not been without cause

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: It is not, at least, because I love you, cried Montalais.
children.prevalue: It is not at least because I love you cried Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Granted. I will even say, at this moment, I am certain that you hate me.
children.prevalue: Granted I will even say at this moment I am certain that you hate me

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Oh, you have never spoken so truly.
children.prevalue: Oh you have never spoken so truly

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Well, on my part, I detest you.
children.prevalue: Well on my part I detest you

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Ah! I take the act.
children.prevalue: Ah I take the act

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Take it. You find me brutal and foolish; on my part I find you have a harsh voice, and your face is too often distorted with anger. At this moment you would allow yourself to be thrown out of that window rather than allow me to kiss the tip of your finger; I would precipitate myself from the top of the balcony rather than touch the hem of your robe. But, in five minutes, you will love me, and I shall adore you. Oh, it is just so.
children.prevalue: Take it You find me brutal and foolish on my part I find you have a harsh voice and your face is too often distorted with anger At this moment you would allow yourself to be thrown out of that window rather than allow me to kiss the tip of your finger I would precipitate myself from the top of the balcony rather than touch the hem of your robe But in five minutes you will love me and I shall adore you Oh it is just so

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: I doubt it.
children.prevalue: I doubt it

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: And I swear it.
children.prevalue: And I swear it

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Coxcomb!
children.prevalue: Coxcomb

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: And then, that is not the true reason. You stand in need of me, Aure, and I of you. When it pleases you to be gay, I make you laugh; when it suits me to be loving, I look at you. I have given you a commission of lady of honor which you wished for; you will give me, presently, something I wish for.
children.prevalue: And then that is not the true reason You stand in need of me Aure and I of you When it pleases you to be gay I make you laugh when it suits me to be loving I look at you I have given you a commission of lady of honor which you wished for you will give me presently something I wish for

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: I will?
children.prevalue: I will

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Yes, you will; but, at this moment, my dear Aure, I declare to you that I wish for absolutely nothing, so be at ease.
children.prevalue: Yes you will but at this moment my dear Aure I declare to you that I wish for absolutely nothing so be at ease

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: You are a frightful man, Malicorne; I was going to rejoice at getting this commission, and thus you quench my joy.
children.prevalue: You are a frightful man Malicorne I was going to rejoice at getting this commission and thus you quench my joy

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Good; there is no time lost,you will rejoice when I am gone.
children.prevalue: Good there is no time lost you will rejoice when I am gone

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Go, then; and after
children.prevalue: Go then and after

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: So be it; but in the first place, a piece of advice.
children.prevalue: So be it but in the first place a piece of advice

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: What is it?
children.prevalue: What is it

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Resume your goodhumor,you are ugly when you pout.
children.prevalue: Resume your goodhumor you are ugly when you pout

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Coarse!
children.prevalue: Coarse

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Come, let us tell the truth to each other, while we are about it.
children.prevalue: Come let us tell the truth to each other while we are about it

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Oh, Malicorne! Badhearted man!
children.prevalue: Oh Malicorne Badhearted man

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Oh, Montalais! Ungrateful girl!
children.prevalue: Oh Montalais Ungrateful girl

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: The young man leant with his elbow upon the windowframe; Montalais took a book and opened it. Malicorne stood up, brushed his hat with his sleeve, smoothed down his black doublet;Montalais, though pretending to read, looked at him out of the corner of her eye.
children.prevalue: The young man leant with his elbow upon the windowframe Montalais took a book and opened it Malicorne stood up brushed his hat with his sleeve smoothed down his black doublet Montalais though pretending to read looked at him out of the corner of her eye

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Good! cried she, furious; he has assumed his respectful airand he will pout for a week.
children.prevalue: Good cried she furious he has assumed his respectful airand he will pout for a week

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: A fortnight, mademoiselle, said Malicorne, bowing.
children.prevalue: A fortnight mademoiselle said Malicorne bowing

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Montalais lifted up her little doubled fist. Monster! said she; oh! that I were a man!
children.prevalue: Montalais lifted up her little doubled fist Monster said she oh that I were a man

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: What would you do to me?
children.prevalue: What would you do to me

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: I would strangle you.
children.prevalue: I would strangle you

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Ah! very well, then, said Malicorne; I believe I begin to desire something.
children.prevalue: Ah very well then said Malicorne I believe I begin to desire something

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: And what do you desire, Monsieur Demon? That I should lose my soul from anger?
children.prevalue: And what do you desire Monsieur Demon That I should lose my soul from anger

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Malicorne was rolling his hat respectfully between his fingers; but, all at once, he let fall his hat, seized the young girl by the shoulders, pulled her towards him, and sealed her mouth with two lips that were very warm, for a man pretending to so much indifference. Aure would have cried out, but the cry was stifled in his kiss. Nervous and, apparently, angry, the young girl pushed Malicorne against the wall.
children.prevalue: Malicorne was rolling his hat respectfully between his fingers but all at once he let fall his hat seized the young girl by the shoulders pulled her towards him and sealed her mouth with two lips that were very warm for a man pretending to so much indifference Aure would have cried out but the cry was stifled in his kiss Nervous and apparently angry the young girl pushed Malicorne against the wall

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Good! said Malicorne, philosophically, that's enough for six weeks. Adieu, mademoiselle, accept my very humble salutation. And he made three steps towards the door.
children.prevalue: Good said Malicorne philosophically that s enough for six weeks Adieu mademoiselle accept my very humble salutation And he made three steps towards the door

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Well! no,you shall not go! cried Montalais, stamping with her little foot. Stay where you are! I order you!
children.prevalue: Well no you shall not go cried Montalais stamping with her little foot Stay where you are I order you

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: You order me?
children.prevalue: You order me

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Yes; am I not mistress?
children.prevalue: Yes am I not mistress

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Of my heart and soul, without doubt.
children.prevalue: Of my heart and soul without doubt

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: A pretty property! ma foi! The soul is silly and the heart dry.
children.prevalue: A pretty property ma foi The soul is silly and the heart dry

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Beware, Montalais, I know you, said Malicorne; you are going to fall in love with your humble servant.
children.prevalue: Beware Montalais I know you said Malicorne you are going to fall in love with your humble servant

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Well, yes! said she, hanging round his neck with childish indolence, rather than with loving abandonment. Well, yes! for I must thank you at least.
children.prevalue: Well yes said she hanging round his neck with childish indolence rather than with loving abandonment Well yes for I must thank you at least

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: And for what?
children.prevalue: And for what

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: For the commission; is it not my whole future?
children.prevalue: For the commission is it not my whole future

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: And mine.
children.prevalue: And mine

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Montalais looked at him.
children.prevalue: Montalais looked at him

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: It is frightful, said she, that one can never guess whether you are speaking seriously or not.
children.prevalue: It is frightful said she that one can never guess whether you are speaking seriously or not

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: I cannot speak more seriously. I was going to Paris,you are going there,we are going there.
children.prevalue: I cannot speak more seriously I was going to Paris you are going there we are going there

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: And so it was for that motive only you have served me; selfish fellow!
children.prevalue: And so it was for that motive only you have served me selfish fellow

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: What would you have me say, Aure? I cannot live without you.
children.prevalue: What would you have me say Aure I cannot live without you

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Well! in truth, it is just so with me; you are, nevertheless, it must be confessed, a very badhearted young man.
children.prevalue: Well in truth it is just so with me you are nevertheless it must be confessed a very badhearted young man

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Aure, my dear Aure, take care! if you take to calling me names again, you know the effect they produce upon me, and I shall adore you. And so saying, Malicorne drew the young girl a second time towards him. But at that instant a step resounded on the staircase. The young people were so close, that they would have been surprised in the arms of each other, if Montalais had not violently pushed Malicorne, with his back against the door, just then opening. A loud cry, followed by angry reproaches, immediately resounded. It was Madame de SaintRemy who uttered the cry and the angry words. The unlucky Malicorne almost crushed her between the wall and the door she was coming in at.
children.prevalue: Aure my dear Aure take care if you take to calling me names again you know the effect they produce upon me and I shall adore you And so saying Malicorne drew the young girl a second time towards him But at that instant a step resounded on the staircase The young people were so close that they would have been surprised in the arms of each other if Montalais had not violently pushed Malicorne with his back against the door just then opening A loud cry followed by angry reproaches immediately resounded It was Madame de SaintRemy who uttered the cry and the angry words The unlucky Malicorne almost crushed her between the wall and the door she was coming in at

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: It is again that goodfornothing! cried the old lady. Always here!
children.prevalue: It is again that goodfornothing cried the old lady Always here

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Ah, madame! replied Malicorne, in a respectful tone; it is eight long days since I was here.
children.prevalue: Ah madame replied Malicorne in a respectful tone it is eight long days since I was here

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Behind Madame de SaintRemy stood Mademoiselle de la Valliere. She heard the explosion of maternal anger, and as she divined the cause of it, she entered the chamber trembling, and perceived the unlucky Malicorne, whose woeful countenance might have softened or set laughing whoever observed it coolly. He had promptly intrenched himself behind a large chair, as if to avoid the first attacks of Madame de SaintRemy; he had no hopes of prevailing with words, for she spoke louder than he, and without stopping; but he reckoned upon the eloquence of his gestures. The old lady would neither listen to nor see anything; Malicorne had long been one of her antipathies. But her anger was too great not to overflow from Malicorne on his accomplice. Montalais had her turn.
children.prevalue: Behind Madame de SaintRemy stood Mademoiselle de la Valliere She heard the explosion of maternal anger and as she divined the cause of it she entered the chamber trembling and perceived the unlucky Malicorne whose woeful countenance might have softened or set laughing whoever observed it coolly He had promptly intrenched himself behind a large chair as if to avoid the first attacks of Madame de SaintRemy he had no hopes of prevailing with words for she spoke louder than he and without stopping but he reckoned upon the eloquence of his gestures The old lady would neither listen to nor see anything Malicorne had long been one of her antipathies But her anger was too great not to overflow from Malicorne on his accomplice Montalais had her turn

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: And you, mademoiselle; you may be certain I shall inform madame of what is going on in the apartment of one of her ladies of honor?
children.prevalue: And you mademoiselle you may be certain I shall inform madame of what is going on in the apartment of one of her ladies of honor

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Oh, dear mother! cried Mademoiselle de la Valliere, for mercy's sake, spare
children.prevalue: Oh dear mother cried Mademoiselle de la Valliere for mercy s sake spare

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Hold your tongue, mademoiselle, and do not uselessly trouble yourself to intercede for unworthy people; that a young maid of honor like you should be subjected to a bad example is, certes, a misfortune great enough; but that you should sanction it by your indulgence is what I will not allow.
children.prevalue: Hold your tongue mademoiselle and do not uselessly trouble yourself to intercede for unworthy people that a young maid of honor like you should be subjected to a bad example is certes a misfortune great enough but that you should sanction it by your indulgence is what I will not allow

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: But in truth, said Montalais, rebelling again, I do not know under what pretense you treat me thus. I am doing no harm, I suppose?
children.prevalue: But in truth said Montalais rebelling again I do not know under what pretense you treat me thus I am doing no harm I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: And that great goodfornothing, mademoiselle, resumed Madame de SaintRemy, pointing to Malicorne, is he here to do any good, I ask you?
children.prevalue: And that great goodfornothing mademoiselle resumed Madame de SaintRemy pointing to Malicorne is he here to do any good I ask you

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: He is neither here for good nor harm, madame; he comes to see me, that is all.
children.prevalue: He is neither here for good nor harm madame he comes to see me that is all

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: It is all very well! all very well! said the old lady. Her royal highness shall be informed of it, and she will judge.
children.prevalue: It is all very well all very well said the old lady Her royal highness shall be informed of it and she will judge

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: At all events, I do not see why, replied Montalais, it should be forbidden M. Malicorne to have intentions towards me, if his intentions are honorable.
children.prevalue: At all events I do not see why replied Montalais it should be forbidden M Malicorne to have intentions towards me if his intentions are honorable

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Honorable intentions with such a face! cried Madame de SaintRemy.
children.prevalue: Honorable intentions with such a face cried Madame de SaintRemy

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I thank you in the name of my face, madame, said Malicorne.
children.prevalue: I thank you in the name of my face madame said Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Come, my daughter, come, continued Madame de SaintRemy; we will go and inform madame that at the very moment she is weeping for her husband, at the moment when we are all weeping for a master in this old castle of Blois, the abode of grief, there are people who amuse themselves with flirtations!
children.prevalue: Come my daughter come continued Madame de SaintRemy we will go and inform madame that at the very moment she is weeping for her husband at the moment when we are all weeping for a master in this old castle of Blois the abode of grief there are people who amuse themselves with flirtations

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Oh! cried both the accused, with one voice.
children.prevalue: Oh cried both the accused with one voice

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: A maid of honor! a maid of honor! cried the old lady, lifting her hands towards heaven.
children.prevalue: A maid of honor a maid of honor cried the old lady lifting her hands towards heaven

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Well! it is there you are mistaken, madame, said Montalais, highly exasperated; I am no longer a maid of honor, of madame's at least.
children.prevalue: Well it is there you are mistaken madame said Montalais highly exasperated I am no longer a maid of honor of madame s at least

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Have you given in your resignation, mademoiselle? That is well! I cannot but applaud such a determination, and I do applaud it.
children.prevalue: Have you given in your resignation mademoiselle That is well I cannot but applaud such a determination and I do applaud it

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: I do not give in my resignation, madame; I take another service,that is all.
children.prevalue: I do not give in my resignation madame I take another service that is all

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: In the bourgeoisie or in the robe? asked Madame de SaintRemy, disdainfully.
children.prevalue: In the bourgeoisie or in the robe asked Madame de SaintRemy disdainfully

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Please to learn, madame, that I am not a girl to serve either bourgeoises or robines; and that instead of the miserable court at which you vegetate, I am going to reside in a court almost royal.
children.prevalue: Please to learn madame that I am not a girl to serve either bourgeoises or robines and that instead of the miserable court at which you vegetate I am going to reside in a court almost royal

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Ha, ha! a royal court, said Madame de SaintRemy, forcing a laugh; a royal court! What do you think of that, my daughter?
children.prevalue: Ha ha a royal court said Madame de SaintRemy forcing a laugh a royal court What do you think of that my daughter

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: And she turned towards Mademoiselle de la Valliere, whom she would by main force have dragged away from Montalais, and who instead of obeying the impulse of Madame de SaintRemy, looked first at her mother and then at Montalais with her beautiful conciliatory eyes.
children.prevalue: And she turned towards Mademoiselle de la Valliere whom she would by main force have dragged away from Montalais and who instead of obeying the impulse of Madame de SaintRemy looked first at her mother and then at Montalais with her beautiful conciliatory eyes

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I did not say a royal court, madame, replied Montalais; because Madame Henrietta of England, who is about to become the wife of S. A. R. Monsieur, is not a queen. I said almost royal, and I spoke correctly, since she will be sisterinlaw to the king.
children.prevalue: I did not say a royal court madame replied Montalais because Madame Henrietta of England who is about to become the wife of S A R Monsieur is not a queen I said almost royal and I spoke correctly since she will be sisterinlaw to the king

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: A thunderbolt falling upon the castle of Blois would not have astonished Madame de SaintRemy more than the last sentence of Montalais.
children.prevalue: A thunderbolt falling upon the castle of Blois would not have astonished Madame de SaintRemy more than the last sentence of Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: What do you say? of Son Altesse Royale Madame Henrietta? stammered out the old lady.
children.prevalue: What do you say of Son Altesse Royale Madame Henrietta stammered out the old lady

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I say I am going to belong to her household, as maid of honor; that is what I say.
children.prevalue: I say I am going to belong to her household as maid of honor that is what I say

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: As maid of honor! cried, at the same time, Madame de SaintRemy with despair, and Mademoiselle de la Valliere with delight.
children.prevalue: As maid of honor cried at the same time Madame de SaintRemy with despair and Mademoiselle de la Valliere with delight

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Yes, madame, as maid of honor.
children.prevalue: Yes madame as maid of honor

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: The old lady's head sank down as if the blow had been too severe for her. But, almost immediately recovering herself, she launched a last projectile at her adversary.
children.prevalue: The old lady s head sank down as if the blow had been too severe for her But almost immediately recovering herself she launched a last projectile at her adversary

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Oh! oh! said she; I have heard of many of these sorts of promises beforehand, which often lead people to flatter themselves with wild hopes, and at the last moment, when the time comes to keep the promises, and have the hopes realized, they are surprised to see the great credit upon which they reckoned vanish like smoke.
children.prevalue: Oh oh said she I have heard of many of these sorts of promises beforehand which often lead people to flatter themselves with wild hopes and at the last moment when the time comes to keep the promises and have the hopes realized they are surprised to see the great credit upon which they reckoned vanish like smoke

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Oh! madame, the credit of my protector is incontestable and his promises are as good as deeds.
children.prevalue: Oh madame the credit of my protector is incontestable and his promises are as good as deeds

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: And would it be indiscreet to ask you the name of this powerful protector?
children.prevalue: And would it be indiscreet to ask you the name of this powerful protector

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Oh! mon Dieu! no! it is that gentleman there, said Montalais, pointing to Malicorne, who, during this scene, had preserved the most imperturbable coolness, and the most comic dignity.
children.prevalue: Oh mon Dieu no it is that gentleman there said Montalais pointing to Malicorne who during this scene had preserved the most imperturbable coolness and the most comic dignity

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Monsieur! cried Madame de SaintRemy, with an explosion of hilarity, monsieur is your protector! Is the man whose credit is so powerful, and whose promises are as good as deeds, Monsieur Malicorne!
children.prevalue: Monsieur cried Madame de SaintRemy with an explosion of hilarity monsieur is your protector Is the man whose credit is so powerful and whose promises are as good as deeds Monsieur Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Malicorne bowed.
children.prevalue: Malicorne bowed

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: As to Montalais, as her sole reply, she drew the brevet from her pocket, and showed it to the old lady.
children.prevalue: As to Montalais as her sole reply she drew the brevet from her pocket and showed it to the old lady

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Here is the brevet, said she.
children.prevalue: Here is the brevet said she

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: At once all was over. As soon as she had cast a rapid glance over this fortunate brevet, the good lady clasped her hands, an unspeakable expression of envy and despair contracted her countenance, and she was obliged to sit down to avoid fainting. Montalais was not malicious enough to rejoice extravagantly at her victory, or to overwhelm the conquered enemy, particularly when that enemy was the mother of her friend; she used then, but did not abuse her triumph. Malicorne was less generous; he assumed noble poses in his fauteuil and stretched himself out with a familiarity which, two hours earlier, would have drawn upon him threats of a caning.
children.prevalue: At once all was over As soon as she had cast a rapid glance over this fortunate brevet the good lady clasped her hands an unspeakable expression of envy and despair contracted her countenance and she was obliged to sit down to avoid fainting Montalais was not malicious enough to rejoice extravagantly at her victory or to overwhelm the conquered enemy particularly when that enemy was the mother of her friend she used then but did not abuse her triumph Malicorne was less generous he assumed noble poses in his fauteuil and stretched himself out with a familiarity which two hours earlier would have drawn upon him threats of a caning

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Maid of honor to the young madame! repeated Madame de SaintRemy, still but half convinced.
children.prevalue: Maid of honor to the young madame repeated Madame de SaintRemy still but half convinced

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Yes, madame, and through the protection of M. Malicorne, moreover.
children.prevalue: Yes madame and through the protection of M Malicorne moreover

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: It is incredible! repeated the old lady: is it not incredible, Louise? But Louise did not reply; she was sitting, thoughtfully, almost sad; passing one had over her beautiful brow, she sighed heavily.
children.prevalue: It is incredible repeated the old lady is it not incredible Louise But Louise did not reply she was sitting thoughtfully almost sad passing one had over her beautiful brow she sighed heavily

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Well, but, monsieur, said Madame de SaintRemy, all at once, how did you manage to obtain this post?
children.prevalue: Well but monsieur said Madame de SaintRemy all at once how did you manage to obtain this post

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: I asked for it, madame.
children.prevalue: I asked for it madame

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Of whom?
children.prevalue: Of whom

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: One of my friends.
children.prevalue: One of my friends

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: And you have friends sufficiently powerful at court to give you such proofs of their credit?
children.prevalue: And you have friends sufficiently powerful at court to give you such proofs of their credit

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: It appears so.
children.prevalue: It appears so

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: And may one ask the name of these friends?
children.prevalue: And may one ask the name of these friends

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: I did not say I had many friends, madame, I said I had one friend.
children.prevalue: I did not say I had many friends madame I said I had one friend

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: And that friend is called?
children.prevalue: And that friend is called

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Peste! madame, you go too far! When one has a friend as powerful as mine, we do not publish his name in that fashion, in open day, in order that he may be stolen from us.
children.prevalue: Peste madame you go too far When one has a friend as powerful as mine we do not publish his name in that fashion in open day in order that he may be stolen from us

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: You are right, monsieur, to be silent as to that name; for I think it would be pretty difficult for you to tell it.
children.prevalue: You are right monsieur to be silent as to that name for I think it would be pretty difficult for you to tell it

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: At all events, said Montalais, if the friend does not exist, the brevet does, and that cuts short the question.
children.prevalue: At all events said Montalais if the friend does not exist the brevet does and that cuts short the question

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Then, I conceive, said Madame de SaintRemy, with the gracious smile of the cat who is going to scratch, when I found monsieur here just now
children.prevalue: Then I conceive said Madame de SaintRemy with the gracious smile of the cat who is going to scratch when I found monsieur here just now

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: He brought you the brevet.
children.prevalue: He brought you the brevet

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Exactly, madame; you have guessed rightly.
children.prevalue: Exactly madame you have guessed rightly

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Well, then, nothing can be more moral or proper.
children.prevalue: Well then nothing can be more moral or proper

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: I think so, madame.
children.prevalue: I think so madame

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: And I have been wrong, as it appears, in reproaching you, mademoiselle.
children.prevalue: And I have been wrong as it appears in reproaching you mademoiselle

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Very wrong, madame; but I am so accustomed to your reproaches, that I pardon you these.
children.prevalue: Very wrong madame but I am so accustomed to your reproaches that I pardon you these

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: In that case, let us begone, Louise; we have nothing to do but retire. Well!
children.prevalue: In that case let us begone Louise we have nothing to do but retire Well

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Madame! said La Valliere starting, did you speak?
children.prevalue: Madame said La Valliere starting did you speak

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: You do not appear to be listening, my child.
children.prevalue: You do not appear to be listening my child

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: No, madame, I was thinking.
children.prevalue: No madame I was thinking

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: About what?
children.prevalue: About what

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: A thousand things.
children.prevalue: A thousand things

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: You bear me no illwill, at least, Louise? cried Montalais, pressing her hand.
children.prevalue: You bear me no illwill at least Louise cried Montalais pressing her hand

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: And why should I, my dear Aure? replied the girl in a voice soft as a flute.
children.prevalue: And why should I my dear Aure replied the girl in a voice soft as a flute

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Dame! resumed Madame de SaintRemy; if she did bear you a little illwill, poor girl, she could not be much blamed.
children.prevalue: Dame resumed Madame de SaintRemy if she did bear you a little illwill poor girl she could not be much blamed

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: And why should she bear me illwill, good gracious?
children.prevalue: And why should she bear me illwill good gracious

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: It appears to me that she is of as good a family, and as pretty as you.
children.prevalue: It appears to me that she is of as good a family and as pretty as you

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Mother! mother! cried Louise.
children.prevalue: Mother mother cried Louise

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Prettier a hundred times, madamenot of a better family; but that does not tell me why Louise should bear me illwill.
children.prevalue: Prettier a hundred times madamenot of a better family but that does not tell me why Louise should bear me illwill

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Do you think it will be very amusing for her to be buried alive at Blois, when you are going to shine at Paris?
children.prevalue: Do you think it will be very amusing for her to be buried alive at Blois when you are going to shine at Paris

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: But, madame, it is not I who prevent Louise following me thither; on the contrary, I should certainly be most happy if she came there.
children.prevalue: But madame it is not I who prevent Louise following me thither on the contrary I should certainly be most happy if she came there

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: But it appears that M. Malicorne, who is allpowerful at court
children.prevalue: But it appears that M Malicorne who is allpowerful at court

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Ah! so much the worse, madame, said Malicorne, every one for himself in this poor world.
children.prevalue: Ah so much the worse madame said Malicorne every one for himself in this poor world

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Malicorne! Malicorne! said Montalais. Then stooping towards the young man:
children.prevalue: Malicorne Malicorne said Montalais Then stooping towards the young man

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Occupy Madame de SaintRemy, either in disputing with her, or making it up with her; I must speak to Louise. And, at the same time, a soft pressure of the hand recompensed Malicorne for his future obedience. Malicorne went grumbling towards Madame de SaintRemy, whilst Montalais said to her friend, throwing one arm around her neck:
children.prevalue: Occupy Madame de SaintRemy either in disputing with her or making it up with her I must speak to Louise And at the same time a soft pressure of the hand recompensed Malicorne for his future obedience Malicorne went grumbling towards Madame de SaintRemy whilst Montalais said to her friend throwing one arm around her neck

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: What is the matter? Tell me. Is it true that you would not love me if I were to shine, as your mother says?
children.prevalue: What is the matter Tell me Is it true that you would not love me if I were to shine as your mother says

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Oh, no! said the young girl, with difficulty restraining her tears; on the contrary, I rejoice at your good fortune.
children.prevalue: Oh no said the young girl with difficulty restraining her tears on the contrary I rejoice at your good fortune

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Rejoice! why, one would say you are ready to cry!
children.prevalue: Rejoice why one would say you are ready to cry

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Do people never weep except from envy?
children.prevalue: Do people never weep except from envy

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Oh! yes, I understand; I am going to Paris and that word Paris recalls to your mind a certain cavalier
children.prevalue: Oh yes I understand I am going to Paris and that word Paris recalls to your mind a certain cavalier

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Aure!
children.prevalue: Aure

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: A certain cavalier who formerly lived near Blois, and who now resides at Paris.
children.prevalue: A certain cavalier who formerly lived near Blois and who now resides at Paris

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: In truth, I know not what ails me, but I feel stifled.
children.prevalue: In truth I know not what ails me but I feel stifled

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Weep, then, weep, as you cannot give me a smile!
children.prevalue: Weep then weep as you cannot give me a smile

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Louise raised her sweet face, which the tears, rolling down one after the other, illumined like diamonds.
children.prevalue: Louise raised her sweet face which the tears rolling down one after the other illumined like diamonds

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Come, confess, said Montalais.
children.prevalue: Come confess said Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: What shall I confess?
children.prevalue: What shall I confess

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: What makes you weep; people don't weep without cause. I am your friend; whatever you would wish me to do, I will do. Malicorne is more powerful than you would think. Do you wish to go to Paris?
children.prevalue: What makes you weep people don t weep without cause I am your friend whatever you would wish me to do I will do Malicorne is more powerful than you would think Do you wish to go to Paris

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Alas! sighed Louise.
children.prevalue: Alas sighed Louise

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Do you wish to come to Paris?
children.prevalue: Do you wish to come to Paris

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: To remain here alone, in this old castle, I who have enjoyed the delightful habit of listening to your songs, of pressing your hand, of running about the park with you. Oh! how I shall be ennuyee! how quickly I shall die!
children.prevalue: To remain here alone in this old castle I who have enjoyed the delightful habit of listening to your songs of pressing your hand of running about the park with you Oh how I shall be ennuyee how quickly I shall die

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Do you wish to come to Paris?
children.prevalue: Do you wish to come to Paris

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Louise breathed another sigh.
children.prevalue: Louise breathed another sigh

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: You do not answer me.
children.prevalue: You do not answer me

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: What would you that I should reply?
children.prevalue: What would you that I should reply

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Yes or no; that is not very difficult, I think.
children.prevalue: Yes or no that is not very difficult I think

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Oh! you are very fortunate, Montalais!
children.prevalue: Oh you are very fortunate Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: That is to say you would like to be in my place.
children.prevalue: That is to say you would like to be in my place

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Louise was silent.
children.prevalue: Louise was silent

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Little obstinate thing! said Montalais; did ever any one keep her secrets from her friend thus? But, confess that you would like to come to Paris; confess that you are dying with the wish to see Raoul again.
children.prevalue: Little obstinate thing said Montalais did ever any one keep her secrets from her friend thus But confess that you would like to come to Paris confess that you are dying with the wish to see Raoul again

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: I cannot confess that.
children.prevalue: I cannot confess that

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Then you are wrong.
children.prevalue: Then you are wrong

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: In what way?
children.prevalue: In what way

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Becausedo you not see this brevet?
children.prevalue: Becausedo you not see this brevet

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: To be sure I do.
children.prevalue: To be sure I do

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Well, I would have got you a similar one.
children.prevalue: Well I would have got you a similar one

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: By whose means?
children.prevalue: By whose means

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Malicorne's.
children.prevalue: Malicorne s

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Aure, are you telling the truth? Is that possible?
children.prevalue: Aure are you telling the truth Is that possible

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Malicorne is there; and what he has done for me, he surely can do for you.
children.prevalue: Malicorne is there and what he has done for me he surely can do for you

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Malicorne had heard his name pronounced twice; he was delighted at having an opportunity of coming to a conclusion with Madame de SaintRemy, and he turned round:
children.prevalue: Malicorne had heard his name pronounced twice he was delighted at having an opportunity of coming to a conclusion with Madame de SaintRemy and he turned round

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: What is the question, mademoiselle?

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The introduction of these two new personages into this history and that mysterious affinity of names and sentiments, merit some attention on the part of both historian and reader. We will then enter into some details concerning Messieurs Malicorne and Manicamp. Malicorne, we know, had made the journey to Orleans in search of the brevet destined for Mademoiselle de Montalais, the arrival of which had produced such a strong feeling at the castle of Blois. At that moment, M. de Manicamp was at Orleans. A singular person was this M. de Manicamp; a very intelligent young fellow, always poor, always needy, although he dipped his hand freely into the purse of M. le Comte de Guiche, one of the best furnished purses of the period. M. le Comte de Guiche had had, as the companion of his boyhood, this De Manicamp, a poor gentleman, vassalborn, of the house of Gramont. M. de Manicamp, with his tact and talent had created himself a revenue in the opulent family of the celebrated marechal. From his infancy he had, with calculation beyond his age, lent his mane and complaisance to the follies of the Comte de Guiche. If his noble companion had stolen some fruit destined for Madame la Marechale, if he had broken a mirror, or put out a dog's eye, Manicamp declared himself guilty of the crime committed, and received the punishment, which was not made the milder for falling on the innocent. But this was the way this system of abnegation was paid for: instead of wearing such mean habiliments as his paternal fortunes entitled him to, he was able to appear brilliant, superb, like a young noble of fifty thousand livres a year. It was not that he was mean in character or humble in spirit; no, he was a philosopher, or rather he had the indifference, the apathy, the obstinacy which banish from man every sentiment of the supernatural. His sole ambition was to spend money. But, in this respect, the worthy M. de Manicamp was a gulf. Three or four times every year he drained the Comte de Guiche, and when the Comte de Guiche was thoroughly drained, when he had turned out his pockets and his purse before him, when he declared that it would be at least a fortnight before paternal munificence would refill those pockets and that purse, Manicamp lost all his energy, he went to bed, remained there, ate nothing and sold his handsome clothes, under the pretense that, remaining in bed, he did not want them. During this prostration of mind and strength, the purse of the Comte de Guiche was getting full again, and when once filled, overflowed into that of De Manicamp, who bought new clothes, dressed himself again, and recommenced the same life he had followed before. The mania of selling his new clothes for a quarter of what they were worth, had rendered our hero sufficiently celebrated in Orleans, a city where, in general, we should be puzzled to say why he came to pass his days of penitence. Provincial debauches, petitsmaitres of six hundred livres a year, shared the fragments of his opulence.

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Among the admirers of these splendid toilettes, our friend Malicorne was conspicuous; he was the son of a syndic of the city, of whom M. de Conde, always needy as a De Conde, often borrowed money at enormous interest. M. Malicorne kept the paternal moneychest; that is to say, that in those times of easy morals, he had made for himself, by following the example of his father, and lending at high interest for short terms, a revenue of eighteen hundred livres, without reckoning six hundred livres furnished by the generosity of the syndic; so that Malicorne was the king of the gay youth of Orleans, having two thousand four hundred livres to scatter, squander, and waste on follies of every kind. But, quite contrary to Manicamp, Malicorne was terribly ambitious. He loved from ambition; he spent money out of ambition; and he would have ruined himself for ambition. Malicorne had determined to rise, at whatever price it might cost, and for this, whatever price it did cost, he had given himself a mistress and a friend. The mistress, Mademoiselle de Montalais, was cruel, as regarded love; but she was of a noble family, and that was sufficient for Malicorne. The friend had little or no friendship, but he was the favorite of the Comte de Guiche, himself the friend of Monsieur, the king's brother; and that was sufficient for Malicorne. Only, in the chapter of charges, Mademoiselle de Montalais cost per annum:ribbons, gloves, and sweets, a thousand livres. De Manicamp costmoney lent, never returnedfrom twelve to fifteen hundred livres per annum. So that there was nothing left for Malicorne. Ah! yes, we are mistaken; there was left the paternal strong box. He employed a mode of proceeding, upon which he preserved the most profound secrecy, and which consisted in advancing to himself, from the coffers of the syndic, half a dozen year's profits, that is to say, fifteen thousand livres, swearing to himselfobserve, quite to himselfto repay this deficiency as soon as an opportunity should present itself. The opportunity was expected to be the concession of a good post in the household of Monsieur, when that household would be established at the period of his marriage. This juncture had arrived, and the household was about to be established. A good post in the family of a prince of the blood, when it is given by the credit, and on the recommendation of a friend, like the Comte de Guiche, is worth at least twelve thousand livres per annum; and by the means which M. Malicorne had taken to make his revenues fructify, twelve thousand livres might rise to twenty thousand. Then, when once an incumbent of this post, he would marry Mademoiselle de Montalais. Mademoiselle de Montalais, of a half noble family, not only would be dowered, but would ennoble Malicorne. But, in order that Mademoiselle de Montalais, who had not a large patrimonial fortune, although an only daughter, should be suitably dowered, it was necessary that she should belong to some great princess, as prodigal as the dowager Madame was covetous. And in order that the wife should not be of one party whilst the husband belonged to the other, a situation which presents serious inconveniences, particularly with characters like those of the future consortsMalicorne had imagined the idea of making the central point of union the household of Monsieur, the king's brother. Mademoiselle de Montalais would be maid of honor to Madame. M. Malicorne would be officer to Monsieur.

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: It is plain the plan was formed by a clear head; it is plain, also, that it had been bravely executed. Malicorne had asked Manicamp to ask a brevet of maid of honor of the Comte de Guiche; and the Comte de Guiche had asked this brevet of Monsieur, who had signed it without hesitation. The constructive plan of Malicornefor we may well suppose that the combinations of a mind as active as his were not confined to the present, but extended to the futurethe constructive plan of Malicorne, we say, was this:To obtain entrance into the household of Madame Henrietta for a woman devoted to himself, who was intelligent, young, handsome, and intriguing; to learn, by means of this woman, all the feminine secrets of the young household; whilst he, Malicorne, and his friend Manicamp, should, between them, know all the male secrets of the young community. It was by these means that a rapid and splendid fortune might be acquired at one and the same time. Malicorne was a vile name; he who bore it had too much wit to conceal this truth from himself; but an estate might be purchased; and Malicorne of some place, or even De Malicorne itself, for short, would ring more nobly on the ear.

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: It was not improbable that a most aristocratic origin might be hunted up by the heralds for this name of Malicorne; might it not come from some estate where a bull with mortal horns had caused some great misfortune, and baptized the soil with the blood it had spilt? Certes, this plan presented itself bristling with difficulties: but the greatest of all was Mademoiselle de Montalais herself. Capricious, variable, close, giddy, free, prudish, a virgin armed with claws, Erigone stained with grapes, she sometimes overturned, with a single dash of her white fingers, or with a single puff from her laughing lips, the edifice which had exhausted Malicorne's patience for a month.

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Love apart, Malicorne was happy; but this love, which he could not help feeling, he had the strength to conceal with care; persuaded that at the least relaxing of the ties by which he had bound his Protean female, the demon would overthrow and laugh at him. He humbled his mistress by disdaining her. Burning with desire, when she advanced to tempt him, he had the art to appear ice, persuaded that if he opened his arms, she would run away laughing at him. On her side, Montalais believed she did not love Malicorne; whilst, on the contrary, in reality she did. Malicorne repeated to her so often his protestation of indifference, that she finished, sometimes, by believing him; and then she believed she detested Malicorne. If she tried to bring him back by coquetry, Malicorne played the coquette better than she could. But what made Montalais hold to Malicorne in an indissoluble fashion, was that Malicorne always came cram full of fresh news from the court and the city; Malicorne always brought to Blois a fashion, a secret, or a perfume; that Malicorne never asked for a meeting, but, on the contrary, required to be supplicated to receive the favors he burned to obtain. On her side, Montalais was no miser with stories. By her means, Malicorne learnt all that passed at Blois, in the family of the dowager Madame; and he related to Manicamp tales that made him ready to die with laughing, which the latter, out of idleness, took readymade to M. de Guiche, who carried them to Monsieur.

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Such, in two words, was the woof of petty interests and petty conspiracies which united Blois with Orleans, and Orleans with Pairs; and which was about to bring into the last named city where she was to produce so great a revolution, the poor little La Valliere, who was far from suspecting, as she returned joyfully, leaning on the arm of her mother, for what a strange future she was reserved. As to the good man, Malicornewe speak of the syndic of Orleanshe did not see more clearly into the present than others did into the future; and had no suspicion as he walked, every day, between three and five o'clock, after his dinner, upon the Place SainteCatherine, in his gray coat, cut after the fashion of Louis XIII. and his cloth shoes with great knots of ribbon, that it was he who was paying for all those bursts of laughter, all those stolen kisses, all those whisperings, all those little keepsakes, and all those bubble projects which formed a chain of fortyfive leagues in length, from the palais of Blois to the Palais Royal.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Malicorne, then, left Blois, as we have said, and went to find his friend, Manicamp, then in temporary retreat in the city of Orleans. It was just at the moment when that young nobleman was employed in selling the last decent clothing he had left. He had, a fortnight before, extorted from the Comte de Guiche a hundred pistoles, all he had, to assist in equipping him properly to go and meet Madame, on her arrival at Le Havre. He had drawn from Malicorne, three days before, fifty pistoles, the price of the brevet obtained for Montalais. He had then no expectation of anything else, having exhausted all his resources, with the exception of selling a handsome suit of cloth and satin, embroidered and laced with gold, which had been the admiration of the court. But to be able to sell this suit, the last he had left,as we have been forced to confess to the readerManicamp had been obliged to take to his bed. No more fire, no more pocketmoney, no more walkingmoney, nothing but sleep to take the place of repasts, companies and balls. It has been saidHe who sleeps, dines; but it has never been affirmedHe who sleeps, playsor, He who sleeps, dances. Manicamp, reduced to this extremity of neither playing nor dancing, for a week at least, was, consequently, very sad; he was expecting a usurer, and saw Malicorne enter. A cry of distress escaped him.

children.prevalue: No I thought he was at Paris You will then only have fifteen leagues to go instead of thirty

children.value: You are a wonderfully clever fellow! If I were to ride fifteen leagues in these clothes, they would never be fit to put on again; and, instead of selling them for thirty pistoles, I should be obliged to take fifteen.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: On Malicorne's arrival at Orleans, he was informed that the Comte de Guiche had just set out for Paris. Malicorne rested himself for a couple of hours, and then prepared to continue his journey. He reached Paris during the night, and alighted at a small hotel, where, in his previous journeys to the capital, he had been accustomed to put up, and at eight o'clock the next morning presented himself at the Hotel Grammont. Malicorne arrived just in time, for the Comte de Guiche was on the point of taking leave of Monsieur before setting out for Le Havre, where the principal members of the French nobility had gone to await Madame's arrival from England. Malicorne pronounced the name of Manicamp, and was immediately admitted. He found the Comte de Guiche in the courtyard of the Hotel Grammont, inspecting his horses, which his trainers and equerries were passing in review before him. The count, in the presence of his tradespeople and of his servants, was engaged in praising or blaming, as the case seemed to deserve, the appointments, horses, and harness that were being submitted to him; when, in the midst of this important occupation, the name of Manicamp was announced.
children.prevalue: On Malicorne s arrival at Orleans he was informed that the Comte de Guiche had just set out for Paris Malicorne rested himself for a couple of hours and then prepared to continue his journey He reached Paris during the night and alighted at a small hotel where in his previous journeys to the capital he had been accustomed to put up and at eight o clock the next morning presented himself at the Hotel Grammont Malicorne arrived just in time for the Comte de Guiche was on the point of taking leave of Monsieur before setting out for Le Havre where the principal members of the French nobility had gone to await Madame s arrival from England Malicorne pronounced the name of Manicamp and was immediately admitted He found the Comte de Guiche in the courtyard of the Hotel Grammont inspecting his horses which his trainers and equerries were passing in review before him The count in the presence of his tradespeople and of his servants was engaged in praising or blaming as the case seemed to deserve the appointments horses and harness that were being submitted to him when in the midst of this important occupation the name of Manicamp was announced

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Manicamp! he exclaimed; let him enter by all means. And he advanced a few steps toward the door.
children.prevalue: Manicamp he exclaimed let him enter by all means And he advanced a few steps toward the door

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Malicorne slipped through the halfopen door, and looking at the Comte de Guiche, who was surprised to see a face he did not recognize, instead of the one he expected, said: Forgive me, monsieur le comte, but I believe a mistake has been made. M. Manicamp himself was announced to you, instead of which it is only an envoy from him.
children.prevalue: Malicorne slipped through the halfopen door and looking at the Comte de Guiche who was surprised to see a face he did not recognize instead of the one he expected said Forgive me monsieur le comte but I believe a mistake has been made M Manicamp himself was announced to you instead of which it is only an envoy from him

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Ah! exclaimed De Guiche, coldly; and what do you bring me?
children.prevalue: Ah exclaimed De Guiche coldly and what do you bring me

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: A letter, monsieur le comte. Malicorne handed him the first document, and narrowly watched the count's face, who, as he read it, began to laugh.
children.prevalue: A letter monsieur le comte Malicorne handed him the first document and narrowly watched the count s face who as he read it began to laugh

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: What! he exclaimed, another maid of honor? Are all the maids of honor in France, then, under his protection?
children.prevalue: What he exclaimed another maid of honor Are all the maids of honor in France then under his protection

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Malicorne bowed.
children.prevalue: Malicorne bowed

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Why does he not come himself? he inquired.
children.prevalue: Why does he not come himself he inquired

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: He is confined to his bed.
children.prevalue: He is confined to his bed

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: The deuce! he has no money then, I suppose, said De Guiche, shrugging his shoulders. What does he do with his money?
children.prevalue: The deuce he has no money then I suppose said De Guiche shrugging his shoulders What does he do with his money

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Malicorne made a movement, to indicate that upon this subject he was as ignorant as the count himself. Why does he not make use of his credit, then? continued De Guiche.
children.prevalue: Malicorne made a movement to indicate that upon this subject he was as ignorant as the count himself Why does he not make use of his credit then continued De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: With regard to that, I think
children.prevalue: With regard to that I think

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: What?
children.prevalue: What

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: That Manicamp has credit with no one but yourself, monsieur le comte!
children.prevalue: That Manicamp has credit with no one but yourself monsieur le comte

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: He will not be at Le Havre, then? Whereupon Malicorne made another movement.
children.prevalue: He will not be at Le Havre then Whereupon Malicorne made another movement

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: But every one will be there.
children.prevalue: But every one will be there

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: I trust, monsieur le comte, that he will not neglect so excellent an opportunity.
children.prevalue: I trust monsieur le comte that he will not neglect so excellent an opportunity

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: He should be at Paris by this time.
children.prevalue: He should be at Paris by this time

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: He will take the direct road perhaps to make up for lost time.
children.prevalue: He will take the direct road perhaps to make up for lost time

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Where is he now?
children.prevalue: Where is he now

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: At Orleans.
children.prevalue: At Orleans

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Monsieur, said De Guiche, you seem to me a man of very good taste.
children.prevalue: Monsieur said De Guiche you seem to me a man of very good taste

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Malicorne was wearing some of Manicamp's oldnew clothes. He bowed in return, saying, You do me a very great honor, monsieur le comte.
children.prevalue: Malicorne was wearing some of Manicamp s oldnew clothes He bowed in return saying You do me a very great honor monsieur le comte

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Whom have I the pleasure of addressing?
children.prevalue: Whom have I the pleasure of addressing

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: My name is Malicorne, monsieur.
children.prevalue: My name is Malicorne monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: M. de Malicorne, what do you think of these pistolholsters?
children.prevalue: M de Malicorne what do you think of these pistolholsters

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Malicorne was a man of great readiness and immediately understood the position of affairs. Besides, the de which had been prefixed to his name, raised him to the rank of the person with whom he was conversing. He looked at the holsters with the air of a connoisseur and said, without hesitation: Somewhat heavy, monsieur.
