children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: You see, said De Guiche to the saddler, this gentleman, who understands these matters well, thinks the holsters heavy, a complaint I had already made. The saddler was full of excuses.
children.prevalue: You see said De Guiche to the saddler this gentleman who understands these matters well thinks the holsters heavy a complaint I had already made The saddler was full of excuses

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: What do you think, asked De Guiche, of this horse, which I have just purchased?
children.prevalue: What do you think asked De Guiche of this horse which I have just purchased

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: To look at it, it seems perfect, monsieur le comte; but I must mount it before I give you my opinion.
children.prevalue: To look at it it seems perfect monsieur le comte but I must mount it before I give you my opinion

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Do so, M. de Malicorne, and ride him round the court two or three times.
children.prevalue: Do so M de Malicorne and ride him round the court two or three times

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The courtyard of the hotel was so arranged, that whenever there was any occasion for it, it could be used as a ridingschool. Malicorne, with perfect ease, arranged the bridle and snafflereins, placed his left hand on the horse's mane, and, with his foot in the stirrup, raised himself and seated himself in the saddle. At first, he made the horse walk the whole circuit of the courtyard at a footpace; next at a trot; lastly at a gallop. He then drew up close to the count, dismounted, and threw the bridle to a groom standing by. Well, said the count, what do you think of it, M. de Malicorne?
children.prevalue: The courtyard of the hotel was so arranged that whenever there was any occasion for it it could be used as a ridingschool Malicorne with perfect ease arranged the bridle and snafflereins placed his left hand on the horse s mane and with his foot in the stirrup raised himself and seated himself in the saddle At first he made the horse walk the whole circuit of the courtyard at a footpace next at a trot lastly at a gallop He then drew up close to the count dismounted and threw the bridle to a groom standing by Well said the count what do you think of it M de Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: This horse, monsieur le comte, is of the Mecklenburg breed. In looking whether the bit suited his mouth, I saw that he was rising seven, the very age when the training of a horse intended for a charger should commence. The forehand is light. A horse which holds its head high, it is said, never tires his rider's hand. The withers are rather low. The drooping of the hindquarters would almost make me doubt the purity of its German breed, and I think there is English blood in him. He stands well on his legs, but he trots high, and may cut himself, which requires attention to be paid to his shoeing. He is tractable; and as I made him turn round and change his feet, I found him quick and ready in doing so.
children.prevalue: This horse monsieur le comte is of the Mecklenburg breed In looking whether the bit suited his mouth I saw that he was rising seven the very age when the training of a horse intended for a charger should commence The forehand is light A horse which holds its head high it is said never tires his rider s hand The withers are rather low The drooping of the hindquarters would almost make me doubt the purity of its German breed and I think there is English blood in him He stands well on his legs but he trots high and may cut himself which requires attention to be paid to his shoeing He is tractable and as I made him turn round and change his feet I found him quick and ready in doing so

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Well said, M. de Malicorne, exclaimed the comte; you are a judge of horses, I perceive; then, turning towards him again, he continued, you are most becomingly dressed, M. de Malicorne. That is not a provincial cut, I presume. Such a style of dress is not to be met with at Tours or Orleans.
children.prevalue: Well said M de Malicorne exclaimed the comte you are a judge of horses I perceive then turning towards him again he continued you are most becomingly dressed M de Malicorne That is not a provincial cut I presume Such a style of dress is not to be met with at Tours or Orleans

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: No, monsieur le comte; my clothes were made at Paris.
children.prevalue: No monsieur le comte my clothes were made at Paris

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: There is no doubt about that. But let us resume our own affair. Manicamp wishes for the appointment of a second maid of honor.
children.prevalue: There is no doubt about that But let us resume our own affair Manicamp wishes for the appointment of a second maid of honor

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: You perceive what he has written, monsieur le comte.
children.prevalue: You perceive what he has written monsieur le comte

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: For whom was the first appointment?
children.prevalue: For whom was the first appointment

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Malicorne felt the color rise in his face as he answered hurriedly.
children.prevalue: Malicorne felt the color rise in his face as he answered hurriedly

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: A charming maid of honor, Mademoiselle de Montalais.
children.prevalue: A charming maid of honor Mademoiselle de Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Ah, ah! you are acquainted with her?
children.prevalue: Ah ah you are acquainted with her

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: We are affianced, or nearly so.
children.prevalue: We are affianced or nearly so

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: That is quite another thing, then; a thousand compliments, exclaimed De Guiche, upon whose lips a courtier's jest was already fitting, but to whom the word affianced, addressed by Malicorne with respect to Mademoiselle de Montalais, recalled the respect due to women.
children.prevalue: That is quite another thing then a thousand compliments exclaimed De Guiche upon whose lips a courtier s jest was already fitting but to whom the word affianced addressed by Malicorne with respect to Mademoiselle de Montalais recalled the respect due to women

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: And for whom is the second appointment destined? asked De Guiche; is it for anyone to whom Manicamp may happen to be affianced? In that case I pity her, poor girl! for she will have a sad fellow for a husband.
children.prevalue: And for whom is the second appointment destined asked De Guiche is it for anyone to whom Manicamp may happen to be affianced In that case I pity her poor girl for she will have a sad fellow for a husband

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: No, monsieur le comte; the second appointment is for Mademoiselle de la Baume le Blanc de la Valliere.
children.prevalue: No monsieur le comte the second appointment is for Mademoiselle de la Baume le Blanc de la Valliere

children.value: Unknown, said De Guiche.
children.prevalue: Unknown said De Guiche

children.prevalue: Unknown yes monsieur said Malicorne smiling in his turn

children.value: Very good. I will speak to Monsieur about it. By the by, she is of gentle birth?
children.prevalue: Very good I will speak to Monsieur about it By the by she is of gentle birth

children.value: She belongs to a very good family and is maid of honor to Madame.
children.prevalue: She belongs to a very good family and is maid of honor to Madame

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: That's well. Will you accompany me to Monsieur?
children.prevalue: That s well Will you accompany me to Monsieur

children.value: Most certainly, if I may be permitted the honor.
children.prevalue: Most certainly if I may be permitted the honor

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Have you your carriage?
children.prevalue: Have you your carriage

children.prevalue: No I came here on horseback

children.value: Dressed as you are?
children.prevalue: Dressed as you are

children.value: No, monsieur; I posted from Orleans, and I changed my traveling suit for the one I have on, in order to present myself to you.
children.prevalue: No monsieur I posted from Orleans and I changed my traveling suit for the one I have on in order to present myself to you

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: True, you already told me you had come from Orleans; saying which he crumpled Manicamp's letter in his hand, and thrust it in his pocket.
children.prevalue: True you already told me you had come from Orleans saying which he crumpled Manicamp s letter in his hand and thrust it in his pocket

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: I beg your pardon, said Malicorne, timidly; but I do not think you have read all.
children.prevalue: I beg your pardon said Malicorne timidly but I do not think you have read all

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Not read all, do you say?
children.prevalue: Not read all do you say

children.prevalue: No there were two letters in the same envelope

children.value: Oh! are you sure?
children.prevalue: Oh are you sure

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Quite sure.
children.prevalue: Quite sure

children.value: Let us look, then, said the count, as he opened the letter again.
children.prevalue: Let us look then said the count as he opened the letter again

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Ah! you are right, he said opening the paper which he had not yet read.
children.prevalue: Ah you are right he said opening the paper which he had not yet read

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: I suspected it, he continuedanother application for an appointment under Monsieur. This Manicamp is a regular vampire:he is carrying on a trade in it.
children.prevalue: I suspected it he continuedanother application for an appointment under Monsieur This Manicamp is a regular vampire he is carrying on a trade in it

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: No, monsieur le comte, he wishes to make a present of it.
children.prevalue: No monsieur le comte he wishes to make a present of it

children.value: To whom?
children.prevalue: To whom

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: To myself, monsieur.
children.prevalue: To myself monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Why did you not say so at once, my dear M. Mauvaisecorne?
children.prevalue: Why did you not say so at once my dear M Mauvaisecorne

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Malicorne, monsieur le comte.
children.prevalue: Malicorne monsieur le comte

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Forgive me; it is that Latin that bothers methat terrible mine of etymologies. Why the deuce are young men of family taught Latin? Mala and mauvaiseyou understand it is the same thing. You will forgive me, I trust, M. de Malicorne.
children.prevalue: Forgive me it is that Latin that bothers methat terrible mine of etymologies Why the deuce are young men of family taught Latin Mala and mauvaiseyou understand it is the same thing You will forgive me I trust M de Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Your kindness affects me much, monsieur: but it is a reason why I should make you acquainted with one circumstance without any delay.
children.prevalue: Your kindness affects me much monsieur but it is a reason why I should make you acquainted with one circumstance without any delay

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: What is it?
children.prevalue: What is it

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: That I was not born a gentleman. I am not without courage, and not altogether deficient in ability; but my name is Malicorne simply.
children.prevalue: That I was not born a gentleman I am not without courage and not altogether deficient in ability but my name is Malicorne simply

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: You appear to me, monsieur! exclaimed the count, looking at the astute face of his companion, to be a most agreeable man. Your face pleases me, M. Malicorne, and you must possess some indisputably excellent qualities to have pleased that egotistical Manicamp. Be candid and tell me whether you are not some saint descended upon the earth.
children.prevalue: You appear to me monsieur exclaimed the count looking at the astute face of his companion to be a most agreeable man Your face pleases me M Malicorne and you must possess some indisputably excellent qualities to have pleased that egotistical Manicamp Be candid and tell me whether you are not some saint descended upon the earth

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Why so?
children.prevalue: Why so

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: For the simple reason that he makes you a present of anything. Did you not say that he intended to make you a present of some appointment in the king's household?
children.prevalue: For the simple reason that he makes you a present of anything Did you not say that he intended to make you a present of some appointment in the king s household

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: I beg your pardon, count; but, if I succeed in obtaining the appointment, you, and not he, will have bestowed it on me.
children.prevalue: I beg your pardon count but if I succeed in obtaining the appointment you and not he will have bestowed it on me

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Besides he will not have given it to you for nothing, I suppose. Stay, I have it;there is a Malicorne at Orleans who lends money to the prince.
children.prevalue: Besides he will not have given it to you for nothing I suppose Stay I have it there is a Malicorne at Orleans who lends money to the prince

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: I think that must be my father, monsieur.
children.prevalue: I think that must be my father monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Ah! the prince has the father, and that terrible dragon of a Manicamp has the son. Take care, monsieur, I know him. He will fleece you completely.
children.prevalue: Ah the prince has the father and that terrible dragon of a Manicamp has the son Take care monsieur I know him He will fleece you completely

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: The only difference is, that I lend without interest, said Malicorne, smiling.
children.prevalue: The only difference is that I lend without interest said Malicorne smiling

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: I was correct in saying you were either a saint or very much resembled one. M. Malicorne, you shall have the post you want, or I will forfeit my name.
children.prevalue: I was correct in saying you were either a saint or very much resembled one M Malicorne you shall have the post you want or I will forfeit my name

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Ah! monsieur le comte, what a debt of gratitude shall I not owe you? said Malicorne, transported.
children.prevalue: Ah monsieur le comte what a debt of gratitude shall I not owe you said Malicorne transported

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Let us go to the prince, my dear M. Malicorne. And De Guiche proceeded toward the door, desiring Malicorne to follow him. At the very moment they were about to cross the threshold, a young man appeared on the other side. He was from twentyfour to twentyfive years of age, of pale complexion, bright eyes and brown hair and eyebrows. Goodday, said he, suddenly, almost pushing De Guiche back into the courtyard again.
children.prevalue: Let us go to the prince my dear M Malicorne And De Guiche proceeded toward the door desiring Malicorne to follow him At the very moment they were about to cross the threshold a young man appeared on the other side He was from twentyfour to twentyfive years of age of pale complexion bright eyes and brown hair and eyebrows Goodday said he suddenly almost pushing De Guiche back into the courtyard again

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Is that you, De Wardes?What! and booted, spurred and whip in hand, too?
children.prevalue: Is that you De Wardes What and booted spurred and whip in hand too

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: The most befitting costume for a man about to set off for Le Havre. There will be no one left in Paris tomorrow. And hereupon he saluted Malicorne with great ceremony, whose handsome dress gave him the appearance of a prince.
children.prevalue: The most befitting costume for a man about to set off for Le Havre There will be no one left in Paris tomorrow And hereupon he saluted Malicorne with great ceremony whose handsome dress gave him the appearance of a prince

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: M. Malicorne, said De Guiche to his friend. De Wardes bowed.
children.prevalue: M Malicorne said De Guiche to his friend De Wardes bowed

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: M. de Wardes, said Guiche to Malicorne, who bowed in return. By the by, De Wardes, continued De Guiche, you who are so well acquainted with these matters, can you tell us, probably, what appointments are still vacant at the court; or rather in the prince's household?
children.prevalue: M de Wardes said Guiche to Malicorne who bowed in return By the by De Wardes continued De Guiche you who are so well acquainted with these matters can you tell us probably what appointments are still vacant at the court or rather in the prince s household

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: In the prince's household, said De Wardes looking up with an air of consideration, let me seethe appointment of the master of the horse is vacant, I believe.
children.prevalue: In the prince s household said De Wardes looking up with an air of consideration let me seethe appointment of the master of the horse is vacant I believe

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Oh, said Malicorne, there is no question of such a post as that, monsieur; my ambition is not nearly so exalted.
children.prevalue: Oh said Malicorne there is no question of such a post as that monsieur my ambition is not nearly so exalted

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: De Wardes had a more penetrating observation than De Guiche, and fathomed Malicorne immediately. The fact is, he said, looking at him from head to foot, a man must be either a duke or a peer to fill that post.
children.prevalue: De Wardes had a more penetrating observation than De Guiche and fathomed Malicorne immediately The fact is he said looking at him from head to foot a man must be either a duke or a peer to fill that post

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: All I solicit, said Malicorne, is a very humble appointment; I am of little importance, and I do not rank myself above my position.
children.prevalue: All I solicit said Malicorne is a very humble appointment I am of little importance and I do not rank myself above my position

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: M. Malicorne, whom you see here, said De Guiche to De Wardes, is a very excellent fellow, whose only misfortune is that of not being of gentle birth. As far as I am concerned, you know, I attach little value to those who have but gentle birth to boast of.
children.prevalue: M Malicorne whom you see here said De Guiche to De Wardes is a very excellent fellow whose only misfortune is that of not being of gentle birth As far as I am concerned you know I attach little value to those who have but gentle birth to boast of

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Assuredly, said De Wardes; but will you allow me to remark, my dear count, that, without rank of some sort, one can hardly hope to belong to his royal highness's household?
children.prevalue: Assuredly said De Wardes but will you allow me to remark my dear count that without rank of some sort one can hardly hope to belong to his royal highness s household

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: You are right, said the count, court etiquette is absolute. The devil!we never so much as gave it a thought.
children.prevalue: You are right said the count court etiquette is absolute The devil we never so much as gave it a thought

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Alas! a sad misfortune for me, monsieur le comte, said Malicorne, changing color.
children.prevalue: Alas a sad misfortune for me monsieur le comte said Malicorne changing color

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Yet not without remedy, I hope, returned De Guiche.
children.prevalue: Yet not without remedy I hope returned De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: The remedy is found easily enough, exclaimed De Wardes; you can be created a gentleman. His Eminence, the Cardinal Mazarin, did nothing else from morning till night.
children.prevalue: The remedy is found easily enough exclaimed De Wardes you can be created a gentleman His Eminence the Cardinal Mazarin did nothing else from morning till night

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Hush, hush, De Wardes, said the count; no jests of that kind; it ill becomes us to turn such matters into ridicule. Letters of nobility, it is true, are purchasable; but that is a sufficient misfortune without the nobles themselves laughing at it.
children.prevalue: Hush hush De Wardes said the count no jests of that kind it ill becomes us to turn such matters into ridicule Letters of nobility it is true are purchasable but that is a sufficient misfortune without the nobles themselves laughing at it

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Upon my word, De Guiche, you're quite a Puritan, as the English say.
children.prevalue: Upon my word De Guiche you re quite a Puritan as the English say

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: At this moment the Vicomte de Bragelonne was announced by one of the servants in the courtyard, in precisely the same manner as he would have done in a room.
children.prevalue: At this moment the Vicomte de Bragelonne was announced by one of the servants in the courtyard in precisely the same manner as he would have done in a room

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Come here, my dear Raoul. What! you, too, booted and spurred? You are setting off, then?
children.prevalue: Come here my dear Raoul What you too booted and spurred You are setting off then

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Bragelonne approached the group of young men, and saluted them with that quiet and serious manner peculiar to him. His salutation was principally addressed to De Wardes, with whom he was unacquainted, and whose features, on his perceiving Raoul, had assumed a strange sternness of expression. I have come, De Guiche, he said, to ask your companionship. We set off for Le Havre, I presume.
children.prevalue: Bragelonne approached the group of young men and saluted them with that quiet and serious manner peculiar to him His salutation was principally addressed to De Wardes with whom he was unacquainted and whose features on his perceiving Raoul had assumed a strange sternness of expression I have come De Guiche he said to ask your companionship We set off for Le Havre I presume

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: This is admirabledelightful. We shall have a most enjoyable journey. M. Malicorne, M. Bragelonneah! M. de Wardes, let me present you. The young men saluted each other in a restrained manner. Their very natures seemed, from the beginning, disposed to take exception to each other. De Wardes was pliant, subtle, full of dissimulation; Raoul was calm, grave, and upright. Decide between usbetween De Wardes and myself, Raoul.
children.prevalue: This is admirabledelightful We shall have a most enjoyable journey M Malicorne M Bragelonneah M de Wardes let me present you The young men saluted each other in a restrained manner Their very natures seemed from the beginning disposed to take exception to each other De Wardes was pliant subtle full of dissimulation Raoul was calm grave and upright Decide between usbetween De Wardes and myself Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Upon what subject?
children.prevalue: Upon what subject

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Upon the subject of noble birth.
children.prevalue: Upon the subject of noble birth

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Who can be better informed on that subject than a De Gramont?
children.prevalue: Who can be better informed on that subject than a De Gramont

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: No compliments; it is your opinion I ask.
children.prevalue: No compliments it is your opinion I ask

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: At least, inform me of the subject under discussion.
children.prevalue: At least inform me of the subject under discussion

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: De Wardes asserts that the distribution of titles is abused; I, on the contrary, maintain that a title is useless to the man on whom it is bestowed.
children.prevalue: De Wardes asserts that the distribution of titles is abused I on the contrary maintain that a title is useless to the man on whom it is bestowed

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: And you are correct, said Bragelonne, quietly.
children.prevalue: And you are correct said Bragelonne quietly

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: But, monsieur le vicomte, interrupted De Wardes, with a kind of obstinacy, I affirm that it is I who am correct.
children.prevalue: But monsieur le vicomte interrupted De Wardes with a kind of obstinacy I affirm that it is I who am correct

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: What was your opinion, monsieur?
children.prevalue: What was your opinion monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: I was saying that everything is done in France at the present moment, to humiliate men of family.
children.prevalue: I was saying that everything is done in France at the present moment to humiliate men of family

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: And by whom?
children.prevalue: And by whom

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: By the king himself. He surrounds himself with people who cannot show four quarterings.
children.prevalue: By the king himself He surrounds himself with people who cannot show four quarterings

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Nonsense, said De Guiche, where could you possibly have seen that, De Wardes?
children.prevalue: Nonsense said De Guiche where could you possibly have seen that De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: One example will suffice, he returned, directing his look fully upon Raoul.
children.prevalue: One example will suffice he returned directing his look fully upon Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: State it then.
children.prevalue: State it then

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Do you know who has just been nominated captaingeneral of the musketeers?an appointment more valuable than a peerage; for it gives precedence over all the marechals of France.
children.prevalue: Do you know who has just been nominated captaingeneral of the musketeers an appointment more valuable than a peerage for it gives precedence over all the marechals of France

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Raoul's color mounted in his face; for he saw the object De Wardes had in view. No; who has been appointed? In any case it must have been very recently, for the appointment was vacant eight days ago; a proof of which is, that the king refused Monsieur, who solicited the post for one of his proteges.
children.prevalue: Raoul s color mounted in his face for he saw the object De Wardes had in view No who has been appointed In any case it must have been very recently for the appointment was vacant eight days ago a proof of which is that the king refused Monsieur who solicited the post for one of his proteges

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: Well, the king refused it to Monsieur's protege, in order to bestow it upon the Chevalier d'Artagnan, a younger brother of some Gascon family, who has been trailing his sword in the antechambers during the last thirty years.
children.prevalue: Well the king refused it to Monsieur s protege in order to bestow it upon the Chevalier d Artagnan a younger brother of some Gascon family who has been trailing his sword in the antechambers during the last thirty years

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: Forgive me if I interrupt you, said Raoul, darting a glance full of severity at De Wardes; but you give me the impression of being unacquainted with the gentleman of whom you are speaking.
children.prevalue: Forgive me if I interrupt you said Raoul darting a glance full of severity at De Wardes but you give me the impression of being unacquainted with the gentleman of whom you are speaking

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: I not acquainted with M. d'Artagnan? Can you tell me, monsieur, who does not know him?
children.prevalue: I not acquainted with M d Artagnan Can you tell me monsieur who does not know him

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Those who do know him, monsieur, replied Raoul, with still greater calmness and sternness of manner, are in the habit of saying, that if he is not as good a gentleman as the kingwhich is not his faulthe is the equal of all the kings of the earth in courage and loyalty. Such is my opinion, monsieur; and I thank heaven I have known M. d'Artagnan from my birth.
children.prevalue: Those who do know him monsieur replied Raoul with still greater calmness and sternness of manner are in the habit of saying that if he is not as good a gentleman as the kingwhich is not his faulthe is the equal of all the kings of the earth in courage and loyalty Such is my opinion monsieur and I thank heaven I have known M d Artagnan from my birth

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: De Wardes was about to reply, when De Guiche interrupted him.
children.prevalue: De Wardes was about to reply when De Guiche interrupted him

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The discussion was becoming full of bitterness. De Guiche perfectly understood the whole matter, for there was in Bragelonne's face a look instinctively hostile, while in that of De Wardes there was something like a determination to offend. Without inquiring into the different feelings which actuated his two friends, De Guiche resolved to ward off the blow which he felt was on the point of being dealt by one of them, and perhaps by both. Gentlemen, he said, we must take our leave of each other, I must pay a visit to Monsieur. You, De Wardes, will accompany me to the Louvre, and you, Raoul, will remain here master of the house; and as all that is done here is under your advice, you will bestow the last glance upon my preparations for departure.
children.prevalue: The discussion was becoming full of bitterness De Guiche perfectly understood the whole matter for there was in Bragelonne s face a look instinctively hostile while in that of De Wardes there was something like a determination to offend Without inquiring into the different feelings which actuated his two friends De Guiche resolved to ward off the blow which he felt was on the point of being dealt by one of them and perhaps by both Gentlemen he said we must take our leave of each other I must pay a visit to Monsieur You De Wardes will accompany me to the Louvre and you Raoul will remain here master of the house and as all that is done here is under your advice you will bestow the last glance upon my preparations for departure

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Raoul, with the air of one who neither seeks nor fears a quarrel, bowed his head in token of assent, and seated himself upon a bench in the sun. That is well, said De Guiche, remain where you are, Raoul, and tell them to show you the two horses I have just purchased; you will give me your opinion, for I only bought them on condition that you ratified the purchase. By the by, I have to beg your pardon for having omitted to inquire after the Comte de la Fere. While pronouncing these latter words, he closely observed De Wardes, in order to perceive what effect the name of Raoul's father would produce upon him. I thank you, answered the young man, the count is very well. A gleam of deep hatred passed into De Wardes's eyes. De Guiche, who appeared not to notice the foreboding expression, went up to Raoul, and grasping him by the hand, said,It is agreed, then, Bragelonne, is it not, that you will rejoin us in the courtyard of the Palais Royal? He then signed to De Wardes to follow him, who had been engaged in balancing himself first on one foot, then on the other. We are going, said he, come, M. Malicorne. This name made Raoul start; for it seemed that he had already heard it pronounced before, but he could not remember on what occasion. While trying to recall it halfdreamily, yet halfirritated at his conversation with De Wardes, the three young men set out on their way towards the Palais Royal, where Monsieur was residing. Malicorne learned two things; the first, that the young men had something to say to each other; and the second, that he ought not to walk in the same line with them; and therefore he walked behind. Are you mad? said De Guiche to his companion, as soon as they had left the Hotel de Grammont; you attack M. d'Artagnan, and that, too, before Raoul.
children.prevalue: Raoul with the air of one who neither seeks nor fears a quarrel bowed his head in token of assent and seated himself upon a bench in the sun That is well said De Guiche remain where you are Raoul and tell them to show you the two horses I have just purchased you will give me your opinion for I only bought them on condition that you ratified the purchase By the by I have to beg your pardon for having omitted to inquire after the Comte de la Fere While pronouncing these latter words he closely observed De Wardes in order to perceive what effect the name of Raoul s father would produce upon him I thank you answered the young man the count is very well A gleam of deep hatred passed into De Wardes s eyes De Guiche who appeared not to notice the foreboding expression went up to Raoul and grasping him by the hand said It is agreed then Bragelonne is it not that you will rejoin us in the courtyard of the Palais Royal He then signed to De Wardes to follow him who had been engaged in balancing himself first on one foot then on the other We are going said he come M Malicorne This name made Raoul start for it seemed that he had already heard it pronounced before but he could not remember on what occasion While trying to recall it halfdreamily yet halfirritated at his conversation with De Wardes the three young men set out on their way towards the Palais Royal where Monsieur was residing Malicorne learned two things the first that the young men had something to say to each other and the second that he ought not to walk in the same line with them and therefore he walked behind Are you mad said De Guiche to his companion as soon as they had left the Hotel de Grammont you attack M d Artagnan and that too before Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Well, said De Wardes, what then?
children.prevalue: Well said De Wardes what then

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: What do you mean by 'what then?'
children.prevalue: What do you mean by what then

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Certainly, is there any prohibition against attacking M. d'Artagnan?
children.prevalue: Certainly is there any prohibition against attacking M d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: But you know very well that M. d'Artagnan was one of those celebrated and terrible four men who were called the musketeers.
children.prevalue: But you know very well that M d Artagnan was one of those celebrated and terrible four men who were called the musketeers

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: That they may be; but I do not perceive why, on that account, I should be forbidden to hate M. d'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: That they may be but I do not perceive why on that account I should be forbidden to hate M d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: What cause has he given you?
children.prevalue: What cause has he given you

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Me! personally, none.
children.prevalue: Me personally none

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Why hate him, therefore?
children.prevalue: Why hate him therefore

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Ask my dead father that question.
children.prevalue: Ask my dead father that question

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Really, my dear De Wardes, you surprise me. M. d'Artagnan is not one to leave unsettled any enmity he may have to arrange, without completely clearing his account. Your father, I have heard, carried matters with a high hand. Moreover, there are no enmities so bitter that they cannot be washed away by blood, by a good swordthrust loyally given.
children.prevalue: Really my dear De Wardes you surprise me M d Artagnan is not one to leave unsettled any enmity he may have to arrange without completely clearing his account Your father I have heard carried matters with a high hand Moreover there are no enmities so bitter that they cannot be washed away by blood by a good swordthrust loyally given

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Listen to me, my dear De Guiche, this inveterate dislike existed between my father and M. d'Artagnan, and when I was quite a child, he acquainted me with the reason for it, and, as forming part of my inheritance, I regard it as a particular legacy bestowed upon me.
children.prevalue: Listen to me my dear De Guiche this inveterate dislike existed between my father and M d Artagnan and when I was quite a child he acquainted me with the reason for it and as forming part of my inheritance I regard it as a particular legacy bestowed upon me

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: And does this hatred concern M. d'Artagnan alone?
children.prevalue: And does this hatred concern M d Artagnan alone

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: As for that, M. d'Artagnan was so intimately associated with his three friends, that some portion of the full measure of my hatred falls to their lot, and that hatred is of such a nature, whenever the opportunity occurs, they shall have no occasion to complain of their allowance.
children.prevalue: As for that M d Artagnan was so intimately associated with his three friends that some portion of the full measure of my hatred falls to their lot and that hatred is of such a nature whenever the opportunity occurs they shall have no occasion to complain of their allowance

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: De Guiche had kept his eyes fixed on De Wardes, and shuddered at the bitter manner in which the young man smiled. Something like a presentiment flashed across his mind; he knew that the time had passed away for grands coups entre gentilshommes; but that the feeling of hatred treasured up in the mind, instead of being diffused abroad, was still hatred all the same; that a smile was sometimes as full of meaning as a threat; and, in a word, that to the fathers who had hated with their hearts and fought with their arms, would now succeed the sons, who would indeed hate with their hearts, but would no longer combat their enemies save by means of intrigue or treachery. As, therefore, it certainly was not Raoul whom he could suspect either of intrigue or treachery, it was on Raoul's account that De Guiche trembled. However, while these gloomy forebodings cast a shade of anxiety over De Guiche's countenance, De Wardes had resumed the entire mastery over himself.
children.prevalue: De Guiche had kept his eyes fixed on De Wardes and shuddered at the bitter manner in which the young man smiled Something like a presentiment flashed across his mind he knew that the time had passed away for grands coups entre gentilshommes but that the feeling of hatred treasured up in the mind instead of being diffused abroad was still hatred all the same that a smile was sometimes as full of meaning as a threat and in a word that to the fathers who had hated with their hearts and fought with their arms would now succeed the sons who would indeed hate with their hearts but would no longer combat their enemies save by means of intrigue or treachery As therefore it certainly was not Raoul whom he could suspect either of intrigue or treachery it was on Raoul s account that De Guiche trembled However while these gloomy forebodings cast a shade of anxiety over De Guiche s countenance De Wardes had resumed the entire mastery over himself

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: At all events, he observed, I have no personal illwill towards M. de Bragelonne; I do not know him even.
children.prevalue: At all events he observed I have no personal illwill towards M de Bragelonne I do not know him even

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: In any case, said De Guiche, with a certain amount of severity in his tone of voice, do not forget one circumstance, that Raoul is my most intimate friend; a remark at which De Wardes bowed.
children.prevalue: In any case said De Guiche with a certain amount of severity in his tone of voice do not forget one circumstance that Raoul is my most intimate friend a remark at which De Wardes bowed

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The conversation terminated there, although De Guiche tried his utmost to draw out his secret from him; but, doubtless, De Wardes had determined to say nothing further, and he remained impenetrable. De Guiche therefore promised himself a more satisfactory result with Raoul. In the meantime they had reached the Palais Royal, which was surrounded by a crowd of lookerson. The household belonging to Monsieur awaited his command to mount their horses, in order to form part of the escort of the ambassadors, to whom had been intrusted the care of bringing the young princess to Paris. The brilliant display of horses, arms, and rich liveries, afforded some compensation in those times, thanks to the kindly feelings of the people, and to the traditions of deep devotion to their sovereigns, for the enormous expenses charged upon the taxes. Mazarin had said: Let them sing, provided they pay; while Louis XIV.'s remark was, Let them look. Sight had replaced the voice; the people could still look but they were no longer allowed to sing. De Guiche left De Wardes and Malicorne at the bottom of the grand staircase, while he himself, who shared the favor and good graces of Monsieur with the Chevalier de Lorraine, who always smiled at him most affectionately, though he could not endure him, went straight to the prince's apartments, whom he found engaged in admiring himself in the glass, and rouging his face. In a corner of the cabinet, the Chevalier de Lorraine was extended full length upon some cushions, having just had his long hair curled, with which he was playing in the same manner a woman would have done. The prince turned round as the count entered, and perceiving who it was, said: Ah! is that you, De Guiche; come here and tell me the truth.
children.prevalue: The conversation terminated there although De Guiche tried his utmost to draw out his secret from him but doubtless De Wardes had determined to say nothing further and he remained impenetrable De Guiche therefore promised himself a more satisfactory result with Raoul In the meantime they had reached the Palais Royal which was surrounded by a crowd of lookerson The household belonging to Monsieur awaited his command to mount their horses in order to form part of the escort of the ambassadors to whom had been intrusted the care of bringing the young princess to Paris The brilliant display of horses arms and rich liveries afforded some compensation in those times thanks to the kindly feelings of the people and to the traditions of deep devotion to their sovereigns for the enormous expenses charged upon the taxes Mazarin had said Let them sing provided they pay while Louis XIV s remark was Let them look Sight had replaced the voice the people could still look but they were no longer allowed to sing De Guiche left De Wardes and Malicorne at the bottom of the grand staircase while he himself who shared the favor and good graces of Monsieur with the Chevalier de Lorraine who always smiled at him most affectionately though he could not endure him went straight to the prince s apartments whom he found engaged in admiring himself in the glass and rouging his face In a corner of the cabinet the Chevalier de Lorraine was extended full length upon some cushions having just had his long hair curled with which he was playing in the same manner a woman would have done The prince turned round as the count entered and perceiving who it was said Ah is that you De Guiche come here and tell me the truth

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: You know, my lord, it is one of my defects to speak the truth.
children.prevalue: You know my lord it is one of my defects to speak the truth

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: You will hardly believe, De Guiche, how that wicked chevalier has annoyed me.
children.prevalue: You will hardly believe De Guiche how that wicked chevalier has annoyed me

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The chevalier shrugged his shoulders.
children.prevalue: The chevalier shrugged his shoulders

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Why, he pretends, continued the prince, that Mademoiselle Henrietta is better looking as a woman than I am as a man.
children.prevalue: Why he pretends continued the prince that Mademoiselle Henrietta is better looking as a woman than I am as a man

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Do not forget, my lord, said De Guiche, frowning slightly, you require me to speak the truth.
children.prevalue: Do not forget my lord said De Guiche frowning slightly you require me to speak the truth

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Certainly, said the prince, tremblingly.
children.prevalue: Certainly said the prince tremblingly

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Well, and I shall tell it you.
children.prevalue: Well and I shall tell it you

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Do not be in a hurry, Guiche, exclaimed the prince, you have plenty of time; look at me attentively, and try to recollect Madame. Besides, her portrait is here. Look at it. And he held out to him a miniature of the finest possible execution. De Guiche took it, and looked at it for a long time attentively.
children.prevalue: Do not be in a hurry Guiche exclaimed the prince you have plenty of time look at me attentively and try to recollect Madame Besides her portrait is here Look at it And he held out to him a miniature of the finest possible execution De Guiche took it and looked at it for a long time attentively

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Upon my honor, my lord, this is indeed a most lovely face.
children.prevalue: Upon my honor my lord this is indeed a most lovely face

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: But look at me, count, look at me, said the prince, endeavoring to direct upon himself the attention of the count, who was completely absorbed in contemplation of the portrait.
children.prevalue: But look at me count look at me said the prince endeavoring to direct upon himself the attention of the count who was completely absorbed in contemplation of the portrait

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: It is wonderful, murmured Guiche.
children.prevalue: It is wonderful murmured Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Really one would imagine you had never seen the young lady before.
children.prevalue: Really one would imagine you had never seen the young lady before

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: It is true, my lord, I have seen her but it was five years ago; there is a great difference between a child twelve years old, and a girl of seventeen.
children.prevalue: It is true my lord I have seen her but it was five years ago there is a great difference between a child twelve years old and a girl of seventeen

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Well, what is your opinion?
children.prevalue: Well what is your opinion

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: My opinion is that the portrait must be flattering, my lord.
children.prevalue: My opinion is that the portrait must be flattering my lord

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Of that, said the prince triumphantly, there can be no doubt; but let us suppose that it is not, what would your opinion be?
children.prevalue: Of that said the prince triumphantly there can be no doubt but let us suppose that it is not what would your opinion be

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: My lord, that your highness is exceedingly happy to have so charming a bride.
children.prevalue: My lord that your highness is exceedingly happy to have so charming a bride

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The Chevalier de Lorraine burst out laughing. The prince understood how severe towards himself this opinion of the Comte de Guiche was, and he looked somewhat displeased, saying, My friends are not over indulgent. De Guiche looked at the portrait again, and, after lengthened contemplation, returned it with apparent unwillingness, saying, Most decidedly, my lord, I should rather prefer to look ten times at your highness, than to look at Madame once again. It seemed as if the chevalier had detected some mystery in these words, which were incomprehensible to the prince, for he exclaimed: Very well, get married yourself. Monsieur continued painting himself, and when he had finished, looked at the portrait again once more, turned to admire himself in the glass, and smiled, and no doubt was satisfied with the comparison. You are very kind to have come, he said to Guiche, I feared you would leave without bidding me adieu.
children.prevalue: The Chevalier de Lorraine burst out laughing The prince understood how severe towards himself this opinion of the Comte de Guiche was and he looked somewhat displeased saying My friends are not over indulgent De Guiche looked at the portrait again and after lengthened contemplation returned it with apparent unwillingness saying Most decidedly my lord I should rather prefer to look ten times at your highness than to look at Madame once again It seemed as if the chevalier had detected some mystery in these words which were incomprehensible to the prince for he exclaimed Very well get married yourself Monsieur continued painting himself and when he had finished looked at the portrait again once more turned to admire himself in the glass and smiled and no doubt was satisfied with the comparison You are very kind to have come he said to Guiche I feared you would leave without bidding me adieu

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Your highness knows me too well to believe me capable of so great a disrespect.
children.prevalue: Your highness knows me too well to believe me capable of so great a disrespect

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Besides, I suppose you have something to ask from me before leaving Paris?
children.prevalue: Besides I suppose you have something to ask from me before leaving Paris

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Your highness has indeed guessed correctly, for I have a request to make.
children.prevalue: Your highness has indeed guessed correctly for I have a request to make

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Very good, what is it?
children.prevalue: Very good what is it

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: The Chevalier de Lorraine immediately displayed the greatest attention, for he regarded every favor conferred upon another as a robbery committed against himself. And, as Guiche hesitated, the prince said: If it be money, nothing could be more fortunate, for I am in funds; the superintendent of the finances has sent me 500,000 pistoles.
children.prevalue: The Chevalier de Lorraine immediately displayed the greatest attention for he regarded every favor conferred upon another as a robbery committed against himself And as Guiche hesitated the prince said If it be money nothing could be more fortunate for I am in funds the superintendent of the finances has sent me 500 000 pistoles

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: I thank your highness; but is not an affair of money.
children.prevalue: I thank your highness but is not an affair of money

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: What is it, then? Tell me.
children.prevalue: What is it then Tell me

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: The appointment of a maid of honor.
children.prevalue: The appointment of a maid of honor

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Oh! oh! Guiche, what a protector you have become of young ladies, said the prince, you never speak of any one else now.
children.prevalue: Oh oh Guiche what a protector you have become of young ladies said the prince you never speak of any one else now

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: The Chevalier de Lorraine smiled, for he knew very well that nothing displeased the prince more than to show any interest in ladies. My lord, said the comte, it is not I who am directly interested in the lady of whom I have just spoken; I am acting on behalf of one of my friends.
children.prevalue: The Chevalier de Lorraine smiled for he knew very well that nothing displeased the prince more than to show any interest in ladies My lord said the comte it is not I who am directly interested in the lady of whom I have just spoken I am acting on behalf of one of my friends

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Ah! that is different; what is the name of the young lady in whom your friend is so interested?
children.prevalue: Ah that is different what is the name of the young lady in whom your friend is so interested

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Mlle. de la Baume le Blanc de la Valliere; she is already maid of honor to the dowager princess.
children.prevalue: Mlle de la Baume le Blanc de la Valliere she is already maid of honor to the dowager princess

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Why, she is lame, said the Chevalier de Lorraine, stretching himself on his cushions.
children.prevalue: Why she is lame said the Chevalier de Lorraine stretching himself on his cushions

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Lame, repeated the prince, and Madame to have her constantly before her eyes? Most certainly not; it may be dangerous for her when in an interesting condition.
children.prevalue: Lame repeated the prince and Madame to have her constantly before her eyes Most certainly not it may be dangerous for her when in an interesting condition

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: The Chevalier de Lorraine burst out laughing.
children.prevalue: The Chevalier de Lorraine burst out laughing

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Chevalier, said Guiche, your conduct is ungenerous; while I am soliciting a favor, you do me all the mischief you can.
children.prevalue: Chevalier said Guiche your conduct is ungenerous while I am soliciting a favor you do me all the mischief you can

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Forgive me, comte, said the Chevalier de Lorraine, somewhat uneasy at the tone in which Guiche had made his remark, but I had no intention of doing so, and I begin to believe that I have mistaken one young lady for another.
children.prevalue: Forgive me comte said the Chevalier de Lorraine somewhat uneasy at the tone in which Guiche had made his remark but I had no intention of doing so and I begin to believe that I have mistaken one young lady for another

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: There is no doubt of it, monsieur; and I do not hesitate to declare that such is the case.
children.prevalue: There is no doubt of it monsieur and I do not hesitate to declare that such is the case

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Do you attach much importance to it, Guiche? inquired the prince.
children.prevalue: Do you attach much importance to it Guiche inquired the prince

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: I do, my lord.
children.prevalue: I do my lord

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Well, you shall have it; but ask me for no more appointments, for there are none to give away.
children.prevalue: Well you shall have it but ask me for no more appointments for there are none to give away

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Ah! exclaimed the chevalier, midday already, that is the hour fixed for the departure.
children.prevalue: Ah exclaimed the chevalier midday already that is the hour fixed for the departure

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: You dismiss me, monsieur? inquired Guiche.
children.prevalue: You dismiss me monsieur inquired Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Really, count, you treat me very ill today, replied the chevalier.
children.prevalue: Really count you treat me very ill today replied the chevalier

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: For heaven's sake, count, for heaven's sake, chevalier, said Monsieur, do you not see how you are distressing me?
children.prevalue: For heaven s sake count for heaven s sake chevalier said Monsieur do you not see how you are distressing me

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Your highness's signature? said Guiche.
children.prevalue: Your highness s signature said Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Take a blank appointment from that drawer, and give it to me. Guiche handed the prince the document indicated, and at the same time presented him with a pen already dipped in ink; whereupon the prince signed. Here, he said, returning him the appointment, but I give it on one condition.
children.prevalue: Take a blank appointment from that drawer and give it to me Guiche handed the prince the document indicated and at the same time presented him with a pen already dipped in ink whereupon the prince signed Here he said returning him the appointment but I give it on one condition

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Name it.
children.prevalue: Name it

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: That you make friends with the chevalier.
children.prevalue: That you make friends with the chevalier

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Willingly, said Guiche. And he held out his hand to the chevalier with an indifference amounting to contempt.
children.prevalue: Willingly said Guiche And he held out his hand to the chevalier with an indifference amounting to contempt

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Adieu, count, said the chevalier, without seeming in any way to have noticed the count's slight; adieu, and bring us back a princess who will not talk with her own portrait too much.
children.prevalue: Adieu count said the chevalier without seeming in any way to have noticed the count s slight adieu and bring us back a princess who will not talk with her own portrait too much

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Yes, set off and lose no time. By the by, who will accompany you?
children.prevalue: Yes set off and lose no time By the by who will accompany you

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Bragelonne and De Wardes.
children.prevalue: Bragelonne and De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Both excellent and fearless companions.
children.prevalue: Both excellent and fearless companions

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Too fearless, said the chevalier; endeavor to bring them both back, count.
children.prevalue: Too fearless said the chevalier endeavor to bring them both back count

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: A bad heart, bad! murmured De Guiche; he scents mischief everywhere, and sooner than anything else. And taking leave of the prince, he quitted the apartment. As soon as he reached the vestibule, he waved in the air the paper which the prince had signed. Malicorne hurried forward, and received it, trembling with delight. When, however, he held in his hand, Guiche observed that he still awaited something further.
children.prevalue: A bad heart bad murmured De Guiche he scents mischief everywhere and sooner than anything else And taking leave of the prince he quitted the apartment As soon as he reached the vestibule he waved in the air the paper which the prince had signed Malicorne hurried forward and received it trembling with delight When however he held in his hand Guiche observed that he still awaited something further

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Patience, monsieur, he said; the Chevalier de Lorraine was there, and I feared an utter failure if I asked too much at once. Wait until I return. Adieu.
children.prevalue: Patience monsieur he said the Chevalier de Lorraine was there and I feared an utter failure if I asked too much at once Wait until I return Adieu

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Adieu, monsieur le comte; a thousand thanks, said Malicorne.
children.prevalue: Adieu monsieur le comte a thousand thanks said Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Send Manicamp to me. By the way, monsieur, is it true that Mlle. de la Valliere is lame? As he said this, he noticed that Bragelonne, who had just at that moment entered the courtyard, turned suddenly pale. The poor lover had heard the remark, which, however, was not the case with Malicorne, for he was already beyond the reach of the count's voice.
children.prevalue: Send Manicamp to me By the way monsieur is it true that Mlle de la Valliere is lame As he said this he noticed that Bragelonne who had just at that moment entered the courtyard turned suddenly pale The poor lover had heard the remark which however was not the case with Malicorne for he was already beyond the reach of the count s voice

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Why is Louise's name spoken of here, said Raoul to himself; oh! let not De Wardes, who stands smiling yonder, even say a word about her in my presence.
children.prevalue: Why is Louise s name spoken of here said Raoul to himself oh let not De Wardes who stands smiling yonder even say a word about her in my presence

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Now, gentlemen, exclaimed the Comte de Guiche, prepare to start.
children.prevalue: Now gentlemen exclaimed the Comte de Guiche prepare to start

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: At this moment the prince, who had complete his toilette, appeared at the window, and was immediately saluted by the acclamations of all who composed the escort, and ten minutes afterwards, banners, scarfs, and feathers were fluttering and waving in the air, as the cavalcade galloped away.
children.prevalue: At this moment the prince who had complete his toilette appeared at the window and was immediately saluted by the acclamations of all who composed the escort and ten minutes afterwards banners scarfs and feathers were fluttering and waving in the air as the cavalcade galloped away

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: This brilliant and animated company, the members of which were inspired by various feelings, arrived at Le Havre four days after their departure from Paris. It was about five o'clock in the afternoon, and no intelligence had yet been received of Madame. They were soon engaged in quest of apartments; but the greatest confusion immediately ensued among the masters, and violent quarrels among their attendants. In the midst of this disorder, the Comte de Guiche fancied he recognized Manicamp. It was, indeed, Manicamp himself; but as Malicorne had taken possession of his very best costume, he had not been able to get any other than a suit of violet velvet, trimmed with silver. Guiche recognized him as much by his dress as by his features, for he had very frequently seen Manicamp in his violet suit, which was his last resource. Manicamp presented himself to the count under an arch of torches, which set in a blaze, rather than illuminated, the gate by which Le Havre is entered, and which is situated close to the tower of Francis I. The count, remarking the woebegone expression of Manicamp's face, could not resist laughing. Well, my poor Manicamp, he exclaimed, how violet you look; are you in mourning?
children.prevalue: This brilliant and animated company the members of which were inspired by various feelings arrived at Le Havre four days after their departure from Paris It was about five o clock in the afternoon and no intelligence had yet been received of Madame They were soon engaged in quest of apartments but the greatest confusion immediately ensued among the masters and violent quarrels among their attendants In the midst of this disorder the Comte de Guiche fancied he recognized Manicamp It was indeed Manicamp himself but as Malicorne had taken possession of his very best costume he had not been able to get any other than a suit of violet velvet trimmed with silver Guiche recognized him as much by his dress as by his features for he had very frequently seen Manicamp in his violet suit which was his last resource Manicamp presented himself to the count under an arch of torches which set in a blaze rather than illuminated the gate by which Le Havre is entered and which is situated close to the tower of Francis I The count remarking the woebegone expression of Manicamp s face could not resist laughing Well my poor Manicamp he exclaimed how violet you look are you in mourning

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Yes, replied Manicamp; I am in mourning.
children.prevalue: Yes replied Manicamp I am in mourning

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: For whom, or for what?
children.prevalue: For whom or for what

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: For my blueandgold suit, which has disappeared, and in the place of which I could find nothing but this; and I was even obliged to economize from compulsion, in order to get possession of it.
children.prevalue: For my blueandgold suit which has disappeared and in the place of which I could find nothing but this and I was even obliged to economize from compulsion in order to get possession of it

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Indeed?
children.prevalue: Indeed

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: It is singular you should be astonished at that, since you leave me without any money.
children.prevalue: It is singular you should be astonished at that since you leave me without any money

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: At all events, here you are, and that is the principal thing.
children.prevalue: At all events here you are and that is the principal thing

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: By the most horrible roads.
children.prevalue: By the most horrible roads

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Where are you lodging?
children.prevalue: Where are you lodging

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Lodging?
children.prevalue: Lodging

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Yes!
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: I am not lodging anywhere.
children.prevalue: I am not lodging anywhere

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: De Guiche began to laugh. Well, said he, where do you intend to lodge?
children.prevalue: De Guiche began to laugh Well said he where do you intend to lodge

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: In the same place you do.
children.prevalue: In the same place you do

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: But I don't know, myself.
children.prevalue: But I don t know myself

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: What do you mean by saying you don't know?
children.prevalue: What do you mean by saying you don t know

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Certainly, how is it likely I should know where I should stay?
children.prevalue: Certainly how is it likely I should know where I should stay

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Have you not retained an hotel?
children.prevalue: Have you not retained an hotel

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: I?
children.prevalue: I

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Yes, you or the prince.
children.prevalue: Yes you or the prince

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Neither of us has thought of it. Le Havre is of considerable size, I suppose; and provided I can get a stable for a dozen horses, and a suitable house in a good quarter
children.prevalue: Neither of us has thought of it Le Havre is of considerable size I suppose and provided I can get a stable for a dozen horses and a suitable house in a good quarter

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Certainly, there are some very excellent houses.
children.prevalue: Certainly there are some very excellent houses

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Well then
children.prevalue: Well then

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: But not for us.
children.prevalue: But not for us

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: What do you mean by saying not for us?for whom, then?
children.prevalue: What do you mean by saying not for us for whom then

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: For the English, of course.
children.prevalue: For the English of course

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: For the English?
children.prevalue: For the English

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Yes; the houses are all taken.
children.prevalue: Yes the houses are all taken

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: By whom?
children.prevalue: By whom

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: By the Duke of Buckingham.
children.prevalue: By the Duke of Buckingham

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: I beg your pardon? said Guiche, whose attention this name had awakened.
children.prevalue: I beg your pardon said Guiche whose attention this name had awakened

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Yes, by the Duke of Buckingham. His Grace was preceded by a courier, who arrived here three days ago, and immediately retained all the houses fit for habitation the town possesses.
children.prevalue: Yes by the Duke of Buckingham His Grace was preceded by a courier who arrived here three days ago and immediately retained all the houses fit for habitation the town possesses

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Come, come, Manicamp, let us understand each other.
children.prevalue: Come come Manicamp let us understand each other

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Well, what I have told you is clear enough, it seems to me.
children.prevalue: Well what I have told you is clear enough it seems to me

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: But surely Buckingham does not occupy the whole of Le Havre?
children.prevalue: But surely Buckingham does not occupy the whole of Le Havre

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: He certainly does not occupy it, since he has not yet arrived; but, once disembarked, he will occupy it.
children.prevalue: He certainly does not occupy it since he has not yet arrived but once disembarked he will occupy it

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Oh! oh!
children.prevalue: Oh oh

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: It is quite clear you are not acquainted with the English; they have a perfect rage for monopolizing everything.
children.prevalue: It is quite clear you are not acquainted with the English they have a perfect rage for monopolizing everything

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: That may be; but a man who has the whole of one house, is satisfied with it, and does not require two.
children.prevalue: That may be but a man who has the whole of one house is satisfied with it and does not require two

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Yes, but two men?
children.prevalue: Yes but two men

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Be it so; for two men, two houses, or four or six, or ten, if you like; but there are a hundred houses at Le Havre.
children.prevalue: Be it so for two men two houses or four or six or ten if you like but there are a hundred houses at Le Havre

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Yes, and all the hundred are let.
children.prevalue: Yes and all the hundred are let

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Impossible!
children.prevalue: Impossible

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: What an obstinate fellow you are. I tell you Buckingham has hired all the houses surrounding the one which the queen dowager of England and the princess her daughter will inhabit.
children.prevalue: What an obstinate fellow you are I tell you Buckingham has hired all the houses surrounding the one which the queen dowager of England and the princess her daughter will inhabit

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: He is singular enough, indeed, said De Wardes, caressing his horse's neck.
children.prevalue: He is singular enough indeed said De Wardes caressing his horse s neck

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Such is the case, however, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Such is the case however monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: You are quite sure of it, Monsieur de Manicamp? and as he put this question, he looked slyly at De Guiche, as though to interrogate him upon the degree of confidence to be placed in his friend's state of mind. During this discussion the night had closed in, and the torches, pages, attendants, squires, horses, and carriages, blocked up the gate and the open place; the torches were reflected in the channel, which the rising tide was gradually filling, while on the other side of the jetty might be noticed groups of curious lookerson, consisting of sailors and townspeople, who seemed anxious to miss nothing of the spectacle. Amidst all this hesitation of purpose, Bragelonne, as though a perfect stranger to the scene, remained on his horse somewhat in the rear of Guiche, and watched the rays of light reflected on the water, inhaling with rapture the sea breezes, and listening to the waves which noisily broke upon the shore and on the beach, tossing the spray into the air with a noise that echoed in the distance. But, exclaimed De Guiche, what is Buckingham's motive for providing such a supply of lodgings?
children.prevalue: You are quite sure of it Monsieur de Manicamp and as he put this question he looked slyly at De Guiche as though to interrogate him upon the degree of confidence to be placed in his friend s state of mind During this discussion the night had closed in and the torches pages attendants squires horses and carriages blocked up the gate and the open place the torches were reflected in the channel which the rising tide was gradually filling while on the other side of the jetty might be noticed groups of curious lookerson consisting of sailors and townspeople who seemed anxious to miss nothing of the spectacle Amidst all this hesitation of purpose Bragelonne as though a perfect stranger to the scene remained on his horse somewhat in the rear of Guiche and watched the rays of light reflected on the water inhaling with rapture the sea breezes and listening to the waves which noisily broke upon the shore and on the beach tossing the spray into the air with a noise that echoed in the distance But exclaimed De Guiche what is Buckingham s motive for providing such a supply of lodgings

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Yes, yes, said De Wardes; what reason has he?
children.prevalue: Yes yes said De Wardes what reason has he

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: A very excellent one, replied Manicamp.
children.prevalue: A very excellent one replied Manicamp

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: You know what it is, then?
children.prevalue: You know what it is then

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: I fancy I do.
children.prevalue: I fancy I do

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Tell us, then.
children.prevalue: Tell us then

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Bend your head down towards me.
children.prevalue: Bend your head down towards me

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: What! may it not be spoken except in private?
children.prevalue: What may it not be spoken except in private

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: You shall judge of that yourself.
children.prevalue: You shall judge of that yourself

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Very well. De Guiche bent down.
children.prevalue: Very well De Guiche bent down

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Love, said Manicamp.
children.prevalue: Love said Manicamp

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: I do not understand you at all.
children.prevalue: I do not understand you at all

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Say rather, you cannot understand me yet.
children.prevalue: Say rather you cannot understand me yet

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Explain yourself.
children.prevalue: Explain yourself

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Very well; it is quite certain, count, that his royal highness will be the most unfortunate of husbands.
children.prevalue: Very well it is quite certain count that his royal highness will be the most unfortunate of husbands

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: What do you mean?
children.prevalue: What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: The Duke of Buckingham
children.prevalue: The Duke of Buckingham

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: It is a name of ill omen to the princes of the house of France.
children.prevalue: It is a name of ill omen to the princes of the house of France

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: And so the duke is madly in love with Madame, so the rumor runs, and will have no one approach her but himself.
children.prevalue: And so the duke is madly in love with Madame so the rumor runs and will have no one approach her but himself

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: De Guiche colored. Thank you, thank you, said he to Manicamp, grasping his hand. Then, recovering himself, added, Whatever you do, Manicamp, be careful that this project of Buckingham's is not made known to any Frenchman here; for, if so, many a sword would be unsheathed in this country that does not fear English steel.
children.prevalue: De Guiche colored Thank you thank you said he to Manicamp grasping his hand Then recovering himself added Whatever you do Manicamp be careful that this project of Buckingham s is not made known to any Frenchman here for if so many a sword would be unsheathed in this country that does not fear English steel

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: But after all, said Manicamp, I have had no satisfactory proof given me of the love in question, and it may be no more than an idle tale.
children.prevalue: But after all said Manicamp I have had no satisfactory proof given me of the love in question and it may be no more than an idle tale

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: No, no, said De Guiche, it must be the truth; and despite his command over himself, he clenched his teeth.
children.prevalue: No no said De Guiche it must be the truth and despite his command over himself he clenched his teeth

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Well, said Manicamp, after all, what does it matter to you? What does it matter to me whether the prince is to be what the late king was? Buckingham the father for the queen, Buckingham the son for the princess.
