children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: You are suffering? asked Raoul.
children.prevalue: You are suffering asked Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Cruelly.
children.prevalue: Cruelly

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Bodily, I suppose?
children.prevalue: Bodily I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Yes; bodily.
children.prevalue: Yes bodily

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: This has indeed been a harassing day, continued the young man, his eyes fixed upon his friend.
children.prevalue: This has indeed been a harassing day continued the young man his eyes fixed upon his friend

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Yes; a night's rest will probably restore me.
children.prevalue: Yes a night s rest will probably restore me

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Shall I leave you?
children.prevalue: Shall I leave you

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: No; I wish to talk to you.
children.prevalue: No I wish to talk to you

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: You shall not speak to me, Guiche, until you have first answered my questions.
children.prevalue: You shall not speak to me Guiche until you have first answered my questions

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Proceed then.
children.prevalue: Proceed then

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: You will be frank with me?
children.prevalue: You will be frank with me

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I always am.
children.prevalue: I always am

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Can you imagine why Buckingham has been so violent?
children.prevalue: Can you imagine why Buckingham has been so violent

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I suspect.
children.prevalue: I suspect

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Because he is in love with Madame, is it not?
children.prevalue: Because he is in love with Madame is it not

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: One could almost swear to it, to observe him.
children.prevalue: One could almost swear to it to observe him

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: You are mistaken; there is nothing of the kind.
children.prevalue: You are mistaken there is nothing of the kind

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: It is you who are mistaken, Raoul; I have read his distress in his eyes, in his every gesture and action the whole day.
children.prevalue: It is you who are mistaken Raoul I have read his distress in his eyes in his every gesture and action the whole day

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: You are a poet, my dear count, and find subjects for your muse everywhere.
children.prevalue: You are a poet my dear count and find subjects for your muse everywhere

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I can perceive love clearly enough.
children.prevalue: I can perceive love clearly enough

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Where it does not exist?
children.prevalue: Where it does not exist

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Nay, where it does exist.
children.prevalue: Nay where it does exist

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Do you not think you are deceiving yourself, Guiche?
children.prevalue: Do you not think you are deceiving yourself Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I am convinced of what I say, said the count.
children.prevalue: I am convinced of what I say said the count

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Now, inform me, count, said Raoul, fixing a penetrating look upon him, what happened to render you so clearsighted.
children.prevalue: Now inform me count said Raoul fixing a penetrating look upon him what happened to render you so clearsighted

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Guiche hesitated for a moment, and then answered, Selflove, I suppose.
children.prevalue: Guiche hesitated for a moment and then answered Selflove I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Selflove is a pedantic word, Guiche.
children.prevalue: Selflove is a pedantic word Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: What do you mean?
children.prevalue: What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: I mean that, generally, you are less out of spirits than seems to be the case this evening.
children.prevalue: I mean that generally you are less out of spirits than seems to be the case this evening

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: I am fatigued.
children.prevalue: I am fatigued

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Listen to me, Guiche; we have been campaigners together; we have been on horseback for eighteen hours at a time, and our horses dying from exhaustion, or hunger, have fallen beneath us, and yet we have laughed at our mishaps. Believe me, it is not fatigue that saddens you tonight.
children.prevalue: Listen to me Guiche we have been campaigners together we have been on horseback for eighteen hours at a time and our horses dying from exhaustion or hunger have fallen beneath us and yet we have laughed at our mishaps Believe me it is not fatigue that saddens you tonight

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: It is annoyance, then.
children.prevalue: It is annoyance then

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: What annoyance?
children.prevalue: What annoyance

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: That of this evening.
children.prevalue: That of this evening

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The mad conduct of the Duke of Buckingham, do you mean?
children.prevalue: The mad conduct of the Duke of Buckingham do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Of course; is it not vexations for us, the representatives of our sovereign master, to witness the devotion of an Englishman to our future mistress, the second lady in point of rank in the kingdom?
children.prevalue: Of course is it not vexations for us the representatives of our sovereign master to witness the devotion of an Englishman to our future mistress the second lady in point of rank in the kingdom

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Yes, you are right; but I do not think any danger is to be apprehended from Buckingham.
children.prevalue: Yes you are right but I do not think any danger is to be apprehended from Buckingham

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: No; still he is intrusive. Did he not, on his arrival here, almost succeed in creating a disturbance between the English and ourselves; and, had it not been for you, for your admirable presence, for your singular decision of character, swords would have been drawn in the very streets of the town.
children.prevalue: No still he is intrusive Did he not on his arrival here almost succeed in creating a disturbance between the English and ourselves and had it not been for you for your admirable presence for your singular decision of character swords would have been drawn in the very streets of the town

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: You observe, however, that he has changed his tactics.
children.prevalue: You observe however that he has changed his tactics

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Yes, certainly; but this is the very thing that amazes me so much. You spoke to him in a low tone of voice, what did you say to him? You think he loves her; you admit that such a passion does not give way readily. He does not love her, then! De Guiche pronounced the latter with so marked an expression that Raoul raised his head. The noble character of the young man's countenance expressed a displeasure which could easily be read.
children.prevalue: Yes certainly but this is the very thing that amazes me so much You spoke to him in a low tone of voice what did you say to him You think he loves her you admit that such a passion does not give way readily He does not love her then De Guiche pronounced the latter with so marked an expression that Raoul raised his head The noble character of the young man s countenance expressed a displeasure which could easily be read

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: What I said to him, count, replied Raoul, I will repeat to you. Listen to me. I said, 'You are regarding with wistful feelings, and most injurious desire, the sister of your prince,her to whom you are not affianced, who is not, who can never be anything to you; you are outraging those who, like ourselves, have come to seek a young lady to escort her to her husband.'
children.prevalue: What I said to him count replied Raoul I will repeat to you Listen to me I said You are regarding with wistful feelings and most injurious desire the sister of your prince her to whom you are not affianced who is not who can never be anything to you you are outraging those who like ourselves have come to seek a young lady to escort her to her husband

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: You spoke to him in that manner? asked Guiche, coloring.
children.prevalue: You spoke to him in that manner asked Guiche coloring

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: In those very terms; I even added more. 'How would you regard us,' I said, 'if you were to perceive among us a man mad enough, disloyal enough, to entertain other than sentiments of the most perfect respect for a princess who is the destined wife of our master?'
children.prevalue: In those very terms I even added more How would you regard us I said if you were to perceive among us a man mad enough disloyal enough to entertain other than sentiments of the most perfect respect for a princess who is the destined wife of our master

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: These words were so applicable to De Guiche that he turned pale, and, overcome by a sudden agitation, was barely able to stretch out one hand mechanically towards Raoul, as he covered his eyes and face with the other.
children.prevalue: These words were so applicable to De Guiche that he turned pale and overcome by a sudden agitation was barely able to stretch out one hand mechanically towards Raoul as he covered his eyes and face with the other

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: But, continued Raoul, not interrupted by this movement of his friend, Heaven be praised, the French, who are pronounced to be thoughtless and indiscreet, reckless, even, are capable of bringing a calm and sound judgment to bear on matters of such high importance. I added even more, for I said, 'Learn, my lord, that we gentlemen of France devote ourselves to our sovereigns by sacrificing them our affections, as well as our fortunes and our lives; and whenever it may chance to happen that the tempter suggests one of those vile thoughts that set the heart on fire, we extinguish the flame, even if it has to be done by shedding our blood for the purpose. Thus it is that the honor of three is saved: our country's, our master's, and our own. It is thus that we act, your Grace; it is thus that every man of honor ought to act.' In this manner, my dear Guiche, continued Bragelonne, I addressed the Duke of Buckingham; and he admitted I was right, and resigned himself unresistingly to my arguments.
children.prevalue: But continued Raoul not interrupted by this movement of his friend Heaven be praised the French who are pronounced to be thoughtless and indiscreet reckless even are capable of bringing a calm and sound judgment to bear on matters of such high importance I added even more for I said Learn my lord that we gentlemen of France devote ourselves to our sovereigns by sacrificing them our affections as well as our fortunes and our lives and whenever it may chance to happen that the tempter suggests one of those vile thoughts that set the heart on fire we extinguish the flame even if it has to be done by shedding our blood for the purpose Thus it is that the honor of three is saved our country s our master s and our own It is thus that we act your Grace it is thus that every man of honor ought to act In this manner my dear Guiche continued Bragelonne I addressed the Duke of Buckingham and he admitted I was right and resigned himself unresistingly to my arguments

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: De Guiche, who had hitherto sat leaning forward while Raoul was speaking, drew himself up, his eyes glancing proudly; he seized Raoul's hand, his face, which had been as cold as ice, seemed on fire. And you spoke magnificently, he said, in a halfchoked voice; you are indeed a friend, Raoul. But now, I entreat you, leave me to myself.
children.prevalue: De Guiche who had hitherto sat leaning forward while Raoul was speaking drew himself up his eyes glancing proudly he seized Raoul s hand his face which had been as cold as ice seemed on fire And you spoke magnificently he said in a halfchoked voice you are indeed a friend Raoul But now I entreat you leave me to myself

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Do you wish it?
children.prevalue: Do you wish it

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Yes; I need repose. Many things have agitated me today, both in mind and body; when you return tomorrow I shall no longer be the same man.
children.prevalue: Yes I need repose Many things have agitated me today both in mind and body when you return tomorrow I shall no longer be the same man

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: I leave you, then, said Raoul, as he withdrew. The count advanced a step towards his friend, and pressed him warmly in his arms. But in this friendly pressure Raoul could detect the nervous agitation of a great internal conflict.
children.prevalue: I leave you then said Raoul as he withdrew The count advanced a step towards his friend and pressed him warmly in his arms But in this friendly pressure Raoul could detect the nervous agitation of a great internal conflict

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: The night was clear, starlit, and splendid; the tempest had passed away, and the sweet influences of the evening had restored life, peace and security everywhere. A few fleecy clouds were floating in the heavens, and indicated from their appearance a continuance of beautiful weather, tempered by a gentle breeze from the east. Upon the large square in front of the hotel, the shadows of the tents, intersected by the golden moonbeams, formed as it were a huge mosaic of jet and yellow flagstones. Soon, however, the entire town was wrapped in slumber; a feeble light still glimmered in Madame's apartment, which looked out upon the square, and the soft rays from the expiring lamp seemed to be the image of the calm sleep of a young girl, hardly yet sensible of life's anxieties, and in whom the flame of existence sinks placidly as sleep steals over the body.
children.prevalue: The night was clear starlit and splendid the tempest had passed away and the sweet influences of the evening had restored life peace and security everywhere A few fleecy clouds were floating in the heavens and indicated from their appearance a continuance of beautiful weather tempered by a gentle breeze from the east Upon the large square in front of the hotel the shadows of the tents intersected by the golden moonbeams formed as it were a huge mosaic of jet and yellow flagstones Soon however the entire town was wrapped in slumber a feeble light still glimmered in Madame s apartment which looked out upon the square and the soft rays from the expiring lamp seemed to be the image of the calm sleep of a young girl hardly yet sensible of life s anxieties and in whom the flame of existence sinks placidly as sleep steals over the body

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Bragelonne quitted the tent with the slow and measured step of a man curious to observe, but anxious not to be seen. Sheltered behind the thick curtains of his own tent, embracing with a glance the whole square, he noticed that, after a few moments' pause, the curtains of De Guiche's tent were agitated, and then drawn partially aside. Behind them he could perceive the shadow of De Guiche, his eyes, glittering in the obscurity, fastened ardently upon the princess's sitting apartment, which was partially lighted by the lamp in the inner room. The soft light which illumined the windows was the count's star. The fervent aspirations of his nature could be read in his eyes. Raoul, concealed in the shadow, divined the many passionate thoughts that established, between the tent of the young ambassador and the balcony of the princess, a mysterious and magical bond of sympathya bond created by thoughts imprinted with so much strength and persistence of will, that they must have caused happy and loving dreams to alight upon the perfumed couch, which the count, with the eyes of his soul, devoured so eagerly.
children.prevalue: Bragelonne quitted the tent with the slow and measured step of a man curious to observe but anxious not to be seen Sheltered behind the thick curtains of his own tent embracing with a glance the whole square he noticed that after a few moments pause the curtains of De Guiche s tent were agitated and then drawn partially aside Behind them he could perceive the shadow of De Guiche his eyes glittering in the obscurity fastened ardently upon the princess s sitting apartment which was partially lighted by the lamp in the inner room The soft light which illumined the windows was the count s star The fervent aspirations of his nature could be read in his eyes Raoul concealed in the shadow divined the many passionate thoughts that established between the tent of the young ambassador and the balcony of the princess a mysterious and magical bond of sympathya bond created by thoughts imprinted with so much strength and persistence of will that they must have caused happy and loving dreams to alight upon the perfumed couch which the count with the eyes of his soul devoured so eagerly

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: But De Guiche and Raoul were not the only watchers. The window of one of the houses looking on the square was opened too, the casement of the house where Buckingham resided. By the aid of the rays of light which issued from this latter, the profile of the duke could be distinctly seen, as he indolently reclined upon the carved balcony with its velvet hangings; he also was breathing in the direction of the princess's apartment his prayers and the wild visions of his love.
children.prevalue: But De Guiche and Raoul were not the only watchers The window of one of the houses looking on the square was opened too the casement of the house where Buckingham resided By the aid of the rays of light which issued from this latter the profile of the duke could be distinctly seen as he indolently reclined upon the carved balcony with its velvet hangings he also was breathing in the direction of the princess s apartment his prayers and the wild visions of his love

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Raoul could not resist smiling, as thinking of Madame, he said to himself, Hers is, indeed, a heart well besieged; and then added, compassionately, as he thought of Monsieur, and he is a husband well threatened too; it is a good thing for him that he is a prince of such high rank, that he has an army to safeguard for him that which is his own. Bragelonne watched for some time the conduct of the two lovers, listened to the loud and uncivil slumbers of Manicamp, who snored as imperiously as though he was wearing his blue and gold, instead of his violet suit.
children.prevalue: Raoul could not resist smiling as thinking of Madame he said to himself Hers is indeed a heart well besieged and then added compassionately as he thought of Monsieur and he is a husband well threatened too it is a good thing for him that he is a prince of such high rank that he has an army to safeguard for him that which is his own Bragelonne watched for some time the conduct of the two lovers listened to the loud and uncivil slumbers of Manicamp who snored as imperiously as though he was wearing his blue and gold instead of his violet suit

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Then he turned towards the night breeze which bore towards him, he seemed to think, the distant song of the nightingale; and, after having laid in a due provision of melancholy, another nocturnal malady, he retired to rest thinking, with regard to his own love affair, that perhaps four or even a larger number of eyes, quite as ardent as those of De Guiche and Buckingham, were coveting his own idol in the chateau at Blois. And Mademoiselle de Montalais is by no means a very conscientious garrison, said he to himself, sighing aloud.
children.prevalue: Then he turned towards the night breeze which bore towards him he seemed to think the distant song of the nightingale and after having laid in a due provision of melancholy another nocturnal malady he retired to rest thinking with regard to his own love affair that perhaps four or even a larger number of eyes quite as ardent as those of De Guiche and Buckingham were coveting his own idol in the chateau at Blois And Mademoiselle de Montalais is by no means a very conscientious garrison said he to himself sighing aloud

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The next day the fetes took place, accompanied by all the pomp and animation that the resources of the town and the cheerful disposition of men's minds could supply. During the last few hours spent in Le Havre, every preparation for the departure had been made. After Madame had taken leave of the English fleet, and, once again, had saluted the country in saluting its flags, she entered her carriage, surrounded by a brilliant escort. De Guiche had hoped that the Duke of Buckingham would accompany the admiral to England; but Buckingham succeeded in demonstrating to the queen that there would be great impropriety in allowing Madame to proceed to Paris, almost unprotected. As soon as it had been settled that Buckingham was to accompany Madame, the young duke selected a corps of gentlemen and officers to form part of his own suite, so that it was almost an army that now set out towards Paris, scattering gold, and exciting the liveliest demonstrations as they passed through the different towns and villages on the route. The weather was very fine. France is a beautiful country, especially along the route by which the procession passed. Spring cast its flowers and its perfumed foliage on their path. Normandy, with its vast variety of vegetation, its blue skies and silver rivers, displayed itself in all the loveliness of a paradise to the new sister of the king. Fetes and brilliant displays received them everywhere along the line of march. De Guiche and Buckingham forgot everything; De Guiche in his anxiety to prevent any fresh attempts on the part of the duke, and Buckingham, in his desire to awaken in the heart of the princess a softer remembrance of the country to which the recollection of many happy days belonged. But, alas! the poor duke could perceive that the image of that country so cherished by himself became, from day to day, more and more effaced in Madame's mind, in exact proportion as her affection for France became more deeply engraved on her heart. In fact, it was not difficult to perceive that his most devoted attention awakened no acknowledgement, and that the grace with which he rode one of his most fiery horses was thrown away, for it was only casually and by the merest accident that the princess's eyes were turned towards him. In vain did he try, in order to fix upon himself one of those looks, which were thrown carelessly around, or bestowed elsewhere, to produce in the animal he rode its greatest display of strength, speed, temper and address; in vain did he, by exciting his horse almost to madness, spur him, at the risk of dashing himself in pieces against the trees, or of rolling in the ditches, over the gates and barriers which they passed, or down the steep declivities of the hills. Madame, whose attention had been aroused by the noise, turned her head for a moment to observe the cause of it, and then, slightly smiling, again entered into conversation with her faithful guardians, Raoul and De Guiche, who were quietly riding at her carriage doors. Buckingham felt himself a prey to all the tortures of jealousy; an unknown, unheard of anguish glided through his veins, and laid siege to his heart; and then, as if to show that he knew the folly of his conduct, and that he wished to correct, by the humblest submission, his flights of absurdity, he mastered his horse, and compelled him, reeking with sweat and flecked with foam, to champ his bit close beside the carriage, amidst the crowd of courtiers. Occasionally he obtained a word from Madame as a recompense, and yet her speech seemed almost a reproach.

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: That is well, my lord, she said, now you are reasonable.
children.prevalue: That is well my lord she said now you are reasonable

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Or from Raoul, Your Grace is killing your horse.
children.prevalue: Or from Raoul Your Grace is killing your horse

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Buckingham listened patiently to Raoul's remarks, for he instinctively felt, without having had any proof that such was the case, that Raoul checked the display of De Guiche's feelings, and that, had it not been for Raoul, some mad act or proceeding, either of the count, or of Buckingham himself, would have brought about an open rupture, or a disturbanceperhaps even exile itself. From the moment of that excited conversation the two young men had held in front of the tents at Le Havre, when Raoul made the duke perceive the impropriety of his conduct, Buckingham felt himself attracted towards Raoul almost in spite of himself. He often entered into conversation with him, and it was nearly always to talk to him either of his father or of D'Artagnan, their mutual friend, in whose praise Buckingham was nearly as enthusiastic as Raoul. Raoul endeavored, as much as possible, to make the conversation turn upon this subject in De Wardes's presence, who had, during the whole journey, been exceedingly annoyed at the superior position taken by Bragelonne, and especially by his influence over De Guiche. De Wardes had that keen and merciless penetration most evil natures possess; he had immediately remarked De Guiche's melancholy, and divined the nature of his regard for the princess. Instead, however, of treating the subject with the same reserve which Raoul practiced; instead of regarding with that respect, which was their due, the obligations and duties of society, De Wardes resolutely attacked in the count the eversounding chord of juvenile audacity and pride. It happened one evening, during a halt at Mantes, that while De Guiche and De Wardes were leaning against a barrier, engaged in conversation, Buckingham and Raoul were also talking together as they walked up and down. Manicamp was engaged in devoted attendance on the princess, who already treated him without reserve, on account of his versatile fancy, his frank courtesy of manner, and conciliatory disposition.
children.prevalue: Buckingham listened patiently to Raoul s remarks for he instinctively felt without having had any proof that such was the case that Raoul checked the display of De Guiche s feelings and that had it not been for Raoul some mad act or proceeding either of the count or of Buckingham himself would have brought about an open rupture or a disturbanceperhaps even exile itself From the moment of that excited conversation the two young men had held in front of the tents at Le Havre when Raoul made the duke perceive the impropriety of his conduct Buckingham felt himself attracted towards Raoul almost in spite of himself He often entered into conversation with him and it was nearly always to talk to him either of his father or of D Artagnan their mutual friend in whose praise Buckingham was nearly as enthusiastic as Raoul Raoul endeavored as much as possible to make the conversation turn upon this subject in De Wardes s presence who had during the whole journey been exceedingly annoyed at the superior position taken by Bragelonne and especially by his influence over De Guiche De Wardes had that keen and merciless penetration most evil natures possess he had immediately remarked De Guiche s melancholy and divined the nature of his regard for the princess Instead however of treating the subject with the same reserve which Raoul practiced instead of regarding with that respect which was their due the obligations and duties of society De Wardes resolutely attacked in the count the eversounding chord of juvenile audacity and pride It happened one evening during a halt at Mantes that while De Guiche and De Wardes were leaning against a barrier engaged in conversation Buckingham and Raoul were also talking together as they walked up and down Manicamp was engaged in devoted attendance on the princess who already treated him without reserve on account of his versatile fancy his frank courtesy of manner and conciliatory disposition

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Confess, said De Wardes, that you are really ill, and that your pedagogue of a friend has not succeeded in curing you.
children.prevalue: Confess said De Wardes that you are really ill and that your pedagogue of a friend has not succeeded in curing you

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: I do not understand you, said the count.
children.prevalue: I do not understand you said the count

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: And yet it is easy enough; you are dying of love.
children.prevalue: And yet it is easy enough you are dying of love

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: You are mad, De Wardes.
children.prevalue: You are mad De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Madness it would be, I admit, if Madame were really indifferent to your martyrdom; but she takes so much notice of it, observes it to such an extent, that she compromises herself, and I tremble lest, on our arrival at Paris, M. de Bragelonne may not denounce both of you.
children.prevalue: Madness it would be I admit if Madame were really indifferent to your martyrdom but she takes so much notice of it observes it to such an extent that she compromises herself and I tremble lest on our arrival at Paris M de Bragelonne may not denounce both of you

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: For shame, De Wardes, again attacking De Bragelonne.
children.prevalue: For shame De Wardes again attacking De Bragelonne

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Come, come, a truce to child's play, replied the count's evil genius, in an undertone; you know as well as I do what I mean. Besides, you must have observed how the princess's glance softens as she looks at you;you can tell, by the very inflection of her voice, what pleasure she takes in listening to you, and can feel how thoroughly she appreciates the verses you recite to her. You cannot deny, too, that every morning she tells you how indifferently she slept the previous night.
children.prevalue: Come come a truce to child s play replied the count s evil genius in an undertone you know as well as I do what I mean Besides you must have observed how the princess s glance softens as she looks at you you can tell by the very inflection of her voice what pleasure she takes in listening to you and can feel how thoroughly she appreciates the verses you recite to her You cannot deny too that every morning she tells you how indifferently she slept the previous night

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: True, De Wardes, quite true; but what good is there in your telling me all that?
children.prevalue: True De Wardes quite true but what good is there in your telling me all that

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Is it not important to know the exact position of affairs?
children.prevalue: Is it not important to know the exact position of affairs

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: No, no; not when I am a witness of things that are enough to drive one mad.
children.prevalue: No no not when I am a witness of things that are enough to drive one mad

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Stay, stay, said De Wardes; look, she calls you,do you understand? Profit by the occasion, while your pedagogue is absent.
children.prevalue: Stay stay said De Wardes look she calls you do you understand Profit by the occasion while your pedagogue is absent

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: De Guiche could not resist; an invincible attraction drew him towards the princess. De Wardes smiled as he saw him withdraw.
children.prevalue: De Guiche could not resist an invincible attraction drew him towards the princess De Wardes smiled as he saw him withdraw

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: You are mistaken, monsieur, said Raoul, suddenly stepping across the barrier against which the previous moment the two friends had been leaning. The pedagogue is here, and has overheard you.
children.prevalue: You are mistaken monsieur said Raoul suddenly stepping across the barrier against which the previous moment the two friends had been leaning The pedagogue is here and has overheard you

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: De Wardes, at the sound of Raoul's voice, which he recognized without having occasion to look at him, half drew his sword.
children.prevalue: De Wardes at the sound of Raoul s voice which he recognized without having occasion to look at him half drew his sword

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Put up your sword, said Raoul; you know perfectly well that, until our journey is at an end, every demonstration of that nature is useless. Why do you distill into the heart of the man you term your friend all the bitterness that infects your own? As regards myself, you wish to arouse a feeling of deep dislike against a man of honormy father's friend and my own; and as for the count you wish him to love one who is destined for your master. Really, monsieur, I should regard you as a coward, and a traitor too, if I did not, with greater justice, regard you as a madman.
children.prevalue: Put up your sword said Raoul you know perfectly well that until our journey is at an end every demonstration of that nature is useless Why do you distill into the heart of the man you term your friend all the bitterness that infects your own As regards myself you wish to arouse a feeling of deep dislike against a man of honormy father s friend and my own and as for the count you wish him to love one who is destined for your master Really monsieur I should regard you as a coward and a traitor too if I did not with greater justice regard you as a madman

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Monsieur, exclaimed De Wardes, exasperated, I was deceived, I find, in terming you a pedagogue. The tone you assume, and the style which is peculiarly your own, is that of a Jesuit, and not of a gentleman. Discontinue, I beg, whenever I am present, this style I complain of, and the tone also. I hate M. d'Artagnan, because he was guilty of a cowardly act towards my father.
children.prevalue: Monsieur exclaimed De Wardes exasperated I was deceived I find in terming you a pedagogue The tone you assume and the style which is peculiarly your own is that of a Jesuit and not of a gentleman Discontinue I beg whenever I am present this style I complain of and the tone also I hate M d Artagnan because he was guilty of a cowardly act towards my father

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: You lie, monsieur, said Raoul, coolly.
children.prevalue: You lie monsieur said Raoul coolly

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: You give me the lie, monsieur? exclaimed De Wardes.
children.prevalue: You give me the lie monsieur exclaimed De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Why not, if what you assert is untrue?
children.prevalue: Why not if what you assert is untrue

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: You give me the lie, and will not draw your sword?
children.prevalue: You give me the lie and will not draw your sword

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I have resolved, monsieur, not to kill you until Madame shall have been delivered safely into her husband's hands.
children.prevalue: I have resolved monsieur not to kill you until Madame shall have been delivered safely into her husband s hands

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Kill me! Believe me, monsieur, your schoolmaster's rod does not kill so easily.
children.prevalue: Kill me Believe me monsieur your schoolmaster s rod does not kill so easily

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: No, replied Raoul, sternly, but M. d'Artagnan's sword kills; and, not only do I possess his sword, but he has himself taught me how to use it; and with that sword, when a befitting time arrives, I will avenge his namea name you have dishonored.
children.prevalue: No replied Raoul sternly but M d Artagnan s sword kills and not only do I possess his sword but he has himself taught me how to use it and with that sword when a befitting time arrives I will avenge his namea name you have dishonored

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Take care, monsieur, exclaimed De Wardes; if you do not immediately give me satisfaction, I will avail myself of every means to revenge myself.
children.prevalue: Take care monsieur exclaimed De Wardes if you do not immediately give me satisfaction I will avail myself of every means to revenge myself

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Indeed, monsieur, said Buckingham, suddenly, appearing upon the scene of action, that is a threat which savors of assassination, and therefore, ill becomes a gentleman.
children.prevalue: Indeed monsieur said Buckingham suddenly appearing upon the scene of action that is a threat which savors of assassination and therefore ill becomes a gentleman

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: What did you say, my lord? said De Wardes, turning round towards him.
children.prevalue: What did you say my lord said De Wardes turning round towards him

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: I said, monsieur, that the words you have just spoken are displeasing to my English ears.
children.prevalue: I said monsieur that the words you have just spoken are displeasing to my English ears

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Very well, monsieur, if what you say is true, exclaimed De Wardes, thoroughly incensed, I at least find in you one who will not escape me. Understand my words as you like.
children.prevalue: Very well monsieur if what you say is true exclaimed De Wardes thoroughly incensed I at least find in you one who will not escape me Understand my words as you like

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I take them in the manner they cannot but be understood, replied Buckingham, with that haughty tone which characterized him, and which, even in ordinary conversation, gave a tone of defiance to everything he said; M. de Bragelonne is my friend, you insult M. de Bragelonne, and you shall give me satisfaction for that insult.
children.prevalue: I take them in the manner they cannot but be understood replied Buckingham with that haughty tone which characterized him and which even in ordinary conversation gave a tone of defiance to everything he said M de Bragelonne is my friend you insult M de Bragelonne and you shall give me satisfaction for that insult

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: De Wardes cast a look upon De Bragelonne, who, faithful to the character he had assumed, remained calm and unmoved, even after the duke's defiance.
children.prevalue: De Wardes cast a look upon De Bragelonne who faithful to the character he had assumed remained calm and unmoved even after the duke s defiance

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: It would seem that I did not insult M. de Bragelonne, since M. de Bragelonne, who carries a sword by his side, does not consider himself insulted.
children.prevalue: It would seem that I did not insult M de Bragelonne since M de Bragelonne who carries a sword by his side does not consider himself insulted

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: At all events you insult someone.
children.prevalue: At all events you insult someone

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Yes, I insulted M. d'Artagnan, resumed De Wardes, who had observed that this was the only means of stinging Raoul, so as to awaken his anger.
children.prevalue: Yes I insulted M d Artagnan resumed De Wardes who had observed that this was the only means of stinging Raoul so as to awaken his anger

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: That, then, said Buckingham, is another matter.
children.prevalue: That then said Buckingham is another matter

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Precisely so, said De Wardes; it is the province of M. d'Artagnan's friends to defend him.
children.prevalue: Precisely so said De Wardes it is the province of M d Artagnan s friends to defend him

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I am entirely of your opinion, replied the duke, who had regained all his indifference of manner; if M. de Bragelonne were offended, I could not reasonably be expected to espouse his quarrel, since he is himself here; but when you say that it is a quarrel of M. d'Artagnan
children.prevalue: I am entirely of your opinion replied the duke who had regained all his indifference of manner if M de Bragelonne were offended I could not reasonably be expected to espouse his quarrel since he is himself here but when you say that it is a quarrel of M d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: You will of course leave me to deal with the matter, said De Wardes.
children.prevalue: You will of course leave me to deal with the matter said De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Nay, on the contrary, for I draw my sword, said Buckingham, unsheathing it as he spoke; for if M. d'Artagnan injured your father, he rendered, or at least did all that he could to render, a great service to mine.
children.prevalue: Nay on the contrary for I draw my sword said Buckingham unsheathing it as he spoke for if M d Artagnan injured your father he rendered or at least did all that he could to render a great service to mine

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: De Wardes was thunderstruck.
children.prevalue: De Wardes was thunderstruck

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: M. d'Artagnan, continued Buckingham, is the bravest gentleman I know. I shall be delighted, as I owe him many personal obligations, to settle them with you, by crossing my sword with yours. At the same moment Buckingham drew his sword from its scabbard, saluted Raoul, and put himself on guard.
children.prevalue: M d Artagnan continued Buckingham is the bravest gentleman I know I shall be delighted as I owe him many personal obligations to settle them with you by crossing my sword with yours At the same moment Buckingham drew his sword from its scabbard saluted Raoul and put himself on guard

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: De Wardes advanced a step to meet him.
children.prevalue: De Wardes advanced a step to meet him

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Stay, gentlemen, said Raoul, advancing towards them, and placing his own drawn sword between the combatants, the affair is hardly worth the trouble of blood being shed almost in the presence of the princess. M. de Wardes speaks ill of M. d'Artagnan, with whom he is not even acquainted.
children.prevalue: Stay gentlemen said Raoul advancing towards them and placing his own drawn sword between the combatants the affair is hardly worth the trouble of blood being shed almost in the presence of the princess M de Wardes speaks ill of M d Artagnan with whom he is not even acquainted

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: What, monsieur, said De Wardes, setting his teeth hard together, and resting the point of his sword on the toe of his boot, do you assert that I do not know M. d'Artagnan?
children.prevalue: What monsieur said De Wardes setting his teeth hard together and resting the point of his sword on the toe of his boot do you assert that I do not know M d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Certainly not; you do not know him, replied Raoul, coldly, and you are even not aware where he is to be found.
children.prevalue: Certainly not you do not know him replied Raoul coldly and you are even not aware where he is to be found

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Not know where he is?
children.prevalue: Not know where he is

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Such must be the case, since you fix your quarrel with him upon strangers, instead of seeking M. d'Artagnan where he is to be found. De Wardes turned pale. Well, monsieur, continued Raoul, I will tell you where M. d'Artagnan is: he is now in Paris; when on duty he is to be met with at the Louvre,when not on duty, in the Rue des Lombards. M. d'Artagnan can easily be discovered at either of those two places. Having, therefore, as you assert, so many causes of complaint against him, show your courage in seeking him out, and afford him an opportunity of giving you that satisfaction you seem to ask of every one but of himself. De Wardes passed his hand across his forehead, which was covered with perspiration. For shame, M. de Wardes! so quarrelsome a disposition is hardly becoming after the publication of the edicts against duels. Pray think of that; the king will be incensed at our disobedience, particularly at such a time,and his majesty will be in the right.
children.prevalue: Such must be the case since you fix your quarrel with him upon strangers instead of seeking M d Artagnan where he is to be found De Wardes turned pale Well monsieur continued Raoul I will tell you where M d Artagnan is he is now in Paris when on duty he is to be met with at the Louvre when not on duty in the Rue des Lombards M d Artagnan can easily be discovered at either of those two places Having therefore as you assert so many causes of complaint against him show your courage in seeking him out and afford him an opportunity of giving you that satisfaction you seem to ask of every one but of himself De Wardes passed his hand across his forehead which was covered with perspiration For shame M de Wardes so quarrelsome a disposition is hardly becoming after the publication of the edicts against duels Pray think of that the king will be incensed at our disobedience particularly at such a time and his majesty will be in the right

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Excuses, murmured De Wardes; mere pretexts.
children.prevalue: Excuses murmured De Wardes mere pretexts

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Really, M. De Wardes, resumed Raoul, such remarks are the idlest bluster. You know very well that the Duke of Buckingham is a man of undoubted courage, who has already fought ten duels, and will probably fight eleven. His name alone is significant enough. As far as I am concerned, you are well aware that I can fight also. I fought at Lens, at Bleneau, at the Dunes in front of the artillery, a hundred paces in front of the line, while youI say this parentheticallywere a hundred paces behind it. True it is, that on that occasion there was far too great a concourse of persons present for your courage to be observed, and on that account perhaps you did not reveal it; while here, it would be a display, and would excite remarkyou wish that others should talk about you, in what manner you do not care. Do not depend upon me, M. de Wardes to assist you in your designs, for I shall certainly not afford you that pleasure.
children.prevalue: Really M De Wardes resumed Raoul such remarks are the idlest bluster You know very well that the Duke of Buckingham is a man of undoubted courage who has already fought ten duels and will probably fight eleven His name alone is significant enough As far as I am concerned you are well aware that I can fight also I fought at Lens at Bleneau at the Dunes in front of the artillery a hundred paces in front of the line while youI say this parentheticallywere a hundred paces behind it True it is that on that occasion there was far too great a concourse of persons present for your courage to be observed and on that account perhaps you did not reveal it while here it would be a display and would excite remarkyou wish that others should talk about you in what manner you do not care Do not depend upon me M de Wardes to assist you in your designs for I shall certainly not afford you that pleasure

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Sensibly observed, said Buckingham, putting up his sword, and I ask your forgiveness, M. de Bragelonne, for having allowed myself to yield to a first impulse.
children.prevalue: Sensibly observed said Buckingham putting up his sword and I ask your forgiveness M de Bragelonne for having allowed myself to yield to a first impulse

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: De Wardes, however, on the contrary, perfectly furious, bounded forward and raised his sword, threateningly, against Raoul, who had scarcely enough time to put himself in a posture of defense.
children.prevalue: De Wardes however on the contrary perfectly furious bounded forward and raised his sword threateningly against Raoul who had scarcely enough time to put himself in a posture of defense

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Take care, monsieur, said Bragelonne, tranquilly, or you will put out one of my eyes.
children.prevalue: Take care monsieur said Bragelonne tranquilly or you will put out one of my eyes

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: You will not fight, then? said De Wardes.
children.prevalue: You will not fight then said De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Not at this moment; but this I promise to do; immediately on our arrival at Paris I will conduct you to M. d'Artagnan, to whom you shall detail all the causes of complaint you have against him. M d'Artagnan will solicit the king's permission to measure swords with you. The king will yield his consent, and when you shall have received the swordthrust in due course, you will consider, in a calmer frame of mind, the precepts of the Gospel, which enjoin forgetfulness of injuries.
children.prevalue: Not at this moment but this I promise to do immediately on our arrival at Paris I will conduct you to M d Artagnan to whom you shall detail all the causes of complaint you have against him M d Artagnan will solicit the king s permission to measure swords with you The king will yield his consent and when you shall have received the swordthrust in due course you will consider in a calmer frame of mind the precepts of the Gospel which enjoin forgetfulness of injuries

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Ah! exclaimed De Wardes, furious at this imperturbable coolness, one can clearly see you are half a bastard, M. de Bragelonne.
children.prevalue: Ah exclaimed De Wardes furious at this imperturbable coolness one can clearly see you are half a bastard M de Bragelonne

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Raoul became as pale as death; his eyes flashed lightning, causing De Wardes involuntarily to fall back. Buckingham, also, who had perceived their expression, threw himself between the two adversaries, whom he had expected to see precipitate themselves on each other. De Wardes had reserved this injury for the last; he clasped his sword firmly in his hand, and awaited the encounter. You are right, monsieur, said Raoul, mastering his emotion, I am only acquainted with my father's name; but I know too well that the Comte de la Fere is too upright and honorable a man to allow me to fear for a single moment that there is, as you insinuate, any stain upon my birth. My ignorance, therefore, of my mother's name is a misfortune for me, and not a reproach. You are deficient in loyalty of conduct; you are wanting in courtesy, in reproaching me with misfortune. It matters little, however, the insult has been given, and I consider myself insulted accordingly. It is quite understood, then, that after you shall have received satisfaction from M. d'Artagnan, you will settle your quarrel with me.
children.prevalue: Raoul became as pale as death his eyes flashed lightning causing De Wardes involuntarily to fall back Buckingham also who had perceived their expression threw himself between the two adversaries whom he had expected to see precipitate themselves on each other De Wardes had reserved this injury for the last he clasped his sword firmly in his hand and awaited the encounter You are right monsieur said Raoul mastering his emotion I am only acquainted with my father s name but I know too well that the Comte de la Fere is too upright and honorable a man to allow me to fear for a single moment that there is as you insinuate any stain upon my birth My ignorance therefore of my mother s name is a misfortune for me and not a reproach You are deficient in loyalty of conduct you are wanting in courtesy in reproaching me with misfortune It matters little however the insult has been given and I consider myself insulted accordingly It is quite understood then that after you shall have received satisfaction from M d Artagnan you will settle your quarrel with me

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: I admire your prudence, monsieur, replied De Wardes with a bitter smile; a little while ago you promised me a swordthrust from M. d'Artagnan, and now, after I shall have received his, you offer me one from yourself.
children.prevalue: I admire your prudence monsieur replied De Wardes with a bitter smile a little while ago you promised me a swordthrust from M d Artagnan and now after I shall have received his you offer me one from yourself

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Do not disturb yourself, replied Raoul, with concentrated anger; in all affairs of that nature, M. d'Artagnan is exceedingly skillful, and I will beg him as a favor to treat you as he did your father; in other words, to spare your life at least, so as to leave me the pleasure, after your recovery, of killing you outright; for you have the heart of a viper, M. de Wardes, and in very truth, too many precautions cannot be taken against you.
children.prevalue: Do not disturb yourself replied Raoul with concentrated anger in all affairs of that nature M d Artagnan is exceedingly skillful and I will beg him as a favor to treat you as he did your father in other words to spare your life at least so as to leave me the pleasure after your recovery of killing you outright for you have the heart of a viper M de Wardes and in very truth too many precautions cannot be taken against you

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I shall take my precautions against you, said De Wardes, be assured of it.
children.prevalue: I shall take my precautions against you said De Wardes be assured of it

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Allow me, monsieur, said Buckingham, to translate your remark by a piece of advice I am about to give M. de Bragelonne; M. de Bragelonne, wear a cuirass.
children.prevalue: Allow me monsieur said Buckingham to translate your remark by a piece of advice I am about to give M de Bragelonne M de Bragelonne wear a cuirass

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: De Wardes clenched his hands. Ah! said he, you two gentlemen intend to wait until you have taken that precaution before you measure your swords against mine.
children.prevalue: De Wardes clenched his hands Ah said he you two gentlemen intend to wait until you have taken that precaution before you measure your swords against mine

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Very well, monsieur, said Raoul, since you positively will have it so, let us settle the affair now. And, drawing his sword, he advanced towards De Wardes.
children.prevalue: Very well monsieur said Raoul since you positively will have it so let us settle the affair now And drawing his sword he advanced towards De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: What are you going to do? said Buckingham.
children.prevalue: What are you going to do said Buckingham

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Be easy, said Raoul, it will not be very long.
children.prevalue: Be easy said Raoul it will not be very long

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: De Wardes placed himself on his guard; their swords crossed. De Wardes flew upon Raoul with such impetuosity, that at the first clashing of the steel blades Buckingham clearly saw that Raoul was only trifling with his adversary. Buckingham stepped aside, and watched the combat. Raoul was as calm as if he were handling a foil instead of a sword; having retreated a step, he parried three or four fierce thrusts which De Wardes made at him, caught the sword of the latter with within his own, and sent it flying twenty paces the other side of the barrier. Then as De Wardes stood disarmed and astounded at his defeat, Raoul sheathed his sword, seized him by the collar and the waist band, and hurled his adversary to the other end of the barrier, trembling, and mad with rage.
children.prevalue: De Wardes placed himself on his guard their swords crossed De Wardes flew upon Raoul with such impetuosity that at the first clashing of the steel blades Buckingham clearly saw that Raoul was only trifling with his adversary Buckingham stepped aside and watched the combat Raoul was as calm as if he were handling a foil instead of a sword having retreated a step he parried three or four fierce thrusts which De Wardes made at him caught the sword of the latter with within his own and sent it flying twenty paces the other side of the barrier Then as De Wardes stood disarmed and astounded at his defeat Raoul sheathed his sword seized him by the collar and the waist band and hurled his adversary to the other end of the barrier trembling and mad with rage

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: We shall meet again, murmured De Wardes, rising from the ground and picking up his sword.
children.prevalue: We shall meet again murmured De Wardes rising from the ground and picking up his sword

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: I have done nothing for the last hour, said Raoul, rising from the ground, but say the same thing. Then, turning towards the duke, he said, I entreat you to be silent about this affair; I am ashamed to have gone so far, but my anger carried me away, and I ask your forgiveness for it;forget it, too.
children.prevalue: I have done nothing for the last hour said Raoul rising from the ground but say the same thing Then turning towards the duke he said I entreat you to be silent about this affair I am ashamed to have gone so far but my anger carried me away and I ask your forgiveness for it forget it too

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Dear viscount, said the duke, pressing with his own the vigorous and valiant hand of his companion, allow me, on the contrary, to remember it, and to look after your safety; that man is dangerous,he will kill you.
children.prevalue: Dear viscount said the duke pressing with his own the vigorous and valiant hand of his companion allow me on the contrary to remember it and to look after your safety that man is dangerous he will kill you

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: My father, replied Raoul, lived for twenty years under the menace of a much more formidable enemy, and he still lives.
children.prevalue: My father replied Raoul lived for twenty years under the menace of a much more formidable enemy and he still lives

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Your father had good friends, viscount.
children.prevalue: Your father had good friends viscount

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Yes, sighed Raoul, such friends, indeed, that none are now left like them.
children.prevalue: Yes sighed Raoul such friends indeed that none are now left like them

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Do not say that, I beg, at the very moment I offer you my friendship; and Buckingham opened his arms to embrace Raoul, who delightedly received the proffered alliance. In my family, added Buckingham, you are aware, M. de Bragelonne, we die to save our friends.
children.prevalue: Do not say that I beg at the very moment I offer you my friendship and Buckingham opened his arms to embrace Raoul who delightedly received the proffered alliance In my family added Buckingham you are aware M de Bragelonne we die to save our friends

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: I know it well, duke, replied Raoul.
children.prevalue: I know it well duke replied Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Nothing further interrupted the journey. Under a pretext that was little remarked, M. de Wardes went forward in advance of the others. He took Manicamp with him, for his equable and dreamy disposition acted as a counterpoise to his own. It is a subject of remark, that quarrelsome and restless characters invariably seek the companionship of gentle, timorous dispositions, as if the former sought, in the contrast, a repose for their own illhumor, and the latter a protection for their weakness. Buckingham and Bragelonne, admitting De Guiche into their friendship, in concert with him, sang the praises of the princess during the whole of the journey. Bragelonne, had, however, insisted that their three voices should be in concert, instead of singing in solo parts, as De Guiche and his rival seemed to have acquired a dangerous habit of doing. This style of harmony pleased the queenmother exceedingly, but it was not perhaps so agreeable to the young princess, who was an incarnation of coquetry, and who, without any fear as far as her own voice was concerned, sought opportunities of so perilously distinguishing herself. She possessed one of those fearless and incautious dispositions that find gratification in an excess of sensitiveness of feeling, and for whom, also, danger has a certain fascination. And so her glances, her smiles, her toilette, an inexhaustible armory of weapons of offense, were showered on the three young men with overwhelming force; and, from her wellstored arsenal issued glances, kindly recognitions, and a thousand other little charming attentions which were intended to strike at long range the gentlemen who formed the escort, the townspeople, the officers of the different cities she passed through, pages, populace, and servants; it was wholesale slaughter, a general devastation. By the time Madame arrived at Paris, she had reduced to slavery about a hundred thousand lovers: and brought in her train to Paris half a dozen men who were almost mad about her, and two who were, indeed, literally out of their minds. Raoul was the only person who divined the power of this woman's attraction, and as his heart was already engaged, he arrived in the capital full of indifference and distrust. Occasionally during the journey he conversed with the queen of England respecting the power of fascination which Madame possessed, and the mother, whom so many misfortunes and deceptions had taught experience, replied: Henrietta was sure to be illustrious in one way or another, whether born in a palace or born in obscurity; for she is a woman of great imagination, capricious and selfwilled. De Wardes and Manicamp, in their selfassumed character of courtiers, had announced the princess's arrival. The procession was met at Nanterre by a brilliant escort of cavaliers and carriages. It was Monsieur himself, followed by the Chevalier de Lorraine and by his favorites, the latter being themselves followed by a portion of the king's military household, who had arrived to meet his affianced bride. At St. Germain, the princess and her mother had changed their heavy traveling carriage, somewhat impaired by the journey, for a light, richly decorated chariot drawn by six horses with white and gold harness. Seated in this open carriage, as though upon a throne, and beneath a parasol of embroidered silk, fringed with feathers, sat the young and lovely princess, on whose beaming face were reflected the softened rosetints which suited her delicate skin to perfection. Monsieur, on reaching the carriage, was struck by her beauty; he showed his admiration in so marked a manner that the Chevalier de Lorraine shrugged his shoulders as he listened to his compliments, while Buckingham and De Guiche were almost heartbroken. After the usual courtesies had been rendered, and the ceremony completed, the procession slowly resumed the road to Paris. The presentations had been carelessly made, and Buckingham, with the rest of the English gentlemen, had been introduced to Monsieur, from whom they had received but very indifferent attention. But, during their progress, as he observed that the duke devoted himself with his accustomed eagerness to the carriagedoor, he asked the Chevalier de Lorraine, his inseparable companion, Who is that cavalier?
