Lorraine his inseparable companion Who is that cavalier

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: He was presented to your highness a short while ago; it is the handsome Duke of Buckingham.
children.prevalue: He was presented to your highness a short while ago it is the handsome Duke of Buckingham

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Ah, yes, I remember.
children.prevalue: Ah yes I remember

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Madame's knight, added the favorite, with an inflection of the voice which envious minds can alone give to the simplest phrases.
children.prevalue: Madame s knight added the favorite with an inflection of the voice which envious minds can alone give to the simplest phrases

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: What do you say? replied the prince.
children.prevalue: What do you say replied the prince

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: I said 'Madame's knight'.
children.prevalue: I said Madame s knight

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Has she a recognized knight, then?
children.prevalue: Has she a recognized knight then

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: One would think you can judge of that for yourself; look, only, how they are laughing and flirting. All three of them.
children.prevalue: One would think you can judge of that for yourself look only how they are laughing and flirting All three of them

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: What do you mean by all three?
children.prevalue: What do you mean by all three

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Do you not see that De Guiche is one of the party?
children.prevalue: Do you not see that De Guiche is one of the party

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Yes, I see. But what does that prove?
children.prevalue: Yes I see But what does that prove

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: That Madame has two admirers instead of one.
children.prevalue: That Madame has two admirers instead of one

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: You poison the simplest thing!
children.prevalue: You poison the simplest thing

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I poison nothing. Ah! your royal highness's mind is perverted. The honors of the kingdom of France are being paid to your wife and you are not satisfied.
children.prevalue: I poison nothing Ah your royal highness s mind is perverted The honors of the kingdom of France are being paid to your wife and you are not satisfied

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The Duke of Orleans dreaded the satirical humor of the Chevalier de Lorraine whenever it reached a certain degree of bitterness, and he changed the conversation abruptly. The princess is pretty, said he, very negligently, as if he were speaking of a stranger.
children.prevalue: The Duke of Orleans dreaded the satirical humor of the Chevalier de Lorraine whenever it reached a certain degree of bitterness and he changed the conversation abruptly The princess is pretty said he very negligently as if he were speaking of a stranger

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Yes, replied the chevalier, in the same tone.
children.prevalue: Yes replied the chevalier in the same tone

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: You say 'yes' like a 'no'. She has very beautiful black eyes.
children.prevalue: You say yes like a no She has very beautiful black eyes

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Yes, but small.
children.prevalue: Yes but small

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: That is so, but they are brilliant. She is tall, and of a good figure.
children.prevalue: That is so but they are brilliant She is tall and of a good figure

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: I fancy she stoops a little, my lord.
children.prevalue: I fancy she stoops a little my lord

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I do not deny it. She has a noble appearance.
children.prevalue: I do not deny it She has a noble appearance

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Yes, but her face is thin.
children.prevalue: Yes but her face is thin

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: I thought her teeth beautiful.
children.prevalue: I thought her teeth beautiful

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: They can easily be seen, for her mouth is large enough. Decidedly, I was wrong, my lord; you are certainly handsomer than your wife.
children.prevalue: They can easily be seen for her mouth is large enough Decidedly I was wrong my lord you are certainly handsomer than your wife

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: But do you think me as handsome as Buckingham?
children.prevalue: But do you think me as handsome as Buckingham

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Certainly, and he thinks so, too; for look, my lord, he is redoubling his attentions to Madame to prevent your effacing the impression he has made.
children.prevalue: Certainly and he thinks so too for look my lord he is redoubling his attentions to Madame to prevent your effacing the impression he has made

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Monsieur made a movement of impatience, but as he noticed a smile of triumph pass across the chevalier's lips, he drew up his horse to a footpace. Why, said he, should I occupy myself any longer about my cousin? Do I not already know her? Were we not brought up together? Did I not see her at the Louvre when she was quite a child?
children.prevalue: Monsieur made a movement of impatience but as he noticed a smile of triumph pass across the chevalier s lips he drew up his horse to a footpace Why said he should I occupy myself any longer about my cousin Do I not already know her Were we not brought up together Did I not see her at the Louvre when she was quite a child

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: A great change has taken place in her since then, prince. At the period you allude to, she was somewhat less brilliant, and scarcely so proud, either. One evening, particularly, you may remember, my lord, the king refused to dance with her, because he thought her plain and badly dressed!
children.prevalue: A great change has taken place in her since then prince At the period you allude to she was somewhat less brilliant and scarcely so proud either One evening particularly you may remember my lord the king refused to dance with her because he thought her plain and badly dressed

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: These words made the Duke of Orleans frown. It was by no means flattering for him to marry a princess of whom, when young, the king had not thought much. He would probably have retorted, but at this moment De Guiche quitted the carriage to join the prince. He had remarked the prince and the chevalier together, and full of anxious attention he seemed to try and guess the nature of the remarks which they had just exchanged. The chevalier, whether he had some treacherous object in view, or from imprudence, did not take the trouble to dissimulate. Count, he said, you're a man of excellent taste.
children.prevalue: These words made the Duke of Orleans frown It was by no means flattering for him to marry a princess of whom when young the king had not thought much He would probably have retorted but at this moment De Guiche quitted the carriage to join the prince He had remarked the prince and the chevalier together and full of anxious attention he seemed to try and guess the nature of the remarks which they had just exchanged The chevalier whether he had some treacherous object in view or from imprudence did not take the trouble to dissimulate Count he said you re a man of excellent taste

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Thank you for the compliment, replied De Guiche; but why do you say that?
children.prevalue: Thank you for the compliment replied De Guiche but why do you say that

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Well I appeal to his highness.
children.prevalue: Well I appeal to his highness

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: No doubt of it, said Monsieur; and Guiche knows perfectly well that I regard him as a most finished cavalier.
children.prevalue: No doubt of it said Monsieur and Guiche knows perfectly well that I regard him as a most finished cavalier

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Well, since that is decided, I resume. You have been in the princess's society, count, for the last eight days, have you not?
children.prevalue: Well since that is decided I resume You have been in the princess s society count for the last eight days have you not

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Yes, replied De Guiche, coloring in spite of himself.
children.prevalue: Yes replied De Guiche coloring in spite of himself

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Well then, tell us frankly, what do you think of her personal appearance?
children.prevalue: Well then tell us frankly what do you think of her personal appearance

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Of her personal appearance? returned De Guiche, stupefied.
children.prevalue: Of her personal appearance returned De Guiche stupefied

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Yes; of her appearance, of her mind, of herself, in fact.
children.prevalue: Yes of her appearance of her mind of herself in fact

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Astounded by this question, De Guiche hesitated answering.
children.prevalue: Astounded by this question De Guiche hesitated answering

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Come, come, De Guiche, resumed the chevalier, laughingly, tell us your opinion frankly; the prince commands it.
children.prevalue: Come come De Guiche resumed the chevalier laughingly tell us your opinion frankly the prince commands it

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Yes, yes, said the prince, be frank.
children.prevalue: Yes yes said the prince be frank

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: De Guiche stammered out a few unintelligible words.
children.prevalue: De Guiche stammered out a few unintelligible words

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: I am perfectly well aware, returned Monsieur, that the subject is a delicate one, but you know you can tell me everything. What do you think of her?
children.prevalue: I am perfectly well aware returned Monsieur that the subject is a delicate one but you know you can tell me everything What do you think of her

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: In order to avoid betraying his real thoughts, De Guiche had recourse to the only defense which a man taken by surprise really has, and accordingly told an untruth. I do not find Madame, he said, either good or bad looking, yet rather good than bad looking.
children.prevalue: In order to avoid betraying his real thoughts De Guiche had recourse to the only defense which a man taken by surprise really has and accordingly told an untruth I do not find Madame he said either good or bad looking yet rather good than bad looking

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: What! count, exclaimed the chevalier, you who went into such ecstasies and uttered so many exclamations at the sight of her portrait.
children.prevalue: What count exclaimed the chevalier you who went into such ecstasies and uttered so many exclamations at the sight of her portrait

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: De Guiche colored violently. Very fortunately, his horse, which was slightly restive, enabled him by a sudden plunge to conceal his agitation. What portrait? he murmured, joining them again. The chevalier had not taken his eyes off him.
children.prevalue: De Guiche colored violently Very fortunately his horse which was slightly restive enabled him by a sudden plunge to conceal his agitation What portrait he murmured joining them again The chevalier had not taken his eyes off him

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Yes, the portrait. Was not the miniature a good likeness?
children.prevalue: Yes the portrait Was not the miniature a good likeness

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: I do not remember. I had forgotten the portrait; it quite escaped my recollection.
children.prevalue: I do not remember I had forgotten the portrait it quite escaped my recollection

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: And yet it made a very marked impression upon you, said the chevalier.
children.prevalue: And yet it made a very marked impression upon you said the chevalier

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: That is not unlikely.
children.prevalue: That is not unlikely

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Is she witty, at all events? inquired the duke.
children.prevalue: Is she witty at all events inquired the duke

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: I believe so, my lord.
children.prevalue: I believe so my lord

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Is M. de Buckingham witty, too? said the chevalier.
children.prevalue: Is M de Buckingham witty too said the chevalier

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: I do not know.
children.prevalue: I do not know

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: My own opinion is that he must be, replied the chevalier, for he makes Madame laugh, and she seems to take no little pleasure in his society, which never happens to a clever woman when in the company of a simpleton.
children.prevalue: My own opinion is that he must be replied the chevalier for he makes Madame laugh and she seems to take no little pleasure in his society which never happens to a clever woman when in the company of a simpleton

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Of course, then, he must be clever, said De Guiche, simply.
children.prevalue: Of course then he must be clever said De Guiche simply

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: At this moment Raoul opportunely arrived, seeing how De Guiche was pressed by his dangerous questioner, to whom he addressed a remark, and in that way changed the conversation. The entree was brilliant and joyous.
children.prevalue: At this moment Raoul opportunely arrived seeing how De Guiche was pressed by his dangerous questioner to whom he addressed a remark and in that way changed the conversation The entree was brilliant and joyous

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: The king, in honor of his brother, had directed that the festivities should be on a scale of the greatest possible magnificence. Madame and her mother alighted at the Louvre, where, during their exile they had so gloomily submitted to obscurity, misery, and privations of every description. That palace, which had been so inhospitable a residence for the unhappy daughter of Henry IV., the naked walls, the uneven floorings, the ceilings matted with cobwebs, the vast dilapidated chimneyplaces, the cold hearths on which the charity extended to them by parliament hardly permitted a fire to glow, was completely altered in appearance. The richest hangings and the thickest carpets, glistening flagstones, and pictures, with their richly gilded frames; in every direction could be seen candelabra, mirrors, and furniture and fittings of the most sumptuous character; in every direction, also, were guards of the proudest military bearing, with floating plumes, crowds of attendants and courtiers in the antechambers and upon the staircases. In the courtyards, where the grass had formerly been allowed to luxuriate, as if the ungrateful Mazarin had thought it a good idea to let the Parisians perceive the solitude and disorder were, with misery and despair, the fit accompaniments of fallen monarchy; the immense courtyards, formerly silent and desolate, were now thronged with courtiers whose horses were pacing and prancing to and fro. The carriages were filled with young and beautiful women, who awaited the opportunity of saluting, as she passed, the daughter of that daughter of France who, during her widowhood and exile, had sometimes gone without wood for her fire, and bread for her table, whom the meanest attendant at the chateau had treated with indifference and contempt. And so, the Madame Henriette once more returned to the Louvre, with her heart more swollen with bitter recollections than her daughter's, whose disposition was fickle and forgetful, with triumph and delight. She knew but too well this brilliant reception was paid to the happy mother of a king restored to his throne, a throne second to none in Europe, while the worse than indifferent reception she had before met with was paid to her, the daughter of Henry IV., as a punishment for having been unfortunate. After the princess had been installed in their apartments and had rested, the gentlemen who had formed their escort, having, in like manner, recovered from their fatigue, they resumed their accustomed habits and occupations. Raoul began by setting off to see his father, who had left for Blois. He then tried to see M. d'Artagnan, who, however, being engaged in the organization of a military household for the king, could not be found anywhere. Bragelonne next sought out De Guiche, but the count was occupied in a long conference with his tailors and with Manicamp, which consumed his whole time. With the Duke of Buckingham he fared still worse, for the duke was purchasing horses after horses, diamonds upon diamonds. He monopolized every embroiderer, jeweler, and tailor that Paris could boast of. Between De Guiche and himself a vigorous contest ensued, invariably a courteous one, in which, in order to insure success, the duke was ready to spend a million; while the Marechal de Gramont had only allowed his son sixty thousand francs. So Buckingham laughed and spent his money. Guiche groaned in despair, and would have shown it more violently, had it not been for the advice De Bragelonne gave him.

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: A million! repeated De Guiche daily; I must submit. Why will not the marechal advance me a portion of my patrimony?
children.prevalue: A million repeated De Guiche daily I must submit Why will not the marechal advance me a portion of my patrimony

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Because you would throw it away, said Raoul.
children.prevalue: Because you would throw it away said Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: What can that matter to him? If I am to die of it, I shall die of it, and then I shall need nothing further.
children.prevalue: What can that matter to him If I am to die of it I shall die of it and then I shall need nothing further

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: But what need is there to die? said Raoul.
children.prevalue: But what need is there to die said Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I do not wish to be conquered in elegance by an Englishman.
children.prevalue: I do not wish to be conquered in elegance by an Englishman

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: My dear count, said Manicamp, elegance is not a costly commodity, it is only a very difficult accomplishment.
children.prevalue: My dear count said Manicamp elegance is not a costly commodity it is only a very difficult accomplishment

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Yes, but difficult things cost a good deal of money, and I have only got sixty thousand francs.
children.prevalue: Yes but difficult things cost a good deal of money and I have only got sixty thousand francs

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: A very embarrassing state of things, truly, said De Wardes; even if you spent as much as Buckingham, there is only nine hundred and forty thousand francs difference.
children.prevalue: A very embarrassing state of things truly said De Wardes even if you spent as much as Buckingham there is only nine hundred and forty thousand francs difference

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Where am I to find them?
children.prevalue: Where am I to find them

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Get into debt.
children.prevalue: Get into debt

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: I am in debt already.
children.prevalue: I am in debt already

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: A greater reason for getting further.
children.prevalue: A greater reason for getting further

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Advice like this resulted in De Guiche becoming excited to such an extent that he committed extravagances where Buckingham only incurred expenses. The rumor of this extravagant profuseness delighted the hearts of all the shopkeepers in Paris; from the hotel of the Duke of Buckingham to that of the Comte de Gramont nothing but miracles was attempted. While all this was going on, Madame was resting herself, and Bragelonne was engaged in writing to Mademoiselle de la Valliere. He had already dispatched four letters, and not an answer to any one of them had been received, when, on the very morning fixed for the marriage ceremony, which was to take place in the chapel at the Palais Royal, Raoul, who was dressing, heard his valet announce M. de Malicorne. What can this Malicorne want with me? thought Raoul; and then said to his valet, Let him wait.
children.prevalue: Advice like this resulted in De Guiche becoming excited to such an extent that he committed extravagances where Buckingham only incurred expenses The rumor of this extravagant profuseness delighted the hearts of all the shopkeepers in Paris from the hotel of the Duke of Buckingham to that of the Comte de Gramont nothing but miracles was attempted While all this was going on Madame was resting herself and Bragelonne was engaged in writing to Mademoiselle de la Valliere He had already dispatched four letters and not an answer to any one of them had been received when on the very morning fixed for the marriage ceremony which was to take place in the chapel at the Palais Royal Raoul who was dressing heard his valet announce M de Malicorne What can this Malicorne want with me thought Raoul and then said to his valet Let him wait

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: It is a gentleman from Blois, said the valet.
children.prevalue: It is a gentleman from Blois said the valet

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Admit him at once, said Raoul, eagerly.
children.prevalue: Admit him at once said Raoul eagerly

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Malicorne entered as brilliant as a star, and wearing a superb sword at his side. After having saluted Raoul most gracefully, he said: M. de Bragelonne, I am the bearer of a thousand compliments from a lady to you.
children.prevalue: Malicorne entered as brilliant as a star and wearing a superb sword at his side After having saluted Raoul most gracefully he said M de Bragelonne I am the bearer of a thousand compliments from a lady to you

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Raoul colored. From a lady, said he, from a lady of Blois?
children.prevalue: Raoul colored From a lady said he from a lady of Blois

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Yes, monsieur; from Mademoiselle de Montalais.
children.prevalue: Yes monsieur from Mademoiselle de Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Thank you, monsieur; I recollect you now, said Raoul. And what does Mademoiselle de Montalais require of me.
children.prevalue: Thank you monsieur I recollect you now said Raoul And what does Mademoiselle de Montalais require of me

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Malicorne drew four letters from his pocket, which he offered to Raoul.
children.prevalue: Malicorne drew four letters from his pocket which he offered to Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: My own letters, is it possible? he said, turning pale; my letters, and the seals unbroken?
children.prevalue: My own letters is it possible he said turning pale my letters and the seals unbroken

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Monsieur, your letters did not find at Blois the person to whom they were addressed, and so they are now returned to you.
children.prevalue: Monsieur your letters did not find at Blois the person to whom they were addressed and so they are now returned to you

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Mademoiselle de la Valliere has left Blois, then? exclaimed Raoul.
children.prevalue: Mademoiselle de la Valliere has left Blois then exclaimed Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Eight days ago.
children.prevalue: Eight days ago

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Where is she, then?
children.prevalue: Where is she then

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: In Paris.
children.prevalue: In Paris

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: How is it known that these letters were from me?
children.prevalue: How is it known that these letters were from me

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Mademoiselle de Montalais recognized your handwriting and your seal, said Malicorne.
children.prevalue: Mademoiselle de Montalais recognized your handwriting and your seal said Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Raoul colored and smiled. Mademoiselle de Montalais is exceedingly amiable, he said; she is always kind and charming.
children.prevalue: Raoul colored and smiled Mademoiselle de Montalais is exceedingly amiable he said she is always kind and charming

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Always, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Always monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Surely she could have given me some precise information about Mademoiselle de la Valliere. I never could find her in this immense city.
children.prevalue: Surely she could have given me some precise information about Mademoiselle de la Valliere I never could find her in this immense city

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Malicorne drew another packet from his pocket. You may possibly find in this letter what you are anxious to learn.
children.prevalue: Malicorne drew another packet from his pocket You may possibly find in this letter what you are anxious to learn

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Raoul hurriedly broke the seal. The writing was that of Mademoiselle Aure, and inclosed were these words:Paris, Palais Royal. The day of the nuptial blessing.
children.prevalue: Raoul hurriedly broke the seal The writing was that of Mademoiselle Aure and inclosed were these words Paris Palais Royal The day of the nuptial blessing

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: What does this mean? inquired Raoul of Malicorne; you probably know?
children.prevalue: What does this mean inquired Raoul of Malicorne you probably know

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: I do, monsieur.
children.prevalue: I do monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: For pity's sake, tell me, then.
children.prevalue: For pity s sake tell me then

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Impossible, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Impossible monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Why so?
children.prevalue: Why so

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Because Mademoiselle Aure has forbidden me to do so.
children.prevalue: Because Mademoiselle Aure has forbidden me to do so

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Raoul looked at his strange visitor, and remained silent;At least, tell me whether it is fortunate or unfortunate.
children.prevalue: Raoul looked at his strange visitor and remained silent At least tell me whether it is fortunate or unfortunate

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: That you will see.
children.prevalue: That you will see

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: You are very severe in your reservations.
children.prevalue: You are very severe in your reservations

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Will you grant me one favor, monsieur? said Malicorne.
children.prevalue: Will you grant me one favor monsieur said Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: In exchange for that you refuse me?
children.prevalue: In exchange for that you refuse me

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Precisely.
children.prevalue: Precisely

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: What is it?
children.prevalue: What is it

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: I have the greatest desire to see the ceremony, and I have no ticket to admit me, in spite of all the steps I have taken to secure one. Could you get me admitted?
children.prevalue: I have the greatest desire to see the ceremony and I have no ticket to admit me in spite of all the steps I have taken to secure one Could you get me admitted

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Do me this kindness, then, I entreat.
children.prevalue: Do me this kindness then I entreat

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Most willingly, monsieur; come with me.
children.prevalue: Most willingly monsieur come with me

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: I am exceedingly indebted to you, monsieur, said Malicorne.
children.prevalue: I am exceedingly indebted to you monsieur said Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: I thought you were a friend of M. de Manicamp.
children.prevalue: I thought you were a friend of M de Manicamp

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: I am, monsieur; but this morning I was with him as he was dressing, and I let a bottle of blacking fall over his new dress, and he flew at me sword in hand, so that I was obliged to make my escape. That is the reason I could not ask him for a ticket. He wanted to kill me.
children.prevalue: I am monsieur but this morning I was with him as he was dressing and I let a bottle of blacking fall over his new dress and he flew at me sword in hand so that I was obliged to make my escape That is the reason I could not ask him for a ticket He wanted to kill me

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: I can well believe it, laughed Raoul. I know Manicamp is capable of killing a man who has been unfortunate enough to commit the crime you have to reproach yourself with, but I will repair the mischief as far as you are concerned. I will but fasten my cloak, and shall then be ready to serve you, not only as a guide, but as your introducer, too.
children.prevalue: I can well believe it laughed Raoul I know Manicamp is capable of killing a man who has been unfortunate enough to commit the crime you have to reproach yourself with but I will repair the mischief as far as you are concerned I will but fasten my cloak and shall then be ready to serve you not only as a guide but as your introducer too

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Madame's marriage was celebrated in the chapel of the Palais Royal, in the presence of a crowd of courtiers, who had been most scrupulously selected. However, notwithstanding the marked favor which an invitation indicated, Raoul, faithful to his promise to Malicorne, who was so anxious to witness the ceremony, obtained admission for him. After he had fulfilled this engagement, Raoul approached De Guiche, who, as if in contrast with his magnificent costume, exhibited a countenance so utterly dejected, that the Duke of Buckingham was the only one present who could contend with him as far as pallor and discomfiture were concerned.
children.prevalue: Madame s marriage was celebrated in the chapel of the Palais Royal in the presence of a crowd of courtiers who had been most scrupulously selected However notwithstanding the marked favor which an invitation indicated Raoul faithful to his promise to Malicorne who was so anxious to witness the ceremony obtained admission for him After he had fulfilled this engagement Raoul approached De Guiche who as if in contrast with his magnificent costume exhibited a countenance so utterly dejected that the Duke of Buckingham was the only one present who could contend with him as far as pallor and discomfiture were concerned

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Take care, count, said Raoul, approaching his friend, and preparing to support him at the moment the archbishop blessed the married couple. In fact, the Prince of Conde was attentively scrutinizing these two images of desolation, standing like caryatides on either side of the nave of the church. The count, after that, kept a more careful watch over himself.
children.prevalue: Take care count said Raoul approaching his friend and preparing to support him at the moment the archbishop blessed the married couple In fact the Prince of Conde was attentively scrutinizing these two images of desolation standing like caryatides on either side of the nave of the church The count after that kept a more careful watch over himself

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: At the termination of the ceremony, the king and queen passed onward towards the grand receptionroom, where Madame and her suite were to be presented to them. It was remarked that the king, who had seemed more than surprised at his sisterinlaw's appearance, was most flattering in his compliments to her. Again, it was remarked that the queenmother, fixing a long and thoughtful gaze upon Buckingham, leaned towards Madame de Motteville as though to ask her, Do you not see how much he resembles his father? and finally it was remarked that Monsieur watched everybody, and seemed quite discontented. After the reception of the princess and ambassadors, Monsieur solicited the king's permission to present to him as well as to Madame the persons belonging to their new household.
children.prevalue: At the termination of the ceremony the king and queen passed onward towards the grand receptionroom where Madame and her suite were to be presented to them It was remarked that the king who had seemed more than surprised at his sisterinlaw s appearance was most flattering in his compliments to her Again it was remarked that the queenmother fixing a long and thoughtful gaze upon Buckingham leaned towards Madame de Motteville as though to ask her Do you not see how much he resembles his father and finally it was remarked that Monsieur watched everybody and seemed quite discontented After the reception of the princess and ambassadors Monsieur solicited the king s permission to present to him as well as to Madame the persons belonging to their new household

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Are you aware, vicomte, inquired the Prince de Conde of Raoul, whether the household has been selected by a person of taste, and whether there are any faces worth looking at?
children.prevalue: Are you aware vicomte inquired the Prince de Conde of Raoul whether the household has been selected by a person of taste and whether there are any faces worth looking at

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: I have not the slightest idea, monseigneur, replied Raoul.
children.prevalue: I have not the slightest idea monseigneur replied Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: You affect ignorance, surely.
children.prevalue: You affect ignorance surely

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: In what way, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: In what way monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: You are a friend of De Guiche, who is one of the friends of the prince.
children.prevalue: You are a friend of De Guiche who is one of the friends of the prince

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: That may be so, monseigneur; but the matter having no interest whatever for me, I have never questioned De Guiche on the subject; and De Guiche, on his part, never having been questioned, did not communicate any particulars to me.
children.prevalue: That may be so monseigneur but the matter having no interest whatever for me I have never questioned De Guiche on the subject and De Guiche on his part never having been questioned did not communicate any particulars to me

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: But Manicamp?
children.prevalue: But Manicamp

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: It is true I saw Manicamp at Le Havre, and during the journey here, but I was no more inquisitive with him than I had been towards De Guiche. Besides, is it likely that Manicamp should know anything of such matters? for he is a person of only secondary importance.
children.prevalue: It is true I saw Manicamp at Le Havre and during the journey here but I was no more inquisitive with him than I had been towards De Guiche Besides is it likely that Manicamp should know anything of such matters for he is a person of only secondary importance

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: My dear vicomte, do you not know better than that? said the prince; why, it is these persons of secondary importance, who, on such occasions, have all the influence; and the truth is, that nearly everything has been done through Manicamp's presentations to De Guiche, and through De Guiche to Monsieur.
children.prevalue: My dear vicomte do you not know better than that said the prince why it is these persons of secondary importance who on such occasions have all the influence and the truth is that nearly everything has been done through Manicamp s presentations to De Guiche and through De Guiche to Monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I assure you, monseigneur, I was ignorant of that, said Raoul, and what your highness does me the honor to impart is perfectly new to me.
children.prevalue: I assure you monseigneur I was ignorant of that said Raoul and what your highness does me the honor to impart is perfectly new to me

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I will most readily believe you, although it seems incredible; besides we shall not have long to wait. See, the flying squadron is advancing, as good Queen Catherine used to say. Ah! ah! what pretty faces!
children.prevalue: I will most readily believe you although it seems incredible besides we shall not have long to wait See the flying squadron is advancing as good Queen Catherine used to say Ah ah what pretty faces

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: A bevy of young girls at this moment entered the salon, conducted by Madame de Navailles, and to Manicamp's credit be it said, if indeed he had taken that part in their selection which the Prince de Conde assigned him, it was a display calculated to dazzle those who, like the prince, could appreciate every character and style of beauty. A young, faircomplexioned girl, from twenty to oneandtwenty years of age, and whose large blue eyes flashed, as she opened them, in the most dazzling manner, walked at the head of the band and was the first presented.
children.prevalue: A bevy of young girls at this moment entered the salon conducted by Madame de Navailles and to Manicamp s credit be it said if indeed he had taken that part in their selection which the Prince de Conde assigned him it was a display calculated to dazzle those who like the prince could appreciate every character and style of beauty A young faircomplexioned girl from twenty to oneandtwenty years of age and whose large blue eyes flashed as she opened them in the most dazzling manner walked at the head of the band and was the first presented

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, said Madame de Navailles to Monsieur, who, as he saluted his wife, repeated Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente.
children.prevalue: Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente said Madame de Navailles to Monsieur who as he saluted his wife repeated Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Ah! ah! said the Prince de Conde to Raoul, she is presentable enough.
children.prevalue: Ah ah said the Prince de Conde to Raoul she is presentable enough

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Yes, said Raoul, but has she not a somewhat haughty style?
children.prevalue: Yes said Raoul but has she not a somewhat haughty style

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Bah! we know these airs very well, vicomte; three months hence she will be tame enough. But look, there, indeed, is a pretty face.
children.prevalue: Bah we know these airs very well vicomte three months hence she will be tame enough But look there indeed is a pretty face

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Yes, said Raoul, and one I am acquainted with.
children.prevalue: Yes said Raoul and one I am acquainted with

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Mademoiselle Aure de Montalais, said Madame de Navailles. The name and Christian name were carefully repeated by Monsieur.
children.prevalue: Mademoiselle Aure de Montalais said Madame de Navailles The name and Christian name were carefully repeated by Monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Great heavens! exclaimed Raoul, fixing his bewildered gaze upon the entrance doorway.
children.prevalue: Great heavens exclaimed Raoul fixing his bewildered gaze upon the entrance doorway

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: What's the matter? inquired the prince; was it Mademoiselle Aure de Montalais who made you utter such a 'Great heavens'?
children.prevalue: What s the matter inquired the prince was it Mademoiselle Aure de Montalais who made you utter such a Great heavens

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: No, monseigneur, no, replied Raoul, pale and trembling.
children.prevalue: No monseigneur no replied Raoul pale and trembling

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Well, then, if it be not Mademoiselle Aure de Montalais, it is that pretty blonde who follows her. What beautiful eyes! She is rather thin, but has fascinations without number.
children.prevalue: Well then if it be not Mademoiselle Aure de Montalais it is that pretty blonde who follows her What beautiful eyes She is rather thin but has fascinations without number

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Mademoiselle de la Baume le Blanc de la Valliere! said Madame de Navailles; and, as this name resounded through his whole being, a cloud seemed to rise from his breast to his eyes, so that he neither saw nor heard anything more; and the prince, finding him nothing more than a mere echo which remained silent under his railleries, moved forward to inspect somewhat closer the beautiful girls whom his first glance had already particularized.
children.prevalue: Mademoiselle de la Baume le Blanc de la Valliere said Madame de Navailles and as this name resounded through his whole being a cloud seemed to rise from his breast to his eyes so that he neither saw nor heard anything more and the prince finding him nothing more than a mere echo which remained silent under his railleries moved forward to inspect somewhat closer the beautiful girls whom his first glance had already particularized

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Louise here! Louise a maid of honor to Madame! murmured Raoul, and his eyes, which did not suffice to satisfy his reason, wandered from Louise to Montalais. The latter had already emancipated herself from her assumed timidity, which she only needed for the presentation and for her reverences.
children.prevalue: Louise here Louise a maid of honor to Madame murmured Raoul and his eyes which did not suffice to satisfy his reason wandered from Louise to Montalais The latter had already emancipated herself from her assumed timidity which she only needed for the presentation and for her reverences

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Mademoiselle de Montalais, from the corner of the room to which she had retired, was looking with no slight confidence at the different persons present; and, having discovered Raoul, she amused herself with the profound astonishment which her own and her friend's presence there caused the unhappy lover. Her waggish and malicious look, which Raoul tried to avoid meeting, and which yet he sought inquiringly from time to time, placed him on the rack. As for Louise, whether from natural timidity, or some other reason for which Raoul could not account, she kept her eyes constantly cast down; intimidated, dazzled, and with impeded respiration, she withdrew herself as much as possible aside, unaffected even by the nudges Montalais gave her with her elbow. The whole scene was a perfect enigma for Raoul, the key to which he would have given anything to obtain. But no one was there who could assist him, not even Malicorne; who, a little uneasy at finding himself in the presence of so many persons of good birth, and not a little discouraged by Montalais's bantering glances, had described a circle, and by degrees succeeded in getting a few paces from the prince, behind the group of maids of honor, and nearly within reach of Mademoiselle Aure's voice, she being the planet around which he, as her attendant satellite, seemed constrained to gravitate. As he recovered his selfpossession, Raoul fancied he recognized voices on his right hand side that were familiar to him, and he perceived De Wardes, De Guiche, and the Chevalier de Lorraine conversing together. It is true they were talking in tones so low, that the sound of their words could hardly be heard in the vast apartment. To speak in that manner from any particular place without bending down, or turning round, or looking at the person with whom one may be engaged in conversation, is a talent that cannot be immediately acquired by newcomers. Long study is needed for such conversations, which, without a look, gesture, or movement of the head, seem like the conversation of a group of statues. In fact, the king's and queen's grand assemblies, while their majesties were speaking, and while every one present seemed to be listening in the midst of the most profound silence, some of these noiseless conversations took place, in which adulation was not the prevailing feature. But Raoul was one among others exceedingly clever in this art, so much a matter of etiquette, that from the movement of the lips, he was often able to guess the sense of the words.

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Who is that Montalais? inquired De Wardes, and that La Valliere? What countrytown have we had sent here?

children.value: Gentlemen, gentlemen, said De Guiche, looking at Raoul with uneasiness, be a little careful, I entreat you.

children.value: But the uneasiness of the count, in appearance at least, was not needed. Raoul had preserved the firmest and most indifferent countenance, although he had not lost a word that passed. He seemed to keep an account of the insolence and license of the two speakers in order to settle matters with them at the earliest opportunity.

children.prevalue: Who are these young ladies lovers

children.prevalue: Yes Montalais first

children.value: Take care, gentlemen, exclaimed De Guiche, anxious to put a stop to the chevalier's reply; take care, Madame is listening to us.
children.prevalue: Take care gentlemen exclaimed De Guiche anxious to put a stop to the chevalier s reply take care Madame is listening to us

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Raoul had thrust his hand up to the wrist into his justaucorps in great agitation. But the very malignity which he saw was excited against these poor girls made him take a serious resolution. Poor Louise, he thought, has come here only with an honorable object in view, and under honorable protection; and I must learn what that object is which she has in view, and who it is that protects her. And following Malicorne's maneuver, he made his way toward the group of the maids of honor. The presentations were soon over. The king, who had done nothing but look at and admire Madame, shortly afterwards left the receptionroom, accompanied by the two queens. The Chevalier de Lorraine resumed his place beside Monsieur, and, as he accompanied him, insinuated a few drops of the venom he had collected during the last hour, while looking at some of the faces in the court, and suspecting that some of their hearts might be happy. A few of the persons present followed the king as he quitted the apartment; but such of the courtiers as assumed an independence of character, and professed a gallantry of disposition, began to approach the ladies of the court. The prince paid his compliments to Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, Buckingham devoted himself to Madame Chalais and Mademoiselle de Lafayette, whom Madame already distinguished by her notice, and whom she held in high regard. As for the Comte de Guiche, who had abandoned Monsieur as soon as he could approach Madame alone, he conversed, with great animation, with Madame de Valentinois, and with Mademoiselle de Crequy and de Chatillon.

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Amid these varied political, and amorous interests, Malicorne was anxious to gain Montalais's attention; but the latter preferred talking with Raoul, even if it were only to amuse herself with his innumerable questions and his astonishment. Raoul had gone directly to Mademoiselle de la Valliere, and had saluted her with the profoundest respect, at which Louise blushed, and could not say a word. Montalais, however, hurried to her assistance.

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Well, monsieur le vicomte, here we are, you see.
children.prevalue: Well monsieur le vicomte here we are you see

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: I do, indeed, see you, said Raoul smiling, and it is exactly because you are here that I wish to ask for some explanation.
children.prevalue: I do indeed see you said Raoul smiling and it is exactly because you are here that I wish to ask for some explanation

children.value: Malicorne approached the group with his most fascinating smile.
children.prevalue: Malicorne approached the group with his most fascinating smile

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Go away, Malicorne; really you are exceedingly indiscreet. At this remark Malicorne bit his lips and retired a few steps, without making any reply. His smile, however, changed its expression, and from its former frankness, became mocking in its expression.
children.prevalue: Go away Malicorne really you are exceedingly indiscreet At this remark Malicorne bit his lips and retired a few steps without making any reply His smile however changed its expression and from its former frankness became mocking in its expression

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: You wished for an explanation, M. Raoul? inquired Montalais.
children.prevalue: You wished for an explanation M Raoul inquired Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: It is surely worth one, I think; Mademoiselle de la Valliere is a maid of honor to Madame!
children.prevalue: It is surely worth one I think Mademoiselle de la Valliere is a maid of honor to Madame

children.value: Why should she not be a maid of honor, as well as myself? inquired Montalais.
children.prevalue: Why should she not be a maid of honor as well as myself inquired Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Pray accept my compliments, young ladies, said Raoul, who fancied he perceived they were not disposed to answer him in a direct manner.
children.prevalue: Pray accept my compliments young ladies said Raoul who fancied he perceived they were not disposed to answer him in a direct manner

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Your remark was not made in a very complimentary manner, vicomte.
children.prevalue: Your remark was not made in a very complimentary manner vicomte

children.value: Mine?
children.prevalue: Mine

children.value: Certainly; I appeal to Louise.
children.prevalue: Certainly I appeal to Louise

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: M. de Bragelonne probably thinks the position is above my condition, said Louise, hesitatingly.
children.prevalue: M de Bragelonne probably thinks the position is above my condition said Louise hesitatingly

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Assuredly not, replied Raoul, eagerly, you know very well that such is not my feeling; were you called upon to occupy a queen's throne, I should not be surprised; how much greater reason, then, such a position as this? The only circumstance that amazes me is, that I should have learned it only today, and that by the merest accident.

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: That is true, replied Montalais, with her usual giddiness; you know nothing about it, and there is no reason you should. M. de Bragelonne had written several letters to you, but your mother was the only person who remained behind at Blois, and it was necessary to prevent these letters from falling into her hands; I intercepted them, and returned them to M. Raoul, so that he believed you were still at Blois while you were here in Paris, and had no idea whatever, indeed, how high you had risen in rank.

children.value: Did you not inform M. Raoul, as I begged you to do?
children.prevalue: Did you not inform M Raoul as I begged you to do

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Why should I? to give him opportunity of making some of his severe remarks and moral reflections, and to undo what we have had so much trouble in effecting? Certainly not.
children.prevalue: Why should I to give him opportunity of making some of his severe remarks and moral reflections and to undo what we have had so much trouble in effecting Certainly not

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Am I so very severe, then? said Raoul, inquiringly.
children.prevalue: Am I so very severe then said Raoul inquiringly

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Besides, said Montalais, it is sufficient to say that it suited me. I was about setting off for Parisyou were away; Louise was weeping her eyes out; interpret that as you please; I begged a friend, a protector of mine, who had obtained the appointment for me, to solicit one for Louise; the appointment arrived. Louise left in order to get her costume prepared; as I had my own ready, I remained behind; I received your letters, and returned them to you, adding a few words, promising you a surprise. Your surprise is before you, monsieur, and seems to be a fair one enough; you have nothing more to ask. Come, M. Malicorne, it is now time to leave these young people together: they have many things to talk about; give me your hand; I trust that you appreciate the honor conferred upon you, M. Malicorne.

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Forgive me, said Raoul, arresting the giddy girl, and giving to his voice an intonation, the gravity of which contrasted with that of Montalais; forgive me, but may I inquire the name of the protector you speak of; for if protection be extended towards you, Mademoiselle de Montalais,for which, indeed, so many reasons exist, added Raoul, bowing, I do not see that the same reasons exist why Mademoiselle de la Valliere should be similarly cared for.

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: But, M. Raoul, said Louise, innocently, there is no difference in the matter, and I do not see why I should not tell it you myself; it was M. Malicorne who obtained it for me.

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Raoul remained for a moment almost stupefied, asking himself if they were trifling with him; he then turned round to interrogate Malicorne, but he had been hurried away by Montalais, and was already at some distance from them. Mademoiselle de la Valliere attempted to follow her friend, but Raoul, with gentle authority, detained her.

children.value: Louise, one word, I beg.
children.prevalue: Louise one word I beg

children.value: But, M. Raoul, said Louise, blushing, we are alone. Every one has left. They will become anxious, and will be looking for us.
children.prevalue: But M Raoul said Louise blushing we are alone Every one has left They will become anxious and will be looking for us

children.value: Fear nothing, said the young man, smiling, we are neither of us of sufficient importance for our absence to be remarked.

children.value: But I have my duty to perform, M. Raoul.
children.prevalue: But I have my duty to perform M Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Do not be alarmed, I am acquainted with these usages of the court; you will not be on duty until tomorrow; a few minutes are at your disposal, which will enable you to give me the information I am about to have the honor to ask you for.
children.prevalue: Do not be alarmed I am acquainted with these usages of the court you will not be on duty until tomorrow a few minutes are at your disposal which will enable you to give me the information I am about to have the honor to ask you for

children.value: How serious you are, M. Raoul! said Louise.

children.value: Because the circumstances are serious. Are you listening?
children.prevalue: Because the circumstances are serious Are you listening

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: I am listening; I would only repeat, monsieur, that we are quite alone.
children.prevalue: I am listening I would only repeat monsieur that we are quite alone

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: You are right, said Raoul, and, offering her his hand, he led the young girl into the gallery adjoining the receptionroom, the windows of which looked out upon the courtyard. Every one hurried towards the middle window, which had a balcony outside, from which all the details of the slow and formal preparations for departure could be seen. Raoul opened one of the side windows, and then, being alone with Louise, said to her: You know, Louise, that from my childhood I have regarded you as my sister, as one who has been the confidante of all my troubles, to whom I have entrusted all my hopes.
children.prevalue: You are right said Raoul and offering her his hand he led the young girl into the gallery adjoining the receptionroom the windows of which looked out upon the courtyard Every one hurried towards the middle window which had a balcony outside from which all the details of the slow and formal preparations for departure could be seen Raoul opened one of the side windows and then being alone with Louise said to her You know Louise that from my childhood I have regarded you as my sister as one who has been the confidante of all my troubles to whom I have entrusted all my hopes

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Yes, M. Raoul, she answered softly; yes, M. Raoul, I know that.
children.prevalue: Yes M Raoul she answered softly yes M Raoul I know that

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: You used, on your side, to show the same friendship towards me, and had the same confidence in me; why have you not, on this occasion, been my friend,why have you shown suspicion of me?

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Mademoiselle de la Valliere did not answer. I fondly thought you loved me, said Raoul, whose voice became more and more agitated; I fondly thought you consented to all the plans we had, together, laid down for our own happiness, at the time when we wandered up and down the walks of CourCheverny, under the avenue of poplar trees leading to Blois. You do not answer me, Louise. Is it possible, he inquired, breathing with difficulty, that you no longer love me?

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: I did not say so, replied Louise, softly.
children.prevalue: I did not say so replied Louise softly

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Oh! tell me the truth, I implore you. All my hopes in life are centered in you. I chose you for your gentle and simple tastes. Do not suffer yourself to be dazzled, Louise, now that you are in the midst of a court where all that is pure too soon becomes corruptwhere all that is young too soon grows old. Louise, close your ears, so as not to hear what may be said; shut your eyes, so as not to see the examples before you; shut your lips, that you may not inhale the corrupting influences about you. Without falsehood or subterfuge, Louise, am I to believe what Mademoiselle de Montalais stated? Louise, did you come to Paris because I was no longer at Blois?

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: La Valliere blushed and concealed her face in her hands.
children.prevalue: La Valliere blushed and concealed her face in her hands

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Yes, it was so, then! exclaimed Raoul, delightedly; that was, then, your reason for coming here. I love you as I never yet loved you. Thanks, Louise, for this devotion; but measures must be taken to place you beyond all insult, to shield you from every lure. Louise, a maid of honor, in the court of a young princess in these days of free manners and inconstant affectionsa maid of honor is placed as an object of attack without having any means of defence afforded her; this state of things cannot continue; you must be married in order to be respected.
children.prevalue: Yes it was so then exclaimed Raoul delightedly that was then your reason for coming here I love you as I never yet loved you Thanks Louise for this devotion but measures must be taken to place you beyond all insult to shield you from every lure Louise a maid of honor in the court of a young princess in these days of free manners and inconstant affectionsa maid of honor is placed as an object of attack without having any means of defence afforded her this state of things cannot continue you must be married in order to be respected

children.value: Married?
children.prevalue: Married

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Yes, here is my hand, Louise; will you place yours within it?
children.prevalue: Yes here is my hand Louise will you place yours within it

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: But your father?
children.prevalue: But your father

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: My father leaves me perfectly free.
children.prevalue: My father leaves me perfectly free

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Yet
children.prevalue: Yet

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: I understand your scruples, Louise; I will consult my father.
children.prevalue: I understand your scruples Louise I will consult my father

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Reflect, M. Raoul; wait.
children.prevalue: Reflect M Raoul wait

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Wait! it is impossible. Reflect, Louise, when you are concerned! it would be insulting,give me your hand, dear Louise; I am my own master. My father will consent, I know; give me your hand, do not keep me waiting thus. One word in answer, one word only; if not, I shall begin to think that, in order to change you forever, nothing more was needed than a single step in the palace, a single breath of favor, a smile from the queen, a look from the king.

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Raoul had no sooner pronounced this latter word, than La Valliere became as pale as death, no doubt from fear at seeing the young man excite himself. With a movement as rapid as thought, she placed both her hands in those of Raoul, and then fled, without adding a syllable; disappearing without casting a look behind her. Raoul felt his whole frame tremble at the contact of her hand; he received the compact as a solemn bargain wrung by affection from her childlike timidity.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Raoul quitted the Palais Royal full of ideas that admitted no delay in execution. He mounted his horse in the courtyard, and followed the road to Blois, while the marriage festivities of Monsieur and the princess of England were being celebrated with exceeding animation by the courtiers, but to the despair of De Guiche and Buckingham. Raoul lost no time on the road, and in sixteen hours he arrived at Blois. As he traveled along, he marshaled his arguments in the most becoming manner. Fever is an argument that cannot be answered, and Raoul had an attack. Athos was in his study, making additions to his memoirs, when Raoul entered, accompanied by Grimaud. Keensighted and penetrating, a mere glance at his son told him that something extraordinary had befallen him.
