children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: You seem to come on a matter of importance, said he to Raoul, after he had embraced him, pointing to a seat.
children.prevalue: You seem to come on a matter of importance said he to Raoul after he had embraced him pointing to a seat

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Yes, monsieur, replied the young man; and I entreat you to give me the same kind attention that has never yet failed me.
children.prevalue: Yes monsieur replied the young man and I entreat you to give me the same kind attention that has never yet failed me

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Speak, Raoul.
children.prevalue: Speak Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: I present the case to you, monsieur, free from all preface, for that would be unworthy of you. Mademoiselle de la Valliere is in Paris as one of Madame's maids of honor. I have pondered deeply on the matter; I love Mademoiselle de la Valliere above everything; and it is not proper to leave her in a position where her reputation, her virtue even, may be assailed. It is my wish, therefore, to marry her, monsieur, and I have come to solicit your consent to my marriage.
children.prevalue: I present the case to you monsieur free from all preface for that would be unworthy of you Mademoiselle de la Valliere is in Paris as one of Madame s maids of honor I have pondered deeply on the matter I love Mademoiselle de la Valliere above everything and it is not proper to leave her in a position where her reputation her virtue even may be assailed It is my wish therefore to marry her monsieur and I have come to solicit your consent to my marriage

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: While this communication was being made to him, Athos maintained the profoundest silence and reserve. Raoul, who had begun his address with an assumption of selfpossession, finished it by allowing a manifest emotion to escape him at every word. Athos fixed upon Bragelonne a searching look, overshadowed indeed by a slight sadness.
children.prevalue: While this communication was being made to him Athos maintained the profoundest silence and reserve Raoul who had begun his address with an assumption of selfpossession finished it by allowing a manifest emotion to escape him at every word Athos fixed upon Bragelonne a searching look overshadowed indeed by a slight sadness

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: You have reflected well upon it? he inquired.
children.prevalue: You have reflected well upon it he inquired

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Yes, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Yes monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: I believe you are already acquainted with my views respecting this alliance?
children.prevalue: I believe you are already acquainted with my views respecting this alliance

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Yes, monsieur, replied Raoul, in a low tone of voice; but you added, that if I persisted
children.prevalue: Yes monsieur replied Raoul in a low tone of voice but you added that if I persisted

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: You do persist, then?
children.prevalue: You do persist then

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Raoul stammered out an almost unintelligible assent.
children.prevalue: Raoul stammered out an almost unintelligible assent

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Your passion, continued Athos, tranquilly, must indeed be very great, since, notwithstanding my dislike to this union, you persist in wanting it.
children.prevalue: Your passion continued Athos tranquilly must indeed be very great since notwithstanding my dislike to this union you persist in wanting it

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Raoul passed his hand trembling across his forehead to remove the perspiration that collected there. Athos looked at him, and his heart was touched by pity. He rose and said,
children.prevalue: Raoul passed his hand trembling across his forehead to remove the perspiration that collected there Athos looked at him and his heart was touched by pity He rose and said

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: It is no matter. My own personal feelings are not to be taken into consideration since yours are concerned; I am ready to give it. Tell me what you want.
children.prevalue: It is no matter My own personal feelings are not to be taken into consideration since yours are concerned I am ready to give it Tell me what you want

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Your kind indulgence, first of all, monsieur, said Raoul, taking hold of his hand.
children.prevalue: Your kind indulgence first of all monsieur said Raoul taking hold of his hand

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: You have mistaken my feelings, Raoul, I have more than mere indulgence for you in my heart.
children.prevalue: You have mistaken my feelings Raoul I have more than mere indulgence for you in my heart

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Raoul kissed as devotedly as a lover could have done the hand he held in his own.
children.prevalue: Raoul kissed as devotedly as a lover could have done the hand he held in his own

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Come, come, said Athos, I am quite ready; what do you wish me to sign?
children.prevalue: Come come said Athos I am quite ready what do you wish me to sign

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Nothing whatever, monsieur, only it would be very kind if you would take the trouble to write to the king, to whom I belong, and solicit his majesty's permission for me to marry Mademoiselle de la Valliere.
children.prevalue: Nothing whatever monsieur only it would be very kind if you would take the trouble to write to the king to whom I belong and solicit his majesty s permission for me to marry Mademoiselle de la Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Well thought, Raoul! After, or rather before myself, you have a master to consult, that master being the king; it is loyal in you to submit yourself voluntarily to this double proof; I will grant your request without delay, Raoul.
children.prevalue: Well thought Raoul After or rather before myself you have a master to consult that master being the king it is loyal in you to submit yourself voluntarily to this double proof I will grant your request without delay Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The count approached the window, and leaning out, called to Grimaud, who showed his head from an arbor covered with jasmine, which he was occupied in trimming.
children.prevalue: The count approached the window and leaning out called to Grimaud who showed his head from an arbor covered with jasmine which he was occupied in trimming

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: My horses, Grimaud, continued the count.
children.prevalue: My horses Grimaud continued the count

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Why this order, monsieur? inquired Raoul.
children.prevalue: Why this order monsieur inquired Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: We shall set off in a few hours.
children.prevalue: We shall set off in a few hours

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Whither?
children.prevalue: Whither

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: For Paris.
children.prevalue: For Paris

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Paris, monsieur?
children.prevalue: Paris monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Is not the king at Paris?
children.prevalue: Is not the king at Paris

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Well, ought we not to go there?
children.prevalue: Well ought we not to go there

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Yes, monsieur, said Raoul, almost alarmed by this kind condescension. I do not ask you to put yourself to such inconvenience, and a letter merely
children.prevalue: Yes monsieur said Raoul almost alarmed by this kind condescension I do not ask you to put yourself to such inconvenience and a letter merely

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: You mistake my position, Raoul; it is not respectful that a simple gentleman, such as I am, should write to his sovereign. I wish to speak, I ought to speak, to the king, and I will do so. We will go together, Raoul.
children.prevalue: You mistake my position Raoul it is not respectful that a simple gentleman such as I am should write to his sovereign I wish to speak I ought to speak to the king and I will do so We will go together Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: You overpower me with your kindness, monsieur.
children.prevalue: You overpower me with your kindness monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: How do you think his majesty is affected?
children.prevalue: How do you think his majesty is affected

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Towards me, monsieur?
children.prevalue: Towards me monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Excellently well disposed.
children.prevalue: Excellently well disposed

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: You know that to be so? continued the count.
children.prevalue: You know that to be so continued the count

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: The king has himself told me so.
children.prevalue: The king has himself told me so

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: On what occasion?
children.prevalue: On what occasion

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Upon the recommendation of M. d'Artagnan, I believe, and on account of an affair in the Place de Greve, when I had the honor to draw my sword in the king's service. I have reason to believe that, vanity apart, I stand well with his majesty.
children.prevalue: Upon the recommendation of M d Artagnan I believe and on account of an affair in the Place de Greve when I had the honor to draw my sword in the king s service I have reason to believe that vanity apart I stand well with his majesty

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: So much the better.
children.prevalue: So much the better

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: But I entreat you, monsieur, pursued Raoul, not to maintain towards me your present grave and serious manner. Do not make me bitterly regret having listened to a feeling stronger than anything else.
children.prevalue: But I entreat you monsieur pursued Raoul not to maintain towards me your present grave and serious manner Do not make me bitterly regret having listened to a feeling stronger than anything else

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: That is the second time you have said so, Raoul; it was quite unnecessary; you require my formal consent, and you have it. We need talk no more on the subject, therefore. Come and see my new plantations, Raoul.
children.prevalue: That is the second time you have said so Raoul it was quite unnecessary you require my formal consent and you have it We need talk no more on the subject therefore Come and see my new plantations Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: The young man knew very well, that, after the expression of his father's wish, no opportunity of discussion was left him. He bowed his head, and followed his father into the garden. Athos slowly pointed out to him the grafts, the cuttings, and the avenues he was planting. This perfect repose of manner disconcerted Raoul extremely; the affection with which his own heart was filled seemed so great that the whole world could hardly contain it. How, then, could his father's heart remain void, and closed to its influence? Bragelonne, therefore, collecting all his courage, suddenly exclaimed,
children.prevalue: The young man knew very well that after the expression of his father s wish no opportunity of discussion was left him He bowed his head and followed his father into the garden Athos slowly pointed out to him the grafts the cuttings and the avenues he was planting This perfect repose of manner disconcerted Raoul extremely the affection with which his own heart was filled seemed so great that the whole world could hardly contain it How then could his father s heart remain void and closed to its influence Bragelonne therefore collecting all his courage suddenly exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: It is impossible, monsieur, you can have any reason to reject Mademoiselle de la Valliere! In Heaven's name, she is so good, so gentle and pure, that your mind, so perfect in its penetration, ought to appreciate her accordingly. Does any secret repugnance, or any hereditary dislike, exist between you and her family?
children.prevalue: It is impossible monsieur you can have any reason to reject Mademoiselle de la Valliere In Heaven s name she is so good so gentle and pure that your mind so perfect in its penetration ought to appreciate her accordingly Does any secret repugnance or any hereditary dislike exist between you and her family

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Look, Raoul, at that beautiful lily of the valley, said Athos; observe how the shade and the damp situation suit it, particularly the shadow which that sycamoretree casts over it, so that the warmth, and not the blazing heat of the sun, filters through its leaves.
children.prevalue: Look Raoul at that beautiful lily of the valley said Athos observe how the shade and the damp situation suit it particularly the shadow which that sycamoretree casts over it so that the warmth and not the blazing heat of the sun filters through its leaves

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Raoul stopped, bit his lips, and then, with the blood mantling in his face, he said, courageously,One word of explanation, I beg, monsieur. You cannot forget that your son is a man.
children.prevalue: Raoul stopped bit his lips and then with the blood mantling in his face he said courageously One word of explanation I beg monsieur You cannot forget that your son is a man

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: In that case, replied Athos, drawing himself up with sternness, prove to me that you are a man, for you do not show yourself a son. I begged you to wait the opportunity of forming an illustrious alliance. I would have obtained a wife for you from the first ranks of the rich nobility. I wish you to be distinguished by the splendor which glory and fortune confer, for nobility of descent you have already.
children.prevalue: In that case replied Athos drawing himself up with sternness prove to me that you are a man for you do not show yourself a son I begged you to wait the opportunity of forming an illustrious alliance I would have obtained a wife for you from the first ranks of the rich nobility I wish you to be distinguished by the splendor which glory and fortune confer for nobility of descent you have already

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Monsieur, exclaimed Raoul, carried away by a first impulse. I was reproached the other day for not knowing who my mother was.
children.prevalue: Monsieur exclaimed Raoul carried away by a first impulse I was reproached the other day for not knowing who my mother was

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Athos turned pale; then, knitting his brows like the greatest of all the heathen deities:I am waiting to learn the reply you made, he demanded, in an imperious manner.
children.prevalue: Athos turned pale then knitting his brows like the greatest of all the heathen deities I am waiting to learn the reply you made he demanded in an imperious manner

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Forgive me! oh, forgive me, murmured the young man, sinking at once from the lofty tone he had assumed.
children.prevalue: Forgive me oh forgive me murmured the young man sinking at once from the lofty tone he had assumed

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: What was your reply, monsieur? inquired the count, stamping his feet upon the ground.
children.prevalue: What was your reply monsieur inquired the count stamping his feet upon the ground

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Monsieur, my sword was in my hand immediately, my adversary placed himself on guard, I struck his sword over the palisade, and threw him after it.
children.prevalue: Monsieur my sword was in my hand immediately my adversary placed himself on guard I struck his sword over the palisade and threw him after it

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Why did you suffer him to live?
children.prevalue: Why did you suffer him to live

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: The king has prohibited duelling, and, at the moment, I was an ambassador of the king.
children.prevalue: The king has prohibited duelling and at the moment I was an ambassador of the king

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Very well, said Athos, but all the greater reason I should see his majesty.
children.prevalue: Very well said Athos but all the greater reason I should see his majesty

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: What do you intend to ask him?
children.prevalue: What do you intend to ask him

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Authority to draw my sword against the man who has inflicted this injury upon me.
children.prevalue: Authority to draw my sword against the man who has inflicted this injury upon me

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: If I did not act as I ought to have done, I beg you to forgive me.
children.prevalue: If I did not act as I ought to have done I beg you to forgive me

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Did I reproach you, Raoul?
children.prevalue: Did I reproach you Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Still, the permission you are going to ask from the king?
children.prevalue: Still the permission you are going to ask from the king

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: I will implore his majesty to sign your marriagecontract, but on one condition.
children.prevalue: I will implore his majesty to sign your marriagecontract but on one condition

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Are conditions necessary with me, monsieur? Command, and you shall be obeyed.
children.prevalue: Are conditions necessary with me monsieur Command and you shall be obeyed

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: On the condition, I repeat, continued Athos; that you tell me the name of the man who spoke of your mother in that way.
children.prevalue: On the condition I repeat continued Athos that you tell me the name of the man who spoke of your mother in that way

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: What need is there that you should know his name; the offense was directed against myself, and the permission once obtained from his majesty, to revenge it is my affair.
children.prevalue: What need is there that you should know his name the offense was directed against myself and the permission once obtained from his majesty to revenge it is my affair

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Tell me his name, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Tell me his name monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: I will not allow you to expose yourself.
children.prevalue: I will not allow you to expose yourself

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Do you take me for a Don Diego? His name, I say.
children.prevalue: Do you take me for a Don Diego His name I say

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: You insist upon it?
children.prevalue: You insist upon it

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: I demand it.
children.prevalue: I demand it

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: The Vicomte de Wardes.
children.prevalue: The Vicomte de Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Very well, said Athos, tranquilly, I know him. But our horses are ready, I see; and, instead of delaying our departure for a couple of hours, we will set off at once. Come, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Very well said Athos tranquilly I know him But our horses are ready I see and instead of delaying our departure for a couple of hours we will set off at once Come monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: While the Comte de la Fere was proceeding on his way to Pairs, accompanied by Raoul, the Palais Royal was the theatre wherein a scene of what Moliere would have called excellent comedy, was being performed. Four days had elapsed since his marriage, and Monsieur, having breakfasted very hurriedly, passed into his antechamber, frowning and out of temper. The repast had not been overagreeable. Madame had had breakfast served in her own apartment, and Monsieur had breakfasted almost alone; the Chevalier de Lorraine and Manicamp were the only persons present at the meal, which lasted threequarters of an hour without a single syllable having been uttered. Manicamp, who was less intimate with his royal highness than the Chevalier de Lorraine, vainly endeavored to detect, from the expression of the prince's face, what had made him so illhumored. The Chevalier de Lorraine, who had no occasion to speculate about anything, inasmuch as he knew all, ate his breakfast with that extraordinary appetite which the troubles of one's friends but stimulates, and enjoyed at the same time both Monsieur's illhumor and the vexation of Manicamp. He seemed delighted, while he went on eating, to detain a prince, who was very impatient to move, still at table. Monsieur at times repented the ascendency which he had permitted the Chevalier de Lorraine to acquire over him, and which exempted the latter from any observance of etiquette towards him. Monsieur was now in one of those moods, but he dreaded as much as he liked the chevalier, and contented himself with nursing his anger without betraying it. Every now and then Monsieur raised his eyes to the ceiling, then lowered them towards the slices of pate which the chevalier was attacking, and finally, not caring to betray the resentment, he gesticulated in a manner which Harlequin might have envied. At last, however, Monsieur could control himself no longer, and at the dessert, rising from the table in excessive wrath, as we have related, he left the Chevalier de Lorraine to finish his breakfast as he pleased. Seeing Monsieur rise from the table, Manicamp, napkin in hand, rose also. Monsieur ran rather than walked, towards the antechamber, where, noticing an usher in attendance, he gave him some directions in a low tone of voice. Then, turning back again, but avoiding passing through the breakfast apartment, he crossed several rooms, with the intention of seeking the queenmother in her oratory, where she usually remained.

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: It was about ten o'clock in the morning. Anne of Austria was engaged in writing as Monsieur entered. The queenmother was extremely attached to her son, for he was handsome in person and amiable in disposition. He was, in fact, more affectionate, and it might be, more effeminate than the king. He pleased his mother by those trifling sympathizing attentions all women are glad to receive. Anne of Austria, who would have been rejoiced to have had a daughter, almost found in this, her favorite son, the attentions, solicitude, and playful manners of a child of twelve years of age. All the time he passed with his mother he employed in admiring her arms, in giving his opinion upon her cosmetics, and recipes for compounding essences, in which she was very particular; and then, too, he kissed her hands and cheeks in the most childlike and endearing manner, and had always some sweetmeats to offer her, or some new style of dress to recommend. Anne of Austria loved the king, or rather the regal power in her eldest son; Louis XIV. represented legitimacy by right divine. With the king, her character was that of the queenmother, with Philip she was simply the mother. The latter knew that, of all places, a mother's heart is the most compassionate and surest. When quite a child he always fled there for refuge when he and his brother quarreled, often, after having struck him, which constituted the crime of high treason on his part, after certain engagements with hands and nails, in which the king and his rebellious subject indulged in their nightdresses respecting the right to a disputed bed, having their servant Laporte as umpire,Philip, conqueror, but terrified at victory, used to flee to his mother to obtain reinforcements from her, or at least the assurance of forgiveness, which Louis XIV. granted with difficulty, and after an interval. Anne, from this habit of peaceable intervention, succeeded in arranging the disputes of her sons, and in sharing, at the same time, all their secrets. The king, somewhat jealous of that maternal solicitude which was bestowed particularly on his brother, felt disposed to show towards Anne of Austria more submission and attachment than his character really dictated. Anne of Austria had adopted this line of conduct especially towards the young queen. In this manner she ruled with almost despotic sway over the royal household, and she was already preparing her batteries to govern with the same absolute authority the household of her second son. Anne experienced almost a feeling of pride whenever she saw any one enter her apartment with woebegone looks, pale cheeks, or red eyes, gathering from appearances that assistance was required either by the weakest or the most rebellious. She was writing, we have said, when Monsieur entered her oratory, not with red eyes or pale cheeks, but restless, out of temper, and annoyed. With an absent air he kissed his mother's hands, and sat himself down before receiving her permission to do so. Considering the strict rules of etiquette established at the court of Anne of Austria, this forgetfulness of customary civilities was a sign of preoccupation, especially on Philip's part, who, of his own accord, observed a respect towards her of a somewhat exaggerated character. If, therefore, he so notoriously failed in this regard, there must be a serious cause for it.

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: What is the matter, Philip? inquired Anne of Austria, turning towards her son.
children.prevalue: What is the matter Philip inquired Anne of Austria turning towards her son

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: A good many things, murmured the prince, in a doleful tone of voice.
children.prevalue: A good many things murmured the prince in a doleful tone of voice

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: You look like a man who has a great deal to do, said the queen, laying down her pen. Philip frowned, but did not reply. Among the various subjects which occupy your mind, said Anne of Austria, there must surely be one that absorbs it more than others.
children.prevalue: You look like a man who has a great deal to do said the queen laying down her pen Philip frowned but did not reply Among the various subjects which occupy your mind said Anne of Austria there must surely be one that absorbs it more than others

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: One has indeed occupied me more than any other.
children.prevalue: One has indeed occupied me more than any other

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Well, what is it? I am listening.
children.prevalue: Well what is it I am listening

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Philip opened his mouth as if to express all the troubles his mind was filled with, and which he seemed to be waiting only for an opportunity of declaring. But he suddenly became silent, and a sigh alone expressed all that his heart was overflowing with.
children.prevalue: Philip opened his mouth as if to express all the troubles his mind was filled with and which he seemed to be waiting only for an opportunity of declaring But he suddenly became silent and a sigh alone expressed all that his heart was overflowing with

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Come, Philip, show a little firmness, said the queenmother. When one has to complain of anything, it is generally an individual who is the cause of it. Am I not right?
children.prevalue: Come Philip show a little firmness said the queenmother When one has to complain of anything it is generally an individual who is the cause of it Am I not right

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I do not say no, madame.
children.prevalue: I do not say no madame

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Whom do you wish to speak about? Come, take courage.
children.prevalue: Whom do you wish to speak about Come take courage

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: In fact, madame, what I might possibly have to say must be kept a profound secret; for when a lady is in the case
children.prevalue: In fact madame what I might possibly have to say must be kept a profound secret for when a lady is in the case

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Ah! you are speaking of Madame, then? inquired the queenmother, with a feeling of the liveliest curiosity.
children.prevalue: Ah you are speaking of Madame then inquired the queenmother with a feeling of the liveliest curiosity

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Well, then, if you wish to speak of Madame, do not hesitate to do so. I am your mother, and she is no more than a stranger to me. Yet, as she is my daughterinlaw, rest assured I shall be interested, even were it for your own sake alone, in hearing all you may have to say about her.
children.prevalue: Well then if you wish to speak of Madame do not hesitate to do so I am your mother and she is no more than a stranger to me Yet as she is my daughterinlaw rest assured I shall be interested even were it for your own sake alone in hearing all you may have to say about her

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Pray tell me, madame, in your turn, whether you have not remarked something?
children.prevalue: Pray tell me madame in your turn whether you have not remarked something

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'Something'! Philip? Your words almost frighten me, from their want of meaning. What do you mean by 'something?'
children.prevalue: Something Philip Your words almost frighten me from their want of meaning What do you mean by something

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Madame is pretty, certainly.
children.prevalue: Madame is pretty certainly

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: No doubt of it.
children.prevalue: No doubt of it

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Yet not altogether beautiful.
children.prevalue: Yet not altogether beautiful

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: No, but as she grows older, she will probably become strikingly beautiful. You must have remarked the change which a few years have already made in her. Her beauty will improve more and more; she is now only sixteen years of age. At fifteen I was, myself, very thin; but even as she is at present, Madame is very pretty.
children.prevalue: No but as she grows older she will probably become strikingly beautiful You must have remarked the change which a few years have already made in her Her beauty will improve more and more she is now only sixteen years of age At fifteen I was myself very thin but even as she is at present Madame is very pretty

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: And consequently others have remarked it.
children.prevalue: And consequently others have remarked it

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Undoubtedly, for a woman of ordinary rank is noticedand with still greater reason a princess.
children.prevalue: Undoubtedly for a woman of ordinary rank is noticedand with still greater reason a princess

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: She has been well brought up, I suppose?
children.prevalue: She has been well brought up I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Madame Henriette, her mother, is a woman somewhat cold in manner, slightly pretentious, but full of noble thoughts. The princess's education may have been neglected, but her principles, I believe, are good. Such at least was the opinion I formed of her when she resided in France; but she afterwards returned to England, and I am ignorant what may have occurred there.
children.prevalue: Madame Henriette her mother is a woman somewhat cold in manner slightly pretentious but full of noble thoughts The princess s education may have been neglected but her principles I believe are good Such at least was the opinion I formed of her when she resided in France but she afterwards returned to England and I am ignorant what may have occurred there

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: What do you mean?
children.prevalue: What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Simply that there are some heads naturally giddy, which are easily turned by prosperity.
children.prevalue: Simply that there are some heads naturally giddy which are easily turned by prosperity

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: That is the very word, madame. I think the princess rather giddy.
children.prevalue: That is the very word madame I think the princess rather giddy

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: We must not exaggerate, Philip; she is clever and witty, and has a certain amount of coquetry very natural in a young woman; but this defect in persons of high rank and position, is a great advantage at a court. A princess who is tinged with coquetry usually forms a brilliant court; her smile stimulates luxury, arouses wit, and even courage; the nobles, too, fight better for a prince whose wife is beautiful.
children.prevalue: We must not exaggerate Philip she is clever and witty and has a certain amount of coquetry very natural in a young woman but this defect in persons of high rank and position is a great advantage at a court A princess who is tinged with coquetry usually forms a brilliant court her smile stimulates luxury arouses wit and even courage the nobles too fight better for a prince whose wife is beautiful

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Thank you extremely, madame, said Philip, with some temper; you really have drawn some very alarming pictures for me.
children.prevalue: Thank you extremely madame said Philip with some temper you really have drawn some very alarming pictures for me

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: In what respect? asked the queen, with pretended simplicity.
children.prevalue: In what respect asked the queen with pretended simplicity

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: You know, madame, said Philip, dolefully, whether I had or had not a very great dislike to getting married.
children.prevalue: You know madame said Philip dolefully whether I had or had not a very great dislike to getting married

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Now, indeed, you alarm me. You have some serious cause of complaint against Madame.
children.prevalue: Now indeed you alarm me You have some serious cause of complaint against Madame

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: I do not precisely say it is serious.
children.prevalue: I do not precisely say it is serious

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: In that case, then, throw aside your doleful looks. If you show yourself to others in your present state, people will take you for a very unhappy husband.
children.prevalue: In that case then throw aside your doleful looks If you show yourself to others in your present state people will take you for a very unhappy husband

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The fact is, replied Philip, I am not altogether satisfied as a husband, and I shall not be sorry if others know it.
children.prevalue: The fact is replied Philip I am not altogether satisfied as a husband and I shall not be sorry if others know it

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: For shame, Philip.
children.prevalue: For shame Philip

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Well, then, madame, I will tell you frankly that I do not understand the life I am required to lead.
children.prevalue: Well then madame I will tell you frankly that I do not understand the life I am required to lead

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Explain yourself.
children.prevalue: Explain yourself

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: My wife does not seem to belong to me; she is always leaving me for some reason or another. In the mornings there are visits, correspondences, and toilettes; in the evenings, balls and concerts.
children.prevalue: My wife does not seem to belong to me she is always leaving me for some reason or another In the mornings there are visits correspondences and toilettes in the evenings balls and concerts

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: You are jealous, Philip.
children.prevalue: You are jealous Philip

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: I! Heaven forbid. Let others act the part of a jealous husband, not I. But I am annoyed.
children.prevalue: I Heaven forbid Let others act the part of a jealous husband not I But I am annoyed

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: All these things you reproach your wife with are perfectly innocent, and, so long as you have nothing of greater importance
children.prevalue: All these things you reproach your wife with are perfectly innocent and so long as you have nothing of greater importance

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Yet, listen; without being very blamable, a woman can excite a good deal of uneasiness. Certain visitors may be received, certain preferences shown, which expose young women to remark, and which are enough to drive out of their senses even those husbands who are least disposed to be jealous.
children.prevalue: Yet listen without being very blamable a woman can excite a good deal of uneasiness Certain visitors may be received certain preferences shown which expose young women to remark and which are enough to drive out of their senses even those husbands who are least disposed to be jealous

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Ah! now we are coming to the real point at last, and not without some difficulty. You speak of frequent visits, and certain preferencesvery good; for the last hour we have been beating about the bush, and at last you have broached the true question.
children.prevalue: Ah now we are coming to the real point at last and not without some difficulty You speak of frequent visits and certain preferencesvery good for the last hour we have been beating about the bush and at last you have broached the true question

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Well then, yes
children.prevalue: Well then yes

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: This is more serious than I thought. It is possible, then, that Madame can have given you grounds for these complaints against her?
children.prevalue: This is more serious than I thought It is possible then that Madame can have given you grounds for these complaints against her

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Precisely so.
children.prevalue: Precisely so

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: What, your wife, married only four days ago, prefers some other person to yourself? Take care, Philip, you exaggerate your grievances; in wishing to prove everything, you prove nothing.
children.prevalue: What your wife married only four days ago prefers some other person to yourself Take care Philip you exaggerate your grievances in wishing to prove everything you prove nothing

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: The prince, bewildered by his mother's serious manner, wished to reply, but he could only stammer out some unintelligible words.
children.prevalue: The prince bewildered by his mother s serious manner wished to reply but he could only stammer out some unintelligible words

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: You draw back, then? said Anne of Austria. I prefer that, as it is an acknowledgement of your mistake.
children.prevalue: You draw back then said Anne of Austria I prefer that as it is an acknowledgement of your mistake

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: No! exclaimed Philip, I do not draw back, and I will prove all I asserted. I spoke of preference and of visits, did I not? Well, listen.
children.prevalue: No exclaimed Philip I do not draw back and I will prove all I asserted I spoke of preference and of visits did I not Well listen

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Anne of Austria prepared herself to listen, with that love of gossip which the best woman living and the best mother, were she a queen even, always finds in being mixed up with the petty squabbles of a household.
children.prevalue: Anne of Austria prepared herself to listen with that love of gossip which the best woman living and the best mother were she a queen even always finds in being mixed up with the petty squabbles of a household

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Well, said Philip, tell me one thing.
children.prevalue: Well said Philip tell me one thing

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: What is that?
children.prevalue: What is that

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Why does my wife retain an English court about her? said Philip, as he crossed his arms and looked his mother steadily in the face, as if he were convinced that she could not answer the question.
children.prevalue: Why does my wife retain an English court about her said Philip as he crossed his arms and looked his mother steadily in the face as if he were convinced that she could not answer the question

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: For a very simple reason, returned Anne of Austria; because the English are her countrymen, because they have expended large sums in order to accompany her to France, and because it would hardly be polite not politic, certainlyto dismiss abruptly those members of the English nobility who have not shrunk from any devotion or sacrifice.
children.prevalue: For a very simple reason returned Anne of Austria because the English are her countrymen because they have expended large sums in order to accompany her to France and because it would hardly be polite not politic certainlyto dismiss abruptly those members of the English nobility who have not shrunk from any devotion or sacrifice

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: A wonderful sacrifice indeed, returned Philip, to desert a wretched country to come to a beautiful one, where a greater effect can be produced for a guinea that can be procured elsewhere for four! Extraordinary devotion, really, to travel a hundred leagues in company with a woman one is in love with!
children.prevalue: A wonderful sacrifice indeed returned Philip to desert a wretched country to come to a beautiful one where a greater effect can be produced for a guinea that can be procured elsewhere for four Extraordinary devotion really to travel a hundred leagues in company with a woman one is in love with

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: In love, Philip! think what you are saying. Who is in love with Madame?
children.prevalue: In love Philip think what you are saying Who is in love with Madame

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: The Duke of Buckingham. Perhaps you will defend him, too?
children.prevalue: The Duke of Buckingham Perhaps you will defend him too

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Anne of Austria blushed and smiled at the same time. The name of the Duke of Buckingham recalled certain recollections of a very tender and melancholy nature. The Duke of Buckingham? she murmured.
children.prevalue: Anne of Austria blushed and smiled at the same time The name of the Duke of Buckingham recalled certain recollections of a very tender and melancholy nature The Duke of Buckingham she murmured

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Yes; one of those armchair soldiers
children.prevalue: Yes one of those armchair soldiers

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: The Buckinghams are loyal and brave, said Anne of Austria, courageously.
children.prevalue: The Buckinghams are loyal and brave said Anne of Austria courageously

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: This is too bad; my own mother takes the part of my wife's lover against me, exclaimed Philip, incensed to such an extent that his weak organization was affected almost to tears.
children.prevalue: This is too bad my own mother takes the part of my wife s lover against me exclaimed Philip incensed to such an extent that his weak organization was affected almost to tears

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Philip, my son, exclaimed Anne of Austria, such an expression is unworthy of you. Your wife has no lover; and, had she one, it would not be the Duke of Buckingham. The members of that family, I repeat, are loyal and discreet, and the rights of hospitality are sure to be respected by them.
children.prevalue: Philip my son exclaimed Anne of Austria such an expression is unworthy of you Your wife has no lover and had she one it would not be the Duke of Buckingham The members of that family I repeat are loyal and discreet and the rights of hospitality are sure to be respected by them

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: The Duke of Buckingham is an Englishman, madame, said Philip, and may I ask if the English so very religiously respect what belongs to princes of France?
children.prevalue: The Duke of Buckingham is an Englishman madame said Philip and may I ask if the English so very religiously respect what belongs to princes of France

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Anne blushed a second time, and turned aside under the pretext of taking her pen from her desk again, but in reality to conceal her confusion from her son. Really, Philip, she said, you seem to discover expressions for the purpose of embarrassing me, and your anger blinds you while it alarms me; reflect a little.
children.prevalue: Anne blushed a second time and turned aside under the pretext of taking her pen from her desk again but in reality to conceal her confusion from her son Really Philip she said you seem to discover expressions for the purpose of embarrassing me and your anger blinds you while it alarms me reflect a little

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: There is no need for reflection, madame. I can see with my own eyes.
children.prevalue: There is no need for reflection madame I can see with my own eyes

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Well, and what do you see?
children.prevalue: Well and what do you see

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: That Buckingham never quits my wife. He presumes to make presents to her, and she ventures to accept them. Yesterday she was talking about sauchets a la violette; well, our French perfumers, you know very well, madame, for you have over and over again asked for it without successour French perfumers, I say, have never been able to procure this scent. The duke, however, wore about him a sachet a la violette, and I am sure that the one my wife has came from him.
children.prevalue: That Buckingham never quits my wife He presumes to make presents to her and she ventures to accept them Yesterday she was talking about sauchets a la violette well our French perfumers you know very well madame for you have over and over again asked for it without successour French perfumers I say have never been able to procure this scent The duke however wore about him a sachet a la violette and I am sure that the one my wife has came from him

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Indeed, monsieur, said Anne of Austria, you build your pyramids on needle points; be careful. What harm, I ask you, can there be in a man giving to his countrywoman a recipe for a new essence? These strange ideas, I protest, painfully recall your father to me; he who so frequently and so unjustly made me suffer.
children.prevalue: Indeed monsieur said Anne of Austria you build your pyramids on needle points be careful What harm I ask you can there be in a man giving to his countrywoman a recipe for a new essence These strange ideas I protest painfully recall your father to me he who so frequently and so unjustly made me suffer

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: The Duke of Buckingham's father was probably more reserved and more respectful than his son, said Philip, thoughtlessly, not perceiving how deeply he had wounded his mother's feelings. The queen turned pale, and pressed her clenched hands upon her bosom; but, recovering herself immediately, she said, You came here with some intention or another, I suppose?
children.prevalue: The Duke of Buckingham s father was probably more reserved and more respectful than his son said Philip thoughtlessly not perceiving how deeply he had wounded his mother s feelings The queen turned pale and pressed her clenched hands upon her bosom but recovering herself immediately she said You came here with some intention or another I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: What was it?
children.prevalue: What was it

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: I came, madame, intending to complain energetically, and to inform you that I will not submit to such behavior from the Duke of Buckingham.
children.prevalue: I came madame intending to complain energetically and to inform you that I will not submit to such behavior from the Duke of Buckingham

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: What do you intend to do, then?
children.prevalue: What do you intend to do then

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: I shall complain to the king.
children.prevalue: I shall complain to the king

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: And what do you expect the king to reply?
children.prevalue: And what do you expect the king to reply

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Very well, then, said Monsieur, with an expression of stern determination on his countenance, which offered a singular contrast to its usual gentleness. Very well. I will right myself!
children.prevalue: Very well then said Monsieur with an expression of stern determination on his countenance which offered a singular contrast to its usual gentleness Very well I will right myself

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: What do you call righting yourself? inquired Anne of Austria, in alarm.
children.prevalue: What do you call righting yourself inquired Anne of Austria in alarm

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: I will have the Duke of Buckingham quit the princess, I will have him quit France, and I will see that my wishes are intimated to him.
children.prevalue: I will have the Duke of Buckingham quit the princess I will have him quit France and I will see that my wishes are intimated to him

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: You will intimate nothing of the kind, Philip, said the queen, for if you act in that manner, and violate hospitality to that extent, I will invoke the severity of the king against you.
children.prevalue: You will intimate nothing of the kind Philip said the queen for if you act in that manner and violate hospitality to that extent I will invoke the severity of the king against you

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Do you threaten me, madame? exclaimed Philip, almost in tears; do you threaten me in the midst of my complaints?
children.prevalue: Do you threaten me madame exclaimed Philip almost in tears do you threaten me in the midst of my complaints

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: I do not threaten you; I do but place an obstacle in the path of your hasty anger. I maintain, that, to adopt towards the Duke of Buckingham, or any other Englishman, any rigorous measureto take even a discourteous step towards him, would be to plunge France and England into the most disastrous disagreement. Can it be possible that a prince of the blood, the brother of the king of France, does not know how to hide an injury, even did it exist in reality, where political necessity requires it? Philip made a movement. Besides, continued the queen, the injury is neither true nor possible, and it is merely a matter of silly jealousy.
children.prevalue: I do not threaten you I do but place an obstacle in the path of your hasty anger I maintain that to adopt towards the Duke of Buckingham or any other Englishman any rigorous measureto take even a discourteous step towards him would be to plunge France and England into the most disastrous disagreement Can it be possible that a prince of the blood the brother of the king of France does not know how to hide an injury even did it exist in reality where political necessity requires it Philip made a movement Besides continued the queen the injury is neither true nor possible and it is merely a matter of silly jealousy

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Madame, I know what I know.
children.prevalue: Madame I know what I know

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Whatever you may know, I can only advise you to be patient.
children.prevalue: Whatever you may know I can only advise you to be patient

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: I am not patient by disposition, madame.
children.prevalue: I am not patient by disposition madame

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: The queen rose, full of severity, and with an icy ceremonious manner. Explain what you really require, monsieur, she said.
children.prevalue: The queen rose full of severity and with an icy ceremonious manner Explain what you really require monsieur she said

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: I do not require anything, madame; I simply express what I desire. If the Duke of Buckingham does not, of his own accord, discontinue his visits to my apartments I shall forbid him entrance.
children.prevalue: I do not require anything madame I simply express what I desire If the Duke of Buckingham does not of his own accord discontinue his visits to my apartments I shall forbid him entrance

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: That is a point you will refer to the king, said Anne of Austria, her heart swelling as she spoke, and her voice trembling with emotion.
children.prevalue: That is a point you will refer to the king said Anne of Austria her heart swelling as she spoke and her voice trembling with emotion

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: But, madame, exclaimed Philip, striking his hands together, act as my mother and not as the queen, since I speak to you as a son; it is simply a matter of a few minutes' conversation between the duke and myself.
children.prevalue: But madame exclaimed Philip striking his hands together act as my mother and not as the queen since I speak to you as a son it is simply a matter of a few minutes conversation between the duke and myself

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: It is that very conversation I forbid, said the queen, resuming her authority, because it is unworthy of you.
children.prevalue: It is that very conversation I forbid said the queen resuming her authority because it is unworthy of you

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Be it so; I will not appear in the matter, but I shall intimate my will to Madame.
children.prevalue: Be it so I will not appear in the matter but I shall intimate my will to Madame

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Oh! said the queenmother, with a melancholy arising from reflection, never tyrannize over a wifenever behave too haughtily or imperiously towards your own. A woman unwillingly convinced, is unconvinced.
children.prevalue: Oh said the queenmother with a melancholy arising from reflection never tyrannize over a wifenever behave too haughtily or imperiously towards your own A woman unwillingly convinced is unconvinced

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: What is to be done, then?I will consult my friends about it.
children.prevalue: What is to be done then I will consult my friends about it

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Yes, your doubledealing advisers, your Chevalier de Lorraineyour De Wardes. Intrust the conduct of this affair to me. You wish the Duke of Buckingham to leave, do you not?
children.prevalue: Yes your doubledealing advisers your Chevalier de Lorraineyour De Wardes Intrust the conduct of this affair to me You wish the Duke of Buckingham to leave do you not

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: As soon as possible, madame.
children.prevalue: As soon as possible madame

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Send the duke to me, then; smile upon your wife, behave to her, to the king, to every one, as usual. But follow no advice but mine. Alas! I too well know what any household comes to, that is troubled by advisers.
children.prevalue: Send the duke to me then smile upon your wife behave to her to the king to every one as usual But follow no advice but mine Alas I too well know what any household comes to that is troubled by advisers

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: You shall be obeyed, madame.
children.prevalue: You shall be obeyed madame

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: And you will be satisfied at the result. Send the duke to me.
children.prevalue: And you will be satisfied at the result Send the duke to me

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: That will not be difficult.
children.prevalue: That will not be difficult

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Where do you suppose him to be?
children.prevalue: Where do you suppose him to be

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: At my wife's door, whose levee he is probably awaiting.
children.prevalue: At my wife s door whose levee he is probably awaiting

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Very well, said Anne of Austria, calmly. Be good enough to tell the duke that I shall be charmed if he will pay me a visit.
children.prevalue: Very well said Anne of Austria calmly Be good enough to tell the duke that I shall be charmed if he will pay me a visit

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Philip kissed his mother's hand, and started off to find the Duke of Buckingham.
children.prevalue: Philip kissed his mother s hand and started off to find the Duke of Buckingham

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The Duke of Buckingham, obedient to the queenmother's invitation, presented himself in her apartments half an hour after the departure of the Duc d'Orleans. When his name was announced by the gentlemanusher in attendance, the queen, who was sitting with her elbow resting on a table, and her head buried in her hands, rose, and smilingly received the graceful and respectful salutation which the duke addressed to her. Anne of Austria was still beautiful. It is well known that at her then somewhat advanced age, her long auburn hair, perfectly formed hands, and bright ruby lips, were still the admiration of all who saw her. On the present occasion, abandoned entirely to a remembrance which evoked all the past in her heart, she looked almost as beautiful as in the days of her youth, when her palace was open to the visits of the Duke of Buckingham's father, then a young and impassioned man, as well as an unfortunate prince, who lived for her alone, and died with her name upon his lips. Anne of Austria fixed upon Buckingham a look so tender in its expression, that it denoted, not alone the indulgence of maternal affection, but a gentleness of expression like the coquetry of a woman who loves.
children.prevalue: The Duke of Buckingham obedient to the queenmother s invitation presented himself in her apartments half an hour after the departure of the Duc d Orleans When his name was announced by the gentlemanusher in attendance the queen who was sitting with her elbow resting on a table and her head buried in her hands rose and smilingly received the graceful and respectful salutation which the duke addressed to her Anne of Austria was still beautiful It is well known that at her then somewhat advanced age her long auburn hair perfectly formed hands and bright ruby lips were still the admiration of all who saw her On the present occasion abandoned entirely to a remembrance which evoked all the past in her heart she looked almost as beautiful as in the days of her youth when her palace was open to the visits of the Duke of Buckingham s father then a young and impassioned man as well as an unfortunate prince who lived for her alone and died with her name upon his lips Anne of Austria fixed upon Buckingham a look so tender in its expression that it denoted not alone the indulgence of maternal affection but a gentleness of expression like the coquetry of a woman who loves

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Your majesty, said Buckingham, respectfully, desired to speak to me.
children.prevalue: Your majesty said Buckingham respectfully desired to speak to me

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Yes, duke, said the queen, in English; will you be good enough to sit down?
children.prevalue: Yes duke said the queen in English will you be good enough to sit down

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The favor which Anne of Austria thus extended to the young man, and the welcome sound of the language of a country from which the duke had been estranged since his stay in France, deeply affected him. He immediately conjectured that the queen had a request to make of him. After having abandoned the first few moments to the irrepressible emotions she experienced, the queen resumed the smiling air with which she had received him. What do you think of France? she said, in French.
children.prevalue: The favor which Anne of Austria thus extended to the young man and the welcome sound of the language of a country from which the duke had been estranged since his stay in France deeply affected him He immediately conjectured that the queen had a request to make of him After having abandoned the first few moments to the irrepressible emotions she experienced the queen resumed the smiling air with which she had received him What do you think of France she said in French

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: It is a lovely country, madame, replied the duke.
children.prevalue: It is a lovely country madame replied the duke

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Had you ever seen it before?
children.prevalue: Had you ever seen it before

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Once only, madame.
children.prevalue: Once only madame

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: But, like all true Englishmen, you prefer England?
children.prevalue: But like all true Englishmen you prefer England

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: I prefer my own native land to France, replied the duke; but if your majesty were to ask me which of the two cities, London or Pairs, I should prefer as a residence, I should be forced to answer Paris.
children.prevalue: I prefer my own native land to France replied the duke but if your majesty were to ask me which of the two cities London or Pairs I should prefer as a residence I should be forced to answer Paris

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Anne of Austria observed the ardent manner with which these words had been pronounced. I am told, my lord, you have rich possessions in your own country, and that you live in a splendid and timehonored place.
children.prevalue: Anne of Austria observed the ardent manner with which these words had been pronounced I am told my lord you have rich possessions in your own country and that you live in a splendid and timehonored place

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: It was my father's residence, replied Buckingham, casting down his eyes.
children.prevalue: It was my father s residence replied Buckingham casting down his eyes

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Those are indeed great advantages and souvenirs, replied the queen, alluding, in spite of herself, to recollections from which it is impossible voluntarily to detach one's self.
children.prevalue: Those are indeed great advantages and souvenirs replied the queen alluding in spite of herself to recollections from which it is impossible voluntarily to detach one s self

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: In fact, said the duke, yielding to the melancholy influence of this opening conversation, sensitive persons live as much in the past or the future, as in the present.
children.prevalue: In fact said the duke yielding to the melancholy influence of this opening conversation sensitive persons live as much in the past or the future as in the present

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: That is very true, said the queen, in a low tone of voice. It follows, then, my lord, she added, that you, who are a man of feeling, will soon quit France in order to shut yourself up with your wealth and your relics of the past.
children.prevalue: That is very true said the queen in a low tone of voice It follows then my lord she added that you who are a man of feeling will soon quit France in order to shut yourself up with your wealth and your relics of the past

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Buckingham raised his head and said, I think not, madame.
children.prevalue: Buckingham raised his head and said I think not madame

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: What do you mean?
children.prevalue: What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: On the contrary, I think of leaving England in order to take up my residence in France.
children.prevalue: On the contrary I think of leaving England in order to take up my residence in France

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: It was now Anne of Austria's turn to exhibit surprise. Why? she said. Are you not in favor with the new king?
children.prevalue: It was now Anne of Austria s turn to exhibit surprise Why she said Are you not in favor with the new king

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Perfectly so, madame, for his majesty's kindness to me is unbounded.
children.prevalue: Perfectly so madame for his majesty s kindness to me is unbounded

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: It cannot, said the queen, be because your fortune has diminished, for it is said to be enormous.
children.prevalue: It cannot said the queen be because your fortune has diminished for it is said to be enormous

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: My income, madame, has never been so large.
children.prevalue: My income madame has never been so large

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: There is some secret cause, then?
children.prevalue: There is some secret cause then

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: No, madame, said Buckingham, eagerly, there is nothing secret in my reason for this determination. I prefer residence in France; I like a court so distinguished by its refinement and courtesy; I like the amusements, somewhat serious in their nature, which are not the amusements of my own country, and which are met with in France.
children.prevalue: No madame said Buckingham eagerly there is nothing secret in my reason for this determination I prefer residence in France I like a court so distinguished by its refinement and courtesy I like the amusements somewhat serious in their nature which are not the amusements of my own country and which are met with in France

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Anne of Austria smiled shrewdly. Amusements of a serious nature? she said. Has your Grace well reflected on their seriousness? The duke hesitated. There is no amusement so serious, continued the queen, as to prevent a man of your rank
children.prevalue: Anne of Austria smiled shrewdly Amusements of a serious nature she said Has your Grace well reflected on their seriousness The duke hesitated There is no amusement so serious continued the queen as to prevent a man of your rank

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Your majesty seems to insist greatly on that point, interrupted the duke.
children.prevalue: Your majesty seems to insist greatly on that point interrupted the duke

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Do you think so, my lord?
children.prevalue: Do you think so my lord

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: If you will forgive me for saying so, it is the second time you have vaunted the attractions of England at the expense of the delight which all experience who live in France.
children.prevalue: If you will forgive me for saying so it is the second time you have vaunted the attractions of England at the expense of the delight which all experience who live in France

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Anne of Austria approached the young man, and placing her beautiful hand upon his shoulder, which trembled at the touch, said, Believe me, monsieur, nothing can equal a residence in one's own native country. I have very frequently had occasion to regret Spain. I have lived long, my lord, very long for a woman, and I confess to you, that not a year has passed I have not regretted Spain.
children.prevalue: Anne of Austria approached the young man and placing her beautiful hand upon his shoulder which trembled at the touch said Believe me monsieur nothing can equal a residence in one s own native country I have very frequently had occasion to regret Spain I have lived long my lord very long for a woman and I confess to you that not a year has passed I have not regretted Spain

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Not one year, madame? said the young duke coldly. Not one of those years when you reigned Queen of Beautyas you still are, indeed?
children.prevalue: Not one year madame said the young duke coldly Not one of those years when you reigned Queen of Beautyas you still are indeed

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: A truce to flattery, duke, for I am old enough to be your mother. She emphasized these latter words in a manner, and with a gentleness, which penetrated Buckingham's heart. Yes, she said, I am old enough to be your mother; and for this reason, I will give you a word of advice.
children.prevalue: A truce to flattery duke for I am old enough to be your mother She emphasized these latter words in a manner and with a gentleness which penetrated Buckingham s heart Yes she said I am old enough to be your mother and for this reason I will give you a word of advice

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: That advice being that I should return to London? he exclaimed.
children.prevalue: That advice being that I should return to London he exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Yes, my lord.
children.prevalue: Yes my lord

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: The duke clasped his hands with a terrified gesture, which could not fail of its effect upon the queen, already disposed to softer feelings by the tenderness of her own recollections. It must be so, added the queen.
children.prevalue: The duke clasped his hands with a terrified gesture which could not fail of its effect upon the queen already disposed to softer feelings by the tenderness of her own recollections It must be so added the queen

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: What! he again exclaimed, am I seriously told that I must leave,that I must exile myself,that I am to flee at once?
children.prevalue: What he again exclaimed am I seriously told that I must leave that I must exile myself that I am to flee at once

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Exile yourself, did you say? One would fancy France was your native country.
children.prevalue: Exile yourself did you say One would fancy France was your native country

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Madame, the country of those who love is the country of those whom they love.
children.prevalue: Madame the country of those who love is the country of those whom they love

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Not another word, my lord; you forget whom you are addressing.
children.prevalue: Not another word my lord you forget whom you are addressing

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Buckingham threw himself on his knees. Madame, you are the source of intelligence, of goodness, and of compassion; you are the first person in this kingdom, not only by your rank, but the first person in the world on account of your angelic attributes. I have said nothing, madame. Have I, indeed, said anything you should answer with such a cruel remark? What have I betrayed?
children.prevalue: Buckingham threw himself on his knees Madame you are the source of intelligence of goodness and of compassion you are the first person in this kingdom not only by your rank but the first person in the world on account of your angelic attributes I have said nothing madame Have I indeed said anything you should answer with such a cruel remark What have I betrayed

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: You have betrayed yourself, said the queen, in a low tone of voice.
children.prevalue: You have betrayed yourself said the queen in a low tone of voice

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I have said nothing,I know nothing.
children.prevalue: I have said nothing I know nothing

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: You forget you have spoken and thought in the presence of a woman; and besides
children.prevalue: You forget you have spoken and thought in the presence of a woman and besides

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Besides, said the duke, no one knows you are listening to me.
children.prevalue: Besides said the duke no one knows you are listening to me

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: On the contrary, it is known; you have all the defects and all the qualities of youth.
children.prevalue: On the contrary it is known you have all the defects and all the qualities of youth

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: I have been betrayed or denounced, then?
children.prevalue: I have been betrayed or denounced then

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: By whom?
children.prevalue: By whom

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: By those who, at Le Havre, had, with infernal perspicacity, read my heart like an open book.
children.prevalue: By those who at Le Havre had with infernal perspicacity read my heart like an open book

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: I do not know whom you mean.
children.prevalue: I do not know whom you mean

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: M. de Bragelonne, for instance.
children.prevalue: M de Bragelonne for instance

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: I know the name without being acquainted with the person to whom it belongs. M. de Bragelonne has said nothing.
children.prevalue: I know the name without being acquainted with the person to whom it belongs M de Bragelonne has said nothing

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Who can it be, then? If any one, madame, had had the boldness to notice in me that which I do not myself wish to behold
children.prevalue: Who can it be then If any one madame had had the boldness to notice in me that which I do not myself wish to behold

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: What would you do, duke?
children.prevalue: What would you do duke

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: There are secrets which kill those who discover them.
children.prevalue: There are secrets which kill those who discover them

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: He, then, who has discovered your secret, madman that you are, still lives; and, what is more, you will not slay him, for he is armed on all sides,he is a husband, a jealous man,he is the second gentleman in France,he is my son, the Duc du Orleans.
children.prevalue: He then who has discovered your secret madman that you are still lives and what is more you will not slay him for he is armed on all sides he is a husband a jealous man he is the second gentleman in France he is my son the Duc du Orleans

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: The duke turned pale as death. You are very cruel, madame, he said.
children.prevalue: The duke turned pale as death You are very cruel madame he said

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: You see, Buckingham, said Anne of Austria, sadly, how you pass from one extreme to another, and fight with shadows, when it would seem so easy to remain at peace with yourself.
children.prevalue: You see Buckingham said Anne of Austria sadly how you pass from one extreme to another and fight with shadows when it would seem so easy to remain at peace with yourself

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: If we fight, madame, we die on the field of battle, replied the young man, gently, abandoning himself to the most gloomy depression.
children.prevalue: If we fight madame we die on the field of battle replied the young man gently abandoning himself to the most gloomy depression

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Anne ran towards him and took him by the hand. Villiers, she said, in English, with a vehemence of tone which nothing could resist, what is it you ask? Do you ask a mother to sacrifice her son,a queen to consent to the dishonor of her house? Child that you are, do not dream of it. What! in order to spare your tears am I to commit these crimes? Villiers! you speak of the dead; the dead, at least, were full of respect and submission; they resigned themselves to an order of exile; they carried their despair away with them in their hearts, like a priceless possession, because the despair was caused by the woman they loved, and because death, thus deceptive, was like a gift of a favor conferred upon them.
children.prevalue: Anne ran towards him and took him by the hand Villiers she said in English with a vehemence of tone which nothing could resist what is it you ask Do you ask a mother to sacrifice her son a queen to consent to the dishonor of her house Child that you are do not dream of it What in order to spare your tears am I to commit these crimes Villiers you speak of the dead the dead at least were full of respect and submission they resigned themselves to an order of exile they carried their despair away with them in their hearts like a priceless possession because the despair was caused by the woman they loved and because death thus deceptive was like a gift of a favor conferred upon them

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Buckingham rose, his features distorted, and his hands pressed against his heart. You are right, madame, he said, but those of whom you speak had received their order of exile from the lips of the one whom they loved; they were not driven away; they were entreated to leave, and were not laughed at.
children.prevalue: Buckingham rose his features distorted and his hands pressed against his heart You are right madame he said but those of whom you speak had received their order of exile from the lips of the one whom they loved they were not driven away they were entreated to leave and were not laughed at

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: No, murmured Anne of Austria, they were not forgotten. But who says you are driven away, or that you are exiled? Who says that your devotion will not be remembered? I do not speak on any one's behalf but my own, when I tell you to leave. Do me this kindness,grant me this favor; let me, for this also, be indebted to one of your name.
children.prevalue: No murmured Anne of Austria they were not forgotten But who says you are driven away or that you are exiled Who says that your devotion will not be remembered I do not speak on any one s behalf but my own when I tell you to leave Do me this kindness grant me this favor let me for this also be indebted to one of your name

children.name: Paragraph_60
