children.value: It is for your sake, then, madame?
children.prevalue: It is for your sake then madame

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: For mine alone.
children.prevalue: For mine alone

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: No one whom I shall leave behind me will venture to mock,no prince even who shall say, 'I required it.'
children.prevalue: No one whom I shall leave behind me will venture to mock no prince even who shall say I required it

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Listen to me, duke, and hereupon the dignified features of the queen assumed a solemn expression. I swear to you that no one commands in this matter but myself. I swear to you that, not only shall no one either laugh or boast in any way, but no one even shall fail in the respect due to your rank. Rely upon me, duke, as I rely upon you.
children.prevalue: Listen to me duke and hereupon the dignified features of the queen assumed a solemn expression I swear to you that no one commands in this matter but myself I swear to you that not only shall no one either laugh or boast in any way but no one even shall fail in the respect due to your rank Rely upon me duke as I rely upon you

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: You do not explain yourself, madame; my heart is full of bitterness, and I am in utter despair; no consolation, however gentle and affectionate, can afford me relief.
children.prevalue: You do not explain yourself madame my heart is full of bitterness and I am in utter despair no consolation however gentle and affectionate can afford me relief

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Do you remember your mother, duke? replied the queen, with a winning smile.
children.prevalue: Do you remember your mother duke replied the queen with a winning smile

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Very slightly, madame; yet I remember how she used to cover me with her caresses and her tears whenever I wept.
children.prevalue: Very slightly madame yet I remember how she used to cover me with her caresses and her tears whenever I wept

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Villiers, murmured the queen, passing her arm round the young man's neck, look upon me as your mother, and believe that no one shall ever make my son weep.
children.prevalue: Villiers murmured the queen passing her arm round the young man s neck look upon me as your mother and believe that no one shall ever make my son weep

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: I thank you, madame, said the young man affected and almost suffocated by his emotion; I feel there is still room in my heart for a gentler and nobler sentiment than love.
children.prevalue: I thank you madame said the young man affected and almost suffocated by his emotion I feel there is still room in my heart for a gentler and nobler sentiment than love

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: The queenmother looked at him and pressed his hand. Go, she said.
children.prevalue: The queenmother looked at him and pressed his hand Go she said

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: When must I leave? Command me.
children.prevalue: When must I leave Command me

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: At any time that may suit you, my lord, resumed the queen; you will choose your own day of departure. Instead, however, of setting off today, as you would doubtless wish to do, or tomorrow, as others may have expected, leave the day after tomorrow, in the evening; but announce today that it is your wish to leave.
children.prevalue: At any time that may suit you my lord resumed the queen you will choose your own day of departure Instead however of setting off today as you would doubtless wish to do or tomorrow as others may have expected leave the day after tomorrow in the evening but announce today that it is your wish to leave

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: My wish? murmured the young duke.
children.prevalue: My wish murmured the young duke

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Yes, duke.
children.prevalue: Yes duke

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: And shall I never return to France?
children.prevalue: And shall I never return to France

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Anne of Austria reflected for a moment, seemingly absorbed in sad and serious thought. It would be a consolation for me, she said, if you were to return on the day when I shall be carried to my final restingplace at SaintDennis beside the king, my husband.
children.prevalue: Anne of Austria reflected for a moment seemingly absorbed in sad and serious thought It would be a consolation for me she said if you were to return on the day when I shall be carried to my final restingplace at SaintDennis beside the king my husband

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Madame, you are goodness itself; the tide of prosperity is setting in on you; your cup brims over with happiness, and many long years are yet before you.
children.prevalue: Madame you are goodness itself the tide of prosperity is setting in on you your cup brims over with happiness and many long years are yet before you

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: In that case you will not come for some time, then, said the queen, endeavoring to smile.
children.prevalue: In that case you will not come for some time then said the queen endeavoring to smile

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: I shall not return, said Buckingham, young as I am. Death does not reckon by years; it is impartial; some die young, some reach old age.
children.prevalue: I shall not return said Buckingham young as I am Death does not reckon by years it is impartial some die young some reach old age

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: I will not harbor any sorrowful ideas, duke. Let me comfort you; return in two years. I perceive from your face that the very idea which saddens you so much now, will have disappeared before six months have passed, and will be not only dead but forgotten in the period of absence I have assigned you.
children.prevalue: I will not harbor any sorrowful ideas duke Let me comfort you return in two years I perceive from your face that the very idea which saddens you so much now will have disappeared before six months have passed and will be not only dead but forgotten in the period of absence I have assigned you

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: I think you judged me better a little while ago, madame, replied the young man, when you said that time is powerless against members of the family of Buckingham.
children.prevalue: I think you judged me better a little while ago madame replied the young man when you said that time is powerless against members of the family of Buckingham

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Silence, said the queen, kissing the duke upon the forehead with an affection she could not restrain. Go, go; spare me and forget yourself no longer. I am the queen; you are the subject of the king of England; King Charles awaits your return. Adieu, Villiers,farewell.
children.prevalue: Silence said the queen kissing the duke upon the forehead with an affection she could not restrain Go go spare me and forget yourself no longer I am the queen you are the subject of the king of England King Charles awaits your return Adieu Villiers farewell

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Forever! replied the young man, and he fled, endeavoring to master his emotions.
children.prevalue: Forever replied the young man and he fled endeavoring to master his emotions

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Anne leaned her head upon her hands, and then looking at herself in the glass, murmured, It has been truly said, that a woman who has truly loved is always young, and that the bloom of the girl of twenty years ever lies concealed in some secret cloister of the heart. [1]
children.prevalue: Anne leaned her head upon her hands and then looking at herself in the glass murmured It has been truly said that a woman who has truly loved is always young and that the bloom of the girl of twenty years ever lies concealed in some secret cloister of the heart 1

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Raoul and the Comte de la Fere reached Paris the evening of the same day on which Buckingham had held the conversation with the queenmother. The count had scarcely arrived, when, through Raoul, he solicited an audience of the king. His majesty had passed a portion of the morning in looking over, with madame and the ladies of the court, various goods of Lyons manufacture, of which he had made his sisterinlaw a present. A court dinner had succeeded, then cards, and afterwards, according to his usual custom, the king, leaving the cardtables at eight o'clock, passed into his cabinet in order to work with M. Colbert and M. Fouquet. Raoul entered the antechamber at the very moment the two ministers quitted it, and the king, perceiving him through the halfclosed door, said, What do you want, M. de Bragelonne?
children.prevalue: Raoul and the Comte de la Fere reached Paris the evening of the same day on which Buckingham had held the conversation with the queenmother The count had scarcely arrived when through Raoul he solicited an audience of the king His majesty had passed a portion of the morning in looking over with madame and the ladies of the court various goods of Lyons manufacture of which he had made his sisterinlaw a present A court dinner had succeeded then cards and afterwards according to his usual custom the king leaving the cardtables at eight o clock passed into his cabinet in order to work with M Colbert and M Fouquet Raoul entered the antechamber at the very moment the two ministers quitted it and the king perceiving him through the halfclosed door said What do you want M de Bragelonne

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The young man approached: An audience, sire, he replied, for the Comte de la Fere, who has just arrived from Blois, and is most anxious to have an interview with your majesty.
children.prevalue: The young man approached An audience sire he replied for the Comte de la Fere who has just arrived from Blois and is most anxious to have an interview with your majesty

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: I have an hour to spare between cards and supper, said the king. Is the Comte de la Fere at hand?
children.prevalue: I have an hour to spare between cards and supper said the king Is the Comte de la Fere at hand

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: He is below, and awaits your majesty's permission.
children.prevalue: He is below and awaits your majesty s permission

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Let him come up at once, said the king, and five minutes afterwards Athos entered the presence of Louis XIV. He was received by the king with that gracious kindness of manner which Louis, with a tact beyond his years, reserved for the purpose of gaining those who were not to be conquered by ordinary favors. Let me hope, comte, said the king, that you have come to ask me for something.
children.prevalue: Let him come up at once said the king and five minutes afterwards Athos entered the presence of Louis XIV He was received by the king with that gracious kindness of manner which Louis with a tact beyond his years reserved for the purpose of gaining those who were not to be conquered by ordinary favors Let me hope comte said the king that you have come to ask me for something

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: I will not conceal from your majesty, replied the comte, that I am indeed come for that purpose.
children.prevalue: I will not conceal from your majesty replied the comte that I am indeed come for that purpose

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: That is well, said the king, joyously.
children.prevalue: That is well said the king joyously

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: It is not for myself, sire.
children.prevalue: It is not for myself sire

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: So much the worse; but, at least, I will do for your protege what you refuse to permit me to do for you.
children.prevalue: So much the worse but at least I will do for your protege what you refuse to permit me to do for you

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Your majesty encourages me. I have come to speak on behalf of the Vicomte de Bragelonne.
children.prevalue: Your majesty encourages me I have come to speak on behalf of the Vicomte de Bragelonne

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: It is the same as if you spoke on your own behalf, comte.
children.prevalue: It is the same as if you spoke on your own behalf comte

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Not altogether so, sire. I am desirous of obtaining from your majesty that which I cannot ask for myself. The vicomte thinks of marrying.
children.prevalue: Not altogether so sire I am desirous of obtaining from your majesty that which I cannot ask for myself The vicomte thinks of marrying

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: He is still very young; but that does not matter. He is an eminently distinguished man; I will choose a wife for him.
children.prevalue: He is still very young but that does not matter He is an eminently distinguished man I will choose a wife for him

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: He has already chosen one, sire, and only awaits your consent.
children.prevalue: He has already chosen one sire and only awaits your consent

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: It is only a question, then, of signing the marriagecontract? Athos bowed. Has he chose a wife whose fortune and position accord with your own anticipation?
children.prevalue: It is only a question then of signing the marriagecontract Athos bowed Has he chose a wife whose fortune and position accord with your own anticipation

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Athos hesitated for a moment. His affirmed wife is of good birth, but has no fortune.
children.prevalue: Athos hesitated for a moment His affirmed wife is of good birth but has no fortune

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: That is a misfortune we can remedy.
children.prevalue: That is a misfortune we can remedy

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: You overwhelm me with gratitude, sire; but your majesty will permit me to offer a remark?
children.prevalue: You overwhelm me with gratitude sire but your majesty will permit me to offer a remark

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Do so, comte.
children.prevalue: Do so comte

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Your majesty seems to intimate an intention of giving a marriageportion to this young lady.
children.prevalue: Your majesty seems to intimate an intention of giving a marriageportion to this young lady

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I should regret, sire, if the step I have taken towards your majesty should be attended by this result.
children.prevalue: I should regret sire if the step I have taken towards your majesty should be attended by this result

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: No false delicacy, comte; what is the bride's name?
children.prevalue: No false delicacy comte what is the bride s name

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Mademoiselle de la Baume le Blanc de la Valliere, said Athos, coldly.
children.prevalue: Mademoiselle de la Baume le Blanc de la Valliere said Athos coldly

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I seem to know that name, said the king, as if reflecting; there was a Marquis de la Valliere.
children.prevalue: I seem to know that name said the king as if reflecting there was a Marquis de la Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Yes, sire, it is his daughter.
children.prevalue: Yes sire it is his daughter

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: But he died, and his widow married again M. de SaintRemy, I think, steward of the dowager Madame's household.
children.prevalue: But he died and his widow married again M de SaintRemy I think steward of the dowager Madame s household

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Your majesty is correctly informed.
children.prevalue: Your majesty is correctly informed

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: More than that, the young lady has lately become one of the princess's maids of honor.
children.prevalue: More than that the young lady has lately become one of the princess s maids of honor

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Your majesty is better acquainted with her history than am I.
children.prevalue: Your majesty is better acquainted with her history than am I

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: The king again reflected, and glancing at the comte's anxious countenance, said: The young lady does not seem to me to be very pretty, comte.
children.prevalue: The king again reflected and glancing at the comte s anxious countenance said The young lady does not seem to me to be very pretty comte

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: I am not quite sure, replied Athos.
children.prevalue: I am not quite sure replied Athos

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I have seen her, but she hardly struck me as being so.
children.prevalue: I have seen her but she hardly struck me as being so

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: She seems to be a good and modest girl, but has little beauty, sire.
children.prevalue: She seems to be a good and modest girl but has little beauty sire

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Beautiful fair hair, however.
children.prevalue: Beautiful fair hair however

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I think so.
children.prevalue: I think so

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: And her blue eyes are tolerably good.
children.prevalue: And her blue eyes are tolerably good

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Yes, sire.
children.prevalue: Yes sire

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: With regard to her beauty, then, the match is but an ordinary one. Now for the money side of the question.
children.prevalue: With regard to her beauty then the match is but an ordinary one Now for the money side of the question

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Fifteen to twenty thousand francs dowry at the very outset, sire; the lovers are disinterested enough; for myself, I care little for money.
children.prevalue: Fifteen to twenty thousand francs dowry at the very outset sire the lovers are disinterested enough for myself I care little for money

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: For superfluity, you mean; but a needful amount is of importance. With fifteen thousand francs, without landed property, a woman cannot live at court. We will make up the deficiency; I will do it for De Bragelonne. The king again remarked the coldness with which Athos received the remark.
children.prevalue: For superfluity you mean but a needful amount is of importance With fifteen thousand francs without landed property a woman cannot live at court We will make up the deficiency I will do it for De Bragelonne The king again remarked the coldness with which Athos received the remark

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Let us pass from the question of money to that of rank, said Louis XIV.; the daughter of the Marquis de la Valliere, that is well enough; but there is that excellent SaintRemy, who somewhat damages the credit of the family; and you, comte, are rather particular, I believe, about your own family.
children.prevalue: Let us pass from the question of money to that of rank said Louis XIV the daughter of the Marquis de la Valliere that is well enough but there is that excellent SaintRemy who somewhat damages the credit of the family and you comte are rather particular I believe about your own family

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Sire, I no longer hold to anything but my devotion to your majesty.
children.prevalue: Sire I no longer hold to anything but my devotion to your majesty

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: The king again paused. A moment, comte. You have surprised me in no little degree from the beginning of your conversation. You came to ask me to authorize a marriage, and you seem greatly disturbed in having to make the request. Nay, pardon me, comte, but I am rarely deceived, young as I am; for while with some persons I place my friendship at the disposal of my understanding, with others I call my distrust to my aid, by which my discernment is increased. I repeat, that you do not prefer your request as though you wished it success.
children.prevalue: The king again paused A moment comte You have surprised me in no little degree from the beginning of your conversation You came to ask me to authorize a marriage and you seem greatly disturbed in having to make the request Nay pardon me comte but I am rarely deceived young as I am for while with some persons I place my friendship at the disposal of my understanding with others I call my distrust to my aid by which my discernment is increased I repeat that you do not prefer your request as though you wished it success

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Well, sire, that is true.
children.prevalue: Well sire that is true

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: I do not understand you, then; refuse.
children.prevalue: I do not understand you then refuse

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Nay, sire; I love De Bragelonne with my whole heart; he is smitten with Mademoiselle de la Valliere, he weaves dreams of bliss for the future; I am not one who is willing to destroy the illusions of youth. This marriage is objectionable to me, but I implore your majesty to consent to it forthwith, and thus make Raoul happy.
children.prevalue: Nay sire I love De Bragelonne with my whole heart he is smitten with Mademoiselle de la Valliere he weaves dreams of bliss for the future I am not one who is willing to destroy the illusions of youth This marriage is objectionable to me but I implore your majesty to consent to it forthwith and thus make Raoul happy

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Tell me, comte, is she in love with him?
children.prevalue: Tell me comte is she in love with him

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: If your majesty requires me to speak candidly, I do not believe in Mademoiselle de la Valliere's affection; the delight at being at court, the honor of being in the service of Madame, counteract in her head whatever affection she may happen to have in her heart; it is a marriage similar to many others which already exist at court; but De Bragelonne wishes it, and so let it be.
children.prevalue: If your majesty requires me to speak candidly I do not believe in Mademoiselle de la Valliere s affection the delight at being at court the honor of being in the service of Madame counteract in her head whatever affection she may happen to have in her heart it is a marriage similar to many others which already exist at court but De Bragelonne wishes it and so let it be

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: And yet you do not resemble those easytempered fathers who volunteer as steppingstones for their children, said the king.
children.prevalue: And yet you do not resemble those easytempered fathers who volunteer as steppingstones for their children said the king

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: I am determined enough against the viciously disposed, but not so against men of upright character. Raoul is suffering; he is in great distress of mind; his disposition, naturally light and cheerful, has become gloomy and melancholy. I do not wish to deprive your majesty of the services he may be able to render.
children.prevalue: I am determined enough against the viciously disposed but not so against men of upright character Raoul is suffering he is in great distress of mind his disposition naturally light and cheerful has become gloomy and melancholy I do not wish to deprive your majesty of the services he may be able to render

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: I understand you, said the king; and what is more, I understand your heart, too, comte.
children.prevalue: I understand you said the king and what is more I understand your heart too comte

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: There is no occasion, therefore, replied the comte, to tell your majesty that my object is to make these children, or rather Raoul, happy.
children.prevalue: There is no occasion therefore replied the comte to tell your majesty that my object is to make these children or rather Raoul happy

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: And I, too, as much as yourself, comte, wish to secure M. de Bragelonne's happiness.
children.prevalue: And I too as much as yourself comte wish to secure M de Bragelonne s happiness

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: I only await your majesty's signature. Raoul will have the honor of presenting himself before your majesty to receive your consent.
children.prevalue: I only await your majesty s signature Raoul will have the honor of presenting himself before your majesty to receive your consent

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: You are mistaken, comte, said the king, firmly; I have just said that I desire to secure M. de Bragelonne's happiness, and from the present moment, therefore, I oppose his marriage.
children.prevalue: You are mistaken comte said the king firmly I have just said that I desire to secure M de Bragelonne s happiness and from the present moment therefore I oppose his marriage

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: But, sire, exclaimed Athos, your majesty has promised!
children.prevalue: But sire exclaimed Athos your majesty has promised

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Not so, comte, I did not promise you, for it is opposed to my own views.
children.prevalue: Not so comte I did not promise you for it is opposed to my own views

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: I appreciate your majesty's considerate and generous intentions on my behalf; but I take the liberty of recalling to you that I undertook to approach you as an ambassador.
children.prevalue: I appreciate your majesty s considerate and generous intentions on my behalf but I take the liberty of recalling to you that I undertook to approach you as an ambassador

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: An ambassador, comte, frequently asks, but does not always obtain what he asks.
children.prevalue: An ambassador comte frequently asks but does not always obtain what he asks

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: But, sire, it will be such a blow for De Bragelonne.
children.prevalue: But sire it will be such a blow for De Bragelonne

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: My hand shall deal the blow; I will speak to the vicomte.
children.prevalue: My hand shall deal the blow I will speak to the vicomte

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Love, sire, is overwhelming in its might.
children.prevalue: Love sire is overwhelming in its might

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Love can be resisted, comte. I myself can assure you of that.
children.prevalue: Love can be resisted comte I myself can assure you of that

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: When one has the soul of a king,your own, for instance, sire.
children.prevalue: When one has the soul of a king your own for instance sire

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Do not make yourself uneasy on the subject. I have certain views for De Bragelonne. I do not say that he shall not marry Mademoiselle de la Valliere, but I do not wish him to marry so young; I do not wish him to marry her until she has acquired a fortune; and he, on his side, no less deserves favor, such as I wish to confer upon him. In a word, comte, I wish them to wait.
children.prevalue: Do not make yourself uneasy on the subject I have certain views for De Bragelonne I do not say that he shall not marry Mademoiselle de la Valliere but I do not wish him to marry so young I do not wish him to marry her until she has acquired a fortune and he on his side no less deserves favor such as I wish to confer upon him In a word comte I wish them to wait

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Yet once more, sire.
children.prevalue: Yet once more sire

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Comte, you told me you came here to request a favor.
children.prevalue: Comte you told me you came here to request a favor

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Assuredly, sire.
children.prevalue: Assuredly sire

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Grant me one, then, instead; let us speak no longer upon this matter. It is probable that, before long, war may be declared. I require men about me who are unfettered. I should hesitate to send under fire a married man, or a father of a family. I should hesitate also, on De Bragelonne's account, to endow with a fortune, without some sound reason for it, a young girl, a perfect stranger; such an act would sow jealousy amongst my nobility. Athos bowed, and remained silent.
children.prevalue: Grant me one then instead let us speak no longer upon this matter It is probable that before long war may be declared I require men about me who are unfettered I should hesitate to send under fire a married man or a father of a family I should hesitate also on De Bragelonne s account to endow with a fortune without some sound reason for it a young girl a perfect stranger such an act would sow jealousy amongst my nobility Athos bowed and remained silent

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Is that all you wished to ask me? added Louis XIV.
children.prevalue: Is that all you wished to ask me added Louis XIV

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Absolutely all, sire; and I take my leave of your majesty. Is it, however, necessary that I should inform Raoul?
children.prevalue: Absolutely all sire and I take my leave of your majesty Is it however necessary that I should inform Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Spare yourself the trouble and annoyance. Tell the vicomte that at my levee tomorrow morning I will speak to him. I shall expect you this evening, comte, to join my cardtable.
children.prevalue: Spare yourself the trouble and annoyance Tell the vicomte that at my levee tomorrow morning I will speak to him I shall expect you this evening comte to join my cardtable

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: I am in travelingcostume, sire.
children.prevalue: I am in travelingcostume sire

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: A day will come, I hope, when you will leave me no more. Before long, comte, the monarchy will be established in such a manner as to enable me to offer a worthy hospitality to men of your merit.
children.prevalue: A day will come I hope when you will leave me no more Before long comte the monarchy will be established in such a manner as to enable me to offer a worthy hospitality to men of your merit

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Provided, sire, a monarch reigns grandly in the hearts of his subjects, the palace he inhabits matters little, since he is worshipped in a temple. With these words Athos left the cabinet, and found De Bragelonne, who was awaiting him anxiously.
children.prevalue: Provided sire a monarch reigns grandly in the hearts of his subjects the palace he inhabits matters little since he is worshipped in a temple With these words Athos left the cabinet and found De Bragelonne who was awaiting him anxiously

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Well, monsieur? said the young man.
children.prevalue: Well monsieur said the young man

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: The king, Raoul, is well intentioned towards us both; not, perhaps, in the sense you suppose, but he is kind, and generously disposed to our house.
children.prevalue: The king Raoul is well intentioned towards us both not perhaps in the sense you suppose but he is kind and generously disposed to our house

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: You have bad news to communicate to me, monsieur, said the young man, turning very pale.
children.prevalue: You have bad news to communicate to me monsieur said the young man turning very pale

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: The king himself will inform you tomorrow morning that it is not bad news.
children.prevalue: The king himself will inform you tomorrow morning that it is not bad news

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: The king has not signed, however?
children.prevalue: The king has not signed however

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: The king wishes himself to settle the terms of the contract, and he desires to make it so grand that he requires time for consideration. Throw the blame rather on your own impatience, than on the king's good feelings towards you.
children.prevalue: The king wishes himself to settle the terms of the contract and he desires to make it so grand that he requires time for consideration Throw the blame rather on your own impatience than on the king s good feelings towards you

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Raoul, in utter consternation, on account of his knowledge of the count's frankness as well as his diplomacy, remained plunged in dull and gloomy stupor.
children.prevalue: Raoul in utter consternation on account of his knowledge of the count s frankness as well as his diplomacy remained plunged in dull and gloomy stupor

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Will you not go with me to my lodgings? said Athos.
children.prevalue: Will you not go with me to my lodgings said Athos

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: I beg your pardon, monsieur; I will follow you, he stammered out, following Athos down the staircase.
children.prevalue: I beg your pardon monsieur I will follow you he stammered out following Athos down the staircase

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Since I am here, said Athos, suddenly, cannot I see M. d'Artagnan?
children.prevalue: Since I am here said Athos suddenly cannot I see M d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Shall I show you his apartments? said De Bragelonne.
children.prevalue: Shall I show you his apartments said De Bragelonne

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Do so.
children.prevalue: Do so

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: They are on the opposite staircase.
children.prevalue: They are on the opposite staircase

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: They altered their course, but on reaching the landing of the grand staircase, Raoul perceived a servant in the Comte de Guiche's livery, who ran towards him as soon as he heard his voice.
children.prevalue: They altered their course but on reaching the landing of the grand staircase Raoul perceived a servant in the Comte de Guiche s livery who ran towards him as soon as he heard his voice

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: What is it? said Raoul.
children.prevalue: What is it said Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: This note, monsieur. My master heard of your return and wrote to you without delay; I have been looking for you for the last halfhour.
children.prevalue: This note monsieur My master heard of your return and wrote to you without delay I have been looking for you for the last halfhour

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Raoul approached Athos as he unsealed the letter, saying, With your permission, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Raoul approached Athos as he unsealed the letter saying With your permission monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Dear Raoul, wrote the Comte de Guiche, I have an affair in hand which requires immediate attention; I know you have returned; come to me as soon as possible.
children.prevalue: Dear Raoul wrote the Comte de Guiche I have an affair in hand which requires immediate attention I know you have returned come to me as soon as possible

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Hardly had he finished reading it, when a servant in the livery of the Duke of Buckingham, turning out of the gallery, recognized Raoul, and approached him respectfully, saying, From his Grace, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Hardly had he finished reading it when a servant in the livery of the Duke of Buckingham turning out of the gallery recognized Raoul and approached him respectfully saying From his Grace monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Well, Raoul, as I see you are already as busy as a general of an army, I shall leave you, and will find M. d'Artagnan myself.
children.prevalue: Well Raoul as I see you are already as busy as a general of an army I shall leave you and will find M d Artagnan myself

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: You will excuse me, I trust, said Raoul.
children.prevalue: You will excuse me I trust said Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Yes, yes, I excuse you; adieu, Raoul; you will find me at my apartments until tomorrow; during the day I may set out for Blois, unless I have orders to the contrary.
children.prevalue: Yes yes I excuse you adieu Raoul you will find me at my apartments until tomorrow during the day I may set out for Blois unless I have orders to the contrary

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: I shall present my respects to you tomorrow, monsieur.
children.prevalue: I shall present my respects to you tomorrow monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: As soon as Athos had left, Raoul opened Buckingham's letter.
children.prevalue: As soon as Athos had left Raoul opened Buckingham s letter

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Monsieur de Bragelonne, it ran, You are, of all the Frenchmen I have known, the one with whom I am most pleased; I am about to put your friendship to the proof. I have received a certain message, written in very good French. As I am an Englishman, I am afraid of not comprehending it very clearly. The letter has a good name attached to it, and that is all I can tell you. Will you be good enough to come and see me? for I am told you have arrived from Blois.
children.prevalue: Monsieur de Bragelonne it ran You are of all the Frenchmen I have known the one with whom I am most pleased I am about to put your friendship to the proof I have received a certain message written in very good French As I am an Englishman I am afraid of not comprehending it very clearly The letter has a good name attached to it and that is all I can tell you Will you be good enough to come and see me for I am told you have arrived from Blois

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Your devoted
children.prevalue: Your devoted

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: VILLIERS, Duke of Buckingham.
children.prevalue: VILLIERS Duke of Buckingham

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: I am going now to see your master, said Raoul to De Guiche's servant, as he dismissed him; and I shall be with the Duke of Buckingham in an hour, he added, dismissing with these words the duke's messenger.
children.prevalue: I am going now to see your master said Raoul to De Guiche s servant as he dismissed him and I shall be with the Duke of Buckingham in an hour he added dismissing with these words the duke s messenger

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Raoul, on betaking himself to De Guiche, found him conversing with De Wardes and Manicamp. De Wardes, since the affair of the barricade, had treated Raoul as a stranger; they behaved as if they were not acquainted. As Raoul entered, De Guiche walked up to him; and Raoul, as he grasped his friend's hand, glanced rapidly at his two companions, hoping to be able to read on their faces what was passing in their minds. De Wardes was cold and impenetrable; Manicamp seemed absorbed in the contemplation of some trimming to his dress. De Guiche led Raoul to an adjoining cabinet, and made him sit down, saying, How well you look!
children.prevalue: Raoul on betaking himself to De Guiche found him conversing with De Wardes and Manicamp De Wardes since the affair of the barricade had treated Raoul as a stranger they behaved as if they were not acquainted As Raoul entered De Guiche walked up to him and Raoul as he grasped his friend s hand glanced rapidly at his two companions hoping to be able to read on their faces what was passing in their minds De Wardes was cold and impenetrable Manicamp seemed absorbed in the contemplation of some trimming to his dress De Guiche led Raoul to an adjoining cabinet and made him sit down saying How well you look

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: That is singular, replied Raoul, for I am far from being in good spirits.
children.prevalue: That is singular replied Raoul for I am far from being in good spirits

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: It is your case, then, Raoul, as it is my own,our love affairs do not progress.
children.prevalue: It is your case then Raoul as it is my own our love affairs do not progress

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: So much the better, count, as far as you are concerned; the worst news would be good news.
children.prevalue: So much the better count as far as you are concerned the worst news would be good news

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: In that case do not distress yourself, for, not only am I very unhappy, but, what is more, I see others about me who are happy.
children.prevalue: In that case do not distress yourself for not only am I very unhappy but what is more I see others about me who are happy

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Really, I do not understand you, replied Raoul; explain yourself.
children.prevalue: Really I do not understand you replied Raoul explain yourself

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: You will soon learn. I have tried, but in vain, to overcome the feeling you saw dawn in me, increase, and take entire possession of me. I have summoned all your advice and my own strength to my aid. I have well weighed the unfortunate affair in which I have embarked; I have sounded its depths; that it is an abyss, I am aware, but it matters little for I shall pursue my own course.
children.prevalue: You will soon learn I have tried but in vain to overcome the feeling you saw dawn in me increase and take entire possession of me I have summoned all your advice and my own strength to my aid I have well weighed the unfortunate affair in which I have embarked I have sounded its depths that it is an abyss I am aware but it matters little for I shall pursue my own course

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: This is madness, De Guiche! you cannot advance another step without risking your own ruin today, perhaps your life tomorrow.
children.prevalue: This is madness De Guiche you cannot advance another step without risking your own ruin today perhaps your life tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Whatever may happen, I have done with reflections; listen.
children.prevalue: Whatever may happen I have done with reflections listen

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: And you hope to succeed; you believe that Madame will love you?
children.prevalue: And you hope to succeed you believe that Madame will love you

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Raoul, I believe nothing; I hope, because hope exists in man, and never abandons him until death.
children.prevalue: Raoul I believe nothing I hope because hope exists in man and never abandons him until death

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: But, admitting that you obtain the happiness you covet, even then, you are more certainly lost than if you had failed in obtaining it.
children.prevalue: But admitting that you obtain the happiness you covet even then you are more certainly lost than if you had failed in obtaining it

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I beseech you, Raoul, not to interrupt me any more; you could never convince me, for I tell you beforehand, I do not wish to be convinced; I have gone so far I cannot recede; I have suffered so much, death itself would be a boon. I no longer love to madness, Raoul, I am being engulfed by a whirlpool of jealousy.
children.prevalue: I beseech you Raoul not to interrupt me any more you could never convince me for I tell you beforehand I do not wish to be convinced I have gone so far I cannot recede I have suffered so much death itself would be a boon I no longer love to madness Raoul I am being engulfed by a whirlpool of jealousy

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Raoul struck his hands together with an expression resembling anger. Well? said he.
children.prevalue: Raoul struck his hands together with an expression resembling anger Well said he

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Well or ill matters little. This is what I claim from you, my friend, my almost brother. During the last three days Madame has been living in a perfect intoxication of gayety. On the first day, I dared not look at her; I hated her for not being as unhappy as myself. The next day I could not bear her out of my sight; and she, Raoulat least I thought I remarked itshe looked at me, if not with pity, at least with gentleness. But between her looks and mine, a shadow intervened; another's smile invited hers. Beside her horse another's always gallops, which is not mine; in her ear another's caressing voice, not mine, unceasingly vibrates. Raoul, for three days past my brain has been on fire; flame, not blood, courses through my veins. That shadow must be driven away, that smile must be quenched; that voice must be silenced.
children.prevalue: Well or ill matters little This is what I claim from you my friend my almost brother During the last three days Madame has been living in a perfect intoxication of gayety On the first day I dared not look at her I hated her for not being as unhappy as myself The next day I could not bear her out of my sight and she Raoulat least I thought I remarked itshe looked at me if not with pity at least with gentleness But between her looks and mine a shadow intervened another s smile invited hers Beside her horse another s always gallops which is not mine in her ear another s caressing voice not mine unceasingly vibrates Raoul for three days past my brain has been on fire flame not blood courses through my veins That shadow must be driven away that smile must be quenched that voice must be silenced

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: You wish Monsieur's death, exclaimed Raoul.
children.prevalue: You wish Monsieur s death exclaimed Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: No, no, I am not jealous of the husband; I am jealous of the lover.
children.prevalue: No no I am not jealous of the husband I am jealous of the lover

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Of the lover? said Raoul.
children.prevalue: Of the lover said Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Have you not observed it, you who were formerly so keensighted?
children.prevalue: Have you not observed it you who were formerly so keensighted

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Are you jealous of the Duke of Buckingham?
children.prevalue: Are you jealous of the Duke of Buckingham

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: To the very death.
children.prevalue: To the very death

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Again jealous?
children.prevalue: Again jealous

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: This time the affair will be easy to arrange between us; I have taken the initiative, and have sent him a letter.
children.prevalue: This time the affair will be easy to arrange between us I have taken the initiative and have sent him a letter

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: It was you, then, who wrote to him?
children.prevalue: It was you then who wrote to him

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: How do you know that?
children.prevalue: How do you know that

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: I know it, because he told me so. Look at this; and he handed De Guiche the letter he had received nearly at the same moment as his own. De Guiche read it eagerly, and said, He is a brave man, and more than that, a gallant man.
children.prevalue: I know it because he told me so Look at this and he handed De Guiche the letter he had received nearly at the same moment as his own De Guiche read it eagerly and said He is a brave man and more than that a gallant man

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Most certainly the duke is a gallant man; I need not ask if you wrote to him in a similar style.
children.prevalue: Most certainly the duke is a gallant man I need not ask if you wrote to him in a similar style

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: He will show you my letter when you call on him on my behalf.
children.prevalue: He will show you my letter when you call on him on my behalf

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: But that is almost out of the question.
children.prevalue: But that is almost out of the question

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: What is?
children.prevalue: What is

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: That I shall call on him for that purpose.
children.prevalue: That I shall call on him for that purpose

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Why so?
children.prevalue: Why so

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: The duke consults me as you do.
children.prevalue: The duke consults me as you do

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: I suppose you will give me the preference! Listen to me, Raoul, I wish you to tell his Graceit is a very simple matterthat today, tomorrow, the following day, or any other day he may choose, I will meet him at Vincennes.
children.prevalue: I suppose you will give me the preference Listen to me Raoul I wish you to tell his Graceit is a very simple matterthat today tomorrow the following day or any other day he may choose I will meet him at Vincennes

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Reflect, De Guiche.
children.prevalue: Reflect De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I thought I told you I have reflected.
children.prevalue: I thought I told you I have reflected

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The duke is a stranger here; he is on a mission which renders his person inviolable.... Vincennes is close to the Bastile.
children.prevalue: The duke is a stranger here he is on a mission which renders his person inviolable Vincennes is close to the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: The consequences concern me.
children.prevalue: The consequences concern me

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: But the motive for this meeting? What motive do you wish me to assign?
children.prevalue: But the motive for this meeting What motive do you wish me to assign

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Be perfectly easy on that score, he will not ask any. The duke must be as sick of me as I am of him. I implore you, therefore, seek the duke, and if it is necessary to entreat him, to accept my offer, I will do so.
children.prevalue: Be perfectly easy on that score he will not ask any The duke must be as sick of me as I am of him I implore you therefore seek the duke and if it is necessary to entreat him to accept my offer I will do so

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: That is useless. The duke has already informed me that he wishes to speak to me. The duke is now playing cards with the king. Let us both go there. I will draw him aside in the gallery; you will remain aloof. Two words will be sufficient.
children.prevalue: That is useless The duke has already informed me that he wishes to speak to me The duke is now playing cards with the king Let us both go there I will draw him aside in the gallery you will remain aloof Two words will be sufficient

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: That is well arranged. I will take De Wardes to keep me in countenance.
children.prevalue: That is well arranged I will take De Wardes to keep me in countenance

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Why not Manicamp? De Wardes can join us at any time; we can leave him here.
children.prevalue: Why not Manicamp De Wardes can join us at any time we can leave him here

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Yes, that is true.
children.prevalue: Yes that is true

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: He knows nothing?
children.prevalue: He knows nothing

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Positively nothing. You continue still on an unfriendly footing, then?
children.prevalue: Positively nothing You continue still on an unfriendly footing then

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Has he not told you anything?
children.prevalue: Has he not told you anything

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Nothing.
children.prevalue: Nothing

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: I do not like the man, and, as I never liked him, the result is, that I am on no worse terms with him today than I was yesterday.
children.prevalue: I do not like the man and as I never liked him the result is that I am on no worse terms with him today than I was yesterday

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Let us go, then.
children.prevalue: Let us go then

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: The four descended the stairs. De Guiche's carriage was waiting at the door, and took them to the Palais Royal. As they were going along, Raoul was engaged in devising his scheme of action. The sole depositary of two secrets, he did not despair of concluding some arrangement between the two parties. He knew the influence he exercised over Buckingham, and the ascendency he had acquired over De Guiche, and affairs did not look utterly hopeless. On their arrival in the gallery, dazzling with the blaze of light, where the most beautiful and illustrious women of the court moved to and fro, like stars in their own atmosphere, Raoul could not prevent himself for a moment forgetting De Guiche in order to seek out Louise, who, amidst her companions, like a dove completely fascinated, gazed long and fixedly upon the royal circle, which glittered with jewels and gold. All its members were standing, the king alone being seated. Raoul perceived Buckingham, who was standing a few paces from Monsieur, in a group of French and English, who were admiring his aristocratic carriage and the incomparable magnificence of his costume. Some of the older courtiers remembered having seen his father, but their recollections were not prejudicial to the son.
children.prevalue: The four descended the stairs De Guiche s carriage was waiting at the door and took them to the Palais Royal As they were going along Raoul was engaged in devising his scheme of action The sole depositary of two secrets he did not despair of concluding some arrangement between the two parties He knew the influence he exercised over Buckingham and the ascendency he had acquired over De Guiche and affairs did not look utterly hopeless On their arrival in the gallery dazzling with the blaze of light where the most beautiful and illustrious women of the court moved to and fro like stars in their own atmosphere Raoul could not prevent himself for a moment forgetting De Guiche in order to seek out Louise who amidst her companions like a dove completely fascinated gazed long and fixedly upon the royal circle which glittered with jewels and gold All its members were standing the king alone being seated Raoul perceived Buckingham who was standing a few paces from Monsieur in a group of French and English who were admiring his aristocratic carriage and the incomparable magnificence of his costume Some of the older courtiers remembered having seen his father but their recollections were not prejudicial to the son

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Buckingham was conversing with Fouquet, who was talking with him aloud about BelleIsle. I cannot speak to him at present, said Raoul.
children.prevalue: Buckingham was conversing with Fouquet who was talking with him aloud about BelleIsle I cannot speak to him at present said Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Wait, then, and choose your opportunity, but finish everything speedily. I am on thorns.
children.prevalue: Wait then and choose your opportunity but finish everything speedily I am on thorns

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: See, our deliverer approaches, said Raoul, perceiving D'Artagnan, who, magnificently dressed in his new uniform of captain of the musketeers, had just made his entry in the gallery; and he advanced towards D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: See our deliverer approaches said Raoul perceiving D Artagnan who magnificently dressed in his new uniform of captain of the musketeers had just made his entry in the gallery and he advanced towards D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: The Comte de la Fere has been looking for you, chevalier, said Raoul.
children.prevalue: The Comte de la Fere has been looking for you chevalier said Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Yes, replied D'Artagnan, I have just left him.
children.prevalue: Yes replied D Artagnan I have just left him

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: I thought you would have passed a portion of the evening together.
children.prevalue: I thought you would have passed a portion of the evening together

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: We have arranged to meet again.
children.prevalue: We have arranged to meet again

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: As he answered Raoul, his absent looks were directed on all sides, as if seeking some one in the crowd or looking for something in the room. Suddenly his gaze became fixed, like that of an eagle on its prey. Raoul followed the direction of his glance, and noticed that De Guiche and D'Artagnan saluted each other, but he could not distinguish at whom the captain's lingering and haughty glance was aimed.
children.prevalue: As he answered Raoul his absent looks were directed on all sides as if seeking some one in the crowd or looking for something in the room Suddenly his gaze became fixed like that of an eagle on its prey Raoul followed the direction of his glance and noticed that De Guiche and D Artagnan saluted each other but he could not distinguish at whom the captain s lingering and haughty glance was aimed

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Chevalier, said Raoul, there is no one here but yourself who can render me a service.
children.prevalue: Chevalier said Raoul there is no one here but yourself who can render me a service

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: What is it, my dear vicomte?
children.prevalue: What is it my dear vicomte

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: It is simply to go and interrupt the Duke of Buckingham, to whom I wish to say two words, and, as the duke is conversing with M. Fouquet, you understand that it would not do for me to throw myself into the middle of the conversation.
children.prevalue: It is simply to go and interrupt the Duke of Buckingham to whom I wish to say two words and as the duke is conversing with M Fouquet you understand that it would not do for me to throw myself into the middle of the conversation

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Ah, ah, is M. Fouquet there? inquired D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Ah ah is M Fouquet there inquired D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Do you not see him?
children.prevalue: Do you not see him

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Yes, now I do. But do you think I have a greater right than you have?
children.prevalue: Yes now I do But do you think I have a greater right than you have

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: You are a more important personage.
children.prevalue: You are a more important personage

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Yes, you're right; I am captain of the musketeers; I have had the post promised me so long, and have enjoyed it for so brief a period, that I am always forgetting my dignity.
children.prevalue: Yes you re right I am captain of the musketeers I have had the post promised me so long and have enjoyed it for so brief a period that I am always forgetting my dignity

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: You will do me this service, will you not?
children.prevalue: You will do me this service will you not

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: M. Fouquetthe deuce!
children.prevalue: M Fouquetthe deuce

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Are you not on good terms with him?
children.prevalue: Are you not on good terms with him

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: It is rather he who may not be on good terms with me; however, since it must be done some day or another
children.prevalue: It is rather he who may not be on good terms with me however since it must be done some day or another

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Stay; I think he is looking at you; or is it likely that it might be
children.prevalue: Stay I think he is looking at you or is it likely that it might be

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: No, no; don't deceive yourself, it is indeed me for whom this honor is intended.
children.prevalue: No no don t deceive yourself it is indeed me for whom this honor is intended

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: The opportunity is a good one, then?
children.prevalue: The opportunity is a good one then

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Do you think so?
children.prevalue: Do you think so

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Pray go.
children.prevalue: Pray go

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Well, I will.
children.prevalue: Well I will

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: De Guiche had not removed his eyes from Raoul, who made a sign to him that all was arranged. D'Artagnan walked straight up to the group, and civilly saluted M. Fouquet as well as the others.
children.prevalue: De Guiche had not removed his eyes from Raoul who made a sign to him that all was arranged D Artagnan walked straight up to the group and civilly saluted M Fouquet as well as the others

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Good evening, M. d'Artagnan; we were speaking of BelleIsle, said Fouquet, with that usage of society, and that perfect knowledge of the language of looks, which require half a lifetime thoroughly to acquire, and which some persons, notwithstanding all their study, never attain.
children.prevalue: Good evening M d Artagnan we were speaking of BelleIsle said Fouquet with that usage of society and that perfect knowledge of the language of looks which require half a lifetime thoroughly to acquire and which some persons notwithstanding all their study never attain

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Of BelleIleenMer! Ah! said D'Artagnan. It belongs to you, I believe, M. Fouquet?
children.prevalue: Of BelleIleenMer Ah said D Artagnan It belongs to you I believe M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: M. Fouquet has just told us that he had presented it to the king, said Buckingham.
children.prevalue: M Fouquet has just told us that he had presented it to the king said Buckingham

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Do you know BelleIsle, chevalier? inquired Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Do you know BelleIsle chevalier inquired Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: I have only been there once, replied D'Artagnan, with readiness and goodhumor.
children.prevalue: I have only been there once replied D Artagnan with readiness and goodhumor

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Did you remain there long?
children.prevalue: Did you remain there long

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Scarcely a day.
children.prevalue: Scarcely a day

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Did you see much of it while you were there?
children.prevalue: Did you see much of it while you were there

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: All that could be seen in a day.
children.prevalue: All that could be seen in a day

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: A great deal can be seen with observation as keen as yours, said Fouquet; at which D'Artagnan bowed.
children.prevalue: A great deal can be seen with observation as keen as yours said Fouquet at which D Artagnan bowed

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: During this Raoul made a sign to Buckingham. M. Fouquet, said Buckingham, I leave the captain with you, he is more learned than I am in bastions, scarps, and counterscarps, and I will join one of my friends, who has just beckoned me. Saying this, Buckingham disengaged himself from the group, and advanced towards Raoul, stopping for a moment at the table where the queenmother, the young queen, and the king were playing together.
children.prevalue: During this Raoul made a sign to Buckingham M Fouquet said Buckingham I leave the captain with you he is more learned than I am in bastions scarps and counterscarps and I will join one of my friends who has just beckoned me Saying this Buckingham disengaged himself from the group and advanced towards Raoul stopping for a moment at the table where the queenmother the young queen and the king were playing together

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Now, Raoul, said De Guiche, there he is; be firm and quick.
children.prevalue: Now Raoul said De Guiche there he is be firm and quick

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Buckingham, having made some complimentary remark to Madame, continued his way towards Raoul, who advanced to meet him, while De Guiche remained in his place, though he followed him with his eyes. The maneuver was so arranged that the young men met in an open space which was left vacant, between the groups of players and the gallery, where they walked, stopping now and then for the purpose of saying a few words to some of the graver courtiers who were walking there. At the moment when the two lines were about to unite, they were broken by a third. It was Monsieur who advanced towards the Duke of Buckingham. Monsieur had his most engaging smile on his red and perfumed lips.
children.prevalue: Buckingham having made some complimentary remark to Madame continued his way towards Raoul who advanced to meet him while De Guiche remained in his place though he followed him with his eyes The maneuver was so arranged that the young men met in an open space which was left vacant between the groups of players and the gallery where they walked stopping now and then for the purpose of saying a few words to some of the graver courtiers who were walking there At the moment when the two lines were about to unite they were broken by a third It was Monsieur who advanced towards the Duke of Buckingham Monsieur had his most engaging smile on his red and perfumed lips

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: My dear duke, said he, with the most affectionate politeness; is it really true what I have just been told?
children.prevalue: My dear duke said he with the most affectionate politeness is it really true what I have just been told

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Buckingham turned round; he had not noticed Monsieur approach; but had merely heard his voice. He started in spite of his command over himself, and a slight pallor overspread his face. Monseigneur, he asked, what has been told you that surprises you so much?
children.prevalue: Buckingham turned round he had not noticed Monsieur approach but had merely heard his voice He started in spite of his command over himself and a slight pallor overspread his face Monseigneur he asked what has been told you that surprises you so much

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: That which throws me into despair, and will, in truth, be a real cause of mourning for the whole court.
children.prevalue: That which throws me into despair and will in truth be a real cause of mourning for the whole court

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Your highness is very kind, for I perceive that you allude to my departure.
children.prevalue: Your highness is very kind for I perceive that you allude to my departure

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Precisely.
children.prevalue: Precisely

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Guiche had overheard the conversation from where he was standing, and started in his turn. His departure, he murmured. What does he say?
children.prevalue: Guiche had overheard the conversation from where he was standing and started in his turn His departure he murmured What does he say

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Philip continued with the same gracious air, I can easily conceive, monsieur, why the king of Great Britain recalls you; we all know that King Charles II., who appreciates true gentlemen, cannot dispense with you. But it cannot be supposed we can let you go without great regret; and I beg you to receive the expression of my own.
children.prevalue: Philip continued with the same gracious air I can easily conceive monsieur why the king of Great Britain recalls you we all know that King Charles II who appreciates true gentlemen cannot dispense with you But it cannot be supposed we can let you go without great regret and I beg you to receive the expression of my own

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Believe me, monseigneur, said the duke, that if I quit the court of France
children.prevalue: Believe me monseigneur said the duke that if I quit the court of France

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Because you are recalled; but, if you suppose the expression of my own wish on the subject might possibly have any influence with the king, I will gladly volunteer to entreat his majesty Charles II. to leave you with us a little while longer.
children.prevalue: Because you are recalled but if you suppose the expression of my own wish on the subject might possibly have any influence with the king I will gladly volunteer to entreat his majesty Charles II to leave you with us a little while longer

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: I am overwhelmed, monseigneur, by so much kindness, replied Buckingham; but I have received positive commands. My residence in France was limited; I have prolonged it at the risk of displeasing my gracious sovereign. It is only this very day that I recollected I ought to have set off four days ago.
children.prevalue: I am overwhelmed monseigneur by so much kindness replied Buckingham but I have received positive commands My residence in France was limited I have prolonged it at the risk of displeasing my gracious sovereign It is only this very day that I recollected I ought to have set off four days ago

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Indeed, said Monsieur.
children.prevalue: Indeed said Monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Yes; but, added Buckingham, raising his voice in such a manner that the princess could hear him,but I resemble that dweller in the East, who turned mad, and remained so for several days, owing to a delightful dream that he had had, but who one day awoke, if not completely cured, in some respects rational at least. The court of France has its intoxicating properties, which are not unlike this dream, my lord; but at last I wake and leave it. I shall be unable, therefore, to prolong my residence, as your highness has so kindly invited me to do.
children.prevalue: Yes but added Buckingham raising his voice in such a manner that the princess could hear him but I resemble that dweller in the East who turned mad and remained so for several days owing to a delightful dream that he had had but who one day awoke if not completely cured in some respects rational at least The court of France has its intoxicating properties which are not unlike this dream my lord but at last I wake and leave it I shall be unable therefore to prolong my residence as your highness has so kindly invited me to do

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: When do you leave? inquired Philip, with an expression full of interest.
children.prevalue: When do you leave inquired Philip with an expression full of interest

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Tomorrow, monseigneur. My carriages have been ready for three days.
children.prevalue: Tomorrow monseigneur My carriages have been ready for three days

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: The Duc d'Orleans made a movement of the head, which seemed to signify, Since you are determined, duke, there is nothing to be said. Buckingham returned the gesture, concealing under a smile a contraction of his heart; and then Monsieur moved away in the same direction by which he had approached. At the same moment, however, De Guiche advanced from the opposite direction. Raoul feared that the impatient young man might possibly make the proposition himself, and hurried forth before him.
children.prevalue: The Duc d Orleans made a movement of the head which seemed to signify Since you are determined duke there is nothing to be said Buckingham returned the gesture concealing under a smile a contraction of his heart and then Monsieur moved away in the same direction by which he had approached At the same moment however De Guiche advanced from the opposite direction Raoul feared that the impatient young man might possibly make the proposition himself and hurried forth before him

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: No, no, Raoul, all is useless now, said Guiche, holding both his hands towards the duke, and leading him behind a column. Forgive me, duke, for what I wrote to you, I was mad; give me back my letter.
children.prevalue: No no Raoul all is useless now said Guiche holding both his hands towards the duke and leading him behind a column Forgive me duke for what I wrote to you I was mad give me back my letter

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: It is true, said the duke, you cannot owe me a grudge any longer now.
children.prevalue: It is true said the duke you cannot owe me a grudge any longer now

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Forgive me, duke; my friendship, my lasting friendship is yours.
children.prevalue: Forgive me duke my friendship my lasting friendship is yours

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: There is certainly no reason why you should bear me any illwill from the moment I leave her never to see her again.
children.prevalue: There is certainly no reason why you should bear me any illwill from the moment I leave her never to see her again

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Raoul heard these words, and comprehending that his presence was now useless between the young men, who had now only friendly words to exchange, withdrew a few paces; a movement which brought him closer to De Wardes, who was conversing with the Chevalier de Lorraine respecting the departure of Buckingham. A strategic retreat, said De Wardes.
children.prevalue: Raoul heard these words and comprehending that his presence was now useless between the young men who had now only friendly words to exchange withdrew a few paces a movement which brought him closer to De Wardes who was conversing with the Chevalier de Lorraine respecting the departure of Buckingham A strategic retreat said De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Why so?
children.prevalue: Why so

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Because the dear duke saves a swordthrust by it. At which reply both laughed.
children.prevalue: Because the dear duke saves a swordthrust by it At which reply both laughed

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Raoul, indignant, turned round frowningly, flushed with anger and his lip curling with disdain. The Chevalier de Lorraine turned on his heel, but De Wardes remained and waited.
children.prevalue: Raoul indignant turned round frowningly flushed with anger and his lip curling with disdain The Chevalier de Lorraine turned on his heel but De Wardes remained and waited

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: You will not break yourself of the habit, said Raoul to De Wardes, of insulting the absent; yesterday it was M. d'Artagnan, today it is the Duke of Buckingham.
children.prevalue: You will not break yourself of the habit said Raoul to De Wardes of insulting the absent yesterday it was M d Artagnan today it is the Duke of Buckingham

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: You know very well, monsieur, returned De Wardes, that I sometimes insult those who are present.
children.prevalue: You know very well monsieur returned De Wardes that I sometimes insult those who are present

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: De Wardes was close to Raoul, their shoulders met, their faces approached, as if to mutually inflame each other by the fire of their looks and of their anger. It could be seen that the one was at the height of fury, the other at the end of his patience. Suddenly a voice was heard behind them full of grace and courtesy, saying, I believe I heard my name pronounced.
children.prevalue: De Wardes was close to Raoul their shoulders met their faces approached as if to mutually inflame each other by the fire of their looks and of their anger It could be seen that the one was at the height of fury the other at the end of his patience Suddenly a voice was heard behind them full of grace and courtesy saying I believe I heard my name pronounced

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: They turned round and saw D'Artagnan, who, with a smiling eye and a cheerful face, had just placed his hand on De Wardes's shoulder. Raoul stepped back to make room for the musketeer. De Wardes trembled from head to foot, turned pale, but did not move. D'Artagnan, still with the same smile, took the place which Raoul had abandoned to him.
children.prevalue: They turned round and saw D Artagnan who with a smiling eye and a cheerful face had just placed his hand on De Wardes s shoulder Raoul stepped back to make room for the musketeer De Wardes trembled from head to foot turned pale but did not move D Artagnan still with the same smile took the place which Raoul had abandoned to him

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Thank you, my dear Raoul, he said. M. de Wardes, I wish to talk with you. Do not leave us, Raoul; every one can hear what I have to say to M. de Wardes. His smile immediately faded away, and his glace became cold and sharp as a sword.
children.prevalue: Thank you my dear Raoul he said M de Wardes I wish to talk with you Do not leave us Raoul every one can hear what I have to say to M de Wardes His smile immediately faded away and his glace became cold and sharp as a sword

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: I am at your orders, monsieur, said De Wardes.
children.prevalue: I am at your orders monsieur said De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: For a very long time, resumed D'Artagnan, I have sought an opportunity of conversing with you; today is the first time I have found it. The place is badly chosen, I admit, but you will perhaps have the goodness to accompany me to my apartments, which are on the staircase at the end of this gallery.
children.prevalue: For a very long time resumed D Artagnan I have sought an opportunity of conversing with you today is the first time I have found it The place is badly chosen I admit but you will perhaps have the goodness to accompany me to my apartments which are on the staircase at the end of this gallery

children.name: Paragraph_122
