children.value: I follow you, monsieur, said De Wardes.
children.prevalue: I follow you monsieur said De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: Are you alone here? said D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Are you alone here said D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: No; I have M. Manicamp and M. de Guiche, two of my friends.
children.prevalue: No I have M Manicamp and M de Guiche two of my friends

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: That's well, said D'Artagnan; but two persons are not sufficient; you will be able to find a few others, I trust.
children.prevalue: That s well said D Artagnan but two persons are not sufficient you will be able to find a few others I trust

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: Certainly, said the young man, who did not know what object D'Artagnan had in view. As many as you please.
children.prevalue: Certainly said the young man who did not know what object D Artagnan had in view As many as you please

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: Are they friends?
children.prevalue: Are they friends

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Yes, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Yes monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: Real friends?
children.prevalue: Real friends

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: No doubt of it.
children.prevalue: No doubt of it

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: Very well, get a good supply, then. Do you come, too, Raoul; bring M. de Guiche and the Duke of Buckingham.
children.prevalue: Very well get a good supply then Do you come too Raoul bring M de Guiche and the Duke of Buckingham

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: What a disturbance, replied De Wardes, attempting to smile. The captain slightly signed to him with his hand, as though to recommend him to be patient, and then led the way to his apartments. [2]
children.prevalue: What a disturbance replied De Wardes attempting to smile The captain slightly signed to him with his hand as though to recommend him to be patient and then led the way to his apartments 2

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: D'Artagnan's apartment was not unoccupied; for the Comte de la Fere, seated in the recess of a window, awaited him. Well, said he to D'Artagnan, as he saw him enter.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan s apartment was not unoccupied for the Comte de la Fere seated in the recess of a window awaited him Well said he to D Artagnan as he saw him enter

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Well, said the latter, M. de Wardes has done me the honor to pay me a visit, in company with some of his own friends, as well as of ours. In fact, behind the musketeer appeared De Wardes and Manicamp, followed by De Guiche and Buckingham, who looked surprised, not knowing what was expected of them. Raoul was accompanied by two or three gentlemen; and, as he entered, glanced round the room, and perceiving the count, he went and placed himself by his side. D'Artagnan received his visitors with all the courtesy he was capable of; he preserved his unmoved and unconcerned look. All the persons present were men of distinction, occupying posts of honor and credit at the court. After he had apologized to each of them for any inconvenience he might have put them to, he turned towards De Wardes, who, in spite of his customary selfcommand, could not prevent his face betraying some surprise mingled with not a little uneasiness.
children.prevalue: Well said the latter M de Wardes has done me the honor to pay me a visit in company with some of his own friends as well as of ours In fact behind the musketeer appeared De Wardes and Manicamp followed by De Guiche and Buckingham who looked surprised not knowing what was expected of them Raoul was accompanied by two or three gentlemen and as he entered glanced round the room and perceiving the count he went and placed himself by his side D Artagnan received his visitors with all the courtesy he was capable of he preserved his unmoved and unconcerned look All the persons present were men of distinction occupying posts of honor and credit at the court After he had apologized to each of them for any inconvenience he might have put them to he turned towards De Wardes who in spite of his customary selfcommand could not prevent his face betraying some surprise mingled with not a little uneasiness

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Now, monsieur, said D'Artagnan, since we are no longer within the precincts of the king's palace, and since we can speak out without failing in respect to propriety, I will inform you why I have taken the liberty to request you to visit me here, and why I have invited these gentlemen to be present at the same time. My friend, the Comte de la Fere, has acquainted me with the injurious reports you are spreading about myself. You have stated that you regard me as your mortal enemy, because I was, so you affirm, that of your father.
children.prevalue: Now monsieur said D Artagnan since we are no longer within the precincts of the king s palace and since we can speak out without failing in respect to propriety I will inform you why I have taken the liberty to request you to visit me here and why I have invited these gentlemen to be present at the same time My friend the Comte de la Fere has acquainted me with the injurious reports you are spreading about myself You have stated that you regard me as your mortal enemy because I was so you affirm that of your father

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Perfectly true, monsieur, I have said so, replied De Wardes, whose pallid face became slightly tinged with color.
children.prevalue: Perfectly true monsieur I have said so replied De Wardes whose pallid face became slightly tinged with color

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: You accuse me, therefore, of a crime, or a fault, or of some mean and cowardly act. Have the goodness to state your charge against me in precise terms.
children.prevalue: You accuse me therefore of a crime or a fault or of some mean and cowardly act Have the goodness to state your charge against me in precise terms

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: In the presence of witnesses?
children.prevalue: In the presence of witnesses

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Most certainly in the presence of witnesses; and you see I have selected them as being experienced in affairs of honor.
children.prevalue: Most certainly in the presence of witnesses and you see I have selected them as being experienced in affairs of honor

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: You do not appreciate my delicacy, monsieur. I have accused you, it is true; but I have kept the nature of the accusation a perfect secret. I entered into no details; but have rested satisfied by expressing my hatred in the presence of those on whom a duty was almost imposed to acquaint you with it. You have not taken the discreetness I have shown into consideration, although you were interested in remaining silent. I can hardly recognize your habitual prudence in that, M. d'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: You do not appreciate my delicacy monsieur I have accused you it is true but I have kept the nature of the accusation a perfect secret I entered into no details but have rested satisfied by expressing my hatred in the presence of those on whom a duty was almost imposed to acquaint you with it You have not taken the discreetness I have shown into consideration although you were interested in remaining silent I can hardly recognize your habitual prudence in that M d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: D'Artagnan, who was quietly biting the corner of his moustache, said, I have already had the honor to beg you to state the particulars of the grievances you say you have against me.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan who was quietly biting the corner of his moustache said I have already had the honor to beg you to state the particulars of the grievances you say you have against me

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Aloud?
children.prevalue: Aloud

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Certainly, aloud.
children.prevalue: Certainly aloud

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: In that case, I will speak.
children.prevalue: In that case I will speak

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Speak, monsieur, said D'Artagnan, bowing; we are all listening to you.
children.prevalue: Speak monsieur said D Artagnan bowing we are all listening to you

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Well, monsieur, it is not a question of a personal injury towards myself, but one towards my father.
children.prevalue: Well monsieur it is not a question of a personal injury towards myself but one towards my father

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: That you have already stated.
children.prevalue: That you have already stated

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Yes; but there are certain subjects which are only approached with hesitation.
children.prevalue: Yes but there are certain subjects which are only approached with hesitation

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: If that hesitation, in your case, really does exist, I entreat you to overcome it.
children.prevalue: If that hesitation in your case really does exist I entreat you to overcome it

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Even if it refer to a disgraceful action?
children.prevalue: Even if it refer to a disgraceful action

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Yes; in every and any case.
children.prevalue: Yes in every and any case

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Those who were present at this scene had, at first, looked at each other with a good deal of uneasiness. They were reassured, however, when they saw that D'Artagnan manifested no emotion whatever.
children.prevalue: Those who were present at this scene had at first looked at each other with a good deal of uneasiness They were reassured however when they saw that D Artagnan manifested no emotion whatever

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: De Wardes still maintained the same unbroken silence. Speak, monsieur, said the musketeer; you see you are keeping us waiting.
children.prevalue: De Wardes still maintained the same unbroken silence Speak monsieur said the musketeer you see you are keeping us waiting

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Listen, then:My father loved a lady of noble birth, and this lady loved my father. D'Artagnan and Athos exchanged looks. De Wardes continued: M. d'Artagnan found some letters which indicated a rendezvous, substituted himself, under disguise, for the person who was expected, and took advantage of the darkness.
children.prevalue: Listen then My father loved a lady of noble birth and this lady loved my father D Artagnan and Athos exchanged looks De Wardes continued M d Artagnan found some letters which indicated a rendezvous substituted himself under disguise for the person who was expected and took advantage of the darkness

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: That is perfectly true, said D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: That is perfectly true said D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: A slight murmur was heard from those present. Yes, I was guilty of that dishonorable action. You should have added, monsieur, since you are so impartial, that, at the period when the circumstance which you have just related happened, I was not oneandtwenty years of age.
children.prevalue: A slight murmur was heard from those present Yes I was guilty of that dishonorable action You should have added monsieur since you are so impartial that at the period when the circumstance which you have just related happened I was not oneandtwenty years of age

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: A renewed murmur was heard, but this time of astonishment, and almost of doubt.
children.prevalue: A renewed murmur was heard but this time of astonishment and almost of doubt

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: It was a most shameful deception, I admit, said D'Artagnan, and I have not waited for M. de Wardes's reproaches to reproach myself for it, and very bitterly, too. Age has, however, made me more reasonable, and, above all, more upright; and this injury has been atoned for by a long and lasting regret. But I appeal to you, gentlemen; this affair took place in 1626, at a period, happily for yourselves, known to you by tradition only, at a period when love was not overscrupulous, when consciences did not distill, as in the present day, poison and bitterness. We were young soldiers, always fighting, or being attacked, our swords always in our hands, or at least ready to be drawn from their sheaths. Death then always stared us in the face, war hardened us, and the cardinal pressed us sorely. I have repented of it, and more than thatI still repent it, M. de Wardes.
children.prevalue: It was a most shameful deception I admit said D Artagnan and I have not waited for M de Wardes s reproaches to reproach myself for it and very bitterly too Age has however made me more reasonable and above all more upright and this injury has been atoned for by a long and lasting regret But I appeal to you gentlemen this affair took place in 1626 at a period happily for yourselves known to you by tradition only at a period when love was not overscrupulous when consciences did not distill as in the present day poison and bitterness We were young soldiers always fighting or being attacked our swords always in our hands or at least ready to be drawn from their sheaths Death then always stared us in the face war hardened us and the cardinal pressed us sorely I have repented of it and more than thatI still repent it M de Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: I can well understand that, monsieur, for the action itself needed repentance; but you were not the less the cause of that lady's disgrace. She, of whom you have been speaking, covered with shame, borne down by the affront you brought upon her, fled, quitted France, and no one ever knew what became of her.
children.prevalue: I can well understand that monsieur for the action itself needed repentance but you were not the less the cause of that lady s disgrace She of whom you have been speaking covered with shame borne down by the affront you brought upon her fled quitted France and no one ever knew what became of her

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Stay, said the Comte de la Fere, stretching his hand towards De Wardes, with a peculiar smile upon his face, you are mistaken; she was seen; and there are persons even now present, who, having often heard her spoken of, will easily recognize her by the description I am about to give. She was about fiveandtwenty years of age, slender in form, of a pale complexion, and fairhaired; she was married in England.
children.prevalue: Stay said the Comte de la Fere stretching his hand towards De Wardes with a peculiar smile upon his face you are mistaken she was seen and there are persons even now present who having often heard her spoken of will easily recognize her by the description I am about to give She was about fiveandtwenty years of age slender in form of a pale complexion and fairhaired she was married in England

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Married? exclaimed De Wardes.
children.prevalue: Married exclaimed De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: So, you were not aware she was married? You see we are far better informed than yourself. Do you happen to know she was usually styled 'My Lady,' without the addition of any name to that description?
children.prevalue: So you were not aware she was married You see we are far better informed than yourself Do you happen to know she was usually styled My Lady without the addition of any name to that description

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Yes, I know that.
children.prevalue: Yes I know that

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Good Heavens! murmured Buckingham.
children.prevalue: Good Heavens murmured Buckingham

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Very well, monsieur. That woman, who came from England, returned to England after having thrice attempted M. d'Artagnan's life. That was but just, you will say, since M. d'Artagnan had insulted her. But that which was not just was, that, when in England, this woman, by her seductions, completely enslaved a young man in the service of Lord de Winter, by name Felton. You change color, my lord, said Athos, turning to the Duke of Buckingham, and your eyes kindle with anger and sorrow. Let your Grace finish the recital, then, and tell M. de Wardes who this woman was who placed the knife in the hand of your father's murderer.
children.prevalue: Very well monsieur That woman who came from England returned to England after having thrice attempted M d Artagnan s life That was but just you will say since M d Artagnan had insulted her But that which was not just was that when in England this woman by her seductions completely enslaved a young man in the service of Lord de Winter by name Felton You change color my lord said Athos turning to the Duke of Buckingham and your eyes kindle with anger and sorrow Let your Grace finish the recital then and tell M de Wardes who this woman was who placed the knife in the hand of your father s murderer

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: A cry escaped from the lips of all present. The young duke passed his handkerchief across his forehead, which was covered with perspiration. A dead silence ensued among the spectators.
children.prevalue: A cry escaped from the lips of all present The young duke passed his handkerchief across his forehead which was covered with perspiration A dead silence ensued among the spectators

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: You see, M. de Wardes, said D'Artagnan, whom this recital had impressed more and more, as his own recollection revived as Athos spoke, you see that my crime did not cause the destruction of any one's soul, and that the soul in question may fairly be considered to have been altogether lost before my regret. It is, however, an act of conscience on my part. Now this matter is settled, therefore, it remains for me to ask, with the greatest humility, your forgiveness for this shameless action, as most certainly I should have asked it of your father, if he were still alive, and if I had met him after my return to France, subsequent to the death of King Charles I.
children.prevalue: You see M de Wardes said D Artagnan whom this recital had impressed more and more as his own recollection revived as Athos spoke you see that my crime did not cause the destruction of any one s soul and that the soul in question may fairly be considered to have been altogether lost before my regret It is however an act of conscience on my part Now this matter is settled therefore it remains for me to ask with the greatest humility your forgiveness for this shameless action as most certainly I should have asked it of your father if he were still alive and if I had met him after my return to France subsequent to the death of King Charles I

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: That is too much, M. d'Artagnan, exclaimed many voices, with animation.
children.prevalue: That is too much M d Artagnan exclaimed many voices with animation

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: No, gentlemen, said the captain. And now, M. de Wardes, I hope all is finished between us, and that you will have no further occasion to speak ill of me again. Do you consider it completely settled?
children.prevalue: No gentlemen said the captain And now M de Wardes I hope all is finished between us and that you will have no further occasion to speak ill of me again Do you consider it completely settled

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: De Wardes bowed, and muttered to himself inarticulately.
children.prevalue: De Wardes bowed and muttered to himself inarticulately

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: I trust also, said D'Artagnan, approaching the young man closely, that you will no longer speak ill of any one, as it seems you have the unfortunate habit of doing; for a man so puritanically conscientious as you are, who can reproach an old soldier for a youthful freak fiveandthirty years after it happened, will allow me to ask whether you, who advocate such excessive purity of conscience, will undertake on your side to do nothing contrary either to conscience or the principle of honor. And now, listen attentively to what I am going to say, M. de Wardes, in conclusion. Take care that no tale, with which your name may be associated, reaches my ear.
children.prevalue: I trust also said D Artagnan approaching the young man closely that you will no longer speak ill of any one as it seems you have the unfortunate habit of doing for a man so puritanically conscientious as you are who can reproach an old soldier for a youthful freak fiveandthirty years after it happened will allow me to ask whether you who advocate such excessive purity of conscience will undertake on your side to do nothing contrary either to conscience or the principle of honor And now listen attentively to what I am going to say M de Wardes in conclusion Take care that no tale with which your name may be associated reaches my ear

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Monsieur, said De Wardes, it is useless threatening to no purpose.
children.prevalue: Monsieur said De Wardes it is useless threatening to no purpose

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: I have not yet finished, M. de Wardes, and you must listen to me still further. The circle of listeners, full of eager curiosity, drew closer. You spoke just now of the honor of a woman, and of the honor of your father. We were glad to hear you speak in that manner; for it is pleasing to think that such a sentiment of delicacy and rectitude, and which did not exist, it seems, in our minds, lives in our children; and it is delightful, too, to see a young man, at an age when men from habit become the destroyers of the honor of women, respect and defend it.
children.prevalue: I have not yet finished M de Wardes and you must listen to me still further The circle of listeners full of eager curiosity drew closer You spoke just now of the honor of a woman and of the honor of your father We were glad to hear you speak in that manner for it is pleasing to think that such a sentiment of delicacy and rectitude and which did not exist it seems in our minds lives in our children and it is delightful too to see a young man at an age when men from habit become the destroyers of the honor of women respect and defend it

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: De Wardes bit his lip and clenched his hands, evidently much disturbed to learn how this discourse, the commencement of which was announced in so threatening a manner, would terminate.
children.prevalue: De Wardes bit his lip and clenched his hands evidently much disturbed to learn how this discourse the commencement of which was announced in so threatening a manner would terminate

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: How did it happen, then, that you allowed yourself to say to M. de Bragelonne that he did not know who his mother was?
children.prevalue: How did it happen then that you allowed yourself to say to M de Bragelonne that he did not know who his mother was

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Raoul's eyes flashed, as, darting forward, he exclaimed,Chevalier, this is a personal affair of my own! At which exclamation, a smile, full of malice, passed across De Wardes's face.
children.prevalue: Raoul s eyes flashed as darting forward he exclaimed Chevalier this is a personal affair of my own At which exclamation a smile full of malice passed across De Wardes s face

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: D'Artagnan put Raoul aside, saying,Do not interrupt me, young man. And looking at De Wardes in an authoritative manner, he continued:I am now dealing with a matter which cannot be settled by means of the sword. I discuss it before men of honor, all of whom have more than once had their swords in their hands in affairs of honor. I selected them expressly. These gentlemen well know that every secret for which men fight ceases to be a secret. I again put my question to M. de Wardes. What was the subject of conversation when you offended this young man, in offending his father and mother at the same time?
children.prevalue: D Artagnan put Raoul aside saying Do not interrupt me young man And looking at De Wardes in an authoritative manner he continued I am now dealing with a matter which cannot be settled by means of the sword I discuss it before men of honor all of whom have more than once had their swords in their hands in affairs of honor I selected them expressly These gentlemen well know that every secret for which men fight ceases to be a secret I again put my question to M de Wardes What was the subject of conversation when you offended this young man in offending his father and mother at the same time

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: It seems to me, returned De Wardes, that liberty of speech is allowed, when it is supported by every means which a man of courage has at his disposal.
children.prevalue: It seems to me returned De Wardes that liberty of speech is allowed when it is supported by every means which a man of courage has at his disposal

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Tell me what the means are by which a man of courage can sustain a slanderous expression.
children.prevalue: Tell me what the means are by which a man of courage can sustain a slanderous expression

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The sword.
children.prevalue: The sword

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: You fail, not only in logic, in your argument, but in religion and honor. You expose the lives of many others, without referring to your own, which seems to be full of hazard. Besides, fashions pass away, monsieur, and the fashion of duelling has passed away, without referring in any way to the edicts of his majesty which forbid it. Therefore, in order to be consistent with your own chivalrous notions, you will at once apologize to M. de Bragelonne; you will tell him how much you regret having spoken so lightly, and that the nobility and purity of his race are inscribed, not in his heart alone, but still more in every action of his life. You will do and say this, M. de Wardes, as I, an old officer, did and said just now to your boy's moustache.
children.prevalue: You fail not only in logic in your argument but in religion and honor You expose the lives of many others without referring to your own which seems to be full of hazard Besides fashions pass away monsieur and the fashion of duelling has passed away without referring in any way to the edicts of his majesty which forbid it Therefore in order to be consistent with your own chivalrous notions you will at once apologize to M de Bragelonne you will tell him how much you regret having spoken so lightly and that the nobility and purity of his race are inscribed not in his heart alone but still more in every action of his life You will do and say this M de Wardes as I an old officer did and said just now to your boy s moustache

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: And if I refuse? inquired De Wardes.
children.prevalue: And if I refuse inquired De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: In that case the result will be
children.prevalue: In that case the result will be

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: That which you think you will prevent, said De Wardes, laughing; the result will be that your conciliatory address will end in a violation of the king's prohibition.
children.prevalue: That which you think you will prevent said De Wardes laughing the result will be that your conciliatory address will end in a violation of the king s prohibition

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Not so, said the captain, you are quite mistaken.
children.prevalue: Not so said the captain you are quite mistaken

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: What will be the result, then?
children.prevalue: What will be the result then

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: The result will be that I shall go to the king, with whom I am on tolerably good terms, to whom I have been happy enough to render certain services, dating from a period when you were not born, and who, at my request, has just sent me an order in blank for M. Baisemeaux de Montlezun, governor of the Bastile; and I shall say to the king: 'Sire, a man has in a most cowardly way insulted M. de Bragelonne by insulting his mother; I have written this man's name upon the lettre de cachet which your majesty has been kind enough to give me, so that M. de Wardes is in the Bastile for three years. And D'Artagnan, drawing the order signed by the king from his pocket, held it towards De Wardes.
children.prevalue: The result will be that I shall go to the king with whom I am on tolerably good terms to whom I have been happy enough to render certain services dating from a period when you were not born and who at my request has just sent me an order in blank for M Baisemeaux de Montlezun governor of the Bastile and I shall say to the king Sire a man has in a most cowardly way insulted M de Bragelonne by insulting his mother I have written this man s name upon the lettre de cachet which your majesty has been kind enough to give me so that M de Wardes is in the Bastile for three years And D Artagnan drawing the order signed by the king from his pocket held it towards De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Remarking that the young man was not quite convinced, and received the warning as an idle threat, he shrugged his shoulders and walked leisurely towards the table, upon which lay a writingcase and a pen, the length of which would have terrified the topographical Porthos. De Wardes then saw that nothing could well be more seriously intended than the threat in question, for the Bastile, even at that period, was already held in dread. He advanced a step towards Raoul, and, in an almost unintelligible voice, said,I offer my apologies in the terms which M. d'Artagnan just now dictated, and which I am forced to make to you.
children.prevalue: Remarking that the young man was not quite convinced and received the warning as an idle threat he shrugged his shoulders and walked leisurely towards the table upon which lay a writingcase and a pen the length of which would have terrified the topographical Porthos De Wardes then saw that nothing could well be more seriously intended than the threat in question for the Bastile even at that period was already held in dread He advanced a step towards Raoul and in an almost unintelligible voice said I offer my apologies in the terms which M d Artagnan just now dictated and which I am forced to make to you

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: One moment, monsieur, said the musketeer, with the greatest tranquillity, you mistake the terms of the apology. I did not say, 'and which I am forced to make'; I said, 'and which my conscience induces me to make.' This latter expression, believe me, is better than the former; and it will be far preferable, since it will be the most truthful expression of your own sentiments.
children.prevalue: One moment monsieur said the musketeer with the greatest tranquillity you mistake the terms of the apology I did not say and which I am forced to make I said and which my conscience induces me to make This latter expression believe me is better than the former and it will be far preferable since it will be the most truthful expression of your own sentiments

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: I subscribe to it, said De Wardes; but submit, gentlemen, that a thrust of the sword through the body, as was the custom formerly, was far better than tyranny like this.
children.prevalue: I subscribe to it said De Wardes but submit gentlemen that a thrust of the sword through the body as was the custom formerly was far better than tyranny like this

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: No, monsieur, replied Buckingham; for the swordthrust, when received, was no indication that a particular person was right or wrong; it only showed that he was more or less skillful in the use of the weapon.
children.prevalue: No monsieur replied Buckingham for the swordthrust when received was no indication that a particular person was right or wrong it only showed that he was more or less skillful in the use of the weapon

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Monsieur! exclaimed De Wardes.
children.prevalue: Monsieur exclaimed De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: There, now, interrupted D'Artagnan, you are going to say something very rude, and I am rendering a service by stopping you in time.
children.prevalue: There now interrupted D Artagnan you are going to say something very rude and I am rendering a service by stopping you in time

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Is that all, monsieur? inquired De Wardes.
children.prevalue: Is that all monsieur inquired De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Absolutely everything, replied D'Artagnan; and these gentlemen, as well as myself, are quite satisfied with you.
children.prevalue: Absolutely everything replied D Artagnan and these gentlemen as well as myself are quite satisfied with you

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Believe me, monsieur, that your reconciliations are not successful.
children.prevalue: Believe me monsieur that your reconciliations are not successful

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: In what way?
children.prevalue: In what way

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Because, as we are now about to separate, I would wager that M. de Bragelonne and myself are greater enemies than ever.
children.prevalue: Because as we are now about to separate I would wager that M de Bragelonne and myself are greater enemies than ever

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: You are deceived, monsieur, as far as I am concerned, returned Raoul; for I do not retain the slightest animosity in my heart against you.
children.prevalue: You are deceived monsieur as far as I am concerned returned Raoul for I do not retain the slightest animosity in my heart against you

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: This last blow overwhelmed De Wardes. He cast his eyes around him like a man bewildered. D'Artagnan saluted most courteously the gentlemen who had been present at the explanation; and every one, on leaving the room, shook hands with him; but not one hand was held out towards De Wardes. Oh! exclaimed the young man, can I not find some one on whom to wreak my vengeance?
children.prevalue: This last blow overwhelmed De Wardes He cast his eyes around him like a man bewildered D Artagnan saluted most courteously the gentlemen who had been present at the explanation and every one on leaving the room shook hands with him but not one hand was held out towards De Wardes Oh exclaimed the young man can I not find some one on whom to wreak my vengeance

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: You can, monsieur, for I am here, whispered a voice full of menace in his ear.
children.prevalue: You can monsieur for I am here whispered a voice full of menace in his ear

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: De Wardes turned round, and saw the Duke of Buckingham, who, having probably remained behind with that intention, had just approached him. You, monsieur? exclaimed De Wardes.
children.prevalue: De Wardes turned round and saw the Duke of Buckingham who having probably remained behind with that intention had just approached him You monsieur exclaimed De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Yes, I! I am no subject of the king of France; I am not going to remain on the territory, since I am about setting off for England. I have accumulated in my heart such a mass of despair and rage, that I, too, like yourself, need to revenge myself upon some one. I approve M. d'Artagnan's principles profoundly, but I am not bound to apply them to you. I am an Englishman, and, in my turn, I propose to you what you proposed to others to no purpose. Since you, therefore, are so terribly incensed, take me as a remedy. In thirtyfour hours' time I shall be at Calais. Come with me; the journey will appear shorter if together, than if alone. We will fight, when we get there, upon the sands which are covered by the rising tide, and which form part of the French territory during six hours of the day, but belong to the territory of Heaven during the other six.
children.prevalue: Yes I I am no subject of the king of France I am not going to remain on the territory since I am about setting off for England I have accumulated in my heart such a mass of despair and rage that I too like yourself need to revenge myself upon some one I approve M d Artagnan s principles profoundly but I am not bound to apply them to you I am an Englishman and in my turn I propose to you what you proposed to others to no purpose Since you therefore are so terribly incensed take me as a remedy In thirtyfour hours time I shall be at Calais Come with me the journey will appear shorter if together than if alone We will fight when we get there upon the sands which are covered by the rising tide and which form part of the French territory during six hours of the day but belong to the territory of Heaven during the other six

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: I accept willingly, said De Wardes.
children.prevalue: I accept willingly said De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: I assure you, said the duke, that if you kill me, you will be rendering me an infinite service.
children.prevalue: I assure you said the duke that if you kill me you will be rendering me an infinite service

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: I will do my utmost to make myself agreeable to you, duke, said De Wardes.
children.prevalue: I will do my utmost to make myself agreeable to you duke said De Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: It is agreed, then, that I carry you off with me?
children.prevalue: It is agreed then that I carry you off with me

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: I shall be at your commands. I needed some real danger and some mortal risk to run, to tranquilize me.
children.prevalue: I shall be at your commands I needed some real danger and some mortal risk to run to tranquilize me

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: In that case, I think you have met with what you are looking for. Farewell, M. de Wardes; tomorrow morning, my valet will tell you the exact hour of our departure; we can travel together like two excellent friends. I generally travel as fast as I can. Adieu.
children.prevalue: In that case I think you have met with what you are looking for Farewell M de Wardes tomorrow morning my valet will tell you the exact hour of our departure we can travel together like two excellent friends I generally travel as fast as I can Adieu

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Buckingham saluted De Wardes, and returned towards the king's apartments; De Wardes, irritated beyond measure, left the Palais Royal, and hurried through the streets homeward to the house where he lodged.
children.prevalue: Buckingham saluted De Wardes and returned towards the king s apartments De Wardes irritated beyond measure left the Palais Royal and hurried through the streets homeward to the house where he lodged

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: After the austere lesson administered to De Wardes, Athos and D'Artagnan together descended the staircase which led to the courtyard of the Palais Royal. You perceive, said Athos to D'Artagnan, that Raoul cannot, sooner or later, avoid a duel with De Wardes, for De Wardes is as brave as he is vicious and wicked.
children.prevalue: After the austere lesson administered to De Wardes Athos and D Artagnan together descended the staircase which led to the courtyard of the Palais Royal You perceive said Athos to D Artagnan that Raoul cannot sooner or later avoid a duel with De Wardes for De Wardes is as brave as he is vicious and wicked

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: I know such fellows well, replied D'Artagnan; I had an affair with the father. I assure you that, although at that time I had good muscles and a sort of brute courageI assure you that the father did me some mischief. But you should have seen how I fought it out with him. Ah, Athos, such encounters never take place in these times! I had a hand which could never remain at rest, a hand like quicksilver,you knew its quality, for you have seen me at work. My sword was no longer than a piece of steel; it was a serpent that assumed every form and every length, seeking where it might thrust its head; in other words, where it might fix its bite. I advanced half a dozen paces, then three, and then, body to body, I pressed my antagonist closely, then I darted back again ten paces. No human power could resist that ferocious ardor. Well, De Wardes the father, with the bravery of his race, with his dogged courage, occupied a good deal of my time; and my fingers, at the end of the engagement, were, I well remember, tired enough.
children.prevalue: I know such fellows well replied D Artagnan I had an affair with the father I assure you that although at that time I had good muscles and a sort of brute courageI assure you that the father did me some mischief But you should have seen how I fought it out with him Ah Athos such encounters never take place in these times I had a hand which could never remain at rest a hand like quicksilver you knew its quality for you have seen me at work My sword was no longer than a piece of steel it was a serpent that assumed every form and every length seeking where it might thrust its head in other words where it might fix its bite I advanced half a dozen paces then three and then body to body I pressed my antagonist closely then I darted back again ten paces No human power could resist that ferocious ardor Well De Wardes the father with the bravery of his race with his dogged courage occupied a good deal of my time and my fingers at the end of the engagement were I well remember tired enough

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: It is, then, as I said, resumed Athos, the son will always be looking out for Raoul, and will end by meeting him; and Raoul can easily be found when he is sought for.
children.prevalue: It is then as I said resumed Athos the son will always be looking out for Raoul and will end by meeting him and Raoul can easily be found when he is sought for

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Agreed; but Raoul calculates well; he bears no grudge against De Wardes,he has said so; he will wait until he is provoked, and in that case his position is a good one. The king will not be able to get out of temper about the matter; besides we shall know how to pacify his majesty. But why so full of these fears and anxieties? You don't easily get alarmed.
children.prevalue: Agreed but Raoul calculates well he bears no grudge against De Wardes he has said so he will wait until he is provoked and in that case his position is a good one The king will not be able to get out of temper about the matter besides we shall know how to pacify his majesty But why so full of these fears and anxieties You don t easily get alarmed

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: I will tell you what makes me anxious; Raoul is to see the king tomorrow, when his majesty will inform him of his wishes respecting a certain marriage. Raoul, loving as he does, will get out of temper, and once in an angry mood, if he were to meet De Wardes, the shell would explode.
children.prevalue: I will tell you what makes me anxious Raoul is to see the king tomorrow when his majesty will inform him of his wishes respecting a certain marriage Raoul loving as he does will get out of temper and once in an angry mood if he were to meet De Wardes the shell would explode

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: We will prevent the explosion.
children.prevalue: We will prevent the explosion

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Not I, said Athos, for I must return to Blois. All this gilded elegance of the court, all these intrigues, sicken me. I am no longer a young man who can make terms with the meanness of the day. I have read in the Great Book many things too beautiful and too comprehensive to longer take any interest in the trifling phrases which these men whisper among themselves when they wish to deceive others. In one word, I am weary of Paris wherever and whenever you are not with me; and as I cannot have you with me always, I wish to return to Blois.
children.prevalue: Not I said Athos for I must return to Blois All this gilded elegance of the court all these intrigues sicken me I am no longer a young man who can make terms with the meanness of the day I have read in the Great Book many things too beautiful and too comprehensive to longer take any interest in the trifling phrases which these men whisper among themselves when they wish to deceive others In one word I am weary of Paris wherever and whenever you are not with me and as I cannot have you with me always I wish to return to Blois

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: How wrong you are, Athos; how you gainsay your origin and the destiny of your noble nature. Men of your stamp are created to continue, to the very last moment, in full possession of their great faculties. Look at my sword, a Spanish blade, the one I wore at La Rochelle; it served me for thirty years without fail; one day in the winter it fell upon the marble floor on the Louvre and was broken. I had a huntingknife made of it which will last a hundred years yet. You, Athos, with your loyalty, your frankness, your cool courage, and your sound information, are the very man kings need to warn and direct them. Remain here; Monsieur Fouquet will not last as long as my Spanish blade.
children.prevalue: How wrong you are Athos how you gainsay your origin and the destiny of your noble nature Men of your stamp are created to continue to the very last moment in full possession of their great faculties Look at my sword a Spanish blade the one I wore at La Rochelle it served me for thirty years without fail one day in the winter it fell upon the marble floor on the Louvre and was broken I had a huntingknife made of it which will last a hundred years yet You Athos with your loyalty your frankness your cool courage and your sound information are the very man kings need to warn and direct them Remain here Monsieur Fouquet will not last as long as my Spanish blade

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Is it possible, said Athos, smiling, that my friend, D'Artagnan, who, after having raised me to the skies, making me an object of worship, casts me down from the top of Olympus, and hurls me to the ground? I have more exalted ambition, D'Artagnan. To be a ministerto be a slave,never! Am I not still greater? I am nothing. I remember having heard you occasionally call me 'the great Athos'; I defy you, therefore, if I were minister, to continue to bestow that title upon me. No, no; I do not yield myself in this manner.
children.prevalue: Is it possible said Athos smiling that my friend D Artagnan who after having raised me to the skies making me an object of worship casts me down from the top of Olympus and hurls me to the ground I have more exalted ambition D Artagnan To be a ministerto be a slave never Am I not still greater I am nothing I remember having heard you occasionally call me the great Athos I defy you therefore if I were minister to continue to bestow that title upon me No no I do not yield myself in this manner

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: We will not speak of it any more, then; renounce everything, even the brotherly feeling which unites us.
children.prevalue: We will not speak of it any more then renounce everything even the brotherly feeling which unites us

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: It is almost cruel what you say.
children.prevalue: It is almost cruel what you say

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: D'Artagnan pressed Athos's hand warmly. No, no; renounce everything without fear. Raoul can get on without you. I am at Paris.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan pressed Athos s hand warmly No no renounce everything without fear Raoul can get on without you I am at Paris

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: In that case I shall return to Blois. We will take leave of each other tonight; tomorrow at daybreak I shall be on my horse again.
children.prevalue: In that case I shall return to Blois We will take leave of each other tonight tomorrow at daybreak I shall be on my horse again

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: You cannot return to your hotel alone; why did you not bring Grimaud with you?
children.prevalue: You cannot return to your hotel alone why did you not bring Grimaud with you

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Grimaud takes his rest now; he goes to bed early, for my poor old servant gets easily fatigued. He came from Blois with me, and I compelled him to remain within doors; for if, in retracing the forty leagues which separate us from Blois, he needed to draw breath even, he would die without a murmur. But I don't want to lose Grimaud.
children.prevalue: Grimaud takes his rest now he goes to bed early for my poor old servant gets easily fatigued He came from Blois with me and I compelled him to remain within doors for if in retracing the forty leagues which separate us from Blois he needed to draw breath even he would die without a murmur But I don t want to lose Grimaud

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: You shall have one of my musketeers to carry a torch for you. Hola! some one there, called out D'Artagnan, leaning over the gilded balustrade. The heads of seven or eight musketeers appeared. I wish some gentleman, who is so disposed, to escort the Comte de la Fere, cried D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: You shall have one of my musketeers to carry a torch for you Hola some one there called out D Artagnan leaning over the gilded balustrade The heads of seven or eight musketeers appeared I wish some gentleman who is so disposed to escort the Comte de la Fere cried D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Thank you for your readiness, gentlemen, said Athos; I regret to have occasion to trouble you in this manner.
children.prevalue: Thank you for your readiness gentlemen said Athos I regret to have occasion to trouble you in this manner

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I would willingly escort the Comte de la Fere, said some one, if I had not to speak to Monsieur d'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: I would willingly escort the Comte de la Fere said some one if I had not to speak to Monsieur d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Who is that? said D'Artagnan, looking into the darkness.
children.prevalue: Who is that said D Artagnan looking into the darkness

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: I, Monsieur d'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: I Monsieur d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Heaven forgive me, if that is not Monsieur Baisemeaux's voice.
children.prevalue: Heaven forgive me if that is not Monsieur Baisemeaux s voice

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: It is, monsieur.
children.prevalue: It is monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: What are you doing in the courtyard, my dear Baisemeaux?
children.prevalue: What are you doing in the courtyard my dear Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: I am waiting your orders, my dear Monsieur d'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: I am waiting your orders my dear Monsieur d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Wretch that I am, thought D'Artagnan; true, you have been told, I suppose, that some one was to be arrested, and have come yourself, instead of sending an officer?
children.prevalue: Wretch that I am thought D Artagnan true you have been told I suppose that some one was to be arrested and have come yourself instead of sending an officer

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: I came because I had occasion to speak to you.
children.prevalue: I came because I had occasion to speak to you

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: You did not send to me?
children.prevalue: You did not send to me

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I waited until you were disengaged, said Monsieur Baisemeaux, timidly.
children.prevalue: I waited until you were disengaged said Monsieur Baisemeaux timidly

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: I leave you, D'Artagnan, said Athos.
children.prevalue: I leave you D Artagnan said Athos

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Not before I have present Monsieur Baisemeaux de Montlezun, the governor of the Bastile.
children.prevalue: Not before I have present Monsieur Baisemeaux de Montlezun the governor of the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Baisemeaux and Athos saluted each other.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux and Athos saluted each other

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Surely you must know each other, said D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Surely you must know each other said D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I have an indistinct recollection of Monsieur Baisemeaux, said Athos.
children.prevalue: I have an indistinct recollection of Monsieur Baisemeaux said Athos

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: You remember, my dear, Baisemeaux, the king's guardsman with whom we used formerly to have such delightful meetings in the cardinal's time?
children.prevalue: You remember my dear Baisemeaux the king s guardsman with whom we used formerly to have such delightful meetings in the cardinal s time

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Perfectly, said Athos, taking leave of him with affability.
children.prevalue: Perfectly said Athos taking leave of him with affability

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Monsieur le Comte de la Fere, whose nom de guerre was Athos, whispered D'Artagnan to Baisemeaux.
children.prevalue: Monsieur le Comte de la Fere whose nom de guerre was Athos whispered D Artagnan to Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Yes, yes, a brave man, one of the celebrated four.
children.prevalue: Yes yes a brave man one of the celebrated four

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Precisely so. But, my dear Baisemeaux, shall we talk now?
children.prevalue: Precisely so But my dear Baisemeaux shall we talk now

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: If you please.
children.prevalue: If you please

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: In the first place, as for the ordersthere are none. The king does not intend to arrest the person in question.
children.prevalue: In the first place as for the ordersthere are none The king does not intend to arrest the person in question

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: So much the worse, said Baisemeaux with a sigh.
children.prevalue: So much the worse said Baisemeaux with a sigh

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: What do you mean by so much the worse? exclaimed D'Artagnan, laughing.
children.prevalue: What do you mean by so much the worse exclaimed D Artagnan laughing

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: No doubt of it, returned the governor, my prisoners are my income.
children.prevalue: No doubt of it returned the governor my prisoners are my income

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: I beg your pardon, I did not see it in that light.
children.prevalue: I beg your pardon I did not see it in that light

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: And so there are no orders, repeated Baisemeaux with a sigh. What an admirable situation yours is, captain, he continued, after a pause; captainlieutenant of the musketeers.
children.prevalue: And so there are no orders repeated Baisemeaux with a sigh What an admirable situation yours is captain he continued after a pause captainlieutenant of the musketeers

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Oh, it is good enough; but I don't see why you should envy me; you, governor of the Bastile, the first castle in France.
children.prevalue: Oh it is good enough but I don t see why you should envy me you governor of the Bastile the first castle in France

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: I am well aware of that, said Baisemeaux, in a sorrowful tone of voice.
children.prevalue: I am well aware of that said Baisemeaux in a sorrowful tone of voice

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: You say that like a man confessing his sins. I would willingly exchange my profits for yours.
children.prevalue: You say that like a man confessing his sins I would willingly exchange my profits for yours

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Don't speak of profits to me, if you wish to save me the bitterest anguish of mind.
children.prevalue: Don t speak of profits to me if you wish to save me the bitterest anguish of mind

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Why do you look first on one side and then on the other, as if you were afraid of being arrested yourself, you whose business it is to arrest others?
children.prevalue: Why do you look first on one side and then on the other as if you were afraid of being arrested yourself you whose business it is to arrest others

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: I was looking to see whether any one could see or listen to us; it would be safer to confer more in private, if you would grant me such a favor.
children.prevalue: I was looking to see whether any one could see or listen to us it would be safer to confer more in private if you would grant me such a favor

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Baisemeaux, you seem to forget we are acquaintances of five and thirty years' standing. Don't assume such sanctified airs; make yourself quite comfortable; I don't eat governors of the Bastile raw.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux you seem to forget we are acquaintances of five and thirty years standing Don t assume such sanctified airs make yourself quite comfortable I don t eat governors of the Bastile raw

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Heaven be praised!
children.prevalue: Heaven be praised

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Come into the courtyard with me; it's a beautiful moonlit night; we will walk up and down, arm in arm, under the trees, while you tell me your pitiful tale. He drew the doleful governor into the courtyard, took him by the arm as he had said, and, in his rough, goodhumored way, cried: Out with it, rattle away, Baisemeaux; what have you got to say?
children.prevalue: Come into the courtyard with me it s a beautiful moonlit night we will walk up and down arm in arm under the trees while you tell me your pitiful tale He drew the doleful governor into the courtyard took him by the arm as he had said and in his rough goodhumored way cried Out with it rattle away Baisemeaux what have you got to say

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: It's a long story.
children.prevalue: It s a long story

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: You prefer your own lamentations, then; my opinion is, it will be longer than ever. I'll wager you are making fifty thousand francs out of your pigeons in the Bastile.
children.prevalue: You prefer your own lamentations then my opinion is it will be longer than ever I ll wager you are making fifty thousand francs out of your pigeons in the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Would to heaven that were the case, M. d'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Would to heaven that were the case M d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: You surprise me, Baisemeaux; just look at you, acting the anchorite. I should like to show you your face in a glass, and you would see how plump and floridlooking you are, as fat and round as a cheese, with eyes like lighted coals; and if it were not for that ugly wrinkle you try to cultivate on your forehead, you would hardly look fifty years old, and you are sixty, if I am not mistaken.
children.prevalue: You surprise me Baisemeaux just look at you acting the anchorite I should like to show you your face in a glass and you would see how plump and floridlooking you are as fat and round as a cheese with eyes like lighted coals and if it were not for that ugly wrinkle you try to cultivate on your forehead you would hardly look fifty years old and you are sixty if I am not mistaken

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: All quite true.
children.prevalue: All quite true

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Of course I knew it was true, as true as the fifty thousand francs profit you make; at which remark Baisemeaux stamped on the ground.
children.prevalue: Of course I knew it was true as true as the fifty thousand francs profit you make at which remark Baisemeaux stamped on the ground

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Well, well, said D'Artagnan, I will add up your accounts for you: you were captain of M. Mazarin's guards; and twelve thousand francs a year would in twelve years amount to one hundred and forty thousand francs.
children.prevalue: Well well said D Artagnan I will add up your accounts for you you were captain of M Mazarin s guards and twelve thousand francs a year would in twelve years amount to one hundred and forty thousand francs

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Twelve thousand francs! Are you mad? cried Baisemeaux; the old miser gave me no more than six thousand, and the expenses of the post amounted to six thousand five hundred francs. M. Colbert, who deducted the other six thousand francs, condescended to allow me to take fifty thousand francs as a gratification; so that, if it were not for my little estate at Montlezun, which brings me in twelve thousand francs a year, I could not have met my engagements.
children.prevalue: Twelve thousand francs Are you mad cried Baisemeaux the old miser gave me no more than six thousand and the expenses of the post amounted to six thousand five hundred francs M Colbert who deducted the other six thousand francs condescended to allow me to take fifty thousand francs as a gratification so that if it were not for my little estate at Montlezun which brings me in twelve thousand francs a year I could not have met my engagements

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Well, then, how about the fifty thousand francs from the Bastile? There, I trust, you are boarded and lodged, and get your six thousand francs salary besides.
children.prevalue: Well then how about the fifty thousand francs from the Bastile There I trust you are boarded and lodged and get your six thousand francs salary besides

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Admitted!
children.prevalue: Admitted

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Whether the year be good or bad, there are fifty prisoners, who, on the average, bring you in a thousand francs a year each.
children.prevalue: Whether the year be good or bad there are fifty prisoners who on the average bring you in a thousand francs a year each

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: I don't deny it.
children.prevalue: I don t deny it

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Well, there is at once an income of fifty thousand francs; you have held the post three years, and must have received in that time one hundred and fifty thousand francs.
children.prevalue: Well there is at once an income of fifty thousand francs you have held the post three years and must have received in that time one hundred and fifty thousand francs

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: You forget one circumstance, dear M. d'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: You forget one circumstance dear M d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: What is that?
children.prevalue: What is that

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: That while you received your appointment as captain from the king himself, I received mine as governor from Messieurs Tremblay and Louviere.
children.prevalue: That while you received your appointment as captain from the king himself I received mine as governor from Messieurs Tremblay and Louviere

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Quite right, and Tremblay was not a man to let you have the post for nothing.
children.prevalue: Quite right and Tremblay was not a man to let you have the post for nothing

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Nor Louviere either: the result was, that I gave seventyfive thousand francs to Tremblay as his share.
children.prevalue: Nor Louviere either the result was that I gave seventyfive thousand francs to Tremblay as his share

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Very agreeable that! and to Louviere?
children.prevalue: Very agreeable that and to Louviere

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: The very same.
children.prevalue: The very same

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Money down?
children.prevalue: Money down

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: No: that would have been impossible. The king did not wish, or rather M. Mazarin did not wish, to have the appearance of removing those two gentlemen, who had sprung from the barricades; he permitted them, therefore, to make certain extravagant conditions for their retirement.
children.prevalue: No that would have been impossible The king did not wish or rather M Mazarin did not wish to have the appearance of removing those two gentlemen who had sprung from the barricades he permitted them therefore to make certain extravagant conditions for their retirement

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: What were those conditions?
children.prevalue: What were those conditions

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Tremble... three years' income for the goodwill.
children.prevalue: Tremble three years income for the goodwill

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: The deuce! so that the one hundred and fifty thousand francs have passed into their hands.
children.prevalue: The deuce so that the one hundred and fifty thousand francs have passed into their hands

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Precisely so.
children.prevalue: Precisely so

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: And beyond that?
children.prevalue: And beyond that

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: A sum of one hundred and fifty thousand francs, or fifteen thousand pistoles, whichever you please, in three payments.
children.prevalue: A sum of one hundred and fifty thousand francs or fifteen thousand pistoles whichever you please in three payments

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Exorbitant.
children.prevalue: Exorbitant

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Yes, but that is not all.
children.prevalue: Yes but that is not all

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: What besides?
children.prevalue: What besides

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: In default of the fulfillment by me of any one of those conditions, those gentlemen enter upon their functions again. The king has been induced to sign that.
children.prevalue: In default of the fulfillment by me of any one of those conditions those gentlemen enter upon their functions again The king has been induced to sign that

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: It is monstrous, incredible!
children.prevalue: It is monstrous incredible

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Such is the fact, however.
children.prevalue: Such is the fact however

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: I do indeed pity you, Baisemeaux. But why, in the name of fortune, did M. Mazarin grant you this pretended favor? It would have been far better to have refused you altogether.
children.prevalue: I do indeed pity you Baisemeaux But why in the name of fortune did M Mazarin grant you this pretended favor It would have been far better to have refused you altogether

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Certainly, but he was strongly persuaded to do so by my protector.
children.prevalue: Certainly but he was strongly persuaded to do so by my protector

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Who is he?
children.prevalue: Who is he

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: One of your own friends, indeed; M. d'Herblay.
children.prevalue: One of your own friends indeed M d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: M. d'Herblay! Aramis!
children.prevalue: M d Herblay Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Just so; he has been very kind towards me.
children.prevalue: Just so he has been very kind towards me

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Kind! to make you enter into such a bargain!
children.prevalue: Kind to make you enter into such a bargain

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Listen! I wished to leave the cardinal's service. M. d'Herblay spoke on my behalf to Louviere and Tremblaythey objected; I wished to have the appointment very much, for I knew what it could be made to produce; in my distress I confided in M. d'Herblay, and he offered to become my surety for the different payments.
children.prevalue: Listen I wished to leave the cardinal s service M d Herblay spoke on my behalf to Louviere and Tremblaythey objected I wished to have the appointment very much for I knew what it could be made to produce in my distress I confided in M d Herblay and he offered to become my surety for the different payments

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: You astound me! Aramis became your surety?
children.prevalue: You astound me Aramis became your surety

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Like a man of honor; he procured the signature; Tremblay and Louviere resigned their appointments; I have paid every year twentyfive thousand francs to these two gentlemen; on the thirtyfirst of May, every year, M. d'Herblay himself comes to the Bastile, and brings me five thousand pistoles to distribute between my crocodiles.
children.prevalue: Like a man of honor he procured the signature Tremblay and Louviere resigned their appointments I have paid every year twentyfive thousand francs to these two gentlemen on the thirtyfirst of May every year M d Herblay himself comes to the Bastile and brings me five thousand pistoles to distribute between my crocodiles

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: You owe Aramis one hundred and fifty thousand francs, then?
children.prevalue: You owe Aramis one hundred and fifty thousand francs then

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: That is the very thing which is the cause of my despair, for I only owe him one hundred thousand.
children.prevalue: That is the very thing which is the cause of my despair for I only owe him one hundred thousand

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: I don't quite understand you.
children.prevalue: I don t quite understand you

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: He came and settled with the vampires only two years. Today, however, is the thirtyfirst of May, and he has not been yet, and tomorrow, at midday, the payment falls due; if, therefore, I don't pay tomorrow, those gentlemen can, by the terms of the contract, break off the bargain; I shall be stripped of everything; I shall have worked for three years, and given two hundred and fifty thousand francs for nothing, absolutely for nothing at all, dear M. d'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: He came and settled with the vampires only two years Today however is the thirtyfirst of May and he has not been yet and tomorrow at midday the payment falls due if therefore I don t pay tomorrow those gentlemen can by the terms of the contract break off the bargain I shall be stripped of everything I shall have worked for three years and given two hundred and fifty thousand francs for nothing absolutely for nothing at all dear M d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: This is very strange, murmured D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: This is very strange murmured D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: You can now imagine that I may well have wrinkles on my forehead, can you not?
children.prevalue: You can now imagine that I may well have wrinkles on my forehead can you not

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Yes, indeed!
children.prevalue: Yes indeed

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: And you can imagine, too, that notwithstanding I may be as round as a cheese, with a complexion like an apple, and my eyes like coals on fire, I may almost be afraid that I shall not have a cheese or an apple left me to eat, and that my eyes will be left me only to weep with.
children.prevalue: And you can imagine too that notwithstanding I may be as round as a cheese with a complexion like an apple and my eyes like coals on fire I may almost be afraid that I shall not have a cheese or an apple left me to eat and that my eyes will be left me only to weep with

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: It is really a very grievous affair.
children.prevalue: It is really a very grievous affair

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: I have come to you, M. d'Artagnan, for you are the only man who can get me out of my trouble.
children.prevalue: I have come to you M d Artagnan for you are the only man who can get me out of my trouble

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: In what way?
children.prevalue: In what way

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: You are acquainted with the Abbe d'Herblay, and you know that he is a somewhat mysterious gentleman.
children.prevalue: You are acquainted with the Abbe d Herblay and you know that he is a somewhat mysterious gentleman

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Well, you can, perhaps, give me the address of his presbytery, for I have been to NoisyleSec, and he is no longer there.
children.prevalue: Well you can perhaps give me the address of his presbytery for I have been to NoisyleSec and he is no longer there

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: I should think not, indeed. He is Bishop of Vannes.
children.prevalue: I should think not indeed He is Bishop of Vannes

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: What! Vannes in Bretagne?
children.prevalue: What Vannes in Bretagne

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: The little man began to tear his hair, saying, How can I get to Vannes from here by midday tomorrow? I am a lost man.
children.prevalue: The little man began to tear his hair saying How can I get to Vannes from here by midday tomorrow I am a lost man

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Your despair quite distresses me.
children.prevalue: Your despair quite distresses me

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Vannes, Vannes! cried Baisemeaux.
children.prevalue: Vannes Vannes cried Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: But listen; a bishop is not always a resident. M. d'Herblay may not possibly be so far away as you fear.
children.prevalue: But listen a bishop is not always a resident M d Herblay may not possibly be so far away as you fear

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Pray tell me his address.
children.prevalue: Pray tell me his address

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: I really don't know it.
children.prevalue: I really don t know it

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: In that case I am lost. I will go and throw myself at the king's feet.
children.prevalue: In that case I am lost I will go and throw myself at the king s feet

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: But, Baisemeaux, I can hardly believe what you tell me; besides, since the Bastile is capable of producing fifty thousand francs a year, why have you not tried to screw one hundred thousand out of it?
children.prevalue: But Baisemeaux I can hardly believe what you tell me besides since the Bastile is capable of producing fifty thousand francs a year why have you not tried to screw one hundred thousand out of it

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: Because I am an honest man, M. d'Artagnan, and because my prisoners are fed like ambassadors.
children.prevalue: Because I am an honest man M d Artagnan and because my prisoners are fed like ambassadors

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Well, you're in a fair way to get out of your difficulties; give yourself a good attack of indigestion with your excellent living, and put yourself out of the way between this and midday tomorrow.
children.prevalue: Well you re in a fair way to get out of your difficulties give yourself a good attack of indigestion with your excellent living and put yourself out of the way between this and midday tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: How can you be hardhearted enough to laugh?
children.prevalue: How can you be hardhearted enough to laugh

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: Nay, you really afflict me. Come, Baisemeaux, if you can pledge me your word of honor, do so, that you will not open your lips to any one about what I am going to say to you.
children.prevalue: Nay you really afflict me Come Baisemeaux if you can pledge me your word of honor do so that you will not open your lips to any one about what I am going to say to you

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Never, never!
children.prevalue: Never never

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: You wish to put your hands on Aramis?
children.prevalue: You wish to put your hands on Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: At any cost!
children.prevalue: At any cost

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: Well, go and see where M. Fouquet is.
children.prevalue: Well go and see where M Fouquet is

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: Why, what connection can there be
children.prevalue: Why what connection can there be

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: How stupid you are! Don't you know that Vannes is in the diocese of BelleIsle, or BelleIsle in the diocese of Vannes? BelleIsle belongs to M. Fouquet, and M. Fouquet nominated M. d'Herblay to that bishopric!
children.prevalue: How stupid you are Don t you know that Vannes is in the diocese of BelleIsle or BelleIsle in the diocese of Vannes BelleIsle belongs to M Fouquet and M Fouquet nominated M d Herblay to that bishopric

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: I see, I see; you restore me to life again.
children.prevalue: I see I see you restore me to life again

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: So much the better. Go and tell M. Fouquet very simply that you wish to speak to M. d'Herblay.
children.prevalue: So much the better Go and tell M Fouquet very simply that you wish to speak to M d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: Of course, of course, exclaimed Baisemeaux, delightedly.
children.prevalue: Of course of course exclaimed Baisemeaux delightedly

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: But, said D'Artagnan, checking him by a severe look, your word of honor?
children.prevalue: But said D Artagnan checking him by a severe look your word of honor

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: I give you my sacred word of honor, replied the little man, about to set off running.
