children.prevalue: I give you my sacred word of honor replied the little man about to set off running

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: Where are you going?
children.prevalue: Where are you going

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: To M. Fouquet's house.
children.prevalue: To M Fouquet s house

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: It is useless doing that; M. Fouquet is playing at cards with the king. All you can do is to pay M. Fouquet a visit early tomorrow morning.
children.prevalue: It is useless doing that M Fouquet is playing at cards with the king All you can do is to pay M Fouquet a visit early tomorrow morning

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: I will do so. Thank you.
children.prevalue: I will do so Thank you

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: Good luck attend you, said D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Good luck attend you said D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: Thank you.
children.prevalue: Thank you

children.name: Paragraph_145
children.value: This is a strange affair, murmured D'Artagnan, as he slowly ascended the staircase after he had left Baisemeaux. What possible interest can Aramis have in obliging Baisemeaux in this manner? Well, I suppose we shall learn some day or another.
children.prevalue: This is a strange affair murmured D Artagnan as he slowly ascended the staircase after he had left Baisemeaux What possible interest can Aramis have in obliging Baisemeaux in this manner Well I suppose we shall learn some day or another

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Fouquet was present, as D'Artagnan had said, at the king's cardtable. It seemed as if Buckingham's departure had shed a balm on the lacerated hearts of the previous evening. Monsieur, radiant with delight, made a thousand affectionate signs to his mother. The Count de Guiche could not separate himself from Buckingham, and while playing, conversed with him upon the circumstance of his projected voyage. Buckingham, thoughtful, and kind in his manner, like a man who has adopted a resolution, listened to the count, and from time to time cast a look full of regret and hopeless affection at Madame. The princess, in the midst of her elation of spirits, divided her attention between the king, who was playing with her, Monsieur, who quietly joked her about her enormous winnings, and De Guiche, who exhibited an extravagant delight. Of Buckingham she took but little notice; for her, this fugitive, this exile, was now simply a remembrance, no longer a man. Light hearts are thus constituted; while they themselves continue untouched, they roughly break off with every one who may possibly interfere with their little calculations of self comfort. Madame had received Buckingham's smiles and attentions and sighs while he was present; but what was the good of sighing, smiling, and kneeling at a distance? Can one tell in what direction the winds in the Channel, which toss mighty vessels to and fro, carry such sighs as these? The duke could not fail to mark this change, and his heart was cruelly hurt. Of a sensitive character, proud and susceptible of deep attachment, he cursed the day on which such a passion had entered his heart. The looks he cast, from time to time at Madame, became colder by degrees at the chilling complexion of his thoughts. He could hardly yet despair, but he was strong enough to impose silence upon the tumultuous outcries of his heart. In exact proportion, however, as Madame suspected this change of feeling, she redoubled her activity to regain the ray of light she was about to lose; her timid and indecisive mind was displayed in brilliant flashes of wit and humor. At any cost she felt that she must be remarked above everything and every one, even above the king himself. And she was so, for the queens, notwithstanding their dignity, and the king, despite the respect which etiquette required, were all eclipsed by her. The queens, stately and ceremonious, were softened and could not restrain their laughter. Madame Henriette, the queenmother, was dazzled by the brilliancy which cast distinction upon her family, thanks to the wit of the granddaughter of Henry IV. The king, jealous, as a young man and as a monarch, of the superiority of those who surrounded him, could not resist admitting himself vanquished by a petulance so thoroughly French in its nature, whose energy more than ever increased by English humor. Like a child, he was captivated by her radiant beauty, which her wit made still more dazzling. Madame's eyes flashed like lightning. Wit and humor escaped from her scarlet lips like persuasion from the lips of Nestor of old. The whole court, subdued by her enchanting grace, noticed for the first time that laughter could be indulged in before the greatest monarch in the world, like people who merited their appellation of the wittiest and most polished people in Europe.

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Madame, from that evening, achieved and enjoyed a success capable of bewildering all not born to those altitudes termed thrones; which, in spite of their elevation, are sheltered from such giddiness. From that very moment Louis XIV. acknowledged Madame as a person to be recognized. Buckingham regarded her as a coquette deserving the cruelest tortures, and De Guiche looked upon her as a divinity; the courtiers as a star whose light might some day become the focus of all favor and power. And yet Louis XIV., a few years previously, had not even condescended to offer his hand to that ugly girl for a ballet; and Buckingham had worshipped this coquette on both knees. De Guiche had once looked upon this divinity as a mere woman; and the courtiers had not dared to extol this star in her upward progress, fearful to disgust the monarch whom such a dull star had formerly displeased.
children.prevalue: Madame from that evening achieved and enjoyed a success capable of bewildering all not born to those altitudes termed thrones which in spite of their elevation are sheltered from such giddiness From that very moment Louis XIV acknowledged Madame as a person to be recognized Buckingham regarded her as a coquette deserving the cruelest tortures and De Guiche looked upon her as a divinity the courtiers as a star whose light might some day become the focus of all favor and power And yet Louis XIV a few years previously had not even condescended to offer his hand to that ugly girl for a ballet and Buckingham had worshipped this coquette on both knees De Guiche had once looked upon this divinity as a mere woman and the courtiers had not dared to extol this star in her upward progress fearful to disgust the monarch whom such a dull star had formerly displeased

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Let us see what was taking place during this memorable evening at the king's cardtable. The young queen, although Spanish by birth, and the niece of Anne of Austria, loved the king, and could not conceal her affection. Anne of Austria, a keen observer, like all women, and imperious, like every queen, was sensible of Madame's power, and acquiesced in it immediately, a circumstance which induced the young queen to raise the siege and retire to her apartments. The king hardly paid any attention to her departure, notwithstanding the pretended symptoms of indisposition by which it was accompanied. Encouraged by the rules of etiquette, which he had begun to introduce at the court as an element of every relation of life, Louis XIV. did not disturb himself; he offered his hand to Madame without looking at Monsieur his brother, and led the young princess to the door of her apartments. It was remarked, that at the threshold of the door, his majesty, freed from every restraint, or not equal to the situation, sighed very deeply. The ladies presentnothing escapes a woman's glanceMademoiselle Montalais, for instancedid not fail to say to each other, the king sighed, and Madame sighed too. This had been indeed the case. Madame had sighed very noiselessly, but with an accompaniment very far more dangerous for the king's repose. Madame had sighed, first closing her beautiful black eyes, next opening them, and then, laden, as they were, with an indescribable mournfulness of expression, she had raised them towards the king, whose face at that moment visibly heightened in color. The consequence of these blushes, of those interchanged sighs, and of this royal agitation, was, that Montalais had committed an indiscretion which had certainly affected her companion, for Mademoiselle de la Valliere, less clear sighted, perhaps, turned pale when the king blushed; and her attendance being required upon Madame, she tremblingly followed the princess without thinking of taking the gloves, which court etiquette required her to do. True it is that the young country girl might allege as her excuse the agitation into which the king seemed to be thrown, for Mademoiselle de la Valliere, busily engaged in closing the door, had involuntarily fixed her eyes upon the king, who, as he retired backwards, had his face towards it. The king returned to the room where the cardtables were set out. He wished to speak to the different persons there, but it was easy to see that his mind was absent. He jumbled different accounts together, which was taken advantage of by some of the noblemen who had retained those habits since the time of Monsieur Mazarinwho had a poor memory, but was a good calculator. In this way, Monsieur Manicamp, with a thoughtless and absent airfor M. Manicamp was the honestest man in the world, appropriated twenty thousand francs, which were littering the table, and which did not seem to belong to any person in particular. In the same way, Monsieur de Wardes, whose head was doubtless a little bewildered by the occurrences of the evening, somehow forgot to leave behind him the sixty double louis which he had won for the Duke of Buckingham, and which the duke, incapable, like his father, of soiling his hands with coin of any sort, had left lying on the table before him. The king only recovered his attention in some degree at the moment that Monsieur Colbert, who had been narrowly observant for some minutes, approached, and, doubtless, with great respect, yet with much perseverance, whispered a counsel of some sort into the still tingling ears of the king. The king, at the suggestion, listened with renewed attention and immediately looking around him, said, Is Monsieur Fouquet no longer here?
children.prevalue: Let us see what was taking place during this memorable evening at the king s cardtable The young queen although Spanish by birth and the niece of Anne of Austria loved the king and could not conceal her affection Anne of Austria a keen observer like all women and imperious like every queen was sensible of Madame s power and acquiesced in it immediately a circumstance which induced the young queen to raise the siege and retire to her apartments The king hardly paid any attention to her departure notwithstanding the pretended symptoms of indisposition by which it was accompanied Encouraged by the rules of etiquette which he had begun to introduce at the court as an element of every relation of life Louis XIV did not disturb himself he offered his hand to Madame without looking at Monsieur his brother and led the young princess to the door of her apartments It was remarked that at the threshold of the door his majesty freed from every restraint or not equal to the situation sighed very deeply The ladies presentnothing escapes a woman s glanceMademoiselle Montalais for instancedid not fail to say to each other the king sighed and Madame sighed too This had been indeed the case Madame had sighed very noiselessly but with an accompaniment very far more dangerous for the king s repose Madame had sighed first closing her beautiful black eyes next opening them and then laden as they were with an indescribable mournfulness of expression she had raised them towards the king whose face at that moment visibly heightened in color The consequence of these blushes of those interchanged sighs and of this royal agitation was that Montalais had committed an indiscretion which had certainly affected her companion for Mademoiselle de la Valliere less clear sighted perhaps turned pale when the king blushed and her attendance being required upon Madame she tremblingly followed the princess without thinking of taking the gloves which court etiquette required her to do True it is that the young country girl might allege as her excuse the agitation into which the king seemed to be thrown for Mademoiselle de la Valliere busily engaged in closing the door had involuntarily fixed her eyes upon the king who as he retired backwards had his face towards it The king returned to the room where the cardtables were set out He wished to speak to the different persons there but it was easy to see that his mind was absent He jumbled different accounts together which was taken advantage of by some of the noblemen who had retained those habits since the time of Monsieur Mazarinwho had a poor memory but was a good calculator In this way Monsieur Manicamp with a thoughtless and absent airfor M Manicamp was the honestest man in the world appropriated twenty thousand francs which were littering the table and which did not seem to belong to any person in particular In the same way Monsieur de Wardes whose head was doubtless a little bewildered by the occurrences of the evening somehow forgot to leave behind him the sixty double louis which he had won for the Duke of Buckingham and which the duke incapable like his father of soiling his hands with coin of any sort had left lying on the table before him The king only recovered his attention in some degree at the moment that Monsieur Colbert who had been narrowly observant for some minutes approached and doubtless with great respect yet with much perseverance whispered a counsel of some sort into the still tingling ears of the king The king at the suggestion listened with renewed attention and immediately looking around him said Is Monsieur Fouquet no longer here

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Yes, sire, I am here, replied the superintendent, till then engaged with Buckingham, and approached the king, who advanced a step towards him with a smiling yet negligent air. Forgive me, said Louis, if I interrupt your conversation; but I claim your attention wherever I may require your services.
children.prevalue: Yes sire I am here replied the superintendent till then engaged with Buckingham and approached the king who advanced a step towards him with a smiling yet negligent air Forgive me said Louis if I interrupt your conversation but I claim your attention wherever I may require your services

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: I am always at the king's service, replied Fouquet.
children.prevalue: I am always at the king s service replied Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: And your cashbox, too, said the king, laughing with a false smile.
children.prevalue: And your cashbox too said the king laughing with a false smile

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: My cashbox more than anything else, said Fouquet, coldly.
children.prevalue: My cashbox more than anything else said Fouquet coldly

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The fact is, I wish to give a fete at Fontainebleauto keep open house for fifteen days, and I shall require and he stopped, glancing at Colbert. Fouquet waited without showing discomposure; and the king resumed, answering Colbert's icy smile, four million francs.
children.prevalue: The fact is I wish to give a fete at Fontainebleauto keep open house for fifteen days and I shall require and he stopped glancing at Colbert Fouquet waited without showing discomposure and the king resumed answering Colbert s icy smile four million francs

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Four million, repeated Fouquet, bowing profoundly. And his nails, buried in his bosom, were thrust into his flesh, but the tranquil expression of his face remained unaltered. When will they be required, sire?
children.prevalue: Four million repeated Fouquet bowing profoundly And his nails buried in his bosom were thrust into his flesh but the tranquil expression of his face remained unaltered When will they be required sire

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Take your time,I meanno, no; as soon as possible.
children.prevalue: Take your time I meanno no as soon as possible

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: A certain time will be necessary, sire.
children.prevalue: A certain time will be necessary sire

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Time! exclaimed Colbert, triumphantly.
children.prevalue: Time exclaimed Colbert triumphantly

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The time, monsieur, said the superintendent, with the haughtiest disdain, simply to count the money; a million can only be drawn and weighed in a day.
children.prevalue: The time monsieur said the superintendent with the haughtiest disdain simply to count the money a million can only be drawn and weighed in a day

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Four days, then, said Colbert.
children.prevalue: Four days then said Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: My clerks, replied Fouquet, addressing himself to the king, will perform wonders on his majesty's service, and the sum shall be ready in three days.
children.prevalue: My clerks replied Fouquet addressing himself to the king will perform wonders on his majesty s service and the sum shall be ready in three days

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: It was for Colbert now to turn pale. Louis looked at him astonished. Fouquet withdrew without any parade or weakness, smiling at his numerous friends, in whose countenances alone he read the sincerity of their friendshipan interest partaking of compassion. Fouquet, however, should not be judged by his smile, for, in reality, he felt as if he had been stricken by death. Drops of blood beneath his coat stained the fine linen that clothed his chest. His dress concealed the blood, and his smile the rage which devoured him. His domestics perceived, by the manner in which he approached his carriage, that their master was not in the best of humors: the result of their discernment was, that his orders were executed with that exactitude of maneuver which is found on board a manofwar, commanded during a storm by an illtempered captain. The carriage, therefore, did not simply roll alongit flew. Fouquet had hardly time to recover himself during the drive; on his arrival he went at once to Aramis, who had not yet retired for the night. As for Porthos, he had supped very agreeably off a roast leg of mutton, two pheasants, and a perfect heap of crayfish; he then directed his body to be anointed with perfumed oils, in the manner of the wrestlers of old; and when this anointment was completed, he had himself wrapped in flannels and placed in a warm bed. Aramis, as we have already said, had not retired. Seated at his ease in a velvet dressinggown, he wrote letter after letter in that fine and hurried handwriting, a page of which contained a quarter of a volume. The door was thrown hurriedly open, and the superintendent appeared, pale, agitated, anxious. Aramis looked up: Goodevening, said he; and his searching look detected his host's sadness and disordered state of mind. Was your play as good as his majesty's? asked Aramis, by way of beginning the conversation.
children.prevalue: It was for Colbert now to turn pale Louis looked at him astonished Fouquet withdrew without any parade or weakness smiling at his numerous friends in whose countenances alone he read the sincerity of their friendshipan interest partaking of compassion Fouquet however should not be judged by his smile for in reality he felt as if he had been stricken by death Drops of blood beneath his coat stained the fine linen that clothed his chest His dress concealed the blood and his smile the rage which devoured him His domestics perceived by the manner in which he approached his carriage that their master was not in the best of humors the result of their discernment was that his orders were executed with that exactitude of maneuver which is found on board a manofwar commanded during a storm by an illtempered captain The carriage therefore did not simply roll alongit flew Fouquet had hardly time to recover himself during the drive on his arrival he went at once to Aramis who had not yet retired for the night As for Porthos he had supped very agreeably off a roast leg of mutton two pheasants and a perfect heap of crayfish he then directed his body to be anointed with perfumed oils in the manner of the wrestlers of old and when this anointment was completed he had himself wrapped in flannels and placed in a warm bed Aramis as we have already said had not retired Seated at his ease in a velvet dressinggown he wrote letter after letter in that fine and hurried handwriting a page of which contained a quarter of a volume The door was thrown hurriedly open and the superintendent appeared pale agitated anxious Aramis looked up Goodevening said he and his searching look detected his host s sadness and disordered state of mind Was your play as good as his majesty s asked Aramis by way of beginning the conversation

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Fouquet threw himself upon a couch, and then pointed to the door to the servant who had followed him; when the servant had left he said, Excellent.
children.prevalue: Fouquet threw himself upon a couch and then pointed to the door to the servant who had followed him when the servant had left he said Excellent

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Aramis, who had followed every movement with his eyes, noticed that he stretched himself upon the cushions with a sort of feverish impatience. You have lost as usual? inquired Aramis, his pen still in his hand.
children.prevalue: Aramis who had followed every movement with his eyes noticed that he stretched himself upon the cushions with a sort of feverish impatience You have lost as usual inquired Aramis his pen still in his hand

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Even more than usual, replied Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Even more than usual replied Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: You know how to support losses?
children.prevalue: You know how to support losses

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Sometimes.
children.prevalue: Sometimes

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: What, Monsieur Fouquet a bad player!
children.prevalue: What Monsieur Fouquet a bad player

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: There is play and play, Monsieur d'Herblay.
children.prevalue: There is play and play Monsieur d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: How much have you lost? inquired Aramis, with a slight uneasiness.
children.prevalue: How much have you lost inquired Aramis with a slight uneasiness

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Fouquet collected himself a moment, and then, without the slightest emotion, said, The evening has cost me four millions, and a bitter laugh drowned the last vibration of these words.
children.prevalue: Fouquet collected himself a moment and then without the slightest emotion said The evening has cost me four millions and a bitter laugh drowned the last vibration of these words

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Aramis, who did not expect such an amount, dropped his pen. Four millions, he said; you have lost four millions,impossible!
children.prevalue: Aramis who did not expect such an amount dropped his pen Four millions he said you have lost four millions impossible

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Monsieur Colbert held my cards for me, replied the superintendent, with a similar bitter laugh.
children.prevalue: Monsieur Colbert held my cards for me replied the superintendent with a similar bitter laugh

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Ah, now I understand; so, so, a new application for funds?
children.prevalue: Ah now I understand so so a new application for funds

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Yes, and from the king's own lips. It was impossible to ruin a man with a more charming smile. What do you think of it?
children.prevalue: Yes and from the king s own lips It was impossible to ruin a man with a more charming smile What do you think of it

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: It is clear that your destruction is the object in view.
children.prevalue: It is clear that your destruction is the object in view

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: That is your opinion?
children.prevalue: That is your opinion

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Still. Besides, there is nothing in it which should astonish you, for we have foreseen it all along.
children.prevalue: Still Besides there is nothing in it which should astonish you for we have foreseen it all along

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Yes; but I did not expect four millions.
children.prevalue: Yes but I did not expect four millions

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: No doubt the amount is serious, but, after all, four millions are not quite the death of a man, especially when the man in question is Monsieur Fouquet.
children.prevalue: No doubt the amount is serious but after all four millions are not quite the death of a man especially when the man in question is Monsieur Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: My dear D'Herblay, if you knew the contents of my coffers, you would be less easy.
children.prevalue: My dear D Herblay if you knew the contents of my coffers you would be less easy

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: And you promised?
children.prevalue: And you promised

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: What could I do?
children.prevalue: What could I do

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: That's true.
children.prevalue: That s true

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The very day I refuse, Colbert will procure the money; whence I know not, but he will procure it: and I shall be lost.
children.prevalue: The very day I refuse Colbert will procure the money whence I know not but he will procure it and I shall be lost

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: There is no doubt of that. In how many days did you promise the four millions?
children.prevalue: There is no doubt of that In how many days did you promise the four millions

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: In three days. The king seemed exceedingly pressed.
children.prevalue: In three days The king seemed exceedingly pressed

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: In three days?
children.prevalue: In three days

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: When I think, resumed Fouquet, that just now as I passed along the streets, the people cried out, 'There is the rich Monsieur Fouquet,' it is enough to turn my brain.
children.prevalue: When I think resumed Fouquet that just now as I passed along the streets the people cried out There is the rich Monsieur Fouquet it is enough to turn my brain

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Stay, monsieur, the matter is not worth so much trouble, said Aramis, calmly, sprinkling some sand over the letter he had just written.
children.prevalue: Stay monsieur the matter is not worth so much trouble said Aramis calmly sprinkling some sand over the letter he had just written

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Suggest a remedy, then, for this evil without a remedy.
children.prevalue: Suggest a remedy then for this evil without a remedy

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: There is only one remedy for you,pay.
children.prevalue: There is only one remedy for you pay

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: But it is very uncertain whether I have the money. Everything must be exhausted; BelleIsle is paid for; the pension has been paid; and money, since the investigation of the accounts of those who farm the revenue, is scarce. Besides, admitting that I pay this time, how can I do so on another occasion? When kings have tasted money, they are like tigers who have tasted flesh, they devour everything. The day will arrivemust arrivewhen I shall have to say, 'Impossible, sire,' and on that very day I am a lost man.
children.prevalue: But it is very uncertain whether I have the money Everything must be exhausted BelleIsle is paid for the pension has been paid and money since the investigation of the accounts of those who farm the revenue is scarce Besides admitting that I pay this time how can I do so on another occasion When kings have tasted money they are like tigers who have tasted flesh they devour everything The day will arrivemust arrivewhen I shall have to say Impossible sire and on that very day I am a lost man

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Aramis raised his shoulders slightly, saying:
children.prevalue: Aramis raised his shoulders slightly saying

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: A man in your position, my lord, is only lost when he wishes to be so.
children.prevalue: A man in your position my lord is only lost when he wishes to be so

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: A man, whatever his position may be, cannot hope to struggle against a king.
children.prevalue: A man whatever his position may be cannot hope to struggle against a king

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Nonsense; when I was young I wrestled successfully with the Cardinal Richelieu, who was king of France,nay morecardinal.
children.prevalue: Nonsense when I was young I wrestled successfully with the Cardinal Richelieu who was king of France nay morecardinal

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Where are my armies, my troops, my treasures? I have not even BelleIsle.
children.prevalue: Where are my armies my troops my treasures I have not even BelleIsle

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Bah! necessity is the mother of invention, and when you think all is lost, something will be discovered which will retrieve everything.
children.prevalue: Bah necessity is the mother of invention and when you think all is lost something will be discovered which will retrieve everything

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Who will discover this wonderful something?
children.prevalue: Who will discover this wonderful something

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Yourself.
children.prevalue: Yourself

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: I! I resign my office of inventor.
children.prevalue: I I resign my office of inventor

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Then I will.
children.prevalue: Then I will

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Be it so. But set to work without delay.
children.prevalue: Be it so But set to work without delay

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Oh! we have time enough!
children.prevalue: Oh we have time enough

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: You kill me, D'Herblay, with your calmness, said the superintendent, passing his handkerchief over his face.
children.prevalue: You kill me D Herblay with your calmness said the superintendent passing his handkerchief over his face

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Do you not remember that I one day told you not to make yourself uneasy, if you possessed courage? Have you any?
children.prevalue: Do you not remember that I one day told you not to make yourself uneasy if you possessed courage Have you any

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I believe so.
children.prevalue: I believe so

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Then don't make yourself uneasy.
children.prevalue: Then don t make yourself uneasy

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: It is decided then, that, at the last moment, you will come to my assistance.
children.prevalue: It is decided then that at the last moment you will come to my assistance

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: It will only be the repayment of a debt I owe you.
children.prevalue: It will only be the repayment of a debt I owe you

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: It is the vocation of financiers to anticipate the wants of men such as yourself, D'Herblay.
children.prevalue: It is the vocation of financiers to anticipate the wants of men such as yourself D Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: If obligingness is the vocation of financiers, charity is the virtue of the clergy. Only, on this occasion, do you act, monsieur. You are not yet sufficiently reduced, and at the last moment we will see what is to be done.
children.prevalue: If obligingness is the vocation of financiers charity is the virtue of the clergy Only on this occasion do you act monsieur You are not yet sufficiently reduced and at the last moment we will see what is to be done

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: We shall see, then, in a very short time.
children.prevalue: We shall see then in a very short time

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Very well. However, permit me to tell you that, personally, I regret exceedingly that you are at present so short of money, because I myself was about to ask you for some.
children.prevalue: Very well However permit me to tell you that personally I regret exceedingly that you are at present so short of money because I myself was about to ask you for some

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: For yourself?
children.prevalue: For yourself

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: For myself, or some of my people, for mine or for ours.
children.prevalue: For myself or some of my people for mine or for ours

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: How much do you want?
children.prevalue: How much do you want

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Be easy on that score; a roundish sum, it is true, but not too exorbitant.
children.prevalue: Be easy on that score a roundish sum it is true but not too exorbitant

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Tell me the amount.
children.prevalue: Tell me the amount

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Fifty thousand francs.
children.prevalue: Fifty thousand francs

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Oh! a mere nothing. Of course one has always fifty thousand francs. Why the deuce cannot that knave Colbert be as easily satisfied as you areand I should give myself far less trouble than I do. When do you need this sum?
children.prevalue: Oh a mere nothing Of course one has always fifty thousand francs Why the deuce cannot that knave Colbert be as easily satisfied as you areand I should give myself far less trouble than I do When do you need this sum

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Tomorrow morning; but you wish to know its destination?
children.prevalue: Tomorrow morning but you wish to know its destination

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Nay, nay, chevalier, I need no explanation.
children.prevalue: Nay nay chevalier I need no explanation

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Tomorrow is the first of June.
children.prevalue: Tomorrow is the first of June

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: One of our bonds becomes due.
children.prevalue: One of our bonds becomes due

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: I did not know we had any bonds.
children.prevalue: I did not know we had any bonds

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Certainly, tomorrow we pay our last third instalment.
children.prevalue: Certainly tomorrow we pay our last third instalment

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: What third?
children.prevalue: What third

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Of the one hundred and fifty thousand francs to Baisemeaux.
children.prevalue: Of the one hundred and fifty thousand francs to Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Baisemeaux? Who is he?
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux Who is he

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: The governor of the Bastile.
children.prevalue: The governor of the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Yes, I remember. On what grounds am I to pay one hundred and fifty thousand francs for that man.
children.prevalue: Yes I remember On what grounds am I to pay one hundred and fifty thousand francs for that man

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: On account of the appointment which he, or rather we, purchased from Louviere and Tremblay.
children.prevalue: On account of the appointment which he or rather we purchased from Louviere and Tremblay

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: I have a very vague recollection of the matter.
children.prevalue: I have a very vague recollection of the matter

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: That is likely enough, for you have so many affairs to attend to. However, I do not believe you have any affair in the world of greater importance than this one.
children.prevalue: That is likely enough for you have so many affairs to attend to However I do not believe you have any affair in the world of greater importance than this one

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Tell me, then, why we purchased this appointment.
children.prevalue: Tell me then why we purchased this appointment

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Why, in order to render him a service in the first place, and afterwards ourselves.
children.prevalue: Why in order to render him a service in the first place and afterwards ourselves

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Ourselves? You are joking.
children.prevalue: Ourselves You are joking

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Monseigneur, the time may come when the governor of the Bastile may prove a very excellent acquaintance.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur the time may come when the governor of the Bastile may prove a very excellent acquaintance

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: I have not the good fortune to understand you, D'Herblay.
children.prevalue: I have not the good fortune to understand you D Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Monseigneur, we had our own poets, our own engineer, our own architect, our own musicians, our own printer, and our own painters; we needed our own governor of the Bastile.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur we had our own poets our own engineer our own architect our own musicians our own printer and our own painters we needed our own governor of the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Do you think so?
children.prevalue: Do you think so

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Let us not deceive ourselves, monseigneur; we are very much opposed to paying the Bastile a visit, added the prelate, displaying, beneath his pale lips, teeth which were still the same beautiful teeth so much admired thirty years previously by Marie Michon.
children.prevalue: Let us not deceive ourselves monseigneur we are very much opposed to paying the Bastile a visit added the prelate displaying beneath his pale lips teeth which were still the same beautiful teeth so much admired thirty years previously by Marie Michon

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: And you think it is not too much to pay one hundred and fifty thousand francs for that? I thought you generally put out money at better interest than that.
children.prevalue: And you think it is not too much to pay one hundred and fifty thousand francs for that I thought you generally put out money at better interest than that

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: The day will come when you will admit your mistake.
children.prevalue: The day will come when you will admit your mistake

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: My dear D'Herblay, the very day on which a man enters the Bastile, he is no longer protected by his past.
children.prevalue: My dear D Herblay the very day on which a man enters the Bastile he is no longer protected by his past

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Yes, he is, if the bonds are perfectly regular; besides, that good fellow Baisemeaux has not a courtier's heart. I am certain, my lord, that he will not remain ungrateful for that money, without taking into account, I repeat, that I retain the acknowledgements.
children.prevalue: Yes he is if the bonds are perfectly regular besides that good fellow Baisemeaux has not a courtier s heart I am certain my lord that he will not remain ungrateful for that money without taking into account I repeat that I retain the acknowledgements

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: It is a strange affair! usury in a matter of benevolence.
children.prevalue: It is a strange affair usury in a matter of benevolence

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Do not mix yourself up with it, monseigneur; if there be usury, it is I who practice it, and both of us reap the advantage from itthat is all.
children.prevalue: Do not mix yourself up with it monseigneur if there be usury it is I who practice it and both of us reap the advantage from itthat is all

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Some intrigue, D'Herblay?
children.prevalue: Some intrigue D Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: I do not deny it.
children.prevalue: I do not deny it

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: And Baisemeaux an accomplice in it?
children.prevalue: And Baisemeaux an accomplice in it

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Why not?there are worse accomplices than he. May I depend, then, upon the five thousand pistoles tomorrow?
children.prevalue: Why not there are worse accomplices than he May I depend then upon the five thousand pistoles tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Do you want them this evening?
children.prevalue: Do you want them this evening

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: It would be better, for I wish to start early; poor Baisemeaux will not be able to imagine what has be become of me, and must be upon thorns.
children.prevalue: It would be better for I wish to start early poor Baisemeaux will not be able to imagine what has be become of me and must be upon thorns

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: You shall have the amount in an hour. Ah, D'Herblay, the interest of your one hundred and fifty thousand francs will never pay my four millions for me.
children.prevalue: You shall have the amount in an hour Ah D Herblay the interest of your one hundred and fifty thousand francs will never pay my four millions for me

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Why not, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: Why not monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Goodnight, I have business to transact with my clerks before I retire.
children.prevalue: Goodnight I have business to transact with my clerks before I retire

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: A good night's rest, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: A good night s rest monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: D'Herblay, you wish things that are impossible.
children.prevalue: D Herblay you wish things that are impossible

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Shall I have my fifty thousand francs this evening?
children.prevalue: Shall I have my fifty thousand francs this evening

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Go to sleep, then, in perfect safetyit is I who tell you to do so.
children.prevalue: Go to sleep then in perfect safetyit is I who tell you to do so

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Notwithstanding this assurance, and the tone in which it was given, Fouquet left the room shaking his head, and heaving a sigh.
children.prevalue: Notwithstanding this assurance and the tone in which it was given Fouquet left the room shaking his head and heaving a sigh

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The clock of St. Paul was striking seven as Aramis, on horseback, dressed as a simple citizen, that is to say, in colored suit, with no distinctive mark about him, except a kind of huntingknife by his side, passed before the Rue du PetitMusc, and stopped opposite the Rue des Tournelles, at the gate of the Bastile. Two sentinels were on duty at the gate; they made no difficulty about admitting Aramis, who entered without dismounting, and they pointed out the way he was to go by a long passage with buildings on both sides. This passage led to the drawbridge, or, in other words, to the real entrance. The drawbridge was down, and the duty of the day was about being entered upon. The sentinel at the outer guardhouse stopped Aramis's further progress, asking him, in a rough tone of voice, what had brought him there. Aramis explained, with his usual politeness, that a wish to speak to M. Baisemeaux de Montlezun had occasioned his visit. The first sentinel then summoned a second sentinel, stationed within an inner lodge, who showed his face at the grating, and inspected the new arrival most attentively. Aramis reiterated the expression of his wish to see the governor; whereupon the sentinel called to an officer of lower grade, who was walking about in a tolerably spacious courtyard and who, in turn, on being informed of his object, ran to seek one of the officers of the governor's staff. The latter, after having listened to Aramis's request, begged him to wait a moment, then went away a short distance, but returned to ask his name. I cannot tell it you, monsieur, said Aramis; I need only mention that I have matters of such importance to communicate to the governor, that I can only rely beforehand upon one thing, that M. de Baisemeaux will be delighted to see me; nay, more than that, when you have told him that it is the person whom he expected on the first of June, I am convinced he will hasten here himself. The officer could not possibly believe that a man of the governor's importance should put himself out for a person of so little importance as the citizenlooking visitor on horseback. It happens most fortunately, monsieur, he said, that the governor is just going out, and you can perceive his carriage with the horses already harnessed, in the courtyard yonder; there will be no occasion for him to come to meet you, as he will see you as he passes by. Aramis bowed to signify his assent; he did not wish to inspire others with too exalted an opinion of himself, and therefore waited patiently and in silence, leaning upon the saddlebow of his horse. Ten minutes had hardly elapsed when the governor's carriage was observed to move. The governor appeared at the door, and got into the carriage, which immediately prepared to start. The same ceremony was observed for the governor himself as with a suspected stranger; the sentinel at the lodge advanced as the carriage was about to pass under the arch, and the governor opened the carriagedoor, himself setting the example of obedience to orders; so that, in this way, the sentinel could convince himself that no one quitted the Bastile improperly. The carriage rolled along under the archway, but at the moment the irongate was opened, the officer approached the carriage, which had again been stopped, and said something to the governor, who immediately put his head out of the doorway, and perceived Aramis on horseback at the end of the drawbridge. He immediately uttered almost a shout of delight, and got out, or rather darted out of his carriage, running towards Aramis, whose hands he seized, making a thousand apologies. He almost embraced him. What a difficult matter to enter the Bastile! said Aramis. Is it the same for those who are sent here against their wills, as for those who come of their own accord?

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: A thousand pardons, my lord. How delighted I am to see your Grace!
children.prevalue: A thousand pardons my lord How delighted I am to see your Grace

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Hush! What are you thinking of, my dear M. Baisemeaux? What do you suppose would be thought of a bishop in my present costume?
children.prevalue: Hush What are you thinking of my dear M Baisemeaux What do you suppose would be thought of a bishop in my present costume

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Pray, excuse me, I had forgotten. Take this gentleman's horse to the stables, cried Baisemeaux.
children.prevalue: Pray excuse me I had forgotten Take this gentleman s horse to the stables cried Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: No, no, said Aramis; I have five thousand pistoles in the saddlebags.
children.prevalue: No no said Aramis I have five thousand pistoles in the saddlebags

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The governor's countenance became so radiant, that if the prisoners had seen him they would have imagined some prince of the royal blood had arrived. Yes, you are right, the horse shall be taken to the government house. Will you get into the carriage, my dear M. d'Herblay? and it shall take us back to my house.
children.prevalue: The governor s countenance became so radiant that if the prisoners had seen him they would have imagined some prince of the royal blood had arrived Yes you are right the horse shall be taken to the government house Will you get into the carriage my dear M d Herblay and it shall take us back to my house

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Get into a carriage to cross a courtyard! do you believe I am so great an invalid? No, no, we will go on foot.
children.prevalue: Get into a carriage to cross a courtyard do you believe I am so great an invalid No no we will go on foot

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Baisemeaux then offered his arm as a support, but the prelate did not accept it. They arrived in this manner at the government house, Baisemeaux rubbing his hands and glancing at the horse from time to time, while Aramis was looking at the bleak bare walls. A tolerably handsome vestibule and a staircase of white stone led to the governor's apartments, who crossed the antechamber, the diningroom, where breakfast was being prepared, opened a small side door, and closeted himself with his guest in a large cabinet, the windows of which opened obliquely upon the courtyard and the stables. Baisemeaux installed the prelate with that allinclusive politeness of which a good man, or a grateful man, alone possesses the secret. An armchair, a footstool, a small table beside him, on which to rest his hand, everything was prepared by the governor himself. With his own hands, too, he placed upon the table, with much solicitude, the bag containing the gold, which one of the soldiers had brought up with the most respectful devotion; and the soldier having left the room, Baisemeaux himself closed the door after him, drew aside one of the windowcurtains, and looked steadfastly at Aramis to see if the prelate required anything further.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux then offered his arm as a support but the prelate did not accept it They arrived in this manner at the government house Baisemeaux rubbing his hands and glancing at the horse from time to time while Aramis was looking at the bleak bare walls A tolerably handsome vestibule and a staircase of white stone led to the governor s apartments who crossed the antechamber the diningroom where breakfast was being prepared opened a small side door and closeted himself with his guest in a large cabinet the windows of which opened obliquely upon the courtyard and the stables Baisemeaux installed the prelate with that allinclusive politeness of which a good man or a grateful man alone possesses the secret An armchair a footstool a small table beside him on which to rest his hand everything was prepared by the governor himself With his own hands too he placed upon the table with much solicitude the bag containing the gold which one of the soldiers had brought up with the most respectful devotion and the soldier having left the room Baisemeaux himself closed the door after him drew aside one of the windowcurtains and looked steadfastly at Aramis to see if the prelate required anything further

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Well, my lord, he said, still standing up, of all men of their word, you still continue to be the most punctual.
children.prevalue: Well my lord he said still standing up of all men of their word you still continue to be the most punctual

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: In matters of business, dear M. de Baisemeaux, exactitude is not a virtue only, it is a duty as well.
children.prevalue: In matters of business dear M de Baisemeaux exactitude is not a virtue only it is a duty as well

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Yes, in matters of business, certainly; but what you have with me is not of that character; it is a service you are rendering me.
children.prevalue: Yes in matters of business certainly but what you have with me is not of that character it is a service you are rendering me

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Come, confess, dear M. de Baisemeaux, that, notwithstanding this exactitude, you have not been without a little uneasiness.
children.prevalue: Come confess dear M de Baisemeaux that notwithstanding this exactitude you have not been without a little uneasiness

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: About your health, I certainly have, stammered out Baisemeaux.
children.prevalue: About your health I certainly have stammered out Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I wished to come here yesterday, but I was not able, as I was too fatigued, continued Aramis. Baisemeaux anxiously slipped another cushion behind his guest's back. But, continued Aramis, I promised myself to come and pay you a visit today, early in the morning.
children.prevalue: I wished to come here yesterday but I was not able as I was too fatigued continued Aramis Baisemeaux anxiously slipped another cushion behind his guest s back But continued Aramis I promised myself to come and pay you a visit today early in the morning

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: You are really very kind, my lord.
children.prevalue: You are really very kind my lord

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: And it was a good thing for me I was punctual, I think.
children.prevalue: And it was a good thing for me I was punctual I think

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: What do you mean?
children.prevalue: What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Yes, you were going out. At which latter remark Baisemeaux colored and said, It is true I was going out.
children.prevalue: Yes you were going out At which latter remark Baisemeaux colored and said It is true I was going out

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Then I prevent you, said Aramis; whereupon the embarrassment of Baisemeaux became visibly greater. I am putting you to inconvenience, he continued, fixing a keen glace upon the poor governor; if I had known that, I should not have come.
children.prevalue: Then I prevent you said Aramis whereupon the embarrassment of Baisemeaux became visibly greater I am putting you to inconvenience he continued fixing a keen glace upon the poor governor if I had known that I should not have come

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: How can your lordship imagine that you could ever inconvenience me?
children.prevalue: How can your lordship imagine that you could ever inconvenience me

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Confess you were going in search of money.
children.prevalue: Confess you were going in search of money

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: No, stammered out Baisemeaux, no! I assure you I was going to
children.prevalue: No stammered out Baisemeaux no I assure you I was going to

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Does the governor still intend to go to M. Fouquet? suddenly called out the major from below. Baisemeaux ran to the window like a madman. No, no, he exclaimed in a state of desperation, who the deuce is speaking of M. Fouquet? are you drunk below there? why am I interrupted when I am engaged on business?
children.prevalue: Does the governor still intend to go to M Fouquet suddenly called out the major from below Baisemeaux ran to the window like a madman No no he exclaimed in a state of desperation who the deuce is speaking of M Fouquet are you drunk below there why am I interrupted when I am engaged on business

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: You were going to M. Fouquet's, said Aramis, biting his lips, to M. Fouquet, the abbe, or the superintendent?
children.prevalue: You were going to M Fouquet s said Aramis biting his lips to M Fouquet the abbe or the superintendent

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Baisemeaux almost made up his mind to tell an untruth, but he could not summon courage to do so. To the superintendent, he said.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux almost made up his mind to tell an untruth but he could not summon courage to do so To the superintendent he said

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: It is true, then, that you were in want of money, since you were going to a person who gives it away!
children.prevalue: It is true then that you were in want of money since you were going to a person who gives it away

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: I assure you, my lord
children.prevalue: I assure you my lord

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: You were afraid?
children.prevalue: You were afraid

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: My dear lord, it was the uncertainty and ignorance in which I was as to where you were to be found.
children.prevalue: My dear lord it was the uncertainty and ignorance in which I was as to where you were to be found

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: You would have found the money you require at M. Fouquet's, for he is a man whose hand is always open.
children.prevalue: You would have found the money you require at M Fouquet s for he is a man whose hand is always open

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: I swear that I should never have ventured to ask M. Fouquet for money. I only wished to ask him for your address.
children.prevalue: I swear that I should never have ventured to ask M Fouquet for money I only wished to ask him for your address

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: To ask M. Fouquet for my address? exclaimed Aramis, opening his eyes in real astonishment.
children.prevalue: To ask M Fouquet for my address exclaimed Aramis opening his eyes in real astonishment

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Yes, said Baisemeaux, greatly disturbed by the glance which the prelate fixed upon him,at M. Fouquet's certainly.
children.prevalue: Yes said Baisemeaux greatly disturbed by the glance which the prelate fixed upon him at M Fouquet s certainly

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: There is no harm in that, dear M. Baisemeaux, only I would ask, why ask my address of M. Fouquet?
children.prevalue: There is no harm in that dear M Baisemeaux only I would ask why ask my address of M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: That I might write to you.
children.prevalue: That I might write to you

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I understand, said Aramis smiling, but that is not what I meant; I do not ask you what you required my address for: I only ask why you should go to M. Fouquet for it?
children.prevalue: I understand said Aramis smiling but that is not what I meant I do not ask you what you required my address for I only ask why you should go to M Fouquet for it

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Oh! said Baisemeaux, as BelleIsle is the property of M. Fouquet, and as BelleIsle is in the diocese of Vannes, and as you are bishop of Vannes
children.prevalue: Oh said Baisemeaux as BelleIsle is the property of M Fouquet and as BelleIsle is in the diocese of Vannes and as you are bishop of Vannes

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: But, my dear Baisemeaux, since you knew I was bishop of Vannes, you had no occasion to ask M. Fouquet for my address.
children.prevalue: But my dear Baisemeaux since you knew I was bishop of Vannes you had no occasion to ask M Fouquet for my address

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Well, monsieur, said Baisemeaux, completely at bay, if I have acted indiscreetly, I beg your pardon most sincerely.
children.prevalue: Well monsieur said Baisemeaux completely at bay if I have acted indiscreetly I beg your pardon most sincerely

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Nonsense, observed Aramis calmly: how can you possibly have acted indiscreetly? And while he composed his face, and continued to smile cheerfully on the governor, he was considering how Baisemeaux, who was not aware of his address, knew, however, that Vannes was his residence. I shall clear all this up, he said to himself; and then speaking aloud, added,Well, my dear governor shall we now arrange our little accounts?
children.prevalue: Nonsense observed Aramis calmly how can you possibly have acted indiscreetly And while he composed his face and continued to smile cheerfully on the governor he was considering how Baisemeaux who was not aware of his address knew however that Vannes was his residence I shall clear all this up he said to himself and then speaking aloud added Well my dear governor shall we now arrange our little accounts

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: I am at your orders, my lord; but tell me beforehand, my lord, whether you will do me the honor to breakfast with me as usual?
children.prevalue: I am at your orders my lord but tell me beforehand my lord whether you will do me the honor to breakfast with me as usual

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Very willingly, indeed.
children.prevalue: Very willingly indeed

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: That's well, said Baisemeaux, as he struck the bell before him three times.
children.prevalue: That s well said Baisemeaux as he struck the bell before him three times

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: What does that mean? inquired Aramis.
children.prevalue: What does that mean inquired Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: That I have some one to breakfast with me, and that preparations are to be made accordingly.
children.prevalue: That I have some one to breakfast with me and that preparations are to be made accordingly

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: And you rang thrice. Really, my dear governor, I begin to think you are acting ceremoniously with me.
children.prevalue: And you rang thrice Really my dear governor I begin to think you are acting ceremoniously with me

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: No, indeed. Besides, the least I can do is to receive you in the best way I can.
children.prevalue: No indeed Besides the least I can do is to receive you in the best way I can

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: But why so?
children.prevalue: But why so

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Because not even a prince could have done what you have done for me.
children.prevalue: Because not even a prince could have done what you have done for me

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Nonsense! nonsense!
children.prevalue: Nonsense nonsense

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Nay, I assure you
children.prevalue: Nay I assure you

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Let us speak of other matters, said Aramis. Or rather, tell me how your affairs here are getting on.
children.prevalue: Let us speak of other matters said Aramis Or rather tell me how your affairs here are getting on

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Not over well.
children.prevalue: Not over well

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: The deuce!
children.prevalue: The deuce

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: M. de Mazarin was not hard enough.
children.prevalue: M de Mazarin was not hard enough

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Yes, I see; you require a government full of suspicionlike that of the old cardinal, for instance.
children.prevalue: Yes I see you require a government full of suspicionlike that of the old cardinal for instance

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Yes; matters went on better under him. The brother of his 'gray eminence' made his fortune here.
children.prevalue: Yes matters went on better under him The brother of his gray eminence made his fortune here

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Believe me, my dear governor, said Aramis, drawing closer to Baisemeaux, a young king is well worth an old cardinal. Youth has its suspicions, its fits of anger, its prejudices, as old age has its hatreds, its precautions, and its fears. Have you paid your three years' profits to Louvidre and Tremblay?
children.prevalue: Believe me my dear governor said Aramis drawing closer to Baisemeaux a young king is well worth an old cardinal Youth has its suspicions its fits of anger its prejudices as old age has its hatreds its precautions and its fears Have you paid your three years profits to Louvidre and Tremblay

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Most certainly I have.
children.prevalue: Most certainly I have

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: So that you have nothing more to give them than the fifty thousand francs I have brought with me?
children.prevalue: So that you have nothing more to give them than the fifty thousand francs I have brought with me

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Nothing.
children.prevalue: Nothing

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Have you not saved anything, then?
children.prevalue: Have you not saved anything then

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: My lord, in giving the fifty thousand francs of my own to these gentlemen, I assure you that I gave them everything I gain. I told M. d'Artagnan so yesterday evening.
children.prevalue: My lord in giving the fifty thousand francs of my own to these gentlemen I assure you that I gave them everything I gain I told M d Artagnan so yesterday evening

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Ah! said Aramis, whose eyes sparkled for a moment, but became immediately afterwards as unmoved as before; so you have been to see my old friend D'Artagnan; how was he?
children.prevalue: Ah said Aramis whose eyes sparkled for a moment but became immediately afterwards as unmoved as before so you have been to see my old friend D Artagnan how was he

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Wonderfully well.
children.prevalue: Wonderfully well

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: And what did you say to him, M. de Baisemeaux?
children.prevalue: And what did you say to him M de Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: I told him, continued the governor, not perceiving his own thoughtlessness; I told him that I fed my prisoners too well.
children.prevalue: I told him continued the governor not perceiving his own thoughtlessness I told him that I fed my prisoners too well

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: How many have you? inquired Aramis, in an indifferent tone of voice.
children.prevalue: How many have you inquired Aramis in an indifferent tone of voice

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Sixty.
children.prevalue: Sixty

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Well, that is a tolerably round number.
children.prevalue: Well that is a tolerably round number

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: In former times, my lord, there were, during certain years, as many as two hundred.
children.prevalue: In former times my lord there were during certain years as many as two hundred

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Still a minimum of sixty is not to be grumbled at.
children.prevalue: Still a minimum of sixty is not to be grumbled at

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Perhaps not; for, to anybody but myself, each prisoner would bring in two hundred and fifty pistoles; for instance, for a prince of the blood I have fifty francs a day.
children.prevalue: Perhaps not for to anybody but myself each prisoner would bring in two hundred and fifty pistoles for instance for a prince of the blood I have fifty francs a day

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Only you have no prince of the blood; at least, I suppose so, said Aramis, with a slight tremor in his voice.
children.prevalue: Only you have no prince of the blood at least I suppose so said Aramis with a slight tremor in his voice

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: No, thank heaven!I mean, no, unfortunately.
children.prevalue: No thank heaven I mean no unfortunately

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: What do you mean by unfortunately?
children.prevalue: What do you mean by unfortunately

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Because my appointment would be improved by it. So fifty francs per day for a prince of the blood, thirtysix for a marechal of France
children.prevalue: Because my appointment would be improved by it So fifty francs per day for a prince of the blood thirtysix for a marechal of France

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: But you have as many marechals of France, I suppose, as you have princes of the blood?
children.prevalue: But you have as many marechals of France I suppose as you have princes of the blood

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Alas! no more. It is true lieutenantgenerals and brigadiers pay twentysix francs, and I have two of them. After that, come councilors of parliament, who bring me fifteen francs, and I have six of them.
children.prevalue: Alas no more It is true lieutenantgenerals and brigadiers pay twentysix francs and I have two of them After that come councilors of parliament who bring me fifteen francs and I have six of them

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: I did not know, said Aramis, that councilors were so productive.
children.prevalue: I did not know said Aramis that councilors were so productive

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Yes; but from fifteen francs I sink at once to ten francs; namely, for an ordinary judge, and for an ecclesiastic.
children.prevalue: Yes but from fifteen francs I sink at once to ten francs namely for an ordinary judge and for an ecclesiastic

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: And you have seven, you say; an excellent affair.
children.prevalue: And you have seven you say an excellent affair

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Nay, a bad one, and for this reason. How can I possibly treat these poor fellows, who are of some good, at all events, otherwise than as a councilor of parliament?
children.prevalue: Nay a bad one and for this reason How can I possibly treat these poor fellows who are of some good at all events otherwise than as a councilor of parliament

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Yes, you are right; I do not see five francs difference between them.
children.prevalue: Yes you are right I do not see five francs difference between them

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: You understand; if I have a fine fish, I pay four or five francs for it; if I get a fine fowl, it cost me a franc and a half. I fatten a good deal of poultry, but I have to buy grain, and you cannot imagine the army of rats that infest this place.
children.prevalue: You understand if I have a fine fish I pay four or five francs for it if I get a fine fowl it cost me a franc and a half I fatten a good deal of poultry but I have to buy grain and you cannot imagine the army of rats that infest this place

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Why not get half a dozen cats to deal with them?
children.prevalue: Why not get half a dozen cats to deal with them

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Cats, indeed; yes, they eat them, but I was obliged to give up the idea because of the way in which they treated my grain. I have been obliged to have some terrier dogs sent me from England to kill the rats. These dogs, unfortunately, have tremendous appetites; they eat as much as a prisoner of the fifth order, without taking into account the rabbits and fowls they kill.
children.prevalue: Cats indeed yes they eat them but I was obliged to give up the idea because of the way in which they treated my grain I have been obliged to have some terrier dogs sent me from England to kill the rats These dogs unfortunately have tremendous appetites they eat as much as a prisoner of the fifth order without taking into account the rabbits and fowls they kill

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Was Aramis really listening or not? No one could have told; his downcast eyes showed the attentive man, but the restless hand betrayed the man absorbed in thoughtAramis was meditating.
children.prevalue: Was Aramis really listening or not No one could have told his downcast eyes showed the attentive man but the restless hand betrayed the man absorbed in thoughtAramis was meditating

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: I was saying, continued Baisemeaux, that a goodsized fowl costs me a franc and a half, and that a fine fish costs me four or five francs. Three meals are served at the Bastile, and, as the prisoners, having nothing to do, are always eating, a tenfranc man costs me seven francs and a half.
children.prevalue: I was saying continued Baisemeaux that a goodsized fowl costs me a franc and a half and that a fine fish costs me four or five francs Three meals are served at the Bastile and as the prisoners having nothing to do are always eating a tenfranc man costs me seven francs and a half

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: But did you not say that you treated those at ten francs like those at fifteen?
children.prevalue: But did you not say that you treated those at ten francs like those at fifteen

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Yes, certainly.
children.prevalue: Yes certainly

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Very well! Then you gain seven francs and a half upon those who pay you fifteen francs.
children.prevalue: Very well Then you gain seven francs and a half upon those who pay you fifteen francs

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: I must compensate myself somehow, said Baisemeaux, who saw how he had been snapped up.
children.prevalue: I must compensate myself somehow said Baisemeaux who saw how he had been snapped up

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: You are quite right, my dear governor; but have you no prisoners below ten francs?
children.prevalue: You are quite right my dear governor but have you no prisoners below ten francs

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Oh, yes! we have citizens and barristers at five francs.
children.prevalue: Oh yes we have citizens and barristers at five francs

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: And do they eat, too?
children.prevalue: And do they eat too

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Not a doubt about it; only you understand that they do not get fish or poultry, nor rich wines at every meal; but at all events thrice a week they have a good dish at their dinner.
children.prevalue: Not a doubt about it only you understand that they do not get fish or poultry nor rich wines at every meal but at all events thrice a week they have a good dish at their dinner

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Really, you are quite a philanthropist, my dear governor, and you will ruin yourself.
children.prevalue: Really you are quite a philanthropist my dear governor and you will ruin yourself

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: No; understand me; when the fifteenfranc has not eaten his fowl, or the tenfranc has left his dish unfinished, I send it to the fivefranc prisoner; it is a feast for the poor devil, and one must be charitable, you know.
children.prevalue: No understand me when the fifteenfranc has not eaten his fowl or the tenfranc has left his dish unfinished I send it to the fivefranc prisoner it is a feast for the poor devil and one must be charitable you know

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: And what do you make out of your fivefranc prisoners?
children.prevalue: And what do you make out of your fivefranc prisoners

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: A franc and a half.
children.prevalue: A franc and a half

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Baisemeaux, you're an honest fellow; in honest truth I say so.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux you re an honest fellow in honest truth I say so

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Thank you, my lord. But I feel most for the small tradesmen and bailiffs' clerks, who are rated at three francs. They do not often see Rhine carp or Channel sturgeon.
children.prevalue: Thank you my lord But I feel most for the small tradesmen and bailiffs clerks who are rated at three francs They do not often see Rhine carp or Channel sturgeon

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: But do not the fivefranc gentlemen sometimes leave some scraps?
children.prevalue: But do not the fivefranc gentlemen sometimes leave some scraps

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Oh! my lord, do not believe I am so stingy as that; I delight the heart of some poor little tradesman or clerk by sending him a wing of a red partridge, a slice of venison, or a slice of a truffled pasty, dishes which he never tasted except in his dreams; these are the leavings of the twentyfourfranc prisoners; and as he eats and drinks, at dessert he cries 'Long live the King,' and blesses the Bastile; with a couple bottles of champagne, which cost me five sous, I make him tipsy every Sunday. That class of people call down blessings upon me, and are sorry to leave the prison. Do you know that I have remarked, and it does me infinite honor, that certain prisoners, who have been set at liberty, have, almost immediately afterwards, got imprisoned again? Why should this be the case, unless it be to enjoy the pleasures of my kitchen? It is really the fact.
children.prevalue: Oh my lord do not believe I am so stingy as that I delight the heart of some poor little tradesman or clerk by sending him a wing of a red partridge a slice of venison or a slice of a truffled pasty dishes which he never tasted except in his dreams these are the leavings of the twentyfourfranc prisoners and as he eats and drinks at dessert he cries Long live the King and blesses the Bastile with a couple bottles of champagne which cost me five sous I make him tipsy every Sunday That class of people call down blessings upon me and are sorry to leave the prison Do you know that I have remarked and it does me infinite honor that certain prisoners who have been set at liberty have almost immediately afterwards got imprisoned again Why should this be the case unless it be to enjoy the pleasures of my kitchen It is really the fact

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Aramis smiled with an expression of incredulity.
children.prevalue: Aramis smiled with an expression of incredulity

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: You smile, said Baisemeaux.
children.prevalue: You smile said Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: I do, returned Aramis.
children.prevalue: I do returned Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: I tell you that we have names which have been inscribed on our books thrice in the space of two years.
children.prevalue: I tell you that we have names which have been inscribed on our books thrice in the space of two years

children.name: Paragraph_110
