children.value: I must see it before I believe it, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: I must see it before I believe it said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Well, I can show it to you, although it is prohibited to communicate the registers to strangers; and if you really wish to see it with your own eyes
children.prevalue: Well I can show it to you although it is prohibited to communicate the registers to strangers and if you really wish to see it with your own eyes

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: I should be delighted, I confess.
children.prevalue: I should be delighted I confess

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Very well, said Baisemeaux, and he took out of a cupboard a large register. Aramis followed him most anxiously with his eyes, and Baisemeaux returned, placed the register upon the table, and turned over the leaves for a minute, and stayed at the letter M.
children.prevalue: Very well said Baisemeaux and he took out of a cupboard a large register Aramis followed him most anxiously with his eyes and Baisemeaux returned placed the register upon the table and turned over the leaves for a minute and stayed at the letter M

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Look here, said he, Martinier, January, 1659; Martinier, June, 1660; Martinier, March, 1661. Mazarinades, etc.; you understand it was only a pretext; people were not sent to the Bastile for jokes against M. Mazarin; the fellow denounced himself in order to get imprisoned here.
children.prevalue: Look here said he Martinier January 1659 Martinier June 1660 Martinier March 1661 Mazarinades etc you understand it was only a pretext people were not sent to the Bastile for jokes against M Mazarin the fellow denounced himself in order to get imprisoned here

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: And what was his object?
children.prevalue: And what was his object

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: None other than to return to my kitchen at three francs a day.
children.prevalue: None other than to return to my kitchen at three francs a day

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Three francspoor devil!
children.prevalue: Three francspoor devil

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: The poet, my lord, belongs to the lowest scale, the same style of board as the small tradesman and bailiff's clerk; but I repeat, it is to those people that I give these little surprises.
children.prevalue: The poet my lord belongs to the lowest scale the same style of board as the small tradesman and bailiff s clerk but I repeat it is to those people that I give these little surprises

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Aramis mechanically turned over the leaves of the register, continuing to read the names, but without appearing to take any interest in the names he read.
children.prevalue: Aramis mechanically turned over the leaves of the register continuing to read the names but without appearing to take any interest in the names he read

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: In 1661, you perceive, said Baisemeaux, eighty entries; and in 1659, eighty also.
children.prevalue: In 1661 you perceive said Baisemeaux eighty entries and in 1659 eighty also

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Ah! said Aramis. Seldon; I seem to know that name. Was it not you who spoke to me about a certain young man?
children.prevalue: Ah said Aramis Seldon I seem to know that name Was it not you who spoke to me about a certain young man

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: Yes, a poor devil of a student, who madeWhat do you call that where two Latin verses rhyme together?
children.prevalue: Yes a poor devil of a student who madeWhat do you call that where two Latin verses rhyme together

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: A distich.
children.prevalue: A distich

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: Yes; that is it.
children.prevalue: Yes that is it

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Poor fellow; for a distich.
children.prevalue: Poor fellow for a distich

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: Do you know that he made this distich against the Jesuits?
children.prevalue: Do you know that he made this distich against the Jesuits

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: That makes no difference; the punishment seems very severe. Do not pity him; last year you seemed to interest yourself in him.
children.prevalue: That makes no difference the punishment seems very severe Do not pity him last year you seemed to interest yourself in him

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Yes, I did so.
children.prevalue: Yes I did so

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: Well, as your interest is allpowerful here, my lord, I have treated him since that time as a prisoner at fifteen francs.
children.prevalue: Well as your interest is allpowerful here my lord I have treated him since that time as a prisoner at fifteen francs

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: The same as this one, then, said Aramis, who had continued turning over the leaves, and who had stopped at one of the names which followed Martinier.
children.prevalue: The same as this one then said Aramis who had continued turning over the leaves and who had stopped at one of the names which followed Martinier

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: Yes, the same as that one.
children.prevalue: Yes the same as that one

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: Is that Marchiali an Italian? said Aramis, pointing with his finger to the name which had attracted his attention.
children.prevalue: Is that Marchiali an Italian said Aramis pointing with his finger to the name which had attracted his attention

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: Hush! said Baisemeaux.
children.prevalue: Hush said Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: Why hush? said Aramis, involuntarily clenching his white hand.
children.prevalue: Why hush said Aramis involuntarily clenching his white hand

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: I thought I had already spoken to you about that Marchiali.
children.prevalue: I thought I had already spoken to you about that Marchiali

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: No, it is the first time I ever heard his name pronounced.
children.prevalue: No it is the first time I ever heard his name pronounced

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: That may be, but perhaps I have spoken to you about him without naming him.
children.prevalue: That may be but perhaps I have spoken to you about him without naming him

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: Is he an old offender? asked Aramis, attempting to smile.
children.prevalue: Is he an old offender asked Aramis attempting to smile

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: On the contrary, he is quite young.
children.prevalue: On the contrary he is quite young

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: Is his crime, then, very heinous?
children.prevalue: Is his crime then very heinous

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: Unpardonable.
children.prevalue: Unpardonable

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: Has he assassinated any one?
children.prevalue: Has he assassinated any one

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: Bah!
children.prevalue: Bah

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: An incendiary, then?
children.prevalue: An incendiary then

children.name: Paragraph_145
children.value: Bah!
children.prevalue: Bah

children.name: Paragraph_146
children.value: Has he slandered any one?
children.prevalue: Has he slandered any one

children.name: Paragraph_147
children.value: No, no! It is he who and Baisemeaux approached Aramis's ear, making a sort of eartrumpet of his hands, and whispered: It is he who presumes to resemble the
children.prevalue: No no It is he who and Baisemeaux approached Aramis s ear making a sort of eartrumpet of his hands and whispered It is he who presumes to resemble the

children.name: Paragraph_148
children.value: Yes, yes, said Aramis; I now remember you already spoke about it last year to me; but the crime appeared to me so slight.
children.prevalue: Yes yes said Aramis I now remember you already spoke about it last year to me but the crime appeared to me so slight

children.name: Paragraph_149
children.value: Slight, do you say?
children.prevalue: Slight do you say

children.name: Paragraph_150
children.value: Or rather, so involuntary.
children.prevalue: Or rather so involuntary

children.name: Paragraph_151
children.value: My lord, it is not involuntarily that such a resemblance is detected.
children.prevalue: My lord it is not involuntarily that such a resemblance is detected

children.name: Paragraph_152
children.value: Well, the fact is, I had forgotten it. But, my dear host, said Aramis, closing the register, if I am not mistaken, we are summoned.
children.prevalue: Well the fact is I had forgotten it But my dear host said Aramis closing the register if I am not mistaken we are summoned

children.name: Paragraph_153
children.value: Baisemeaux took the register, hastily restored it to its place in the closet, which he locked, and put the key in his pocket. Will it be agreeable to your lordship to breakfast now? said he; for you are right in supposing that breakfast was announced.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux took the register hastily restored it to its place in the closet which he locked and put the key in his pocket Will it be agreeable to your lordship to breakfast now said he for you are right in supposing that breakfast was announced

children.name: Paragraph_154
children.value: Assuredly, my dear governor, and they passed into the diningroom.
children.prevalue: Assuredly my dear governor and they passed into the diningroom

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Aramis was generally temperate; but on this occasion, while taking every care of his constitution, he did ample justice to Baisemeaux's breakfast, which, in all respects, was most excellent. The latter on his side, was animated with the wildest gayety; the sight of the five thousand pistoles, which he glanced at from time to time, seemed to open his heart. Every now and then he looked at Aramis with an expression of the deepest gratitude; while the latter, leaning back in his chair, took a few sips of wine from his glass, with the air of a connoisseur. Let me never hear any ill words against the fare of the Bastile, said he, half closing his eyes; happy are the prisoners who can get only half a bottle of such Burgundy every day.
children.prevalue: Aramis was generally temperate but on this occasion while taking every care of his constitution he did ample justice to Baisemeaux s breakfast which in all respects was most excellent The latter on his side was animated with the wildest gayety the sight of the five thousand pistoles which he glanced at from time to time seemed to open his heart Every now and then he looked at Aramis with an expression of the deepest gratitude while the latter leaning back in his chair took a few sips of wine from his glass with the air of a connoisseur Let me never hear any ill words against the fare of the Bastile said he half closing his eyes happy are the prisoners who can get only half a bottle of such Burgundy every day

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: All those at fifteen francs drink it, said Baisemeaux. It is very old Volnay.
children.prevalue: All those at fifteen francs drink it said Baisemeaux It is very old Volnay

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Does that poor student, Seldon, drink such good wine?
children.prevalue: Does that poor student Seldon drink such good wine

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Oh, no!
children.prevalue: Oh no

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: I thought I heard you say he was boarded at fifteen francs.
children.prevalue: I thought I heard you say he was boarded at fifteen francs

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: He! no, indeed; a man who makes districtsdistichs I meanat fifteen francs! No, no! it is his neighbor who is at fifteen francs.
children.prevalue: He no indeed a man who makes districtsdistichs I meanat fifteen francs No no it is his neighbor who is at fifteen francs

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Which neighbor?
children.prevalue: Which neighbor

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The other, second Bertaudiere.
children.prevalue: The other second Bertaudiere

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Excuse me, my dear governor; but you speak a language which requires quite an apprenticeship to understand.
children.prevalue: Excuse me my dear governor but you speak a language which requires quite an apprenticeship to understand

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Very true, said the governor. Allow me to explain: second Bertaudiere is the person who occupies the second floor of the tower of the Bertaudiere.
children.prevalue: Very true said the governor Allow me to explain second Bertaudiere is the person who occupies the second floor of the tower of the Bertaudiere

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: So that Bertaudiere is the name of one of the towers of the Bastile? The fact is, I think I recollect hearing that each tower has a name of its own. Whereabouts is the one you are speaking of?
children.prevalue: So that Bertaudiere is the name of one of the towers of the Bastile The fact is I think I recollect hearing that each tower has a name of its own Whereabouts is the one you are speaking of

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Look, said Baisemeaux, going to the window. It is that tower to the leftthe second one.
children.prevalue: Look said Baisemeaux going to the window It is that tower to the leftthe second one

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Is the prisoner at fifteen francs there?
children.prevalue: Is the prisoner at fifteen francs there

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Since when?
children.prevalue: Since when

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Seven or eight years, nearly.
children.prevalue: Seven or eight years nearly

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: What do you mean by nearly? Do you not know the dates more precisely?
children.prevalue: What do you mean by nearly Do you not know the dates more precisely

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: It was not in my time, M. d'Herblay.
children.prevalue: It was not in my time M d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: But I should have thought that Louviere or Tremblay would have told you.
children.prevalue: But I should have thought that Louviere or Tremblay would have told you

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The secrets of the Bastile are never handed over with the keys of the governorship.
children.prevalue: The secrets of the Bastile are never handed over with the keys of the governorship

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Indeed! Then the cause of his imprisonment is a mysterya state secret.
children.prevalue: Indeed Then the cause of his imprisonment is a mysterya state secret

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Oh, no! I do not suppose it is a state secret, but a secretlike everything that happens at the Bastile.
children.prevalue: Oh no I do not suppose it is a state secret but a secretlike everything that happens at the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: But, said Aramis, why do you speak more freely of Seldon than of second Bertaudiere?
children.prevalue: But said Aramis why do you speak more freely of Seldon than of second Bertaudiere

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Because, in my opinion, the crime of the man who writes a distich is not so great as that of the man who resembles
children.prevalue: Because in my opinion the crime of the man who writes a distich is not so great as that of the man who resembles

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Yes, yes; I understand you. Still, do not the turnkeys talk with your prisoners?
children.prevalue: Yes yes I understand you Still do not the turnkeys talk with your prisoners

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Of course.
children.prevalue: Of course

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The prisoners, I suppose, tell them they are not guilty?
children.prevalue: The prisoners I suppose tell them they are not guilty

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: They are always telling them that; it is a matter of course; the same song over and over again.
children.prevalue: They are always telling them that it is a matter of course the same song over and over again

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: But does not the resemblance you were speaking about just now strike the turnkeys?
children.prevalue: But does not the resemblance you were speaking about just now strike the turnkeys

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: My dear M. d'Herblay, it is only for men attached to the court, as you are, to take trouble about such matters.
children.prevalue: My dear M d Herblay it is only for men attached to the court as you are to take trouble about such matters

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: You're right, you're right, my dear M. Baisemeaux. Let me give you another taste of this Volnay.
children.prevalue: You re right you re right my dear M Baisemeaux Let me give you another taste of this Volnay

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Not a taste merely, a full glass; fill yours too.
children.prevalue: Not a taste merely a full glass fill yours too

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Nay, nay! You are a musketeer still, to the very tips of your fingers, while I have become a bishop. A taste for me; a glass for yourself.
children.prevalue: Nay nay You are a musketeer still to the very tips of your fingers while I have become a bishop A taste for me a glass for yourself

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: As you please. And Aramis and the governor nodded to each other, as they drank their wine. But, said Aramis, looking with fixed attention at the rubycolored wine he had raised to the level of his eyes, as if he wished to enjoy it with all his senses at the same moment, but what you might call a resemblance, another would not, perhaps, take any notice of.
children.prevalue: As you please And Aramis and the governor nodded to each other as they drank their wine But said Aramis looking with fixed attention at the rubycolored wine he had raised to the level of his eyes as if he wished to enjoy it with all his senses at the same moment but what you might call a resemblance another would not perhaps take any notice of

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Most certainly he would, though, if it were any one who knew the person he resembles.
children.prevalue: Most certainly he would though if it were any one who knew the person he resembles

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I really think, dear M. Baisemeaux, that it can be nothing more than a resemblance of your own creation.
children.prevalue: I really think dear M Baisemeaux that it can be nothing more than a resemblance of your own creation

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Upon my honor, it is not so.
children.prevalue: Upon my honor it is not so

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Stay, continued Aramis. I have seen many persons very like the one we are speaking of; but, out of respect, no one ever said anything about it.
children.prevalue: Stay continued Aramis I have seen many persons very like the one we are speaking of but out of respect no one ever said anything about it

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Very likely; because there is resemblance and resemblance. This is a striking one, and, if you were to see him, you would admit it to be so.
children.prevalue: Very likely because there is resemblance and resemblance This is a striking one and if you were to see him you would admit it to be so

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: If I were to see him, indeed, said Aramis, in an indifferent tone; but in all probability I never shall.
children.prevalue: If I were to see him indeed said Aramis in an indifferent tone but in all probability I never shall

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Why not?
children.prevalue: Why not

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Because if I were even to put my foot inside one of those horrible dungeons, I should fancy I was buried there forever.
children.prevalue: Because if I were even to put my foot inside one of those horrible dungeons I should fancy I was buried there forever

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: No, no; the cells are very good places to live in.
children.prevalue: No no the cells are very good places to live in

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: I really do not, and cannot believe it, and that is a fact.
children.prevalue: I really do not and cannot believe it and that is a fact

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Pray do not speak ill of second Bertaudiere. It is really a good room, very nicely furnished and carpeted. The young fellow has by no means been unhappy there; the best lodging the Bastile affords has been his. There is a chance for you.
children.prevalue: Pray do not speak ill of second Bertaudiere It is really a good room very nicely furnished and carpeted The young fellow has by no means been unhappy there the best lodging the Bastile affords has been his There is a chance for you

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Nay, nay, said Aramis, coldly; you will never make me believe there are any good rooms in the Bastile; and, as for your carpets, they exist only in your imagination. I should find nothing but spiders, rats, and perhaps toads, too.
children.prevalue: Nay nay said Aramis coldly you will never make me believe there are any good rooms in the Bastile and as for your carpets they exist only in your imagination I should find nothing but spiders rats and perhaps toads too

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Toads? cried Baisemeaux.
children.prevalue: Toads cried Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Yes, in the dungeons.
children.prevalue: Yes in the dungeons

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Ah! I don't say there are not toads in the dungeons, replied Baisemeaux. Butwill you be convinced by your own eyes? he continued, with a sudden impulse.
children.prevalue: Ah I don t say there are not toads in the dungeons replied Baisemeaux Butwill you be convinced by your own eyes he continued with a sudden impulse

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: No, certainly not.
children.prevalue: No certainly not

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Not even to satisfy yourself of the resemblance which you deny, as you do the carpets?
children.prevalue: Not even to satisfy yourself of the resemblance which you deny as you do the carpets

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Some spectrallooking person, a mere shadow; an unhappy, dying man.
children.prevalue: Some spectrallooking person a mere shadow an unhappy dying man

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Nothing of the kindas brisk and vigorous a young fellow as ever lived.
children.prevalue: Nothing of the kindas brisk and vigorous a young fellow as ever lived

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Melancholy and illtempered, then?
children.prevalue: Melancholy and illtempered then

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Not at all; very gay and lively.
children.prevalue: Not at all very gay and lively

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Nonsense; you are joking.
children.prevalue: Nonsense you are joking

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Will you follow me? said Baisemeaux.
children.prevalue: Will you follow me said Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: What for?
children.prevalue: What for

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: To go the round of the Bastile.
children.prevalue: To go the round of the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Why?
children.prevalue: Why

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: You will then see for yourselfsee with your own eyes.
children.prevalue: You will then see for yourselfsee with your own eyes

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: But the regulations?
children.prevalue: But the regulations

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Never mind them. Today my major has leave of absence; the lieutenant is visiting the post on the bastions; we are sole masters of the situation.
children.prevalue: Never mind them Today my major has leave of absence the lieutenant is visiting the post on the bastions we are sole masters of the situation

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: No, no, my dear governor; why, the very idea of the sound of the bolts makes me shudder. You will only have to forget me in second or fourth Bertaudiere, and then
children.prevalue: No no my dear governor why the very idea of the sound of the bolts makes me shudder You will only have to forget me in second or fourth Bertaudiere and then

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: You are refusing an opportunity that may never present itself again. Do you know that, to obtain the favor I propose to you gratis, some of the princes of the blood have offered me as much as fifty thousand francs.
children.prevalue: You are refusing an opportunity that may never present itself again Do you know that to obtain the favor I propose to you gratis some of the princes of the blood have offered me as much as fifty thousand francs

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Really! he must be worth seeing, then?
children.prevalue: Really he must be worth seeing then

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Forbidden fruit, my lord; forbidden fruit. You who belong to the church ought to know that.
children.prevalue: Forbidden fruit my lord forbidden fruit You who belong to the church ought to know that

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Well, if had any curiosity, it would be to see the poor author of the distich.
children.prevalue: Well if had any curiosity it would be to see the poor author of the distich

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Very well, we will see him, too; but if I were at all curious, it would be about the beautiful carpeted room and its lodger.
children.prevalue: Very well we will see him too but if I were at all curious it would be about the beautiful carpeted room and its lodger

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Furniture is very commonplace; and a face with no expression in it offers little or no interest.
children.prevalue: Furniture is very commonplace and a face with no expression in it offers little or no interest

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: But a boarder at fifteen francs is always interesting.
children.prevalue: But a boarder at fifteen francs is always interesting

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: By the by, I forgot to ask you about that. Why fifteen francs for him, and only three francs for poor Seldon?
children.prevalue: By the by I forgot to ask you about that Why fifteen francs for him and only three francs for poor Seldon

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: The distinction made in that instance was a truly noble act, and one which displayed the king's goodness of heart to great advantage.
children.prevalue: The distinction made in that instance was a truly noble act and one which displayed the king s goodness of heart to great advantage

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: The king's, you say.
children.prevalue: The king s you say

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: The cardinal's, I mean. 'This unhappy man,' said M. Mazarin, 'is destined to remain in prison forever.'
children.prevalue: The cardinal s I mean This unhappy man said M Mazarin is destined to remain in prison forever

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Why so?
children.prevalue: Why so

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Why, it seems that his crime is a lasting one; and, consequently, his punishment ought to be so, too.
children.prevalue: Why it seems that his crime is a lasting one and consequently his punishment ought to be so too

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Lasting?
children.prevalue: Lasting

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: No doubt of it, unless he is fortunate enough to catch the smallpox, and even that is difficult, for we never get any impure air here.
children.prevalue: No doubt of it unless he is fortunate enough to catch the smallpox and even that is difficult for we never get any impure air here

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Nothing can be more ingenious than your train of reasoning, my dear M. Baisemeaux. Do you, however, mean to say that this unfortunate man must suffer without interruption or termination?
children.prevalue: Nothing can be more ingenious than your train of reasoning my dear M Baisemeaux Do you however mean to say that this unfortunate man must suffer without interruption or termination

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: I did not say he was to suffer, my lord; a fifteenfranc boarder does not suffer.
children.prevalue: I did not say he was to suffer my lord a fifteenfranc boarder does not suffer

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: He suffers imprisonment, at all events.
children.prevalue: He suffers imprisonment at all events

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: No doubt; there is no help for that, but this suffering is sweetened for him. You must admit that this young fellow was not born to eat all the good things he does eat; for instance, such things as we have on the table now; this pasty that has not been touched, these crawfish from the River Marne, of which we have hardly taken any, and which are almost as large as lobsters; all these things will at once be taken to second Bertaudiere, with a bottle of that Volnay which you think so excellent. After you have seen it you will believe it, I hope.
children.prevalue: No doubt there is no help for that but this suffering is sweetened for him You must admit that this young fellow was not born to eat all the good things he does eat for instance such things as we have on the table now this pasty that has not been touched these crawfish from the River Marne of which we have hardly taken any and which are almost as large as lobsters all these things will at once be taken to second Bertaudiere with a bottle of that Volnay which you think so excellent After you have seen it you will believe it I hope

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Yes, my dear governor, certainly; but all this time you are thinking only of your very happy fifteenfranc prisoner, and you forget poor Seldon, my protege.
children.prevalue: Yes my dear governor certainly but all this time you are thinking only of your very happy fifteenfranc prisoner and you forget poor Seldon my protege

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Well, out of consideration for you, it shall be a gala day for him; he shall have some biscuits and preserves with this small bottle of port.
children.prevalue: Well out of consideration for you it shall be a gala day for him he shall have some biscuits and preserves with this small bottle of port

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: You are a goodhearted fellow; I have said so already, and I repeat it, my dear Baisemeaux.
children.prevalue: You are a goodhearted fellow I have said so already and I repeat it my dear Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Well, let us set off, then, said the governor, a little bewildered, partly from the wine he had drunk, and partly from Aramis's praises.
children.prevalue: Well let us set off then said the governor a little bewildered partly from the wine he had drunk and partly from Aramis s praises

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Do not forget that I only go to oblige you, said the prelate.
children.prevalue: Do not forget that I only go to oblige you said the prelate

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Very well; but you will thank me when you get there.
children.prevalue: Very well but you will thank me when you get there

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Let us go, then.
children.prevalue: Let us go then

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Wait until I have summoned the jailer, said Baisemeaux, as he struck the bell twice; at which summons a man appeared. I am going to visit the towers, said the governor. No guards, no drums, no noise at all.
children.prevalue: Wait until I have summoned the jailer said Baisemeaux as he struck the bell twice at which summons a man appeared I am going to visit the towers said the governor No guards no drums no noise at all

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: If I were not to leave my cloak here, said Aramis, pretending to be alarmed, I should really think I was going to prison on my own account.
children.prevalue: If I were not to leave my cloak here said Aramis pretending to be alarmed I should really think I was going to prison on my own account

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: The jailer preceded the governor, Aramis walking on his right hand; some of the soldiers who happened to be in the courtyard drew themselves up in a line, as stiff as posts, as the governor passed along. Baisemeaux led the way down several steps which conducted to a sort of esplanade; thence they arrived at the drawbridge, where the sentinels on duty received the governor with the proper honors. The governor turned toward Aramis, and, speaking in such a tone that the sentinels could not lose a word, he observed,I hope you have a good memory, monsieur?
children.prevalue: The jailer preceded the governor Aramis walking on his right hand some of the soldiers who happened to be in the courtyard drew themselves up in a line as stiff as posts as the governor passed along Baisemeaux led the way down several steps which conducted to a sort of esplanade thence they arrived at the drawbridge where the sentinels on duty received the governor with the proper honors The governor turned toward Aramis and speaking in such a tone that the sentinels could not lose a word he observed I hope you have a good memory monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Why? inquired Aramis.
children.prevalue: Why inquired Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: On account of your plans and your measurements, for you know that no one is allowed, not architects even, to enter where the prisoners are, with paper, pens or pencil.
children.prevalue: On account of your plans and your measurements for you know that no one is allowed not architects even to enter where the prisoners are with paper pens or pencil

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Good, said Aramis to himself, it seems I am an architect, then. It sounds like one of D'Artagnan's jokes, who perceived in me the engineer of BelleIsle. Then he added aloud: Be easy on that score, monsieur; in our profession, a mere glance and a good memory are quite sufficient.
children.prevalue: Good said Aramis to himself it seems I am an architect then It sounds like one of D Artagnan s jokes who perceived in me the engineer of BelleIsle Then he added aloud Be easy on that score monsieur in our profession a mere glance and a good memory are quite sufficient

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Baisemeaux did not change countenance, and the soldiers took Aramis for what he seemed to be. Very well; we will first visit la Bertaudiere, said Baisemeaux, still intending the sentinels to hear him. Then, turning to the jailer, he added: You will take the opportunity of carrying to No. 2 the few dainties I pointed out.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux did not change countenance and the soldiers took Aramis for what he seemed to be Very well we will first visit la Bertaudiere said Baisemeaux still intending the sentinels to hear him Then turning to the jailer he added You will take the opportunity of carrying to No 2 the few dainties I pointed out

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Dear M. de Baisemeaux, said Aramis, you are always forgetting No. 3.
children.prevalue: Dear M de Baisemeaux said Aramis you are always forgetting No 3

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: So I am, said the governor; and upon that, they began to ascend. The number of bolts, gratings, and locks for this single courtyard would have sufficed for the safety of an entire city. Aramis was neither an imaginative nor a sensitive man; he had been somewhat of a poet in his youth, but his heart was hard and indifferent, as the heart of every man of fiftyfive years of age is, who has been frequently and passionately attached to women in his lifetime, or rather who has been passionately loved by them. But when he placed his foot upon the worn stone steps, along which so many unhappy wretches had passed, when he felt himself impregnated, as it were, with the atmosphere of those gloomy dungeons, moistened with tears, there could be but little doubt he was overcome by his feelings, for his head was bowed and his eyes became dim, as he followed Baisemeaux without a syllable.
children.prevalue: So I am said the governor and upon that they began to ascend The number of bolts gratings and locks for this single courtyard would have sufficed for the safety of an entire city Aramis was neither an imaginative nor a sensitive man he had been somewhat of a poet in his youth but his heart was hard and indifferent as the heart of every man of fiftyfive years of age is who has been frequently and passionately attached to women in his lifetime or rather who has been passionately loved by them But when he placed his foot upon the worn stone steps along which so many unhappy wretches had passed when he felt himself impregnated as it were with the atmosphere of those gloomy dungeons moistened with tears there could be but little doubt he was overcome by his feelings for his head was bowed and his eyes became dim as he followed Baisemeaux without a syllable

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: On the second flight of stairs, whether from fatigue or emotion, the breathing of the visitor began to fail him, and he leaned against the wall. Will you begin with this one? said Baisemeaux; for since we are going to both, it matters very little whether we ascend from the second to the third story, or descend from the third to the second.
children.prevalue: On the second flight of stairs whether from fatigue or emotion the breathing of the visitor began to fail him and he leaned against the wall Will you begin with this one said Baisemeaux for since we are going to both it matters very little whether we ascend from the second to the third story or descend from the third to the second

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: No, no, exclaimed Aramis, eagerly, higher, if you please; the one above is the more urgent. They continued their ascent. Ask the jailer for the keys, whispered Aramis. Baisemeaux did so, took the keys, and, himself, opened the door of the third room. The jailer was the first to enter; he placed upon the table the provisions, which the kindhearted governor called dainties, and then left the room. The prisoner had not stirred; Baisemeaux then entered, while Aramis remained at the threshold, from which place he saw a youth about eighteen years of age, who, raising his head at the unusual noise, jumped off the bed, as he perceived the governor, and clasping his hands together, began to cry out, My mother, my mother, in tones which betrayed such deep distress that Aramis, despite his command over himself, felt a shudder pass through his frame. My dear boy, said Baisemeaux, endeavoring to smile, I have brought you a diversion and an extra,the one for the mind, the other for the body; this gentleman has come to take your measure, and here are some preserves for your dessert.
children.prevalue: No no exclaimed Aramis eagerly higher if you please the one above is the more urgent They continued their ascent Ask the jailer for the keys whispered Aramis Baisemeaux did so took the keys and himself opened the door of the third room The jailer was the first to enter he placed upon the table the provisions which the kindhearted governor called dainties and then left the room The prisoner had not stirred Baisemeaux then entered while Aramis remained at the threshold from which place he saw a youth about eighteen years of age who raising his head at the unusual noise jumped off the bed as he perceived the governor and clasping his hands together began to cry out My mother my mother in tones which betrayed such deep distress that Aramis despite his command over himself felt a shudder pass through his frame My dear boy said Baisemeaux endeavoring to smile I have brought you a diversion and an extra the one for the mind the other for the body this gentleman has come to take your measure and here are some preserves for your dessert

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Oh, monsieur! exclaimed the young man, keep me in solitude for a year, let me have nothing but bread and water for a year, but tell me that at the end of a year I shall leave this place, tell me that at the end of a year I shall see my mother again.
children.prevalue: Oh monsieur exclaimed the young man keep me in solitude for a year let me have nothing but bread and water for a year but tell me that at the end of a year I shall leave this place tell me that at the end of a year I shall see my mother again

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: But I have heard you say that your mother was very poor, and that you were very badly lodged when you were living with her, while hereupon my word!
children.prevalue: But I have heard you say that your mother was very poor and that you were very badly lodged when you were living with her while hereupon my word

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: If she were poor, monsieur, the greater reason to restore her only means of support to her. Badly lodged with her! Oh, monsieur, every one is always well lodged when he is free.
children.prevalue: If she were poor monsieur the greater reason to restore her only means of support to her Badly lodged with her Oh monsieur every one is always well lodged when he is free

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: At all events, since you yourself admit you have done nothing but write that unhappy distich
children.prevalue: At all events since you yourself admit you have done nothing but write that unhappy distich

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: But without any intention, I swear. Let me be punishedcut off the hand which wrote it, I will work with the otherbut restore my mother to me.
children.prevalue: But without any intention I swear Let me be punishedcut off the hand which wrote it I will work with the otherbut restore my mother to me

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: My boy, said Baisemeaux, you know very well that it does not depend upon me; all I can do for you is to increase your rations, give you a glass of port wine now and then, slip in a biscuit for you between a couple of plates.
children.prevalue: My boy said Baisemeaux you know very well that it does not depend upon me all I can do for you is to increase your rations give you a glass of port wine now and then slip in a biscuit for you between a couple of plates

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Great heaven! exclaimed the young man, falling backward and rolling on the ground.
children.prevalue: Great heaven exclaimed the young man falling backward and rolling on the ground

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Aramis, unable to bear this scene any longer, withdrew as far as the landing. Unhappy, wretched man, he murmured.
children.prevalue: Aramis unable to bear this scene any longer withdrew as far as the landing Unhappy wretched man he murmured

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Yes, monsieur, he is indeed very wretched, said the jailer; but it is his parents' fault.
children.prevalue: Yes monsieur he is indeed very wretched said the jailer but it is his parents fault

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: In what way?
children.prevalue: In what way

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: No doubt. Why did they let him learn Latin? Too much knowledge, you see; it is that which does harm. Now I, for instance, can't read or write, and therefore I am not in prison. Aramis looked at the man, who seemed to think that being a jailer in the Bastile was not being in prison. As for Baisemeaux, noticing the little effect produced by his advice and his port wine, he left the dungeon quite upset. You have forgotten to close the door, said the jailer.
children.prevalue: No doubt Why did they let him learn Latin Too much knowledge you see it is that which does harm Now I for instance can t read or write and therefore I am not in prison Aramis looked at the man who seemed to think that being a jailer in the Bastile was not being in prison As for Baisemeaux noticing the little effect produced by his advice and his port wine he left the dungeon quite upset You have forgotten to close the door said the jailer

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: So I have, said Baisemeaux; there are the keys, do you do it.
children.prevalue: So I have said Baisemeaux there are the keys do you do it

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I will solicit the pardon of that poor boy, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: I will solicit the pardon of that poor boy said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: And if you do not succeed, said Baisemeaux, at least beg that he may be transferred to the tenfranc list, by which both he and I shall be gainers.
children.prevalue: And if you do not succeed said Baisemeaux at least beg that he may be transferred to the tenfranc list by which both he and I shall be gainers

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: If the other prisoner calls out for his mother in a similar manner, said Aramis, I prefer not to enter at all, but will take my measure from outside.
children.prevalue: If the other prisoner calls out for his mother in a similar manner said Aramis I prefer not to enter at all but will take my measure from outside

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: No fear of that, monsieur architect, the one we are now going to see is as gentle as a lamb; before he could call after his mother he must open his lips, and he never says a word.
children.prevalue: No fear of that monsieur architect the one we are now going to see is as gentle as a lamb before he could call after his mother he must open his lips and he never says a word

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Let us go in, then, said Aramis, gloomily.
children.prevalue: Let us go in then said Aramis gloomily

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Are you the architect of the prisons, monsieur? said the jailer.
children.prevalue: Are you the architect of the prisons monsieur said the jailer

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I am.
children.prevalue: I am

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: It is odd, then, that you are not more accustomed to all this.
children.prevalue: It is odd then that you are not more accustomed to all this

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Aramis perceived that, to avoid giving rise to any suspicions, he must summon all his strength of mind to his assistance. Baisemeaux, who carried the keys, opened the door. Stay outside, he said to the jailer, and wait for us at the bottom of the steps. The jailer obeyed and withdrew.
children.prevalue: Aramis perceived that to avoid giving rise to any suspicions he must summon all his strength of mind to his assistance Baisemeaux who carried the keys opened the door Stay outside he said to the jailer and wait for us at the bottom of the steps The jailer obeyed and withdrew

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Baisemeaux entered first, and opened the second door himself. By the light which filtered through the ironbarred window, could be seen a handsome young man, short in stature, with closely cut hair, and a beard beginning to grow; he was sitting on a stool, his elbow resting on an armchair, and with all the upper part of his body reclining against it. His dress, thrown upon the bed, was of rich black velvet, and he inhaled the fresh air which blew in upon his breast through a shirt of the very finest cambric. As the governor entered, the young man turned his head with a look full of indifference; and on recognizing Baisemeaux, he arose and saluted him courteously. But when his eyes fell upon Aramis, who remained in the background, the latter trembled, turned pale, and his hat, which he held in his hand, fell upon the ground, as if all his muscles had become relaxed at once. Baisemeaux, habituated to the presence of his prisoner, did not seem to share any of the sensations which Aramis experienced, but, with all the zeal of a good servant, he busied himself in arranging on the table the pasty and crawfish he had brought with him. Occupied in this manner, he did not remark how disturbed his guest had become. When he had finished, however, he turned to the young prisoner and said: You are looking very well,are you so?
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux entered first and opened the second door himself By the light which filtered through the ironbarred window could be seen a handsome young man short in stature with closely cut hair and a beard beginning to grow he was sitting on a stool his elbow resting on an armchair and with all the upper part of his body reclining against it His dress thrown upon the bed was of rich black velvet and he inhaled the fresh air which blew in upon his breast through a shirt of the very finest cambric As the governor entered the young man turned his head with a look full of indifference and on recognizing Baisemeaux he arose and saluted him courteously But when his eyes fell upon Aramis who remained in the background the latter trembled turned pale and his hat which he held in his hand fell upon the ground as if all his muscles had become relaxed at once Baisemeaux habituated to the presence of his prisoner did not seem to share any of the sensations which Aramis experienced but with all the zeal of a good servant he busied himself in arranging on the table the pasty and crawfish he had brought with him Occupied in this manner he did not remark how disturbed his guest had become When he had finished however he turned to the young prisoner and said You are looking very well are you so

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Quite well, I thank you, monsieur, replied the young man.
children.prevalue: Quite well I thank you monsieur replied the young man

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The effect of the voice was such as almost to overpower Aramis, and notwithstanding his control over himself, he advanced a few steps towards him, with his eyes wide open and his lips trembling. The movement he made was so marked that Baisemeaux, notwithstanding his preoccupation, observed it. This gentleman is an architect who has come to examine your chimney, said Baisemeaux; does it smoke?
children.prevalue: The effect of the voice was such as almost to overpower Aramis and notwithstanding his control over himself he advanced a few steps towards him with his eyes wide open and his lips trembling The movement he made was so marked that Baisemeaux notwithstanding his preoccupation observed it This gentleman is an architect who has come to examine your chimney said Baisemeaux does it smoke

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Never, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Never monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: You were saying just now, said the governor, rubbing his hands together, that it was not possible for a man to be happy in prison; here, however, is one who is so. You have nothing to complain of, I hope?
children.prevalue: You were saying just now said the governor rubbing his hands together that it was not possible for a man to be happy in prison here however is one who is so You have nothing to complain of I hope

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Nothing.
children.prevalue: Nothing

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Do you ever feel weary? said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Do you ever feel weary said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Never.
children.prevalue: Never

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Ha, ha, said Baisemeaux, in a low tone of voice; was I right?
children.prevalue: Ha ha said Baisemeaux in a low tone of voice was I right

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Well, my dear governor, it is impossible not to yield to evidence. Is it allowed to put any question to him?
children.prevalue: Well my dear governor it is impossible not to yield to evidence Is it allowed to put any question to him

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: As many as you like.
children.prevalue: As many as you like

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Very well; be good enough to ask him if he knows why he is here.
children.prevalue: Very well be good enough to ask him if he knows why he is here

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: This gentleman requests me to ask you, said Baisemeaux, if you are aware of the cause of your imprisonment?
children.prevalue: This gentleman requests me to ask you said Baisemeaux if you are aware of the cause of your imprisonment

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: No, monsieur, said the young man, unaffectedly, I am not.
children.prevalue: No monsieur said the young man unaffectedly I am not

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: That is hardly possible, said Aramis, carried away by his feelings in spite of himself; if you were really ignorant of the cause of your detention, you would be furious.
children.prevalue: That is hardly possible said Aramis carried away by his feelings in spite of himself if you were really ignorant of the cause of your detention you would be furious

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: I was so during the early days of my imprisonment.
children.prevalue: I was so during the early days of my imprisonment

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Why are you not so now?
children.prevalue: Why are you not so now

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Because I have reflected.
children.prevalue: Because I have reflected

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: That is strange, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: That is strange said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Is it not odd? said Baisemeaux.
children.prevalue: Is it not odd said Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: May one venture to ask you, monsieur, on what you have reflected?
children.prevalue: May one venture to ask you monsieur on what you have reflected

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: I felt that as I had committed no crime, Heaven could not punish me.
children.prevalue: I felt that as I had committed no crime Heaven could not punish me

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: What is a prison, then, inquired Aramis, if it be not a punishment.
children.prevalue: What is a prison then inquired Aramis if it be not a punishment

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Alas! I cannot tell, said the young man; all that I can tell you now is the very opposite of what I felt seven years ago.
children.prevalue: Alas I cannot tell said the young man all that I can tell you now is the very opposite of what I felt seven years ago

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: To hear you converse, to witness your resignation, one might almost believe that you liked your imprisonment?
children.prevalue: To hear you converse to witness your resignation one might almost believe that you liked your imprisonment

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: I endure it.
children.prevalue: I endure it

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: In the certainty of recovering your freedom some day, I suppose?
children.prevalue: In the certainty of recovering your freedom some day I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: I have no certainty; hope, I have, and that is all; and yet I acknowledge that this hope becomes less every day.
children.prevalue: I have no certainty hope I have and that is all and yet I acknowledge that this hope becomes less every day

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Still, why should you not again be free, since you have already been so?
children.prevalue: Still why should you not again be free since you have already been so

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: That is precisely the reason, replied the young man, which prevents me from expecting liberty; why should I have been imprisoned at all if it had been intended to release me afterwards?
children.prevalue: That is precisely the reason replied the young man which prevents me from expecting liberty why should I have been imprisoned at all if it had been intended to release me afterwards

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: How old are you?
children.prevalue: How old are you

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: I do not know.
children.prevalue: I do not know

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: What is your name?
children.prevalue: What is your name

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: I have forgotten the name by which I was called.
children.prevalue: I have forgotten the name by which I was called

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Who are your parents?
children.prevalue: Who are your parents

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: I never knew them.
children.prevalue: I never knew them

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: But those who brought you up?
children.prevalue: But those who brought you up

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: They did not call me their son.
children.prevalue: They did not call me their son

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Did you ever love any one before coming here?
children.prevalue: Did you ever love any one before coming here

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: I loved my nurse, and my flowers.
children.prevalue: I loved my nurse and my flowers

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Was that all?
children.prevalue: Was that all

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: I also loved my valet.
children.prevalue: I also loved my valet

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Do you regret your nurse and your valet?
children.prevalue: Do you regret your nurse and your valet

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: I wept very much when they died.
children.prevalue: I wept very much when they died

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Did they die since you have been here, or before you came?
children.prevalue: Did they die since you have been here or before you came

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: They died the evening before I was carried off.
children.prevalue: They died the evening before I was carried off

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Both at the same time?
children.prevalue: Both at the same time

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Yes, both at the same time.
children.prevalue: Yes both at the same time

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: In what manner were you carried off?
children.prevalue: In what manner were you carried off

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: A man came for me, directed me to get into a carriage, which was closed and locked, and brought me here.
children.prevalue: A man came for me directed me to get into a carriage which was closed and locked and brought me here

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Would you be able to recognize that man again?
children.prevalue: Would you be able to recognize that man again

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: He was masked.
children.prevalue: He was masked

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Is this not an extraordinary tale? said Baisemeaux, in a low tone of voice, to Aramis, who could hardly breathe.
children.prevalue: Is this not an extraordinary tale said Baisemeaux in a low tone of voice to Aramis who could hardly breathe

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: It is indeed extraordinary, he murmured.
children.prevalue: It is indeed extraordinary he murmured

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: But what is still more extraordinary is, that he has never told me so much as he has just told you.
children.prevalue: But what is still more extraordinary is that he has never told me so much as he has just told you

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Perhaps the reason may be that you have never questioned him, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Perhaps the reason may be that you have never questioned him said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: It's possible, replied Baisemeaux; I have no curiosity. Have you looked at the room? it's a fine one, is it not?
children.prevalue: It s possible replied Baisemeaux I have no curiosity Have you looked at the room it s a fine one is it not

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Very much so.
children.prevalue: Very much so

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: A carpet
children.prevalue: A carpet

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Beautiful.
children.prevalue: Beautiful

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: I'll wager he had nothing like it before he came here.
children.prevalue: I ll wager he had nothing like it before he came here

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: I think so, too. And then again turning towards the young man, he said, Do you not remember to have been visited at some time or another by a strange lady or gentleman?
children.prevalue: I think so too And then again turning towards the young man he said Do you not remember to have been visited at some time or another by a strange lady or gentleman

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Yes, indeed; thrice by a woman, who each time came to the door in a carriage, and entered covered with a veil, which she raised when we were together and alone.
children.prevalue: Yes indeed thrice by a woman who each time came to the door in a carriage and entered covered with a veil which she raised when we were together and alone

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Do you remember that woman?
children.prevalue: Do you remember that woman

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: What did she say to you?
children.prevalue: What did she say to you

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: The young man smiled mournfully, and then replied, She inquired, as you have just done, if I were happy, and if I were getting weary.
children.prevalue: The young man smiled mournfully and then replied She inquired as you have just done if I were happy and if I were getting weary

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: What did she do on arriving, and on leaving you?
children.prevalue: What did she do on arriving and on leaving you

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: She pressed me in her arms, held me in her embrace, and kissed me.
children.prevalue: She pressed me in her arms held me in her embrace and kissed me

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Do you remember her?
children.prevalue: Do you remember her

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Perfectly.
children.prevalue: Perfectly

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Do you recall her features distinctly?
children.prevalue: Do you recall her features distinctly

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: You would recognize her, then, if accident brought her before you, or led you into her person?
children.prevalue: You would recognize her then if accident brought her before you or led you into her person

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Most certainly.
children.prevalue: Most certainly

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: A flush of fleeting satisfaction passed across Aramis's face. At this moment Baisemeaux heard the jailer approaching. Shall we leave? he said, hastily, to Aramis.
children.prevalue: A flush of fleeting satisfaction passed across Aramis s face At this moment Baisemeaux heard the jailer approaching Shall we leave he said hastily to Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Aramis, who probably had learnt all that he cared to know, replied, When you like.
children.prevalue: Aramis who probably had learnt all that he cared to know replied When you like

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: The young man saw them prepare to leave, and saluted them politely. Baisemeaux replied merely by a nod of the head, while Aramis, with a respect, arising perhaps from the sight of such misfortune, saluted the prisoner profoundly. They left the room, Baisemeaux closing the door behind them.
children.prevalue: The young man saw them prepare to leave and saluted them politely Baisemeaux replied merely by a nod of the head while Aramis with a respect arising perhaps from the sight of such misfortune saluted the prisoner profoundly They left the room Baisemeaux closing the door behind them

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Well, said Baisemeaux, as they descended the staircase, what do you think of it all?
children.prevalue: Well said Baisemeaux as they descended the staircase what do you think of it all

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: I have discovered the secret, my dear governor, he said.
children.prevalue: I have discovered the secret my dear governor he said

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Bah! what is the secret, then?
children.prevalue: Bah what is the secret then

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: A murder was committed in that house.
children.prevalue: A murder was committed in that house

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Nonsense.
children.prevalue: Nonsense

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: But attend; the valet and nurse died the same day.
children.prevalue: But attend the valet and nurse died the same day

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Well.
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: And by poison. What do you think?
children.prevalue: And by poison What do you think

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: That is very likely to be true.
children.prevalue: That is very likely to be true

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: What! that that young man is an assassin?
children.prevalue: What that that young man is an assassin

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Who said that? What makes you think that poor young fellow could be an assassin?
children.prevalue: Who said that What makes you think that poor young fellow could be an assassin

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: The very thing I was saying. A crime was committed in his house, said Aramis, and that was quite sufficient; perhaps he saw the criminals, and it was feared that he might say something.
children.prevalue: The very thing I was saying A crime was committed in his house said Aramis and that was quite sufficient perhaps he saw the criminals and it was feared that he might say something

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: The deuce! if I only thought that
children.prevalue: The deuce if I only thought that

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: I would redouble the surveillance.
children.prevalue: I would redouble the surveillance

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Oh, he does not seem to wish to escape.
children.prevalue: Oh he does not seem to wish to escape

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: You do not know what prisoners are.
children.prevalue: You do not know what prisoners are

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Has he any books?
children.prevalue: Has he any books

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: None; they are strictly prohibited, and under M. de Mazarin's own hand.
children.prevalue: None they are strictly prohibited and under M de Mazarin s own hand

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Have you the writing still?
children.prevalue: Have you the writing still

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: Yes, my lord; would you like to look at it as you return to take your cloak?
children.prevalue: Yes my lord would you like to look at it as you return to take your cloak

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: I should, for I like to look at autographs.
children.prevalue: I should for I like to look at autographs

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: Well, then, this one is of the most unquestionable authenticity; there is only one erasure.
children.prevalue: Well then this one is of the most unquestionable authenticity there is only one erasure

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Ah, ah! an erasure; and in what respect?
children.prevalue: Ah ah an erasure and in what respect

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: With respect to a figure. At first there was written: 'To be boarded at fifty francs.'
children.prevalue: With respect to a figure At first there was written To be boarded at fifty francs

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: As princes of the blood, in fact?
children.prevalue: As princes of the blood in fact

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: But the cardinal must have seen his mistake, you understand; for he canceled the zero, and has added a one before the five. But, by the by
children.prevalue: But the cardinal must have seen his mistake you understand for he canceled the zero and has added a one before the five But by the by

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: What?
children.prevalue: What

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: You do not speak of the resemblance.
children.prevalue: You do not speak of the resemblance

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: I do not speak of it, dear M. de Baisemeaux, for a very simple reason because it does not exist.
children.prevalue: I do not speak of it dear M de Baisemeaux for a very simple reason because it does not exist

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: The deuce it doesn't.
children.prevalue: The deuce it doesn t

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: Or, if it does exist, it is only in your own imagination; but, supposing it were to exist elsewhere, I think it would be better for you not to speak of about it.
children.prevalue: Or if it does exist it is only in your own imagination but supposing it were to exist elsewhere I think it would be better for you not to speak of about it

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: Really.
children.prevalue: Really

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: The king, Louis XIV.you understandwould be excessively angry with you, if he were to learn that you contributed in any way to spread the report that one of his subjects has the effrontery to resemble him.
children.prevalue: The king Louis XIV you understandwould be excessively angry with you if he were to learn that you contributed in any way to spread the report that one of his subjects has the effrontery to resemble him

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: It is true, quite true, said Baisemeaux, thoroughly alarmed; but I have not spoken of the circumstance to any one but yourself, and you understand, monseigneur, that I perfectly rely on your discretion.
children.prevalue: It is true quite true said Baisemeaux thoroughly alarmed but I have not spoken of the circumstance to any one but yourself and you understand monseigneur that I perfectly rely on your discretion

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: Oh, be easy.
children.prevalue: Oh be easy

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: Do you still wish to see the note?
children.prevalue: Do you still wish to see the note

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: While engaged in this manner in conversation, they had returned to the governor's apartments; Baisemeaux took from the cupboard a private register, like the one he had already shown Aramis, but fastened by a lock, the key which opened it being one of a small bunch which Baisemeaux always carried with him. Then placing the book upon the table, he opened it at the letter M, and showed Aramis the following note in the column of observations: No books at any time; all linen and clothes of the finest and best quality to be procured; no exercise; always the same jailer; no communications with any one. Musical instruments; every liberty and every indulgence which his welfare may require; to be boarded at fifteen francs. M. de Baisemeaux can claim more if the fifteen francs be not sufficient.
children.prevalue: While engaged in this manner in conversation they had returned to the governor s apartments Baisemeaux took from the cupboard a private register like the one he had already shown Aramis but fastened by a lock the key which opened it being one of a small bunch which Baisemeaux always carried with him Then placing the book upon the table he opened it at the letter M and showed Aramis the following note in the column of observations No books at any time all linen and clothes of the finest and best quality to be procured no exercise always the same jailer no communications with any one Musical instruments every liberty and every indulgence which his welfare may require to be boarded at fifteen francs M de Baisemeaux can claim more if the fifteen francs be not sufficient

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: Ah, said Baisemeaux, now I think of it, I shall claim it.
children.prevalue: Ah said Baisemeaux now I think of it I shall claim it

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: Aramis shut the book. Yes, he said, it is indeed M. de Mazarin's handwriting; I recognize it well. Now, my dear governor, he continued, as if this last communication had exhausted his interest, let us now turn over to our own little affairs.
children.prevalue: Aramis shut the book Yes he said it is indeed M de Mazarin s handwriting I recognize it well Now my dear governor he continued as if this last communication had exhausted his interest let us now turn over to our own little affairs

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: Well, what time for repayment do you wish me to take? Fix it yourself.
children.prevalue: Well what time for repayment do you wish me to take Fix it yourself

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: There need not be any particular period fixed; give me a simple acknowledgement for one hundred and fifty thousand francs.
children.prevalue: There need not be any particular period fixed give me a simple acknowledgement for one hundred and fifty thousand francs

children.name: Paragraph_145
children.value: When to be made payable?
children.prevalue: When to be made payable

children.name: Paragraph_146
children.value: When I require it; but, you understand, I shall only wish it when you yourself do.
children.prevalue: When I require it but you understand I shall only wish it when you yourself do

children.name: Paragraph_147
children.value: Oh, I am quite easy on that score, said Baisemeaux, smiling; but I have already given you two receipts.
children.prevalue: Oh I am quite easy on that score said Baisemeaux smiling but I have already given you two receipts

children.name: Paragraph_148
children.value: Which I now destroy, said Aramis; and after having shown the two receipts to Baisemeaux, he destroyed them. Overcome by so great a mark of confidence, Baisemeaux unhesitatingly wrote out an acknowledgement of a debt of one hundred and fifty thousand francs, payable at the pleasure of the prelate. Aramis, who had, by glancing over the governor's shoulder, followed the pen as he wrote, put the acknowledgement into his pocket without seeming to have read it, which made Baisemeaux perfectly easy. Now, said Aramis, you will not be angry with me if I were to carry off one of your prisoners?
children.prevalue: Which I now destroy said Aramis and after having shown the two receipts to Baisemeaux he destroyed them Overcome by so great a mark of confidence Baisemeaux unhesitatingly wrote out an acknowledgement of a debt of one hundred and fifty thousand francs payable at the pleasure of the prelate Aramis who had by glancing over the governor s shoulder followed the pen as he wrote put the acknowledgement into his pocket without seeming to have read it which made Baisemeaux perfectly easy Now said Aramis you will not be angry with me if I were to carry off one of your prisoners

children.name: Paragraph_149
children.value: What do you mean?
children.prevalue: What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_150
children.value: By obtaining his pardon, of course. Have I not already told you that I took a great interest in poor Seldon?
children.prevalue: By obtaining his pardon of course Have I not already told you that I took a great interest in poor Seldon

children.name: Paragraph_151
children.value: Yes, quite true, you did so.
children.prevalue: Yes quite true you did so

children.name: Paragraph_152
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_153
children.value: That is your affair; do as you think proper. I see you have an open hand, and an arm that can reach a great way.
children.prevalue: That is your affair do as you think proper I see you have an open hand and an arm that can reach a great way

children.name: Paragraph_154
children.value: Adieu, adieu. And Aramis left, carrying with him the governor's best wishes.
children.prevalue: Adieu adieu And Aramis left carrying with him the governor s best wishes

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: At the very time M. de Baisemeaux was showing Aramis the prisoners in the Bastile, a carriage drew up at Madame de Belliere's door, and, at that still early hour, a young woman alighted, her head muffled in a silk hood. When the servants announced Madame Vanel to Madame de Belliere, the latter was engaged, or rather was absorbed, in reading a letter, which she hurriedly concealed. She had hardly finished her morning toilette, her maid being still in the next room. At the nameat the footsteps of Marguerite Vanel, Madame de Belliere ran to meet her. She fancied she could detect in her friend's eyes a brightness which was neither that of health nor of pleasure. Marguerite embraced her, pressed her hands, and hardly allowed her time to speak. Dearest, she said, have you forgotten me? Have you quite given yourself up to the pleasures of the court?
