children.prevalue: At the very time M de Baisemeaux was showing Aramis the prisoners in the Bastile a carriage drew up at Madame de Belliere s door and at that still early hour a young woman alighted her head muffled in a silk hood When the servants announced Madame Vanel to Madame de Belliere the latter was engaged or rather was absorbed in reading a letter which she hurriedly concealed She had hardly finished her morning toilette her maid being still in the next room At the nameat the footsteps of Marguerite Vanel Madame de Belliere ran to meet her She fancied she could detect in her friend s eyes a brightness which was neither that of health nor of pleasure Marguerite embraced her pressed her hands and hardly allowed her time to speak Dearest she said have you forgotten me Have you quite given yourself up to the pleasures of the court

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: I have not even seen the marriage fetes.
children.prevalue: I have not even seen the marriage fetes

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: What are you doing with yourself, then?
children.prevalue: What are you doing with yourself then

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: I am getting ready to leave for Belliere.
children.prevalue: I am getting ready to leave for Belliere

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: For Belliere?
children.prevalue: For Belliere

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: You are becoming rustic in your tastes, then; I delight to see you so disposed. But you are pale.
children.prevalue: You are becoming rustic in your tastes then I delight to see you so disposed But you are pale

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: No, I am perfectly well.
children.prevalue: No I am perfectly well

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: So much the better; I was becoming uneasy about you. You do not know what I have been told.
children.prevalue: So much the better I was becoming uneasy about you You do not know what I have been told

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: People say so many things.
children.prevalue: People say so many things

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Yes, but this is very singular.
children.prevalue: Yes but this is very singular

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: How well you know how to excite curiosity, Marguerite.
children.prevalue: How well you know how to excite curiosity Marguerite

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Well, I was afraid of vexing you.
children.prevalue: Well I was afraid of vexing you

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Never; you have yourself always admired me for my evenness of temper.
children.prevalue: Never you have yourself always admired me for my evenness of temper

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Well, then, it is said thatno, I shall never be able to tell you.
children.prevalue: Well then it is said thatno I shall never be able to tell you

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Do not let us talk about it, then, said Madame de Belliere, who detected the illnature that was concealed by all these prefaces, yet felt the most anxious curiosity on the subject.
children.prevalue: Do not let us talk about it then said Madame de Belliere who detected the illnature that was concealed by all these prefaces yet felt the most anxious curiosity on the subject

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Well, then, my dear marquise, it is said, for some time past, you no longer continue to regret Monsieur de Belliere as you used to.
children.prevalue: Well then my dear marquise it is said for some time past you no longer continue to regret Monsieur de Belliere as you used to

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: It is an illnatured report, Marguerite. I do regret, and shall always regret, my husband; but it is now two years since he died. I am only twentyeight years old, and my grief at his loss ought not always to control every action and thought of my life. You, Marguerite, who are the model of a wife, would not believe me if I were to say so.
children.prevalue: It is an illnatured report Marguerite I do regret and shall always regret my husband but it is now two years since he died I am only twentyeight years old and my grief at his loss ought not always to control every action and thought of my life You Marguerite who are the model of a wife would not believe me if I were to say so

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Why not? Your heart is so soft and yielding, she said, spitefully.
children.prevalue: Why not Your heart is so soft and yielding she said spitefully

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Yours is so, too, Marguerite, and yet I did not perceive that you allowed yourself to be overcome by grief when your heart was wounded. These words were in direct allusion to Marguerite's rupture with the superintendent, and were also a veiled but direct reproach made against her friend's heart.
children.prevalue: Yours is so too Marguerite and yet I did not perceive that you allowed yourself to be overcome by grief when your heart was wounded These words were in direct allusion to Marguerite s rupture with the superintendent and were also a veiled but direct reproach made against her friend s heart

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: As if she only awaited this signal to discharge her shaft, Marguerite exclaimed, Well, Elise, it is said you are in love. And she looked fixedly at Madame de Belliere, who blushed against her will.
children.prevalue: As if she only awaited this signal to discharge her shaft Marguerite exclaimed Well Elise it is said you are in love And she looked fixedly at Madame de Belliere who blushed against her will

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Women can never escape slander, replied the marquise, after a moment's pause.
children.prevalue: Women can never escape slander replied the marquise after a moment s pause

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: No one slanders you, Elise.
children.prevalue: No one slanders you Elise

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: What!people say that I am in love, and yet they do not slander me!
children.prevalue: What people say that I am in love and yet they do not slander me

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: In the first place, if it be true, it is no slander, but simply a scandalloving report. In the next placefor you did not allow me to finish what I was sayingthe public does not assert that you have abandoned yourself to this passion. It represents you, on the contrary, as a virtuous but loving woman, defending yourself with claws and teeth, shutting yourself up in your own house as in a fortress; in other respects, as impenetrable as that of Danae, notwithstanding Danae's tower was made of brass.
children.prevalue: In the first place if it be true it is no slander but simply a scandalloving report In the next placefor you did not allow me to finish what I was sayingthe public does not assert that you have abandoned yourself to this passion It represents you on the contrary as a virtuous but loving woman defending yourself with claws and teeth shutting yourself up in your own house as in a fortress in other respects as impenetrable as that of Danae notwithstanding Danae s tower was made of brass

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: You are witty, Marguerite, said Madame de Belliere, angrily.
children.prevalue: You are witty Marguerite said Madame de Belliere angrily

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: You always flatter me, Elise. In short, however, you are reported to be incorruptible and unapproachable. You cannot decide whether the world is calumniating you or not; but what is it you are musing about while I am speaking to you?
children.prevalue: You always flatter me Elise In short however you are reported to be incorruptible and unapproachable You cannot decide whether the world is calumniating you or not but what is it you are musing about while I am speaking to you

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I?
children.prevalue: I

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Yes; you are blushing and do not answer me.
children.prevalue: Yes you are blushing and do not answer me

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: I was trying, said the marquise, raising her beautiful eyes brightened with an indication of growing temper, I was trying to discover to what you could possibly have alluded, you who are so learned in mythological subjects, in comparing me to Danae.
children.prevalue: I was trying said the marquise raising her beautiful eyes brightened with an indication of growing temper I was trying to discover to what you could possibly have alluded you who are so learned in mythological subjects in comparing me to Danae

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: You were trying to guess that? said Marguerite, laughing.
children.prevalue: You were trying to guess that said Marguerite laughing

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Yes; do you not remember that at the convent, when we were solving our problems in arithmeticah! what I have to tell you is learned also, but it is my turndo you not remember, that if one of the terms were given, we were to find the other? Therefore do you guess now?
children.prevalue: Yes do you not remember that at the convent when we were solving our problems in arithmeticah what I have to tell you is learned also but it is my turndo you not remember that if one of the terms were given we were to find the other Therefore do you guess now

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I cannot conjecture what you mean.
children.prevalue: I cannot conjecture what you mean

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: And yet nothing is more simple. You pretend that I am in love, do you not?
children.prevalue: And yet nothing is more simple You pretend that I am in love do you not

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: So it is said.
children.prevalue: So it is said

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Very well; it is not said, I suppose, that I am in love with an abstraction. There must surely be a name mentioned in this report.
children.prevalue: Very well it is not said I suppose that I am in love with an abstraction There must surely be a name mentioned in this report

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Certainly, a name is mentioned.
children.prevalue: Certainly a name is mentioned

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Very well; it is not surprising, then, that I should try to guess this name, since you do not tell it.
children.prevalue: Very well it is not surprising then that I should try to guess this name since you do not tell it

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: My dear marquise, when I saw you blush, I did not think you would have to spend much time in conjectures.
children.prevalue: My dear marquise when I saw you blush I did not think you would have to spend much time in conjectures

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: It was the word Danae which you used that surprised me. Danae means a shower of gold, does it not?
children.prevalue: It was the word Danae which you used that surprised me Danae means a shower of gold does it not

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: That is to say that the Jupiter of Danae changed himself into a shower of gold for her.
children.prevalue: That is to say that the Jupiter of Danae changed himself into a shower of gold for her

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: My lover, then, he whom you assign me
children.prevalue: My lover then he whom you assign me

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: I beg your pardon; I am your friend, and assign you no one.
children.prevalue: I beg your pardon I am your friend and assign you no one

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: That may be; but those who are ill disposed towards me.
children.prevalue: That may be but those who are ill disposed towards me

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Do you wish to hear the name?
children.prevalue: Do you wish to hear the name

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: I have been waiting this half hour for it.
children.prevalue: I have been waiting this half hour for it

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Well, then, you shall hear it. Do not be shocked; he is a man high in power.
children.prevalue: Well then you shall hear it Do not be shocked he is a man high in power

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Good, said the marquise, as she clenched her hands like a patient at the approach of the knife.
children.prevalue: Good said the marquise as she clenched her hands like a patient at the approach of the knife

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: He is a very wealthy man, continued Marguerite; the wealthiest, it may be. In a word, it is
children.prevalue: He is a very wealthy man continued Marguerite the wealthiest it may be In a word it is

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: The marquise closed her eyes for a moment.
children.prevalue: The marquise closed her eyes for a moment

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: It is the Duke of Buckingham, said Marguerite, bursting into laughter. This perfidy had been calculated with extreme ability; the name that was pronounced, instead of the name which the marquise awaited, had precisely the same effect upon her as the badly sharpened axes, that had hacked, without destroying, Messieurs de Chalais and de Thou upon the scaffold. She recovered herself, however, and said, I was perfectly right in saying you were a witty woman, for you are making the time pass away most agreeably. This joke is a most amusing one, for I have never seen the Duke of Buckingham.
children.prevalue: It is the Duke of Buckingham said Marguerite bursting into laughter This perfidy had been calculated with extreme ability the name that was pronounced instead of the name which the marquise awaited had precisely the same effect upon her as the badly sharpened axes that had hacked without destroying Messieurs de Chalais and de Thou upon the scaffold She recovered herself however and said I was perfectly right in saying you were a witty woman for you are making the time pass away most agreeably This joke is a most amusing one for I have never seen the Duke of Buckingham

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Never? said Marguerite, restraining her laughter.
children.prevalue: Never said Marguerite restraining her laughter

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: I have never even left my own house since the duke has been at Paris.
children.prevalue: I have never even left my own house since the duke has been at Paris

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Oh! resumed Madame Vanel, stretching out her foot towards a paper which was lying on the carpet near the window; it is not necessary for people to see each other, since they can write. The marquise trembled, for this paper was the envelope of the letter she was reading as her friend had entered, and was sealed with the superintendent's arms. As she leaned back on the sofa on which she was sitting, Madame de Belliere covered the paper with the thick folds of her large silk dress, and so concealed it.
children.prevalue: Oh resumed Madame Vanel stretching out her foot towards a paper which was lying on the carpet near the window it is not necessary for people to see each other since they can write The marquise trembled for this paper was the envelope of the letter she was reading as her friend had entered and was sealed with the superintendent s arms As she leaned back on the sofa on which she was sitting Madame de Belliere covered the paper with the thick folds of her large silk dress and so concealed it

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Come, Marguerite, tell me, is it to tell me all these foolish reports that you have come to see me so early in the day?
children.prevalue: Come Marguerite tell me is it to tell me all these foolish reports that you have come to see me so early in the day

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: No; I came to see you, in the first place, and to remind you of those habits of our earlier days, so delightful to remember, when we used to wander about together at Vincennes, and, sitting beneath an oak, or in some sylvan shade, used to talk of those we loved, and who loved us.
children.prevalue: No I came to see you in the first place and to remind you of those habits of our earlier days so delightful to remember when we used to wander about together at Vincennes and sitting beneath an oak or in some sylvan shade used to talk of those we loved and who loved us

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Do you propose that we should go out together now?
children.prevalue: Do you propose that we should go out together now

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: My carriage is here, and I have three hours at my disposal.
children.prevalue: My carriage is here and I have three hours at my disposal

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: I am not dressed yet, Marguerite; but if you wish that we should talk together, we can, without going to the woods of Vincennes, find in my own garden here, beautiful trees, shady groves, a green sward covered with daisies and violets, the perfume of which can be perceived from where we are sitting.
children.prevalue: I am not dressed yet Marguerite but if you wish that we should talk together we can without going to the woods of Vincennes find in my own garden here beautiful trees shady groves a green sward covered with daisies and violets the perfume of which can be perceived from where we are sitting

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: I regret your refusal, my dear marquise, for I wanted to pour out my whole heart into yours.
children.prevalue: I regret your refusal my dear marquise for I wanted to pour out my whole heart into yours

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: I repeat again, Marguerite, my heart is yours just as much in this room, or beneath the limetrees in the garden here, as it would be under the oaks in the woods yonder.
children.prevalue: I repeat again Marguerite my heart is yours just as much in this room or beneath the limetrees in the garden here as it would be under the oaks in the woods yonder

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: It is not the same thing for me. In approaching Vincennes, marquise, my ardent aspirations approach nearer to that object towards which they have for some days past been directed. The marquise suddenly raised her head. Are you surprised, then, that I am still thinking of SaintMande?
children.prevalue: It is not the same thing for me In approaching Vincennes marquise my ardent aspirations approach nearer to that object towards which they have for some days past been directed The marquise suddenly raised her head Are you surprised then that I am still thinking of SaintMande

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Of SaintMande? exclaimed Madame de Belliere; and the looks of both women met each other like two resistless swords.
children.prevalue: Of SaintMande exclaimed Madame de Belliere and the looks of both women met each other like two resistless swords

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: You, so proud! said the marquise, disdainfully.
children.prevalue: You so proud said the marquise disdainfully

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: I, so proud! replied Madame Vanel. Such is my nature. I do not forgive neglectI cannot endure infidelity. When I leave any one who weeps at my abandonment, I feel induced still to love him; but when others forsake me and laugh at their infidelity, I love distractedly.
children.prevalue: I so proud replied Madame Vanel Such is my nature I do not forgive neglectI cannot endure infidelity When I leave any one who weeps at my abandonment I feel induced still to love him but when others forsake me and laugh at their infidelity I love distractedly

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Madame de Belliere could not restrain an involuntary movement.
children.prevalue: Madame de Belliere could not restrain an involuntary movement

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: She is jealous, said Marguerite to herself.
children.prevalue: She is jealous said Marguerite to herself

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Then, continued the marquise, you are quite enamored of the Duke of BuckinghamI mean of M. Fouquet? Elise felt the allusion, and her blood seemed to congeal in her heart. And you wished to go to Vincennes,to SaintMande, even?
children.prevalue: Then continued the marquise you are quite enamored of the Duke of BuckinghamI mean of M Fouquet Elise felt the allusion and her blood seemed to congeal in her heart And you wished to go to Vincennes to SaintMande even

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: I hardly know what I wished: you would have advised me perhaps.
children.prevalue: I hardly know what I wished you would have advised me perhaps

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: In what respect?
children.prevalue: In what respect

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: You have often done so.
children.prevalue: You have often done so

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Most certainly I should not have done so in the present instance, for I do not forgive as you do. I am less loving, perhaps; when my heart has been once wounded, it remains so always.
children.prevalue: Most certainly I should not have done so in the present instance for I do not forgive as you do I am less loving perhaps when my heart has been once wounded it remains so always

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: But M. Fouquet has not wounded you, said Marguerite Vanel, with the most perfect simplicity.
children.prevalue: But M Fouquet has not wounded you said Marguerite Vanel with the most perfect simplicity

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: You perfectly understand what I mean. M. Fouquet has not wounded me; I do not know of either obligation or injury received at his hands, but you have reason to complain of him. You are my friend, and I am afraid I should not advise you as you would like.
children.prevalue: You perfectly understand what I mean M Fouquet has not wounded me I do not know of either obligation or injury received at his hands but you have reason to complain of him You are my friend and I am afraid I should not advise you as you would like

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Ah! you are prejudging the case.
children.prevalue: Ah you are prejudging the case

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: The sighs you spoke of just now are more than indications.
children.prevalue: The sighs you spoke of just now are more than indications

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: You overwhelm me, said the young woman suddenly, as if collecting her whole strength, like a wrestler preparing for a last struggle; you take only my evil dispositions and my weaknesses into calculation, and do not speak of my pure and generous feelings. If, at this moment, I feel instinctively attracted towards the superintendent, if I even make an advance to him, which, I confess, is very probable, my motive for it is, that M. Fouquet's fate deeply affects me, and because he is, in my opinion, one of the most unfortunate men living.
children.prevalue: You overwhelm me said the young woman suddenly as if collecting her whole strength like a wrestler preparing for a last struggle you take only my evil dispositions and my weaknesses into calculation and do not speak of my pure and generous feelings If at this moment I feel instinctively attracted towards the superintendent if I even make an advance to him which I confess is very probable my motive for it is that M Fouquet s fate deeply affects me and because he is in my opinion one of the most unfortunate men living

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Ah! said the marquise, placing her hand upon her heart, something new, then, has occurred?
children.prevalue: Ah said the marquise placing her hand upon her heart something new then has occurred

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Do you not know it?
children.prevalue: Do you not know it

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: I am utterly ignorant of everything about him, said Madame de Belliere, with the poignant anguish that suspends thought and speech, and even life itself.
children.prevalue: I am utterly ignorant of everything about him said Madame de Belliere with the poignant anguish that suspends thought and speech and even life itself

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: In the first place, then, the king's favor is entirely withdrawn from M. Fouquet, and conferred on M. Colbert.
children.prevalue: In the first place then the king s favor is entirely withdrawn from M Fouquet and conferred on M Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: So it is stated.
children.prevalue: So it is stated

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: It is very clear, since the discovery of the plot of BelleIsle.
children.prevalue: It is very clear since the discovery of the plot of BelleIsle

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: I was told that the discovery of the fortifications there had turned out to M. Fouquet's honor.
children.prevalue: I was told that the discovery of the fortifications there had turned out to M Fouquet s honor

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Marguerite began to laugh in so cruel a manner that Madame de Belliere could at that moment have delightedly plunged a dagger in her bosom. Dearest, continued Marguerite, there is no longer any question of M. Fouquet's honor; his safety is concerned. Before three days are passed the ruin of the superintendent will be complete.
children.prevalue: Marguerite began to laugh in so cruel a manner that Madame de Belliere could at that moment have delightedly plunged a dagger in her bosom Dearest continued Marguerite there is no longer any question of M Fouquet s honor his safety is concerned Before three days are passed the ruin of the superintendent will be complete

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Stay, said the marquise, in her turn smiling, that is going a little fast.
children.prevalue: Stay said the marquise in her turn smiling that is going a little fast

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: I said three days, because I wish to deceive myself with a hope; but probably the catastrophe will be complete within twentyfour hours.
children.prevalue: I said three days because I wish to deceive myself with a hope but probably the catastrophe will be complete within twentyfour hours

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Why so?
children.prevalue: Why so

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: For the simplest of all reasons,that M. Fouquet has no more money.
children.prevalue: For the simplest of all reasons that M Fouquet has no more money

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: In matters of finance, my dear Marguerite, some are without money today, who tomorrow can procure millions.
children.prevalue: In matters of finance my dear Marguerite some are without money today who tomorrow can procure millions

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: That might be M. Fouquet's case when he had two wealthy and clever friends who amassed money for him, and wrung it from every possible or impossible source; but those friends are dead.
children.prevalue: That might be M Fouquet s case when he had two wealthy and clever friends who amassed money for him and wrung it from every possible or impossible source but those friends are dead

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Money does not die, Marguerite; it may be concealed, but it can be looked for, bought and found.
children.prevalue: Money does not die Marguerite it may be concealed but it can be looked for bought and found

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: You see things on the bright side, and so much the better for you. It is really very unfortunate that you are not the Egeria of M. Fouquet; you might now show him the source whence he could obtain the millions which the king asked him for yesterday.
children.prevalue: You see things on the bright side and so much the better for you It is really very unfortunate that you are not the Egeria of M Fouquet you might now show him the source whence he could obtain the millions which the king asked him for yesterday

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Millions! said the marquise, in terror.
children.prevalue: Millions said the marquise in terror

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Fouran even number.
children.prevalue: Fouran even number

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Infamous! murmured Madame de Belliere, tortured by her friend's merciless delight.
children.prevalue: Infamous murmured Madame de Belliere tortured by her friend s merciless delight

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: M. Fouquet, I should think, must certainly have four millions, she replied, courageously.
children.prevalue: M Fouquet I should think must certainly have four millions she replied courageously

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: If he has those which the king requires today, said Marguerite, he will not, perhaps, possess those which the king will demand in a month or so.
children.prevalue: If he has those which the king requires today said Marguerite he will not perhaps possess those which the king will demand in a month or so

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: The king will exact money from him again, then?
children.prevalue: The king will exact money from him again then

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: No doubt; and that is my reason for saying that the ruin of poor M. Fouquet is inevitable. Pride will induce him to furnish the money, and when he has no more, he will fall.
children.prevalue: No doubt and that is my reason for saying that the ruin of poor M Fouquet is inevitable Pride will induce him to furnish the money and when he has no more he will fall

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: It is true, said the marquise, trembling; the plan is a bold one; but tell me, does M. Colbert hate M. Fouquet so very much?
children.prevalue: It is true said the marquise trembling the plan is a bold one but tell me does M Colbert hate M Fouquet so very much

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: I think he does not like him. M. Colbert is powerful; he improves on close acquaintance; he has gigantic ideas, a strong will, and discretion; he will rise.
children.prevalue: I think he does not like him M Colbert is powerful he improves on close acquaintance he has gigantic ideas a strong will and discretion he will rise

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: He will be superintendent?
children.prevalue: He will be superintendent

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: It is probable. Such is the reason, my dear marquise, why I felt myself impressed in favor of that poor man, who once loved, and even adored me; and why, when I see him so unfortunate, I forgive his infidelity, which I have reason to believe he also regrets; and why, moreover, I should not have been disinclined to afford him some consolation, or some good advice; he would have understood the step I had taken, and would have thought kindly of me for it. It is gratifying to be loved, you know. Men value love more highly when they are no longer blinded by its influence.
children.prevalue: It is probable Such is the reason my dear marquise why I felt myself impressed in favor of that poor man who once loved and even adored me and why when I see him so unfortunate I forgive his infidelity which I have reason to believe he also regrets and why moreover I should not have been disinclined to afford him some consolation or some good advice he would have understood the step I had taken and would have thought kindly of me for it It is gratifying to be loved you know Men value love more highly when they are no longer blinded by its influence

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: The marquise, bewildered and overcome by these cruel attacks, which had been calculated with the greatest nicety and precision, hardly knew what to answer in return; she even seemed to have lost all power of thought. Her perfidious friend's voice had assumed the most affectionate tone; she spoke as a woman, but concealed the instincts of a wolf.
children.prevalue: The marquise bewildered and overcome by these cruel attacks which had been calculated with the greatest nicety and precision hardly knew what to answer in return she even seemed to have lost all power of thought Her perfidious friend s voice had assumed the most affectionate tone she spoke as a woman but concealed the instincts of a wolf

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Well, said Madame de Belliere, who had a vague hope that Marguerite would cease to overwhelm a vanquished enemy, why do you not go and see M. Fouquet?
children.prevalue: Well said Madame de Belliere who had a vague hope that Marguerite would cease to overwhelm a vanquished enemy why do you not go and see M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Decidedly, marquise, you have made me reflect. No, it would be unbecoming for me to make the first advance. M. Fouquet no doubt loves me, but he is too proud. I cannot expose myself to an affront.... besides, I have my husband to consider. You tell me nothing? Very well, I shall consult M. Colbert on the subject. Marguerite rose smilingly, as though to take leave, but the marquise had not the strength to imitate her. Marguerite advanced a few paces, in order that she might continue to enjoy the humiliating grief in which her rival was plunged, and then said, suddenly,You do not accompany me to the door, then? The marquise rose, pale and almost lifeless, without thinking of the envelope, which had occupied her attention so greatly at the commencement of the conversation, and which was revealed at the first step she took. She then opened the door of her oratory, and without even turning her head towards Marguerite Vanel, entered it, closing the door after her. Marguerite said, or rather muttered a few words, which Madame de Belliere did not even hear. As soon, however, as the marquise had disappeared, her envious enemy, not being able to resist the desire to satisfy herself that her suspicions were well founded, advanced stealthily like a panther, and seized the envelope. Ah! she said, gnashing her teeth, it was indeed a letter from M. Fouquet she was reading when I arrived, and then darted out of the room. During this interval, the marquise, having arrived behind the rampart, as it were, of her door, felt that her strength was failing her; for a moment she remained rigid, pale and motionless as a statue, and then, like a statue shaken on its base by an earthquake, tottered and fell inanimate on the carpet. The noise of the fall resounded at the same moment as the rolling of Marguerite's carriage leaving the hotel.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The blow had been the more painful on account of its being unexpected. It was some time before the marquise recovered herself; but once recovered, she began to reflect upon the events so heartlessly announced to her. She therefore returned, at the risk even of losing her life in the way, to that train of ideas which her relentless friend had forced her to pursue. Treason, thendeep menaces, concealed under the semblance of public interestsuch were Colbert's maneuvers. A detestable delight at an approaching downfall, untiring efforts to attain this object, means of seduction no less wicked than the crime itselfsuch were the weapons Marguerite employed. The crooked atoms of Descartes triumphed; to the man without compassion was united a woman without heart. The marquise perceived, with sorrow rather than indignation, that the king was an accomplice in the plot which betrayed the duplicity of Louis XIII. in his advanced age, and the avarice of Mazarin at a period of life when he had not had the opportunity of gorging himself with French gold. The spirit of this courageous woman soon resumed its energy, no longer overwhelmed by indulgence in compassionate lamentations. The marquise was not one to weep when action was necessary, nor to waste time in bewailing a misfortune as long as means still existed of relieving it. For some minutes she buried her face in her cold fingers, and then, raising her head, rang for her attendants with a steady hand, and with a gesture betraying a fixed determination of purpose. Her resolution was taken.
children.prevalue: The blow had been the more painful on account of its being unexpected It was some time before the marquise recovered herself but once recovered she began to reflect upon the events so heartlessly announced to her She therefore returned at the risk even of losing her life in the way to that train of ideas which her relentless friend had forced her to pursue Treason thendeep menaces concealed under the semblance of public interestsuch were Colbert s maneuvers A detestable delight at an approaching downfall untiring efforts to attain this object means of seduction no less wicked than the crime itselfsuch were the weapons Marguerite employed The crooked atoms of Descartes triumphed to the man without compassion was united a woman without heart The marquise perceived with sorrow rather than indignation that the king was an accomplice in the plot which betrayed the duplicity of Louis XIII in his advanced age and the avarice of Mazarin at a period of life when he had not had the opportunity of gorging himself with French gold The spirit of this courageous woman soon resumed its energy no longer overwhelmed by indulgence in compassionate lamentations The marquise was not one to weep when action was necessary nor to waste time in bewailing a misfortune as long as means still existed of relieving it For some minutes she buried her face in her cold fingers and then raising her head rang for her attendants with a steady hand and with a gesture betraying a fixed determination of purpose Her resolution was taken

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Is everything prepared for my departure? she inquired of one of her female attendants who entered.
children.prevalue: Is everything prepared for my departure she inquired of one of her female attendants who entered

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Yes, madame; but it was not expected that your ladyship would leave for Belliere for the next few days.
children.prevalue: Yes madame but it was not expected that your ladyship would leave for Belliere for the next few days

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: All my jewels and articles of value, then, are packed up?
children.prevalue: All my jewels and articles of value then are packed up

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Yes, madame; but hitherto we have been in the habit of leaving them in Paris. Your ladyship does not generally take your jewels with you into the country.
children.prevalue: Yes madame but hitherto we have been in the habit of leaving them in Paris Your ladyship does not generally take your jewels with you into the country

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: But they are all in order, you say?
children.prevalue: But they are all in order you say

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Yes, in your ladyship's own room.
children.prevalue: Yes in your ladyship s own room

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The gold plate?
children.prevalue: The gold plate

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: In the chest.
children.prevalue: In the chest

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: And the silver plate?
children.prevalue: And the silver plate

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: In the great oak closet.
children.prevalue: In the great oak closet

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The marquise remained silent for a few moments, and then said calmly, Let my goldsmith be sent for.
children.prevalue: The marquise remained silent for a few moments and then said calmly Let my goldsmith be sent for

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Her attendants quitted the room to execute the order. The marquise, however, had entered her own room, and was inspecting her casket of jewels with the greatest attention. Never, until now, had she bestowed such close attention upon riches in which women take so much pride; never, until now, had she looked at her jewels, except for the purpose of making a selection according to their settings or their colors. On this occasion, however, she admired the size of the rubies and the brilliancy of the diamonds; she grieved over every blemish and every defect; she thought the gold light, and the stones wretched. The goldsmith, as he entered, found her thus occupied. M. Faucheux, she said, I believe you supplied me with my gold service?
children.prevalue: Her attendants quitted the room to execute the order The marquise however had entered her own room and was inspecting her casket of jewels with the greatest attention Never until now had she bestowed such close attention upon riches in which women take so much pride never until now had she looked at her jewels except for the purpose of making a selection according to their settings or their colors On this occasion however she admired the size of the rubies and the brilliancy of the diamonds she grieved over every blemish and every defect she thought the gold light and the stones wretched The goldsmith as he entered found her thus occupied M Faucheux she said I believe you supplied me with my gold service

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I did, your ladyship.
children.prevalue: I did your ladyship

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I do not now remember the amount of the account.
children.prevalue: I do not now remember the amount of the account

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Of the new service, madame, or of that which M. de Belliere presented to you on your marriage? for I have furnished both.
children.prevalue: Of the new service madame or of that which M de Belliere presented to you on your marriage for I have furnished both

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: First of all, the new one.
children.prevalue: First of all the new one

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: The covers, the goblets, and the dishes, with their covers, the eauepergne, the icepails, the dishes for the preserves, and the tea and coffee urns, cost your ladyship sixty thousand francs.
children.prevalue: The covers the goblets and the dishes with their covers the eauepergne the icepails the dishes for the preserves and the tea and coffee urns cost your ladyship sixty thousand francs

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: No more?
children.prevalue: No more

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Your ladyship thought the account very high.
children.prevalue: Your ladyship thought the account very high

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Yes, yes; I remember, in fact, that it was dear; but it was the workmanship, I suppose?
children.prevalue: Yes yes I remember in fact that it was dear but it was the workmanship I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Yes, madame; the designs, the chasingsall new patterns.
children.prevalue: Yes madame the designs the chasingsall new patterns

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: What proportion of the cost does the workmanship form? Do not hesitate to tell me.
children.prevalue: What proportion of the cost does the workmanship form Do not hesitate to tell me

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: A third of its value, madame.
children.prevalue: A third of its value madame

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: There is the other service, the old one, that which belonged to my husband?
children.prevalue: There is the other service the old one that which belonged to my husband

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Yes, madame; there is less workmanship in that than in the other. Its intrinsic value does not exceed thirty thousand francs.
children.prevalue: Yes madame there is less workmanship in that than in the other Its intrinsic value does not exceed thirty thousand francs

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Thirty thousand, murmured the marquise. But, M. Faucheux, there is also the service which belonged to my mother; all that massive plate which I did not wish to part with, on account of the associations connected with it.
children.prevalue: Thirty thousand murmured the marquise But M Faucheux there is also the service which belonged to my mother all that massive plate which I did not wish to part with on account of the associations connected with it

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Ah! madame, that would indeed be an excellent resource for those who, unlike your ladyship, might not be in position to keep their plate. In chasing that they worked in solid metal. But that service is no longer in fashion. Its weight is its only advantage.
children.prevalue: Ah madame that would indeed be an excellent resource for those who unlike your ladyship might not be in position to keep their plate In chasing that they worked in solid metal But that service is no longer in fashion Its weight is its only advantage

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: That is all I care about. How much does it weigh?
children.prevalue: That is all I care about How much does it weigh

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Fifty thousand livres at the very least. I do not allude to the enormous vases for the buffet, which alone weigh five thousand livres, or ten thousand the pair.
children.prevalue: Fifty thousand livres at the very least I do not allude to the enormous vases for the buffet which alone weigh five thousand livres or ten thousand the pair

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: One hundred and thirty, murmured the marquise. You are quite sure of your figures, M. Faucheux?
children.prevalue: One hundred and thirty murmured the marquise You are quite sure of your figures M Faucheux

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The amount is entered in my books. Your ladyship is extremely methodical, I am aware.
children.prevalue: The amount is entered in my books Your ladyship is extremely methodical I am aware

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Let us now turn to another subject, said Madame de Belliere; and she opened one of her jewelboxes.
children.prevalue: Let us now turn to another subject said Madame de Belliere and she opened one of her jewelboxes

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: I recognize these emeralds, said M. Faucheux; for it was I who had the setting of them. They are the most beautiful in the whole court. No, I am mistaken; Madame de Chatillon has the most beautiful set; she had them from Messieurs de Guise; but your set, madame, comes next.
children.prevalue: I recognize these emeralds said M Faucheux for it was I who had the setting of them They are the most beautiful in the whole court No I am mistaken Madame de Chatillon has the most beautiful set she had them from Messieurs de Guise but your set madame comes next

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: What are they worth?
children.prevalue: What are they worth

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Mounted?
children.prevalue: Mounted

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: No; supposing I wished to sell them.
children.prevalue: No supposing I wished to sell them

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: I know very well who would buy them, exclaimed M. Faucheux.
children.prevalue: I know very well who would buy them exclaimed M Faucheux

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: That is the very thing I ask. They could be sold, then?
children.prevalue: That is the very thing I ask They could be sold then

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: All your jewels could be sold, madame. It is well known that you possess the most beautiful jewels in Paris. You are not changeable in your tastes; when you make a purchase it is of the very best; and what you purchase you do not part with.
children.prevalue: All your jewels could be sold madame It is well known that you possess the most beautiful jewels in Paris You are not changeable in your tastes when you make a purchase it is of the very best and what you purchase you do not part with

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: What could these emeralds be sold for, then?
children.prevalue: What could these emeralds be sold for then

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: A hundred and thirty thousand francs.
children.prevalue: A hundred and thirty thousand francs

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: The marquise wrote down upon her tablets the amount which the jeweler mentioned. The ruby necklace? she said.
children.prevalue: The marquise wrote down upon her tablets the amount which the jeweler mentioned The ruby necklace she said

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Are they balasrubies, madame?
children.prevalue: Are they balasrubies madame

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Here they are.
children.prevalue: Here they are

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: They are beautifulmagnificent. I did not know your ladyship had these stones.
children.prevalue: They are beautifulmagnificent I did not know your ladyship had these stones

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: What is their value?
children.prevalue: What is their value

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Two hundred thousand francs. The center one is alone worth a hundred thousand.
children.prevalue: Two hundred thousand francs The center one is alone worth a hundred thousand

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: I thought so, said the marquise. As for diamonds, I have them in numbers; rings, necklaces, sprigs, earrings, clasps. Tell me their value, M. Faucheux.
children.prevalue: I thought so said the marquise As for diamonds I have them in numbers rings necklaces sprigs earrings clasps Tell me their value M Faucheux

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: The jeweler took his magnifyingglass and scales, weighed and inspected them, and silently made his calculations. These stones, he said, must have cost your ladyship an income of forty thousand francs.
children.prevalue: The jeweler took his magnifyingglass and scales weighed and inspected them and silently made his calculations These stones he said must have cost your ladyship an income of forty thousand francs

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: You value them at eight hundred thousand francs?
children.prevalue: You value them at eight hundred thousand francs

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Nearly so.
children.prevalue: Nearly so

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: It is about what I imaginedbut the settings are not included?
children.prevalue: It is about what I imaginedbut the settings are not included

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: No, madame; but if I were called upon to sell or to buy, I should be satisfied with the gold of the settings alone as my profit upon the transaction. I should make a good twentyfive thousand francs.
children.prevalue: No madame but if I were called upon to sell or to buy I should be satisfied with the gold of the settings alone as my profit upon the transaction I should make a good twentyfive thousand francs

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: An agreeable sum.
children.prevalue: An agreeable sum

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Very much so, madame.
children.prevalue: Very much so madame

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Will you then accept that profit, then, on condition of converting the jewels into money?
children.prevalue: Will you then accept that profit then on condition of converting the jewels into money

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: But you do not intend to sell you diamonds, I suppose, madame? exclaimed the bewildered jeweler.
children.prevalue: But you do not intend to sell you diamonds I suppose madame exclaimed the bewildered jeweler

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Silence, M. Faucheux, do not disturb yourself about that; give me an answer simply. You are an honorable man, with whom my family has dealt for thirty years; you knew my father and mother, whom your own father and mother served. I address you as a friend; will you accept the gold of the settings in return for a sum of ready money to be placed in my hands?
children.prevalue: Silence M Faucheux do not disturb yourself about that give me an answer simply You are an honorable man with whom my family has dealt for thirty years you knew my father and mother whom your own father and mother served I address you as a friend will you accept the gold of the settings in return for a sum of ready money to be placed in my hands

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Eight hundred thousand francs! it is enormous.
children.prevalue: Eight hundred thousand francs it is enormous

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: I know it.
children.prevalue: I know it

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Impossible to find.
children.prevalue: Impossible to find

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Not so.
children.prevalue: Not so

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: But reflect, madame, upon the effect which will be produced by the sale of your jewels.
children.prevalue: But reflect madame upon the effect which will be produced by the sale of your jewels

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: No one need know it. You can get sets of false jewels made for me, similar to the real. Do not answer a word; I insist upon it. Sell them separately, sell the stones only.
children.prevalue: No one need know it You can get sets of false jewels made for me similar to the real Do not answer a word I insist upon it Sell them separately sell the stones only

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: In that way it is easy. Monsieur is looking out for some sets of jewels as well as single stones for Madame's toilette. There will be a competition for them. I can easily dispose of six hundred thousand francs' worth to Monsieur. I am certain yours are the most beautiful.
children.prevalue: In that way it is easy Monsieur is looking out for some sets of jewels as well as single stones for Madame s toilette There will be a competition for them I can easily dispose of six hundred thousand francs worth to Monsieur I am certain yours are the most beautiful

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: When can you do so?
children.prevalue: When can you do so

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: In less than three days' time.
children.prevalue: In less than three days time

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Very well, the remainder you will dispose of among private individuals. For the present, make me out a contract of sale, payment to be made in four days.
children.prevalue: Very well the remainder you will dispose of among private individuals For the present make me out a contract of sale payment to be made in four days

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: I entreat you to reflect, madame; for if you force the sale, you will lose a hundred thousand francs.
children.prevalue: I entreat you to reflect madame for if you force the sale you will lose a hundred thousand francs

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: If necessary, I will lose two hundred; I wish everything to be settled this evening. Do you accept?
children.prevalue: If necessary I will lose two hundred I wish everything to be settled this evening Do you accept

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: I do, your ladyship. I will not conceal from you that I shall make fifty thousand francs by the transaction.
children.prevalue: I do your ladyship I will not conceal from you that I shall make fifty thousand francs by the transaction

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: So much the better for you. In what way shall I have the money?
children.prevalue: So much the better for you In what way shall I have the money

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Either in gold, or in bills of the bank of Lyons, payable at M. Colbert's.
children.prevalue: Either in gold or in bills of the bank of Lyons payable at M Colbert s

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: I agree, said the marquise, eagerly; return home and bring the sum in question in notes, as soon as possible.
children.prevalue: I agree said the marquise eagerly return home and bring the sum in question in notes as soon as possible

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Yes, madame, but for Heaven's sake
children.prevalue: Yes madame but for Heaven s sake

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Not a word, M. Faucheux. By the by, I was forgetting the silver plate. What is the value of that which I have?
children.prevalue: Not a word M Faucheux By the by I was forgetting the silver plate What is the value of that which I have

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Fifty thousand francs, madame.
children.prevalue: Fifty thousand francs madame

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: That makes a million, said the marquise to herself. M. Faucheux, you will take away with you both the gold and silver plate. I can assign, as a pretext, that I wish it remodeled on patters more in accordance with my own taste. Melt it down, and return me its value in money, at once.
children.prevalue: That makes a million said the marquise to herself M Faucheux you will take away with you both the gold and silver plate I can assign as a pretext that I wish it remodeled on patters more in accordance with my own taste Melt it down and return me its value in money at once

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: It shall be done, your ladyship.
children.prevalue: It shall be done your ladyship

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: You will be good enough to place the money in a chest, and direct one of your clerks to accompany the chest, and without my servants seeing him; and order him to wait for me in a carriage.
children.prevalue: You will be good enough to place the money in a chest and direct one of your clerks to accompany the chest and without my servants seeing him and order him to wait for me in a carriage

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: In Madame de Faucheux's carriage? said the jeweler.
children.prevalue: In Madame de Faucheux s carriage said the jeweler

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: If you will allow it, and I will call for it at your house.
children.prevalue: If you will allow it and I will call for it at your house

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Certainly, your ladyship.
children.prevalue: Certainly your ladyship

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: I will direct some of my servants to convey the plate to your house. The marquise rung. Let the small van be placed at M. Faucheux's disposal, she said. The jeweler bowed and left the house, directing that the van should follow him closely, saying aloud, that the marquise was about to have her plate melted down in order to have other plate manufactured of a more modern style. Three hours afterwards she went to M. Faucheux's house and received from him eight hundred francs in gold inclosed in a chest, which one of the clerks could hardly carry towards Madame Faucheux's carriagefor Madame Faucheux kept her carriage. As the daughter of a president of accounts, she had brought a marriage portion of thirty thousand crowns to her husband, who was syndic of the goldsmiths. These thirty thousand crowns had become very fruitful during twenty years. The jeweler, though a millionaire, was a modest man. He had purchased a substantial carriage, built in 1648, ten years after the king's birth. This carriage, or rather house upon wheels, excited the admiration of the whole quarter in which he residedit was covered with allegorical paintings, and clouds scattered over with stars. The marquise entered this somewhat extraordinary vehicle, sitting opposite the clerk, who endeavored to put his knees out of the way, afraid even of touching the marquise's dress. It was the clerk, too, who told the coachman, who was very proud of having a marquise to drive, to take the road to SaintMande.
children.prevalue: I will direct some of my servants to convey the plate to your house The marquise rung Let the small van be placed at M Faucheux s disposal she said The jeweler bowed and left the house directing that the van should follow him closely saying aloud that the marquise was about to have her plate melted down in order to have other plate manufactured of a more modern style Three hours afterwards she went to M Faucheux s house and received from him eight hundred francs in gold inclosed in a chest which one of the clerks could hardly carry towards Madame Faucheux s carriagefor Madame Faucheux kept her carriage As the daughter of a president of accounts she had brought a marriage portion of thirty thousand crowns to her husband who was syndic of the goldsmiths These thirty thousand crowns had become very fruitful during twenty years The jeweler though a millionaire was a modest man He had purchased a substantial carriage built in 1648 ten years after the king s birth This carriage or rather house upon wheels excited the admiration of the whole quarter in which he residedit was covered with allegorical paintings and clouds scattered over with stars The marquise entered this somewhat extraordinary vehicle sitting opposite the clerk who endeavored to put his knees out of the way afraid even of touching the marquise s dress It was the clerk too who told the coachman who was very proud of having a marquise to drive to take the road to SaintMande

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Monsieur Faucheux's horses were serviceable animals, with thickset knees and legs that had some difficulty in moving. Like the carriage, they belonged to the earlier part of the century. They were not as fleet as the English horses of M. Fouquet, and consequently it took two hours to get to SaintMande. Their progress, it might be said, was majestic. Majesty, however, precludes hurry. The marquise stopped the carriage at the door so well known to her, although she had seen it only once, under circumstances, it will now be remembered, no less painful than those which brought her now to it again. She drew a key from her pocket, and inserted it into the lock, pushed open the door, which noiselessly yielded to her touch, and directed the clerk to carry the chest upstairs to the first floor. The weight of the chest was so great that the clerk was obliged to get the coachman to assist him with it. They placed it in a small cabinet, anteroom, or boudoir rather, adjoining the saloon where we once saw M. Fouquet at the marquise's feet. Madame de Belliere gave the coachman a louis, smiled gracefully at the clerk, and dismissed them both. She closed the door after them, and waited in the room, alone and barricaded. There was no servant to be seen about the rooms, but everything was prepared as though some invisible genius had divined the wishes and desires of an expected guest. The fire was laid, candles in the candelabra, refreshments upon the table, books scattered about, freshcut flowers in the vases. One might almost have imagined it an enchanted house.
children.prevalue: Monsieur Faucheux s horses were serviceable animals with thickset knees and legs that had some difficulty in moving Like the carriage they belonged to the earlier part of the century They were not as fleet as the English horses of M Fouquet and consequently it took two hours to get to SaintMande Their progress it might be said was majestic Majesty however precludes hurry The marquise stopped the carriage at the door so well known to her although she had seen it only once under circumstances it will now be remembered no less painful than those which brought her now to it again She drew a key from her pocket and inserted it into the lock pushed open the door which noiselessly yielded to her touch and directed the clerk to carry the chest upstairs to the first floor The weight of the chest was so great that the clerk was obliged to get the coachman to assist him with it They placed it in a small cabinet anteroom or boudoir rather adjoining the saloon where we once saw M Fouquet at the marquise s feet Madame de Belliere gave the coachman a louis smiled gracefully at the clerk and dismissed them both She closed the door after them and waited in the room alone and barricaded There was no servant to be seen about the rooms but everything was prepared as though some invisible genius had divined the wishes and desires of an expected guest The fire was laid candles in the candelabra refreshments upon the table books scattered about freshcut flowers in the vases One might almost have imagined it an enchanted house

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The marquise lighted the candles, inhaled the perfume of the flowers, sat down, and was soon plunged in profound thought. Her deep musings, melancholy though they were, were not untinged with a certain vague joy. Spread out before her was a treasure, a million wrung from her fortune as a gleaner plucks the blue cornflower from her crown of flowers. She conjured up the sweetest dreams. Her principal thought, and one that took precedence of all others, was to devise means of leaving this money for M. Fouquet without his possibly learning from whom the gift had come. This idea, naturally enough, was the first to present itself to her mind. But although, on reflection, it appeared difficult to carry out, she did not despair of success. She would then ring to summon M. Fouquet and make her escape, happier than if, instead of having given a million, she had herself found one. But, being there, and having seen the boudoir so coquettishly decorated that it might almost be said the least particle of dust had but the moment before been removed by the servants; having observed the drawingroom, so perfectly arranged that it might almost be said her presence there had driven away the fairies who were its occupants, she asked herself if the glance or gaze of those whom she had displacedwhether spirits, fairies, elves, or human creatureshad not already recognized her. To secure success, it was necessary that some steps should be seriously taken, and it was necessary also that the superintendent should comprehend the serious position in which he was placed, in order to yield compliance with the generous fancies of a woman; all the fascinations of an eloquent friendship would be required to persuade him, and, should this be insufficient, the maddening influence of a devoted passion, which, in its resolute determination to carry conviction, would not be turned aside. Was not the superintendent, indeed, known for his delicacy and dignity of feeling? Would he allow himself to accept from any woman that of which she had stripped herself? No! He would resist, and if any voice in the world could overcome his resistance, it would be the voice of the woman he loved.

the generous fancies of a woman all the fascinations of an eloquent friendship would be required to persuade him and should this be insufficient the maddening influence of a devoted passion which in that of which she had stripped herself No He would resist and if any voice in the world could overcome his resistance it would be the voice of the woman he loved

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Another doubt, and that a cruel one, suggested itself to Madame de Belliere with a sharp, acute pain, like a dagger thrust. Did he really love her? Would that volatile mind, that inconstant heart, be likely to be fixed for a moment, even were it to gaze upon an angel? Was it not the same with Fouquet, notwithstanding his genius and his uprightness of conduct, as with those conquerors on the field of battle who shed tears when they have gained a victory? I must learn if it be so, and must judge of that for myself, said the marquise. Who can tell whether that heart, so coveted, is not common in its impulses, and full of alloy? Who can tell if that mind, when the touchstone is applied to it, will not be found of a mean and vulgar character? Come, come, she said, this is doubting and hesitation too muchto the proof, she said, looking at the timepiece. It is now seven o'clock, she said; he must have arrived; it is the hour for signing his papers. With a feverish impatience she rose and walked towards the mirror, in which she smiled with a resolute smile of devotedness; she touched the spring and drew out the handle of the bell. Then, as if exhausted beforehand by the struggle she had just undergone, she threw herself on her knees, in utter abandonment, before a large couch, in which she buried her face in her trembling hands. Ten minutes afterwards she heard the spring of the door sound. The door moved upon invisible hinges, and Fouquet appeared. He looked pale, and seemed bowed down by the weight of some bitter reflection. He did not hurry, but simply came at the summons. The preoccupation of his mind must indeed have been very great, that a man, so devoted to pleasure, for whom indeed pleasure meant everything, should obey such a summons so listlessly. The previous night, in fact, fertile in melancholy ideas, had sharpened his features, generally so noble in their indifference of expression, and had traced dark lines of anxiety around his eyes. Handsome and noble he still was, and the melancholy expression of his mouth, a rare expression with men, gave a new character to his features, by which his youth seemed to be renewed. Dressed in black, the lace in front of his chest much disarranged by his feverishly restless hand, the looks of the superintendent, full of dreamy reflection, were fixed upon the threshold of the room which he had so frequently approached in search of expected happiness. This gloomy gentleness of manner, this smiling sadness of expression, which had replaced his former excessive joy, produced an indescribable effect upon Madame de Belliere, who was regarding him at a distance.
