there are gestures and sighs that every one cannot perceive After Madame had talked for some time with De Guiche she conversed with the king who paid her a visit regularly every day They played wrote verses or selected mottoes or emblematical devices this spring was not only the Maytide of nature it was the youth of an entire people of which those at court were the head The king was handsome young and of unequaled gallantry All women were passionately loved by him even the queen his wife This mighty monarch was however more timid and more reserved than any other person in the kingdom to such a degree indeed that he did not confess his sentiments even to himself This timidity of bearing restrained him within the limits of ordinary politeness and no woman could boast of having any preference shown her beyond that shown to others It might be foretold that the day when his real character would be displayed would be the dawn of a new sovereignty but as yet he had not declared himself M de Guiche took advantage of this and constituted himself the sovereign prince of the whole laughterloving court It had been reported that he was on the best of terms with Mademoiselle de Montalais that he had been assiduously attentive to Mademoiselle de Chatillon but now he was not even barely civil to any of the court beauties He had eyes and ears for one person alone In this manner and as it were without design he devoted himself to Monsieur who had a great regard for him and kept him as much as possible in his own apartments Unsociable from natural disposition he had estranged himself too much previous to the arrival of Madame but after her arrival he did not estrange himself sufficiently This conduct which every one had observed had been particularly remarked by the evil genius of the house the Chevalier de Lorraine for whom Monsieur exhibited the warmest attachment because he was of a very cheerful disposition even in his remarks most full of malice and because he was never at a loss how to wile the time away The Chevalier de Lorraine therefore having noticed that he was threatened with being supplanted by De Guiche resorted to strong measures He disappeared from the court leaving Monsieur much embarrassed The first day of his absence Monsieur hardly inquired about him for he had De Guiche with him and except that the time given to conversation with Madame his days and nights were rigorously devoted to the prince On the second day however Monsieur finding no one near him inquired where the chevalier was He was told that no one knew

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: De Guiche, after having spent the morning in selecting embroideries and fringes with Madame, went to console the prince. But after dinner, as there were some amethysts to be looked at, De Guiche returned to Madame's cabinet. Monsieur was left quite to himself during the time devoted to dressing and decorating himself; he felt that he was the most miserable of men, and again inquired whether there was any news of the chevalier, in reply to which he was told that no one could tell where the chevalier was to be found. Monsieur, hardly knowing in what direction to inflict his weariness, went to Madame's apartments dressed in his morninggown. He found a large assemblage of people there, laughing and whispering in every part of the room; at one end, a group of women around one of the courtiers, talking together, amid smothered bursts of laughter; at the other end, Manicamp and Malicorne were being pillaged at cards by Montalais and Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, while two others were standing by, laughing. In another part were Madame, seated upon some cushions on the floor, and De Guiche, on his knees beside her, spreading out a handful of pearls and precious stones, while the princess, with her white and slender fingers pointed out such among them as pleased her the most. Again, in another corner of the room, a guitar player was playing some of the Spanish seguedillas, to which Madame had taken the greatest fancy ever since she had heard them sung by the young queen with a melancholy expression of voice. But the songs which the Spanish princess had sung with tears in her eyes, the young Englishwoman was humming with a smile that well displayed her beautiful teeth. The cabinet presented, in fact, the most perfect representation of unrestrained pleasure and amusement. As he entered, Monsieur was struck at beholding so many persons enjoying themselves without him. He was so jealous at the sight that he could not resist exclaiming, like a child, What! you are amusing yourselves here, while I am sick and tired of being alone!
children.prevalue: De Guiche after having spent the morning in selecting embroideries and fringes with Madame went to console the prince But after dinner as there were some amethysts to be looked at De Guiche returned to Madame s cabinet Monsieur was left quite to himself during the time devoted to dressing and decorating himself he felt that he was the most miserable of men and again inquired whether there was any news of the chevalier in reply to which he was told that no one could tell where the chevalier was to be found Monsieur hardly knowing in what direction to inflict his weariness went to Madame s apartments dressed in his morninggown He found a large assemblage of people there laughing and whispering in every part of the room at one end a group of women around one of the courtiers talking together amid smothered bursts of laughter at the other end Manicamp and Malicorne were being pillaged at cards by Montalais and Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente while two others were standing by laughing In another part were Madame seated upon some cushions on the floor and De Guiche on his knees beside her spreading out a handful of pearls and precious stones while the princess with her white and slender fingers pointed out such among them as pleased her the most Again in another corner of the room a guitar player was playing some of the Spanish seguedillas to which Madame had taken the greatest fancy ever since she had heard them sung by the young queen with a melancholy expression of voice But the songs which the Spanish princess had sung with tears in her eyes the young Englishwoman was humming with a smile that well displayed her beautiful teeth The cabinet presented in fact the most perfect representation of unrestrained pleasure and amusement As he entered Monsieur was struck at beholding so many persons enjoying themselves without him He was so jealous at the sight that he could not resist exclaiming like a child What you are amusing yourselves here while I am sick and tired of being alone

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The sound of his voice was like a clap of thunder coming to interrupt the warbling of birds under the leafy covert of the trees; a dead silence ensued. De Guiche was on his feet in a moment. Malicorne tried to hide himself behind Montalais. Manicamp stood bolt upright, and assumed a very ceremonious demeanor. The guitar player thrust his instrument under a table, covering it with a piece of carpet to conceal it from the prince's observation. Madame was the only one who did not move, and smiling at her husband, said, Is not this the hour you usually devote to your toilette?
children.prevalue: The sound of his voice was like a clap of thunder coming to interrupt the warbling of birds under the leafy covert of the trees a dead silence ensued De Guiche was on his feet in a moment Malicorne tried to hide himself behind Montalais Manicamp stood bolt upright and assumed a very ceremonious demeanor The guitar player thrust his instrument under a table covering it with a piece of carpet to conceal it from the prince s observation Madame was the only one who did not move and smiling at her husband said Is not this the hour you usually devote to your toilette

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: An hour which others select, it seems, for amusing themselves, replied the prince, grumblingly.
children.prevalue: An hour which others select it seems for amusing themselves replied the prince grumblingly

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: This untoward remark was the signal for a general rout; the women fled like a flock of terrified starlings; the guitar player vanished like a shadow; Malicorne, still protected by Montalais, who purposely widened out her dress, glided behind the hanging tapestry. As for Manicamp, he went to the assistance of De Guiche, who naturally remained near Madame, and both of them, with the princess herself, courageously sustained the attack. The count was too happy to bear malice against the husband; but Monsieur bore a grudge against his wife. Nothing was wanting but a quarrel; he sought it, and the hurried departure of the crowd, which had been so joyous before he arrived, and was so disturbed by his entrance, furnished him with a pretext.
children.prevalue: This untoward remark was the signal for a general rout the women fled like a flock of terrified starlings the guitar player vanished like a shadow Malicorne still protected by Montalais who purposely widened out her dress glided behind the hanging tapestry As for Manicamp he went to the assistance of De Guiche who naturally remained near Madame and both of them with the princess herself courageously sustained the attack The count was too happy to bear malice against the husband but Monsieur bore a grudge against his wife Nothing was wanting but a quarrel he sought it and the hurried departure of the crowd which had been so joyous before he arrived and was so disturbed by his entrance furnished him with a pretext

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Why do they run away at the very sight of me? he inquired, in a supercilious tone; to which remark Madame replied, that, whenever the master of the house made his appearance, the family kept aloof out of respect. As she said this, she made so funny and so pretty a grimace, that De Guiche and Manicamp could not control themselves; they burst into a peal of laugher; Madame followed their example, and even Monsieur himself could not resist it, and he was obliged to sit down, as, for laughing, he could scarcely keep his equilibrium. However, he very soon left off, but his anger had increased. He was still more furious because he had permitted himself to laugh, than from having seen others laugh. He looked at Manicamp steadily, not venturing to show his anger towards De Guiche; but, at a sign which displayed no little amount of annoyance, Manicamp and De Guiche left the room, so that Madame, left alone, began sadly to pick up her pearls and amethysts, no longer smiling, and speaking still less.
children.prevalue: Why do they run away at the very sight of me he inquired in a supercilious tone to which remark Madame replied that whenever the master of the house made his appearance the family kept aloof out of respect As she said this she made so funny and so pretty a grimace that De Guiche and Manicamp could not control themselves they burst into a peal of laugher Madame followed their example and even Monsieur himself could not resist it and he was obliged to sit down as for laughing he could scarcely keep his equilibrium However he very soon left off but his anger had increased He was still more furious because he had permitted himself to laugh than from having seen others laugh He looked at Manicamp steadily not venturing to show his anger towards De Guiche but at a sign which displayed no little amount of annoyance Manicamp and De Guiche left the room so that Madame left alone began sadly to pick up her pearls and amethysts no longer smiling and speaking still less

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: I am very happy, said the duke, to find myself treated as a stranger here, Madame, and he left the room in a passion. On his way out, he met Montalais, who was in attendance in the anteroom. It is very agreeable to pay you a visit here, but outside the door.
children.prevalue: I am very happy said the duke to find myself treated as a stranger here Madame and he left the room in a passion On his way out he met Montalais who was in attendance in the anteroom It is very agreeable to pay you a visit here but outside the door

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Montalais made a very low obeisance. I do not quite understand what your royal highness does me the honor to say.
children.prevalue: Montalais made a very low obeisance I do not quite understand what your royal highness does me the honor to say

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: I say that when you are all laughing together in Madame's apartment, he is an unwelcome visitor who does not remain outside.
children.prevalue: I say that when you are all laughing together in Madame s apartment he is an unwelcome visitor who does not remain outside

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Your royal highness does not think, and does not speak so, of yourself?
children.prevalue: Your royal highness does not think and does not speak so of yourself

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: On the contrary, it is on my own account that I do speak and think. I have no reason, certainly, to flatter myself about the reception I meet with here at any time. How is it that, on the very day there is music and a little society in Madame's apartmentsin my own apartments, indeed, for they are mineon the very day that I wish to amuse myself a little in my turn, every one runs away? Are they afraid to see me, that they all take wing as soon as I appear? Is there anything wrong, then, going on in my absence?
children.prevalue: On the contrary it is on my own account that I do speak and think I have no reason certainly to flatter myself about the reception I meet with here at any time How is it that on the very day there is music and a little society in Madame s apartmentsin my own apartments indeed for they are mineon the very day that I wish to amuse myself a little in my turn every one runs away Are they afraid to see me that they all take wing as soon as I appear Is there anything wrong then going on in my absence

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Yet nothing has been done today, monseigneur, which is not done every day.
children.prevalue: Yet nothing has been done today monseigneur which is not done every day

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: What! do they laugh like that every day?
children.prevalue: What do they laugh like that every day

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Why, yes, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Why yes monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The same group of people simpering and the same singing and strumming going on every day?
children.prevalue: The same group of people simpering and the same singing and strumming going on every day

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: The guitar, monseigneur, was introduced today; but when we have no guitars, we have violins and flutes; ladies soon weary without music.
children.prevalue: The guitar monseigneur was introduced today but when we have no guitars we have violins and flutes ladies soon weary without music

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: The deuce!and the men?
children.prevalue: The deuce and the men

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: What men, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: What men monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: M. de Guiche, M. de Manicamp, and the rest of them?
children.prevalue: M de Guiche M de Manicamp and the rest of them

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: They all belong to your highness's household.
children.prevalue: They all belong to your highness s household

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Yes, yes, you are right, said the prince, as he returned to his own apartments, full of thought. He threw himself into the largest of his armchairs, without looking at himself in the glass. Where can the chevalier be? said he. One of the prince's attendants happened to be near him, overheard his remark, and replied,
children.prevalue: Yes yes you are right said the prince as he returned to his own apartments full of thought He threw himself into the largest of his armchairs without looking at himself in the glass Where can the chevalier be said he One of the prince s attendants happened to be near him overheard his remark and replied

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: No one knows, your highness.
children.prevalue: No one knows your highness

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Still the same answer. The first one who answers me again, 'I do not know,' I will discharge. Every one at this remark hurried out of his apartments, in the same manner as the others had fled from Madame's apartments. The prince then flew into the wildest rage. He kicked over a chiffonier, which tumbled on the carpet, broken into pieces. He next went into the galleries, and with the greatest coolness threw down, one after another, an enameled vase, a porphyry ewer, and a bronze candelabrum. The noise summoned every one to the various doors.
children.prevalue: Still the same answer The first one who answers me again I do not know I will discharge Every one at this remark hurried out of his apartments in the same manner as the others had fled from Madame s apartments The prince then flew into the wildest rage He kicked over a chiffonier which tumbled on the carpet broken into pieces He next went into the galleries and with the greatest coolness threw down one after another an enameled vase a porphyry ewer and a bronze candelabrum The noise summoned every one to the various doors

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: What is your highness's pleasure? said the captain of the guards, timidly.
children.prevalue: What is your highness s pleasure said the captain of the guards timidly

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I am treating myself to some music, replied the prince, gnashing his teeth.
children.prevalue: I am treating myself to some music replied the prince gnashing his teeth

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The captain of the guards desired his royal highness's physician to be sent for. But before he came, Malicorne arrived, saying to the prince, Monseigneur, the Chevalier de Lorraine is here.
children.prevalue: The captain of the guards desired his royal highness s physician to be sent for But before he came Malicorne arrived saying to the prince Monseigneur the Chevalier de Lorraine is here

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The duke looked at Malicorne, and smiled graciously at him, just as the chevalier entered.
children.prevalue: The duke looked at Malicorne and smiled graciously at him just as the chevalier entered

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The Duc d'Orleans uttered a cry of delight on perceiving the Chevalier de Lorraine. This is fortunate, indeed, he said; by what happy chance do I see you? Had you indeed disappeared, as every one assured me?
children.prevalue: The Duc d Orleans uttered a cry of delight on perceiving the Chevalier de Lorraine This is fortunate indeed he said by what happy chance do I see you Had you indeed disappeared as every one assured me

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Yes, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: A caprice?
children.prevalue: A caprice

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: I to venture upon caprices with your highness! The respect
children.prevalue: I to venture upon caprices with your highness The respect

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Put respect out of the way, for you fail in it every day. I absolve you; but why did you leave me?
children.prevalue: Put respect out of the way for you fail in it every day I absolve you but why did you leave me

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Because I felt that I was of no further use to you.
children.prevalue: Because I felt that I was of no further use to you

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Explain yourself.
children.prevalue: Explain yourself

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Your highness has people about you who are far more amusing that I can ever be. I felt I was not strong enough to enter into contest with them, and I therefore withdrew.
children.prevalue: Your highness has people about you who are far more amusing that I can ever be I felt I was not strong enough to enter into contest with them and I therefore withdrew

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: This extreme diffidence shows a want of common sense. Who are those with whom you cannot contend? De Guiche?
children.prevalue: This extreme diffidence shows a want of common sense Who are those with whom you cannot contend De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I name no one.
children.prevalue: I name no one

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: This is absurd. Does De Guiche annoy you?
children.prevalue: This is absurd Does De Guiche annoy you

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: I do not say he does; do not force me to speak, however; you know very well that De Guiche is one of our best friends.
children.prevalue: I do not say he does do not force me to speak however you know very well that De Guiche is one of our best friends

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Who is it, then?
children.prevalue: Who is it then

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Excuse me, monseigneur, let us say no more about it. The chevalier knew perfectly well that curiosity is excited in the same way as thirst by removing that which quenches it; or in other words, by denying an explanation.
children.prevalue: Excuse me monseigneur let us say no more about it The chevalier knew perfectly well that curiosity is excited in the same way as thirst by removing that which quenches it or in other words by denying an explanation

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: No, no, said the prince; I wish to know why you went away.
children.prevalue: No no said the prince I wish to know why you went away

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: In that case, monseigneur, I will tell you; but do not get angry. I remarked that my presence was disagreeable.
children.prevalue: In that case monseigneur I will tell you but do not get angry I remarked that my presence was disagreeable

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: To whom?
children.prevalue: To whom

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: To Madame.
children.prevalue: To Madame

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: What do you mean? said the duke in astonishment.
children.prevalue: What do you mean said the duke in astonishment

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: It is simple enough; Madame is very probably jealous of the regard you are good enough to testify for me.
children.prevalue: It is simple enough Madame is very probably jealous of the regard you are good enough to testify for me

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Has she shown it to you?
children.prevalue: Has she shown it to you

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Madame never addresses a syllable to me, particularly since a certain time.
children.prevalue: Madame never addresses a syllable to me particularly since a certain time

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Since what time?
children.prevalue: Since what time

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Since the time when, M. de Guiche having made himself more agreeable to her than I could, she receives him at every and any hour.
children.prevalue: Since the time when M de Guiche having made himself more agreeable to her than I could she receives him at every and any hour

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The duke colored. At any hour, chevalier; what do you mean by that?
children.prevalue: The duke colored At any hour chevalier what do you mean by that

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: You see, your highness, I have already displeased you; I was quite sure I should.
children.prevalue: You see your highness I have already displeased you I was quite sure I should

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: I am not displeased; but what you say is rather startling. In what respect does Madame prefer De Guiche to you?
children.prevalue: I am not displeased but what you say is rather startling In what respect does Madame prefer De Guiche to you

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I shall say no more, said the chevalier, saluting the prince ceremoniously.
children.prevalue: I shall say no more said the chevalier saluting the prince ceremoniously

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: On the contrary, I require you to speak. If you withdraw on that account, you must indeed be very jealous.
children.prevalue: On the contrary I require you to speak If you withdraw on that account you must indeed be very jealous

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: One cannot help being jealous, monseigneur, when one loves. Is not your royal highness jealous of Madame? Would you not, if you saw some one always near Madame, and always treated with great favor, take umbrage at it? One's friends are as one's lovers. Your highness has sometimes conferred the distinguished honor upon me of calling me your friend.
children.prevalue: One cannot help being jealous monseigneur when one loves Is not your royal highness jealous of Madame Would you not if you saw some one always near Madame and always treated with great favor take umbrage at it One s friends are as one s lovers Your highness has sometimes conferred the distinguished honor upon me of calling me your friend

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Yes, yes,; but you used a phrase which has a very equivocal significance; you are unfortunate in your phrases.
children.prevalue: Yes yes but you used a phrase which has a very equivocal significance you are unfortunate in your phrases

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: What phrase, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: What phrase monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: You said, 'treated with great favor.' What do you mean by favor?
children.prevalue: You said treated with great favor What do you mean by favor

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Nothing can be more simple, said the chevalier, with an expression of great frankness; for instance, whenever a husband remarks that his wife summons such and such a man near her; whenever this man is always to be found by her side, or in attendance at the door of her carriage; whenever the bouquet of the one is always the same color as the ribbons of the other; when music and supper parties are held in private apartments; whenever a dead silence takes place immediately the husband makes his appearance in his wife's rooms; and when the husband suddenly finds that he has, as a companion, the most devoted and the kindest of men, who, a week before, was with him as little as possible; why, then
children.prevalue: Nothing can be more simple said the chevalier with an expression of great frankness for instance whenever a husband remarks that his wife summons such and such a man near her whenever this man is always to be found by her side or in attendance at the door of her carriage whenever the bouquet of the one is always the same color as the ribbons of the other when music and supper parties are held in private apartments whenever a dead silence takes place immediately the husband makes his appearance in his wife s rooms and when the husband suddenly finds that he has as a companion the most devoted and the kindest of men who a week before was with him as little as possible why then

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Well, finish.
children.prevalue: Well finish

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Why, then, I say, monseigneur, one possibly may get jealous. But all these details hardly apply; for our conversation had nothing to do with them.
children.prevalue: Why then I say monseigneur one possibly may get jealous But all these details hardly apply for our conversation had nothing to do with them

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The duke was evidently very much agitated, and seemed to struggle with himself a good deal. You have not told me, he then remarked, why you absented yourself. A little while ago you said it was from a fear of intruding; you added, even, that you had observed a disposition on Madame's part to encourage De Guiche.
children.prevalue: The duke was evidently very much agitated and seemed to struggle with himself a good deal You have not told me he then remarked why you absented yourself A little while ago you said it was from a fear of intruding you added even that you had observed a disposition on Madame s part to encourage De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Pardon me, monseigneur, I did not say that.
children.prevalue: Pardon me monseigneur I did not say that

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: You did, indeed.
children.prevalue: You did indeed

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Well, if I did say so, I observed nothing but what was very inoffensive.
children.prevalue: Well if I did say so I observed nothing but what was very inoffensive

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: At all events, you remarked something.
children.prevalue: At all events you remarked something

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: You embarrass me, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: You embarrass me monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: What does that matter? Answer me. If you speak the truth, why should you feel embarrassed?
children.prevalue: What does that matter Answer me If you speak the truth why should you feel embarrassed

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: I always speak the truth, monseigneur; but I also always hesitate when it is a question of repeating what others say.
children.prevalue: I always speak the truth monseigneur but I also always hesitate when it is a question of repeating what others say

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Ah! repeat? It appears that it is talked about, then?
children.prevalue: Ah repeat It appears that it is talked about then

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: I acknowledge that others have spoken to me on the subject.
children.prevalue: I acknowledge that others have spoken to me on the subject

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Who? said the prince.
children.prevalue: Who said the prince

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The chevalier assumed almost an angry air, as he replied, Monseigneur, you are subjecting me to crossexamination; you treat me as a criminal at the bar; the rumors which idly pass by a gentleman's ears do not remain there. Your highness wishes me to magnify rumors until it attains the importance of an event.
children.prevalue: The chevalier assumed almost an angry air as he replied Monseigneur you are subjecting me to crossexamination you treat me as a criminal at the bar the rumors which idly pass by a gentleman s ears do not remain there Your highness wishes me to magnify rumors until it attains the importance of an event

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: However, said the duke, in great displeasure, the fact remains that you withdrew on account of this report.
children.prevalue: However said the duke in great displeasure the fact remains that you withdrew on account of this report

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: To speak the truth, others have talked to me of the attentions of M. de Guiche to Madame, nothing more; perfectly harmless, I repeat, and more than that, allowable. But do not be unjust, monseigneur, and do not attach any undue importance to it. It does not concern you.
children.prevalue: To speak the truth others have talked to me of the attentions of M de Guiche to Madame nothing more perfectly harmless I repeat and more than that allowable But do not be unjust monseigneur and do not attach any undue importance to it It does not concern you

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: M. de Guiche's attentions to Madame do not concern me?
children.prevalue: M de Guiche s attentions to Madame do not concern me

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: No, monseigneur; and what I say to you I would say to De Guiche himself, so little do I think of the attentions he pays Madame. Nay, I would say it even to Madame herself. Only you understand what I am afraid ofI am afraid of being thought jealous of the favor shown, when I am only jealous as far as friendship is concerned. I know your disposition; I know that when you bestow your affections you become exclusively attached. You love Madameand who, indeed, would not love her? Follow me attentively as I proceed:Madame has noticed among your friends the handsomest and most fascinating of them all; she will begin to influence you on his behalf in such a way that you will neglect the others. Your indifference would kill me; it is already bad enough to have to support Madame's indifference. I have, therefore, made up my mind to give way to the favorite whose happiness I envy, even while I acknowledge my sincere friendship and sincere admiration for him. Well, monseigneur, do you see anything to object to in this reasoning? Is it not that of a man of honor? Is my conduct that of a sincere friend? Answer me, at least, after having so closely questioned me.
children.prevalue: No monseigneur and what I say to you I would say to De Guiche himself so little do I think of the attentions he pays Madame Nay I would say it even to Madame herself Only you understand what I am afraid ofI am afraid of being thought jealous of the favor shown when I am only jealous as far as friendship is concerned I know your disposition I know that when you bestow your affections you become exclusively attached You love Madameand who indeed would not love her Follow me attentively as I proceed Madame has noticed among your friends the handsomest and most fascinating of them all she will begin to influence you on his behalf in such a way that you will neglect the others Your indifference would kill me it is already bad enough to have to support Madame s indifference I have therefore made up my mind to give way to the favorite whose happiness I envy even while I acknowledge my sincere friendship and sincere admiration for him Well monseigneur do you see anything to object to in this reasoning Is it not that of a man of honor Is my conduct that of a sincere friend Answer me at least after having so closely questioned me

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: The duke had seated himself, with his head buried in his hands. After a silence long enough to enable the chevalier to judge the effect of this oratorical display, the duke arose, saying, Come, be candid.
children.prevalue: The duke had seated himself with his head buried in his hands After a silence long enough to enable the chevalier to judge the effect of this oratorical display the duke arose saying Come be candid

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: As I always am.
children.prevalue: As I always am

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Very well. You know that we already observed something respecting that mad fellow, Buckingham.
children.prevalue: Very well You know that we already observed something respecting that mad fellow Buckingham

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Do not say anything against Madame, monseigneur, or I shall take my leave. It is impossible you can be suspicious of Madame?
children.prevalue: Do not say anything against Madame monseigneur or I shall take my leave It is impossible you can be suspicious of Madame

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: No, no, chevalier; I do not suspect Madame; but in fact, I observeI compare
children.prevalue: No no chevalier I do not suspect Madame but in fact I observeI compare

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Buckingham was a madman, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Buckingham was a madman monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: A madman about whom, however, you opened my eyes thoroughly.
children.prevalue: A madman about whom however you opened my eyes thoroughly

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: No, no, said the chevalier, quickly; it was not I who opened your eyes, it was De Guiche. Do not confound us, I beg. And he began to laugh in so harsh a manner that it sounded like the hiss of a serpent.
children.prevalue: No no said the chevalier quickly it was not I who opened your eyes it was De Guiche Do not confound us I beg And he began to laugh in so harsh a manner that it sounded like the hiss of a serpent

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Yes, yes; I remember. You said a few words, but De Guiche showed the most jealousy.
children.prevalue: Yes yes I remember You said a few words but De Guiche showed the most jealousy

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I should think so, continued the chevalier, in the same tone. He was fighting for home and altar.
children.prevalue: I should think so continued the chevalier in the same tone He was fighting for home and altar

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: What did you say? said the duke, haughtily, thoroughly roused by this insidious jest.
children.prevalue: What did you say said the duke haughtily thoroughly roused by this insidious jest

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Am I not right? for does not M. de Guiche hold the chief post of honor in your household?
children.prevalue: Am I not right for does not M de Guiche hold the chief post of honor in your household

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Well, replied the duke, somewhat calmed, had this passion of Buckingham been remarked?
children.prevalue: Well replied the duke somewhat calmed had this passion of Buckingham been remarked

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Very well. Do people say that M. de Guiche's is remarked as much?
children.prevalue: Very well Do people say that M de Guiche s is remarked as much

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Pardon me, monseigneur; you are again mistaken; no one says that M. de Guiche entertains anything of the sort.
children.prevalue: Pardon me monseigneur you are again mistaken no one says that M de Guiche entertains anything of the sort

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Very good.
children.prevalue: Very good

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: You see, monseigneur, that it would have been better, a hundred times better, to have left me in my retirement, than to have allowed you to conjure up, by aid of any scruples I may have had, suspicions which Madame will regard as crimes, and she would be in the right, too.
children.prevalue: You see monseigneur that it would have been better a hundred times better to have left me in my retirement than to have allowed you to conjure up by aid of any scruples I may have had suspicions which Madame will regard as crimes and she would be in the right too

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: What would you do?
children.prevalue: What would you do

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Act reasonably.
children.prevalue: Act reasonably

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: In what way?
children.prevalue: In what way

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: I should not pay the slightest attention to the society of these new Epicurean philosophers; and, in that way, the rumors will cease.
children.prevalue: I should not pay the slightest attention to the society of these new Epicurean philosophers and in that way the rumors will cease

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Well, I will see; I will think it over.
children.prevalue: Well I will see I will think it over

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Oh, you have time enough; the danger is not great; and then, besides, it is not a question of danger or of passion. It all arose from a fear I had to see your friendship for me decrease. From the very moment you restore it, with so kind an assurance of its existence, I have no longer any other idea in my head.
children.prevalue: Oh you have time enough the danger is not great and then besides it is not a question of danger or of passion It all arose from a fear I had to see your friendship for me decrease From the very moment you restore it with so kind an assurance of its existence I have no longer any other idea in my head

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: The duke shook his head as if he meant to say: If you have no more ideas, I have, though. It being now the dinner hour, the prince sent to inform Madame of it; but she returned a message to the effect that she could not be present, but would dine in her own apartment.
children.prevalue: The duke shook his head as if he meant to say If you have no more ideas I have though It being now the dinner hour the prince sent to inform Madame of it but she returned a message to the effect that she could not be present but would dine in her own apartment

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: That is not my fault, said the duke. This morning, having taken them by surprise in the midst of a musical party, I got jealous; and so they are in the sulks with me.
children.prevalue: That is not my fault said the duke This morning having taken them by surprise in the midst of a musical party I got jealous and so they are in the sulks with me

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: We will dine alone, said the chevalier, with a sigh; I regret De Guiche is not here.
children.prevalue: We will dine alone said the chevalier with a sigh I regret De Guiche is not here

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Oh! De Guiche will not remain long in the sulks; he is a very goodnatured fellow.
children.prevalue: Oh De Guiche will not remain long in the sulks he is a very goodnatured fellow

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Monseigneur, said the chevalier, suddenly, an excellent idea has struck me, in our conversation just now. I may have exasperated your highness, and caused you some dissatisfaction. It is but fitting that I should be the mediator. I will go and look for the count, and bring him back with me.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur said the chevalier suddenly an excellent idea has struck me in our conversation just now I may have exasperated your highness and caused you some dissatisfaction It is but fitting that I should be the mediator I will go and look for the count and bring him back with me

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Ah! chevalier, you are really a very goodnatured fellow.
children.prevalue: Ah chevalier you are really a very goodnatured fellow

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: You say that as if you were surprised.
children.prevalue: You say that as if you were surprised

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Well, you are not so tenderhearted every day.
children.prevalue: Well you are not so tenderhearted every day

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: That may be; but confess that I know how to repair a wrong I may have done.
children.prevalue: That may be but confess that I know how to repair a wrong I may have done

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: I confess that.
children.prevalue: I confess that

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Will your highness do me the favor to wait here a few minutes?
children.prevalue: Will your highness do me the favor to wait here a few minutes

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Willingly; be off, and I will try on my Fontainebleau costume.
children.prevalue: Willingly be off and I will try on my Fontainebleau costume

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: The chevalier left the room, called his different attendant with the greatest care, as if he were giving them different orders. All went off in various directions; but he retained his valet de chambre. Ascertain, and immediately, too, of M. de Guiche is not in Madame's apartments. How can one learn it?
children.prevalue: The chevalier left the room called his different attendant with the greatest care as if he were giving them different orders All went off in various directions but he retained his valet de chambre Ascertain and immediately too of M de Guiche is not in Madame s apartments How can one learn it

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Very easily, monsieur. I will ask Malicorne, who will find out from Mlle. de Montalais. I may as well tell you, however, that the inquiry will be useless; for all M. de Guiche's attendants are gone, and he must have left with them.
children.prevalue: Very easily monsieur I will ask Malicorne who will find out from Mlle de Montalais I may as well tell you however that the inquiry will be useless for all M de Guiche s attendants are gone and he must have left with them

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Ascertain, nevertheless.
children.prevalue: Ascertain nevertheless

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Ten minutes had hardly passed, when the valet returned. He beckoned his master mysteriously towards the servants' staircase, and showed him into a small room with a window looking out upon the garden. What is the matter? said the chevalier; why so many precautions?
children.prevalue: Ten minutes had hardly passed when the valet returned He beckoned his master mysteriously towards the servants staircase and showed him into a small room with a window looking out upon the garden What is the matter said the chevalier why so many precautions

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Look, monsieur, said the valet, look yonder, under the walnuttree.
children.prevalue: Look monsieur said the valet look yonder under the walnuttree

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Ah? said the chevalier. I see Manicamp there. What is he waiting for?
children.prevalue: Ah said the chevalier I see Manicamp there What is he waiting for

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: You will see in a moment, monsieur, if you wait patiently. There, do you see now?
children.prevalue: You will see in a moment monsieur if you wait patiently There do you see now

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: I see one, two, four musicians with their instruments, and behind them, urging them on, De Guiche himself. What is he doing there, though?
children.prevalue: I see one two four musicians with their instruments and behind them urging them on De Guiche himself What is he doing there though

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: He is waiting until the little door of the staircase, belonging to the ladies of honor, is opened; by that staircase he will ascend to Madame's apartments, where some new pieces of music are going to be performed during dinner.
children.prevalue: He is waiting until the little door of the staircase belonging to the ladies of honor is opened by that staircase he will ascend to Madame s apartments where some new pieces of music are going to be performed during dinner

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: This is admirable news you tell me.
children.prevalue: This is admirable news you tell me

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Is it not, monsieur?
children.prevalue: Is it not monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Was it M. de Malicorne who told you this?
children.prevalue: Was it M de Malicorne who told you this

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Yes, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Yes monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: He likes you, then?
children.prevalue: He likes you then

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: No, monsieur, it is Monsieur that he likes.
children.prevalue: No monsieur it is Monsieur that he likes

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Why?
children.prevalue: Why

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Because he wishes to belong to his household.
children.prevalue: Because he wishes to belong to his household

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: And most certainly he shall. How much did he give you for that?
children.prevalue: And most certainly he shall How much did he give you for that

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: The secret which I now dispose of to you, monsieur.
children.prevalue: The secret which I now dispose of to you monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: And which I buy for a hundred pistoles. Take them.
children.prevalue: And which I buy for a hundred pistoles Take them

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Thank you, monsieur. Look, look, the little door opens; a woman admits the musicians.
children.prevalue: Thank you monsieur Look look the little door opens a woman admits the musicians

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: It is Montalais.
children.prevalue: It is Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Hush, monseigneur; do not call out her name; whoever says Montalais says Malicorne. If you quarrel with the one, you will be on bad terms with the other.
children.prevalue: Hush monseigneur do not call out her name whoever says Montalais says Malicorne If you quarrel with the one you will be on bad terms with the other

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Very well; I have seen nothing.
children.prevalue: Very well I have seen nothing

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: And I, said the valet, pocketing the purse, have received nothing.
children.prevalue: And I said the valet pocketing the purse have received nothing

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: The chevalier, being now certain that Guiche had entered, returned to the prince, whom he found splendidly dressed and radiant with joy, as with good looks. I am told, he exclaimed, that the king has taken the sun as his device; really, monseigneur, it is you whom this device would best suit.

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Where is De Guiche?
children.prevalue: Where is De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: He cannot be found. He has fledhas evaporated entirely. Your scolding of this morning terrified him. He could not be found in his apartments.
children.prevalue: He cannot be found He has fledhas evaporated entirely Your scolding of this morning terrified him He could not be found in his apartments

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Bah! the hairbrained fellow is capable of setting off posthaste to his own estates. Poor man! we will recall him. Come, let us dine now.
children.prevalue: Bah the hairbrained fellow is capable of setting off posthaste to his own estates Poor man we will recall him Come let us dine now

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Monseigneur, today is a very festival of ideas; I have another.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur today is a very festival of ideas I have another

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: What is it?
children.prevalue: What is it

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Madame is angry with you, and she has reason to be so. You owe her revenge; go and dine with her.
children.prevalue: Madame is angry with you and she has reason to be so You owe her revenge go and dine with her

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Oh! that would be acting like a weak and whimsical husband.
children.prevalue: Oh that would be acting like a weak and whimsical husband

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: It is the duty of a good husband to do so. The princess is no doubt wearied enough; she will be weeping in her plate, and here eyes will get quite red. A husband who is the cause of his wife's eyes getting red is an odious creature. Come, monseigneur, come.
children.prevalue: It is the duty of a good husband to do so The princess is no doubt wearied enough she will be weeping in her plate and here eyes will get quite red A husband who is the cause of his wife s eyes getting red is an odious creature Come monseigneur come

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: I cannot; for I have directed dinner to be served here.
children.prevalue: I cannot for I have directed dinner to be served here

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: Yet see, monseigneur, how dull we shall be; I shall be lowspirited because I know that Madame will be alone; you, hard and savage as you wish to appear, will be sighing all the while. Take me with you to Madame's dinner, and that will be a delightful surprise. I am sure we shall be very merry; you were in the wrong this morning.
children.prevalue: Yet see monseigneur how dull we shall be I shall be lowspirited because I know that Madame will be alone you hard and savage as you wish to appear will be sighing all the while Take me with you to Madame s dinner and that will be a delightful surprise I am sure we shall be very merry you were in the wrong this morning

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Well, perhaps I was.
children.prevalue: Well perhaps I was

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: There is no perhaps at all, for it is a fact you were so.
children.prevalue: There is no perhaps at all for it is a fact you were so

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: Chevalier, chevalier, your advice is not good.
children.prevalue: Chevalier chevalier your advice is not good

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Nay, my advice is good; all the advantages are on your own side. Your violetcolored suit, embroidered with gold, becomes you admirably. Madame will be as much vanquished by the man as by the action. Come, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Nay my advice is good all the advantages are on your own side Your violetcolored suit embroidered with gold becomes you admirably Madame will be as much vanquished by the man as by the action Come monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: You decide me; let us go.
children.prevalue: You decide me let us go

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: The duke left his room, accompanied by the chevalier and went towards Madame's apartments. The chevalier hastily whispered to the valet, Be sure there are some people before that little door, so that no one can escape in that direction. Run, run! And he followed the duke towards the antechambers of Madame's suite of apartments, and when the ushers were about to announce them, the chevalier said, laughing, His highness wishes to surprise Madame.
children.prevalue: The duke left his room accompanied by the chevalier and went towards Madame s apartments The chevalier hastily whispered to the valet Be sure there are some people before that little door so that no one can escape in that direction Run run And he followed the duke towards the antechambers of Madame s suite of apartments and when the ushers were about to announce them the chevalier said laughing His highness wishes to surprise Madame

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Monsieur entered the room abruptly, as persons do who mean well and think they confer pleasure, or as those who hope to surprise some secret, the terrible reward of jealous people. Madame, almost out of her senses with joy at the first bars of music, was dancing in the most unrestrained manner, leaving the dinner, which had been already begun, unfinished. Her partner was M. de Guiche, who, with his arms raised, and his eyes half closed, was kneeling on one knee, like the Spanish dancers, with looks full of passion, and gestures of the most caressing character. The princess was dancing round him with a responsive smile, and the same air of alluring seductiveness. Montalais stood by admiringly; La Valliere, seated in a corner of the room, looked on thoughtfully. It is impossible to describe the effect which the presence of the prince produced upon this gleeful company, and it would be equally impossible to describe the effect which the sight of their happiness produced upon Philip. The Comte de Guiche had no power to move; Madame remained in the middle of one of the figures and of an attitude, unable to utter a word. The Chevalier de Lorraine, leaning his back against the doorway, smiled like a man in the very height of the frankest admiration. The pallor of the prince, and the convulsive twitching of his hands and limbs, were the first symptoms that struck those present. A dead silence succeeded the merry music of the dance. The Chevalier de Lorraine took advantage of this interval to salute Madame and De Guiche most respectfully, affecting to join them together in his reverences as though they were the master and mistress of the house. Monsieur then approached them, saying, in a hoarse tone of voice, I am delighted; I came here expecting to find you ill and lowspirited, and I find you abandoning yourself to new amusements; really, it is most fortunate. My house is the pleasantest in the kingdom. Then turning towards De Guiche, Comte, he said, I did not know you were so good a dancer. And, again addressing his wife, he said, Show a little more consideration for me, Madame; whenever you intend to amuse yourselves here, invite me. I am a prince, unfortunately, very much neglected.

a dancer And again addressing his wife he said Show a little more consideration for me Madame whenever you intend to amuse yourselves here invite me I am a prince unfortunately very much neglected

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Guiche had now recovered his selfpossession, and with the spirited boldness which was natural to him, and sat so well upon him, he said, Your highness knows very well that my very life is at your service, and whenever there is a question of its being needed, I am ready; but today, as it is only a question of dancing to music, I dance.
children.prevalue: Guiche had now recovered his selfpossession and with the spirited boldness which was natural to him and sat so well upon him he said Your highness knows very well that my very life is at your service and whenever there is a question of its being needed I am ready but today as it is only a question of dancing to music I dance

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: And you are perfectly right, said the prince, coldly. But, Madame, he continued, you do not remark that your ladies deprive me of my friends; M. de Guiche does not belong to you, Madame, but to me. If you wish to dine without me you have your ladies. When I dine alone I have my gentlemen; do not strip me of everything.
children.prevalue: And you are perfectly right said the prince coldly But Madame he continued you do not remark that your ladies deprive me of my friends M de Guiche does not belong to you Madame but to me If you wish to dine without me you have your ladies When I dine alone I have my gentlemen do not strip me of everything

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Madame felt the reproach and the lesson, and the color rushed to her face. Monsieur, she replied, I was not aware, when I came to the court of France, that princesses of my rank were to be regarded as the women in Turkey are. I was not aware that we were not allowed to be seen; but, since such is your desire, I will conform myself to it; pray do not hesitate, if you should wish it, to have my windows barred, even.
children.prevalue: Madame felt the reproach and the lesson and the color rushed to her face Monsieur she replied I was not aware when I came to the court of France that princesses of my rank were to be regarded as the women in Turkey are I was not aware that we were not allowed to be seen but since such is your desire I will conform myself to it pray do not hesitate if you should wish it to have my windows barred even

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: This repartee, which made Montalais and De Guiche smile, rekindled the prince's anger, no inconsiderable portion of which had already evaporated in words.
children.prevalue: This repartee which made Montalais and De Guiche smile rekindled the prince s anger no inconsiderable portion of which had already evaporated in words

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Very well, he said, in a concentrated tone of voice, this is the way in which I am respected in my own house.
children.prevalue: Very well he said in a concentrated tone of voice this is the way in which I am respected in my own house

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Monseigneur, monseigneur, murmured the chevalier in the duke's ear, in such a manner that every one could observe he was endeavoring to calm him.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur monseigneur murmured the chevalier in the duke s ear in such a manner that every one could observe he was endeavoring to calm him

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Come, replied the prince, as his only answer to the remark, hurrying him away, and turning round with so hasty a movement that he almost ran against Madame. The chevalier followed him to his own apartment, where the prince had no sooner seated himself than he gave free vent to his fury. The chevalier raised his eyes towards the ceiling, joined his hands together, and said not a word.
children.prevalue: Come replied the prince as his only answer to the remark hurrying him away and turning round with so hasty a movement that he almost ran against Madame The chevalier followed him to his own apartment where the prince had no sooner seated himself than he gave free vent to his fury The chevalier raised his eyes towards the ceiling joined his hands together and said not a word

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Give me your opinion, exclaimed the prince.
children.prevalue: Give me your opinion exclaimed the prince

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Upon what?
children.prevalue: Upon what

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Upon what is taking place here.
children.prevalue: Upon what is taking place here

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Oh, monseigneur, it is a very serious matter.
children.prevalue: Oh monseigneur it is a very serious matter

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: It is abominable! I cannot live in this manner.
children.prevalue: It is abominable I cannot live in this manner

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: How miserable all this is, said the chevalier. We hoped to enjoy tranquillity after that madman Buckingham had left.
children.prevalue: How miserable all this is said the chevalier We hoped to enjoy tranquillity after that madman Buckingham had left

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: And this is worse.
children.prevalue: And this is worse

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: I do not say that, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: I do not say that monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Yes, but I say it; for Buckingham would never have ventured upon a fourth part of what we have just now seen.
children.prevalue: Yes but I say it for Buckingham would never have ventured upon a fourth part of what we have just now seen

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: What do you mean?

children.value: Anne of Austria felt that her happiness was now complete; peace restored to her family, a nation delighted with the presence of a young monarch who had shown an aptitude for affairs of great importance; the revenues of the state increased; external peace assured; everything seemed to promise a tranquil future. Her thoughts recurred, now and then, to the poor young nobleman whom she had received as a mother, and had driven away as a hardhearted stepmother, and she sighed as she thought of him.

children.prevalue: The queen clapped her hands together and began to laugh Philip she said your jealousy is not merely a defect it is a disease

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: And do you imagine that a complaint which exists only in your own imagination can be cured? You wish it to be said you are right in being jealous, when there is no ground whatever for your jealousy.
children.prevalue: And do you imagine that a complaint which exists only in your own imagination can be cured You wish it to be said you are right in being jealous when there is no ground whatever for your jealousy

children.prevalue: Do not exaggerate Philip and take care how you represent your wife to me as a woman of depraved mind

children.prevalue: This morning at ten o clock they were playing music in Madame s apartments

children.value: No harm in that, surely.
children.prevalue: No harm in that surely

children.prevalue: If they were doing any harm they would hide themselves

children.prevalue: Very good exclaimed the duke I expected you to say that Pray remember with precision the words you have just uttered This morning I took them by surprise and showed my dissatisfaction in a very marked manner

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Rely upon it, that is quite sufficient; it was, perhaps, even a little too much. These young women easily take offense. To reproach them for an error they have not committed is, sometimes, almost equivalent to telling them they might be guilty of even worse.

children.prevalue: Very good very good but wait a minute Do not forget what you have just this moment said that this morning s lesson ought to have been sufficient and that if they had been doing what was wrong they would have hidden themselves

children.prevalue: Well what is your opinion Philip

children.prevalue: Unless what

children.prevalue: What madame

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Listen, Philip; I am not disposed to pay people ill compliments every day; I have some influence over young people, but I cannot take advantage of it without running the chances of losing it altogether. Besides, there is nothing to prove that M. de Guiche is guilty.

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: She had hardly finished when Philip heard the door of the anteroom open with some noise. He began to feel nervous. At the sound of the king's footsteps, which could be heard upon the carpet, the duke hurriedly made his escape. Anne of Austria could not resist laughing, and was laughing still when the king entered. He came very affectionately to inquire after the even now uncertain health of the queenmother, and to announce to her that the preparations for the journey to Fontainebleau were complete. Seeing her laugh, his uneasiness on her account diminished, and he addressed her in a vivacious tone himself. Anne of Austria took him by the hand, and, in a voice full of playfulness, said, Do you know, sire that I am proud of being a Spanish woman?
