children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: When the king made his appearance in Madame's apartments, the courtiers, whom the news of a conjugal misunderstanding had dispersed through the various apartments, began to entertain the most serious apprehensions. A storm was brewing in that direction, the elements of which the Chevalier de Lorraine, in the midst of the different groups, was analyzing with delight, contributing to the weaker, and acting, according to his own wicked designs, in such a manner with regard to the stronger, as to produce the most disastrous consequences possible. As Anne of Austria had herself said, the presence of the king gave a solemn and serious character to the event. Indeed, in the year 1662, the dissatisfaction of Monsieur with Madame, and the king's intervention in the private affairs of Monsieur, was a matter of no inconsiderable moment. [3]
children.prevalue: When the king made his appearance in Madame s apartments the courtiers whom the news of a conjugal misunderstanding had dispersed through the various apartments began to entertain the most serious apprehensions A storm was brewing in that direction the elements of which the Chevalier de Lorraine in the midst of the different groups was analyzing with delight contributing to the weaker and acting according to his own wicked designs in such a manner with regard to the stronger as to produce the most disastrous consequences possible As Anne of Austria had herself said the presence of the king gave a solemn and serious character to the event Indeed in the year 1662 the dissatisfaction of Monsieur with Madame and the king s intervention in the private affairs of Monsieur was a matter of no inconsiderable moment 3

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The boldest, even, who had been the associates of the Comte de Guiche, had, from the first moment, held aloof from him, with a sort of nervous apprehension; and the comte himself, infected by the general panic, retired to his own room. The king entered Madame's private apartments, acknowledging and returning the salutations, as he was always in the habit of doing. The ladies of honor were ranged in a line on his passage along the gallery. Although his majesty was very much preoccupied, he gave the glance of a master at the two rows of young and beautiful girls, who modestly cast down their eyes, blushing as they felt the king's gaze fall upon them. One only of the number, whose long hair fell in silken masses upon the most beautiful skin imaginable, was pale, and could hardly sustain herself, notwithstanding the knocks which her companion gave her with her elbow. It was La Valliere whom Montalais supported in that manner by whispering some of that courage to her with which she herself was so abundantly provided. The king could not resist turning round to look at them again. Their faces, which had already been raised, were again lowered, but the only fair head among them remained motionless, as if all the strength and intelligence she had left had abandoned her. When he entered Madame's room, Louis found his sisterinlaw reclining upon the cushions of her cabinet. She rose and made a profound reverence, murmuring some words of thanks for the honor she was receiving. She then resumed her seat, overcome by a sudden weakness, which was no doubt assumed, for a delightful color animated her cheeks, and her eyes, still red from the tears she had recently shed, never had more fire in them. When the king was seated, as soon as he had remarked, with that accuracy of observation which characterized him, the disorder of the apartment, and the no less great disorder of Madame's countenance, he assumed a playful manner, saying, My dear sister, at what hour today would you wish the repetition of the ballet to take place?
children.prevalue: The boldest even who had been the associates of the Comte de Guiche had from the first moment held aloof from him with a sort of nervous apprehension and the comte himself infected by the general panic retired to his own room The king entered Madame s private apartments acknowledging and returning the salutations as he was always in the habit of doing The ladies of honor were ranged in a line on his passage along the gallery Although his majesty was very much preoccupied he gave the glance of a master at the two rows of young and beautiful girls who modestly cast down their eyes blushing as they felt the king s gaze fall upon them One only of the number whose long hair fell in silken masses upon the most beautiful skin imaginable was pale and could hardly sustain herself notwithstanding the knocks which her companion gave her with her elbow It was La Valliere whom Montalais supported in that manner by whispering some of that courage to her with which she herself was so abundantly provided The king could not resist turning round to look at them again Their faces which had already been raised were again lowered but the only fair head among them remained motionless as if all the strength and intelligence she had left had abandoned her When he entered Madame s room Louis found his sisterinlaw reclining upon the cushions of her cabinet She rose and made a profound reverence murmuring some words of thanks for the honor she was receiving She then resumed her seat overcome by a sudden weakness which was no doubt assumed for a delightful color animated her cheeks and her eyes still red from the tears she had recently shed never had more fire in them When the king was seated as soon as he had remarked with that accuracy of observation which characterized him the disorder of the apartment and the no less great disorder of Madame s countenance he assumed a playful manner saying My dear sister at what hour today would you wish the repetition of the ballet to take place

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Madame, shaking her charming head, slowly and languishingly said: Ah! sire, will you graciously excuse my appearance at the repetition? I was about to send to inform you that I could not attend today.
children.prevalue: Madame shaking her charming head slowly and languishingly said Ah sire will you graciously excuse my appearance at the repetition I was about to send to inform you that I could not attend today

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Indeed, said the king, in apparent surprise; are you not well?
children.prevalue: Indeed said the king in apparent surprise are you not well

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: No, sire.
children.prevalue: No sire

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: I will summon your medical attendants, then.
children.prevalue: I will summon your medical attendants then

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: No, for they can do nothing for my indisposition.
children.prevalue: No for they can do nothing for my indisposition

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: You alarm me.
children.prevalue: You alarm me

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Sire, I wish to ask your majesty's permission to return to England.
children.prevalue: Sire I wish to ask your majesty s permission to return to England

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: The king started. Return to England, he said; do you really say what you mean?
children.prevalue: The king started Return to England he said do you really say what you mean

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I say it reluctantly, sire, replied the granddaughter of Henry IV., firmly, her beautiful black eyes flashing. I regret to have to confide such matters to your majesty, but I feel myself too unhappy at your majesty's court; and I wish to return to my own family.
children.prevalue: I say it reluctantly sire replied the granddaughter of Henry IV firmly her beautiful black eyes flashing I regret to have to confide such matters to your majesty but I feel myself too unhappy at your majesty s court and I wish to return to my own family

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Madame, madame, exclaimed the king, as he approached her.
children.prevalue: Madame madame exclaimed the king as he approached her

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Listen to me, sire, continued the young woman, acquiring by degrees that ascendency over her interrogator which her beauty and her nervous nature conferred; young as I am, I have already suffered humiliation, and have endured disdain here. Oh! do not contradict me, sire, she said, with a smile. The king colored.
children.prevalue: Listen to me sire continued the young woman acquiring by degrees that ascendency over her interrogator which her beauty and her nervous nature conferred young as I am I have already suffered humiliation and have endured disdain here Oh do not contradict me sire she said with a smile The king colored

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Then, she continued, I had reasoned myself into the belief that Heaven called me into existence with that objectI, the daughter of a powerful monarch; that since my father had been deprived of life, Heaven could well smite my pride. I have suffered greatly; I have been the cause, too, of my mother suffering much; but I vowed that if Providence ever placed me in a position of independence, even were it that of a workman of the lower classes, who gains her bread by her labor, I would never suffer humiliation again. That day has now arrived; I have been restored to the fortune due to my rank and to my birth; I have even ascended again the steps of a throne, and I thought that, in allying myself with a French prince, I should find in him a relation, a friend, an equal; but I perceive I have found only a master, and I rebel. My mother shall know nothing of it; you whom I respect, and whom Ilove
children.prevalue: Then she continued I had reasoned myself into the belief that Heaven called me into existence with that objectI the daughter of a powerful monarch that since my father had been deprived of life Heaven could well smite my pride I have suffered greatly I have been the cause too of my mother suffering much but I vowed that if Providence ever placed me in a position of independence even were it that of a workman of the lower classes who gains her bread by her labor I would never suffer humiliation again That day has now arrived I have been restored to the fortune due to my rank and to my birth I have even ascended again the steps of a throne and I thought that in allying myself with a French prince I should find in him a relation a friend an equal but I perceive I have found only a master and I rebel My mother shall know nothing of it you whom I respect and whom Ilove

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The king started; never had any voice so gratified his ear.
children.prevalue: The king started never had any voice so gratified his ear

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: You, sire, who know all, since you have come here; you will, perhaps, understand me. If you had not come, I should have gone to you. I wish for permission to go away. I leave it to your delicacy of feeling to exculpate and to protect me.
children.prevalue: You sire who know all since you have come here you will perhaps understand me If you had not come I should have gone to you I wish for permission to go away I leave it to your delicacy of feeling to exculpate and to protect me

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: My dear sister, murmured the king, overpowered by this bold attack, have you reflected upon the enormous difficulty of the project you have conceived?
children.prevalue: My dear sister murmured the king overpowered by this bold attack have you reflected upon the enormous difficulty of the project you have conceived

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Sire, I do not reflect, I feel. Attacked, I instinctively repel the attack, nothing more.
children.prevalue: Sire I do not reflect I feel Attacked I instinctively repel the attack nothing more

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Come, tell me, what have they done to you? said the king.
children.prevalue: Come tell me what have they done to you said the king

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The princess, it will have been seen, by this peculiarly feminine maneuver, had escaped every reproach, and advanced on her side a far more serious one; from the accused she became the accuser. It is an infallible sign of guilt; but notwithstanding that, all women, even the least clever of the sex, invariably know how to derive some such means of turning the tables. The king had forgotten that he was paying her a visit in order to say to her, What have you done to my brother? and he was reduced to weakly asking her, What have they done to you?
children.prevalue: The princess it will have been seen by this peculiarly feminine maneuver had escaped every reproach and advanced on her side a far more serious one from the accused she became the accuser It is an infallible sign of guilt but notwithstanding that all women even the least clever of the sex invariably know how to derive some such means of turning the tables The king had forgotten that he was paying her a visit in order to say to her What have you done to my brother and he was reduced to weakly asking her What have they done to you

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: What have they done to me? replied Madame. One must be a woman to understand it, sirethey have made me shed tears; and, with one of her fingers, whose slenderness and perfect whiteness were unequaled, she pointed to her brilliant eyes swimming with unshed drops, and again began to weep.
children.prevalue: What have they done to me replied Madame One must be a woman to understand it sirethey have made me shed tears and with one of her fingers whose slenderness and perfect whiteness were unequaled she pointed to her brilliant eyes swimming with unshed drops and again began to weep

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I implore you, my dear sister! said the king, advancing to take her warm and throbbing hand, which she abandoned to him.
children.prevalue: I implore you my dear sister said the king advancing to take her warm and throbbing hand which she abandoned to him

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: In the first place, sire, I was deprived of the presence of my brother's friend. The Duke of Buckingham was an agreeable, cheerful visitor; my own countryman, who knew my habits; I will say almost a companion, so accustomed had we been to pass our days together, with our other friends, upon the beautiful piece of water at St. James's.
children.prevalue: In the first place sire I was deprived of the presence of my brother s friend The Duke of Buckingham was an agreeable cheerful visitor my own countryman who knew my habits I will say almost a companion so accustomed had we been to pass our days together with our other friends upon the beautiful piece of water at St James s

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: But Villiers was in love with you.
children.prevalue: But Villiers was in love with you

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: A pretext! What does it matter, she said, seriously, whether the duke was in love with me or not? Is a man in love so very dangerous for me? Ah! sire, it is not sufficient for a man to love a woman. And she smiled so tenderly, and with so much archness, that the king felt his heart swell and throb in his breast.
children.prevalue: A pretext What does it matter she said seriously whether the duke was in love with me or not Is a man in love so very dangerous for me Ah sire it is not sufficient for a man to love a woman And she smiled so tenderly and with so much archness that the king felt his heart swell and throb in his breast

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: At all events, if my brother were jealous? interrupted the king.
children.prevalue: At all events if my brother were jealous interrupted the king

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Very well, I admit that is a reason; and the duke was sent away accordingly.
children.prevalue: Very well I admit that is a reason and the duke was sent away accordingly

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: No, not sent away.
children.prevalue: No not sent away

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Driven away, dismissed, expelled, then, if you prefer it, sire. One of the first gentlemen of Europe obliged to leave the court of the King of France, of Louis XIV., like a beggar, on account of a glance or a bouquet. It was little worthy of a most gallant court; but forgive me, sire; I forgot, that, in speaking thus, I am attacking your sovereign power.
children.prevalue: Driven away dismissed expelled then if you prefer it sire One of the first gentlemen of Europe obliged to leave the court of the King of France of Louis XIV like a beggar on account of a glance or a bouquet It was little worthy of a most gallant court but forgive me sire I forgot that in speaking thus I am attacking your sovereign power

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: I assure you, my dear sister, it was not I who dismissed the Duke of Buckingham; I was charmed with him.
children.prevalue: I assure you my dear sister it was not I who dismissed the Duke of Buckingham I was charmed with him

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: It was not you? said Madame; ah! so much the better; and she emphasized the so much the better, as if she had instead said, so much the worse.
children.prevalue: It was not you said Madame ah so much the better and she emphasized the so much the better as if she had instead said so much the worse

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: A few minutes' silence ensued. She then resumed: The Duke of Buckingham having leftI now know why and by whose meansI thought I should have recovered my tranquillity; but not at all, for all at once Monsieur found another pretext; all at once
children.prevalue: A few minutes silence ensued She then resumed The Duke of Buckingham having leftI now know why and by whose meansI thought I should have recovered my tranquillity but not at all for all at once Monsieur found another pretext all at once

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: All at once, said the king, playfully, some one else presents himself. It is but natural; you are beautiful, and will always meet with men who will madly love you.
children.prevalue: All at once said the king playfully some one else presents himself It is but natural you are beautiful and will always meet with men who will madly love you

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: In that case, exclaimed the princess, I will create a solitude around me, which indeed seems to be what is wished, and what is being prepared for me. But no, I prefer to return to London. There I am known and appreciated. I shall have friends, without fearing they may be regarded as my lovers. Shame! it is a disgraceful suspicion, and unworthy a gentleman. Monsieur has lost everything in my estimation, since he has shown me he can be a tyrant to a woman.
children.prevalue: In that case exclaimed the princess I will create a solitude around me which indeed seems to be what is wished and what is being prepared for me But no I prefer to return to London There I am known and appreciated I shall have friends without fearing they may be regarded as my lovers Shame it is a disgraceful suspicion and unworthy a gentleman Monsieur has lost everything in my estimation since he has shown me he can be a tyrant to a woman

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Nay, nay, my brother's only fault is that of loving you.
children.prevalue: Nay nay my brother s only fault is that of loving you

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Love me! Monsieur love me! Ah! sire, and she burst out laughing. Monsieur will never love any woman, she said; Monsieur loves himself too much; no, unhappily for me, Monsieur's jealousy is of the worst kindhe is jealous without love.
children.prevalue: Love me Monsieur love me Ah sire and she burst out laughing Monsieur will never love any woman she said Monsieur loves himself too much no unhappily for me Monsieur s jealousy is of the worst kindhe is jealous without love

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Confess, however, said the king, who began to be excited by this varied and animated conversation; confess that Guiche loves you.
children.prevalue: Confess however said the king who began to be excited by this varied and animated conversation confess that Guiche loves you

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Ah! sire, I know nothing about that.
children.prevalue: Ah sire I know nothing about that

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: You must have perceived it. A man who loves readily betrays himself.
children.prevalue: You must have perceived it A man who loves readily betrays himself

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: M. de Guiche has not betrayed himself.
children.prevalue: M de Guiche has not betrayed himself

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: My dear sister, you are defending M. de Guiche.
children.prevalue: My dear sister you are defending M de Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: I, indeed! Ah, sire, I only needed a suspicion from yourself to crown my wretchedness.
children.prevalue: I indeed Ah sire I only needed a suspicion from yourself to crown my wretchedness

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: No, madame, no, returned the king, hurriedly; do not distress yourself. Nay, you are weeping. I implore you to calm yourself.
children.prevalue: No madame no returned the king hurriedly do not distress yourself Nay you are weeping I implore you to calm yourself

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: She wept, however, and large tears fell upon her hands; the king took one of her hands in his, and kissed the tears away. She looked at him so sadly and with so much tenderness that he felt his heart giving way under her gaze.
children.prevalue: She wept however and large tears fell upon her hands the king took one of her hands in his and kissed the tears away She looked at him so sadly and with so much tenderness that he felt his heart giving way under her gaze

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: You have no kind of feeling, then, for Guiche? he said, more disturbed than became his character of mediator.
children.prevalue: You have no kind of feeling then for Guiche he said more disturbed than became his character of mediator

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Noneabsolutely none.
children.prevalue: Noneabsolutely none

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Then I can reassure my brother in that respect?
children.prevalue: Then I can reassure my brother in that respect

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Nothing will satisfy him, sire. Do not believe he is jealous. Monsieur has been badly advised by some one, and he is of nervous disposition.
children.prevalue: Nothing will satisfy him sire Do not believe he is jealous Monsieur has been badly advised by some one and he is of nervous disposition

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: He may well be so when you are concerned, said the king.
children.prevalue: He may well be so when you are concerned said the king

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Madame cast down her eyes, and was silent; the king did so likewise, still holding her hand all the while. Their momentary silence seemed to last an age. Madame gently withdrew her hand, and from that moment, she felt her triumph was certain, and that the field of battle was her own.
children.prevalue: Madame cast down her eyes and was silent the king did so likewise still holding her hand all the while Their momentary silence seemed to last an age Madame gently withdrew her hand and from that moment she felt her triumph was certain and that the field of battle was her own

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Monsieur complains, said the king, that you prefer the society of private individuals to his own conversation and society.
children.prevalue: Monsieur complains said the king that you prefer the society of private individuals to his own conversation and society

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: But Monsieur passes his life in looking at his face in the glass, and in plotting all sorts of spiteful things against women with the Chevalier de Lorraine.
children.prevalue: But Monsieur passes his life in looking at his face in the glass and in plotting all sorts of spiteful things against women with the Chevalier de Lorraine

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Oh, you are going somewhat too far.
children.prevalue: Oh you are going somewhat too far

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: I only tell you what is true. Do you observe for yourself, sire, and you will see that I am right.
children.prevalue: I only tell you what is true Do you observe for yourself sire and you will see that I am right

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: I will observe; but, in the meantime, what satisfaction can I give my brother?
children.prevalue: I will observe but in the meantime what satisfaction can I give my brother

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: My departure.
children.prevalue: My departure

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: You repeat that word, exclaimed the king, imprudently, as if, during the last ten minutes, such a change had been produced that Madame would have had all her ideas on the subject thoroughly changed.
children.prevalue: You repeat that word exclaimed the king imprudently as if during the last ten minutes such a change had been produced that Madame would have had all her ideas on the subject thoroughly changed

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Sire, I cannot be happy here any longer, she said. M. de Guiche annoys Monsieur. Will he be sent away, too?
children.prevalue: Sire I cannot be happy here any longer she said M de Guiche annoys Monsieur Will he be sent away too

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: If it be necessary, why not? replied the king, smiling.
children.prevalue: If it be necessary why not replied the king smiling

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Well; and after M. de Guichewhom, by the by, I shall regretI warn you, sire.
children.prevalue: Well and after M de Guichewhom by the by I shall regretI warn you sire

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Ah, you will regret him?
children.prevalue: Ah you will regret him

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Certainly; he is amiable, he has a great friendship for me, and he amuses me.
children.prevalue: Certainly he is amiable he has a great friendship for me and he amuses me

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: If Monsieur were only to hear you, said the king, slightly annoyed, do you know I would not undertake to make it up again between you; nay, I would not even attempt it.
children.prevalue: If Monsieur were only to hear you said the king slightly annoyed do you know I would not undertake to make it up again between you nay I would not even attempt it

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Sire, can you, even now, prevent Monsieur from being jealous of the first person who may approach? I know very well that M. de Guiche is not the first.
children.prevalue: Sire can you even now prevent Monsieur from being jealous of the first person who may approach I know very well that M de Guiche is not the first

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Again I warn you that as a good brother I shall take a dislike to De Guiche.
children.prevalue: Again I warn you that as a good brother I shall take a dislike to De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Ah, sire, do not, I entreat you, adopt either the sympathies or the dislikes of Monsieur. Remain king; better for yourself and for every one else.
children.prevalue: Ah sire do not I entreat you adopt either the sympathies or the dislikes of Monsieur Remain king better for yourself and for every one else

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: You jest charmingly, madame; and I can well understand how the people you attack must adore you.
children.prevalue: You jest charmingly madame and I can well understand how the people you attack must adore you

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: And is that the reason why you, sire, whom I had regarded as my defender, are about to join these who persecute me? said Madame.
children.prevalue: And is that the reason why you sire whom I had regarded as my defender are about to join these who persecute me said Madame

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: I your persecutor! Heaven forbid!
children.prevalue: I your persecutor Heaven forbid

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Then, she continued, languishingly, grant me a favor.
children.prevalue: Then she continued languishingly grant me a favor

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Whatever you wish.
children.prevalue: Whatever you wish

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Let me return to England.
children.prevalue: Let me return to England

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Never, never! exclaimed Louis XIV.
children.prevalue: Never never exclaimed Louis XIV

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: I am a prisoner, then?
children.prevalue: I am a prisoner then

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: In Franceif France is a prisonyes.
children.prevalue: In Franceif France is a prisonyes

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: What must I do, then?
children.prevalue: What must I do then

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: I will tell you. Instead of devoting yourself to friendships which are somewhat unstable, instead of alarming us by your retirement, remain always in our society, do not leave us, let us live as a united family. M. de Guiche is certainly very amiable; but if, at least, we do not possess his wit
children.prevalue: I will tell you Instead of devoting yourself to friendships which are somewhat unstable instead of alarming us by your retirement remain always in our society do not leave us let us live as a united family M de Guiche is certainly very amiable but if at least we do not possess his wit

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Ah, sire, you know very well you are pretending to be modest.
children.prevalue: Ah sire you know very well you are pretending to be modest

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: No, I swear to you. One may be a king, and yet feel that he possesses fewer chances of pleasing than many other gentlemen.
children.prevalue: No I swear to you One may be a king and yet feel that he possesses fewer chances of pleasing than many other gentlemen

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: I am sure, sire, that you do not believe a single word you are saying.
children.prevalue: I am sure sire that you do not believe a single word you are saying

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: The king looked at Madame tenderly, and said, Will you promise me one thing?
children.prevalue: The king looked at Madame tenderly and said Will you promise me one thing

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: What is it?
children.prevalue: What is it

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: That you will no longer waste upon strangers, in your own apartments, the time which you owe us. Shall we make an offensive and defensive alliance against the common enemy?
children.prevalue: That you will no longer waste upon strangers in your own apartments the time which you owe us Shall we make an offensive and defensive alliance against the common enemy

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: An alliance with you, sire?
children.prevalue: An alliance with you sire

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Why not? Are you not a sovereign power?
children.prevalue: Why not Are you not a sovereign power

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: But are you, sire, a reliable ally?
children.prevalue: But are you sire a reliable ally

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: You shall see, madame.
children.prevalue: You shall see madame

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: And when shall this alliance commence?
children.prevalue: And when shall this alliance commence

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: This very day.
children.prevalue: This very day

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: I will draw up the treaty, and you shall sign it.
children.prevalue: I will draw up the treaty and you shall sign it

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Blindly.
children.prevalue: Blindly

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Then, sire, I promise you wonders; you are the star of the court, and when you make your appearance, everything will be resplendent.
children.prevalue: Then sire I promise you wonders you are the star of the court and when you make your appearance everything will be resplendent

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Oh, madame, madame, said Louis XIV., you know well that there is no brilliancy that does not proceed from yourself, and that if I assume the sun as my device, it is only an emblem.
children.prevalue: Oh madame madame said Louis XIV you know well that there is no brilliancy that does not proceed from yourself and that if I assume the sun as my device it is only an emblem

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Sire, you flatter your ally, and you wish to deceive her, said Madame, threatening the king with her finger menacingly raised.
children.prevalue: Sire you flatter your ally and you wish to deceive her said Madame threatening the king with her finger menacingly raised

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: What! you believe I am deceiving you, when I assure you of my affection?
children.prevalue: What you believe I am deceiving you when I assure you of my affection

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: What makes you so suspicious?
children.prevalue: What makes you so suspicious

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: One thing.
children.prevalue: One thing

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: What is it? I shall indeed be unhappy if I do not overcome it.
children.prevalue: What is it I shall indeed be unhappy if I do not overcome it

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: That one thing in question, sire, is not in your power, not even in the power of Heaven.
children.prevalue: That one thing in question sire is not in your power not even in the power of Heaven

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Tell me what it is.
children.prevalue: Tell me what it is

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: The past.
children.prevalue: The past

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: I do not understand, madame, said the king, precisely because he had understood her but too well.
children.prevalue: I do not understand madame said the king precisely because he had understood her but too well

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: The princess took his hand in hers. Sire, she said, I have had the misfortune to displease you for so long a period, that I have almost the right to ask myself today why you were able to accept me as a sisterinlaw.
children.prevalue: The princess took his hand in hers Sire she said I have had the misfortune to displease you for so long a period that I have almost the right to ask myself today why you were able to accept me as a sisterinlaw

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Displease me! You have displeased me?
children.prevalue: Displease me You have displeased me

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Nay, do not deny it, for I remember it well.
children.prevalue: Nay do not deny it for I remember it well

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Our alliance shall date from today, exclaimed the king, with a warmth that was not assumed. You will not think any more of the past, will you? I myself am resolved that I will not. I shall always remember the present; I have it before my eyes; look. And he led the princess before a mirror, in which she saw herself reflected, blushing and beautiful enough to overcome a saint.
children.prevalue: Our alliance shall date from today exclaimed the king with a warmth that was not assumed You will not think any more of the past will you I myself am resolved that I will not I shall always remember the present I have it before my eyes look And he led the princess before a mirror in which she saw herself reflected blushing and beautiful enough to overcome a saint

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: It is all the same, she murmured; it will not be a very worthy alliance.
children.prevalue: It is all the same she murmured it will not be a very worthy alliance

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Must I swear? inquired the king, intoxicated by the voluptuous turn the whole conversation had taken.
children.prevalue: Must I swear inquired the king intoxicated by the voluptuous turn the whole conversation had taken

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Oh, I will not refuse to witness a resounding oath, said Madame; it has always the semblance of security.
children.prevalue: Oh I will not refuse to witness a resounding oath said Madame it has always the semblance of security

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: The king knelt upon a footstool and took Madame's hand. She, with a smile that no painter could ever succeed in depicting, and which a poet might only imagine, gave him both her hands, in which he hid his burning face. Neither of them could utter a syllable. The king felt Madame withdraw her hands, caressing his face while she did so. He rose immediately and left the apartment. The courtiers remarked his heightened color, and concluded that the scene had been a stormy one. The Chevalier de Lorraine, however, hastened to say, Nay, be comforted, gentlemen, his majesty is always pale when he is angry.
children.prevalue: The king knelt upon a footstool and took Madame s hand She with a smile that no painter could ever succeed in depicting and which a poet might only imagine gave him both her hands in which he hid his burning face Neither of them could utter a syllable The king felt Madame withdraw her hands caressing his face while she did so He rose immediately and left the apartment The courtiers remarked his heightened color and concluded that the scene had been a stormy one The Chevalier de Lorraine however hastened to say Nay be comforted gentlemen his majesty is always pale when he is angry

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The king left Madame in a state of agitation it would have been difficult even for himself to have explained. It is impossible, in fact, to depict the secret play of those strange sympathies which, suddenly and apparently without any cause, are excited, after many years passed in the greatest calmness and indifference, by two hearts destined to love each other. Why had Louis formerly disdained, almost hated, Madame? Why did he now find the same woman so beautiful, so captivating? And why, not only were his thoughts occupied about her, but still more, why were they so continuously occupied about her? Why, in fact, had Madame, whose eyes and mind were sought for in another direction, shown during the last week towards the king a semblance of favor which encouraged the belief of still greater regard. It must not be supposed that Louis proposed to himself any plan of seduction; the tie which united Madame to his brother was, or at least, seemed to him, an insuperable barrier; he was even too far removed from that barrier to perceive its existence. But on the downward path of those passions in which the heart rejoices, towards which youth impels us, no one can decide where to stop, not even the man who has in advance calculated all the chances of his own success or another's submission. As far as Madame was concerned, her regard for the king may easily be explained: she was young, a coquette, and ardently fond of admiration. Hers was one of those buoyant, impetuous natures, which upon a theatre would leap over the greatest obstacles to obtain an acknowledgement of applause from the spectators. It was not surprising, then, that, after having been adored by Buckingham, by De Guiche, who was superior to Buckingham, even if it were only from that negative merit, so much appreciated by women, that is to say, noveltyit was not surprising, we say, that the princess should raise her ambition to being admired by the king, who not only was the first person in the kingdom, but was one of the handsomest and cleverest men in Europe. As for the sudden passion with which Louis was inspired for his sisterinlaw, physiology would perhaps supply an explanation by some hackneyed commonplace reasons, and nature by means of her mysterious affinity of characters. Madame had the most beautiful black eyes in the world; Louis, eyes as beautiful, but blue. Madame was laughterloving and unreserved in her manners; Louis, melancholy and diffident. Summoned to meet each other for the first time upon the grounds of interest and common curiosity, these two opposite natures were mutually influenced by the mingling of their reciprocal contradictions of character. Louis, when he returned to his own rooms, acknowledged to himself that Madame was the most attractive woman of his court. Madame, left alone, delightedly thought that she had made a great impression on the king. This feeling with her must remain passive, whilst the king could not but act with all the natural vehemence of the heated fancies of a young man, and of a young man who has but to express a wish to see his wish fulfilled.

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The first thing the king did was to announce to Monsieur that everything was quietly arranged; that Madame had the greatest respect, the sincerest affection for him; but that she was of a proud, impetuous character, and that her susceptibilities were so acute as to require very careful management.
children.prevalue: The first thing the king did was to announce to Monsieur that everything was quietly arranged that Madame had the greatest respect the sincerest affection for him but that she was of a proud impetuous character and that her susceptibilities were so acute as to require very careful management

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Monsieur replied in the reticent tone of voice he generally adopted with his brother, that he could not very well understand the susceptibilities of a woman whose conduct might, in his opinion, expose her to censorious remarks, and that if any one had a right to feel wounded, it was he, Monsieur himself. To this the king replied in a quick tone of voice, which showed the interest he took in his sisterinlaw, Thank Heaven, Madame is above censure.
children.prevalue: Monsieur replied in the reticent tone of voice he generally adopted with his brother that he could not very well understand the susceptibilities of a woman whose conduct might in his opinion expose her to censorious remarks and that if any one had a right to feel wounded it was he Monsieur himself To this the king replied in a quick tone of voice which showed the interest he took in his sisterinlaw Thank Heaven Madame is above censure

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The censure of others, certainly, I admit, said Monsieur; but not above mine, I presume.
children.prevalue: The censure of others certainly I admit said Monsieur but not above mine I presume

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Well, said the king, all I have to say, Philip, is that Madame's conduct does not deserve your censure. She certainly is heedless and singular, but professes the best feelings. The English character is not always well understood in France, and the liberty of English manners sometimes surprises those who do not know the extent to which this liberty is enriched by innocence.
children.prevalue: Well said the king all I have to say Philip is that Madame s conduct does not deserve your censure She certainly is heedless and singular but professes the best feelings The English character is not always well understood in France and the liberty of English manners sometimes surprises those who do not know the extent to which this liberty is enriched by innocence

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Ah! said Monsieur, more and more piqued, from the very moment that your majesty absolves my wife, whom I accuse, my wife is not guilty, and I have nothing more to say.
children.prevalue: Ah said Monsieur more and more piqued from the very moment that your majesty absolves my wife whom I accuse my wife is not guilty and I have nothing more to say

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Philip, replied the king hastily, for he felt the voice of conscience murmuring softly in his heart, that Monsieur was not altogether wrong, what I have done, and what I have said, has been only for your happiness. I was told that you complained of a want of confidence and attention on Madame's part, and I did not wish your uneasiness to be prolonged. It is part of my duty to watch over your household, as over that of the humblest of my subjects. I have satisfied myself, therefore, with the sincerest pleasure, that your apprehensions have no foundation.
children.prevalue: Philip replied the king hastily for he felt the voice of conscience murmuring softly in his heart that Monsieur was not altogether wrong what I have done and what I have said has been only for your happiness I was told that you complained of a want of confidence and attention on Madame s part and I did not wish your uneasiness to be prolonged It is part of my duty to watch over your household as over that of the humblest of my subjects I have satisfied myself therefore with the sincerest pleasure that your apprehensions have no foundation

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: And, continued Monsieur, in an interrogative tone of voice, and fixing his eyes upon his brother, what your majesty has discovered for Madame and I bow myself to your superior judgmenthave you verified for those who have been the cause of the scandal of which I complain?
children.prevalue: And continued Monsieur in an interrogative tone of voice and fixing his eyes upon his brother what your majesty has discovered for Madame and I bow myself to your superior judgmenthave you verified for those who have been the cause of the scandal of which I complain

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: You are right, Philip, said the king; I will reserve that point for future consideration.
children.prevalue: You are right Philip said the king I will reserve that point for future consideration

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: These words comprised an order as well as a consolation; the prince felt it to be so, and withdrew.
children.prevalue: These words comprised an order as well as a consolation the prince felt it to be so and withdrew

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: As for Louis, he went to seek his mother, for he felt that he had need of a more complete absolution than that he had just received from his brother. Anne of Austria did not entertain for M. de Guiche the same reasons for indulgence she had had for Buckingham. She perceived, at the very first words he pronounced, that Louis was not disposed to be severe.
children.prevalue: As for Louis he went to seek his mother for he felt that he had need of a more complete absolution than that he had just received from his brother Anne of Austria did not entertain for M de Guiche the same reasons for indulgence she had had for Buckingham She perceived at the very first words he pronounced that Louis was not disposed to be severe

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: To appear in a contradictory humor was one of the stratagems of the good queen, in order to succeed in ascertaining the truth. But Louis was no longer in his apprenticeship; already for more than a year past he had been king, and during that year he had learned how to dissemble. Listening to Anne of Austria, in order to permit her to disclose her own thoughts, testifying his approval only by look and gesture, he became convinced, from certain piercing glances, and from certain skillful insinuations, that the queen, so clearsighted in matters of gallantry, had, if not guessed, at least suspected, his weakness for Madame. Of all his auxiliaries, Anne of Austria would be the most important to secure; of all his enemies, Anne of Austria would prove most dangerous. Louis, therefore, changed his maneuvers. He complained of Madame, absolved Monsieur, listened to what his mother had to say of De Guiche, as he had previously listened to what she had to say of Buckingham, and then, when he saw that she thought she had gained a complete victory over him, he left her.
children.prevalue: To appear in a contradictory humor was one of the stratagems of the good queen in order to succeed in ascertaining the truth But Louis was no longer in his apprenticeship already for more than a year past he had been king and during that year he had learned how to dissemble Listening to Anne of Austria in order to permit her to disclose her own thoughts testifying his approval only by look and gesture he became convinced from certain piercing glances and from certain skillful insinuations that the queen so clearsighted in matters of gallantry had if not guessed at least suspected his weakness for Madame Of all his auxiliaries Anne of Austria would be the most important to secure of all his enemies Anne of Austria would prove most dangerous Louis therefore changed his maneuvers He complained of Madame absolved Monsieur listened to what his mother had to say of De Guiche as he had previously listened to what she had to say of Buckingham and then when he saw that she thought she had gained a complete victory over him he left her

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The whole of the court, that is to say, all the favorites and more intimate associates, and they were numerous, since there were already five masters, were assembled in the evening for the repetition of the ballet. This interval had been occupied by poor De Guiche in receiving visits; among the number was one which he hoped and feared nearly to an equal extent. It was that of the Chevalier de Lorraine. About three o'clock in the afternoon the chevalier entered De Guiche's rooms. His looks were of the most reassuring character. Monsieur, said he to De Guiche, was in an excellent humor, and no none could say that the slightest cloud had passed across the conjugal sky. Besides, Monsieur was not one to bear illfeeling.
children.prevalue: The whole of the court that is to say all the favorites and more intimate associates and they were numerous since there were already five masters were assembled in the evening for the repetition of the ballet This interval had been occupied by poor De Guiche in receiving visits among the number was one which he hoped and feared nearly to an equal extent It was that of the Chevalier de Lorraine About three o clock in the afternoon the chevalier entered De Guiche s rooms His looks were of the most reassuring character Monsieur said he to De Guiche was in an excellent humor and no none could say that the slightest cloud had passed across the conjugal sky Besides Monsieur was not one to bear illfeeling

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: For a long time past, during his residence at the court, the Chevalier de Lorraine had decided, that of Louis XIII.'s two sons, Monsieur was the one who had inherited the father's characteran uncertain, irresolute character; impulsively good, indifferently disposed at bottom; but certainly a cipher for his friends. He especially cheered De Guiche, by pointing out to him that Madame would, before long, succeed in governing her husband, and that, consequently, that man would govern Monsieur who should succeed in influencing Madame.
children.prevalue: For a long time past during his residence at the court the Chevalier de Lorraine had decided that of Louis XIII s two sons Monsieur was the one who had inherited the father s characteran uncertain irresolute character impulsively good indifferently disposed at bottom but certainly a cipher for his friends He especially cheered De Guiche by pointing out to him that Madame would before long succeed in governing her husband and that consequently that man would govern Monsieur who should succeed in influencing Madame

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: To this, De Guiche full of mistrust and presence of mind, replied, Yes, chevalier; but I believe Madame to be a very dangerous person.
children.prevalue: To this De Guiche full of mistrust and presence of mind replied Yes chevalier but I believe Madame to be a very dangerous person

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: In what respect?
children.prevalue: In what respect

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: She has perceived that Monsieur is not very passionately inclined towards women.
children.prevalue: She has perceived that Monsieur is not very passionately inclined towards women

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Quite true, said the Chevalier de Lorraine, laughing.
children.prevalue: Quite true said the Chevalier de Lorraine laughing

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: In that case, Madame will choose the first one who approaches, in order to make him the object of her preference, and to bring back her husband by jealousy.
children.prevalue: In that case Madame will choose the first one who approaches in order to make him the object of her preference and to bring back her husband by jealousy

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Deep! deep! exclaimed the chevalier.
children.prevalue: Deep deep exclaimed the chevalier

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: But true, replied De Guiche.
children.prevalue: But true replied De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Neither the one nor the other expressed his real thought. De Guiche, at the very moment he thus attacked Madame's character, mentally asked her forgiveness from the bottom of his heart. The chevalier, while admiring De Guiche's penetration, was leading him, blindfolded, to the brink of the precipice. De Guiche then questioned him more directly upon the effect produced by the scene of the morning, and upon the still more serious effect produced by the scene at dinner.
children.prevalue: Neither the one nor the other expressed his real thought De Guiche at the very moment he thus attacked Madame s character mentally asked her forgiveness from the bottom of his heart The chevalier while admiring De Guiche s penetration was leading him blindfolded to the brink of the precipice De Guiche then questioned him more directly upon the effect produced by the scene of the morning and upon the still more serious effect produced by the scene at dinner

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: But I have already told you they are all laughing at it, replied the Chevalier de Lorraine, and Monsieur himself at the head of them.
children.prevalue: But I have already told you they are all laughing at it replied the Chevalier de Lorraine and Monsieur himself at the head of them

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Yet, hazarded De Guiche, I have heard that the king paid Madame a visit.
children.prevalue: Yet hazarded De Guiche I have heard that the king paid Madame a visit

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Yes, precisely so. Madame was the only one who did not laugh, and the king went to her in order to make her laugh, too.
children.prevalue: Yes precisely so Madame was the only one who did not laugh and the king went to her in order to make her laugh too

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: So that
children.prevalue: So that

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: So that nothing is altered in the arrangements of the day, said the chevalier.
children.prevalue: So that nothing is altered in the arrangements of the day said the chevalier

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: And is there a repetition of the ballet this evening?
children.prevalue: And is there a repetition of the ballet this evening

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Are you sure?
children.prevalue: Are you sure

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Quite, returned the chevalier.
children.prevalue: Quite returned the chevalier

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: At this moment of the conversation between the two young men, Raoul entered, looking full of anxiety. As soon as the chevalier, who had a secret dislike for him, as for every other noble character, perceived him enter, he rose from his seat.
children.prevalue: At this moment of the conversation between the two young men Raoul entered looking full of anxiety As soon as the chevalier who had a secret dislike for him as for every other noble character perceived him enter he rose from his seat

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: What do you advise me to do, then? inquired De Guiche of the chevalier.
children.prevalue: What do you advise me to do then inquired De Guiche of the chevalier

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: I advise you to go to sleep in perfect tranquillity, my dear count.
children.prevalue: I advise you to go to sleep in perfect tranquillity my dear count

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: And my advice, De Guiche, said Raoul, is the very opposite.
children.prevalue: And my advice De Guiche said Raoul is the very opposite

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: What is that?
children.prevalue: What is that

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: To mount your horse and set off at once for one of your estates; on your arrival, follow the chevalier's advice, if you like; and, what is more, you can sleep there as long and as tranquilly as you please.
children.prevalue: To mount your horse and set off at once for one of your estates on your arrival follow the chevalier s advice if you like and what is more you can sleep there as long and as tranquilly as you please

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: What! set off! exclaimed the chevalier, feigning surprise; why should De Guiche set off?
children.prevalue: What set off exclaimed the chevalier feigning surprise why should De Guiche set off

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Because, and you cannot be ignorant of ityou particularly so because every one is talking about the scene which has passed between Monsieur and De Guiche.
children.prevalue: Because and you cannot be ignorant of ityou particularly so because every one is talking about the scene which has passed between Monsieur and De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: De Guiche turned pale.
children.prevalue: De Guiche turned pale

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Not at all, replied the chevalier, not at all; and you have been wrongly informed, M. de Bragelonne.
children.prevalue: Not at all replied the chevalier not at all and you have been wrongly informed M de Bragelonne

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: I have been perfectly well informed, on the contrary, monsieur, replied Raoul, and the advice I give De Guiche is that of a friend.
children.prevalue: I have been perfectly well informed on the contrary monsieur replied Raoul and the advice I give De Guiche is that of a friend

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: During this discussion, De Guiche, somewhat shaken, looked alternately first at one and then at the other of his advisers. He inwardly felt that a game, important in all its consequences for the rest of his life, was being played at that moment.
children.prevalue: During this discussion De Guiche somewhat shaken looked alternately first at one and then at the other of his advisers He inwardly felt that a game important in all its consequences for the rest of his life was being played at that moment

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Is it not fact, said the chevalier, putting the question to the count himself, is it not fact, De Guiche, that the scene was not so tempestuous as the Vicomte de Bragelonne seems to think, and who, moreover, was not himself there?
children.prevalue: Is it not fact said the chevalier putting the question to the count himself is it not fact De Guiche that the scene was not so tempestuous as the Vicomte de Bragelonne seems to think and who moreover was not himself there

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Whether tempestuous or not, persisted Raoul, it is not precisely of the scene itself that I am speaking, but of the consequences that may ensue. I know that Monsieur has threatened, I know that Madame has been in tears.
children.prevalue: Whether tempestuous or not persisted Raoul it is not precisely of the scene itself that I am speaking but of the consequences that may ensue I know that Monsieur has threatened I know that Madame has been in tears

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Madame in tears! exclaimed De Guiche, imprudently clasping his hands.
children.prevalue: Madame in tears exclaimed De Guiche imprudently clasping his hands

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Ah! said the chevalier, laughing, this is indeed a circumstance I was not acquainted with. You are decidedly better informed than I am, Monsieur de Bragelonne.
children.prevalue: Ah said the chevalier laughing this is indeed a circumstance I was not acquainted with You are decidedly better informed than I am Monsieur de Bragelonne

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: And it is because I am better informed than yourself, chevalier, that I insist upon De Guiche leaving.
children.prevalue: And it is because I am better informed than yourself chevalier that I insist upon De Guiche leaving

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: No, no; I regret to differ from you, vicomte; but his departure is unnecessary. Why, indeed, should he leave? tell us why.
children.prevalue: No no I regret to differ from you vicomte but his departure is unnecessary Why indeed should he leave tell us why

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: The king!
children.prevalue: The king

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: The king! exclaimed De Guiche.
children.prevalue: The king exclaimed De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Yes; I tell you the king has taken up the affair.
children.prevalue: Yes I tell you the king has taken up the affair

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Bah! said the chevalier, the king likes De Guiche, and particularly his father; reflect, that, if the count were to leave, it would be an admission that he had done something which merited rebuke.
children.prevalue: Bah said the chevalier the king likes De Guiche and particularly his father reflect that if the count were to leave it would be an admission that he had done something which merited rebuke

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Why so?
children.prevalue: Why so

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: No doubt of it; when one runs away, it is either from guilt or fear.
children.prevalue: No doubt of it when one runs away it is either from guilt or fear

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Sometimes, because a man is offended; often because he is wrongfully accused, said Bragelonne. We will assign as a reason for his departure, that he feels hurt and injurednothing will be easier; we will say that we both did our utmost to keep him, and you, at least, will not be speaking otherwise than the truth. Come, De Guiche, you are innocent, and, being so, the scene of today must have wounded you. So set off.
children.prevalue: Sometimes because a man is offended often because he is wrongfully accused said Bragelonne We will assign as a reason for his departure that he feels hurt and injurednothing will be easier we will say that we both did our utmost to keep him and you at least will not be speaking otherwise than the truth Come De Guiche you are innocent and being so the scene of today must have wounded you So set off

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: No, De Guiche, remain where you are, said the chevalier; precisely as M. de Bragelonne has put it, because you are innocent. Once more, forgive me, vicomte; but my opinion is the very opposite to your own.
children.prevalue: No De Guiche remain where you are said the chevalier precisely as M de Bragelonne has put it because you are innocent Once more forgive me vicomte but my opinion is the very opposite to your own

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: And you are at perfect liberty to maintain it, monsieur; but be assured that the exile which De Guiche will voluntarily impose upon himself will be of short duration. He can terminate it whenever he pleases, and returning from his voluntary exile, he will meet with smiles from all lips; while, on the contrary, the anger of the king may now draw down a storm upon his head, the end of which no one can foresee.
children.prevalue: And you are at perfect liberty to maintain it monsieur but be assured that the exile which De Guiche will voluntarily impose upon himself will be of short duration He can terminate it whenever he pleases and returning from his voluntary exile he will meet with smiles from all lips while on the contrary the anger of the king may now draw down a storm upon his head the end of which no one can foresee

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: The chevalier smiled, and muttered to himself, That is the very thing I wish. And at the same time he shrugged his shoulders, a movement which did not escape the count, who dreaded, if he quitted the court, to seem to yield to a feeling of fear.
children.prevalue: The chevalier smiled and muttered to himself That is the very thing I wish And at the same time he shrugged his shoulders a movement which did not escape the count who dreaded if he quitted the court to seem to yield to a feeling of fear

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: No, no; I have decided, Bragelonne; I stay.
children.prevalue: No no I have decided Bragelonne I stay

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: I prophesy, then, said Raoul, sadly, that misfortune will befall you, De Guiche.
children.prevalue: I prophesy then said Raoul sadly that misfortune will befall you De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I, too, am a prophet, but not a prophet of evil; on the contrary, count, I say to you, 'remain.'
children.prevalue: I too am a prophet but not a prophet of evil on the contrary count I say to you remain

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Are you sure, inquired De Guiche, that the repetition of the ballet still takes place?
children.prevalue: Are you sure inquired De Guiche that the repetition of the ballet still takes place

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Quite sure.
children.prevalue: Quite sure

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Well, you see, Raoul, continued De Guiche, endeavoring to smile, you see, the court is not so very sorrowful, or so readily disposed for internal dissensions, when dancing is carried on with such assiduity. Come, acknowledge that, said the count to Raoul, who shook his head, saying, I have nothing to add.
children.prevalue: Well you see Raoul continued De Guiche endeavoring to smile you see the court is not so very sorrowful or so readily disposed for internal dissensions when dancing is carried on with such assiduity Come acknowledge that said the count to Raoul who shook his head saying I have nothing to add

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: But, inquired the chevalier, curious to learn whence Raoul had obtained his information, the exactitude of which he was inwardly forced to admit, since you say you are well informed, vicomte, how can you be better informed than myself, who am one of the prince's most intimate companions?
children.prevalue: But inquired the chevalier curious to learn whence Raoul had obtained his information the exactitude of which he was inwardly forced to admit since you say you are well informed vicomte how can you be better informed than myself who am one of the prince s most intimate companions

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: To such a declaration I submit. You certainly ought to be perfectly well informed, I admit; and, as a man of honor is incapable of saying anything but what he knows to be true, or of speaking otherwise than what he thinks, I will say no more, but confess myself defeated, and leave you in possession of the field of battle.
children.prevalue: To such a declaration I submit You certainly ought to be perfectly well informed I admit and as a man of honor is incapable of saying anything but what he knows to be true or of speaking otherwise than what he thinks I will say no more but confess myself defeated and leave you in possession of the field of battle

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Whereupon Raoul, who now seemed only to care to be left quiet, threw himself upon a couch, whilst the count summoned his servants to aid him in dressing. The chevalier, finding that time was passing away, wished to leave; but he feared, too, that Raoul, left alone with De Guiche, might yet influence him to change his mind. He therefore made use of his last resource.

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Madame, he said, will be brilliant; she appears today in her costume of Pomona.
children.prevalue: Madame he said will be brilliant she appears today in her costume of Pomona

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Yes, that is so, exclaimed the count.
children.prevalue: Yes that is so exclaimed the count

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: And she has just given directions in consequence, continued the chevalier. You know, Monsieur de Bragelonne, that the king is to appear as Spring.
children.prevalue: And she has just given directions in consequence continued the chevalier You know Monsieur de Bragelonne that the king is to appear as Spring

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: It will be admirable, said De Guiche; and that is a better reason for me to remain than any you have yet given, because I am to appear as Autumn, and shall have to dance with Madame. I cannot absent myself without the king's orders, since my departure would interrupt the ballet.
children.prevalue: It will be admirable said De Guiche and that is a better reason for me to remain than any you have yet given because I am to appear as Autumn and shall have to dance with Madame I cannot absent myself without the king s orders since my departure would interrupt the ballet

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: I, said the chevalier, am to be only a simple egypan; true, it is, I am a bad dancer, and my legs are not well made. Gentlemen, adieu. Do not forget the basket of fruit, which you are to offer to Pomona, count.
children.prevalue: I said the chevalier am to be only a simple egypan true it is I am a bad dancer and my legs are not well made Gentlemen adieu Do not forget the basket of fruit which you are to offer to Pomona count

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Rest assured, said De Guiche, delightedly, I shall forget nothing.
children.prevalue: Rest assured said De Guiche delightedly I shall forget nothing

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: I am now quite certain that he will remain, murmured the Chevalier de Lorraine to himself.
children.prevalue: I am now quite certain that he will remain murmured the Chevalier de Lorraine to himself

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Raoul, when the chevalier had left, did not even attempt to dissuade his friend, for he felt that it would be trouble thrown away; he merely observed to the comte, in his melancholy and melodious voice, You are embarking in a most dangerous enterprise. I know you well; you go to extremes in everything, and the lady you love does so, too. Admitting for an instant that she should at last love you

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Oh, never! exclaimed De Guiche.
children.prevalue: Oh never exclaimed De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Why do you say never?
children.prevalue: Why do you say never

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Because it would be a great misfortune for both of us.
children.prevalue: Because it would be a great misfortune for both of us

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: In that case, instead of regarding you simply imprudent, I cannot but consider you absolutely mad.
children.prevalue: In that case instead of regarding you simply imprudent I cannot but consider you absolutely mad

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Why?
children.prevalue: Why

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Are you perfectly suremind, answer me franklythat you do not wish her whom you love to make any sacrifice for you?
children.prevalue: Are you perfectly suremind answer me franklythat you do not wish her whom you love to make any sacrifice for you

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Yes, yes; quite sure.
children.prevalue: Yes yes quite sure

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Love her, then, at a distance.
children.prevalue: Love her then at a distance

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: What! at a distance?
children.prevalue: What at a distance

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Certainly; what matters being present or absent, since you expect nothing from her? Love her portrait, a memento.
children.prevalue: Certainly what matters being present or absent since you expect nothing from her Love her portrait a memento

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Raoul!
children.prevalue: Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Love is a shadow, an illusion, a chimera; be devoted to the affection itself, in giving a name to your ideality.
children.prevalue: Love is a shadow an illusion a chimera be devoted to the affection itself in giving a name to your ideality

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Ah!
children.prevalue: Ah

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: You turn away; your servants approach. I will say no more. In good or bad fortune, De Guiche, depend on me.
children.prevalue: You turn away your servants approach I will say no more In good or bad fortune De Guiche depend on me

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Indeed I shall do so.
children.prevalue: Indeed I shall do so

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Very well; that is all I had to say to you. Spare no pains in your person, De Guiche, and look your very best. Adieu.
children.prevalue: Very well that is all I had to say to you Spare no pains in your person De Guiche and look your very best Adieu

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: You will not be present, then, at the ballet, vicomte?
children.prevalue: You will not be present then at the ballet vicomte

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: No; I shall have a visit to pay in town. Farewell, De Guiche.
children.prevalue: No I shall have a visit to pay in town Farewell De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: The reception was to take place in the king's apartments. In the first place, there were the queens, then Madame, and a few ladies of the court, who had been carefully selected. A great number of courtiers, also selected, occupied the time, before the dancing commenced, in conversing, as people knew how to converse in those times. None of the ladies who had received invitations appeared in the costumes of the fete, as the Chevalier de Lorraine had predicted, but many conversations took place about the rich and ingenious toilettes designed by different painters for the ballet of The DemiGods, for thus were termed the kings and queens of which Fontainebleau was about to become the Pantheon. Monsieur arrived, holding in his hand a drawing representing his character; he looked somewhat anxious; he bowed courteously to the young queen and his mother, but saluted Madame almost cavalierly. His notice of her and his coldness of manner were observed by all. M. de Guiche indemnified the princess by a look of passionate devotion, and it must be admitted that Madame, as she raised her eyes, returned it to him with interest. It is unquestionable that De Guiche had never looked so handsome, for Madame's glance had its customary effect of lighting up the features of the son of the Marshal de Gramont. The king's sisterinlaw felt a storm mustering above her head; she felt, too, that during the whole of the day, so fruitful in future events, she had acted unjustly, if not treasonably, towards one who loved her with such a depth of devotion. In her eyes the moment seemed to have arrived for an acknowledgement to the poor victim of the injustice of the morning. Her heart spoke, and murmured the name of De Guiche; the count was sincerely pitied and accordingly gained the victory over all others. Neither Monsieur, nor the king, nor the Duke of Buckingham, was any longer thought of; De Guiche at that moment reigned without a rival. But although Monsieur also looked very handsome, still he could not be compared to the count. It is well knownindeed all women say sothat a wide difference invariably exists between the good looks of a lover and those of a husband. Besides, in the present case, after Monsieur had left, and after the courteous and affectionate recognition of the young queen and of the queenmother, and the careless and indifferent notice of Madame, which all the courtiers had remarked; all these motives gave the lover the advantage over the husband. Monsieur was too great a personage to notice these details. Nothing is so certain as a well settled idea of superiority to prove the inferiority of the man who has that opinion of himself. The king arrived. Every one looked for what might possibly happen in the glance, which began to bestir the world, like the brow of Jupiter Tonans. Louis had none of his brother's gloominess, but was perfectly radiant. Having examined the greater part of the drawings which were displayed for his inspection on every side, he gave his opinion or made his remarks upon them, and in this manner rendered some happy and others wretched by a single word. Suddenly his glance, which was smilingly directed towards Madame, detected the slight correspondence established between the princess and the count. He bit his lips, but when he opened them again to utter a few commonplace remarks, he said, advancing towards the queens:
