children.value: My note surprised you?
children.prevalue: My note surprised you

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Terrified me rather. But what I have to tell you is more important.
children.prevalue: Terrified me rather But what I have to tell you is more important

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: It cannot be, sire. Do you know that Monsieur refuses to see me?
children.prevalue: It cannot be sire Do you know that Monsieur refuses to see me

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Why so?
children.prevalue: Why so

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Can you not guess why?
children.prevalue: Can you not guess why

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Ah, Madame! in that case we have both the same thing to say to each other.
children.prevalue: Ah Madame in that case we have both the same thing to say to each other

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: What has happened to you, then?
children.prevalue: What has happened to you then

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: You wish me to begin?
children.prevalue: You wish me to begin

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Yes, for I have told you all.
children.prevalue: Yes for I have told you all

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Well, then, as soon as I returned, I found my mother waiting for me, and she led me away to her own apartments.
children.prevalue: Well then as soon as I returned I found my mother waiting for me and she led me away to her own apartments

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: The queenmother? said Madame, with some anxiety, the matter is serious then.
children.prevalue: The queenmother said Madame with some anxiety the matter is serious then

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Indeed it is, for she told me... but, in the first place, allow me to preface what I have to say with one remark. Has Monsieur ever spoken to you about me?
children.prevalue: Indeed it is for she told me but in the first place allow me to preface what I have to say with one remark Has Monsieur ever spoken to you about me

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Often.
children.prevalue: Often

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Has he ever spoken to you about his jealousy?
children.prevalue: Has he ever spoken to you about his jealousy

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: More frequently still.
children.prevalue: More frequently still

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Of his jealousy of me?
children.prevalue: Of his jealousy of me

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: No, but of the Duke of Buckingham and De Guiche.
children.prevalue: No but of the Duke of Buckingham and De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Well, Madame, Monsieur's present idea is a jealousy of myself.
children.prevalue: Well Madame Monsieur s present idea is a jealousy of myself

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Really, replied the princess, smiling archly.
children.prevalue: Really replied the princess smiling archly

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: And it really seems to me, continued the king, that we have never given any ground
children.prevalue: And it really seems to me continued the king that we have never given any ground

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Never! at least I have not. But who told you that Monsieur was jealous?
children.prevalue: Never at least I have not But who told you that Monsieur was jealous

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: My mother represented to me that Monsieur entered her apartments like a madman, that he uttered a thousand complaints against you, andforgive me for saying itagainst your coquetry. It appears that Monsieur indulges in injustice, too.
children.prevalue: My mother represented to me that Monsieur entered her apartments like a madman that he uttered a thousand complaints against you andforgive me for saying itagainst your coquetry It appears that Monsieur indulges in injustice too

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: You are very kind, sire.
children.prevalue: You are very kind sire

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: My mother reassured him; but he pretended that people reassure him too often, and that he had had quite enough of it.
children.prevalue: My mother reassured him but he pretended that people reassure him too often and that he had had quite enough of it

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Would it not be better for him not to make himself uneasy in any way?
children.prevalue: Would it not be better for him not to make himself uneasy in any way

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: The very thing I said.
children.prevalue: The very thing I said

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Confess, sire, that the world is very wicked. Is it possible that a brother and sister cannot converse together, or take pleasure in each other's company, without giving rise to remarks and suspicions? For indeed, sire, we are doing no harm, and have no intention of doing any. And she looked at the king with that proud yet provoking glance that kindles desire in the coldest and wisest of men.
children.prevalue: Confess sire that the world is very wicked Is it possible that a brother and sister cannot converse together or take pleasure in each other s company without giving rise to remarks and suspicions For indeed sire we are doing no harm and have no intention of doing any And she looked at the king with that proud yet provoking glance that kindles desire in the coldest and wisest of men

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: No! sighed the king, that is true.
children.prevalue: No sighed the king that is true

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: You know very well, sire, that if it were to continue, I should be obliged to make a disturbance. Do you decide upon our conduct, and say whether it has, or has not, been perfectly correct.
children.prevalue: You know very well sire that if it were to continue I should be obliged to make a disturbance Do you decide upon our conduct and say whether it has or has not been perfectly correct

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Oh, certainlyperfectly correct.
children.prevalue: Oh certainlyperfectly correct

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Often alone together,for we delight in the same things,we might possibly be led away into error, but have we been? I regard you as a brother, and nothing more.
children.prevalue: Often alone together for we delight in the same things we might possibly be led away into error but have we been I regard you as a brother and nothing more

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The king frowned. She continued:
children.prevalue: The king frowned She continued

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Your hand, which often meets my own, does not excite in me that agitation and emotion which is the case with those who love each other, for instance
children.prevalue: Your hand which often meets my own does not excite in me that agitation and emotion which is the case with those who love each other for instance

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Enough, said the king, enough, I entreat you. You have no pityyou are killing me.
children.prevalue: Enough said the king enough I entreat you You have no pityyou are killing me

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: What is the matter?
children.prevalue: What is the matter

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: In fact, then, you distinctly say you experience nothing when near me.
children.prevalue: In fact then you distinctly say you experience nothing when near me

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Oh, sire! I don't say thatmy affection
children.prevalue: Oh sire I don t say thatmy affection

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Enough, Henrietta, I again entreat you. If you believe me to be marble, as you are, undeceive yourself.
children.prevalue: Enough Henrietta I again entreat you If you believe me to be marble as you are undeceive yourself

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: I do not understand you, sire.
children.prevalue: I do not understand you sire

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Very well, said the king, casting down his eyes. And so our meetings, the pressure of each other's hand, the looks we have exchangedYes, yes; you are right, and I understand your meaning, and he buried his face in his hands.
children.prevalue: Very well said the king casting down his eyes And so our meetings the pressure of each other s hand the looks we have exchangedYes yes you are right and I understand your meaning and he buried his face in his hands

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Take care, sire, said Madame, hurriedly, Monsieur de SaintAignan is looking at you.
children.prevalue: Take care sire said Madame hurriedly Monsieur de SaintAignan is looking at you

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Of course, said Louis, angrily; never even the shadow of liberty! never any sincerity in my intercourse with any one! I imagine I have found a friend, who is nothing but a spy; a dearer friend, who is only asister!
children.prevalue: Of course said Louis angrily never even the shadow of liberty never any sincerity in my intercourse with any one I imagine I have found a friend who is nothing but a spy a dearer friend who is only asister

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Madame was silent, and cast down her eyes.
children.prevalue: Madame was silent and cast down her eyes

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: My husband is jealous, she murmured, in a tone of which nothing could equal its sweetness and charm.
children.prevalue: My husband is jealous she murmured in a tone of which nothing could equal its sweetness and charm

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: You are right, exclaimed the king, suddenly.
children.prevalue: You are right exclaimed the king suddenly

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: You see, she said, looking at him in a manner that set his heart on fire, you are free, you are not suspected, the peace of your house is not disturbed.
children.prevalue: You see she said looking at him in a manner that set his heart on fire you are free you are not suspected the peace of your house is not disturbed

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Alas, said the king, as yet you know nothing, for the queen is jealous.
children.prevalue: Alas said the king as yet you know nothing for the queen is jealous

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Maria Theresa!
children.prevalue: Maria Theresa

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Stark mad with jealousy! Monsieur's jealousy arises from hers; she was weeping and complaining to my mother, and was reproaching us for those bathing parties, which have made me so happy.
children.prevalue: Stark mad with jealousy Monsieur s jealousy arises from hers she was weeping and complaining to my mother and was reproaching us for those bathing parties which have made me so happy

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: And me too, answered Madame, by a look.
children.prevalue: And me too answered Madame by a look

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: When, suddenly, continued the king, Monsieur, who was listening, heard the word 'banos,' which the queen pronounced with some degree of bitterness, that awakened his attention; he entered the room, looking quite wild, broke into the conversation, and began to quarrel with my mother so bitterly that she was obliged to leave him; so that, while you have a jealous husband to deal with, I shall have perpetually present before me a specter of jealousy with swollen eyes, a cadaverous face, and sinister looks.
children.prevalue: When suddenly continued the king Monsieur who was listening heard the word banos which the queen pronounced with some degree of bitterness that awakened his attention he entered the room looking quite wild broke into the conversation and began to quarrel with my mother so bitterly that she was obliged to leave him so that while you have a jealous husband to deal with I shall have perpetually present before me a specter of jealousy with swollen eyes a cadaverous face and sinister looks

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Poor king, murmured Madame, as she lightly touched the king's hand. He retained her hand in his, and in order to press it without exciting suspicion in the spectators, who were not so much taken up with the butterflies that they could not occupy themselves about other matters, and who perceived clearly enough that there was some mystery in the king's and Madame's conversation, Louis placed the dying butterfly before his sisterinlaw, and bent over it as if to count the thousand eyes of its wings, or the particles of golden dust which covered it. Neither of them spoke; however, their hair mingled, their breaths united, and their hands feverishly throbbed in each other's grasp. Five minutes passed in this manner.
children.prevalue: Poor king murmured Madame as she lightly touched the king s hand He retained her hand in his and in order to press it without exciting suspicion in the spectators who were not so much taken up with the butterflies that they could not occupy themselves about other matters and who perceived clearly enough that there was some mystery in the king s and Madame s conversation Louis placed the dying butterfly before his sisterinlaw and bent over it as if to count the thousand eyes of its wings or the particles of golden dust which covered it Neither of them spoke however their hair mingled their breaths united and their hands feverishly throbbed in each other s grasp Five minutes passed in this manner

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The two young people remained for a moment with their heads bent down, bowed, as it were, beneath the double thought of the love which was springing up in their hearts, and which gives birth to so many happy fancies in the imaginations of twenty years of age. Henrietta gave a side glance, from time to time, at the king. Hers was one of those finelyorganized natures capable of looking inwardly at itself, as well as at others at the same moment. She perceived Love lying at the bottom of Louis's heart, as a skillful diver sees a pearl at the bottom of the sea. She knew Louis was hesitating, if not in doubt, and that his indolent or timid heart required aid and encouragement. And so? she said, interrogatively, breaking the silence.
children.prevalue: The two young people remained for a moment with their heads bent down bowed as it were beneath the double thought of the love which was springing up in their hearts and which gives birth to so many happy fancies in the imaginations of twenty years of age Henrietta gave a side glance from time to time at the king Hers was one of those finelyorganized natures capable of looking inwardly at itself as well as at others at the same moment She perceived Love lying at the bottom of Louis s heart as a skillful diver sees a pearl at the bottom of the sea She knew Louis was hesitating if not in doubt and that his indolent or timid heart required aid and encouragement And so she said interrogatively breaking the silence

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: What do you mean? inquired Louis, after a moment's pause.
children.prevalue: What do you mean inquired Louis after a moment s pause

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: I mean, that I shall be obliged to return to the resolution I had formed.
children.prevalue: I mean that I shall be obliged to return to the resolution I had formed

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: To what resolution?
children.prevalue: To what resolution

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: To that which I have already submitted to your majesty.
children.prevalue: To that which I have already submitted to your majesty

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: When?
children.prevalue: When

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: On the very day we had a certain explanation about Monsieur's jealousies.
children.prevalue: On the very day we had a certain explanation about Monsieur s jealousies

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: What did you say to me then? inquired Louis, with some anxiety.
children.prevalue: What did you say to me then inquired Louis with some anxiety

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Do you not remember, sire?
children.prevalue: Do you not remember sire

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Alas! if it be another cause of unhappiness, I shall recollect it soon enough.
children.prevalue: Alas if it be another cause of unhappiness I shall recollect it soon enough

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: A cause of unhappiness for myself alone, sire, replied Madame Henrietta; but as it is necessary, I must submit to it.
children.prevalue: A cause of unhappiness for myself alone sire replied Madame Henrietta but as it is necessary I must submit to it

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: At least, tell me what it is, said the king.
children.prevalue: At least tell me what it is said the king

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Absence.
children.prevalue: Absence

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Still that unkind resolve?
children.prevalue: Still that unkind resolve

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Believe me, sire, I have not found it without a violent struggle with myself; it is absolutely necessary I should return to England.
children.prevalue: Believe me sire I have not found it without a violent struggle with myself it is absolutely necessary I should return to England

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Never, never will I permit you to leave France, exclaimed the king.
children.prevalue: Never never will I permit you to leave France exclaimed the king

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: And yet, sire, said Madame, affecting a gentle yet sorrowful determination, nothing is more urgently necessary; nay, more than that, I am persuaded it is your mother's desire I should do so.
children.prevalue: And yet sire said Madame affecting a gentle yet sorrowful determination nothing is more urgently necessary nay more than that I am persuaded it is your mother s desire I should do so

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Desire! exclaimed the king; that is a very strange expression to use to me.
children.prevalue: Desire exclaimed the king that is a very strange expression to use to me

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Still, replied Madame Henrietta, smilingly, are you not happy in submitting to the wishes of so good a mother?
children.prevalue: Still replied Madame Henrietta smilingly are you not happy in submitting to the wishes of so good a mother

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Enough, I implore you; you rend my very soul.
children.prevalue: Enough I implore you you rend my very soul

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I?
children.prevalue: I

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Yes; for you speak of your departure with tranquillity.
children.prevalue: Yes for you speak of your departure with tranquillity

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: I was not born for happiness, sire, replied the princess, dejectedly; and I acquired, in very early life, the habit of seeing my dearest wishes disappointed.
children.prevalue: I was not born for happiness sire replied the princess dejectedly and I acquired in very early life the habit of seeing my dearest wishes disappointed

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Do you speak truly? said the king. Would your departure gainsay any one of your cherished thoughts?
children.prevalue: Do you speak truly said the king Would your departure gainsay any one of your cherished thoughts

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: If I were to say 'yes,' would you begin to take your misfortune patiently?
children.prevalue: If I were to say yes would you begin to take your misfortune patiently

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: How cruel you are!
children.prevalue: How cruel you are

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Take care, sire; some one is coming.
children.prevalue: Take care sire some one is coming

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: The king looked all round him, and said, No, there is no one, and then continued: Come, Henrietta, instead of trying to contend against Monsieur's jealousy by a departure which would kill me
children.prevalue: The king looked all round him and said No there is no one and then continued Come Henrietta instead of trying to contend against Monsieur s jealousy by a departure which would kill me

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Henrietta slightly shrugged her shoulders like a woman unconvinced. Yes, repeated Louis, which would kill me, I say. Instead of fixing your mind on this departure, does not your imaginationor rather does not your heartsuggest some expedient?
children.prevalue: Henrietta slightly shrugged her shoulders like a woman unconvinced Yes repeated Louis which would kill me I say Instead of fixing your mind on this departure does not your imaginationor rather does not your heartsuggest some expedient

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: What is it you wish my heart to suggest?
children.prevalue: What is it you wish my heart to suggest

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Tell me, how can one prove to another that it is wrong to be jealous?
children.prevalue: Tell me how can one prove to another that it is wrong to be jealous

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: In the first place, sire, by giving no motive for jealousy; in other words, in loving no one but the person in question.
children.prevalue: In the first place sire by giving no motive for jealousy in other words in loving no one but the person in question

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Oh! I expected more than that.
children.prevalue: Oh I expected more than that

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: What did you expect?
children.prevalue: What did you expect

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: That you would simply tell me that jealous people are pacified by concealing the affection which is entertained for the object of jealousy.
children.prevalue: That you would simply tell me that jealous people are pacified by concealing the affection which is entertained for the object of jealousy

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Dissimulation is difficult, sire.
children.prevalue: Dissimulation is difficult sire

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Yet it is only be means of conquering difficulties that any happiness is attained. As far as I am concerned, I swear I will give the lie to those who are jealous of me by pretending to treat you like any other woman.
children.prevalue: Yet it is only be means of conquering difficulties that any happiness is attained As far as I am concerned I swear I will give the lie to those who are jealous of me by pretending to treat you like any other woman

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: A bad, as well as unsafe, means, said the young princess, shaking her pretty head.
children.prevalue: A bad as well as unsafe means said the young princess shaking her pretty head

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: You seem to think everything bad, dear Henrietta, said Louis, discontentedly. You negative everything I propose. Suggest, at least, something else in its stead. Come, try and think. I trust implicitly to a woman's invention. Do you invent in your turn?
children.prevalue: You seem to think everything bad dear Henrietta said Louis discontentedly You negative everything I propose Suggest at least something else in its stead Come try and think I trust implicitly to a woman s invention Do you invent in your turn

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Well, sire, I have hit upon something. Will you listen to it?
children.prevalue: Well sire I have hit upon something Will you listen to it

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Can you ask me? You speak of a matter of life or death to me, and then ask if I will listen.
children.prevalue: Can you ask me You speak of a matter of life or death to me and then ask if I will listen

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Well, I judge of it by my own case. If my husband intended to put me on the wrong scent with regard to another woman, one thing would reassure me more than anything else.
children.prevalue: Well I judge of it by my own case If my husband intended to put me on the wrong scent with regard to another woman one thing would reassure me more than anything else

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: What would that be?
children.prevalue: What would that be

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: In the first place to see that he never took any notice of the woman in question.
children.prevalue: In the first place to see that he never took any notice of the woman in question

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Exactly. That is precisely what I said just now.
children.prevalue: Exactly That is precisely what I said just now

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Very well; but in order to be perfectly reassured on the subject, I should like to see him occupy himself with some one else.
children.prevalue: Very well but in order to be perfectly reassured on the subject I should like to see him occupy himself with some one else

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Ah! I understand you, replied Louis, smiling. But confess, dear Henrietta, if the means is at least ingenious, it is hardly charitable.
children.prevalue: Ah I understand you replied Louis smiling But confess dear Henrietta if the means is at least ingenious it is hardly charitable

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Why so?
children.prevalue: Why so

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: In curing the dread of a wound in a jealous person's mind, you inflict one upon the heart. His fear ceases, it is true; but the evil still exists; and that seems to me to be far worse.
children.prevalue: In curing the dread of a wound in a jealous person s mind you inflict one upon the heart His fear ceases it is true but the evil still exists and that seems to me to be far worse

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Agreed; but he does not detect, he does not suspect the real enemy; he does no prejudice to love itself; he concentrates all his strength on the side where his strength will do no injury to anything or any one. In a word, sire, my plan, which I confess I am surprised to find you dispute, is mischievous to jealous people, it is true; but to lovers it is full of advantage. Besides, let me ask, sire, who, except yourself, has ever thought of pitying jealous people? Are they not a melancholy crew of grumblers always equally unhappy, whether with or without a cause? You may remove that cause, but you never can remove their sufferings. It is a disease which lies in the imagination, and, like all imaginary disorders, it is incurable. By the by, I remember an aphorism upon this subject, of poor Dr. Dawley, a clever and amusing man, who, had it not been for my brother, who could not do without him, I should have with me now. He used to say, 'Whenever you are likely to suffer from two affections, choose that which will give you the least trouble, and I will allow you to retain it; for it is positive,' he said, 'that that very ailment is of the greatest service to me, in order to enable me to get rid of the other.'
children.prevalue: Agreed but he does not detect he does not suspect the real enemy he does no prejudice to love itself he concentrates all his strength on the side where his strength will do no injury to anything or any one In a word sire my plan which I confess I am surprised to find you dispute is mischievous to jealous people it is true but to lovers it is full of advantage Besides let me ask sire who except yourself has ever thought of pitying jealous people Are they not a melancholy crew of grumblers always equally unhappy whether with or without a cause You may remove that cause but you never can remove their sufferings It is a disease which lies in the imagination and like all imaginary disorders it is incurable By the by I remember an aphorism upon this subject of poor Dr Dawley a clever and amusing man who had it not been for my brother who could not do without him I should have with me now He used to say Whenever you are likely to suffer from two affections choose that which will give you the least trouble and I will allow you to retain it for it is positive he said that that very ailment is of the greatest service to me in order to enable me to get rid of the other

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Well and judiciously remarked, Henrietta, replied the king, smiling.
children.prevalue: Well and judiciously remarked Henrietta replied the king smiling

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Oh! we have some clever people in London, sire.
children.prevalue: Oh we have some clever people in London sire

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: And those clever people produce adorable pupils. I will grant this Daley, Darley, Dawley, or whatever you call him, a pension for his aphorism; but I entreat you, Henrietta, to begin by choosing the least of your evils. You do not answeryou smile. I guess that the least of your bugbears is your stay in France. I will allow you to retain this information; and, in order to begin with the cure of the other, I will this very day begin to look out for a subject which shall divert the attention of the jealous members of either sex who persecute us both.
children.prevalue: And those clever people produce adorable pupils I will grant this Daley Darley Dawley or whatever you call him a pension for his aphorism but I entreat you Henrietta to begin by choosing the least of your evils You do not answeryou smile I guess that the least of your bugbears is your stay in France I will allow you to retain this information and in order to begin with the cure of the other I will this very day begin to look out for a subject which shall divert the attention of the jealous members of either sex who persecute us both

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Hush! this time some one is really coming, said Madame; and she stooped to gather a flower from the thick grass at her feet. Some one, in fact, was approaching; for, suddenly, a bevy of young girls ran down from the top of the hillock, following the cavaliersthe cause of this interruption being a magnificent hawkmoth, with wings like roseleaves. The prey in question had fallen into the net of Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, who displayed it with some pride to her less successful rivals. The queen of the chase had seated herself some twenty paces from the bank on which Louis and Madame Henrietta were reclining; and leaned her back against a magnificent oaktree entwined with ivy, and stuck the butterfly on the long cane she carried in her hand. Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente was very beautiful, and the gentlemen, accordingly, deserted her companions, and under the pretext of complimenting her upon her success, pressed in a circle around her. The king and princess looked gloomily at this scene, as spectators of maturer age look on at the games of little children. They seem to be amusing themselves there, said the king.
children.prevalue: Hush this time some one is really coming said Madame and she stooped to gather a flower from the thick grass at her feet Some one in fact was approaching for suddenly a bevy of young girls ran down from the top of the hillock following the cavaliersthe cause of this interruption being a magnificent hawkmoth with wings like roseleaves The prey in question had fallen into the net of Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente who displayed it with some pride to her less successful rivals The queen of the chase had seated herself some twenty paces from the bank on which Louis and Madame Henrietta were reclining and leaned her back against a magnificent oaktree entwined with ivy and stuck the butterfly on the long cane she carried in her hand Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente was very beautiful and the gentlemen accordingly deserted her companions and under the pretext of complimenting her upon her success pressed in a circle around her The king and princess looked gloomily at this scene as spectators of maturer age look on at the games of little children They seem to be amusing themselves there said the king

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Greatly, sire; I have always found that people are amused wherever youth and beauty are to be found.
children.prevalue: Greatly sire I have always found that people are amused wherever youth and beauty are to be found

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: What do you think of Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, Henrietta? inquired the king.
children.prevalue: What do you think of Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente Henrietta inquired the king

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: I think she has rather too much flaxyellow and lilywhiteness in her complexion, replied Madame, fixing in a moment upon the only fault it was possible to find in the almost perfect beauty of the future Madame de Montespan.
children.prevalue: I think she has rather too much flaxyellow and lilywhiteness in her complexion replied Madame fixing in a moment upon the only fault it was possible to find in the almost perfect beauty of the future Madame de Montespan

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Rather too fair, yes; but beautiful, I think, in spite of that.
children.prevalue: Rather too fair yes but beautiful I think in spite of that

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Is that your opinion, sire?
children.prevalue: Is that your opinion sire

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Yes, really.
children.prevalue: Yes really

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Very well; and it is mine, too.
children.prevalue: Very well and it is mine too

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: And she seems to be much sought after.
children.prevalue: And she seems to be much sought after

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: On, that is a matter of course. Lovers flutter from one to another. If we had hunted for lovers instead of butterflies, you can see, from those who surround her, what successful sport we should have had.
children.prevalue: On that is a matter of course Lovers flutter from one to another If we had hunted for lovers instead of butterflies you can see from those who surround her what successful sport we should have had

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Tell me, Henrietta, what would be said if the king were to make himself one of those lovers, and let his glance fall in that direction? Would some one else be jealous, in such a case?
children.prevalue: Tell me Henrietta what would be said if the king were to make himself one of those lovers and let his glance fall in that direction Would some one else be jealous in such a case

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Oh! sire, Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente is a very efficacious remedy, said Madame, with a sigh. She would cure a jealous man, certainly; but she might possibly make a woman jealous, too.
children.prevalue: Oh sire Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente is a very efficacious remedy said Madame with a sigh She would cure a jealous man certainly but she might possibly make a woman jealous too

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Henrietta, exclaimed Louis, you fill my heart with joy. Yes, yes; Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente is far too beautiful to serve as a cloak.
children.prevalue: Henrietta exclaimed Louis you fill my heart with joy Yes yes Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente is far too beautiful to serve as a cloak

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: A king's cloak, said Madame Henrietta, smiling, ought to be beautiful.
children.prevalue: A king s cloak said Madame Henrietta smiling ought to be beautiful

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Do you advise me to do it, then? inquired Louis.
children.prevalue: Do you advise me to do it then inquired Louis

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: I! what should I say, sire, except that to give such an advice would be to supply arms against myself? It would be folly or pride to advise you to take, for the heroine of an assumed affection, a woman more beautiful than the one for whom you pretend to feel real regard.
children.prevalue: I what should I say sire except that to give such an advice would be to supply arms against myself It would be folly or pride to advise you to take for the heroine of an assumed affection a woman more beautiful than the one for whom you pretend to feel real regard

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: The king tried to take Madame's hand in his own; his eyes sought hers; and then he murmured a few words so full of tenderness, but pronounced in so low a tone, that the historian, who ought to hear everything, could not hear them. Then, speaking aloud, he said, Do you yourself choose for me the one who is to cure our jealous friend. To her, then, all my devotion, all my attention, all the time that I can spare from my occupations, shall be devoted. For her shall be the flower that I may pluck for you, the fond thoughts with which you have inspired me. Towards her I will direct the glance I dare not bestow upon you, and which ought to be able to rouse you from your indifference. But, be careful in your selection, lest, in offering her the rose which I may have plucked, I find myself conquered by you; and my looks, my hand, my lips, turn immediately towards you, even were the whole world to guess my secret.
children.prevalue: The king tried to take Madame s hand in his own his eyes sought hers and then he murmured a few words so full of tenderness but pronounced in so low a tone that the historian who ought to hear everything could not hear them Then speaking aloud he said Do you yourself choose for me the one who is to cure our jealous friend To her then all my devotion all my attention all the time that I can spare from my occupations shall be devoted For her shall be the flower that I may pluck for you the fond thoughts with which you have inspired me Towards her I will direct the glance I dare not bestow upon you and which ought to be able to rouse you from your indifference But be careful in your selection lest in offering her the rose which I may have plucked I find myself conquered by you and my looks my hand my lips turn immediately towards you even were the whole world to guess my secret

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: While these words escaped from the king's lips, in a stream of wild affection, Madame blushed, breathless, happy, proud, almost intoxicated with delight. She could find nothing to say in reply; her pride and her thirst for homage were satisfied. I shall fail, she said, raising her beautiful black eyes, but not as you beg me, for all this incense which you wish to burn on the altar of another divinity. Ah! sire, I too shall be jealous of it, and want restored to me; and would not that a particle of it should be lost in the way. Therefore, sire, with your royal permission, I will choose one who shall appear to me the least likely to distract your attention, and who will leave my image intact and unshadowed in your heart.
children.prevalue: While these words escaped from the king s lips in a stream of wild affection Madame blushed breathless happy proud almost intoxicated with delight She could find nothing to say in reply her pride and her thirst for homage were satisfied I shall fail she said raising her beautiful black eyes but not as you beg me for all this incense which you wish to burn on the altar of another divinity Ah sire I too shall be jealous of it and want restored to me and would not that a particle of it should be lost in the way Therefore sire with your royal permission I will choose one who shall appear to me the least likely to distract your attention and who will leave my image intact and unshadowed in your heart

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Happily for me, said the king, your heart is not hard and unfeeling. If it were so, I should be alarmed at the threat you hold out. Precautions were taken on this point, and around you, as around myself, it would be difficult to meet with a disagreeablelooking face.
children.prevalue: Happily for me said the king your heart is not hard and unfeeling If it were so I should be alarmed at the threat you hold out Precautions were taken on this point and around you as around myself it would be difficult to meet with a disagreeablelooking face

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Whilst the king was speaking, Madame had risen from her seat, looked around the greensward, and after a careful and silent examination, she called the king to her side, and said, See yonder, sire, upon the declivity of that little hill, near that group of Guelder roses, that beautiful girl walking alone, her head down, her arms hanging by her side, with her eyes fixed upon the flowers, which she crushes beneath her feet, like one who is lost in thought.
children.prevalue: Whilst the king was speaking Madame had risen from her seat looked around the greensward and after a careful and silent examination she called the king to her side and said See yonder sire upon the declivity of that little hill near that group of Guelder roses that beautiful girl walking alone her head down her arms hanging by her side with her eyes fixed upon the flowers which she crushes beneath her feet like one who is lost in thought

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Mademoiselle de Valliere, do you mean? remarked the king.
children.prevalue: Mademoiselle de Valliere do you mean remarked the king

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Oh!
children.prevalue: Oh

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Will she not suit you, sire?
children.prevalue: Will she not suit you sire

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Why, look how thin the poor child is. She has hardly any flesh upon her bones.
children.prevalue: Why look how thin the poor child is She has hardly any flesh upon her bones

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Nay: am I stout then?
children.prevalue: Nay am I stout then

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: She is so melancholy.
children.prevalue: She is so melancholy

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: The greater contrast to myself, who am accused of being too lively.
children.prevalue: The greater contrast to myself who am accused of being too lively

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: She is lame.
children.prevalue: She is lame

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Do you really think so?
children.prevalue: Do you really think so

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: No doubt of it. Look; she has allowed every one to pass by her, through fear of her defect being remarked.
children.prevalue: No doubt of it Look she has allowed every one to pass by her through fear of her defect being remarked

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Well, she will not run so fast as Daphne, and will not be as able to escape Apollo.
children.prevalue: Well she will not run so fast as Daphne and will not be as able to escape Apollo

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Henrietta, said the king, out of temper; of all your maids of honor, you have really selected for me the one most full of defects.
children.prevalue: Henrietta said the king out of temper of all your maids of honor you have really selected for me the one most full of defects

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Still she is one of my maids of honor.
children.prevalue: Still she is one of my maids of honor

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Of course; but what do you mean?
children.prevalue: Of course but what do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: I mean that, in order to visit this new divinity, you will not be able to do so without paying a visit to my apartments, and that, as propriety will forbid your conversing with her in private, you will be compelled to see her in my circle, to speak, as it were, at me, while speaking to her. I mean, in fact, that those who may be jealous, will be wrong if they suppose you come to my apartments for my sake, since you will go there for Mademoiselle de la Valliere.
children.prevalue: I mean that in order to visit this new divinity you will not be able to do so without paying a visit to my apartments and that as propriety will forbid your conversing with her in private you will be compelled to see her in my circle to speak as it were at me while speaking to her I mean in fact that those who may be jealous will be wrong if they suppose you come to my apartments for my sake since you will go there for Mademoiselle de la Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Who happens to be lame.
children.prevalue: Who happens to be lame

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Hardly that.
children.prevalue: Hardly that

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Who never opens her lips.
children.prevalue: Who never opens her lips

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: But who, when she does open them, displays a beautiful set of teeth.
children.prevalue: But who when she does open them displays a beautiful set of teeth

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Who may serve as a model for an osteologist.
children.prevalue: Who may serve as a model for an osteologist

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Your favor will change her appearance.
children.prevalue: Your favor will change her appearance

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Henrietta!
children.prevalue: Henrietta

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: At all events you allowed me to choose.
children.prevalue: At all events you allowed me to choose

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Alas! yes.
children.prevalue: Alas yes

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Well, my choice is made: I impose her upon you, and you must submit.
children.prevalue: Well my choice is made I impose her upon you and you must submit

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Oh! I would accept one of the furies, if you were to insist upon it.
children.prevalue: Oh I would accept one of the furies if you were to insist upon it

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: La Valliere is as gentle as a lamb: do not fear she will ever contradict you when you tell her you love her, said Madame, laughing.
children.prevalue: La Valliere is as gentle as a lamb do not fear she will ever contradict you when you tell her you love her said Madame laughing

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: You are not afraid, are you, that I shall say too much to her?
children.prevalue: You are not afraid are you that I shall say too much to her

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: It would be for my sake.
children.prevalue: It would be for my sake

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: The treaty is agreed to, then?
children.prevalue: The treaty is agreed to then

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Not only so, but signed. You will continue to show me the friendship of a brother, the attention of a brother, the gallantry of a monarch, will you not?
children.prevalue: Not only so but signed You will continue to show me the friendship of a brother the attention of a brother the gallantry of a monarch will you not

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: I will preserve for you intact a heart that has already become accustomed to beat only at your command.
children.prevalue: I will preserve for you intact a heart that has already become accustomed to beat only at your command

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Very well, do you not see that we have guaranteed the future by this means?
children.prevalue: Very well do you not see that we have guaranteed the future by this means

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: I hope so.
children.prevalue: I hope so

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Will your mother cease to regard me as an enemy?
children.prevalue: Will your mother cease to regard me as an enemy

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Will Maria Theresa leave off speaking in Spanish before Monsieur, who has a horror of conversation held in foreign languages, because he always thinks he is being ill spoken of? and lastly, continued the princess, will people persist in attributing a wrongful affection to the king when the truth is, we can offer nothing to each other, except absolute sympathy, free from mental reservation?
children.prevalue: Will Maria Theresa leave off speaking in Spanish before Monsieur who has a horror of conversation held in foreign languages because he always thinks he is being ill spoken of and lastly continued the princess will people persist in attributing a wrongful affection to the king when the truth is we can offer nothing to each other except absolute sympathy free from mental reservation

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Yes, yes, said the king, hesitatingly. But other things may still be said of us.
children.prevalue: Yes yes said the king hesitatingly But other things may still be said of us

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: What can be said, sire? shall we never be left in tranquillity?
children.prevalue: What can be said sire shall we never be left in tranquillity

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: People will say I am deficient in taste; but what is my selfrespect in comparison with your tranquillity?
children.prevalue: People will say I am deficient in taste but what is my selfrespect in comparison with your tranquillity

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: In comparison with my honor, sire, and that of our family, you mean. Besides, I beg you to attend, do not be so hastily prejudiced against La Valliere. She is slightly lame, it is true, but she is not deficient in good sense. Moreover, all that the king touches is converted into gold.
children.prevalue: In comparison with my honor sire and that of our family you mean Besides I beg you to attend do not be so hastily prejudiced against La Valliere She is slightly lame it is true but she is not deficient in good sense Moreover all that the king touches is converted into gold

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Well, Madame, rest assured of one thing, namely, that I am still grateful to you: you might even yet make me pay dearer for your stay in France.
children.prevalue: Well Madame rest assured of one thing namely that I am still grateful to you you might even yet make me pay dearer for your stay in France

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Sire, some one approaches.
children.prevalue: Sire some one approaches

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Well!
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: One last word.
children.prevalue: One last word

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Say it.
children.prevalue: Say it

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: You are prudent and judicious, sire; but in the present instance you will be obliged to summon to your aid all your prudence, and all your judgment.
children.prevalue: You are prudent and judicious sire but in the present instance you will be obliged to summon to your aid all your prudence and all your judgment

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: Oh! exclaimed Louis, laughing, from this very day I shall begin to act my part, and you shall see whether I am not quite fit to represent the character of a tender swain. After luncheon, there will be a promenade in the forest, and then there is supper and the ballet at ten o'clock.
children.prevalue: Oh exclaimed Louis laughing from this very day I shall begin to act my part and you shall see whether I am not quite fit to represent the character of a tender swain After luncheon there will be a promenade in the forest and then there is supper and the ballet at ten o clock

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: I know it.
children.prevalue: I know it

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: The ardor of my passion shall blaze more brilliantly than the fireworks, shall shine more steadily than our friend Colbert's lamps; it shall shine so dazzlingly that the queens and Monsieur will be almost blinded by it.
children.prevalue: The ardor of my passion shall blaze more brilliantly than the fireworks shall shine more steadily than our friend Colbert s lamps it shall shine so dazzlingly that the queens and Monsieur will be almost blinded by it

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Take care, sire, take care.
children.prevalue: Take care sire take care

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: In Heaven's name, what have I done, then?
children.prevalue: In Heaven s name what have I done then

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: I shall begin to recall the compliments I paid you just now. You prudent! you wise! did I say? Why, you begin by the most reckless inconsistencies! Can a passion be kindled in this manner, like a torch, in a moment? Can a monarch, such as you are, without any preparation, fall at the feet of a girl like La Valliere?
children.prevalue: I shall begin to recall the compliments I paid you just now You prudent you wise did I say Why you begin by the most reckless inconsistencies Can a passion be kindled in this manner like a torch in a moment Can a monarch such as you are without any preparation fall at the feet of a girl like La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Ah! Henrietta, now I understand you. We have not yet begun the campaign, and you are plundering me already.
children.prevalue: Ah Henrietta now I understand you We have not yet begun the campaign and you are plundering me already

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: No, I am only recalling you to commonsense ideas. Let your passion be kindled gradually, instead of allowing it to burst forth so suddenly. Jove's thunders and lightnings are heard and seen before the palace is set on fire. Everything has its commencements. If you are so easily excited, no one will believe you are really captivated, and every one will think you out of your sensesif even, indeed, the truth itself not be guessed. The public is not so fatuous as they seem.
children.prevalue: No I am only recalling you to commonsense ideas Let your passion be kindled gradually instead of allowing it to burst forth so suddenly Jove s thunders and lightnings are heard and seen before the palace is set on fire Everything has its commencements If you are so easily excited no one will believe you are really captivated and every one will think you out of your sensesif even indeed the truth itself not be guessed The public is not so fatuous as they seem

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: The king was obliged to admit that Madame was an angel for sense, and the very reverse for cleverness. He bowed, and said: Agreed, Madame, I will think over my plan of attack: great military menmy cousin De Conde for instancegrow pale in meditation upon their strategical plans, before they move one of the pawns, which people call armies; I therefore wish to draw up a complete plan of campaign; for you know that the tender passion is subdivided in a variety of ways. Well, then, I shall stop at the village of Little Attentions, at the hamlet of LoveLetters, before I follow the road of Visible Affection; the way is clear enough, you know, and poor Madame de Scudery would never forgive me for passing though a haltingplace without stopping.
children.prevalue: The king was obliged to admit that Madame was an angel for sense and the very reverse for cleverness He bowed and said Agreed Madame I will think over my plan of attack great military menmy cousin De Conde for instancegrow pale in meditation upon their strategical plans before they move one of the pawns which people call armies I therefore wish to draw up a complete plan of campaign for you know that the tender passion is subdivided in a variety of ways Well then I shall stop at the village of Little Attentions at the hamlet of LoveLetters before I follow the road of Visible Affection the way is clear enough you know and poor Madame de Scudery would never forgive me for passing though a haltingplace without stopping

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: Oh! now we have returned to our proper senses, shall we say adieu, sire?
children.prevalue: Oh now we have returned to our proper senses shall we say adieu sire

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: Alas! it must be so, for see, we are interrupted.
children.prevalue: Alas it must be so for see we are interrupted

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: Yes, indeed, said Henrietta, they are bringing Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente and her sphinx butterfly in grand procession this way.
children.prevalue: Yes indeed said Henrietta they are bringing Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente and her sphinx butterfly in grand procession this way

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: It is perfectly well understood, that this evening, during the promenade, I am to make my escape into the forest, and find La Valliere without you.
children.prevalue: It is perfectly well understood that this evening during the promenade I am to make my escape into the forest and find La Valliere without you

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: I will take care to send her away.
children.prevalue: I will take care to send her away

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: Very well! I will speak to her when she is with her companions, and I will then discharge my first arrow at her.
children.prevalue: Very well I will speak to her when she is with her companions and I will then discharge my first arrow at her

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: Be skillful, said Madame, laughing, and do not miss the heart.
children.prevalue: Be skillful said Madame laughing and do not miss the heart

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: Then the princess took leave of the king, and went forward to meet the merry troop, which was advancing with much ceremony, and a great many pretended flourishes of trumpets, imitated with their mouths.
children.prevalue: Then the princess took leave of the king and went forward to meet the merry troop which was advancing with much ceremony and a great many pretended flourishes of trumpets imitated with their mouths

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: At the conclusion of the banquet, which was served at five o'clock, the king entered his cabinet, where his tailors were awaiting him for the purpose of trying on the celebrated costume representing Spring, which was the result of so much imagination, and had cost so many efforts of thought to the designers and ornamentworkers of the court. As for the ballet itself, every person knew the part he had to take in it, and how to perform it. The king had resolved to make it surprise. Hardly, therefore, had he finished his conference, and entered his own apartment, than he desired his two masters of the ceremonies, Villeroy and SaintAignan, to be sent for. Both replied that they only awaited his orders, and that everything was ready to begin, but that it was necessary to be sure of fine weather and a favorable night before these orders could be carried out. The king opened his window; the palegold hues of the evening were visible on the horizon through the vistas of the wood, and the moon, white as snow, was already mounting the heavens. Not a ripple could be noticed on the surface of the green waters; the swans themselves, even, reposing with folded wings like ships at anchor, seemed inspirations of the warmth of the air, the freshness of the water, and the silence of the beautiful evening. The king, having observed all these things, and contemplated the magnificent picture before him, gave the order which De Villeroy and De SaintAignan awaited; but with a view of insuring the execution of this order in a royal manner, one last question was necessary, and Louis XIV. put it to the two gentlemen in the following manner:Have you any money?
children.prevalue: At the conclusion of the banquet which was served at five o clock the king entered his cabinet where his tailors were awaiting him for the purpose of trying on the celebrated costume representing Spring which was the result of so much imagination and had cost so many efforts of thought to the designers and ornamentworkers of the court As for the ballet itself every person knew the part he had to take in it and how to perform it The king had resolved to make it surprise Hardly therefore had he finished his conference and entered his own apartment than he desired his two masters of the ceremonies Villeroy and SaintAignan to be sent for Both replied that they only awaited his orders and that everything was ready to begin but that it was necessary to be sure of fine weather and a favorable night before these orders could be carried out The king opened his window the palegold hues of the evening were visible on the horizon through the vistas of the wood and the moon white as snow was already mounting the heavens Not a ripple could be noticed on the surface of the green waters the swans themselves even reposing with folded wings like ships at anchor seemed inspirations of the warmth of the air the freshness of the water and the silence of the beautiful evening The king having observed all these things and contemplated the magnificent picture before him gave the order which De Villeroy and De SaintAignan awaited but with a view of insuring the execution of this order in a royal manner one last question was necessary and Louis XIV put it to the two gentlemen in the following manner Have you any money

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Sire, replied SaintAignan, we have arranged everything with M. Colbert.
children.prevalue: Sire replied SaintAignan we have arranged everything with M Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Ah! very well!
children.prevalue: Ah very well

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Yes, sire, and M. Colbert said he would wait upon your majesty, as soon as your majesty should manifest an intention of carrying out the fetes, of which he has furnished the programme.
children.prevalue: Yes sire and M Colbert said he would wait upon your majesty as soon as your majesty should manifest an intention of carrying out the fetes of which he has furnished the programme

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Let him come in, then, said the king; and as if Colbert had been listening at the door for the purpose of keeping himself au courant with the conversation, he entered as soon as the king had pronounced his name to the two courtiers.
children.prevalue: Let him come in then said the king and as if Colbert had been listening at the door for the purpose of keeping himself au courant with the conversation he entered as soon as the king had pronounced his name to the two courtiers

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Ah! M. Colbert, said the king. Gentlemen, to your posts, whereupon SaintAignan and Villeroy took their leave. The king seated himself in an easychair near the window, saying: The ballet will take place this evening, M. Colbert.
children.prevalue: Ah M Colbert said the king Gentlemen to your posts whereupon SaintAignan and Villeroy took their leave The king seated himself in an easychair near the window saying The ballet will take place this evening M Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: In that case, sire, I will pay all accounts tomorrow.
children.prevalue: In that case sire I will pay all accounts tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Why so?
children.prevalue: Why so

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: I promised the tradespeople to pay their bills the day following that on which the ballet should take place.
children.prevalue: I promised the tradespeople to pay their bills the day following that on which the ballet should take place

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Very well, M. Colbert, pay them, since you have promised to do so.
children.prevalue: Very well M Colbert pay them since you have promised to do so

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Certainly, sire; but I must have money to do that.
children.prevalue: Certainly sire but I must have money to do that

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: What! have not the four millions, which M. Fouquet promised, been sent? I forgot to ask you about it.
children.prevalue: What have not the four millions which M Fouquet promised been sent I forgot to ask you about it

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Sire, they were sent at the hour promised.
children.prevalue: Sire they were sent at the hour promised

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Well, sire, the colored lamps, the fireworks, the musicians, and the cooks, have swallowed up four millions in eight days.
children.prevalue: Well sire the colored lamps the fireworks the musicians and the cooks have swallowed up four millions in eight days

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Entirely?
children.prevalue: Entirely

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: To the last penny. Every time your majesty directed the banks of the grand canal to be illuminated, as much oil was consumed as there was water in the basins.
children.prevalue: To the last penny Every time your majesty directed the banks of the grand canal to be illuminated as much oil was consumed as there was water in the basins

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Well, well, M. Colbert; the fact is, then, you have no more money?
children.prevalue: Well well M Colbert the fact is then you have no more money

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: I have no more, sire, but M. Fouquet has, Colbert replied, his face darkening with a sinister expression of pleasure.
children.prevalue: I have no more sire but M Fouquet has Colbert replied his face darkening with a sinister expression of pleasure

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: What do you mean? inquired Louis.
children.prevalue: What do you mean inquired Louis

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: We have already made M. Fouquet advance six millions. He has given them with too much grace not to have others still to give, if they are required, which is the case at the present moment. It is necessary, therefore, that he should comply.
children.prevalue: We have already made M Fouquet advance six millions He has given them with too much grace not to have others still to give if they are required which is the case at the present moment It is necessary therefore that he should comply

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The king frowned. M. Colbert, said he, accentuating the financier's name, that is not the way I understood the matter; I do not wish to make use, against any of my servants, of a means of pressure which may oppress him and fetter his services. In eight days M. Fouquet has furnished six millions; that is a good round sum.
children.prevalue: The king frowned M Colbert said he accentuating the financier s name that is not the way I understood the matter I do not wish to make use against any of my servants of a means of pressure which may oppress him and fetter his services In eight days M Fouquet has furnished six millions that is a good round sum

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Colbert turned pale. And yet, he said, your majesty did not use this language some time ago, when the news about BelleIsle arrived, for instance.
children.prevalue: Colbert turned pale And yet he said your majesty did not use this language some time ago when the news about BelleIsle arrived for instance

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: You are right, M. Colbert.
children.prevalue: You are right M Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Nothing, however, has changed since then; on the contrary, indeed.
children.prevalue: Nothing however has changed since then on the contrary indeed

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: In my thoughts, monsieur, everything has changed.
children.prevalue: In my thoughts monsieur everything has changed

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Does your majesty then no longer believe the disloyal attempt?
children.prevalue: Does your majesty then no longer believe the disloyal attempt

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: My affairs concern myself alone, monsieur; and I have already told you I transact them without interference.
children.prevalue: My affairs concern myself alone monsieur and I have already told you I transact them without interference

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Then, I perceive, said Colbert, trembling with anger and fear, that I have had the misfortune to fall into disgrace with your majesty.
children.prevalue: Then I perceive said Colbert trembling with anger and fear that I have had the misfortune to fall into disgrace with your majesty

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Not at all; you are, on the contrary, most agreeable to me.
children.prevalue: Not at all you are on the contrary most agreeable to me

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Yet, sire, said the minister, with a certain affected bluntness, so successful when it was a question of flattering Louis's selfesteem, what use is there in being agreeable to your majesty, if one can no longer be of any use?
children.prevalue: Yet sire said the minister with a certain affected bluntness so successful when it was a question of flattering Louis s selfesteem what use is there in being agreeable to your majesty if one can no longer be of any use

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: I reserve your services for a better occasion; and believe me, they will only be the better appreciated.
children.prevalue: I reserve your services for a better occasion and believe me they will only be the better appreciated

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Your majesty's plan, then, in this affair, is
children.prevalue: Your majesty s plan then in this affair is

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: You want money, M. Colbert?
children.prevalue: You want money M Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Seven hundred thousand francs, sire.
children.prevalue: Seven hundred thousand francs sire

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: You will take them from my private treasure. Colbert bowed. And, added Louis, as it seems a difficult matter for you, notwithstanding your economy, to defray, with so limited a sum, the expenses which I intend to incur, I will at once sign an order for three millions.
children.prevalue: You will take them from my private treasure Colbert bowed And added Louis as it seems a difficult matter for you notwithstanding your economy to defray with so limited a sum the expenses which I intend to incur I will at once sign an order for three millions

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The king took a pen and signed an order immediately, then handed it to Colbert. Be satisfied, M. Colbert, the plan I have adopted is one worthy of a king, said Louis XIV., who pronounced these words with all the majesty he knew how to assume in such circumstances; and dismissed Colbert for the purpose of giving an audience to his tailors.
children.prevalue: The king took a pen and signed an order immediately then handed it to Colbert Be satisfied M Colbert the plan I have adopted is one worthy of a king said Louis XIV who pronounced these words with all the majesty he knew how to assume in such circumstances and dismissed Colbert for the purpose of giving an audience to his tailors

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: The order issued by the king was known throughout the whole of Fontainebleau; it was already known, too, that the king was trying on his costume, and that the ballet would be danced in the evening. The news circulated with the rapidity of lightning; during its progress it kindled every variety of coquetry, desire, and wild ambition. At the same moment, as if by enchantment, every one who knew how to hold a needle, every one who could distinguish a coat from a pair of trousers, was summoned to the assistance of those who had received invitations. The king had completed his toilette by nine o'clock; he appeared in an open carriage decorated with branches of trees and flowers. The queens had taken their seats upon a magnificent dias or platform, erected upon the borders of the lake, in a theater of wonderful elegance of construction. In the space of five hours the carpenters had put together all the different parts connected with the building; the upholsterers had laid down the carpets, erected the seats; and, as if at the wave of an enchanter's wand, a thousand arms, aiding, instead of interfering with each other, had constructed the building, amidst the sound of music; whilst, at the same time, other workmen illuminated the theater and the shores of the lake with an incalculable number of lamps. As the heavens, set with stars, were perfectly unclouded, as not even a breath of air could be heard in the woods, and as if Nature itself had yielded complacently to the king's fancies, the back of the theater had been left open; so that, behind the foreground of the scenes, could be seen as a background the beautiful sky, glittering with stars; the sheet of water, illuminated by the lights which were reflected in it; and the bluish outline of the grand masses of woods, with their rounded tops. When the king made his appearance, the theater was full, and presented to the view one vast group, dazzling with gold and precious stones; in which, however, at the first glance, no single face could be distinguished. By degrees, as the sight became accustomed to so much brilliancy, the rarest beauties appeared to the view, as in the evening sky the stars appear one by one to him who closes his eyes and then opens them again.

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The theater represented a grove of trees; a few fauns lifting up their cloven feet were jumping about; a dryad made her appearance on the scene, and was immediately pursued by them; others gathered round her for her defense, and they quarrelled as they danced. Suddenly, for the purpose of restoring peace and order, Spring, accompanied by his whole court, made his appearance. The Elements, subaltern powers of mythology, together with their attributes, hastened to follow their gracious sovereign. The Seasons, allies of Spring, followed him closely, to form a quadrille, which, after many words of more or less flattering import, was the commencement of the dance. The music, hautboys, flutes, and viols, was delightfully descriptive of rural delights. The king had already made his appearance, amid thunders of applause. He was dressed in a tunic of flowers, which set off his graceful and wellformed figure to advantage. His legs, the bestshaped at court, were displayed to great advantage in fleshcolored silken hose, of silk so fine and so transparent that it seemed almost like flesh itself. The most beautiful palelilac satin shoes, with bows of flowers and leaves, imprisoned his small feet. The bust of the figure was in harmonious keeping with the base; Louis's waving hair floated on his shoulders, the freshness of his complexion was enhanced by the brilliancy of his beautiful blue eyes, which softly kindled all hearts; a mouth with tempting lips, which deigned to open in smiles. Such was the prince of that period: justly that evening styled The King of all the Loves. There was something in his carriage which resembled the buoyant movements of an immortal, and he did not dance so much as seem to soar along. His entrance produced, therefore, the most brilliant effect. Suddenly the Comte de SaintAignan was observed endeavoring to approach either the king or Madame.

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: The princesswho was robed in a long dress, diaphanous and light as the finest network tissue from the hands of skillful Mechlin workers, one knee occasionally revealed beneath the folds of the tunic, and her little feet encased in silken slippers decked with pearlsadvanced radiant with beauty, accompanied by her cortege of Bacchantes, and had already reached the spot assigned to her in the dance. The applause continued so long that the comte had ample leisure to join the king.
