children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: What is the matter, SaintAignan? said Spring.
children.prevalue: What is the matter SaintAignan said Spring

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Nothing whatever, replied the courtier, as pale as death; but your majesty has not thought of Fruits.
children.prevalue: Nothing whatever replied the courtier as pale as death but your majesty has not thought of Fruits

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Yes; it is suppressed.
children.prevalue: Yes it is suppressed

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Far from it, sire; your majesty having given no directions about it, the musicians have retained it.
children.prevalue: Far from it sire your majesty having given no directions about it the musicians have retained it

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: How excessively annoying, said the king. This figure cannot be performed, since M. de Guiche is absent. It must be suppressed.
children.prevalue: How excessively annoying said the king This figure cannot be performed since M de Guiche is absent It must be suppressed

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Ah, sire, a quarter of an hour's music without any dancing will produce an effect so chilling as to ruin the success of the ballet.
children.prevalue: Ah sire a quarter of an hour s music without any dancing will produce an effect so chilling as to ruin the success of the ballet

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: But, come, since
children.prevalue: But come since

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Oh, sire, that is not the greatest misfortune; for, after all, the orchestra could still just as well cut it out, if it were necessary; but
children.prevalue: Oh sire that is not the greatest misfortune for after all the orchestra could still just as well cut it out if it were necessary but

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: But what?
children.prevalue: But what

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Why, M. de Guiche is here.
children.prevalue: Why M de Guiche is here

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Here? replied the king, frowning, here? Are you sure?
children.prevalue: Here replied the king frowning here Are you sure

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Yes, sire; and ready dressed for the ballet.
children.prevalue: Yes sire and ready dressed for the ballet

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: The king felt himself color deeply, and said, You are probably mistaken.
children.prevalue: The king felt himself color deeply and said You are probably mistaken

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: So little is that the case, sire, that if your majesty will look to the right, you will see that the comte is in waiting.
children.prevalue: So little is that the case sire that if your majesty will look to the right you will see that the comte is in waiting

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Louis turned hastily towards the side, and in fact, on his right, brilliant in his character of Autumn, De Guiche awaited until the king should look at him, in order that he might address him. To give an idea of the stupefaction of the king, and that of Monsieur, who was moving about restlessly in his box,to describe also the agitated movement of the heads in the theater, and the strange emotion of Madame, at the sight of her partner,is a task we must leave to abler hands. The king stood almost gaping with astonishment as he looked at the comte, who, bowing lowly, approached Louis with the profoundest respect.

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Sire, he said, your majesty's most devoted servant approaches to perform a service on this occasion with similar zeal that he has already shown on the field of battle. Your majesty, in omitting the dance of the Fruits, would be losing the most beautiful scene in the ballet. I did not wish to be the substance of so dark a shadow to your majesty's elegance, skill, and graceful invention; and I have left my tenants in order to place my services at your majesty's commands.
children.prevalue: Sire he said your majesty s most devoted servant approaches to perform a service on this occasion with similar zeal that he has already shown on the field of battle Your majesty in omitting the dance of the Fruits would be losing the most beautiful scene in the ballet I did not wish to be the substance of so dark a shadow to your majesty s elegance skill and graceful invention and I have left my tenants in order to place my services at your majesty s commands

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Every word fell distinctly, in perfect harmony and eloquence, upon Louis XIV.'s ears. Their flattery pleased, as much as De Guiche's courage had astonished him, and he simply replied: I did not tell you to return, comte.
children.prevalue: Every word fell distinctly in perfect harmony and eloquence upon Louis XIV s ears Their flattery pleased as much as De Guiche s courage had astonished him and he simply replied I did not tell you to return comte

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Certainly not, sire; but your majesty did not tell me to remain.
children.prevalue: Certainly not sire but your majesty did not tell me to remain

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: The king perceived that time was passing away, that if this strange scene were prolonged it would complicate everything, and that a single cloud upon the picture would eventually spoil the whole. Besides, the king's heart was filled with two or three new ideas; he had just derived fresh inspiration from the eloquent glances of Madame. Her look had said to him: Since they are jealous of you, divide their suspicions, for the man who distrusts two rivals does not object to either in particular. So that Madame, by this clever diversion, decided him. The king smiled upon De Guiche, who did not comprehend a word of Madame's dumb language, but he remarked that she pretended not to look at him, and he attributed the pardon which had been conferred upon him to the princess's kindness of heart. The king seemed only pleased with every one present. Monsieur was the only one who did not understand anything about the matter. The ballet began; the effect was more than beautiful. When the music, by its bursts of melody, carried away these illustrious dancers, when the simple, untutored pantomime of that period, only the more natural on account of the very indifferent acting of the august actors, had reached its culminating point of triumph, the theater shook with tumultuous applause.

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: De Guiche shone like a sun, but like a courtly sun, that is resigned to fill a subordinate part. Disdainful of a success of which Madame showed no acknowledgement, he thought of nothing but boldly regaining the marked preference of the princess. She, however, did not bestow a single glance upon him. By degrees all his happiness, all his brilliancy, subsided into regret and uneasiness; so that his limbs lost their power, his arms hung heavily by his sides, and his head drooped as though he was stupefied. The king, who had from this moment become in reality the principal dancer in the quadrille, cast a look upon his vanquished rival. De Guiche soon ceased to sustain even the character of the courtier; without applause, he danced indifferently, and very soon could not dance at all, by which accident the triumph of the king and of Madame was assured.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The king remained for a moment to enjoy a triumph as complete as it could possibly be. He then turned towards Madame, for the purpose of admiring her also a little in her turn. Young persons love with more vivacity, perhaps with greater ardor and deeper passion, than others more advanced in years; but all the other feelings are at the same time developed in proportion to their youth and vigor: so that vanity being with them almost always the equivalent of love, the latter feeling, according to the laws of equipoise, never attains that degree of perfection which it acquires in men and women from thirty to five and thirty years of age. Louis thought of Madame, but only after he had studiously thought of himself; and Madame carefully thought of herself, without bestowing a single thought upon the king. The victim, however, of all these royal affections and affectations, was poor De Guiche. Every one could observe his agitation and prostrationa prostration which was, indeed, the more remarkable since people were not accustomed to see him with his arms hanging listlessly by his side, his head bewildered, and his eyes with all their bright intelligence bedimmed. It rarely happened that any uneasiness was excited on his account, whenever a question of elegance or taste was under discussion; and De Guiche's defeat was accordingly attributed by the greater number present to his courtierlike tact and ability. But there were otherskeensighted observers are always to be met with at courtwho remarked his paleness and his altered looks; which he could neither feign nor conceal, and their conclusion was that De Guiche was not acting the part of a flatterer. All these sufferings, successes, and remarks were blended, confounded, and lost in the uproar of applause. When, however, the queens expressed their satisfaction and the spectators their enthusiasm, when the king had retired to his dressingroom to change his costume, and whilst Monsieur, dressed as a woman, as he delighted to be, was in his turn dancing about, De Guiche, who had now recovered himself, approached Madame, who, seated at the back of the theater, was waiting for the second part, and had quitted the others for the purpose of creating a sort of solitude for herself in the midst of the crowd, to meditate, as it were, beforehand, upon chorographic effects; and it will be perfectly understood that, absorbed in deep meditation, she did not see, or rather pretended not to notice, anything that was passing around her. De Guiche, observing that she was alone, near a thicket constructed of painted cloth, approached her. Two of her maids of honor, dressed as hamadryads, seeing De Guiche advance, drew back out of respect., whereupon De Guiche proceeded towards the middle of the circle and saluted her royal highness; but, whether she did or did not observe his salutations, the princess did not even turn her head. A cold shiver passed through poor De Guiche; he was unprepared for such utter indifference, for he had neither seen nor been told of anything that had taken place, and consequently could guess nothing. Remarking, therefore, that his obeisance obtained him no acknowledgement, he advanced one step further, and in a voice which he tried, though vainly, to render calm, said: I have the honor to present my most humble respects to your royal highness.

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Upon this Madame deigned to turn her eyes languishingly towards the comte, observing. Ah! M. de Guiche, is that you? good day!
children.prevalue: Upon this Madame deigned to turn her eyes languishingly towards the comte observing Ah M de Guiche is that you good day

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The comte's patience almost forsook him, as he continued,Your royal highness danced just now most charmingly.
children.prevalue: The comte s patience almost forsook him as he continued Your royal highness danced just now most charmingly

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Do you think so? she replied with indifference.
children.prevalue: Do you think so she replied with indifference

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Yes; the character which your royal highness assumed is in perfect harmony with your own.
children.prevalue: Yes the character which your royal highness assumed is in perfect harmony with your own

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Madame again turned round, and, looking De Guiche full in the face with a bright and steady gaze, said,Why so?
children.prevalue: Madame again turned round and looking De Guiche full in the face with a bright and steady gaze said Why so

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Oh! there can be no doubt of it.
children.prevalue: Oh there can be no doubt of it

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Explain yourself?
children.prevalue: Explain yourself

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: You represented a divinity, beautiful, disdainful, inconstant.
children.prevalue: You represented a divinity beautiful disdainful inconstant

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: You mean Pomona, comte?
children.prevalue: You mean Pomona comte

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I allude to the goddess.
children.prevalue: I allude to the goddess

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Madame remained silent for a moment, with her lips compressed, and then observed,But, comte, you, too, are an excellent dancer.
children.prevalue: Madame remained silent for a moment with her lips compressed and then observed But comte you too are an excellent dancer

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Nay, Madame, I am only one of those who are never noticed, or who are soon forgotten if they ever happen to be noticed.
children.prevalue: Nay Madame I am only one of those who are never noticed or who are soon forgotten if they ever happen to be noticed

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: With this remark, accompanied by one of those deep sighs which affect the remotest fibers of one's being, his heart burdened with sorrow and throbbing fast, his head on fire, and his gaze wandering, he bowed breathlessly, and withdrew behind the thicket. The only reply Madame condescended to make was by slightly raising her shoulders, and, as her ladies of honor had discreetly retired while the conversation lasted, she recalled them by a look. The ladies were Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente and Mademoiselle de Montalais.
children.prevalue: With this remark accompanied by one of those deep sighs which affect the remotest fibers of one s being his heart burdened with sorrow and throbbing fast his head on fire and his gaze wandering he bowed breathlessly and withdrew behind the thicket The only reply Madame condescended to make was by slightly raising her shoulders and as her ladies of honor had discreetly retired while the conversation lasted she recalled them by a look The ladies were Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente and Mademoiselle de Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Did you hear what the Comte de Guiche said? the princess inquired.
children.prevalue: Did you hear what the Comte de Guiche said the princess inquired

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: It really is very singular, she continued, in a compassionate tone, how exile has affected poor M. de Guiche's wit. And then, in a louder voice, fearful lest her unhappy victim might lose a syllable, she said,In the first place he danced badly, and afterwards his remarks were very silly.
children.prevalue: It really is very singular she continued in a compassionate tone how exile has affected poor M de Guiche s wit And then in a louder voice fearful lest her unhappy victim might lose a syllable she said In the first place he danced badly and afterwards his remarks were very silly

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: She then rose, humming the air to which she was presently going to dance. De Guiche had overheard everything. The arrow pierced his heart and wounded him mortally. Then, at the risk of interrupting the progress of the fete by his annoyance, he fled from the scene, tearing his beautiful costume of Autumn in pieces, and scattering, as he went along, the branches of vines, mulberry and almond trees, with all the other artificial attributes of his assumed divinity. A quarter of an hour afterwards he returned to the theater; but it will be readily believed that it was only a powerful effort of reason over his great excitement that enabled him to go back; or perhaps, for love is thus strangely constituted, he found it impossible even to remain much longer separated from the presence of one who had broken his heart. Madame was finishing her figure. She saw, but did not look at De Guiche, who, irritated and revengeful, turned his back upon her as she passed him, escorted by her nymphs, and followed by a hundred flatterers. During this time, at the other end of the theater, near the lake, a young woman was seated, with her eyes fixed upon one of the windows of the theater, from which were issuing streams of lightthe window in question being that of the royal box. As De Guiche quitted the theater for the purpose of getting into the fresh air he so much needed, he passed close to this figure and saluted her. When she perceived the young man, she rose, like a woman surprised in the midst of ideas she was desirous of concealing from herself. De Guiche stopped as he recognized her, and said hurriedly,Good evening, Mademoiselle de la Valliere; I am indeed fortunate in meeting you.

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: I, also, M. de Guiche, am glad of this accidental meeting, said the young girl, as she was about to withdraw.
children.prevalue: I also M de Guiche am glad of this accidental meeting said the young girl as she was about to withdraw

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Pray do not leave me, said De Guiche, stretching out his hand towards her, for you would be contradicting the kind words you have just pronounced. Remain, I implore you: the evening is most lovely. You wish to escape from the merry tumult, and prefer your own society. Well, I can understand it; all women who are possessed of any feeling do, and one never finds them dull or lonely when removed from the giddy vortex of these exciting amusements. Oh! Heaven! he exclaimed, suddenly.
children.prevalue: Pray do not leave me said De Guiche stretching out his hand towards her for you would be contradicting the kind words you have just pronounced Remain I implore you the evening is most lovely You wish to escape from the merry tumult and prefer your own society Well I can understand it all women who are possessed of any feeling do and one never finds them dull or lonely when removed from the giddy vortex of these exciting amusements Oh Heaven he exclaimed suddenly

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: What is the matter, monsieur le comte? inquired La Valliere, with some anxiety. You seem agitated.
children.prevalue: What is the matter monsieur le comte inquired La Valliere with some anxiety You seem agitated

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I! oh, no!
children.prevalue: I oh no

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Will you allow me, M. de Guiche, to return you the thanks I had proposed to offer you on the very first opportunity? It is to your recommendation, I am aware, that I owe my admission among the number of Madame's maids of honor.
children.prevalue: Will you allow me M de Guiche to return you the thanks I had proposed to offer you on the very first opportunity It is to your recommendation I am aware that I owe my admission among the number of Madame s maids of honor

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Indeed! Ah! I remember now, and I congratulate myself. Do you love any one?
children.prevalue: Indeed Ah I remember now and I congratulate myself Do you love any one

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I! exclaimed La Valliere.
children.prevalue: I exclaimed La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Forgive me, I hardly know what I am saying; a thousand times forgive me; Madame was right, quite right, this brutal exile has completely turned my brain.
children.prevalue: Forgive me I hardly know what I am saying a thousand times forgive me Madame was right quite right this brutal exile has completely turned my brain

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: And yet it seemed to me that the king received you with kindness.
children.prevalue: And yet it seemed to me that the king received you with kindness

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Do you think so? Received me with kindnessperhaps soyes
children.prevalue: Do you think so Received me with kindnessperhaps soyes

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: There cannot be a doubt he received you kindly, for, in fact, you returned without his permission.
children.prevalue: There cannot be a doubt he received you kindly for in fact you returned without his permission

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Quite true, and I believe you are right. But have you not seen M. de Bragelonne here?
children.prevalue: Quite true and I believe you are right But have you not seen M de Bragelonne here

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: La Valliere started at the name. Why do you ask? she inquired.
children.prevalue: La Valliere started at the name Why do you ask she inquired

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Have I offended you again? said De Guiche. In that case I am indeed unhappy, and greatly to be pitied.
children.prevalue: Have I offended you again said De Guiche In that case I am indeed unhappy and greatly to be pitied

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Yes, very unhappy, and very much to be pitied, Monsieur de Guiche, for you seem to be suffering terribly.
children.prevalue: Yes very unhappy and very much to be pitied Monsieur de Guiche for you seem to be suffering terribly

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Oh! mademoiselle, why have I not a devoted sister, or a true friend, such as yourself?
children.prevalue: Oh mademoiselle why have I not a devoted sister or a true friend such as yourself

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: You have friends, Monsieur de Guiche, and the Vicomte de Bragelonne, of whom you spoke just now, is, I believe, one of the most devoted.
children.prevalue: You have friends Monsieur de Guiche and the Vicomte de Bragelonne of whom you spoke just now is I believe one of the most devoted

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Yes, yes, you are right, he is one of my best friends. Farewell, Mademoiselle de la Valliere, farewell. And he fled, like one possessed, along the banks of the lake. His dark shadow glided, lengthening as it disappeared, among the illumined yews and glittering undulations of the water. La Valliere looked after him, saying,Yes, yes, he, too, is suffering, and I begin to understand why.

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: She had hardly finished when her companions, Mademoiselle de Montalais and Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, ran forward. They were released from their attendance, and had changed their costumes of nymphs; delighted with the beautiful night, and the success of the evening, they returned to look after their companion.
children.prevalue: She had hardly finished when her companions Mademoiselle de Montalais and Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente ran forward They were released from their attendance and had changed their costumes of nymphs delighted with the beautiful night and the success of the evening they returned to look after their companion

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: What, already here! they said to her. We thought we should be first at the rendezvous.
children.prevalue: What already here they said to her We thought we should be first at the rendezvous

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: I have been here this quarter of an hour, replied La Valliere.
children.prevalue: I have been here this quarter of an hour replied La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Did not the dancing amuse you?
children.prevalue: Did not the dancing amuse you

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: But surely the enchanting spectacle?
children.prevalue: But surely the enchanting spectacle

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: No more than the dancing. As far as beauty is concerned, I much prefer that which these dark woods present, in whose depths can be seen, now in one direction and again in another, a light passing by, as though it were an eye, in color like a midnight rainbow, sometimes open, at others closed.
children.prevalue: No more than the dancing As far as beauty is concerned I much prefer that which these dark woods present in whose depths can be seen now in one direction and again in another a light passing by as though it were an eye in color like a midnight rainbow sometimes open at others closed

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: La Valliere is quite a poetess, said TonnayCharente.
children.prevalue: La Valliere is quite a poetess said TonnayCharente

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: In other words, said Montalais, she is insupportable. Whenever there is a question of laughing a little or of amusing ourselves, La Valliere begins to cry; whenever we girls have reason to cry, because, perhaps, we have mislaid our dresses, or because our vanity as been wounded, or our costume fails to produce an effect, La Valliere laughs.

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: As far as I am concerned, that is not my character, said Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente. I am a woman; and there are few like me; whoever loves me, flatters me; whoever flatters me, pleases me; and whoever pleases
children.prevalue: As far as I am concerned that is not my character said Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente I am a woman and there are few like me whoever loves me flatters me whoever flatters me pleases me and whoever pleases

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Well! said Montalais, you do not finish.
children.prevalue: Well said Montalais you do not finish

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: It is too difficult, replied Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, laughing loudly. Do you, who are so clever, finish for me.
children.prevalue: It is too difficult replied Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente laughing loudly Do you who are so clever finish for me

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: And you, Louise? said Montalais, does any one please you?
children.prevalue: And you Louise said Montalais does any one please you

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: That is a matter that concerns no one but myself, replied the young girl, rising from the mossy bank on which she had been reclining during the whole time the ballet lasted. Now, mesdemoiselles, we have agreed to amuse ourselves tonight without any one to overlook us, and without any escort. We are three in number, we like one another, and the night is lovely. Look yonder, do you not see the moon slowly rising, silvering the topmost branches of the chestnuts and the oaks. Oh, beautiful walk! sweet liberty! exquisite soft turf of the woods, the happiness which your friendship confers upon me! let us walk arm in arm towards those large trees. Out yonder all are at this moment seated at table and fully occupied, or preparing to adorn themselves for a set and formal promenade; horses are being saddled, or harnessed to the carriagesthe queen's mules or Madame's four white ponies. As for ourselves, we shall soon reach some retired spot where no eyes can see us and no step follow ours. Do you not remember, Montalais, the woods of Cheverny and of Chambord, the innumerable rustling poplars of Blois, where we exchanged our mutual hopes?

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: And confidences too?
children.prevalue: And confidences too

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Well, said Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, I also think a good deal; but I take care
children.prevalue: Well said Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente I also think a good deal but I take care

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: To say nothing, said Montalais, so that when Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente thinks, Athenais is the only one who knows it.
children.prevalue: To say nothing said Montalais so that when Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente thinks Athenais is the only one who knows it

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Hush! said Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, I hear steps approaching from this side.
children.prevalue: Hush said Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente I hear steps approaching from this side

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Quick, quick, then, among the high reedgrass, said Montalais; stoop, Athenais, you are so tall.
children.prevalue: Quick quick then among the high reedgrass said Montalais stoop Athenais you are so tall

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente stooped as she was told, and, almost at the same moment, they saw two gentlemen approaching, their heads bent down, walking arm in arm, on the fine gravel walk running parallel with the bank. The young girls had, indeed, made themselves smallindeed invisible.
children.prevalue: Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente stooped as she was told and almost at the same moment they saw two gentlemen approaching their heads bent down walking arm in arm on the fine gravel walk running parallel with the bank The young girls had indeed made themselves smallindeed invisible

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: It is Monsieur de Guiche, whispered Montalais in Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente's ear.
children.prevalue: It is Monsieur de Guiche whispered Montalais in Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente s ear

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: It is Monsieur de Bragelonne, whispered the latter to La Valliere.
children.prevalue: It is Monsieur de Bragelonne whispered the latter to La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: The two young men approached still closer, conversing in animated tones. She was here just now, said the count. If I had only seen her, I should have declared it to be a vision, but I spoke to her.
children.prevalue: The two young men approached still closer conversing in animated tones She was here just now said the count If I had only seen her I should have declared it to be a vision but I spoke to her

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: You are positive, then?
children.prevalue: You are positive then

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Yes; but perhaps I frightened her.
children.prevalue: Yes but perhaps I frightened her

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: In what way?
children.prevalue: In what way

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Oh! I was still half crazy at you know what; so that she could hardly have understood what I was saying, and must have grown alarmed.
children.prevalue: Oh I was still half crazy at you know what so that she could hardly have understood what I was saying and must have grown alarmed

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Oh! said Bragelonne, do not make yourself uneasy: she is all kindness, and will excuse you; she is clearsighted, and will understand.
children.prevalue: Oh said Bragelonne do not make yourself uneasy she is all kindness and will excuse you she is clearsighted and will understand

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Yes, but if she should have understood, and understood too well, she may talk.
children.prevalue: Yes but if she should have understood and understood too well she may talk

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: You do not know Louise, count, said Raoul. Louise possesses every virtue, and has not a single fault. And the two young men passed on, and, as they proceeded, their voices were soon lost in the distance.
children.prevalue: You do not know Louise count said Raoul Louise possesses every virtue and has not a single fault And the two young men passed on and as they proceeded their voices were soon lost in the distance

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: How is it, La Valliere, said Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, that the Vicomte de Bragelonne spoke of you as Louise?
children.prevalue: How is it La Valliere said Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente that the Vicomte de Bragelonne spoke of you as Louise

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: We were brought up together, replied Louise, blushing; M. de Bragelonne has honored me by asking my hand in marriage, but
children.prevalue: We were brought up together replied Louise blushing M de Bragelonne has honored me by asking my hand in marriage but

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: It seems the king will not consent to it.
children.prevalue: It seems the king will not consent to it

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Eh! Why the king? and what has the king to do with it? exclaimed Aure, sharply. Good gracious! has the king any right to interfere in matters of that kind? Politics are politics, as M. de Mazarin used to say; but love is love. If, therefore, you love M. de Bragelonne, marry him. I give my consent.
children.prevalue: Eh Why the king and what has the king to do with it exclaimed Aure sharply Good gracious has the king any right to interfere in matters of that kind Politics are politics as M de Mazarin used to say but love is love If therefore you love M de Bragelonne marry him I give my consent

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Athenais began to laugh.
children.prevalue: Athenais began to laugh

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Oh! I am speaking seriously, replied Montalais, and my opinion in this case is quite as good as the king's, I suppose; is it not, Louise?
children.prevalue: Oh I am speaking seriously replied Montalais and my opinion in this case is quite as good as the king s I suppose is it not Louise

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Come, said La Valliere, these gentlemen have passed; let us take advantage of our being alone to cross the open ground and so take refuge in the woods.
children.prevalue: Come said La Valliere these gentlemen have passed let us take advantage of our being alone to cross the open ground and so take refuge in the woods

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: So much the better, said Athenais, because I see the torches setting out from the chateau and the theater, and they seem as if they were preceding some person of distinction.
children.prevalue: So much the better said Athenais because I see the torches setting out from the chateau and the theater and they seem as if they were preceding some person of distinction

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Let us run, then, said all three. And, gracefully lifting up the long skirts of their silk dresses, they lightly ran across the open space between the lake and the thickest covert of the park. Montalais agile as a deer, Athenais eager as a young wolf, bounded through the dry grass, and, now and then, some bold Acteon might, by the aid of the faint light, have perceived their straight and wellformed limbs somewhat displayed beneath the heavy folds of their satin petticoats. La Valliere, more refined and more bashful, allowed her dress to flow around her; retarded also by the lameness of her foot, it was not long before she called out to her companions to halt, and, left behind, she obliged them both to wait for her. At this moment, a man, concealed in a dry ditch planted with young willow saplings, scrambled quickly up its shelving side, and ran off in the direction of the chateau. The three young girls, on their side, reached the outskirts of the park, every path of which they well knew. The ditches were bordered by high hedges full of flowers, which on that side protected the footpassengers from being intruded upon by the horses and carriages. In fact, the sound of Madame's and the queen's carriages could be heard in the distance upon the hard dry ground of the roads, followed by the mounted cavaliers. Distant music reached them in response, and when the soft notes died away, the nightingale, with throat of pride, poured forth his melodious chants, and his most complicated, learned, and sweetest compositions to those who had met beneath the thick covert of the woods. Near the songster, in the dark background of the large trees, could be seen the glistening eyes of an owl, attracted by the harmony. In this way the fete of the whole court was a fete also for the mysterious inhabitants of the forest; for certainly the deer in the brake, the pheasant on the branch, the fox in its hole, were all listening. One could realize the life led by this nocturnal and invisible population from the restless movements that suddenly took place among the leaves. Our sylvan nymphs uttered a slight cry, but, reassured immediately afterwards, they laughed, and resumed their walk. In this manner they reached the royal oak, the venerable relic of a tree which in its prime has listened to the sighs of Henry II. for the beautiful Diana of Poitiers, and later still to those of Henry IV. for the lovely Gabrielle d'Estrees. Beneath this oak the gardeners had piled up the moss and turf in such a manner that never had a seat more luxuriously rested the wearied limbs of man or monarch. The trunk, somewhat rough to recline against, was sufficiently large to accommodate the three young girls, whose voices were lost among the branches, which stretched upwards to the sky.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The softness of the air, the stillness of the foliage, tacitly imposed upon these young girls an engagement to change immediately their giddy conversation for one of a more serious character. She, indeed, whose disposition was the most lively,Montalais, for instance,was the first to yield to the influence; and she began by heaving a deep sigh, and saying:What happiness to be here alone, and at liberty, with every right to be frank, especially towards one another.
children.prevalue: The softness of the air the stillness of the foliage tacitly imposed upon these young girls an engagement to change immediately their giddy conversation for one of a more serious character She indeed whose disposition was the most lively Montalais for instance was the first to yield to the influence and she began by heaving a deep sigh and saying What happiness to be here alone and at liberty with every right to be frank especially towards one another

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Yes, said Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente; for the court, however brilliant it may be, has always some falsehood concealed beneath the folds of its velvet robes, or the glitter of its diamonds.
children.prevalue: Yes said Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente for the court however brilliant it may be has always some falsehood concealed beneath the folds of its velvet robes or the glitter of its diamonds

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: I, replied La Valliere, I never tell a falsehood; when I cannot speak the truth, I remain silent.
children.prevalue: I replied La Valliere I never tell a falsehood when I cannot speak the truth I remain silent

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: You will not long remain in favor, said Montalais; it is not here as it was at Blois, where we told the dowager Madame all our little annoyances, and all our longings. There were certain days when Madame remembered that she herself had been young, and, on those days, whoever talked with her found in her a sincere friend. She related to us her flirtations with Monsieur, and we told her of the flirtations she had had with others, or, at least, the rumors of them that had spread abroad. Poor woman, so simpleminded! she laughed at them, as we did. Where is she now?
children.prevalue: You will not long remain in favor said Montalais it is not here as it was at Blois where we told the dowager Madame all our little annoyances and all our longings There were certain days when Madame remembered that she herself had been young and on those days whoever talked with her found in her a sincere friend She related to us her flirtations with Monsieur and we told her of the flirtations she had had with others or at least the rumors of them that had spread abroad Poor woman so simpleminded she laughed at them as we did Where is she now

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Ah, Montalais,laughterloving Montalais! cried La Valliere; you see you are sighing again; the woods inspire you, and you are almost reasonable this evening.
children.prevalue: Ah Montalais laughterloving Montalais cried La Valliere you see you are sighing again the woods inspire you and you are almost reasonable this evening

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: You ought not, either of you, said Athenais, to regret the court at Blois so much, unless you do not feel happy with us. A court is a place where men and women resort to talk of matters which mothers, guardians, and especially confessors, severely denounce.
children.prevalue: You ought not either of you said Athenais to regret the court at Blois so much unless you do not feel happy with us A court is a place where men and women resort to talk of matters which mothers guardians and especially confessors severely denounce

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Oh, Athenais! said Louise, blushing.
children.prevalue: Oh Athenais said Louise blushing

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Athenais is frank tonight, said Montalais; let us avail ourselves of it.
children.prevalue: Athenais is frank tonight said Montalais let us avail ourselves of it

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Yes, let us take advantage of it, for this evening I could divulge the softest secrets of my heart.
children.prevalue: Yes let us take advantage of it for this evening I could divulge the softest secrets of my heart

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Ah, if M. Montespan were here! said Montalais.
children.prevalue: Ah if M Montespan were here said Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Do you think that I care for M. de Montespan? murmured the beautiful young girl.
children.prevalue: Do you think that I care for M de Montespan murmured the beautiful young girl

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: He is handsome, I believe?
children.prevalue: He is handsome I believe

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Yes. And that is no small advantage in my eyes.
children.prevalue: Yes And that is no small advantage in my eyes

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: There now, you see
children.prevalue: There now you see

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I will go further, and say, that of all the men whom one sees here, he is the handsomest, and the most
children.prevalue: I will go further and say that of all the men whom one sees here he is the handsomest and the most

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: What was that? said La Valliere, starting suddenly from the mossy bank.
children.prevalue: What was that said La Valliere starting suddenly from the mossy bank

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: A deer hurrying by, perhaps.
children.prevalue: A deer hurrying by perhaps

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I am only afraid of men, said Athenais.
children.prevalue: I am only afraid of men said Athenais

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: When they do not resemble M. de Montespan.
children.prevalue: When they do not resemble M de Montespan

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: A truce to raillery. M. de Montespan is attentive to me, but that does not commit me in any way. Is not M. de Guiche here, he who is so devoted to Madame?
children.prevalue: A truce to raillery M de Montespan is attentive to me but that does not commit me in any way Is not M de Guiche here he who is so devoted to Madame

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Poor fellow! said La Valliere.
children.prevalue: Poor fellow said La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Why to be pitied? Madame is sufficiently beautiful, and of high enough rank, I suppose.
children.prevalue: Why to be pitied Madame is sufficiently beautiful and of high enough rank I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: La Valliere shook her head sorrowfully, saying, When one loves, it is neither beauty nor rank;when one loves it should be the heart, or the eyes only, of him, or of her whom one loves.
children.prevalue: La Valliere shook her head sorrowfully saying When one loves it is neither beauty nor rank when one loves it should be the heart or the eyes only of him or of her whom one loves

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Montalais began to laugh loudly. Heart, eyes, she said; oh, sugarplums!
children.prevalue: Montalais began to laugh loudly Heart eyes she said oh sugarplums

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I speak for myself; replied La Valliere.
children.prevalue: I speak for myself replied La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Noble sentiments, said Athenais, with an air of protection, but with indifference.
children.prevalue: Noble sentiments said Athenais with an air of protection but with indifference

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Are they not your own? asked Louise.
children.prevalue: Are they not your own asked Louise

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Perfectly so; but to continue: how can one pity a man who bestows his attentions upon such a woman as Madame? If any disproportion exists, it is on the count's side.
children.prevalue: Perfectly so but to continue how can one pity a man who bestows his attentions upon such a woman as Madame If any disproportion exists it is on the count s side

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Oh! no, no, returned La Valliere; it is on Madame's side.
children.prevalue: Oh no no returned La Valliere it is on Madame s side

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Explain yourself.
children.prevalue: Explain yourself

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: I will. Madame has not even a wish to know what love is. She diverts herself with the feeling, as children do with fireworks, form which a spark might set a palace on fire. It makes a display, and that is all she cares about. Besides, pleasure forms the tissue of which she wishes her life to be woven. M. de Guiche loves this illustrious personage, but she will never love him.
children.prevalue: I will Madame has not even a wish to know what love is She diverts herself with the feeling as children do with fireworks form which a spark might set a palace on fire It makes a display and that is all she cares about Besides pleasure forms the tissue of which she wishes her life to be woven M de Guiche loves this illustrious personage but she will never love him

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Athenais laughed disdainfully. Do people really ever love? she said. Where are the noble sentiments you just now uttered? Does not a woman's virtue consist in the uncompromising refusal of every intrigue that might compromise her? A properly regulated woman, endowed with a natural heart, ought to look at men, make herself lovedadored, even, by them, and say at the very utmost but once in her life, 'I begin to think that I ought not to have been what I am,I should have detested this one less than others.'
children.prevalue: Athenais laughed disdainfully Do people really ever love she said Where are the noble sentiments you just now uttered Does not a woman s virtue consist in the uncompromising refusal of every intrigue that might compromise her A properly regulated woman endowed with a natural heart ought to look at men make herself lovedadored even by them and say at the very utmost but once in her life I begin to think that I ought not to have been what I am I should have detested this one less than others

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Therefore, exclaimed La Valliere, that is what M. de Montespan has to expect.
children.prevalue: Therefore exclaimed La Valliere that is what M de Montespan has to expect

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Certainly; he, as well as every one else. What! have I not said that I admit he possesses a certain superiority, and would not that be enough? My dear child, a woman is a queen during the entire period nature permits her to enjoy sovereign powerfrom fifteen to thirtyfive years of age. After that, we are free to have a heart, when we only have that left
children.prevalue: Certainly he as well as every one else What have I not said that I admit he possesses a certain superiority and would not that be enough My dear child a woman is a queen during the entire period nature permits her to enjoy sovereign powerfrom fifteen to thirtyfive years of age After that we are free to have a heart when we only have that left

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Oh, oh! murmured La Valliere.
children.prevalue: Oh oh murmured La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Excellent, cried Montalais; a very masterly woman; Athenais, you will make your way in the world.
children.prevalue: Excellent cried Montalais a very masterly woman Athenais you will make your way in the world

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Do you not approve of what I say?
children.prevalue: Do you not approve of what I say

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Completely, replied her laughing companion.
children.prevalue: Completely replied her laughing companion

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: You are not serious, Montalais? said Louise.
children.prevalue: You are not serious Montalais said Louise

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Yes, yes; I approve everything Athenais has just said; only
children.prevalue: Yes yes I approve everything Athenais has just said only

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Only what?
children.prevalue: Only what

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Well, I cannot carry it out. I have the firmest principles; I form resolutions beside which the laws of the Stadtholder and of the King of Spain are child's play; but when the moment arrives to put them into execution, nothing comes of them.
children.prevalue: Well I cannot carry it out I have the firmest principles I form resolutions beside which the laws of the Stadtholder and of the King of Spain are child s play but when the moment arrives to put them into execution nothing comes of them

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Your courage fails? said Athenais, scornfully.
children.prevalue: Your courage fails said Athenais scornfully

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Miserably so.
children.prevalue: Miserably so

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Great weakness of nature, returned Athenais. But at least you make a choice.
children.prevalue: Great weakness of nature returned Athenais But at least you make a choice

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Why, no. It pleases fate to disappoint me in everything; I dream of emperors, and I find only
children.prevalue: Why no It pleases fate to disappoint me in everything I dream of emperors and I find only

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Aure, Aure! exclaimed La Valliere, for pity's sake, do not, for the pleasure of saying something witty, sacrifice those who love you with such devoted affection.
children.prevalue: Aure Aure exclaimed La Valliere for pity s sake do not for the pleasure of saying something witty sacrifice those who love you with such devoted affection

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Oh, I do not trouble myself much about that; those who love me are sufficiently happy that I do not dismiss them altogether. So much the worse for myself if I have a weakness for any one, but so much the worse for others if I revenge myself upon them for it.
children.prevalue: Oh I do not trouble myself much about that those who love me are sufficiently happy that I do not dismiss them altogether So much the worse for myself if I have a weakness for any one but so much the worse for others if I revenge myself upon them for it

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: You are right, said Athenais, and, perhaps, you too will reach the goal. In other words, young ladies, that is termed being a coquette. Men, who are very silly in most things, are particularly so in confounding, under the term of coquetry, a woman's pride, and love of changing her sentiments as she does her dress. I, for instance, am proud; that is to say, impregnable. I treat my admirers harshly, but without any pretention to retain them. Men call me a coquette, because they are vain enough to think I care for them. Other womenMontalais, for instancehave allowed themselves to be influenced by flattery; they would be lost were it not for that most fortunate principle of instinct which urges them to change suddenly, and punish the man whose devotion they so recently accepted.
children.prevalue: You are right said Athenais and perhaps you too will reach the goal In other words young ladies that is termed being a coquette Men who are very silly in most things are particularly so in confounding under the term of coquetry a woman s pride and love of changing her sentiments as she does her dress I for instance am proud that is to say impregnable I treat my admirers harshly but without any pretention to retain them Men call me a coquette because they are vain enough to think I care for them Other womenMontalais for instancehave allowed themselves to be influenced by flattery they would be lost were it not for that most fortunate principle of instinct which urges them to change suddenly and punish the man whose devotion they so recently accepted

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: A very learned dissertation, said Montalais, in the tone of thorough enjoyment.
children.prevalue: A very learned dissertation said Montalais in the tone of thorough enjoyment

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: It is odious! murmured Louise.
children.prevalue: It is odious murmured Louise

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Thanks to that sort of coquetry, for, indeed, that is genuine coquetry, continued Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente; the lover who, a little while since, was puffed up with pride, in a minute afterwards is suffering at every pore of his vanity and selfesteem. He was, perhaps, already beginning to assume the airs of a conqueror, but now he retreats defeated; he was about to assume an air of protection towards us, but he is obliged to prostrate himself once more. The result of all this is, that, instead of having a husband who is jealous and troublesome, free from restraint in his conduct towards us, we have a lover always trembling in our presence, always fascinated by our attractions, always submissive; and for this simple reason, that he finds the same woman never twice of the same mind. Be convinced, therefore, of the advantages of coquetry. Possessing that, one reigns a queen among women in cases where Providence has withheld that precious faculty of holding one's heart and mind in check.
children.prevalue: Thanks to that sort of coquetry for indeed that is genuine coquetry continued Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente the lover who a little while since was puffed up with pride in a minute afterwards is suffering at every pore of his vanity and selfesteem He was perhaps already beginning to assume the airs of a conqueror but now he retreats defeated he was about to assume an air of protection towards us but he is obliged to prostrate himself once more The result of all this is that instead of having a husband who is jealous and troublesome free from restraint in his conduct towards us we have a lover always trembling in our presence always fascinated by our attractions always submissive and for this simple reason that he finds the same woman never twice of the same mind Be convinced therefore of the advantages of coquetry Possessing that one reigns a queen among women in cases where Providence has withheld that precious faculty of holding one s heart and mind in check

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: How clever you are, said Montalais, and how well you understand the duty women owe themselves!
children.prevalue: How clever you are said Montalais and how well you understand the duty women owe themselves

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: I am only settling a case of individual happiness, said Athenais modestly; and defending myself, like all weak, loving dispositions, against the oppressions of the stronger.
children.prevalue: I am only settling a case of individual happiness said Athenais modestly and defending myself like all weak loving dispositions against the oppressions of the stronger

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: La Valliere does not say a word.
children.prevalue: La Valliere does not say a word

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Does she not approve of what we are saying?
children.prevalue: Does she not approve of what we are saying

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Nay; only I do not understand it, said Louise. You talk like people not called upon to live in this world of ours.
children.prevalue: Nay only I do not understand it said Louise You talk like people not called upon to live in this world of ours

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: And very pretty your world is, said Montalais.
children.prevalue: And very pretty your world is said Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: A world, returned Athenais, in which men worship a woman until she has fallen,and insult her when she has fallen.
children.prevalue: A world returned Athenais in which men worship a woman until she has fallen and insult her when she has fallen

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Who spoke to you of falling? said Louise.
children.prevalue: Who spoke to you of falling said Louise

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Yours is a new theory, then; will you tell us how you intend to resist yielding to temptation, if you allow yourself to be hurried away by feelings of affection?
children.prevalue: Yours is a new theory then will you tell us how you intend to resist yielding to temptation if you allow yourself to be hurried away by feelings of affection

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Oh! exclaimed the young girl, raising towards the dark heavens her beautiful large eyes filled with tears, if you did but know what a heart is, I would explain, and convince you; a loving heart is stronger than all your coquetry, more powerful than all your pride. A woman is never truly loved, I believe; a man never loves with idolatry, unless he feels sure he is loved in return. Let old men, whom we read of in comedies, fancy themselves adored by coquettes. A young man is conscious of, and knows them; if he has a fancy, or a strong desire, and an absorbing passion, for a coquette, he cannot mistake her; a coquette may drive him out of his senses, but will never make him fall in love. Love, such as I conceive it to be, is an incessant, complete, and perfect sacrifice; but it is not the sacrifice of one only of the two persons thus united. It is the perfect abnegation of two who are desirous of blending their beings into one. If ever I love, I shall implore my lover to leave me free and pure; I will tell him, and he will understand, that my heart was torn by my refusal, and he, in his love for me, aware of the magnitude of my sacrifice,he, in his turn, I say, will store his devotion for me,will respect me, and will not seek my ruin, to insult me when I shall have fallen, as you said just now, whilst uttering your blasphemies against love, such as I understand it. That is my idea of love. And now you will tell me, perhaps, that my love will despise me; I defy him to do so, unless he be the vilest of men, and my heart assures me that it is not such a man I would choose. A look from me will repay him for the sacrifices he makes, or will inspire him with the virtues which he would never think he possessed.
children.prevalue: Oh exclaimed the young girl raising towards the dark heavens her beautiful large eyes filled with tears if you did but know what a heart is I would explain and convince you a loving heart is stronger than all your coquetry more powerful than all your pride A woman is never truly loved I believe a man never loves with idolatry unless he feels sure he is loved in return Let old men whom we read of in comedies fancy themselves adored by coquettes A young man is conscious of and knows them if he has a fancy or a strong desire and an absorbing passion for a coquette he cannot mistake her a coquette may drive him out of his senses but will never make him fall in love Love such as I conceive it to be is an incessant complete and perfect sacrifice but it is not the sacrifice of one only of the two persons thus united It is the perfect abnegation of two who are desirous of blending their beings into one If ever I love I shall implore my lover to leave me free and pure I will tell him and he will understand that my heart was torn by my refusal and he in his love for me aware of the magnitude of my sacrifice he in his turn I say will store his devotion for me will respect me and will not seek my ruin to insult me when I shall have fallen as you said just now whilst uttering your blasphemies against love such as I understand it That is my idea of love And now you will tell me perhaps that my love will despise me I defy him to do so unless he be the vilest of men and my heart assures me that it is not such a man I would choose A look from me will repay him for the sacrifices he makes or will inspire him with the virtues which he would never think he possessed

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: But, Louise, exclaimed Montalais, you tell us this, and do not carry it into practice.
children.prevalue: But Louise exclaimed Montalais you tell us this and do not carry it into practice

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: What do you mean?
children.prevalue: What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: You are adored by Raoul de Bragelonne, who worships you on both knees. The poor fellow is made the victim of your virtue, just as he would be nay, more than he would be, evenof my coquetry, or Athenais's pride.
children.prevalue: You are adored by Raoul de Bragelonne who worships you on both knees The poor fellow is made the victim of your virtue just as he would be nay more than he would be evenof my coquetry or Athenais s pride

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: All this is simply a different shade of coquetry, said Athenais; and Louise, I perceive, is a coquette without knowing it.
children.prevalue: All this is simply a different shade of coquetry said Athenais and Louise I perceive is a coquette without knowing it

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Oh! said La Valliere.
children.prevalue: Oh said La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Yes, you may call it instinct, if you please, keenest sensibility, exquisite refinement of feeling, perpetual play of restrained outbreaks of affection, which end in smoke. It is very artful too, and very effective. I should even, now that I reflect upon it, have preferred this system of tactics to my own pride, for waging war on members of the other sex, because it offers the advantage sometimes of thoroughly convincing them; but, at the present moment, without utterly condemning myself, I declare it to be superior to the noncomplex coquetry of Montalais. And the two young girls began to laugh.
children.prevalue: Yes you may call it instinct if you please keenest sensibility exquisite refinement of feeling perpetual play of restrained outbreaks of affection which end in smoke It is very artful too and very effective I should even now that I reflect upon it have preferred this system of tactics to my own pride for waging war on members of the other sex because it offers the advantage sometimes of thoroughly convincing them but at the present moment without utterly condemning myself I declare it to be superior to the noncomplex coquetry of Montalais And the two young girls began to laugh

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: La Valliere alone preserved silence, and quietly shook her head. Then, a moment after, she added, If you were to tell me, in the presence of a man, but a fourth part of what you have just said, or even if I were assured that you think it, I should die of shame and grief where I am now.
children.prevalue: La Valliere alone preserved silence and quietly shook her head Then a moment after she added If you were to tell me in the presence of a man but a fourth part of what you have just said or even if I were assured that you think it I should die of shame and grief where I am now

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Very well; die, poor tender little darling, replied Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente; for if there are no men here, there are at least two women, your own friends, who declare you to be attained and convicted of being a coquette from instinct; in other words, the most dangerous kind of coquette the world possesses.
children.prevalue: Very well die poor tender little darling replied Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente for if there are no men here there are at least two women your own friends who declare you to be attained and convicted of being a coquette from instinct in other words the most dangerous kind of coquette the world possesses

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Oh! mesdemoiselles, replied La Valliere, blushing, and almost ready to weep. Her two companions again burst out laughing.
children.prevalue: Oh mesdemoiselles replied La Valliere blushing and almost ready to weep Her two companions again burst out laughing

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Very well! I will ask Bragelonne to tell me.
children.prevalue: Very well I will ask Bragelonne to tell me

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Bragelonne? said Athenais.
children.prevalue: Bragelonne said Athenais

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Yes! Bragelonne, who is as courageous as Caesar, and as clever and witty as M. Fouquet. Poor fellow! for twelve years he has known you, loved you, and yetone can hardly believe ithe has never even kissed the tips of your fingers.
children.prevalue: Yes Bragelonne who is as courageous as Caesar and as clever and witty as M Fouquet Poor fellow for twelve years he has known you loved you and yetone can hardly believe ithe has never even kissed the tips of your fingers

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Tell us the reason of this cruelty, you who are all heart, said Athenais to La Valliere.
children.prevalue: Tell us the reason of this cruelty you who are all heart said Athenais to La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Let me explain it by a single wordvirtue. You will perhaps deny the existence of virtue?
children.prevalue: Let me explain it by a single wordvirtue You will perhaps deny the existence of virtue

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Come, Louise, tell us the truth, said Aure, taking her by the hand.
children.prevalue: Come Louise tell us the truth said Aure taking her by the hand

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: What do you wish me to tell you? cried La Valliere.
children.prevalue: What do you wish me to tell you cried La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Whatever you like; but it will be useless for you to say anything, for I persist in my opinion of you. A coquette from instinct; in other words, as I have already said, and I say it again, the most dangerous of all coquettes.
children.prevalue: Whatever you like but it will be useless for you to say anything for I persist in my opinion of you A coquette from instinct in other words as I have already said and I say it again the most dangerous of all coquettes

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Oh! no, no; for pity's sake do not believe that!
children.prevalue: Oh no no for pity s sake do not believe that

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: What! twelve years of extreme severity.
children.prevalue: What twelve years of extreme severity

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: How can that be, since twelve years ago I was only five years old? The frivolity of the child cannot surely be placed to the young girl's account.
children.prevalue: How can that be since twelve years ago I was only five years old The frivolity of the child cannot surely be placed to the young girl s account

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Well! you are now seventeen; three years instead of twelve. During those three years you have remained constantly and unchangeably cruel. Against you are arrayed the silent shades of Blois, the meetings when you diligently conned the stars together, the evening wanderings beneath the plantaintrees, his impassioned twenty years speaking to your fourteen summers, the fire of his glances addressed to yourself.
children.prevalue: Well you are now seventeen three years instead of twelve During those three years you have remained constantly and unchangeably cruel Against you are arrayed the silent shades of Blois the meetings when you diligently conned the stars together the evening wanderings beneath the plantaintrees his impassioned twenty years speaking to your fourteen summers the fire of his glances addressed to yourself

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Yes, yes; but so it is!
children.prevalue: Yes yes but so it is

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Impossible!
children.prevalue: Impossible

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: But why impossible?
children.prevalue: But why impossible

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Tell us something credible and we will believe you.
children.prevalue: Tell us something credible and we will believe you

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Yet, if you were to suppose one thing.
children.prevalue: Yet if you were to suppose one thing

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: What is that?
children.prevalue: What is that

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Suppose that I thought I was in love, and that I am not.
children.prevalue: Suppose that I thought I was in love and that I am not

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: What! not in love!
children.prevalue: What not in love

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Well, then! if I have acted in a different manner to what others do when they are in love, it is because I do not love; and because my hour has not yet come.
children.prevalue: Well then if I have acted in a different manner to what others do when they are in love it is because I do not love and because my hour has not yet come

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Louise, Louise, said Montalais, take care or I will remind you of the remark you made just now. Raoul is not here; do not overwhelm him while he is absent; be charitable, and if, on closer inspection, you think you do not love him, tell him so, poor fellow! and she began to laugh.
children.prevalue: Louise Louise said Montalais take care or I will remind you of the remark you made just now Raoul is not here do not overwhelm him while he is absent be charitable and if on closer inspection you think you do not love him tell him so poor fellow and she began to laugh

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Louise pitied M. de Guiche just now, said Athenais; would it be possible to detect an explanation of her indifference for the one in this compassion for the other?
children.prevalue: Louise pitied M de Guiche just now said Athenais would it be possible to detect an explanation of her indifference for the one in this compassion for the other

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Say what you please, said La Valliere, sadly; upbraid me as you like, since you do not understand me.
children.prevalue: Say what you please said La Valliere sadly upbraid me as you like since you do not understand me

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Oh! oh! replied Montalais, temper, sorrow, tears; we are jesting, Louise, and are not, I assure you, quite the monsters you suppose. Look at the proud Athenais, as she is called; she does not love M. de Montespan, it is true, but she would be in despair if M. de Montespan did not continue to love her. Look at me; I laugh at M. Malicorne, but the poor fellow whom I laugh at knows precisely when he will be permitted to press his lips upon my hand. And yet the eldest of us is not twenty yet. What a future before us!
children.prevalue: Oh oh replied Montalais temper sorrow tears we are jesting Louise and are not I assure you quite the monsters you suppose Look at the proud Athenais as she is called she does not love M de Montespan it is true but she would be in despair if M de Montespan did not continue to love her Look at me I laugh at M Malicorne but the poor fellow whom I laugh at knows precisely when he will be permitted to press his lips upon my hand And yet the eldest of us is not twenty yet What a future before us

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Silly, silly girls! murmured Louise.
children.prevalue: Silly silly girls murmured Louise

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: You are quite right, said Montalais; and you alone have spoken words of wisdom.
children.prevalue: You are quite right said Montalais and you alone have spoken words of wisdom

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: I do not dispute it, replied Athenais. And so it is clear you do not love poor M. de Bragelonne?
children.prevalue: I do not dispute it replied Athenais And so it is clear you do not love poor M de Bragelonne

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Perhaps she does, said Montalais; she is not yet quite certain of it. But, in any case, listen, Athenais; if M. de Bragelonne is ever free, I will give you a little friendly advice.
children.prevalue: Perhaps she does said Montalais she is not yet quite certain of it But in any case listen Athenais if M de Bragelonne is ever free I will give you a little friendly advice

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: What is that?
children.prevalue: What is that

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: To look at him well before you decide in favor of M. de Montespan.
children.prevalue: To look at him well before you decide in favor of M de Montespan

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Oh! in that way of considering the subject, M. de Bragelonne is not the only one whom one could look at with pleasure; M. de Guiche, for instance, has his value also.
children.prevalue: Oh in that way of considering the subject M de Bragelonne is not the only one whom one could look at with pleasure M de Guiche for instance has his value also

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: He did not distinguish himself this evening, said Montalais; and I know from very good authority that Madame thought him insupportable.
children.prevalue: He did not distinguish himself this evening said Montalais and I know from very good authority that Madame thought him insupportable

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: M. de SaintAignan produced a most brilliant effect, and I am sure that more than one person who saw him dance this evening will not soon forget him. Do you not think so, La Valliere?
children.prevalue: M de SaintAignan produced a most brilliant effect and I am sure that more than one person who saw him dance this evening will not soon forget him Do you not think so La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Why do you ask me? I did not see him, nor do I know him.
children.prevalue: Why do you ask me I did not see him nor do I know him

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: What! you did not see M. de SaintAignan? Don't you know him?
children.prevalue: What you did not see M de SaintAignan Don t you know him

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Come, come, do not affect a virtue more extravagantly excessive than our vanity!you have eyes, I suppose?
children.prevalue: Come come do not affect a virtue more extravagantly excessive than our vanity you have eyes I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Excellent.
children.prevalue: Excellent

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Then you must have seen all those who danced this evening.
children.prevalue: Then you must have seen all those who danced this evening

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Yes, nearly all.
children.prevalue: Yes nearly all

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: That is a very impertinent 'nearly all' for somebody.
children.prevalue: That is a very impertinent nearly all for somebody

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: You must take it for what it is worth.
children.prevalue: You must take it for what it is worth

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Very well; now, among all those gentlemen whom you saw, which do you prefer?
children.prevalue: Very well now among all those gentlemen whom you saw which do you prefer

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Yes, said Montalais, is it M. de SaintAignan, or M. de Guiche, or M.
children.prevalue: Yes said Montalais is it M de SaintAignan or M de Guiche or M

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: I prefer no one; I thought them all about the same.
children.prevalue: I prefer no one I thought them all about the same

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Do you mean, then, that among that brilliant assembly, the first court in the world, no one pleased you?
children.prevalue: Do you mean then that among that brilliant assembly the first court in the world no one pleased you

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: I do not say that.
children.prevalue: I do not say that

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Tell us, then, who your ideal is?
children.prevalue: Tell us then who your ideal is

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: It is not an ideal being.
children.prevalue: It is not an ideal being

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: He exists, then?
children.prevalue: He exists then

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: In very truth, exclaimed La Valliere, aroused and excited; I cannot understand you at all. What! you who have a heart as I have, eyes as I have, and yet you speak of M. de Guiche, of M. de SaintAignan, when the king was there. These words, uttered in a precipitate manner, and in an agitated, fervid tone of voice, made her two companions, between whom she was seated, exclaim in a manner that terrified her, The king!
children.prevalue: In very truth exclaimed La Valliere aroused and excited I cannot understand you at all What you who have a heart as I have eyes as I have and yet you speak of M de Guiche of M de SaintAignan when the king was there These words uttered in a precipitate manner and in an agitated fervid tone of voice made her two companions between whom she was seated exclaim in a manner that terrified her The king

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: La Valliere buried her face in her hands. Yes, she murmured; the king! the king! Have you ever seen any one to be compared to the king?
children.prevalue: La Valliere buried her face in her hands Yes she murmured the king the king Have you ever seen any one to be compared to the king

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: You were right just now in saying you had excellent eyes, Louise, for you see a great distance; too far, indeed. Alas! the king is not one upon whom our poor eyes have a right to hinge themselves.
