children.prevalue: You were right just now in saying you had excellent eyes Louise for you see a great distance too far indeed Alas the king is not one upon whom our poor eyes have a right to hinge themselves

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: That is too true, cried La Valliere; it is not the privilege of all eyes to gaze upon the sun; but I will look upon him, even were I to be blinded in doing so. At this moment, and as though caused by the words which had just escaped La Valliere's lips, a rustling of leaves, and of what sounded like some silken material, was heard behind the adjoining bushes. The young girls hastily rose, almost terrified out of their senses. They distinctly saw the leaves move, without being able to see what it was that stirred them.
children.prevalue: That is too true cried La Valliere it is not the privilege of all eyes to gaze upon the sun but I will look upon him even were I to be blinded in doing so At this moment and as though caused by the words which had just escaped La Valliere s lips a rustling of leaves and of what sounded like some silken material was heard behind the adjoining bushes The young girls hastily rose almost terrified out of their senses They distinctly saw the leaves move without being able to see what it was that stirred them

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: It is a wolf or a wild boar, cried Montalais; fly! fly! The three girls, in the extremity of terror, fled by the first path that presented itself, and did not stop until they had reached the verge of the wood. There, breathless, leaning against each other, feeling their hearts throb wildly, they endeavored to collect their senses, but could only succeed in doing so after the lapse of some minutes. Perceiving at last the lights from the windows of the chateau, they decided to walk towards them. La Valliere was exhausted with fatigue, and Aure and Athenais were obliged to support her.
children.prevalue: It is a wolf or a wild boar cried Montalais fly fly The three girls in the extremity of terror fled by the first path that presented itself and did not stop until they had reached the verge of the wood There breathless leaning against each other feeling their hearts throb wildly they endeavored to collect their senses but could only succeed in doing so after the lapse of some minutes Perceiving at last the lights from the windows of the chateau they decided to walk towards them La Valliere was exhausted with fatigue and Aure and Athenais were obliged to support her

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: We have escaped well, said Montalais.
children.prevalue: We have escaped well said Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: I am greatly afraid, said La Valliere, that it was something worse than a wolf. For my part, and I speak as I think, I should have preferred to have run the risk of being devoured alive by some wild animal than to have been listened to and overheard. Fool, fool that I am! How could I have thought, how could I have said what I did? And saying this her head bowed like the water tossed plume of a bulrush; she felt her limbs fail, and her strength abandoning her, and, gliding almost inanimate from the arms of her companions, sank down upon the turf.
children.prevalue: I am greatly afraid said La Valliere that it was something worse than a wolf For my part and I speak as I think I should have preferred to have run the risk of being devoured alive by some wild animal than to have been listened to and overheard Fool fool that I am How could I have thought how could I have said what I did And saying this her head bowed like the water tossed plume of a bulrush she felt her limbs fail and her strength abandoning her and gliding almost inanimate from the arms of her companions sank down upon the turf

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Let us leave poor La Valliere, who had fainted in the arms of her two companions, and return to the precincts of the royal oak. The young girls had hardly run twenty paces, when the sound which had so much alarmed them was renewed among the branches. A man's figure might indistinctly be perceived, and putting the branches of the bushes aside, he appeared upon the verge of the wood, and perceiving that the place was empty, burst out into a peal of laughter. It is almost superfluous to add that the form in question was that of a young and handsome cavalier, who immediately made a sign to another, who thereupon made his appearance.
children.prevalue: Let us leave poor La Valliere who had fainted in the arms of her two companions and return to the precincts of the royal oak The young girls had hardly run twenty paces when the sound which had so much alarmed them was renewed among the branches A man s figure might indistinctly be perceived and putting the branches of the bushes aside he appeared upon the verge of the wood and perceiving that the place was empty burst out into a peal of laughter It is almost superfluous to add that the form in question was that of a young and handsome cavalier who immediately made a sign to another who thereupon made his appearance

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: What, sire, said the second figure, advancing timidly, has your majesty put our young sentimentalists to flight?
children.prevalue: What sire said the second figure advancing timidly has your majesty put our young sentimentalists to flight

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: It seems so, said the king, and you can show yourself without fear.
children.prevalue: It seems so said the king and you can show yourself without fear

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Take care, sire, you will be recognized.
children.prevalue: Take care sire you will be recognized

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: But I tell you they are flown.
children.prevalue: But I tell you they are flown

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: This is a most fortunate meeting, sire; and, if I dared offer an opinion to your majesty, we ought to follow them.
children.prevalue: This is a most fortunate meeting sire and if I dared offer an opinion to your majesty we ought to follow them

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: They are far enough away by this time.
children.prevalue: They are far enough away by this time

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: They would quickly allow themselves to be overtaken, especially if they knew who were following them.
children.prevalue: They would quickly allow themselves to be overtaken especially if they knew who were following them

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: What do you mean by that, coxcomb that you are?
children.prevalue: What do you mean by that coxcomb that you are

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Why, one of them seems to have taken a fancy to me, and another compared you to the sun.
children.prevalue: Why one of them seems to have taken a fancy to me and another compared you to the sun

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The greater reason why we should not show ourselves, SaintAignan. The sun never shows itself in the nighttime.
children.prevalue: The greater reason why we should not show ourselves SaintAignan The sun never shows itself in the nighttime

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Upon my word, sire, your majesty seems to have very little curiosity. In your place, I should like to know who are the two nymphs, the two dryads, the two hamadryads, who have so good an opinion of us.
children.prevalue: Upon my word sire your majesty seems to have very little curiosity In your place I should like to know who are the two nymphs the two dryads the two hamadryads who have so good an opinion of us

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I shall know them again very well, I assure you, without running after them.
children.prevalue: I shall know them again very well I assure you without running after them

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: By what means?
children.prevalue: By what means

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: By their voices, of course. They belong to the court, and the one who spoke of me had a remarkably sweet voice.
children.prevalue: By their voices of course They belong to the court and the one who spoke of me had a remarkably sweet voice

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Ah! your majesty permits yourself to be influenced by flattery.
children.prevalue: Ah your majesty permits yourself to be influenced by flattery

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: No one will ever say it is a means you make use of.
children.prevalue: No one will ever say it is a means you make use of

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Forgive my stupidity, sire.
children.prevalue: Forgive my stupidity sire

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Come; let us go and look where I told you.
children.prevalue: Come let us go and look where I told you

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Is the passion, then, which your majesty confided to me, already forgotten?
children.prevalue: Is the passion then which your majesty confided to me already forgotten

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Oh! no, indeed. How is it possible to forget such beautiful eyes as Mademoiselle de la Valliere has?
children.prevalue: Oh no indeed How is it possible to forget such beautiful eyes as Mademoiselle de la Valliere has

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Yet the other one has a beautiful voice.
children.prevalue: Yet the other one has a beautiful voice

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Which one?
children.prevalue: Which one

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The lady who has fallen in love with the sun.
children.prevalue: The lady who has fallen in love with the sun

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: M. de SaintAignan!
children.prevalue: M de SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Forgive me, sire.
children.prevalue: Forgive me sire

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Well, I am not sorry you should believe me to be an admirer of sweet voices as well as of beautiful eyes. I know you to be a terrible talker, and tomorrow I shall have to pay for the confidence I have shown you.
children.prevalue: Well I am not sorry you should believe me to be an admirer of sweet voices as well as of beautiful eyes I know you to be a terrible talker and tomorrow I shall have to pay for the confidence I have shown you

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: What do you mean, sire?
children.prevalue: What do you mean sire

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: That tomorrow every one will know that I have designs upon this little La Valliere; but be careful, SaintAignan, I have confided my secret to no one but you, and if any one should speak to me about it, I shall know who has betrayed my secret.
children.prevalue: That tomorrow every one will know that I have designs upon this little La Valliere but be careful SaintAignan I have confided my secret to no one but you and if any one should speak to me about it I shall know who has betrayed my secret

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: You are angry, sire.
children.prevalue: You are angry sire

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: No; but you understand I do not wish to compromise the poor girl.
children.prevalue: No but you understand I do not wish to compromise the poor girl

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Do not be afraid, sire.
children.prevalue: Do not be afraid sire

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: You promise me, then?
children.prevalue: You promise me then

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: I give you my word of honor.
children.prevalue: I give you my word of honor

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Excellent, thought the king, laughing to himself; now every one will know tomorrow that I have been running about after La Valliere tonight.
children.prevalue: Excellent thought the king laughing to himself now every one will know tomorrow that I have been running about after La Valliere tonight

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Then, endeavoring to see where he was, he said: Why we have lost ourselves.
children.prevalue: Then endeavoring to see where he was he said Why we have lost ourselves

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Not quite so bad as that, sire.
children.prevalue: Not quite so bad as that sire

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Where does that gate lead to?
children.prevalue: Where does that gate lead to

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: To RondPoint, sire.
children.prevalue: To RondPoint sire

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Where were we going when we heard the sound of women's voices?
children.prevalue: Where were we going when we heard the sound of women s voices

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Yes, sire, and the termination of a conversation in which I had the honor of hearing my own name pronounced by the side of your majesty's.
children.prevalue: Yes sire and the termination of a conversation in which I had the honor of hearing my own name pronounced by the side of your majesty s

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: You return to that subject too frequently, SaintAignan.
children.prevalue: You return to that subject too frequently SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Your majesty will forgive me, but I am delighted to know that a woman exists whose thoughts are occupied about me, without my knowledge, and without my having done anything to deserve it. Your majesty cannot comprehend this satisfaction, for your rank and merit attract attention, and compel regard.
children.prevalue: Your majesty will forgive me but I am delighted to know that a woman exists whose thoughts are occupied about me without my knowledge and without my having done anything to deserve it Your majesty cannot comprehend this satisfaction for your rank and merit attract attention and compel regard

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: No, no, SaintAignan, believe me or not, as you like, said the king, leaning familiarly upon SaintAignan's arm and taking the path he thought would lead them to the chateau; but this candid confession, this perfectly disinterested preference of one who will, perhaps, never attract my attentionin one word, the mystery of this adventure excites me, and the truth is, that if I were not so taken with La Valliere
children.prevalue: No no SaintAignan believe me or not as you like said the king leaning familiarly upon SaintAignan s arm and taking the path he thought would lead them to the chateau but this candid confession this perfectly disinterested preference of one who will perhaps never attract my attentionin one word the mystery of this adventure excites me and the truth is that if I were not so taken with La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Do not let that interfere with your majesty's intentions: you have time enough before you.
children.prevalue: Do not let that interfere with your majesty s intentions you have time enough before you

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: What do you mean?
children.prevalue: What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: La Valliere is said to be very strict in her ideas.
children.prevalue: La Valliere is said to be very strict in her ideas

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: You excite my curiosity and I am anxious to see her again. Come, let us walk on.
children.prevalue: You excite my curiosity and I am anxious to see her again Come let us walk on

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: The king spoke untruly, for nothing, on the contrary, could make him less anxious, but he had a part to play, and so he walked on hurriedly. SaintAignan followed him at a short distance. Suddenly the king stopped; the courtier followed his example.
children.prevalue: The king spoke untruly for nothing on the contrary could make him less anxious but he had a part to play and so he walked on hurriedly SaintAignan followed him at a short distance Suddenly the king stopped the courtier followed his example

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: SaintAignan, he said, do you not hear some one moaning?
children.prevalue: SaintAignan he said do you not hear some one moaning

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Yes, sire, and weeping, too, it seems.
children.prevalue: Yes sire and weeping too it seems

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: It is in this direction, said the king. It sounds like the tears and sobs of a woman.
children.prevalue: It is in this direction said the king It sounds like the tears and sobs of a woman

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Run, said the king; and, following a bypath, they ran across the grass. As they approached, the cries were more distinctly heard.
children.prevalue: Run said the king and following a bypath they ran across the grass As they approached the cries were more distinctly heard

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Help, help, exclaimed two voices. The king and his companion redoubled their speed, and, as they approached nearer, the sighs they had heard were changed into loud sobs. The cry of Help! help! was again repeated; at the sound of which, the king and SaintAignan increased the rapidity of their pace. Suddenly at the other side of a ditch, under the branches of a willow, they perceived a woman on her knees, holding another in her arms who seemed to have fainted. A few paces from them, a third, standing in the middle of the path, was calling for assistance. Perceiving the two gentlemen, whose rank she could not tell, her cries for assistance were redoubled. The king, who was in advance of his companion, leaped across the ditch, and reached the group at the very moment when, from the end of the path which led to the chateau, a dozen persons were approaching, who had been drawn to the spot by the same cries that had attracted the attention of the king and M. de SaintAignan.
children.prevalue: Help help exclaimed two voices The king and his companion redoubled their speed and as they approached nearer the sighs they had heard were changed into loud sobs The cry of Help help was again repeated at the sound of which the king and SaintAignan increased the rapidity of their pace Suddenly at the other side of a ditch under the branches of a willow they perceived a woman on her knees holding another in her arms who seemed to have fainted A few paces from them a third standing in the middle of the path was calling for assistance Perceiving the two gentlemen whose rank she could not tell her cries for assistance were redoubled The king who was in advance of his companion leaped across the ditch and reached the group at the very moment when from the end of the path which led to the chateau a dozen persons were approaching who had been drawn to the spot by the same cries that had attracted the attention of the king and M de SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: What is the matter, young ladies? said Louis.
children.prevalue: What is the matter young ladies said Louis

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: The king! exclaimed Mademoiselle de Montalais, in her astonishment, letting La Valliere's head fall upon the ground.
children.prevalue: The king exclaimed Mademoiselle de Montalais in her astonishment letting La Valliere s head fall upon the ground

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Yes, it is the king; but that is no reason why you should abandon your companion. Who is she?
children.prevalue: Yes it is the king but that is no reason why you should abandon your companion Who is she

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: It is Mademoiselle de la Valliere, sire.
children.prevalue: It is Mademoiselle de la Valliere sire

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Mademoiselle de la Valliere!
children.prevalue: Mademoiselle de la Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Yes, sire, she has just fainted.
children.prevalue: Yes sire she has just fainted

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Poor child! said the king. Quick, quick, fetch a surgeon. But however great the anxiety with which the king had pronounced these words may have seemed to others, he had not so carefully schooled himself but that they appeared, as well as the gesture which accompanied them, somewhat cold to SaintAignan, to whom the king had confided the sudden love with which she had inspired him.
children.prevalue: Poor child said the king Quick quick fetch a surgeon But however great the anxiety with which the king had pronounced these words may have seemed to others he had not so carefully schooled himself but that they appeared as well as the gesture which accompanied them somewhat cold to SaintAignan to whom the king had confided the sudden love with which she had inspired him

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: SaintAignan, continued the king, watch over Mademoiselle de la Valliere, I beg. Send for a surgeon. I will hasten forward and inform Madame of the accident which has befallen one of her maids of honor. And, in fact, while M. de SaintAignan was busily engaged in making preparations for carrying Mademoiselle de la Valliere to the chateau, the king hurried forward, happy to have an opportunity of approaching Madame, and of speaking to her under a colorable pretext. Fortunately, a carriage was passing; the coachman was told to stop, and the persons who were inside, having been informed of the accident, eagerly gave up their seats to Mademoiselle de la Valliere. The current of fresh air produced by the rapid motion of the carriage soon recalled her to her senses. Having reached the chateau, she was able, though very weak, to alight from the carriage, and, with the assistance of Athenais and of Montalais, to reach the inner apartments. They made her sit down in one of the rooms of the ground floor. After a while, as the accident had not produced much effect upon those who had been walking, the promenade was resumed. During this time, the king had found Madame beneath a tree with overhanging branches, and had seated himself by her side.
children.prevalue: SaintAignan continued the king watch over Mademoiselle de la Valliere I beg Send for a surgeon I will hasten forward and inform Madame of the accident which has befallen one of her maids of honor And in fact while M de SaintAignan was busily engaged in making preparations for carrying Mademoiselle de la Valliere to the chateau the king hurried forward happy to have an opportunity of approaching Madame and of speaking to her under a colorable pretext Fortunately a carriage was passing the coachman was told to stop and the persons who were inside having been informed of the accident eagerly gave up their seats to Mademoiselle de la Valliere The current of fresh air produced by the rapid motion of the carriage soon recalled her to her senses Having reached the chateau she was able though very weak to alight from the carriage and with the assistance of Athenais and of Montalais to reach the inner apartments They made her sit down in one of the rooms of the ground floor After a while as the accident had not produced much effect upon those who had been walking the promenade was resumed During this time the king had found Madame beneath a tree with overhanging branches and had seated himself by her side

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Take care, sire, said Henrietta to him, in a low tone, you do not show yourself as indifferent as you ought to be.
children.prevalue: Take care sire said Henrietta to him in a low tone you do not show yourself as indifferent as you ought to be

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Alas! replied the king, in the same tone, I much fear we have entered into an agreement above our strength to keep. He then added aloud, You have heard of the accident, I suppose?
children.prevalue: Alas replied the king in the same tone I much fear we have entered into an agreement above our strength to keep He then added aloud You have heard of the accident I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: What accident?
children.prevalue: What accident

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Oh! in seeing you I forgot I hurried here expressly to tell you of it. I am, however, painfully affected by it; one of your maids of honor, Mademoiselle de la Valliere, has just fainted.
children.prevalue: Oh in seeing you I forgot I hurried here expressly to tell you of it I am however painfully affected by it one of your maids of honor Mademoiselle de la Valliere has just fainted

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Indeed! poor girl, said the princess, quietly, what was the cause of it?
children.prevalue: Indeed poor girl said the princess quietly what was the cause of it

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: She then added in an undertone, You forget, sire, that you wish others to believe in your passion for this girl, and yet you remain here while she is almost dying, perhaps, elsewhere.
children.prevalue: She then added in an undertone You forget sire that you wish others to believe in your passion for this girl and yet you remain here while she is almost dying perhaps elsewhere

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Ah! Madame, said the king, sighing, how much more perfect you are in your part than I am, and how actively you think of everything.
children.prevalue: Ah Madame said the king sighing how much more perfect you are in your part than I am and how actively you think of everything

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: He then rose, saying loud enough for every one to hear him, Permit me to leave you, Madame; my uneasiness is very great, and I wish to be quite certain, myself, that proper attention has been given to Mademoiselle de la Valliere. And the king left again to return to La Valliere, while those who had been present commented upon the king's remark:My uneasiness is very great.
children.prevalue: He then rose saying loud enough for every one to hear him Permit me to leave you Madame my uneasiness is very great and I wish to be quite certain myself that proper attention has been given to Mademoiselle de la Valliere And the king left again to return to La Valliere while those who had been present commented upon the king s remark My uneasiness is very great

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: On his way Louis met the Comte de SaintAignan. Well, SaintAignan, he inquired, with affected interest, how is the invalid.
children.prevalue: On his way Louis met the Comte de SaintAignan Well SaintAignan he inquired with affected interest how is the invalid

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Really, sire, stammered SaintAignan, to my shame, I confess I do not know.
children.prevalue: Really sire stammered SaintAignan to my shame I confess I do not know

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: What! you do not know? said the king, pretending to take in a serious manner this want of attention for the object of his predilection.
children.prevalue: What you do not know said the king pretending to take in a serious manner this want of attention for the object of his predilection

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Will your majesty pardon me; but I have just met one of our three loquacious woodnymphs, and I confess that my attention has been taken away from other matters.
children.prevalue: Will your majesty pardon me but I have just met one of our three loquacious woodnymphs and I confess that my attention has been taken away from other matters

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Ah! said the king, eagerly, you have found, then
children.prevalue: Ah said the king eagerly you have found then

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The one who deigned to speak of me in such advantageous terms; and, having found mine, I was searching for yours, sire, when I had the happiness to meet your majesty.
children.prevalue: The one who deigned to speak of me in such advantageous terms and having found mine I was searching for yours sire when I had the happiness to meet your majesty

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Very well; but Mademoiselle de la Valliere before everything else, said the king, faithful to the character he had assumed.
children.prevalue: Very well but Mademoiselle de la Valliere before everything else said the king faithful to the character he had assumed

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Oh! our charming invalid! said SaintAignan; how fortunately her fainting fit came on, since your majesty had already occupied yourself about her.
children.prevalue: Oh our charming invalid said SaintAignan how fortunately her fainting fit came on since your majesty had already occupied yourself about her

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: What is the name of your fair lady, SaintAignan? Is it a secret?
children.prevalue: What is the name of your fair lady SaintAignan Is it a secret

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: It ought to be a secret, and a very great one, even; but your majesty is well aware that no secret can possibly exist for you.
children.prevalue: It ought to be a secret and a very great one even but your majesty is well aware that no secret can possibly exist for you

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Well, what is her name?
children.prevalue: Well what is her name

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente.
children.prevalue: Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Is she pretty?
children.prevalue: Is she pretty

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Exceedingly, sire; and I recognized the voice which pronounced my name in such tender accents. I accosted her, questioned her as well as I was able to do, in the midst of the crowd; and she told me, without suspecting anything, that a little while ago she was under the great oak, with her two friends, when the sound of a wolf or a robber had terrified them, and made them run away.
children.prevalue: Exceedingly sire and I recognized the voice which pronounced my name in such tender accents I accosted her questioned her as well as I was able to do in the midst of the crowd and she told me without suspecting anything that a little while ago she was under the great oak with her two friends when the sound of a wolf or a robber had terrified them and made them run away

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: But, inquired the king, anxiously, what are the names of these two friends?
children.prevalue: But inquired the king anxiously what are the names of these two friends

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Sire, said SaintAignan, will your majesty send me forthwith to the Bastile?
children.prevalue: Sire said SaintAignan will your majesty send me forthwith to the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: What for?
children.prevalue: What for

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Because I am an egotist and a fool. My surprise was so great at such a conquest, and at so fortunate a discovery, that I went no further in my inquiries. Besides, I did not think that your majesty would attach any very great importance to what you heard, knowing how much your attention was taken up by Mademoiselle de la Valliere; and then, Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente left me precipitately, to return to Mademoiselle de la Valliere.
children.prevalue: Because I am an egotist and a fool My surprise was so great at such a conquest and at so fortunate a discovery that I went no further in my inquiries Besides I did not think that your majesty would attach any very great importance to what you heard knowing how much your attention was taken up by Mademoiselle de la Valliere and then Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente left me precipitately to return to Mademoiselle de la Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Let us hope, then, that I shall be as fortunate as yourself. Come, SaintAignan.
children.prevalue: Let us hope then that I shall be as fortunate as yourself Come SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Your majesty is ambitions, I perceive, and does not wish to allow any conquest to escape you. Well, I assure you that I will conscientiously set about my inquiries; and, moreover, from one or the other of those Three Graces we shall learn the names of the rest, and by the names their secrets.
children.prevalue: Your majesty is ambitions I perceive and does not wish to allow any conquest to escape you Well I assure you that I will conscientiously set about my inquiries and moreover from one or the other of those Three Graces we shall learn the names of the rest and by the names their secrets

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I, too, said the king, only require to hear her voice to know it again. Come, let us say no more about it, but show me where poor La Valliere is.
children.prevalue: I too said the king only require to hear her voice to know it again Come let us say no more about it but show me where poor La Valliere is

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Well, thought SaintAignan, the king's regard is beginning to display itself, and for that girl too. It is extraordinary; I should never have believed it. And with this thought passing through his mind, he showed the king the room to which La Valliere had been carried; the king entered, followed by SaintAignan. In a low chamber, near a large window looking out upon the gardens, La Valliere, reclining in a large armchair, was inhaling deep draughts of the perfumed evening breeze. From the loosened body of her dress, the lace fell in tumbled folds, mingling with the tresses of her beautiful fair hair, which lay scattered upon her shoulders. Her languishing eyes were filled with tears; she seemed as lifeless as those beautiful visions of our dreams, that pass before the mental eye of the sleeper, halfopening their wings without moving them, unclosing their lips without a sound escaping them. The pearllike pallor of La Valliere possessed a charm it would be impossible to describe. Mental and bodily suffering had produced upon her features a soft and noble expression of grief; from the perfect passiveness of her arms and bust, she more resembled one whose soul had passed away, than a living being; she seemed not to hear either of the whisperings which arose from the court. She seemed to be communing within herself; and her beautiful, delicate hands trembled from time to time as though at the contact of some invisible touch. She was so completely absorbed in her reverie, that the king entered without her perceiving him. At a distance he gazed upon her lovely face, upon which the moon shed its pure silvery light.
children.prevalue: Well thought SaintAignan the king s regard is beginning to display itself and for that girl too It is extraordinary I should never have believed it And with this thought passing through his mind he showed the king the room to which La Valliere had been carried the king entered followed by SaintAignan In a low chamber near a large window looking out upon the gardens La Valliere reclining in a large armchair was inhaling deep draughts of the perfumed evening breeze From the loosened body of her dress the lace fell in tumbled folds mingling with the tresses of her beautiful fair hair which lay scattered upon her shoulders Her languishing eyes were filled with tears she seemed as lifeless as those beautiful visions of our dreams that pass before the mental eye of the sleeper halfopening their wings without moving them unclosing their lips without a sound escaping them The pearllike pallor of La Valliere possessed a charm it would be impossible to describe Mental and bodily suffering had produced upon her features a soft and noble expression of grief from the perfect passiveness of her arms and bust she more resembled one whose soul had passed away than a living being she seemed not to hear either of the whisperings which arose from the court She seemed to be communing within herself and her beautiful delicate hands trembled from time to time as though at the contact of some invisible touch She was so completely absorbed in her reverie that the king entered without her perceiving him At a distance he gazed upon her lovely face upon which the moon shed its pure silvery light

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Good Heavens! he exclaimed, with a terror he could not control, she is dead.
children.prevalue: Good Heavens he exclaimed with a terror he could not control she is dead

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: No, sire, said Montalais, in a low voice; on the contrary, she is better. Are you not better, Louise?
children.prevalue: No sire said Montalais in a low voice on the contrary she is better Are you not better Louise

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: But Louise did not answer. Louise, continued Montalais, the king has deigned to express his uneasiness on your account.
children.prevalue: But Louise did not answer Louise continued Montalais the king has deigned to express his uneasiness on your account

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The king! exclaimed Louise, starting up abruptly, as if a stream of fire had started through her frame to her heart; the king uneasy about me?
children.prevalue: The king exclaimed Louise starting up abruptly as if a stream of fire had started through her frame to her heart the king uneasy about me

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Yes, said Montalais.
children.prevalue: Yes said Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: The king is here, then? said La Valliere, not venturing to look round her.
children.prevalue: The king is here then said La Valliere not venturing to look round her

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: That voice! that voice! whispered Louis, eagerly, to SaintAignan.
children.prevalue: That voice that voice whispered Louis eagerly to SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Yes, it is so, replied SaintAignan; your majesty is right; it is she who declared her love for the sun.
children.prevalue: Yes it is so replied SaintAignan your majesty is right it is she who declared her love for the sun

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Hush! said the king. And then approaching La Valliere, he said, You are not well, Mademoiselle de la Valliere? Just now, indeed, in the park, I saw that you had fainted. How were you attacked?
children.prevalue: Hush said the king And then approaching La Valliere he said You are not well Mademoiselle de la Valliere Just now indeed in the park I saw that you had fainted How were you attacked

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Sire, stammered out the poor child, pale and trembling, I really do not know.
children.prevalue: Sire stammered out the poor child pale and trembling I really do not know

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: You have been walking too far, said the king; and fatigue, perhaps
children.prevalue: You have been walking too far said the king and fatigue perhaps

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: No, sire, said Montalais, eagerly, answering for her friend, it could not be from fatigue, for we passed most of the evening seated beneath the royal oak.
children.prevalue: No sire said Montalais eagerly answering for her friend it could not be from fatigue for we passed most of the evening seated beneath the royal oak

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Under the royal oak? returned the king, starting. I was not deceived; it is as I thought. And he directed a look of intelligence at the comte.
children.prevalue: Under the royal oak returned the king starting I was not deceived it is as I thought And he directed a look of intelligence at the comte

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Yes, said SaintAignan, under the royal oak, with Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente.
children.prevalue: Yes said SaintAignan under the royal oak with Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: How do you know that? inquired Montalais.
children.prevalue: How do you know that inquired Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: In a very simple way. Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente told me so.
children.prevalue: In a very simple way Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente told me so

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: In that case, she probably told you the cause of Mademoiselle de la Valliere's fainting?
children.prevalue: In that case she probably told you the cause of Mademoiselle de la Valliere s fainting

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Why, yes; she told me something about a wolf or a robber. I forget precisely which. La Valliere listened, her eyes fixed, her bosom heaving, as if, gifted with an acuteness of perception, she foresaw a portion of the truth. Louis imagined this attitude and agitation to be the consequence of a terror only partially reassured. Nay, fear nothing, he said, with a rising emotion which he could not conceal; the wolf which terrified you so much was simply a wolf with two legs.
children.prevalue: Why yes she told me something about a wolf or a robber I forget precisely which La Valliere listened her eyes fixed her bosom heaving as if gifted with an acuteness of perception she foresaw a portion of the truth Louis imagined this attitude and agitation to be the consequence of a terror only partially reassured Nay fear nothing he said with a rising emotion which he could not conceal the wolf which terrified you so much was simply a wolf with two legs

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: It was a man, then! said Louise; it was a man who was listening?
children.prevalue: It was a man then said Louise it was a man who was listening

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Suppose it was so, mademoiselle, what great harm was there in his having listened? Is it likely that, even in your own opinion, you would have said anything which could not have been listened to?
children.prevalue: Suppose it was so mademoiselle what great harm was there in his having listened Is it likely that even in your own opinion you would have said anything which could not have been listened to

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: La Valliere wrung her hands, and hid her face in them, as if to hide her blushes. In Heaven's name, she said, who was concealed there? Who was listening?
children.prevalue: La Valliere wrung her hands and hid her face in them as if to hide her blushes In Heaven s name she said who was concealed there Who was listening

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: The king advanced towards her, to take hold of one of her hands. It was I, he said, bowing with marked respect. Is it likely I could have frightened you? La Valliere uttered a loud cry; for the second time her strength forsook her; and moaning in utter despair, she again fell lifeless in her chair. The king had just time to hold out his arm; so that she was partially supported by him. Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente and Montalais, who stood a few paces from the king and La Valliere, motionless and almost petrified at the recollection of their conversation with La Valliere, did not even think of offering their assistance, feeling restrained by the presence of the king, who, with one knee on the ground, held La Valliere round the waist with his arm.
children.prevalue: The king advanced towards her to take hold of one of her hands It was I he said bowing with marked respect Is it likely I could have frightened you La Valliere uttered a loud cry for the second time her strength forsook her and moaning in utter despair she again fell lifeless in her chair The king had just time to hold out his arm so that she was partially supported by him Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente and Montalais who stood a few paces from the king and La Valliere motionless and almost petrified at the recollection of their conversation with La Valliere did not even think of offering their assistance feeling restrained by the presence of the king who with one knee on the ground held La Valliere round the waist with his arm

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: You heard, sire! murmured Athenais. But the king did not reply; he remained with his eyes fixed upon La Valliere's halfclosed eyes, and held her quiescent hand in his own.
children.prevalue: You heard sire murmured Athenais But the king did not reply he remained with his eyes fixed upon La Valliere s halfclosed eyes and held her quiescent hand in his own

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Of course, replied SaintAignan, who, on his side, hoping that Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, too, would faint, advancing towards her, holding his arms extended,of course; we did not even lose a single word. But the haughty Athenais was not a woman to faint easily; she darted a terrible look at SaintAignan, and fled. Montalais, with more courage, advanced hurriedly towards Louise, and received her from the king's hands, who was already fast losing his presence of mind, as he felt his face covered by the perfumed tresses of the seemingly dying girl. Excellent, whispered SaintAignan. This is indeed an adventure; and it will be my own fault if I am not the first to relate it.
children.prevalue: Of course replied SaintAignan who on his side hoping that Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente too would faint advancing towards her holding his arms extended of course we did not even lose a single word But the haughty Athenais was not a woman to faint easily she darted a terrible look at SaintAignan and fled Montalais with more courage advanced hurriedly towards Louise and received her from the king s hands who was already fast losing his presence of mind as he felt his face covered by the perfumed tresses of the seemingly dying girl Excellent whispered SaintAignan This is indeed an adventure and it will be my own fault if I am not the first to relate it

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: The king approached him, and, with a trembling voice and a passionate gesture, said, Not a syllable, comte.
children.prevalue: The king approached him and with a trembling voice and a passionate gesture said Not a syllable comte

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The poor king forgot that, only an hour before, he had given him a similar recommendation, but with the very opposite intention; namely, that the comte should be indiscreet. It followed, as a matter of course, that he latter recommendation was quite as unnecessary as the former. Half an hour afterwards, everybody in Fontainebleau knew that Mademoiselle de la Valliere had had a conversation under the royal oak with Montalais and TonnayCharente, and that in this conversation she had confessed her affection for the king. It was known, also, that the king, after having manifested the uneasiness with which Mademoiselle de la Valliere's health had inspired him, had turned pale, and trembled very much as he received the beautiful girl fainting into his arms; so that it was quite agreed among the courtiers, that the greatest event of the period had just been revealed; that his majesty loved Mademoiselle de la Valliere, and that, consequently, Monsieur could now sleep in perfect tranquillity. It was this, even, that the queenmother, as surprised as the others by the sudden change, hastened to tell the young queen and Philip d'Orleans. Only she set to work in a different manner, by attacking them in the following way:To her daughterinlaw she said, See, now, Therese, how very wrong you were to accuse the king; now it is said he is devoted to some other person; why should there be any greater truth in the report of today than in that of yesterday, or in that of yesterday than in that of today? To Monsieur, in relating to him the adventure of the royal oak, she said, Are you not very absurd in your jealousies, my dear Philip? It is asserted that the king is madly in love with that little La Valliere. Say nothing of it to your wife; for the queen will know all about it very soon. This latter confidential communication had an immediate result. Monsieur, who had regained his composure, went triumphantly to look after his wife, and it was not yet midnight and the fete was to continue until two in the morning, he offered her his hand for a promenade. At the end of a few paces, however, the first thing he did was to disobey his mother's injunctions.

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Do not tell any one, the queen least of all, he said mysteriously, what people say about the king.
children.prevalue: Do not tell any one the queen least of all he said mysteriously what people say about the king

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: What do they say about him? inquired Madame.
children.prevalue: What do they say about him inquired Madame

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: That my brother has suddenly fallen in love.
children.prevalue: That my brother has suddenly fallen in love

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: With whom?
children.prevalue: With whom

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: With Mademoiselle de la Valliere.
children.prevalue: With Mademoiselle de la Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: As it was dark, Madame could smile at her ease.
children.prevalue: As it was dark Madame could smile at her ease

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Ah! she said, and how long is it since this has been the case?
children.prevalue: Ah she said and how long is it since this has been the case

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: For some days, it seems. But that was nothing but nonsense; it is only this evening that he has revealed his passion.
children.prevalue: For some days it seems But that was nothing but nonsense it is only this evening that he has revealed his passion

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: The king shows his good taste, said Madame; in my opinion she is a very charming girl.
children.prevalue: The king shows his good taste said Madame in my opinion she is a very charming girl

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: I verily believe you are jesting.
children.prevalue: I verily believe you are jesting

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: I! in what way?
children.prevalue: I in what way

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: In any case this passion will make some one very happy, even if it be only La Valliere herself.
children.prevalue: In any case this passion will make some one very happy even if it be only La Valliere herself

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Really, continued the princess, you speak as if you had read into the inmost recesses of La Valliere's heart. Who has told you that she agrees to return the king's affection?
children.prevalue: Really continued the princess you speak as if you had read into the inmost recesses of La Valliere s heart Who has told you that she agrees to return the king s affection

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: And who has told you that she will not return it?
children.prevalue: And who has told you that she will not return it

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: She loves the Vicomte de Bragelonne.
children.prevalue: She loves the Vicomte de Bragelonne

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: You think so?
children.prevalue: You think so

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: She is even affianced to him.
children.prevalue: She is even affianced to him

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: She was so.
children.prevalue: She was so

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: What do you mean?
children.prevalue: What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: When they went to ask the king's permission to arrange the marriage, he refused his permission.
children.prevalue: When they went to ask the king s permission to arrange the marriage he refused his permission

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Refused?
children.prevalue: Refused

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Yes, although the request was preferred by the Comte de la Fere himself, for whom the king has the greatest regard, on account of the part he took in your royal brother's restoration, and in other events, also, which happened a long time ago.
children.prevalue: Yes although the request was preferred by the Comte de la Fere himself for whom the king has the greatest regard on account of the part he took in your royal brother s restoration and in other events also which happened a long time ago

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Well! the poor lovers must wait until the king is pleased to change his opinion; they are young, and there is time enough.
children.prevalue: Well the poor lovers must wait until the king is pleased to change his opinion they are young and there is time enough

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: But, dear me, said Philip, laughing, I perceive you do not know the best part of the affair.
children.prevalue: But dear me said Philip laughing I perceive you do not know the best part of the affair

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: No!
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: That by which the king was most deeply touched.
children.prevalue: That by which the king was most deeply touched

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: The king, do you say, has been deeply touched?
children.prevalue: The king do you say has been deeply touched

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: To the very quick of his heart.
children.prevalue: To the very quick of his heart

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: But how?in what manner?tell me directly.
children.prevalue: But how in what manner tell me directly

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: By an adventure, the romance of which cannot be equalled.
children.prevalue: By an adventure the romance of which cannot be equalled

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: You know how I love to hear of such adventures, and yet you keep me waiting, said the princess, impatiently.
children.prevalue: You know how I love to hear of such adventures and yet you keep me waiting said the princess impatiently

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Well, then and Monsieur paused.
children.prevalue: Well then and Monsieur paused

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: I am listening.
children.prevalue: I am listening

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Under the royal oakyou know where the royal oak is?
children.prevalue: Under the royal oakyou know where the royal oak is

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: What can that matter? Under the royal oak, you were saying?
children.prevalue: What can that matter Under the royal oak you were saying

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Well! Mademoiselle de la Valliere, fancying herself to be alone with her two friends, revealed to them her affection for the king.
children.prevalue: Well Mademoiselle de la Valliere fancying herself to be alone with her two friends revealed to them her affection for the king

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Ah! said Madame, beginning to be uneasy, her affection for the king?
children.prevalue: Ah said Madame beginning to be uneasy her affection for the king

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: When was this?
children.prevalue: When was this

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: About an hour ago.
children.prevalue: About an hour ago

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Madame started, and then said, And no one knew of this affection?
children.prevalue: Madame started and then said And no one knew of this affection

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: No one.
children.prevalue: No one

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Not even his majesty?
children.prevalue: Not even his majesty

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Not even his majesty. The artful little puss kept her secret strictly to herself, when suddenly it proved stronger than herself, and so escaped her.
children.prevalue: Not even his majesty The artful little puss kept her secret strictly to herself when suddenly it proved stronger than herself and so escaped her

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: And from whom did you get this absurd tale?
children.prevalue: And from whom did you get this absurd tale

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Why, as everybody else did, from La Valliere herself, who confessed her love to Montalais and TonnayCharente, who were her companions.
children.prevalue: Why as everybody else did from La Valliere herself who confessed her love to Montalais and TonnayCharente who were her companions

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Madame stopped suddenly, and by a hasty movement let go her husband's hand.
children.prevalue: Madame stopped suddenly and by a hasty movement let go her husband s hand

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Did you say it was an hour ago she made this confession? Madame inquired.
children.prevalue: Did you say it was an hour ago she made this confession Madame inquired

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: About that time.
children.prevalue: About that time

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Is the king aware of it?
children.prevalue: Is the king aware of it

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Why, that is the very thing which constitutes the perfect romance of the affair, for the king was behind the royal oak with SaintAignan, and heard the whole of the interesting conversation without losing a single word of it.
children.prevalue: Why that is the very thing which constitutes the perfect romance of the affair for the king was behind the royal oak with SaintAignan and heard the whole of the interesting conversation without losing a single word of it

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Madame felt struck to the heart, saying incautiously, But I have seen the king since, and he never told me a word about it.
children.prevalue: Madame felt struck to the heart saying incautiously But I have seen the king since and he never told me a word about it

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Of course, said Monsieur; he took care not to speak of it to you himself, since he recommended every one not to say a word about it.
children.prevalue: Of course said Monsieur he took care not to speak of it to you himself since he recommended every one not to say a word about it

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: What do you mean? said Madame, growing angry.
children.prevalue: What do you mean said Madame growing angry

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: I mean that they wished to keep you in ignorance of the affair altogether.
children.prevalue: I mean that they wished to keep you in ignorance of the affair altogether

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: But why should they wish to conceal it from me?
children.prevalue: But why should they wish to conceal it from me

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: From the fear that your friendship for the young queen might induce you to say something about it to her, nothing more.
children.prevalue: From the fear that your friendship for the young queen might induce you to say something about it to her nothing more

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Madame hung down her head; her feelings were grievously wounded. She could not enjoy a moment's repose until she had met the king. As a king is, most naturally, the very last person in his kingdom who knows what is said about him, in the same way that a lover is the only one who is kept in ignorance of what is said about his mistress, therefore, when the king perceived Madame, who was looking for him, he approached her in some perturbation, but still gracious and attentive in his manner. Madame waited for him to speak about La Valliere first; but as he did not speak of her, she said, And the poor girl?
children.prevalue: Madame hung down her head her feelings were grievously wounded She could not enjoy a moment s repose until she had met the king As a king is most naturally the very last person in his kingdom who knows what is said about him in the same way that a lover is the only one who is kept in ignorance of what is said about his mistress therefore when the king perceived Madame who was looking for him he approached her in some perturbation but still gracious and attentive in his manner Madame waited for him to speak about La Valliere first but as he did not speak of her she said And the poor girl

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: What poor girl? said the king.
children.prevalue: What poor girl said the king

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: La Valliere. Did you not tell me, sire, that she had fainted?
children.prevalue: La Valliere Did you not tell me sire that she had fainted

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: She is still very ill, said the king, affecting the greatest indifference.
children.prevalue: She is still very ill said the king affecting the greatest indifference

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: But surely that will prejudicially affect the rumor you were going to spread, sire?
children.prevalue: But surely that will prejudicially affect the rumor you were going to spread sire

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: What rumor?
children.prevalue: What rumor

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: That your attention was taken up by her.
children.prevalue: That your attention was taken up by her

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Oh! said the king, carelessly, I trust it will be reported all the same.
children.prevalue: Oh said the king carelessly I trust it will be reported all the same

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Madame still waited; she wished to know if the king would speak to her of the adventure of the royal oak. But the king did not say a word about it. Madame, on her side, did not open her lips about it; so that the king took leave of her without having reposed the slightest confidence in her. Hardly had she watched the king move away, than she set out in search of SaintAignan. SaintAignan was never very difficult to find; he was like the smaller vessels that always follow in the wake of, and as tenders to, the larger ships. SaintAignan was the very man whom Madame needed in her then state of mind. And as for him, he only looked for worthier ears than others he had found to have an opportunity of recounting the event in all its details. And so he did not spare Madame a single word of the whole affair. When he had finished, Madame said to him, Confess, now, that is his all a charming invention.

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Invention, no; a true story, yes.
children.prevalue: Invention no a true story yes

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Confess, whether invention or true story, that it was told to you as you have told it to me, but that you were not there.
children.prevalue: Confess whether invention or true story that it was told to you as you have told it to me but that you were not there

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Upon my honor, Madame, I was there.
children.prevalue: Upon my honor Madame I was there

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: And you think that these confessions may have made an impression on the king?
children.prevalue: And you think that these confessions may have made an impression on the king

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Certainly, as those of Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente did upon me, replied SaintAignan; do not forget, Madame, that Mademoiselle de la Valliere compared the king to the sun; that was flattering enough.
children.prevalue: Certainly as those of Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente did upon me replied SaintAignan do not forget Madame that Mademoiselle de la Valliere compared the king to the sun that was flattering enough

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: The king does not permit himself to be influenced by such flatteries.
children.prevalue: The king does not permit himself to be influenced by such flatteries

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Madame, the king is just as much Adonis as Apollo; and I saw plain enough just now when La Valliere fell into his arms.
children.prevalue: Madame the king is just as much Adonis as Apollo and I saw plain enough just now when La Valliere fell into his arms

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: La Valliere fell into the king's arms!
children.prevalue: La Valliere fell into the king s arms

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: Oh! it was the most graceful picture possible; just imagine, La Valliere had fallen back fainting, and
children.prevalue: Oh it was the most graceful picture possible just imagine La Valliere had fallen back fainting and

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: Well! what did you see?tell mespeak!
children.prevalue: Well what did you see tell mespeak

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: I saw what ten other people saw at the same time as myself; I saw that when La Valliere fell into his arms, the king almost fainted himself.
children.prevalue: I saw what ten other people saw at the same time as myself I saw that when La Valliere fell into his arms the king almost fainted himself

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: Madame smothered a subdued cry, the only indication of her smothered anger.
children.prevalue: Madame smothered a subdued cry the only indication of her smothered anger

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: Thank you, she said, laughing in a convulsive manner, you relate stories delightfully, M. de SaintAignan. And she hurried away, alone, and almost suffocated by painful emotion, towards the chateau.
children.prevalue: Thank you she said laughing in a convulsive manner you relate stories delightfully M de SaintAignan And she hurried away alone and almost suffocated by painful emotion towards the chateau

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Monsieur quitted the princess in the best possible humor, and feeling greatly fatigued, retired to his apartments, leaving every one to finish the night as he chose. When in his room, Monsieur began to dress for the night with careful attention, which displayed itself from time to time in paroxysms of satisfaction. While his attendants were engaged in curling his hair, he sang the principal airs of the ballet which the violins had played, and to which the king had danced. He then summoned his tailors, inspected his costumes for the next day, and, in token of his extreme satisfaction, distributed various presents among them. As, however, the Chevalier de Lorraine, who had seen the prince return to the chateau, entered the room, Monsieur overwhelmed him with kindness. The former, after having saluted the prince, remained silent for a moment, like a sharpshooter who deliberates before deciding in what direction he will renew his fire; then, seeming to make up his mind, he said, Have you remarked a very singular coincidence, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: Monsieur quitted the princess in the best possible humor and feeling greatly fatigued retired to his apartments leaving every one to finish the night as he chose When in his room Monsieur began to dress for the night with careful attention which displayed itself from time to time in paroxysms of satisfaction While his attendants were engaged in curling his hair he sang the principal airs of the ballet which the violins had played and to which the king had danced He then summoned his tailors inspected his costumes for the next day and in token of his extreme satisfaction distributed various presents among them As however the Chevalier de Lorraine who had seen the prince return to the chateau entered the room Monsieur overwhelmed him with kindness The former after having saluted the prince remained silent for a moment like a sharpshooter who deliberates before deciding in what direction he will renew his fire then seeming to make up his mind he said Have you remarked a very singular coincidence monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: No; what is it?
children.prevalue: No what is it

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The bad reception which his majesty, in appearance, gave the Comte de Guiche.
children.prevalue: The bad reception which his majesty in appearance gave the Comte de Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: In appearance?
children.prevalue: In appearance

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Yes, certainly; since, in reality, he has restored him to favor.
children.prevalue: Yes certainly since in reality he has restored him to favor

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: I did not notice it, said the prince.
children.prevalue: I did not notice it said the prince

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: What, did you not remark, that, instead of ordering him to go away again into exile, as was natural, he encouraged him in his opposition by permitting him to resume his place in the ballet?
children.prevalue: What did you not remark that instead of ordering him to go away again into exile as was natural he encouraged him in his opposition by permitting him to resume his place in the ballet

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: And you think the king was wrong, chevalier? said the prince.
children.prevalue: And you think the king was wrong chevalier said the prince

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Are you not of my opinion, prince?
children.prevalue: Are you not of my opinion prince

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Not altogether so, my dear chevalier; and I think the king was quite right not to have made a disturbance against a poor fellow whose want of judgment is more to be complained of than his intention.
children.prevalue: Not altogether so my dear chevalier and I think the king was quite right not to have made a disturbance against a poor fellow whose want of judgment is more to be complained of than his intention

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Really, said the chevalier, as far as I am concerned, I confess that this magnanimity astonishes me to the highest degree.
children.prevalue: Really said the chevalier as far as I am concerned I confess that this magnanimity astonishes me to the highest degree

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Why so? inquired Philip.
children.prevalue: Why so inquired Philip

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Because I should have thought the king had been more jealous, replied the chevalier, spitefully. During the last few minutes Monsieur had felt there was something of an irritating nature concealed under his favorite's remarks; this last word, however, ignited the powder.
children.prevalue: Because I should have thought the king had been more jealous replied the chevalier spitefully During the last few minutes Monsieur had felt there was something of an irritating nature concealed under his favorite s remarks this last word however ignited the powder

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Jealous! exclaimed the prince. Jealous! what do you mean? Jealous of what, if you pleaseor jealous of whom?
children.prevalue: Jealous exclaimed the prince Jealous what do you mean Jealous of what if you pleaseor jealous of whom

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The chevalier perceived that he had allowed an excessively mischievous remark to escape him, as he was in the habit of doing. He endeavored, therefore, apparently to recall it while it was still possible to do so. Jealous of his authority, he said, with an assumed frankness; of what else would you have the king jealous?
children.prevalue: The chevalier perceived that he had allowed an excessively mischievous remark to escape him as he was in the habit of doing He endeavored therefore apparently to recall it while it was still possible to do so Jealous of his authority he said with an assumed frankness of what else would you have the king jealous

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Ah! said the prince, that's very proper.
children.prevalue: Ah said the prince that s very proper

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Did your royal highness, continued the chevalier, solicit dear De Guiche's pardon?
children.prevalue: Did your royal highness continued the chevalier solicit dear De Guiche s pardon

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: No, indeed, said Monsieur. De Guiche is an excellent fellow, and full of courage; but as I do not approve of his conduct with Madame, I wish him neither harm nor good.
children.prevalue: No indeed said Monsieur De Guiche is an excellent fellow and full of courage but as I do not approve of his conduct with Madame I wish him neither harm nor good

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The chevalier had assumed a bitterness with regard to De Guiche, as he had attempted to do with regard to the king; but he thought he perceived that the time for indulgence, and even for the utmost indifference, had arrived, and that, in order to throw some light on the question, it might be necessary for him to put the lamp, as the saying is, beneath the husband's very nose.
children.prevalue: The chevalier had assumed a bitterness with regard to De Guiche as he had attempted to do with regard to the king but he thought he perceived that the time for indulgence and even for the utmost indifference had arrived and that in order to throw some light on the question it might be necessary for him to put the lamp as the saying is beneath the husband s very nose

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Very well, very well, said the chevalier to himself, I must wait for De Wardes; he will do more in one day than I in a month; for I verily believe he is even more envious than I. Then, again, it is not De Wardes I require so much as that some event or another should happen; and in the whole of this affair I see none. That De Guiche returned after he had been sent away is certainly serious enough, but all its seriousness disappears when I learn that De Guiche has returned at the very moment Madame troubles herself no longer about him. Madame, in fact, is occupied with the king, that is clear; but she will not be so much longer if, as it is asserted, the king has ceased to trouble his head about her. The moral of the whole matter is, to remain perfectly neutral, and await the arrival of some new caprice and let that decide the whole affair. And the chevalier thereupon settled himself resignedly in the armchair in which Monsieur permitted him to seat himself in his presence, and, having no more spiteful or malicious remarks to make, the consequence was that De Lorraine's wit seemed to have deserted him. Most fortunately Monsieur was in high goodhumor, and he had enough for two, until the time arrived for dismissing his servants and gentlemen of the chamber, and he passed into his sleepingapartment. As he withdrew, he desired the chevalier to present his compliments to Madame, and say that, as the night was cool, Monsieur, who was afraid of the toothache, would not venture out again into the park during the remainder of the evening. The chevalier entered the princess's apartments at the very moment she came in herself. He acquitted himself faithfully of the commission intrusted to him, and, in the first place, remarked all the indifference and annoyance with which Madame received her husband's communicationa circumstance which appeared to him fraught with something fresh. If Madame had been about to leave her apartments with that strangeness of manner, he would have followed her; but she was returning to them; there was nothing to be done, therefore he turned upon his heel like an unemployed heron, appearing to question earth, air, and water about it; shook his head, and walked away mechanically in the direction of the gardens. He had hardly gone a hundred paces when he met two young men, walking arm in arm, with their heads bent down, and idly kicking the small stones out of their path as they walked on, plunged in thought. It was De Guiche and De Bragelonne, the sight of whom, as it always did, produced upon the chevalier, instinctively, a feeling of repugnance. He did not, however, the less, on that account, salute them with a very low bow, which they returned with interest. Then, observing that the park was nearly deserted, that the illuminations began to burn out, and that the morning breeze was setting in, he turned to the left, and entered the chateau again, by one of the smaller courtyards. The others turned aside to the right, and continued on their way towards the large park. As the chevalier was ascending the side staircase, which led to the private entrance, he saw a woman, followed by another, make her appearance under the arcade which led from the small to the large courtyard. The two women walked so fast that the rustling of their dresses could be distinguished through the silence of the night. The style of their mantles, their graceful figures, a mysterious yet haughty carriage which distinguished them both, especially the one who walked first, struck the chevalier.
