children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I certainly know those two, he said to himself, pausing upon the top step of the small staircase. Then, as with the instinct of a bloodhound he was about to follow them, one of the servants who had been running after him arrested his attention.
children.prevalue: I certainly know those two he said to himself pausing upon the top step of the small staircase Then as with the instinct of a bloodhound he was about to follow them one of the servants who had been running after him arrested his attention

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Monsieur, he said, the courier has arrived.
children.prevalue: Monsieur he said the courier has arrived

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Very well, said the chevalier, there is time enough; tomorrow will do.
children.prevalue: Very well said the chevalier there is time enough tomorrow will do

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: There are some urgent letters which you would be glad to see, perhaps.
children.prevalue: There are some urgent letters which you would be glad to see perhaps

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Where from? inquired the chevalier.
children.prevalue: Where from inquired the chevalier

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: One from England, and the other from Calais; the latter arrived by express, and seems of great importance.
children.prevalue: One from England and the other from Calais the latter arrived by express and seems of great importance

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: From Calais! Who the deuce can have to write to me from Calais?
children.prevalue: From Calais Who the deuce can have to write to me from Calais

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I think I recognize the handwriting of Monsieur le Comte de Wardes.
children.prevalue: I think I recognize the handwriting of Monsieur le Comte de Wardes

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Oh! cried the chevalier, forgetting his intention of acting the spy, in that case I will come up at once. This he did, while the two unknown beings disappeared at the end of the court opposite to the one by which they had just entered. We shall now follow them, and leave the chevalier undisturbed to his correspondence. When they had arrived at the grove of trees, the foremost of the two halted, somewhat out of breath, and, cautiously raising her hood, said, Are we still far from the tree?
children.prevalue: Oh cried the chevalier forgetting his intention of acting the spy in that case I will come up at once This he did while the two unknown beings disappeared at the end of the court opposite to the one by which they had just entered We shall now follow them and leave the chevalier undisturbed to his correspondence When they had arrived at the grove of trees the foremost of the two halted somewhat out of breath and cautiously raising her hood said Are we still far from the tree

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Yes, Madame, more than five hundred paces; but pray rest awhile, you will not be able to walk much longer at this rate.
children.prevalue: Yes Madame more than five hundred paces but pray rest awhile you will not be able to walk much longer at this rate

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: You are right, said the princes, for it was she; and she leaned against a tree. And now, she resumed, after having recovered her breath, tell me the whole truth, and conceal nothing from me.
children.prevalue: You are right said the princes for it was she and she leaned against a tree And now she resumed after having recovered her breath tell me the whole truth and conceal nothing from me

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Oh, Madame, cried the young girl, you are already angry with me.
children.prevalue: Oh Madame cried the young girl you are already angry with me

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: No, my dear Athenais, reassure yourself, I am in no way angry with you. After all, these things do not concern me personally. You are anxious about what you may have said under the oak; you are afraid of having offended the king, and I wish to tranquillize you by ascertaining myself if it were possible you could have been overheard.
children.prevalue: No my dear Athenais reassure yourself I am in no way angry with you After all these things do not concern me personally You are anxious about what you may have said under the oak you are afraid of having offended the king and I wish to tranquillize you by ascertaining myself if it were possible you could have been overheard

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Oh, yes, Madame, the king was close to us.
children.prevalue: Oh yes Madame the king was close to us

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Still, you were not speaking so loud that some of your remarks may not have been lost.
children.prevalue: Still you were not speaking so loud that some of your remarks may not have been lost

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: We thought we were quite alone, Madame.
children.prevalue: We thought we were quite alone Madame

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: There were three of you, you say?
children.prevalue: There were three of you you say

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Yes; La Valliere, Montalais, and myself.
children.prevalue: Yes La Valliere Montalais and myself

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: And you, individually, spoke in a light manner of the king?
children.prevalue: And you individually spoke in a light manner of the king

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I am afraid so. Should such be the case, will your highness have the kindness to make my peace with his majesty?
children.prevalue: I am afraid so Should such be the case will your highness have the kindness to make my peace with his majesty

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: If there should be any occasion for it, I promise you I will do so. However, as I have already told you, it will be better not to anticipate evil. The night is now very dark, and the darkness is still greater under the trees. It is not likely you were recognized by the king. To inform him of it, by being the first to speak, is to denounce yourself.
children.prevalue: If there should be any occasion for it I promise you I will do so However as I have already told you it will be better not to anticipate evil The night is now very dark and the darkness is still greater under the trees It is not likely you were recognized by the king To inform him of it by being the first to speak is to denounce yourself

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Oh, Madame, Madame! if Mademoiselle de la Valliere were recognized, I must have been recognized also. Besides, M. de SaintAignan left no doubt on the subject.
children.prevalue: Oh Madame Madame if Mademoiselle de la Valliere were recognized I must have been recognized also Besides M de SaintAignan left no doubt on the subject

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Did you, then, say anything very disrespectful of the king?
children.prevalue: Did you then say anything very disrespectful of the king

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Not at all; it was one of the others who made some very flattering speeches about the king; and my remarks must have been much in contrast with hers.
children.prevalue: Not at all it was one of the others who made some very flattering speeches about the king and my remarks must have been much in contrast with hers

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Montalais is such a giddy girl, said Madame.
children.prevalue: Montalais is such a giddy girl said Madame

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: It was not Montalais. Montalais said nothing; it was La Valliere.
children.prevalue: It was not Montalais Montalais said nothing it was La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Madame started as if she had not known it perfectly well already. No, no, she said, the king cannot have heard. Besides, we will now try the experiment for which we came out. Show me the oak. Do you know where it is? she continued.
children.prevalue: Madame started as if she had not known it perfectly well already No no she said the king cannot have heard Besides we will now try the experiment for which we came out Show me the oak Do you know where it is she continued

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Alas! Madame, yes.
children.prevalue: Alas Madame yes

children.name: Paragraph_49

children.prevalue: And you can find it again

children.name: Paragraph_50

children.prevalue: With my eyes shut

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Very well; sit down on the bank where you were, where La Valliere was, and speak in the same tone and to the same effect as you did before; I will conceal myself in the thicket, and if I can hear you, I will tell you so.
children.prevalue: Very well sit down on the bank where you were where La Valliere was and speak in the same tone and to the same effect as you did before I will conceal myself in the thicket and if I can hear you I will tell you so

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Yes, Madame.
children.prevalue: Yes Madame

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: If, therefore, you really spoke loud enough for the king to have heard you, in that case
children.prevalue: If therefore you really spoke loud enough for the king to have heard you in that case

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Athenais seemed to await the conclusion of the sentence with some anxiety.
children.prevalue: Athenais seemed to await the conclusion of the sentence with some anxiety

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: In that case, said Madame, in a suffocated voice, arising doubtless from her hurried progress, in that case, I forbid you And Madame again increased her pace. Suddenly, however, she stopped. An idea occurs to me, she said.
children.prevalue: In that case said Madame in a suffocated voice arising doubtless from her hurried progress in that case I forbid you And Madame again increased her pace Suddenly however she stopped An idea occurs to me she said

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: A good idea, no doubt, Madame, replied Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente.
children.prevalue: A good idea no doubt Madame replied Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Montalais must be as much embarrassed as La Valliere and yourself.
children.prevalue: Montalais must be as much embarrassed as La Valliere and yourself

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Less so, for she is less compromised, having said less.
children.prevalue: Less so for she is less compromised having said less

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: That does not matter; she will help you, I dare say, by deviating a little from the exact truth.
children.prevalue: That does not matter she will help you I dare say by deviating a little from the exact truth

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Especially if she knows that your highness is kind enough to interest yourself about me.
children.prevalue: Especially if she knows that your highness is kind enough to interest yourself about me

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Very well, I think I have discovered what it is best for you all to pretend.
children.prevalue: Very well I think I have discovered what it is best for you all to pretend

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: How delightful.
children.prevalue: How delightful

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: You had better say that all three of you were perfectly well aware that the king was behind the tree, or behind the thicket, whichever it might have been; and that you knew M. de SaintAignan was there too.
children.prevalue: You had better say that all three of you were perfectly well aware that the king was behind the tree or behind the thicket whichever it might have been and that you knew M de SaintAignan was there too

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Yes, Madame.
children.prevalue: Yes Madame

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: For you cannot disguise it from yourself, Athenais, SaintAignan takes advantage of some very flattering remarks you made about him.
children.prevalue: For you cannot disguise it from yourself Athenais SaintAignan takes advantage of some very flattering remarks you made about him

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Well, Madame, you see very clearly that one can be overheard, cried Athenais, since M. de SaintAignan overheard us.
children.prevalue: Well Madame you see very clearly that one can be overheard cried Athenais since M de SaintAignan overheard us

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Madame bit her lips, for she had thoughtlessly committed herself. Oh, you know SaintAignan's character very well, she said, the favor the king shows him almost turns his brain, and he talks at random; not only so, he very often invents. That is not the question; the fact remains, did or did not the king overhear?

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Oh, yes, Madame, he certainly did, said Athenais, in despair.
children.prevalue: Oh yes Madame he certainly did said Athenais in despair

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: In that case, do what I said: maintain boldly that all three of you knewmind, all three of you, for if there is a doubt about any one of you, there will be a doubt about all,persist, I say, that you knew that the king and M. de SaintAignan were there, and that you wished to amuse yourself at the expense of those who were listening.

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Oh, Madame, at the king's expense; we shall never dare say that!
children.prevalue: Oh Madame at the king s expense we shall never dare say that

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: It is a simple jest; an innocent deception readily permitted in young girls whom men wish to take by surprise. In this manner everything explains itself. What Montalais said of Malicorne, a mere jest; what you said of M. de SaintAignan, a mere jest too; and what La Valliere might have said of
children.prevalue: It is a simple jest an innocent deception readily permitted in young girls whom men wish to take by surprise In this manner everything explains itself What Montalais said of Malicorne a mere jest what you said of M de SaintAignan a mere jest too and what La Valliere might have said of

children.prevalue: Are you sure of that

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Perfectly.
children.prevalue: Perfectly

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Very well, an additional reason. Say the whole affair was a mere joke. M. de Malicorne will have no occasion to get out of temper; M. de SaintAignan will be completely put out of countenance; he will be laughed at instead of you; and lastly, the king will be punished for a curiosity unworthy of his rank. Let people laugh a little at the king in this affair, and I do not think he will complain of it.

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Oh, Madame, you are indeed an angel of goodness and sense!
children.prevalue: Oh Madame you are indeed an angel of goodness and sense

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: It is to my own advantage.
children.prevalue: It is to my own advantage

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: In what way?
children.prevalue: In what way

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: How can you ask me why it is to my advantage to spare my maids of honor the remarks, annoyances, perhaps even calumnies, that might follow? Alas! you well know that the court has no indulgence for this sort of peccadillo. But we have now been walking for some time, shall we be long before we reach it?

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: About fifty or sixty paces further; turn to the left, Madame, if you please.

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: And you are sure of Montalais? said Madame.
children.prevalue: And you are sure of Montalais said Madame

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Oh, certainly.
children.prevalue: Oh certainly

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Will she do what you ask her?
children.prevalue: Will she do what you ask her

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Everything. She will be delighted.
children.prevalue: Everything She will be delighted

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: And La Valliere ventured the princess.
children.prevalue: And La Valliere ventured the princess

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Ah, there will be some difficulty with her, Madame; she would scorn to tell a falsehood.
children.prevalue: Ah there will be some difficulty with her Madame she would scorn to tell a falsehood

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Yet, when it is in her interest to do so
children.prevalue: Yet when it is in her interest to do so

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: I am afraid that that would not make the slightest difference in her ideas.
children.prevalue: I am afraid that that would not make the slightest difference in her ideas

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Yes, yes, said Madame. I have been already told that; she is one of those overnice and affectedly particular people who place heaven in the foreground in order to conceal themselves behind it. But if she refuses to tell a falsehood,as she will expose herself to the jests of the whole court, as she will have annoyed the king by a confession as ridiculous as it was immodest,Mademoiselle la Baume le Blanc de la Valliere will think it but proper I should send her back again to her pigeons in the country, in order that, in Touraine yonder, or in Le Blaisois,I know not where it may be,she may at her ease study sentiment and pastoral life combined.

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: These words were uttered with a vehemence and harshness that terrified Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente; and the consequence was, that, as far as she was concerned, she promised to tell as many falsehoods as might be necessary. It was in this frame of mind that Madame and her companion reached the precincts of the royal oak.

children.value: We shall soon learn if one can overhear, replied Madame.
children.prevalue: We shall soon learn if one can overhear replied Madame

children.value: Hush! whispered the young girl, holding Madame back with a hurried gesture, entirely forgetful of her companion's rank. Madame stopped.
children.prevalue: Hush whispered the young girl holding Madame back with a hurried gesture entirely forgetful of her companion s rank Madame stopped

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: You see that you can hear, said Athenais.
children.prevalue: You see that you can hear said Athenais

children.prevalue: How

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Listen.
children.prevalue: Listen

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Madame held her breath; and, in fact, the following words pronounced by a gentle and melancholy voice, floated towards them:
children.prevalue: Madame held her breath and in fact the following words pronounced by a gentle and melancholy voice floated towards them

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: I tell you, vicomte, I tell you I love her madly; I tell you I love her to distraction.
children.prevalue: I tell you vicomte I tell you I love her madly I tell you I love her to distraction

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Madame started at the voice; and, beneath her hood, a bright joyous smile illumined her features. It was she who now held back her companion, and with a light step leading her some twenty paces away, that is to say, out of the reach of the voice, she said, Remain here, my dear Athenais, and let no one surprise us. I think it must be you they are conversing about.
children.prevalue: Madame started at the voice and beneath her hood a bright joyous smile illumined her features It was she who now held back her companion and with a light step leading her some twenty paces away that is to say out of the reach of the voice she said Remain here my dear Athenais and let no one surprise us I think it must be you they are conversing about

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Me, Madame?
children.prevalue: Me Madame

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Yes, youor rather your adventure. I will go and listen; if we were both there, we should be discovered. Or, stay!go and fetch Montalais, and then return and wait for me with her at the entrance of the forest. And then, as Athenais hesitated, she again said Go! in a voice which did not admit of reply. Athenais thereupon arranged her dress so as to prevent its rustling being heard; and, by a path beyond the group of trees, she regained the flowergarden. As for Madame, she concealed herself in the thicket, leaning her back against a gigantic chestnuttree, one of the branches of which had been cut in such a manner as to form a seat, and waited there, full of anxiety and apprehension. Now, she said, since one can hear from this place, let us listen to what M. de Bragelonne and that other madlyinlove fool, the Comte de Guiche, have to say about me.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: There was a moment's silence, as if the mysterious sounds of night were hushed to listen, at the same time as Madame, to the youthful passionate disclosures of De Guiche.
children.prevalue: There was a moment s silence as if the mysterious sounds of night were hushed to listen at the same time as Madame to the youthful passionate disclosures of De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Raoul was about to speak. He leaned indolently against the trunk of the large oak, and replied in his sweet and musical voice, Alas, my dear De Guiche, it is a great misfortune.
children.prevalue: Raoul was about to speak He leaned indolently against the trunk of the large oak and replied in his sweet and musical voice Alas my dear De Guiche it is a great misfortune

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Yes, cried the latter, great indeed.
children.prevalue: Yes cried the latter great indeed

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: You do not understand me, De Guiche. I say that it is a great misfortune for you, not merely loving, but not knowing how to conceal your love.
children.prevalue: You do not understand me De Guiche I say that it is a great misfortune for you not merely loving but not knowing how to conceal your love

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: What do you mean? said De Guiche.
children.prevalue: What do you mean said De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Yes, you do not perceive one thing; namely, that it is no longer to the only friend you have,in other words,to a man who would rather die than betray you; you do not perceive, I say, that it is no longer to your only friend that you confide your passion, but to the first person that approaches you.
children.prevalue: Yes you do not perceive one thing namely that it is no longer to the only friend you have in other words to a man who would rather die than betray you you do not perceive I say that it is no longer to your only friend that you confide your passion but to the first person that approaches you

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Are you mad, Bragelonne, exclaimed De Guiche, to say such a thing to me?
children.prevalue: Are you mad Bragelonne exclaimed De Guiche to say such a thing to me

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The fact stands thus, however.
children.prevalue: The fact stands thus however

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Impossible! How, in what manner can I have ever been indiscreet to such an extent?
children.prevalue: Impossible How in what manner can I have ever been indiscreet to such an extent

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I mean, that your eyes, your looks, your sighs, proclaim, in spite of yourself, that exaggerated feeling which leads and hurries a man beyond his own control. In such a case he ceases to be master of himself; he is a prey to a mad passion, that makes him confide his grief to the trees, or to the air, from the very moment he has no longer any living being in reach of his voice. Besides, remember this: it very rarely happens that there is not always some one present to hear, especially the very things which ought not to be heard. De Guiche uttered a deep sigh. Nay, continued Bragelonne, you distress me; since your return here, you have a thousand times, and in a thousand different ways, confessed your love for her; and yet, had you not said one word, your return alone would have been a terrible indiscretion. I persist, then, in drawing this conclusion; that if you do not place a better watch over yourself than you have hitherto done, one day or other something will happen that will cause an explosion. Who will save you then? Answer me. Who will save her? for, innocent as she will be of your affection, your affection will be an accusation against her in the hands of her enemies.
children.prevalue: I mean that your eyes your looks your sighs proclaim in spite of yourself that exaggerated feeling which leads and hurries a man beyond his own control In such a case he ceases to be master of himself he is a prey to a mad passion that makes him confide his grief to the trees or to the air from the very moment he has no longer any living being in reach of his voice Besides remember this it very rarely happens that there is not always some one present to hear especially the very things which ought not to be heard De Guiche uttered a deep sigh Nay continued Bragelonne you distress me since your return here you have a thousand times and in a thousand different ways confessed your love for her and yet had you not said one word your return alone would have been a terrible indiscretion I persist then in drawing this conclusion that if you do not place a better watch over yourself than you have hitherto done one day or other something will happen that will cause an explosion Who will save you then Answer me Who will save her for innocent as she will be of your affection your affection will be an accusation against her in the hands of her enemies

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Alas! murmured De Guiche; and a deep sigh accompanied the exclamation.
children.prevalue: Alas murmured De Guiche and a deep sigh accompanied the exclamation

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: That is not answering me, De Guiche.
children.prevalue: That is not answering me De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Yes, yes.
children.prevalue: Yes yes

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Well, what reply have you to make?
children.prevalue: Well what reply have you to make

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: This, that when the day arrives I shall be no more a living being than I feel myself now.
children.prevalue: This that when the day arrives I shall be no more a living being than I feel myself now

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: I do not understand you.
children.prevalue: I do not understand you

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: So many vicissitudes have worn me out. At present, I am no more a thinking, acting being; at present, the most worthless of men is better than I am; my remaining strength is exhausted, my latestformed resolutions have vanished, and I abandon myself to my fate. When a man is out campaigning, as we have been together, and he sets off alone and unaccompanied for a skirmish, it sometimes happens that he may meet with a party of five or six foragers, and although alone, he defends himself; afterwards, five or six others arrive unexpectedly, his anger is aroused and he persists; but if six, eight, or ten others should still be met with, he either sets spurs to his horse, if he should still happen to retain one, or lets himself be slain to save an ignominious flight. Such, indeed, is my own case: first, I had to struggle against myself; afterwards, against Buckingham; now, since the king is in the field, I will not contend against the king, nor even, I wish you to understand, will the king retire; nor even against the nature of that woman. Still I do not deceive myself; having devoted myself to the service of such a love, I will lose my life in it.
children.prevalue: So many vicissitudes have worn me out At present I am no more a thinking acting being at present the most worthless of men is better than I am my remaining strength is exhausted my latestformed resolutions have vanished and I abandon myself to my fate When a man is out campaigning as we have been together and he sets off alone and unaccompanied for a skirmish it sometimes happens that he may meet with a party of five or six foragers and although alone he defends himself afterwards five or six others arrive unexpectedly his anger is aroused and he persists but if six eight or ten others should still be met with he either sets spurs to his horse if he should still happen to retain one or lets himself be slain to save an ignominious flight Such indeed is my own case first I had to struggle against myself afterwards against Buckingham now since the king is in the field I will not contend against the king nor even I wish you to understand will the king retire nor even against the nature of that woman Still I do not deceive myself having devoted myself to the service of such a love I will lose my life in it

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: It is not the lady you ought to reproach, replied Raoul; it is yourself.
children.prevalue: It is not the lady you ought to reproach replied Raoul it is yourself

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Why so?
children.prevalue: Why so

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: You know the princess's character,somewhat giddy, easily captivated by novelty, susceptible to flattery, whether it come from a blind person or a child, and yet you allow your passion for her to eat your very life away. Look at her,love her, if you will,for no one whose heart is not engaged elsewhere can see her without loving her. Yet, while you love her, respect, in the first place, her husband's rank, then herself, and lastly, your own safety.
children.prevalue: You know the princess s character somewhat giddy easily captivated by novelty susceptible to flattery whether it come from a blind person or a child and yet you allow your passion for her to eat your very life away Look at her love her if you will for no one whose heart is not engaged elsewhere can see her without loving her Yet while you love her respect in the first place her husband s rank then herself and lastly your own safety

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Thanks, Raoul.
children.prevalue: Thanks Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: What for?
children.prevalue: What for

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Because, seeing how much I suffer through this woman, you endeavor to console me, because you tell me all the good of her you think, and perhaps even that which you do not think.
children.prevalue: Because seeing how much I suffer through this woman you endeavor to console me because you tell me all the good of her you think and perhaps even that which you do not think

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Oh, said Raoul, there you are wrong, comte; what I think I do not always say, but in that case I say nothing; but when I speak, I know not how to feign or to deceive; and whoever listens to me may believe me.
children.prevalue: Oh said Raoul there you are wrong comte what I think I do not always say but in that case I say nothing but when I speak I know not how to feign or to deceive and whoever listens to me may believe me

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: During this conversation, Madame, her head stretched forward with eager ear and dilated glance, endeavoring to penetrate the obscurity, thirstily drank in the faintest sound of their voices.
children.prevalue: During this conversation Madame her head stretched forward with eager ear and dilated glance endeavoring to penetrate the obscurity thirstily drank in the faintest sound of their voices

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Oh, I know her better than you do, then! exclaimed Guiche. She is not merely giddy, but frivolous; she is not only attracted by novelty, she is utterly oblivious, and is without faith; she is not simply susceptible to flattery, she is a practiced and cruel coquette. A thorough coquette! yes, yes, I am sure of it. Believe me, Bragelonne, I am suffering all the torments of hell; brave, passionately fond of danger, I meet a danger greater than my strength and my courage. But, believe me, Raoul, I reserve for myself a victory which shall cost her floods of tears.
children.prevalue: Oh I know her better than you do then exclaimed Guiche She is not merely giddy but frivolous she is not only attracted by novelty she is utterly oblivious and is without faith she is not simply susceptible to flattery she is a practiced and cruel coquette A thorough coquette yes yes I am sure of it Believe me Bragelonne I am suffering all the torments of hell brave passionately fond of danger I meet a danger greater than my strength and my courage But believe me Raoul I reserve for myself a victory which shall cost her floods of tears

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: A victory, he asked, and of what kind?
children.prevalue: A victory he asked and of what kind

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Of what kind, you ask?
children.prevalue: Of what kind you ask

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: One day I will accost her, and will address her thus: 'I was young madly in love, I possessed, however, sufficient respect to throw myself at your feet, and to prostrate myself in the dust, if your looks had not raised me to your hand. I fancied I understood your looks, I rose, and then, without having done anything more towards you than love you yet more devotedly, if that were possibleyou, a woman without heart, faith, or love, in very wantonness, dashed me down again from sheer caprice. You are unworthy, princess of the royal blood though you may be, of the love of a man of honor; I offer my life as a sacrifice for having loved you too tenderly, and I die despairing you.'
children.prevalue: One day I will accost her and will address her thus I was young madly in love I possessed however sufficient respect to throw myself at your feet and to prostrate myself in the dust if your looks had not raised me to your hand I fancied I understood your looks I rose and then without having done anything more towards you than love you yet more devotedly if that were possibleyou a woman without heart faith or love in very wantonness dashed me down again from sheer caprice You are unworthy princess of the royal blood though you may be of the love of a man of honor I offer my life as a sacrifice for having loved you too tenderly and I die despairing you

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Oh! cried Raoul, terrified at the accents of profound truth which De Guiche's words betrayed, I was right in saying you were mad, Guiche.
children.prevalue: Oh cried Raoul terrified at the accents of profound truth which De Guiche s words betrayed I was right in saying you were mad Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Yes, yes, exclaimed De Guiche, following out his own idea; since there are no wars here now, I will flee yonder to the north, seek service in the Empire, where some Hungarian, or Croat, or Turk, will perhaps kindly put me out of my misery. De Guiche did not finish, or rather as he finished, a sound made him start, and at the same moment caused Raoul to leap to his feet. As for De Guiche, buried in his own thoughts, he remained seated, with his head tightly pressed between his hands. The branches of the tree were pushed aside, and a woman, pale and much agitated, appeared before the two young men. With one hand she held back the branches, which would have struck her face, and, with the other, she raised the hood of the mantle which covered her shoulders. By her clear and lustrous glance, by her lofty carriage, by her haughty attitude, and, more than all that, by the throbbing of his own heart, De Guiche recognized Madame, and, uttering a loud cry, he removed his hands from his temple, and covered his eyes with them. Raoul, trembling and out of countenance, merely muttered a few words of respect.
children.prevalue: Yes yes exclaimed De Guiche following out his own idea since there are no wars here now I will flee yonder to the north seek service in the Empire where some Hungarian or Croat or Turk will perhaps kindly put me out of my misery De Guiche did not finish or rather as he finished a sound made him start and at the same moment caused Raoul to leap to his feet As for De Guiche buried in his own thoughts he remained seated with his head tightly pressed between his hands The branches of the tree were pushed aside and a woman pale and much agitated appeared before the two young men With one hand she held back the branches which would have struck her face and with the other she raised the hood of the mantle which covered her shoulders By her clear and lustrous glance by her lofty carriage by her haughty attitude and more than all that by the throbbing of his own heart De Guiche recognized Madame and uttering a loud cry he removed his hands from his temple and covered his eyes with them Raoul trembling and out of countenance merely muttered a few words of respect

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Monsieur de Bragelonne, said the princess, have the goodness, I beg, to see if my attendants are not somewhere yonder, either in the walks or in the groves; and you, M. de Guiche, remain here: I am tired, and you will perhaps give me your arm.
children.prevalue: Monsieur de Bragelonne said the princess have the goodness I beg to see if my attendants are not somewhere yonder either in the walks or in the groves and you M de Guiche remain here I am tired and you will perhaps give me your arm

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Had a thunderbolt fallen at the feet of the unhappy young man, he would have been less terrified than by her cold and severe tone. However, as he himself had just said, he was brave; and as in the depths of his own heart he had just decisively made up his mind, De Guiche arose, and, observing Bragelonne's hesitation, he turned towards him a glance full of resignation and grateful acknowledgement. Instead of immediately answering Madame, he even advanced a step towards the vicomte, and holding out the arm which the princess had just desired him to give her, he pressed his friend's hand in his own, with a sigh, in which he seemed to give to friendship all the life that was left in the depths of his heart. Madame, who in her pride had never known what it was to wait, now waited until this mute colloquy was at an end. Her royal hand remained suspended in the air, and, when Raoul had left, it sank without anger, but not without emotion, in that of De Guiche. They were alone in the depths of the dark and silent forest, and nothing could be heard but Raoul's hastily retreating footsteps along the obscure paths. Over their heads was extended the thick and fragrant vault of branches, through the occasional openings of which the stars could be seen glittering in their beauty. Madame softly drew De Guiche about a hundred paces away from that indiscreet tree which had heard, and had allowed so many things to be heard, during the evening, and, leading him to a neighboring glade, so that they could see a certain distance around them, she said in a trembling voice, I have brought you here, because yonder where you were, everything can be overheard.

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Everything can be overheard, did you say, Madame? replied the young man, mechanically.
children.prevalue: Everything can be overheard did you say Madame replied the young man mechanically

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Which means murmured De Guiche.
children.prevalue: Which means murmured De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Which means that I have heard every syllable you have said.
children.prevalue: Which means that I have heard every syllable you have said

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Oh, Heaven! this only was wanting to destroy me, stammered De Guiche; and he bent down his head, like an exhausted swimmer beneath the wave which engulfs him.
children.prevalue: Oh Heaven this only was wanting to destroy me stammered De Guiche and he bent down his head like an exhausted swimmer beneath the wave which engulfs him

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: And so, she said, you judge me as you have said? De Guiche grew pale, turned his head aside, and was silent. He felt almost on the point of fainting.
children.prevalue: And so she said you judge me as you have said De Guiche grew pale turned his head aside and was silent He felt almost on the point of fainting

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: I do not complain, continued the princess, in a tone of voice full of gentleness; I prefer a frankness that wounds me, to flattery, which would deceive me. And so, according to your opinion, M. de Guiche, I am a coquette, an a worthless creature.
children.prevalue: I do not complain continued the princess in a tone of voice full of gentleness I prefer a frankness that wounds me to flattery which would deceive me And so according to your opinion M de Guiche I am a coquette an a worthless creature

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Worthless, cried the young man; you worthless! Oh, no; most certainly I did not say, I could not have said, that that which was the most precious object in life for me could be worthless. No, no; I did not say that.
children.prevalue: Worthless cried the young man you worthless Oh no most certainly I did not say I could not have said that that which was the most precious object in life for me could be worthless No no I did not say that

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: A woman who sees a man perish, consumed by the fire she has kindled, and who does not allay that fire, is, in my opinion, a worthless woman.
children.prevalue: A woman who sees a man perish consumed by the fire she has kindled and who does not allay that fire is in my opinion a worthless woman

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: What can it matter to you what I said? returned the comte. What am I compared to you, and why should you even trouble yourself to know whether I exist or not?
children.prevalue: What can it matter to you what I said returned the comte What am I compared to you and why should you even trouble yourself to know whether I exist or not

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Monsieur de Guiche, both you and I are human beings, and, knowing you as I do, I do not wish you to risk your life; with you I will change my conduct and character. I will be, not frank, for I am always so, but truthful. I implore you, therefore, to love me no more, and to forget utterly that I have ever addressed a word or a glance towards you.
children.prevalue: Monsieur de Guiche both you and I are human beings and knowing you as I do I do not wish you to risk your life with you I will change my conduct and character I will be not frank for I am always so but truthful I implore you therefore to love me no more and to forget utterly that I have ever addressed a word or a glance towards you

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: De Guiche turned around, bending a look full of passionate devotion upon her. You, he said; you excuse yourself; you implore me?
children.prevalue: De Guiche turned around bending a look full of passionate devotion upon her You he said you excuse yourself you implore me

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Certainly; since I have done evil, I ought to repair the evil I have done. And so, comte, this is what we will agree to. You will forgive my frivolity and my coquetry. Nay, do not interrupt me. I will forgive you for having said I was frivolous and a coquette, or something worse, perhaps; and you will renounce your idea of dying, and will preserve for your family, for the king, and for our sex, a cavalier whom every one esteems, and whom many hold dear. Madame pronounced this last word in such an accent of frankness, and even of tenderness, that poor De Guiche's heart felt almost bursting.
children.prevalue: Certainly since I have done evil I ought to repair the evil I have done And so comte this is what we will agree to You will forgive my frivolity and my coquetry Nay do not interrupt me I will forgive you for having said I was frivolous and a coquette or something worse perhaps and you will renounce your idea of dying and will preserve for your family for the king and for our sex a cavalier whom every one esteems and whom many hold dear Madame pronounced this last word in such an accent of frankness and even of tenderness that poor De Guiche s heart felt almost bursting

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Oh! Madame, Madame! he stammered out.
children.prevalue: Oh Madame Madame he stammered out

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Nay, listen further, she continued. When you shall have renounced all thought of me forever, from necessity in the first place, and, next, because you will yield to my entreaty, then you will judge me more favorably, and I am convinced you will replace this loveforgive the frivolity of the expressionby a sincere friendship, which you will be ready to offer me, and which, I promise you, shall be cordially accepted.
children.prevalue: Nay listen further she continued When you shall have renounced all thought of me forever from necessity in the first place and next because you will yield to my entreaty then you will judge me more favorably and I am convinced you will replace this loveforgive the frivolity of the expressionby a sincere friendship which you will be ready to offer me and which I promise you shall be cordially accepted

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: De Guiche, his forehead bedewed with perspiration, a feeling of death in his heart, and a trembling agitation through his whole frame, bit his lip, stamped his foot on the ground, and, in a word, devoured the bitterness of his grief. Madame, he said, what you offer is impossible, and I cannot accept such conditions.
children.prevalue: De Guiche his forehead bedewed with perspiration a feeling of death in his heart and a trembling agitation through his whole frame bit his lip stamped his foot on the ground and in a word devoured the bitterness of his grief Madame he said what you offer is impossible and I cannot accept such conditions

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: What! said Madame, do you refuse my friendship, then?
children.prevalue: What said Madame do you refuse my friendship then

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: No, no! I do not need your friendship, Madame. I prefer to die from love, than to live for friendship.
children.prevalue: No no I do not need your friendship Madame I prefer to die from love than to live for friendship

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Comte!
children.prevalue: Comte

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Oh! Madame, cried De Guiche, the present is a moment for me, in which no other consideration and no other respect exist, than the consideration and respect of a man of honor towards the woman he worships. Drive me away, curse me, denounce me, you will be perfectly right. I have uttered complaints against you, but their bitterness has been owing to my passion for you; I have said I wish to die, and die I will. If I lived, you would forget me; but dead, you would never forget me, I am sure.
children.prevalue: Oh Madame cried De Guiche the present is a moment for me in which no other consideration and no other respect exist than the consideration and respect of a man of honor towards the woman he worships Drive me away curse me denounce me you will be perfectly right I have uttered complaints against you but their bitterness has been owing to my passion for you I have said I wish to die and die I will If I lived you would forget me but dead you would never forget me I am sure

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Henrietta, who was standing buried in thought, and nearly as agitated as De Guiche himself, turned aside her head as but a minute before he had turned aside his. Then, after a moment's pause, she said, And you love me, then, very much?
children.prevalue: Henrietta who was standing buried in thought and nearly as agitated as De Guiche himself turned aside her head as but a minute before he had turned aside his Then after a moment s pause she said And you love me then very much

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Madly; madly enough to die from it, whether you drive me from you, or whether you listen to me still.
children.prevalue: Madly madly enough to die from it whether you drive me from you or whether you listen to me still

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: It is a hopeless case, she said, in a playful manner; a case which must be treated with soothing application. Give me your hand. It is as cold as ice. De Guiche knelt down, and pressed to his lips, not one, but both of Madame's hands.
children.prevalue: It is a hopeless case she said in a playful manner a case which must be treated with soothing application Give me your hand It is as cold as ice De Guiche knelt down and pressed to his lips not one but both of Madame s hands

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Love me, then, said the princess, since it cannot be otherwise. And almost imperceptibly she pressed his fingers, raising him thus, partly in the manner of a queen, and partly as a fond and affectionate woman would have done. De Guiche trembled from head to foot, and Madame, who felt how passion coursed through every fiber of his being, knew that he indeed loved truly. Give me your arm, comte, she said, and let us return.
children.prevalue: Love me then said the princess since it cannot be otherwise And almost imperceptibly she pressed his fingers raising him thus partly in the manner of a queen and partly as a fond and affectionate woman would have done De Guiche trembled from head to foot and Madame who felt how passion coursed through every fiber of his being knew that he indeed loved truly Give me your arm comte she said and let us return

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Ah! Madame, said the comte, trembling and bewildered; you have discovered a third way of killing me.
children.prevalue: Ah Madame said the comte trembling and bewildered you have discovered a third way of killing me

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: But, happily, it is the slowest way, is it not? she replied, as she led him towards the grove of trees they had so lately quitted.
children.prevalue: But happily it is the slowest way is it not she replied as she led him towards the grove of trees they had so lately quitted

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: When De Guiche's affairs, which had been suddenly set to right without his having been able to guess the cause of their improvement, assumed the unexpected aspect we have seen, Raoul, in obedience to the request of the princess, had withdrawn in order not to interrupt an explanation, the results of which he was far from guessing; and he soon after joined the ladies of honor who were walking about in the flowergardens. During this time, the Chevalier de Lorraine, who had returned to his own room, read De Wardes's latter with surprise, for it informed him by the hand of his valet, of the swordthrust received at Calais, and of all the details of the adventure, and invited him to inform De Guiche and Monsieur, whatever there might be in the affair likely to be most disagreeable to both of them. De Wardes particularly endeavored to prove to the chevalier the violence of Madame's affection for Buckingham, and he finished his letter by declaring that he thought this feeling was returned. The chevalier shrugged his shoulders at the last paragraph, and, in fact, De Wardes was out of date, as we have seen. De Wardes was still only at Buckingham's affair. The chevalier threw the letter over his shoulder upon an adjoining table, and said in a disdainful tone, It is really incredible; and yet poor De Wardes is not deficient in ability; but the truth is, it is not very apparent, so easy is it to grow rusty in the country. The deuce take the simpleton, who ought to have written to me about matters of importance, and yet he writes such silly stuff as that. If it had not been for that miserable letter, which has no meaning at all in it, I should have detected in the grove yonder a charming little intrigue, which would have compromised a woman, would have perhaps have been as good as a swordthrust for a man, and have diverted Monsieur for many days to come.

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: He looked at his watch. It is now too late, he said. One o'clock in the morning; every one must have returned to the king's apartments, where the night is to be finished; well, the scent is lost, and unless some extraordinary chance And thus saying, as if to appeal to his good star, the chevalier, greatly out of temper, approached the window, which looked out upon a somewhat solitary part of the garden. Immediately, and as if some evil genius was at his orders, he perceived returning towards the chateau, accompanied by a man, a silk mantle of a dark color, and recognized the figure which had struck his attention half an hour previously.
children.prevalue: He looked at his watch It is now too late he said One o clock in the morning every one must have returned to the king s apartments where the night is to be finished well the scent is lost and unless some extraordinary chance And thus saying as if to appeal to his good star the chevalier greatly out of temper approached the window which looked out upon a somewhat solitary part of the garden Immediately and as if some evil genius was at his orders he perceived returning towards the chateau accompanied by a man a silk mantle of a dark color and recognized the figure which had struck his attention half an hour previously

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Admirable! he thought, striking his hands together, this is my providential mysterious affair. And he started out precipitately, along the staircase, hoping to reach the courtyard in time to recognize the woman in the mantle, and her companion. But as he arrived at the door of the little court, he nearly knocked against Madame, whose radiant face seemed full of charming revelations beneath the mantle which protected without concealing her. Unfortunately, Madame was alone. The chevalier knew that since he had seen her, not five minutes before, with a gentleman, the gentleman in question could not be far off. Consequently, he hardly took time to salute the princess as he drew up to allow her to pass; then when she had advanced a few steps, with the rapidity of a woman who fears recognition, and when the chevalier perceived that she was too much occupied with her own thoughts to trouble herself about him, he darted into the garden, looked hastily round on every side, and embraced within his glance as much of the horizon as he possibly could. He was just in time; the gentleman who had accompanied Madame was still in sight; only he was hurrying towards one of the wings of the chateau, behind which he was on the point of disappearing. There was not an instant to lose; the chevalier darted in pursuit of him, prepared to slacken his pace as he approached the unknown; but in spite of the diligence he used, the unknown had disappeared behind the flight of steps before he approached.

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: It was evident, however, that as the man pursued was walking quietly, in a pensive manner, with his head bent down, either beneath the weight of grief or happiness, when once the angle was passed, unless, indeed, he were to enter by some door or another, the chevalier could not fail to overtake him. And this, certainly, would have happened, if, at the very moment he turned the angle, the chevalier had not run against two persons, who were themselves wheeling in the opposite direction. The chevalier was ready to seek a quarrel with these two troublesome intruders, when, looking up, he recognized the superintendent. Fouquet was accompanied by a person whom the chevalier now saw for the first time. This stranger was the bishop of Vannes. Checked by the important character of the individual, and obliged out of politeness to make his own excuses when he expected to receive them, the chevalier stepped back a few paces; and as Monsieur Fouquet possessed, if not the friendship, at least the respect of every one; as the king himself, although he was rather his enemy than his friend, treated M. Fouquet as a man of great consideration, the chevalier did what the king himself would have done, namely, he bowed to M. Fouquet, who returned his salutation with kindly politeness, perceiving that the gentleman had run against him by mistake and without any intention of being rude. Then, almost immediately afterwards, having recognized the Chevalier de Lorraine, he made a few civil remarks, to which the chevalier was obliged to reply. Brief as the conversation was, De Lorraine saw, with the most unfeigned displeasure, the figure of his unknown becoming dimmer in the distance, and fast disappearing in the darkness. The chevalier resigned himself, and, once resigned, gave his entire attention to Fouquet:You arrive late, monsieur, he said. Your absence has occasioned great surprise, and I heard Monsieur express himself as much astonished that, having been invited by the king, you had not come.

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: It was impossible for me to do so; but I came as soon as I was free.
children.prevalue: It was impossible for me to do so but I came as soon as I was free

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Is Paris quiet?
children.prevalue: Is Paris quiet

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Perfectly so. Paris has received the last tax very well.
children.prevalue: Perfectly so Paris has received the last tax very well

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Ah! I understand you wished to assure yourself of this good feeling before you came to participate in our fetes.
children.prevalue: Ah I understand you wished to assure yourself of this good feeling before you came to participate in our fetes

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: I have arrived, however, somewhat late to enjoy them. I will ask you, therefore, to inform me if the king is in the chateau or not, if I am likely to be able to see him this evening, or if I shall have to wait until tomorrow.
children.prevalue: I have arrived however somewhat late to enjoy them I will ask you therefore to inform me if the king is in the chateau or not if I am likely to be able to see him this evening or if I shall have to wait until tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: We have lost sight of his majesty during the last halfhour nearly, said the chevalier.
children.prevalue: We have lost sight of his majesty during the last halfhour nearly said the chevalier

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Perhaps he is in Madame's apartments? inquired Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Perhaps he is in Madame s apartments inquired Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Not in Madame's apartments, I should think, for I just now met Madame as she was entering by the small staircase; and unless the gentleman whom you a moment ago encountered was the king himself and the chevalier paused, hoping that, in this manner, he might learn who it was he had been hurrying after. But Fouquet, whether he had or had not recognized De Guiche, simply replied, No, monsieur, it was not the king.

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The chevalier, disappointed in his expectation, saluted them; but as he did so, casting a parting glance around him, and perceiving M. Colbert in the center of a group, he said to the superintendent: Stay, monsieur; there is some one under the trees yonder, who will be able to inform you better than myself.
