children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Who? asked Fouquet, whose nearsightedness prevented him from seeing through the darkness.
children.prevalue: Who asked Fouquet whose nearsightedness prevented him from seeing through the darkness

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: M. Colbert, returned the chevalier.
children.prevalue: M Colbert returned the chevalier

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Indeed! That person, then, who is speaking yonder to those men with torches in their hands, is M. Colbert?
children.prevalue: Indeed That person then who is speaking yonder to those men with torches in their hands is M Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: M. Colbert himself. He is giving orders personally to the workmen who are arranging the lamps for the illuminations.
children.prevalue: M Colbert himself He is giving orders personally to the workmen who are arranging the lamps for the illuminations

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Thank you, said Fouquet, with an inclination of the head, which indicated that he had obtained all the information he wished. The chevalier, on his side, having, on the contrary, learned nothing at all, withdrew with a profound salutation.
children.prevalue: Thank you said Fouquet with an inclination of the head which indicated that he had obtained all the information he wished The chevalier on his side having on the contrary learned nothing at all withdrew with a profound salutation

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: He had scarcely left when Fouquet, knitting his brows, fell into a deep reverie. Aramis looked at him for a moment with a mingled feeling of compassion and silence.
children.prevalue: He had scarcely left when Fouquet knitting his brows fell into a deep reverie Aramis looked at him for a moment with a mingled feeling of compassion and silence

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: What! he said to him, the fellow's name alone seemed to affect you. Is it possible that, full of triumph and delight as you were just now, the sight merely of that man is capable of dispiriting you? Tell me, have you faith in your good star?
children.prevalue: What he said to him the fellow s name alone seemed to affect you Is it possible that full of triumph and delight as you were just now the sight merely of that man is capable of dispiriting you Tell me have you faith in your good star

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: No, replied Fouquet, dejectedly.
children.prevalue: No replied Fouquet dejectedly

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Why not?
children.prevalue: Why not

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Because I am too full of happiness at this present moment, he replied, in a trembling voice. You, my dear D'Herblay, who are so learned, will remember the history of a certain tyrant of Samos. What can I throw into the sea to avert approaching evil? Yes! I repeat it once more, I am too full of happiness! so happy that I wish for nothing beyond what I have... I have risen so high... You know my motto: 'Quo non ascendam?' I have risen so high that nothing is left me but to descend from my elevation. I cannot believe in the progress of a success already more than human.
children.prevalue: Because I am too full of happiness at this present moment he replied in a trembling voice You my dear D Herblay who are so learned will remember the history of a certain tyrant of Samos What can I throw into the sea to avert approaching evil Yes I repeat it once more I am too full of happiness so happy that I wish for nothing beyond what I have I have risen so high You know my motto Quo non ascendam I have risen so high that nothing is left me but to descend from my elevation I cannot believe in the progress of a success already more than human

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Aramis smiled as he fixed his kind and penetrating glance upon him. If I were aware of the cause of your happiness, he said, I should probably fear for your grace; but you regard me in the light of a true friend; I mean, you turn to me in misfortune, nothing more. Even that is an immense and precious boon, I know; but the truth is, I have a just right to beg you to confide in me, from time to time, any fortunate circumstances that befall you, in which I should rejoice, you know, more than if they had befallen myself.
children.prevalue: Aramis smiled as he fixed his kind and penetrating glance upon him If I were aware of the cause of your happiness he said I should probably fear for your grace but you regard me in the light of a true friend I mean you turn to me in misfortune nothing more Even that is an immense and precious boon I know but the truth is I have a just right to beg you to confide in me from time to time any fortunate circumstances that befall you in which I should rejoice you know more than if they had befallen myself

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: My dear prelate, said Fouquet, laughing, my secrets are of too profane a character to confide them to a bishop, however great a worldling he may be.
children.prevalue: My dear prelate said Fouquet laughing my secrets are of too profane a character to confide them to a bishop however great a worldling he may be

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Bah! in confession.
children.prevalue: Bah in confession

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Oh! I should blush too much if you were my confessor. And Fouquet began to sigh. Aramis again looked at him without further betrayal of his thoughts than a placid smile.
children.prevalue: Oh I should blush too much if you were my confessor And Fouquet began to sigh Aramis again looked at him without further betrayal of his thoughts than a placid smile

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Well, he said, discretion is a great virtue.
children.prevalue: Well he said discretion is a great virtue

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Silence, said Fouquet; yonder venomous reptile has recognized us, and is crawling this way.
children.prevalue: Silence said Fouquet yonder venomous reptile has recognized us and is crawling this way

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Colbert?
children.prevalue: Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Yes; leave me, D'Herblay; I do not wish that fellow to see you with me, or he will take an aversion to you.
children.prevalue: Yes leave me D Herblay I do not wish that fellow to see you with me or he will take an aversion to you

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Aramis pressed his hand, saying, What need have I of his friendship, while you are here?
children.prevalue: Aramis pressed his hand saying What need have I of his friendship while you are here

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Yes, but I may not always be here, replied Fouquet, dejectedly.
children.prevalue: Yes but I may not always be here replied Fouquet dejectedly

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: On that day, then, if that day should ever dawn, said Aramis, tranquilly, we will think over a means of dispensing with the friendship, or of braving the dislike of M. Colbert. But tell me, my dear Fouquet, instead of conversing with this reptile, as you did him the honor of styling him, a conversation the need for which I do not perceive, why do you not pay a visit, if not to the king, at least to Madame?
children.prevalue: On that day then if that day should ever dawn said Aramis tranquilly we will think over a means of dispensing with the friendship or of braving the dislike of M Colbert But tell me my dear Fouquet instead of conversing with this reptile as you did him the honor of styling him a conversation the need for which I do not perceive why do you not pay a visit if not to the king at least to Madame

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: To Madame, said the superintendent, his mind occupied by his souvenirs. Yes, certainly, to Madame.
children.prevalue: To Madame said the superintendent his mind occupied by his souvenirs Yes certainly to Madame

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: You remember, continued Aramis, that we have been told that Madame stands high in favor during the last two or three days. It enters into your policy, and forms part of our plans, that you should assiduously devote yourself to his majesty's friends. It is a means of counteracting the growing influence of M. Colbert. Present yourself, therefore, as soon as possible to Madame, and, for our sakes, treat this ally with consideration.
children.prevalue: You remember continued Aramis that we have been told that Madame stands high in favor during the last two or three days It enters into your policy and forms part of our plans that you should assiduously devote yourself to his majesty s friends It is a means of counteracting the growing influence of M Colbert Present yourself therefore as soon as possible to Madame and for our sakes treat this ally with consideration

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: But, said Fouquet, are you quite sure that it is upon her that the king has his eyes fixed at the present moment?
children.prevalue: But said Fouquet are you quite sure that it is upon her that the king has his eyes fixed at the present moment

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: If the needle has turned, it must be since the morning. You know I have my police.
children.prevalue: If the needle has turned it must be since the morning You know I have my police

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Very well! I will go there at once, and, at all events, I shall have a means of introduction in the shape of a magnificent pair of antique cameos set with diamonds.
children.prevalue: Very well I will go there at once and at all events I shall have a means of introduction in the shape of a magnificent pair of antique cameos set with diamonds

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I have seen them, and nothing could be more costly and regal.
children.prevalue: I have seen them and nothing could be more costly and regal

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: At this moment they were interrupted by a servant followed by a courier. For you, monseigneur, said the courier aloud, presenting a letter to Fouquet.
children.prevalue: At this moment they were interrupted by a servant followed by a courier For you monseigneur said the courier aloud presenting a letter to Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: For your grace, said the lackey in a low tone, handing Aramis a letter. And as the lackey carried a torch in his hand, he placed himself between the superintendent and the bishop of Vannes, so that both of them could read at the same time. As Fouquet looked at the fine and delicate writing on the envelope, he started with delight. Those who love, or who are beloved, will understand his anxiety in the first place, and his happiness in the next. He hastily tore open the letter, which, however, contained only these words: It is but an hour since I quitted you, it is an age since I told you how much I love you. And that was all. Madame de Belliere had, in fact, left Fouquet about an hour previously, after having passed two days with him; and apprehensive lest his remembrance of her might be effaced for too long a period from the heart she regretted, she dispatched a courier to him as the bearer of this important communication. Fouquet kissed the letter, and rewarded the bearer with a handful of gold. As for Aramis, he, on his side, was engaged in reading, but with more coolness and reflection, the following letter:
children.prevalue: For your grace said the lackey in a low tone handing Aramis a letter And as the lackey carried a torch in his hand he placed himself between the superintendent and the bishop of Vannes so that both of them could read at the same time As Fouquet looked at the fine and delicate writing on the envelope he started with delight Those who love or who are beloved will understand his anxiety in the first place and his happiness in the next He hastily tore open the letter which however contained only these words It is but an hour since I quitted you it is an age since I told you how much I love you And that was all Madame de Belliere had in fact left Fouquet about an hour previously after having passed two days with him and apprehensive lest his remembrance of her might be effaced for too long a period from the heart she regretted she dispatched a courier to him as the bearer of this important communication Fouquet kissed the letter and rewarded the bearer with a handful of gold As for Aramis he on his side was engaged in reading but with more coolness and reflection the following letter

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: The king has this evening been struck with a strange fancy; a woman loves him. He learned it accidentally, as he was listening to the conversation of this young girl with her companions; and his majesty has entirely abandoned himself to his new caprice. The girl's name is Mademoiselle de la Valliere, and she is sufficiently pretty to warrant this caprice becoming a strong attachment. Beware of Mademoiselle de la Valliere.
children.prevalue: The king has this evening been struck with a strange fancy a woman loves him He learned it accidentally as he was listening to the conversation of this young girl with her companions and his majesty has entirely abandoned himself to his new caprice The girl s name is Mademoiselle de la Valliere and she is sufficiently pretty to warrant this caprice becoming a strong attachment Beware of Mademoiselle de la Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: There was not a word about Madame. Aramis slowly folded the letter and put it in his pocket. Fouquet was still delightedly inhaling the perfume of his epistle.
children.prevalue: There was not a word about Madame Aramis slowly folded the letter and put it in his pocket Fouquet was still delightedly inhaling the perfume of his epistle

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Monseigneur, said Aramis, touching Fouquet's arm.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur said Aramis touching Fouquet s arm

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Yes, what is it? he asked.
children.prevalue: Yes what is it he asked

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: An idea has just occurred to me. Are you acquainted with a young girl of the name of La Valliere?
children.prevalue: An idea has just occurred to me Are you acquainted with a young girl of the name of La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Not at all.
children.prevalue: Not at all

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Reflect a little.
children.prevalue: Reflect a little

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Ah! yes, I believe so; one of Madame's maids of honor.
children.prevalue: Ah yes I believe so one of Madame s maids of honor

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: That must be the one.
children.prevalue: That must be the one

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Well, what then?
children.prevalue: Well what then

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Well, monseigneur, it is to that young girl that you must pay your visit this evening.
children.prevalue: Well monseigneur it is to that young girl that you must pay your visit this evening

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Bah! why so?
children.prevalue: Bah why so

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Nay, more than that, it is to her you must present your cameos.
children.prevalue: Nay more than that it is to her you must present your cameos

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Nonsense.
children.prevalue: Nonsense

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: You know, monseigneur, that my advice is not to be regarded lightly.
children.prevalue: You know monseigneur that my advice is not to be regarded lightly

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: But this is unforeseen
children.prevalue: But this is unforeseen

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: That is my affair. Pay your court in due form, and without loss of time, to Mademoiselle de la Valliere. I will be your guarantee with Madame de Belliere that your devotion is altogether politic.
children.prevalue: That is my affair Pay your court in due form and without loss of time to Mademoiselle de la Valliere I will be your guarantee with Madame de Belliere that your devotion is altogether politic

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: What do you mean, my dear D'Herblay, and whose name have you just pronounced?
children.prevalue: What do you mean my dear D Herblay and whose name have you just pronounced

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: A name which ought to convince you that, as I am so well informed about yourself, I may possibly be just as well informed about others. Pay your court, therefore, to La Valliere.
children.prevalue: A name which ought to convince you that as I am so well informed about yourself I may possibly be just as well informed about others Pay your court therefore to La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I will pay my court to whomsoever you like, replied Fouquet, his heart filled with happiness.
children.prevalue: I will pay my court to whomsoever you like replied Fouquet his heart filled with happiness

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Come, come, descend again to the earth, traveler in the seventh heaven, said Aramis; M. Colbert is approaching. He has been recruiting while we were reading; see, how he is surrounded, praised, congratulated; he is decidedly becoming powerful. In fact, Colbert was advancing, escorted by all the courtiers who remained in the gardens, every one of whom complimented him upon the arrangements of the fete: all of which so puffed him up that he could hardly contain himself.
children.prevalue: Come come descend again to the earth traveler in the seventh heaven said Aramis M Colbert is approaching He has been recruiting while we were reading see how he is surrounded praised congratulated he is decidedly becoming powerful In fact Colbert was advancing escorted by all the courtiers who remained in the gardens every one of whom complimented him upon the arrangements of the fete all of which so puffed him up that he could hardly contain himself

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: If La Fontaine were here, said Fouquet, smiling, what an admirable opportunity for him to recite his fable of 'The Frog that wanted to make itself as big as the Ox.'
children.prevalue: If La Fontaine were here said Fouquet smiling what an admirable opportunity for him to recite his fable of The Frog that wanted to make itself as big as the Ox

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Colbert arrived in the center of the circle blazing with light; Fouquet awaited his approach, unmoved and with a slightly mocking smile. Colbert smiled too; he had been observing his enemy during the last quarter of an hour, and had been approaching him gradually. Colbert's smile was a presage of hostility.
children.prevalue: Colbert arrived in the center of the circle blazing with light Fouquet awaited his approach unmoved and with a slightly mocking smile Colbert smiled too he had been observing his enemy during the last quarter of an hour and had been approaching him gradually Colbert s smile was a presage of hostility

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Oh, oh! said Aramis, in a low tone of voice to the superintendent; the scoundrel is going to ask you again for more millions to pay for his fireworks and his colored lamps. Colbert was the first to salute them, and with an air which he endeavored to render respectful. Fouquet hardly moved his head.
children.prevalue: Oh oh said Aramis in a low tone of voice to the superintendent the scoundrel is going to ask you again for more millions to pay for his fireworks and his colored lamps Colbert was the first to salute them and with an air which he endeavored to render respectful Fouquet hardly moved his head

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Well, monseigneur, what do your eyes say? Have we shown our good taste?
children.prevalue: Well monseigneur what do your eyes say Have we shown our good taste

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Perfect taste, replied Fouquet, without permitting the slightest tone of raillery to be remarked in his words.
children.prevalue: Perfect taste replied Fouquet without permitting the slightest tone of raillery to be remarked in his words

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Oh! said Colbert, maliciously, you are treating us with indulgence. We are poor, we servants of the king, and Fontainebleau is no way to be compared as a residence with Vaux.
children.prevalue: Oh said Colbert maliciously you are treating us with indulgence We are poor we servants of the king and Fontainebleau is no way to be compared as a residence with Vaux

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Quite true, replied Fouquet coolly.
children.prevalue: Quite true replied Fouquet coolly

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: But what can we do, monseigneur? continued Colbert, we have done our best on slender resources.
children.prevalue: But what can we do monseigneur continued Colbert we have done our best on slender resources

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Fouquet made a gesture of assent.
children.prevalue: Fouquet made a gesture of assent

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: But, pursued Colbert, it would be only a proper display of your magnificence, monseigneur, if you were to offer to his majesty a fete in your wonderful gardensin those gardens which have cost you sixty millions of francs.
children.prevalue: But pursued Colbert it would be only a proper display of your magnificence monseigneur if you were to offer to his majesty a fete in your wonderful gardensin those gardens which have cost you sixty millions of francs

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Seventytwo, said Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Seventytwo said Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: An additional reason, returned Colbert; it would, indeed, be truly magnificent.
children.prevalue: An additional reason returned Colbert it would indeed be truly magnificent

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: But do you suppose, monsieur, that his majesty would deign to accept my invitation?
children.prevalue: But do you suppose monsieur that his majesty would deign to accept my invitation

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: I have no doubt whatever of it, cried Colbert, hastily; I will guarantee that he does.
children.prevalue: I have no doubt whatever of it cried Colbert hastily I will guarantee that he does

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: You are exceedingly kind, said Fouquet. I may depend on it, then?
children.prevalue: You are exceedingly kind said Fouquet I may depend on it then

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Yes, monseigneur; yes, certainly.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur yes certainly

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Then I will consider the matter, yawned Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Then I will consider the matter yawned Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Accept, accept, whispered Aramis, eagerly.
children.prevalue: Accept accept whispered Aramis eagerly

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: You will consider? repeated Colbert.
children.prevalue: You will consider repeated Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Yes, replied Fouquet; in order to know what day I shall submit my invitation to the king.
children.prevalue: Yes replied Fouquet in order to know what day I shall submit my invitation to the king

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: This very evening, monseigneur, this very evening.
children.prevalue: This very evening monseigneur this very evening

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Agreed, said the superintendent. Gentlemen, I should wish to issue my invitations; but you know that wherever the king goes, the king is in his own palace; it is by his majesty, therefore, that you must be invited. A murmur of delight immediately arose. Fouquet bowed and left.
children.prevalue: Agreed said the superintendent Gentlemen I should wish to issue my invitations but you know that wherever the king goes the king is in his own palace it is by his majesty therefore that you must be invited A murmur of delight immediately arose Fouquet bowed and left

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Proud and dauntless man, thought Colbert, you accept, and yet you know it will cost you ten millions.
children.prevalue: Proud and dauntless man thought Colbert you accept and yet you know it will cost you ten millions

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: You have ruined me, whispered Fouquet, in a low tone, to Aramis.
children.prevalue: You have ruined me whispered Fouquet in a low tone to Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: I have saved you, replied the latter, whilst Fouquet ascended the flight of steps and inquired whether the king was still visible.
children.prevalue: I have saved you replied the latter whilst Fouquet ascended the flight of steps and inquired whether the king was still visible

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The king, anxious to be again quite alone, in order to reflect well upon what was passing in his heart, had withdrawn to his own apartments, where M. de SaintAignan had, after his conversation with Madame, gone to meet him. This conversation has already been related. The favorite, vain of his twofold importance, and feeling that he had become, during the last two hours, the confidant of the king, began to treat the affairs of the court in a somewhat indifferent manner: and, from the position in which he had placed himself, or rather, where chance had placed him, he saw nothing but love and garlands of flowers around him. The king's love for Madame, that of Madame for the king, that of Guiche for Madame, that of La Valliere for the king, that of Malicorne for Montalais, that of Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente for himself, was not all this, truly, more than enough to turn the head of any courtier? Besides, SaintAignan was the model of courtiers, past, present, and to come; and, moreover, showed himself such an excellent narrator, and so discerningly appreciative that the king listened to him with an appearance of great interest, particularly when he described the excited manner with which Madame had sought for him to converse about the affair of Mademoiselle de la Valliere. While the king no longer experienced for Madame any remains of the passion he had once felt for her, there was, in this same eagerness of Madame to procure information about him, great gratification for his vanity, from which he could not free himself. He experienced this pleasure then, but nothing more, and his heart was not, for a single moment, alarmed at what Madame might, or might not, think of his adventure. When, however, SaintAignan had finished, the king, while preparing to retire to rest, asked, Now, SaintAignan, you know what Mademoiselle de la Valliere is, do you not?

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Not only what she is, but what she will be.
children.prevalue: Not only what she is but what she will be

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: What do you mean?
children.prevalue: What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: I mean that she is everything that woman can wish to bethat is to say, beloved by your majesty; I mean, that she will be everything your majesty may wish her to be.
children.prevalue: I mean that she is everything that woman can wish to bethat is to say beloved by your majesty I mean that she will be everything your majesty may wish her to be

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: That is not what I am asking. I do not wish to know what she is today, or what she will be tomorrow; as you have remarked, that is my affair. But tell me what others say of her.
children.prevalue: That is not what I am asking I do not wish to know what she is today or what she will be tomorrow as you have remarked that is my affair But tell me what others say of her

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: They say she is well conducted.
children.prevalue: They say she is well conducted

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Oh! said the king, smiling, that is mere report.
children.prevalue: Oh said the king smiling that is mere report

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: But rare enough, at court, sire, to believe when it is spread.
children.prevalue: But rare enough at court sire to believe when it is spread

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Perhaps you are right. Is she well born?
children.prevalue: Perhaps you are right Is she well born

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Excellently; the daughter of the Marquis de la Valliere, and stepdaughter of that good M. de SaintRemy.
children.prevalue: Excellently the daughter of the Marquis de la Valliere and stepdaughter of that good M de SaintRemy

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Ah, yes! my aunt's majordomo; I remember; and I remember now that I saw her as I passed through Blois. She was presented to the queens. I have even to reproach myself that I did not on that occasion pay her the attention she deserved.
children.prevalue: Ah yes my aunt s majordomo I remember and I remember now that I saw her as I passed through Blois She was presented to the queens I have even to reproach myself that I did not on that occasion pay her the attention she deserved

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Oh, sire! I trust that your majesty will now repair time lost.
children.prevalue: Oh sire I trust that your majesty will now repair time lost

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: And the reportyou tell meis, that Mademoiselle de la Valliere never had a lover.
children.prevalue: And the reportyou tell meis that Mademoiselle de la Valliere never had a lover

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: In any case, I do not think your majesty would be much alarmed at the rivalry.
children.prevalue: In any case I do not think your majesty would be much alarmed at the rivalry

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Yet, stay, said the king, in a very serious tone of voice.
children.prevalue: Yet stay said the king in a very serious tone of voice

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Your majesty?
children.prevalue: Your majesty

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: I remember.
children.prevalue: I remember

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Ah!
children.prevalue: Ah

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: If she has no lover, she has, at least, a betrothed.
children.prevalue: If she has no lover she has at least a betrothed

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: A betrothed!
children.prevalue: A betrothed

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: What! Count, do you not know that?
children.prevalue: What Count do you not know that

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: You, the man who knows all the news?
children.prevalue: You the man who knows all the news

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Your majesty will excuse me. You know this betrothed, then?
children.prevalue: Your majesty will excuse me You know this betrothed then

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Assuredly! his father came to ask me to sign the marriage contract: it is The king was about to pronounce the Vicomte de Bragelonne's name, when he stopped, and knitted his brows.
children.prevalue: Assuredly his father came to ask me to sign the marriage contract it is The king was about to pronounce the Vicomte de Bragelonne s name when he stopped and knitted his brows

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: It is repeated SaintAignan, inquiringly.
children.prevalue: It is repeated SaintAignan inquiringly

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: I don't remember now, replied Louis XIV., endeavoring to conceal an annoyance he had some trouble to disguise.
children.prevalue: I don t remember now replied Louis XIV endeavoring to conceal an annoyance he had some trouble to disguise

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Can I put your majesty in the way? inquired the Comte de SaintAignan.
children.prevalue: Can I put your majesty in the way inquired the Comte de SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: No; for I no longer remember to whom I intended to refer; indeed, I only remember very indistinctly, that one of the maids of honor was to marrythe name, however, has escaped me.
children.prevalue: No for I no longer remember to whom I intended to refer indeed I only remember very indistinctly that one of the maids of honor was to marrythe name however has escaped me

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Was it Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente he was going to marry? inquired SaintAignan.
children.prevalue: Was it Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente he was going to marry inquired SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Very likely, said the king.
children.prevalue: Very likely said the king

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: In that case, the intended was M. de Montespan; but Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente did not speak of it, it seemed to me, in such a manner as would frighten suitors away.
children.prevalue: In that case the intended was M de Montespan but Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente did not speak of it it seemed to me in such a manner as would frighten suitors away

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: At all events, said the king, I know nothing, or almost nothing, about Mademoiselle de la Valliere. SaintAignan, I rely upon you to procure me every information about her.
children.prevalue: At all events said the king I know nothing or almost nothing about Mademoiselle de la Valliere SaintAignan I rely upon you to procure me every information about her

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Yes, sire, and when shall I have the honor of seeing your majesty again, to give you the latest news?
children.prevalue: Yes sire and when shall I have the honor of seeing your majesty again to give you the latest news

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Whenever you have procured it.
children.prevalue: Whenever you have procured it

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I shall obtain it speedily, then, if the information can be as quickly obtained as my wish to see your majesty again.
children.prevalue: I shall obtain it speedily then if the information can be as quickly obtained as my wish to see your majesty again

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Well said, count! By the by, has Madame displayed any illfeeling against this poor girl?
children.prevalue: Well said count By the by has Madame displayed any illfeeling against this poor girl

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: None, sire.
children.prevalue: None sire

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Madame did not get angry, then?
children.prevalue: Madame did not get angry then

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I do not know; I only know that she laughed continually.
children.prevalue: I do not know I only know that she laughed continually

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: That's well; but I think I hear voices in the anteroomsno doubt a courier has just arrived. Inquire, SaintAignan. The count ran to the door and exchanged a few words with the usher; he returned to the king, saying, Sire, it is M. Fouquet who has this moment arrived, by your majesty's orders, he says. He presented himself, but, because of the lateness of the hour, he does not press for an audience this evening, and is satisfied to have his presence here formally announced.
children.prevalue: That s well but I think I hear voices in the anteroomsno doubt a courier has just arrived Inquire SaintAignan The count ran to the door and exchanged a few words with the usher he returned to the king saying Sire it is M Fouquet who has this moment arrived by your majesty s orders he says He presented himself but because of the lateness of the hour he does not press for an audience this evening and is satisfied to have his presence here formally announced

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: M. Fouquet! I wrote to him at three o'clock, inviting him to be at Fontainebleau the following day, and he arrives at Fontainebleau at two o'clock in the morning! This is, indeed, zeal! exclaimed the king, delighted to see himself so promptly obeyed. On the contrary, M. Fouquet shall have his audience. I summoned him, and will receive him. Let him be introduced. As for you, count, pursue your inquiries, and be here tomorrow.
children.prevalue: M Fouquet I wrote to him at three o clock inviting him to be at Fontainebleau the following day and he arrives at Fontainebleau at two o clock in the morning This is indeed zeal exclaimed the king delighted to see himself so promptly obeyed On the contrary M Fouquet shall have his audience I summoned him and will receive him Let him be introduced As for you count pursue your inquiries and be here tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: The king placed his finger on his lips; and SaintAignan, his heart brimful of happiness, hastily withdrew, telling the usher to introduce M. Fouquet, who, thereupon, entered the king's apartment. Louis rose to receive him.
children.prevalue: The king placed his finger on his lips and SaintAignan his heart brimful of happiness hastily withdrew telling the usher to introduce M Fouquet who thereupon entered the king s apartment Louis rose to receive him

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Good evening, M. Fouquet, he said, smiling graciously; I congratulate you on your punctuality; and yet my message must have reached you late?
children.prevalue: Good evening M Fouquet he said smiling graciously I congratulate you on your punctuality and yet my message must have reached you late

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: At nine in the evening, sire.
children.prevalue: At nine in the evening sire

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: You have been working very hard lately, M. Fouquet, for I have been informed that you have not left your rooms at SaintMande during the last three or four days.
children.prevalue: You have been working very hard lately M Fouquet for I have been informed that you have not left your rooms at SaintMande during the last three or four days

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: It is perfectly true, your majesty, that I have kept myself shut up for the past three days, replied Fouquet.
children.prevalue: It is perfectly true your majesty that I have kept myself shut up for the past three days replied Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Do you know, M. Fouquet, that I had a great many things to say to you? continued the king, with a most gracious air.
children.prevalue: Do you know M Fouquet that I had a great many things to say to you continued the king with a most gracious air

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Your majesty overwhelms me, and since you are so graciously disposed towards me, will you permit me to remind you of the promise made to grant an audience?
children.prevalue: Your majesty overwhelms me and since you are so graciously disposed towards me will you permit me to remind you of the promise made to grant an audience

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Ah, yes! some church dignitary, who thinks he has to thank me for something, is it not?
children.prevalue: Ah yes some church dignitary who thinks he has to thank me for something is it not

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Precisely so, sire. The hour is, perhaps, badly chosen; but the time of the companion whom I have brought with me is valuable, and as Fontainebleau is on the way to his diocese
children.prevalue: Precisely so sire The hour is perhaps badly chosen but the time of the companion whom I have brought with me is valuable and as Fontainebleau is on the way to his diocese

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Who is it, then?
children.prevalue: Who is it then

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: The bishop of Vannes, whose appointment your majesty, at my recommendation, deigned, three months since, to sign.
children.prevalue: The bishop of Vannes whose appointment your majesty at my recommendation deigned three months since to sign

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: That is very possible, said the king, who had signed without reading; and he is here?
children.prevalue: That is very possible said the king who had signed without reading and he is here

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Yes, sire; Vannes is an important diocese; the flock belonging to this pastor needed his religious consolation; they are savages, whom it is necessary to polish, at the same time that he instructs them, and M. d'Herblay is unequalled in such kind of missions.
children.prevalue: Yes sire Vannes is an important diocese the flock belonging to this pastor needed his religious consolation they are savages whom it is necessary to polish at the same time that he instructs them and M d Herblay is unequalled in such kind of missions

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: M. d'Herblay! said the king, musingly, as if his name, heard long since, was not, however, unknown to him.
children.prevalue: M d Herblay said the king musingly as if his name heard long since was not however unknown to him

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Oh! said Fouquet, promptly, your majesty is not acquainted with the obscure name of one of your most faithful and valuable servants?
children.prevalue: Oh said Fouquet promptly your majesty is not acquainted with the obscure name of one of your most faithful and valuable servants

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: No, I confess I am not. And so he wishes to set off again?
children.prevalue: No I confess I am not And so he wishes to set off again

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: He has this very day received letters which will, perhaps, compel him to leave, so that, before setting off for that unknown region called Bretagne, he is desirous of paying his respects to your majesty.
children.prevalue: He has this very day received letters which will perhaps compel him to leave so that before setting off for that unknown region called Bretagne he is desirous of paying his respects to your majesty

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Is he waiting?
children.prevalue: Is he waiting

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: He is here, sire.
children.prevalue: He is here sire

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Let him enter.
children.prevalue: Let him enter

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Fouquet made a sign to the usher in attendance, who was waiting behind the tapestry. The door opened, and Aramis entered. The king allowed him to finish the compliments which he addressed to him, and fixed a long look upon a countenance which no one could forget, after having once beheld it.
children.prevalue: Fouquet made a sign to the usher in attendance who was waiting behind the tapestry The door opened and Aramis entered The king allowed him to finish the compliments which he addressed to him and fixed a long look upon a countenance which no one could forget after having once beheld it

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Vannes! he said: you are bishop of Vannes, I believe?
children.prevalue: Vannes he said you are bishop of Vannes I believe

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Yes, sire.
children.prevalue: Yes sire

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Vannes is in Bretagne, I think? Aramis bowed.
children.prevalue: Vannes is in Bretagne I think Aramis bowed

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Near the coast? Aramis again bowed.
children.prevalue: Near the coast Aramis again bowed

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: A few leagues from BellIsle, is it not?
children.prevalue: A few leagues from BellIsle is it not

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Yes, sire, replied Aramis; six leagues, I believe.
children.prevalue: Yes sire replied Aramis six leagues I believe

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Six leagues; a mere step, then, said Louis XIV.
children.prevalue: Six leagues a mere step then said Louis XIV

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Not for us poor Bretons, sire, replied Aramis: six leagues, on the contrary, is a great distance, if it be six leagues on land; and an immense distance, if it be leagues on the sea. Besides, I have the honor to mention to your majesty that there are six leagues of sea from the river to BelleIsle.
children.prevalue: Not for us poor Bretons sire replied Aramis six leagues on the contrary is a great distance if it be six leagues on land and an immense distance if it be leagues on the sea Besides I have the honor to mention to your majesty that there are six leagues of sea from the river to BelleIsle

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: It is said that M. Fouquet has a very beautiful house there? inquired the king.
children.prevalue: It is said that M Fouquet has a very beautiful house there inquired the king

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Yes, it is said so, replied Aramis, looking quietly at Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Yes it is said so replied Aramis looking quietly at Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: What do you mean by 'it is said so?' exclaimed the king.
children.prevalue: What do you mean by it is said so exclaimed the king

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: He has, sire.
children.prevalue: He has sire

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Really, M. Fouquet, I must confess that one circumstance surprises me.
children.prevalue: Really M Fouquet I must confess that one circumstance surprises me

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: What may that be, sire?
children.prevalue: What may that be sire

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: That you should have at the head of the diocese a man like M. d'Herblay, and yet should not have shown him BelleIsle.
children.prevalue: That you should have at the head of the diocese a man like M d Herblay and yet should not have shown him BelleIsle

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Oh, sire, replied the bishop, without giving Fouquet time to answer, we poor Breton prelates seldom leave our residences.
children.prevalue: Oh sire replied the bishop without giving Fouquet time to answer we poor Breton prelates seldom leave our residences

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: M. de Vannes, said the king, I will punish M. Fouquet for his indifference.
children.prevalue: M de Vannes said the king I will punish M Fouquet for his indifference

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: In what way, sire?
children.prevalue: In what way sire

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: I will change your bishopric.
children.prevalue: I will change your bishopric

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Fouquet bit his lips, but Aramis only smiled.
children.prevalue: Fouquet bit his lips but Aramis only smiled

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: What income does Vannes bring you in? continued the king.
children.prevalue: What income does Vannes bring you in continued the king

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Sixty thousand livres, sire, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Sixty thousand livres sire said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: So trifling an amount as that; but you possess other property, Monsieur de Vannes?
children.prevalue: So trifling an amount as that but you possess other property Monsieur de Vannes

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: I have nothing else, sire; only M. Fouquet pays me one thousand two hundred livres a year for his pew in the church.
children.prevalue: I have nothing else sire only M Fouquet pays me one thousand two hundred livres a year for his pew in the church

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Well, M. d'Herblay, I promise you something better than that.
children.prevalue: Well M d Herblay I promise you something better than that

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Sire
children.prevalue: Sire

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: I will not forget you.
children.prevalue: I will not forget you

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Aramis bowed, and the king also bowed to him in a respectful manner, as he was accustomed to do towards women and members of the Church. Aramis gathered that his audience was at an end; he took his leave of the king in the simple, unpretending language of a country pastor, and disappeared.
children.prevalue: Aramis bowed and the king also bowed to him in a respectful manner as he was accustomed to do towards women and members of the Church Aramis gathered that his audience was at an end he took his leave of the king in the simple unpretending language of a country pastor and disappeared

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: He is, indeed, a remarkable face, said the king, following him with his eyes as long as he could see him, and even to a certain degree when he was no longer to be seen.
children.prevalue: He is indeed a remarkable face said the king following him with his eyes as long as he could see him and even to a certain degree when he was no longer to be seen

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Sire, replied Fouquet, if that bishop had been educated early in life, no prelate in the kingdom would deserve the highest distinctions better than he.
children.prevalue: Sire replied Fouquet if that bishop had been educated early in life no prelate in the kingdom would deserve the highest distinctions better than he

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: His learning is not extensive, then?
children.prevalue: His learning is not extensive then

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: He changed the sword for the crucifix, and that rather late in life. But it matters little, if your majesty will permit me to speak of M. de Vannes again on another occasion
children.prevalue: He changed the sword for the crucifix and that rather late in life But it matters little if your majesty will permit me to speak of M de Vannes again on another occasion

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: I beg you to do so. But before speaking of him, let us speak of yourself, M. Fouquet.
children.prevalue: I beg you to do so But before speaking of him let us speak of yourself M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Of me, sire?
children.prevalue: Of me sire

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Yes, I have to pay you a thousand compliments.
children.prevalue: Yes I have to pay you a thousand compliments

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: I cannot express to your majesty the delight with which you overwhelm me.
children.prevalue: I cannot express to your majesty the delight with which you overwhelm me

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: I understand you, M. Fouquet. I confess, however, to have had certain prejudices against you.
children.prevalue: I understand you M Fouquet I confess however to have had certain prejudices against you

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: In that case, I was indeed unhappy, sire.
children.prevalue: In that case I was indeed unhappy sire

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: But they exist no longer. Did you not perceive
children.prevalue: But they exist no longer Did you not perceive

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: I did, indeed, sire; but I awaited with resignation the day when the truth would prevail; and it seems that that day has now arrived.
children.prevalue: I did indeed sire but I awaited with resignation the day when the truth would prevail and it seems that that day has now arrived

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Ah! you knew, then, you were in disgrace with me?
children.prevalue: Ah you knew then you were in disgrace with me

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Alas! sire, I perceived it.
children.prevalue: Alas sire I perceived it

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: And do you know the reason?
children.prevalue: And do you know the reason

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Perfectly well; your majesty thought that I had been wastefully lavish in expenditure.
children.prevalue: Perfectly well your majesty thought that I had been wastefully lavish in expenditure

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Not so; far from that.
children.prevalue: Not so far from that

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Or, rather an indifferent administrator. In a word, you thought that, as the people had no money, there would be none for your majesty either.
children.prevalue: Or rather an indifferent administrator In a word you thought that as the people had no money there would be none for your majesty either

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Yes, I thought so; but I was deceived.
children.prevalue: Yes I thought so but I was deceived

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Fouquet bowed.
children.prevalue: Fouquet bowed

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: And no disturbances, no complaints?
children.prevalue: And no disturbances no complaints

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: And money enough, said Fouquet.
children.prevalue: And money enough said Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: The fact is that you have been profuse with it during the last month.
children.prevalue: The fact is that you have been profuse with it during the last month

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: I have more, not only for all your majesty's requirements, but for all your caprices.
children.prevalue: I have more not only for all your majesty s requirements but for all your caprices

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: I thank you, Monsieur Fouquet, replied the king, seriously. I will not put you to the proof. For the next two months I do not intend to ask you for anything.
children.prevalue: I thank you Monsieur Fouquet replied the king seriously I will not put you to the proof For the next two months I do not intend to ask you for anything

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: I will avail myself of the interval to amass five or six millions, which will be serviceable as money in hand in case of war.
children.prevalue: I will avail myself of the interval to amass five or six millions which will be serviceable as money in hand in case of war

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Five or six millions!
children.prevalue: Five or six millions

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: For the expenses of your majesty's household only, be it understood.
children.prevalue: For the expenses of your majesty s household only be it understood

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: You think war probable, M. Fouquet?
children.prevalue: You think war probable M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: I think that if Heaven has bestowed on the eagle a beak and claws, it is to enable him to show his royal character.
children.prevalue: I think that if Heaven has bestowed on the eagle a beak and claws it is to enable him to show his royal character

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: The king blushed with pleasure.
children.prevalue: The king blushed with pleasure

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: We have spent a great deal of money these few days past, Monsieur Fouquet; will you not scold me for it?
children.prevalue: We have spent a great deal of money these few days past Monsieur Fouquet will you not scold me for it

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: Sire, your majesty has still twenty years of youth to enjoy, and a thousand million francs to lavish in those twenty years.
children.prevalue: Sire your majesty has still twenty years of youth to enjoy and a thousand million francs to lavish in those twenty years

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: That is a great deal of money, M. Fouquet, said the king.
children.prevalue: That is a great deal of money M Fouquet said the king

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: I will economize, sire. Besides, your majesty as two valuable servants in M. Colbert and myself. The one will encourage you to be prodigal with your treasuresand this shall be myself, if my services should continue to be agreeable to your majesty; and the other will economize money for you, and this will be M. Colbert's province.
children.prevalue: I will economize sire Besides your majesty as two valuable servants in M Colbert and myself The one will encourage you to be prodigal with your treasuresand this shall be myself if my services should continue to be agreeable to your majesty and the other will economize money for you and this will be M Colbert s province

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: M. Colbert? returned the king, astonished.
children.prevalue: M Colbert returned the king astonished

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Certainly, sire; M. Colbert is an excellent accountant.
children.prevalue: Certainly sire M Colbert is an excellent accountant

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: At this commendation, bestowed by the traduced on the traducer, the king felt himself penetrated with confidence and admiration. There was not, moreover, either in Fouquet's voice or look, anything which injuriously affected a single syllable of the remark he had made; he did not pass one eulogium, as it were, in order to acquire the right of making two reproaches. The king comprehended him, and yielding to so much generosity and address, he said, You praise M. Colbert, then?
children.prevalue: At this commendation bestowed by the traduced on the traducer the king felt himself penetrated with confidence and admiration There was not moreover either in Fouquet s voice or look anything which injuriously affected a single syllable of the remark he had made he did not pass one eulogium as it were in order to acquire the right of making two reproaches The king comprehended him and yielding to so much generosity and address he said You praise M Colbert then

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: Yes, sire, I praise him; for, besides being a man of merit, I believe him to be devoted to your majesty's interests.
children.prevalue: Yes sire I praise him for besides being a man of merit I believe him to be devoted to your majesty s interests

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: Is that because he has often interfered with your own views? said the king, smiling.
children.prevalue: Is that because he has often interfered with your own views said the king smiling

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: Exactly, sire.
children.prevalue: Exactly sire

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: Explain yourself.
children.prevalue: Explain yourself

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: It is simple enough. I am the man who is needed to make the money come in; he is the man who is needed to prevent it leaving.
children.prevalue: It is simple enough I am the man who is needed to make the money come in he is the man who is needed to prevent it leaving

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: Nay, nay, monsieur le surintendant, you will presently say something which will correct this good opinion.
children.prevalue: Nay nay monsieur le surintendant you will presently say something which will correct this good opinion

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: Do you mean as far as administrative abilities are concerned, sire?
children.prevalue: Do you mean as far as administrative abilities are concerned sire

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: Not in the slightest.
children.prevalue: Not in the slightest

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: Really?
children.prevalue: Really

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: Upon my honor, sire, I do not know throughout France a better clerk than M. Colbert.
children.prevalue: Upon my honor sire I do not know throughout France a better clerk than M Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: This word clerk did not possess, in 1661, the somewhat subservient signification attached to it in the present day; but, as spoken by Fouquet, whom the king had addressed as the superintendent, it seemed to acquire an insignificant and petty character, that at this juncture served admirably to restore Fouquet to his place, and Colbert to his own.
children.prevalue: This word clerk did not possess in 1661 the somewhat subservient signification attached to it in the present day but as spoken by Fouquet whom the king had addressed as the superintendent it seemed to acquire an insignificant and petty character that at this juncture served admirably to restore Fouquet to his place and Colbert to his own

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: And yet, said Louis XIV., it was Colbert, however, that, notwithstanding his economy, had the arrangement of my fetes here at Fontainebleau; and I assure you, Monsieur Fouquet, that in no way has he checked the expenditure of money. Fouquet bowed, but did not reply.
children.prevalue: And yet said Louis XIV it was Colbert however that notwithstanding his economy had the arrangement of my fetes here at Fontainebleau and I assure you Monsieur Fouquet that in no way has he checked the expenditure of money Fouquet bowed but did not reply

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: Is it not your opinion too? said the king.
children.prevalue: Is it not your opinion too said the king

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: I think, sire, he replied, that M. Colbert has done what he had to do in an exceedingly orderly manner, and that he deserves, in this respect, all the praise your majesty may bestow upon him.
children.prevalue: I think sire he replied that M Colbert has done what he had to do in an exceedingly orderly manner and that he deserves in this respect all the praise your majesty may bestow upon him

children.name: Paragraph_145
children.value: The word orderly was a proper accompaniment for the word clerk. The king possessed that extreme sensitiveness of organization, that delicacy of perception, which pierced through and detected the regular order of feelings and sensations, before the actual sensations themselves, and he therefore comprehended that the clerk had, in Fouquet's opinion, been too full of method and order in his arrangements; in other words, that the magnificent fetes of Fontainebleau might have been rendered more magnificent still. The king consequently felt that there was something in the amusements he had provided with which some person or another might be able to find fault; he experienced a little of the annoyance felt by a person coming from the provinces to Paris, dressed out in the very best clothes which his wardrobe can furnish, only to find that the fashionably dressed man there looks at him either too much or not enough. This part of the conversation, which Fouquet had carried on with so much moderation, yet with extreme tact, inspired the king with the highest esteem for the character of the man and the capacity of the minister. Fouquet took his leave at a quarter to three in the morning, and the king went to bed a little uneasy and confused at the indirect lesson he had received; and a good hour was employed by him in going over again in memory the embroideries, the tapestries, the bills of fare of the various banquets, the architecture of the triumphal arches, the arrangements for the illuminations and fireworks, all the offspring of the Clerk Colbert's invention. The result was, the king passed in review before him everything that had taken place during the last eight days, and decided that faults could be found in his fetes. But Fouquet, by his politeness, his thoughtful consideration, and his generosity, had injured Colbert more deeply than the latter, by his artifice, his illwill, and his persevering hatred, had ever yet succeeded in hurting Fouquet.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: As we have seen, SaintAignan had quitted the king's apartment at the very moment the superintendent entered it. SaintAignan was charged with a mission that required dispatch, and he was going to do his utmost to turn his time to the best advantage. He whom we have introduced as the king's friend was indeed an uncommon personage; he was one of those valuable courtiers whose vigilance and acuteness of perception threw all other favorites into the shade, and counterbalanced, by his close attention, the servility of Dangeau, who was not the favorite, but the toady of the king. M. de SaintAignan began to think what was to be done in the present position of affairs. He reflected that his first information ought to come from De Guiche. He therefore set out in search of him, but De Guiche, whom we saw disappear behind one of the wings, and who seemed to have returned to his own apartments, had not entered the chateau. SaintAignan therefore went in quest of him, and after having turned, and twisted, and searched in every direction, he perceived something like a human form leaning against a tree. This figure was as motionless as a statue, and seemed deeply engaged in looking at a window, although its curtains were closely drawn. As this window happened to be Madame's, SaintAignan concluded that the form in question must be that of De Guiche. He advanced cautiously, and found he was not mistaken. De Guiche had, after his conversation with Madame, carried away such a weight of happiness, that all of his strength of mind was hardly sufficient to enable him to support it. On his side, SaintAignan knew that De Guiche had had something to do with La Valliere's introduction to Madame's household, for a courtier knows everything and forgets nothing; but he had never learned under what title or conditions De Guiche had conferred his protection upon La Valliere. But, as in asking a great many questions it is singular if a man does not learn something, SaintAignan reckoned upon learning much or little, as the case might be, if he questioned De Guiche with that extreme tact, and, at the same time, with that persistence in attaining an object, of which he was capable. SaintAignan's plan was as follows: If the information obtained was satisfactory, he would inform the king, with alacrity, that he had lighted upon a pearl, and claim the privilege of setting the pearl in question in the royal crown. If the information were unsatisfactory,which, after all, might be possible,he would examine how far the king cared about La Valliere, and make use of his information in such a manner as to get rid of the girl altogether, and thereby obtain all the merit of her banishment with all the ladies of the court who might have the least pretensions to the king's heart, beginning with Madame and finishing with the queen. In case the king should show himself obstinate in his fancy, then he would not produce the damaging information he had obtained, but would let La Valliere know that this damaging information was carefully preserved in a secret drawer of her confidant's memory. In this manner, he would be able to air his generosity before the poor girl's eyes, and so keep her in constant suspense between gratitude and apprehension, to such an extent as to make her a friend at court, interested, as an accomplice, in trying to make his fortune, while she was making her own. As far as concerned the day when the bombshell of the past should burst, if ever there were any occasion, SaintAignan promised himself that he would by that time have taken all possible precautions, and would pretend an entire ignorance of the matter to the king; while, with regard to La Valliere, he would still have an opportunity of being considered the personification of generosity. It was with such ideas as these, which the fire of covetousness had caused to dawn in half an hour, that SaintAignan, the son of earth, as La Fontaine would have said, determined to get De Guiche into conversation: in other words, to trouble him in his happinessa happiness of which SaintAignan was quite ignorant. It was long past one o'clock in the morning when SaintAignan perceived De Guiche, standing, motionless, leaning against the trunk of a tree, with his eyes fastened upon the lighted window,the sleepiest hour of nighttime, which painters crown with myrtles and budding poppies, the hour when eyes are heavy, hearts throb, and heads feel dull and languidan hour which casts upon the day which has passed away a look of regret, while addressing a loving greeting to the dawning light. For De Guiche it was the dawn of unutterable happiness; he would have bestowed a treasure upon a beggar, had one stood before him, to secure him uninterrupted indulgence in his dreams. It was precisely at this hour that SaintAignan, badly advised,selfishness always counsels badly,came and struck him on the shoulder, at the very moment he was murmuring a word, or rather a name.
