children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Ah! he cried loudly, I was looking for you.
children.prevalue: Ah he cried loudly I was looking for you

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: For me? said De Guiche, starting.
children.prevalue: For me said De Guiche starting

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Yes; and I find you seemingly moonstruck. Is it likely, my dear comte, you have been attacked by a poetical malady, and are making verses?
children.prevalue: Yes and I find you seemingly moonstruck Is it likely my dear comte you have been attacked by a poetical malady and are making verses

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The young man forced a smile upon his lips, while a thousand conflicting sensations were muttering defiance of SaintAignan in the deep recesses of his heart. Perhaps, he said. But by what happy chance
children.prevalue: The young man forced a smile upon his lips while a thousand conflicting sensations were muttering defiance of SaintAignan in the deep recesses of his heart Perhaps he said But by what happy chance

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Ah! your remark shows that you did not hear what I said.
children.prevalue: Ah your remark shows that you did not hear what I said

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: How so?
children.prevalue: How so

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Why, I began by telling you I was looking for you.
children.prevalue: Why I began by telling you I was looking for you

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: You were looking for me?
children.prevalue: You were looking for me

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Yes: and I find you now in the very act.
children.prevalue: Yes and I find you now in the very act

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Of doing what, I should like to know?
children.prevalue: Of doing what I should like to know

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Of singing the praises of Phyllis.
children.prevalue: Of singing the praises of Phyllis

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Well, I do not deny it, said De Guiche, laughing. Yes, my dear comte, I was celebrating Phyllis's praises.
children.prevalue: Well I do not deny it said De Guiche laughing Yes my dear comte I was celebrating Phyllis s praises

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: And you have acquired the right to do so.
children.prevalue: And you have acquired the right to do so

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I?
children.prevalue: I

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: You; no doubt of it. You; the intrepid protector of every beautiful and clever woman.
children.prevalue: You no doubt of it You the intrepid protector of every beautiful and clever woman

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: In the name of goodness, what story have you got hold of now?
children.prevalue: In the name of goodness what story have you got hold of now

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Acknowledged truths, I am well aware. But stay a moment; I am in love.
children.prevalue: Acknowledged truths I am well aware But stay a moment I am in love

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: You?
children.prevalue: You

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: So much the better, my dear comte; tell me all about it. And De Guiche, afraid that SaintAignan might perhaps presently observe the window, where the light was still burning, took the comte's arm and endeavored to lead him away.
children.prevalue: So much the better my dear comte tell me all about it And De Guiche afraid that SaintAignan might perhaps presently observe the window where the light was still burning took the comte s arm and endeavored to lead him away

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Oh! said the latter, resisting, do not take me towards those dark woods, it is too damp there. Let us stay in the moonlight. And while he yielded to the pressure of De Guiche's arm, he remained in the flowergarden adjoining the chateau.
children.prevalue: Oh said the latter resisting do not take me towards those dark woods it is too damp there Let us stay in the moonlight And while he yielded to the pressure of De Guiche s arm he remained in the flowergarden adjoining the chateau

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Well, said De Guiche, resigning himself, lead me where you like, and ask me what you please.
children.prevalue: Well said De Guiche resigning himself lead me where you like and ask me what you please

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: It is impossible to be more agreeable than you are. And then, after a moment's silence, SaintAignan continued, I wish you to tell me something about a certain person in who you have interested yourself.
children.prevalue: It is impossible to be more agreeable than you are And then after a moment s silence SaintAignan continued I wish you to tell me something about a certain person in who you have interested yourself

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: And with whom you are in love?
children.prevalue: And with whom you are in love

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: I will neither admit nor deny it. You understand that a man does not very readily place his heart where there is no hope of return, and that it is most essential he should take measures of security in advance.
children.prevalue: I will neither admit nor deny it You understand that a man does not very readily place his heart where there is no hope of return and that it is most essential he should take measures of security in advance

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: You are right, said De Guiche with a sigh; a man's heart is a very precious gift.
children.prevalue: You are right said De Guiche with a sigh a man s heart is a very precious gift

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Mine particularly is very tender, and in that light I present it to you.
children.prevalue: Mine particularly is very tender and in that light I present it to you

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Oh! you are well known, comte. Well?
children.prevalue: Oh you are well known comte Well

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: It is simply a question of Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente.
children.prevalue: It is simply a question of Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Why, my dear SaintAignan, you are losing your senses, I should think.
children.prevalue: Why my dear SaintAignan you are losing your senses I should think

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Why so?
children.prevalue: Why so

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I have never shown or taken any interest in Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente.
children.prevalue: I have never shown or taken any interest in Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Bah!
children.prevalue: Bah

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Never.
children.prevalue: Never

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Did you not obtain admission for Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente into Madame's household?
children.prevalue: Did you not obtain admission for Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente into Madame s household

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Mademoiselle de TonnayCharenteand you ought to know it better than any one else, my dear comteis of a sufficiently good family to make her presence here desirable, and her admittance very easy.
children.prevalue: Mademoiselle de TonnayCharenteand you ought to know it better than any one else my dear comteis of a sufficiently good family to make her presence here desirable and her admittance very easy

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: You are jesting.
children.prevalue: You are jesting

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: No; and upon my honor I do not know what you mean.
children.prevalue: No and upon my honor I do not know what you mean

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: And you had nothing, then, to do with her admission?
children.prevalue: And you had nothing then to do with her admission

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: You do not know her?
children.prevalue: You do not know her

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: I saw her for the first time the day she was presented to Madame. Therefore, as I have never taken any interest in her, as I do not know her, I am not able to give you the information you require. And De Guiche made a movement as though he were about to leave his questioner.
children.prevalue: I saw her for the first time the day she was presented to Madame Therefore as I have never taken any interest in her as I do not know her I am not able to give you the information you require And De Guiche made a movement as though he were about to leave his questioner

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Nay, nay, one moment, my dear comte, said SaintAignan; you shall not escape me in this manner.
children.prevalue: Nay nay one moment my dear comte said SaintAignan you shall not escape me in this manner

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Why, really, it seems to me that it is now time to return to our apartments.
children.prevalue: Why really it seems to me that it is now time to return to our apartments

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: And yet you were not going in when Idid not meet, but found you.
children.prevalue: And yet you were not going in when Idid not meet but found you

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Therefore, my dear comte, said De Guiche, as long as you have anything to say to me, I place myself entirely at your service.
children.prevalue: Therefore my dear comte said De Guiche as long as you have anything to say to me I place myself entirely at your service

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: And you are quite right in doing so. What matters half an hour more or less? Will you swear that you have no injurious communications to make to me about her, and that any injurious communications you might possibly have to make are not the cause of your silence?
children.prevalue: And you are quite right in doing so What matters half an hour more or less Will you swear that you have no injurious communications to make to me about her and that any injurious communications you might possibly have to make are not the cause of your silence

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Oh! I believe the poor child to be as pure as crystal.
children.prevalue: Oh I believe the poor child to be as pure as crystal

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: You overwhelm me with joy. And yet I do not wish to have towards you the appearance of a man so badly informed as I seem. It is quite certain that you supplied the princess's household with the ladies of honor. Nay, a song has even been written about it.
children.prevalue: You overwhelm me with joy And yet I do not wish to have towards you the appearance of a man so badly informed as I seem It is quite certain that you supplied the princess s household with the ladies of honor Nay a song has even been written about it

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Oh! songs are written about everything.
children.prevalue: Oh songs are written about everything

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Do you know it?
children.prevalue: Do you know it

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: No: sing it to me and I shall make its acquaintance.
children.prevalue: No sing it to me and I shall make its acquaintance

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: I cannot tell you how it begins; I only remember how it ends.
children.prevalue: I cannot tell you how it begins I only remember how it ends

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Very well, at all events, that is something.
children.prevalue: Very well at all events that is something

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: When Maids of Honor happen to run short, Lo!Guiche will furnish the entire Court.
children.prevalue: When Maids of Honor happen to run short Lo Guiche will furnish the entire Court

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: The idea is weak, and the rhyme poor, said De Guiche.
children.prevalue: The idea is weak and the rhyme poor said De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: What can you expect, my dear fellow? it is not Racine's or Moliere's, but La Feuillade's; and a great lord cannot rhyme like a beggarly poet.
children.prevalue: What can you expect my dear fellow it is not Racine s or Moliere s but La Feuillade s and a great lord cannot rhyme like a beggarly poet

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: It is very unfortunate, though, that you only remember the termination.
children.prevalue: It is very unfortunate though that you only remember the termination

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Stay, stay, I have just recollected the beginning of the second couplet.
children.prevalue: Stay stay I have just recollected the beginning of the second couplet

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Why, there's the birdcage, with a pretty pair, The charming Montalais, and...
children.prevalue: Why there s the birdcage with a pretty pair The charming Montalais and

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: And La Valliere, exclaimed Guiche, impatiently, and completely ignorant besides of SaintAignan's object.
children.prevalue: And La Valliere exclaimed Guiche impatiently and completely ignorant besides of SaintAignan s object

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Yes, yes, you have it. You have hit upon the word, 'La Valliere.'
children.prevalue: Yes yes you have it You have hit upon the word La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: A grand discovery indeed.
children.prevalue: A grand discovery indeed

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Montalais and La Valliere, these, then, are the two young girls in whom you interest yourself, said SaintAignan, laughing.
children.prevalue: Montalais and La Valliere these then are the two young girls in whom you interest yourself said SaintAignan laughing

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: And so Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente's name is not to be met with in the song?
children.prevalue: And so Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente s name is not to be met with in the song

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: No, indeed.
children.prevalue: No indeed

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: And are you satisfied, then?
children.prevalue: And are you satisfied then

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Perfectly; but I find Montalais there, said SaintAignan, still laughing.
children.prevalue: Perfectly but I find Montalais there said SaintAignan still laughing

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Oh! you will find her everywhere. She is a singularly active young lady.
children.prevalue: Oh you will find her everywhere She is a singularly active young lady

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: You know her?
children.prevalue: You know her

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Indirectly. She was the protegee of a man named Malicorne, who is a protegee of Manicamp's; Manicamp asked me to get the situation of maid of honor for Montalais in Madame's household, and a situation for Malicorne as an officer in Monsieur's household. Well, I asked for the appointments, for you know very well that I have a weakness for that droll fellow Manicamp.
children.prevalue: Indirectly She was the protegee of a man named Malicorne who is a protegee of Manicamp s Manicamp asked me to get the situation of maid of honor for Montalais in Madame s household and a situation for Malicorne as an officer in Monsieur s household Well I asked for the appointments for you know very well that I have a weakness for that droll fellow Manicamp

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: And you obtained what you sought?
children.prevalue: And you obtained what you sought

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: For Montalais, yes; for Malicorne, yes and no; for as yet he is only on trial. Do you wish to know anything else?
children.prevalue: For Montalais yes for Malicorne yes and no for as yet he is only on trial Do you wish to know anything else

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: The last word of the couplet still remains, La Valliere, said SaintAignan, resuming the smile that so tormented Guiche.
children.prevalue: The last word of the couplet still remains La Valliere said SaintAignan resuming the smile that so tormented Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Well, said the latter, it is true that I obtained admission for her in Madame's household.
children.prevalue: Well said the latter it is true that I obtained admission for her in Madame s household

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Ah! said SaintAignan.
children.prevalue: Ah said SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: But, continued Guiche, assuming a great coldness of manner, you will oblige me, comte, not to jest about that name. Mademoiselle la Baume le Blanc de la Valliere is a young lady perfectly wellconducted.
children.prevalue: But continued Guiche assuming a great coldness of manner you will oblige me comte not to jest about that name Mademoiselle la Baume le Blanc de la Valliere is a young lady perfectly wellconducted

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Perfectly wellconducted do you say?
children.prevalue: Perfectly wellconducted do you say

children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Then you have not heard the last rumor? exclaimed SaintAignan.
children.prevalue: Then you have not heard the last rumor exclaimed SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: No, and you will do me a service, my dear comte, in keeping this report to yourself and to those who circulate it.
children.prevalue: No and you will do me a service my dear comte in keeping this report to yourself and to those who circulate it

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Ah! bah! you take the matter up very seriously.
children.prevalue: Ah bah you take the matter up very seriously

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Yes; Mademoiselle de Valliere is beloved by one of my best friends.
children.prevalue: Yes Mademoiselle de Valliere is beloved by one of my best friends

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: SaintAignan started. Aha! he said.
children.prevalue: SaintAignan started Aha he said

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Yes, comte, continued Guiche; and consequently, you, the most distinguished man in France for polished courtesy of manner, will understand that I cannot allow my friend to be placed in a ridiculous position.
children.prevalue: Yes comte continued Guiche and consequently you the most distinguished man in France for polished courtesy of manner will understand that I cannot allow my friend to be placed in a ridiculous position

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: SaintAignan began to bite his nails, partially from vexation, and partially from disappointed curiosity. Guiche made him a very profound bow.
children.prevalue: SaintAignan began to bite his nails partially from vexation and partially from disappointed curiosity Guiche made him a very profound bow

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: You send me away, said SaintAignan, who was dying to know the name of the friend.
children.prevalue: You send me away said SaintAignan who was dying to know the name of the friend

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: I do not send you away, my dear fellow. I am going to finish my lines to Phyllis.
children.prevalue: I do not send you away my dear fellow I am going to finish my lines to Phyllis

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: And those lines
children.prevalue: And those lines

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Are a quatrain. You understand, I trust, that a quatrain is a serious affair?
children.prevalue: Are a quatrain You understand I trust that a quatrain is a serious affair

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Of course.
children.prevalue: Of course

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: And as, of these four lines, of which it is composed, I have yet three and a half to make, I need my undivided attention.
children.prevalue: And as of these four lines of which it is composed I have yet three and a half to make I need my undivided attention

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: I quite understand. Adieu! comte. By the by
children.prevalue: I quite understand Adieu comte By the by

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: What?
children.prevalue: What

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Are you quick at making verses?
children.prevalue: Are you quick at making verses

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Wonderfully so.
children.prevalue: Wonderfully so

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Will you have quite finished the three lines and a half tomorrow morning?
children.prevalue: Will you have quite finished the three lines and a half tomorrow morning

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: I hope so.
children.prevalue: I hope so

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Adieu, then, until tomorrow.
children.prevalue: Adieu then until tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Adieu, adieu!
children.prevalue: Adieu adieu

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: SaintAignan was obliged to accept the notice to quit; he accordingly did so, and disappeared behind the hedge. Their conversation had led Guiche and SaintAignan a good distance from the chateau.
children.prevalue: SaintAignan was obliged to accept the notice to quit he accordingly did so and disappeared behind the hedge Their conversation had led Guiche and SaintAignan a good distance from the chateau

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Every mathematician, every poet, and every dreamer has his own subjects of interest. SaintAignan, on leaving Guiche, found himself at the extremity of the grove,at the very spot where the outbuildings of the servants begin, and where, behind the thickets of acacias and chestnuttrees interlacing their branches, which were hidden by masses of clematis and young vines, the wall which separated the woods from the courtyard was erected. SaintAignan, alone, took the path which led towards these buildings; De Guiche going off in the opposite direction. The one proceeded to the flowergarden, while the other bent his steps towards the walls. SaintAignan walked on between rows of mountainash, lilac, and hawthorn, which formed an almost impenetrable roof above his head; his feet were buried in the soft gravel and thick moss. He was deliberating a means of taking his revenge, which seemed difficult for him to carry out, and was vexed with himself for not having learned more about La Valliere, notwithstanding the ingenious measures he had resorted to in order to acquire more information about her, when suddenly the murmur of a human voice attracted his attention. He heard whispers, the complaining tones of a woman's voice mingled with entreaties, smothered laughter, sighs, and halfstilted exclamations of surprise; but above them all, the woman's voice prevailed. SaintAignan stopped to look about him; he perceived from the greatest surprise that the voices proceeded, not from the ground, but from the branches of the trees. As he glided along under the covered walk, he raised his head, and observed at the top of the wall a woman perched upon a ladder, in eager conversation with a man seated on a branch of a chestnuttree, whose head alone could be seen, the rest of his body being concealed in the thick covert of the chestnut. [5]
