children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: SaintAignan, who had only been seeking for information, had met with an adventure. This was indeed a piece of good luck. Curious to learn why, and particularly what about, this man and woman were conversing at such an hour, and in such a singular position, SaintAignan made himself as small as he possibly could, and approached almost under the rounds of the ladder. And taking measures to make himself as comfortable as possible, he leaned his back against a tree and listened, and heard the following conversation. The woman was the first to speak.
children.prevalue: SaintAignan who had only been seeking for information had met with an adventure This was indeed a piece of good luck Curious to learn why and particularly what about this man and woman were conversing at such an hour and in such a singular position SaintAignan made himself as small as he possibly could and approached almost under the rounds of the ladder And taking measures to make himself as comfortable as possible he leaned his back against a tree and listened and heard the following conversation The woman was the first to speak

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Really, Monsieur Manicamp, she said, in a voice which, notwithstanding the reproaches she addressed to him, preserved a marked tone of coquetry, really your indiscretion is of a very dangerous character. We cannot talk long in this manner without being observed.
children.prevalue: Really Monsieur Manicamp she said in a voice which notwithstanding the reproaches she addressed to him preserved a marked tone of coquetry really your indiscretion is of a very dangerous character We cannot talk long in this manner without being observed

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: That is very probable, said the man, in the calmest and coolest of tones.
children.prevalue: That is very probable said the man in the calmest and coolest of tones

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: In that case, then, what would people say? Oh! if any one were to see me, I declare I should die of very shame.
children.prevalue: In that case then what would people say Oh if any one were to see me I declare I should die of very shame

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Oh! that would be very silly; I do not believe you would.
children.prevalue: Oh that would be very silly I do not believe you would

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: It might have been different if there had been anything between us; but to injure myself gratuitously is really very foolish of me; so, adieu, Monsieur Manicamp.
children.prevalue: It might have been different if there had been anything between us but to injure myself gratuitously is really very foolish of me so adieu Monsieur Manicamp

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: So far so good; I know the man, and now let me see who the woman is, said SaintAignan, watching the rounds of the ladder, on which were standing two pretty little feet covered with blue satin shoes.
children.prevalue: So far so good I know the man and now let me see who the woman is said SaintAignan watching the rounds of the ladder on which were standing two pretty little feet covered with blue satin shoes

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Nay, nay, for pity's sake, my dear Montalais, cried Manicamp, deuce take it, do not go away; I have a great many things to say to you, of the greatest importance, still.
children.prevalue: Nay nay for pity s sake my dear Montalais cried Manicamp deuce take it do not go away I have a great many things to say to you of the greatest importance still

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Montalais, said SaintAignan to himself, one of the three. Each of the three gossips had her adventure, only I imagined the hero of this one's adventure was Malicorne and not Manicamp.
children.prevalue: Montalais said SaintAignan to himself one of the three Each of the three gossips had her adventure only I imagined the hero of this one s adventure was Malicorne and not Manicamp

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: At her companion's appeal, Montalais stopped in the middle of her descent, and SaintAignan could observe the unfortunate Manicamp climb from one branch of the chestnuttree to another, either to improve his situation or to overcome the fatigue consequent upon his inconvenient position.
children.prevalue: At her companion s appeal Montalais stopped in the middle of her descent and SaintAignan could observe the unfortunate Manicamp climb from one branch of the chestnuttree to another either to improve his situation or to overcome the fatigue consequent upon his inconvenient position

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Now, listen to me, said he; you quite understand, I hope, that my intentions are perfectly innocent?
children.prevalue: Now listen to me said he you quite understand I hope that my intentions are perfectly innocent

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Of course. But why did you write me a letter stimulating my gratitude towards you? Why did you ask me for an interview at such an hour and in such a place as this?
children.prevalue: Of course But why did you write me a letter stimulating my gratitude towards you Why did you ask me for an interview at such an hour and in such a place as this

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I stimulated your gratitude in reminding you that it was I who had been the means of your becoming attached to Madame's household; because most anxiously desirous of obtaining the interview you have been kind enough to grant me, I employed the means which appeared to me most certain to insure it. And my reason for soliciting it, at such an hour and in such a locality, was, that the hour seemed to me to be the most prudent, and the locality the least open to observation. Moreover, I had occasion to speak to you upon certain subjects which require both prudence and solitude.
children.prevalue: I stimulated your gratitude in reminding you that it was I who had been the means of your becoming attached to Madame s household because most anxiously desirous of obtaining the interview you have been kind enough to grant me I employed the means which appeared to me most certain to insure it And my reason for soliciting it at such an hour and in such a locality was that the hour seemed to me to be the most prudent and the locality the least open to observation Moreover I had occasion to speak to you upon certain subjects which require both prudence and solitude

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Monsieur Manicamp!
children.prevalue: Monsieur Manicamp

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: But everything I wish to say is perfectly honorable, I assure you.
children.prevalue: But everything I wish to say is perfectly honorable I assure you

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: I think, Monsieur Manicamp, it will be more becoming in me to take my leave.
children.prevalue: I think Monsieur Manicamp it will be more becoming in me to take my leave

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: No, no!listen to me, or I will jump from my perch here to yours; and be careful how you set me at defiance, for a branch of this chestnuttree causes me a good deal of annoyance, and may provoke me to extreme measures. Do not follow the example of this branch, then, but listen to me.
children.prevalue: No no listen to me or I will jump from my perch here to yours and be careful how you set me at defiance for a branch of this chestnuttree causes me a good deal of annoyance and may provoke me to extreme measures Do not follow the example of this branch then but listen to me

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I am listening, and I agree to do so; but be as brief as possible, for if you have a branch of the chestnuttree which annoys you, I wish you to understand that one of the rounds of the ladder is hurting the soles of my feet, and my shoes are being cut through.
children.prevalue: I am listening and I agree to do so but be as brief as possible for if you have a branch of the chestnuttree which annoys you I wish you to understand that one of the rounds of the ladder is hurting the soles of my feet and my shoes are being cut through

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Do me the kindness to give me your hand.
children.prevalue: Do me the kindness to give me your hand

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Why?
children.prevalue: Why

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Will you have the goodness to do so?
children.prevalue: Will you have the goodness to do so

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: There is my hand, then; but what are you going to do?
children.prevalue: There is my hand then but what are you going to do

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: To draw you towards me.
children.prevalue: To draw you towards me

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: What for? You surely do not wish me to join you in the tree?
children.prevalue: What for You surely do not wish me to join you in the tree

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: No; but I wish you to sit down upon the wall; there, that will do; there is quite room enough, and I would give a great deal to be allowed to sit down beside you.
children.prevalue: No but I wish you to sit down upon the wall there that will do there is quite room enough and I would give a great deal to be allowed to sit down beside you

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: No, no; you are very well where you are; we should be seen.
children.prevalue: No no you are very well where you are we should be seen

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Do you really think so? said Manicamp, in an insinuating voice.
children.prevalue: Do you really think so said Manicamp in an insinuating voice

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I am sure of it.
children.prevalue: I am sure of it

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Very well, I remain in my tree, then, although I cannot be worse placed.
children.prevalue: Very well I remain in my tree then although I cannot be worse placed

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Monsieur Manicamp, we are wandering away from the subject.
children.prevalue: Monsieur Manicamp we are wandering away from the subject

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: You are right, we are so.
children.prevalue: You are right we are so

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: You wrote me a letter?
children.prevalue: You wrote me a letter

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I did.
children.prevalue: I did

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Why did you write?
children.prevalue: Why did you write

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Fancy, at two o'clock today, De Guiche left.
children.prevalue: Fancy at two o clock today De Guiche left

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: What then?
children.prevalue: What then

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Seeing him set off, I followed him, as I usually do.
children.prevalue: Seeing him set off I followed him as I usually do

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Of course, I see that, since you are here now.
children.prevalue: Of course I see that since you are here now

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Don't be in a hurry. You are aware, I suppose, that De Guiche is up to his very neck in disgrace?
children.prevalue: Don t be in a hurry You are aware I suppose that De Guiche is up to his very neck in disgrace

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Alas! yes.
children.prevalue: Alas yes

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: It was the very height of imprudence on his part, then, to come to Fontainebleau to seek those who had at Paris sent him away into exile, and particularly those from whom he had been separated.
children.prevalue: It was the very height of imprudence on his part then to come to Fontainebleau to seek those who had at Paris sent him away into exile and particularly those from whom he had been separated

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Monsieur Manicamp, you reason like Pythagoras.
children.prevalue: Monsieur Manicamp you reason like Pythagoras

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Moreover, De Guiche is as obstinate as a man in love can be, and he refused to listen to any of my remonstrances. I begged, I implored him, but he would not listen to anything. Oh, the deuce!
children.prevalue: Moreover De Guiche is as obstinate as a man in love can be and he refused to listen to any of my remonstrances I begged I implored him but he would not listen to anything Oh the deuce

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: What's the matter?
children.prevalue: What s the matter

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: I beg your pardon, Mademoiselle Montalais, but this confounded branch, about which I have already had the honor of speaking to you, has just torn a certain portion of my dress.
children.prevalue: I beg your pardon Mademoiselle Montalais but this confounded branch about which I have already had the honor of speaking to you has just torn a certain portion of my dress

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: It is quite dark, replied Montalais, laughing; so, pray continue, M. Manicamp.
children.prevalue: It is quite dark replied Montalais laughing so pray continue M Manicamp

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: De Guiche set off on horseback as hard as he could, I following him, at a slower pace. You quite understand that to throw one's self into the water, for instance, with a friend, at the same headlong rate as he himself would do it, would be the act either of a fool or a madman. I therefore allowed De Guiche to get in advance, and I proceeded on my way with a commendable slowness of pace, feeling quite sure that my unfortunate friend would not be received, or, if he had been, that he would ride off again at the very first cross, disagreeable answer; and that I should see him returning much faster than he went, without having, myself, gone much farther than Ris or Melunand that even was a good distance you will admit, for it is eleven leagues to get there and as many to return.
children.prevalue: De Guiche set off on horseback as hard as he could I following him at a slower pace You quite understand that to throw one s self into the water for instance with a friend at the same headlong rate as he himself would do it would be the act either of a fool or a madman I therefore allowed De Guiche to get in advance and I proceeded on my way with a commendable slowness of pace feeling quite sure that my unfortunate friend would not be received or if he had been that he would ride off again at the very first cross disagreeable answer and that I should see him returning much faster than he went without having myself gone much farther than Ris or Melunand that even was a good distance you will admit for it is eleven leagues to get there and as many to return

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Montalais shrugged her shoulders.
children.prevalue: Montalais shrugged her shoulders

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Laugh as much as you like; but if, instead of being comfortably seated on the top of the wall as you are, you were sitting on this branch as if you were on horseback, you would, like Augustus, aspire to descend.
children.prevalue: Laugh as much as you like but if instead of being comfortably seated on the top of the wall as you are you were sitting on this branch as if you were on horseback you would like Augustus aspire to descend

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Be patient, my dear M. Manicamp; a few minutes will soon pass away; you were saying, I think, that you had gone beyond Ris and Melun.
children.prevalue: Be patient my dear M Manicamp a few minutes will soon pass away you were saying I think that you had gone beyond Ris and Melun

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Yes, I went through Ris and Melun, and I continued to go on, more and more surprised that I did not see him returning; and here I am at Fontainebleau; I look for and inquire after De Guiche everywhere, but no one has seen him, no one in the town has spoken to him; he arrived riding at full gallop, he entered the chateau; and there he has disappeared. I have been here at Fontainebleau since eight o'clock this evening inquiring for De Guiche in every direction, but no De Guiche can be found. I am dying with uneasiness. You understand that I have not been running my head into the lion's den, in entering the chateau, as my imprudent friend has done; I came at once to the servants' offices, and I succeeded in getting a letter conveyed to you; and now, for Heaven's sake, my dear young lady, relieve me from my anxiety.
children.prevalue: Yes I went through Ris and Melun and I continued to go on more and more surprised that I did not see him returning and here I am at Fontainebleau I look for and inquire after De Guiche everywhere but no one has seen him no one in the town has spoken to him he arrived riding at full gallop he entered the chateau and there he has disappeared I have been here at Fontainebleau since eight o clock this evening inquiring for De Guiche in every direction but no De Guiche can be found I am dying with uneasiness You understand that I have not been running my head into the lion s den in entering the chateau as my imprudent friend has done I came at once to the servants offices and I succeeded in getting a letter conveyed to you and now for Heaven s sake my dear young lady relieve me from my anxiety

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: There will be no difficulty in that, my dear M. Manicamp; your friend De Guiche has been admirably received.
children.prevalue: There will be no difficulty in that my dear M Manicamp your friend De Guiche has been admirably received

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Bah!
children.prevalue: Bah

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: The king made quite a fuss over him.
children.prevalue: The king made quite a fuss over him

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: The king, who exiled him!
children.prevalue: The king who exiled him

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Madame smiled upon him, and Monsieur appears to like him better than ever.
children.prevalue: Madame smiled upon him and Monsieur appears to like him better than ever

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Ah! ah! said Manicamp, that explains to me, then, why and how he has remained. And did he not say anything about me?
children.prevalue: Ah ah said Manicamp that explains to me then why and how he has remained And did he not say anything about me

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Not a word.
children.prevalue: Not a word

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: That is very unkind. What is he doing now?
children.prevalue: That is very unkind What is he doing now

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: In all probability he is asleep, or, if not asleep, dreaming.
children.prevalue: In all probability he is asleep or if not asleep dreaming

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: And what have they been doing all the evening?
children.prevalue: And what have they been doing all the evening

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Dancing.
children.prevalue: Dancing

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: The famous ballet? How did De Guiche look?
children.prevalue: The famous ballet How did De Guiche look

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Superb!
children.prevalue: Superb

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Dear fellow! And now, pray forgive me, Mademoiselle Montalais; but all I now have to do is pass from where I now am to your apartment.
children.prevalue: Dear fellow And now pray forgive me Mademoiselle Montalais but all I now have to do is pass from where I now am to your apartment

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: What do you mean?
children.prevalue: What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: I cannot suppose that the door of the chateau will be opened for me at this hour; and as for spending the night upon this branch, I possibly might not object to do so, but I declare it is impossible for any other animal than a boaconstrictor to do it.
children.prevalue: I cannot suppose that the door of the chateau will be opened for me at this hour and as for spending the night upon this branch I possibly might not object to do so but I declare it is impossible for any other animal than a boaconstrictor to do it

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: But, M. Manicamp, I cannot introduce a man over the wall in that manner.
children.prevalue: But M Manicamp I cannot introduce a man over the wall in that manner

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Two, if you please, said a second voice, but in so timid a tone that it seemed as if its owner felt the utter impropriety of such a request.
children.prevalue: Two if you please said a second voice but in so timid a tone that it seemed as if its owner felt the utter impropriety of such a request

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Good gracious! exclaimed Montalais, who is that speaking to me?
children.prevalue: Good gracious exclaimed Montalais who is that speaking to me

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Malicorne, Mademoiselle Montalais.
children.prevalue: Malicorne Mademoiselle Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: And as Malicorne spoke, he raised himself from the ground to the lowest branches, and thence to the height of the wall.
children.prevalue: And as Malicorne spoke he raised himself from the ground to the lowest branches and thence to the height of the wall

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Monsieur Malicorne! why, you are both mad!
children.prevalue: Monsieur Malicorne why you are both mad

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: How do you do, Mademoiselle Montalais? inquired Malicorne.
children.prevalue: How do you do Mademoiselle Montalais inquired Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: I needed but this! said Montalais, in despair.
children.prevalue: I needed but this said Montalais in despair

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Oh! Mademoiselle Montalais, murmured Malicorne; do not be so severe, I beseech you.
children.prevalue: Oh Mademoiselle Montalais murmured Malicorne do not be so severe I beseech you

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: In fact, said Manicamp, we are your friends, and you cannot possibly wish your friends to lose their lives; and to leave us to pass the night on these branches is in fact condemning us to death.
children.prevalue: In fact said Manicamp we are your friends and you cannot possibly wish your friends to lose their lives and to leave us to pass the night on these branches is in fact condemning us to death

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Oh! said Montalais, Monsieur Malicorne is so robust that a night passed in the open air with the beautiful stars above him will not do him any harm, and it will be a just punishment for the trick he has played me.
children.prevalue: Oh said Montalais Monsieur Malicorne is so robust that a night passed in the open air with the beautiful stars above him will not do him any harm and it will be a just punishment for the trick he has played me

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Be it so, then; let Malicorne arrange matters with you in the best way he can; I pass over, said Manicamp. And bending down the famous branch against which he had directed such bitter complaints, he succeeded, by the assistance of his hands and feet, in seating himself side by side with Montalais, who tried to push him back, while he endeavored to maintain his position, and, moreover, he succeeded. Having taken possession of the ladder, he stepped on it, and then gallantly offered his hand to his fair antagonist. While this was going on, Malicorne had installed himself in the chestnuttree, in the very place Manicamp had just left, determining within himself to succeed him in the one he now occupied. Manicamp and Montalais descended a few rounds of the ladder, Manicamp insisting, and Montalais laughing and objecting.
children.prevalue: Be it so then let Malicorne arrange matters with you in the best way he can I pass over said Manicamp And bending down the famous branch against which he had directed such bitter complaints he succeeded by the assistance of his hands and feet in seating himself side by side with Montalais who tried to push him back while he endeavored to maintain his position and moreover he succeeded Having taken possession of the ladder he stepped on it and then gallantly offered his hand to his fair antagonist While this was going on Malicorne had installed himself in the chestnuttree in the very place Manicamp had just left determining within himself to succeed him in the one he now occupied Manicamp and Montalais descended a few rounds of the ladder Manicamp insisting and Montalais laughing and objecting

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Suddenly Malicorne's voice was heard in tones of entreaty:
children.prevalue: Suddenly Malicorne s voice was heard in tones of entreaty

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: I entreat you, Mademoiselle Montalais, not to leave me here. My position is very insecure, and some accident will be certain to befall me, if I attempt unaided to reach the other side of the wall; it does not matter if Manicamp tears his clothes, for he can make use of M. de Guiche's wardrobe; but I shall not be able to use even those belonging to M. Manicamp, for they will be torn.
children.prevalue: I entreat you Mademoiselle Montalais not to leave me here My position is very insecure and some accident will be certain to befall me if I attempt unaided to reach the other side of the wall it does not matter if Manicamp tears his clothes for he can make use of M de Guiche s wardrobe but I shall not be able to use even those belonging to M Manicamp for they will be torn

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: My opinion, said Manicamp, without taking any notice of Malicorne's lamentations, is that the best thing to be done is to go and look for De Guiche without delay, for, by and by, perhaps, I may not be able to get to his apartments.
children.prevalue: My opinion said Manicamp without taking any notice of Malicorne s lamentations is that the best thing to be done is to go and look for De Guiche without delay for by and by perhaps I may not be able to get to his apartments

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: That is my own opinion, too, replied Montalais; so, go at once, Monsieur Manicamp.
children.prevalue: That is my own opinion too replied Montalais so go at once Monsieur Manicamp

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: A thousand thanks. Adieu Mademoiselle Montalais, said Manicamp, jumping to the ground; your condescension cannot be repaid.
children.prevalue: A thousand thanks Adieu Mademoiselle Montalais said Manicamp jumping to the ground your condescension cannot be repaid

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Farewell, M. Manicamp; I am now going to get rid of M. Malicorne.
children.prevalue: Farewell M Manicamp I am now going to get rid of M Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Malicorne sighed. Manicamp went away a few paces, but returning to the foot of the ladder, he said, By the by, how do I get to M. de Guiche's apartments?
children.prevalue: Malicorne sighed Manicamp went away a few paces but returning to the foot of the ladder he said By the by how do I get to M de Guiche s apartments

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Nothing easier. You go along by the hedge until you reach a place where the paths cross.
children.prevalue: Nothing easier You go along by the hedge until you reach a place where the paths cross

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: You will see four paths.
children.prevalue: You will see four paths

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Exactly.
children.prevalue: Exactly

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: One of which you will take.
children.prevalue: One of which you will take

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Which of them?
children.prevalue: Which of them

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: That to the right.
children.prevalue: That to the right

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: That to the right?
children.prevalue: That to the right

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: No, to the left.
children.prevalue: No to the left

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: The deuce!
children.prevalue: The deuce

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: No, no, wait a minute
children.prevalue: No no wait a minute

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: You do not seem to be quite sure. Think again, I beg.
children.prevalue: You do not seem to be quite sure Think again I beg

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: You take the middle path.
children.prevalue: You take the middle path

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: But there are four.
children.prevalue: But there are four

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: So there are. All I know is, that one of the four paths leads straight to Madame's apartments; and that one I am well acquainted with.
children.prevalue: So there are All I know is that one of the four paths leads straight to Madame s apartments and that one I am well acquainted with

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: But M. de Guiche is not in Madame's apartments, I suppose?
children.prevalue: But M de Guiche is not in Madame s apartments I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: No, indeed.
children.prevalue: No indeed

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Well, then the path which leads to Madame's apartments is of no use to me, and I would willingly exchange it for the one that leads to where M. de Guiche is lodging.
children.prevalue: Well then the path which leads to Madame s apartments is of no use to me and I would willingly exchange it for the one that leads to where M de Guiche is lodging

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Of course, and I know that as well; but as for indicating it from where we are, it is quite impossible.
children.prevalue: Of course and I know that as well but as for indicating it from where we are it is quite impossible

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Well, let us suppose that I have succeeded in finding that fortunate path.
children.prevalue: Well let us suppose that I have succeeded in finding that fortunate path

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: In that case, you are almost there, for you have nothing else to do but cross the labyrinth.
children.prevalue: In that case you are almost there for you have nothing else to do but cross the labyrinth

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Nothing more than that? The deuce! so there is a labyrinth as well.
children.prevalue: Nothing more than that The deuce so there is a labyrinth as well

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Yes, and complicated enough too; even in daylight one may sometimes be deceived,there are turnings and windings without end: in the first place, you must turn three times to the right, then twice to the left, then turn oncestay, is it once or twice, though? at all events, when you get clear of the labyrinth, you will see an avenue of sycamores, and this avenue leads straight to the pavilion in which M. de Guiche is lodging.
children.prevalue: Yes and complicated enough too even in daylight one may sometimes be deceived there are turnings and windings without end in the first place you must turn three times to the right then twice to the left then turn oncestay is it once or twice though at all events when you get clear of the labyrinth you will see an avenue of sycamores and this avenue leads straight to the pavilion in which M de Guiche is lodging

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Nothing could be more clearly indicated, said Manicamp; and I have not the slightest doubt in the world that if I were to follow your directions, I should lose my way immediately. I have, therefore, a slight service to ask of you.
children.prevalue: Nothing could be more clearly indicated said Manicamp and I have not the slightest doubt in the world that if I were to follow your directions I should lose my way immediately I have therefore a slight service to ask of you

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: What may that be?
children.prevalue: What may that be

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: That you will offer me your arm and guide me yourself, like another like anotherI used to know mythology, but other important matters have made me forget it; pray come with me, then?
children.prevalue: That you will offer me your arm and guide me yourself like another like anotherI used to know mythology but other important matters have made me forget it pray come with me then

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: And am I to be abandoned, then? cried Malicorne.
children.prevalue: And am I to be abandoned then cried Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: It is quite impossible, monsieur, said Montalais to Manicamp; if I were to be seen with you at such an hour, what would be said of me?
children.prevalue: It is quite impossible monsieur said Montalais to Manicamp if I were to be seen with you at such an hour what would be said of me

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Your own conscience would acquit you, said Manicamp, sententiously.
children.prevalue: Your own conscience would acquit you said Manicamp sententiously

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Impossible, monsieur, impossible.
children.prevalue: Impossible monsieur impossible

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: In that case, let me assist Malicorne to get down; he is a very intelligent fellow, and possesses a very keen scent; he will guide me, and if we lose ourselves, both of us will be lost, and the one will save the other. If we are together, and should be met by any one, we shall look as if we had some matter of business in hand; whilst alone I should have the appearance either of a lover or a robber. Come, Malicorne, here is the ladder.
children.prevalue: In that case let me assist Malicorne to get down he is a very intelligent fellow and possesses a very keen scent he will guide me and if we lose ourselves both of us will be lost and the one will save the other If we are together and should be met by any one we shall look as if we had some matter of business in hand whilst alone I should have the appearance either of a lover or a robber Come Malicorne here is the ladder

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Malicorne had already stretched out one of his legs towards the top of the wall, when Manicamp said, in a whisper, Hush!
children.prevalue: Malicorne had already stretched out one of his legs towards the top of the wall when Manicamp said in a whisper Hush

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: What's the matter? inquired Montalais.
children.prevalue: What s the matter inquired Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: I hear footsteps.
children.prevalue: I hear footsteps

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Good heavens!
children.prevalue: Good heavens

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: In fact the fancied footsteps soon became a reality; the foliage was pushed aside, and SaintAignan appeared, with a smile on his lips, and his hand stretched out towards them, taking every one by surprise; that is to say, Malicorne upon the tree with his head stretched out, Montalais upon the round of the ladder and clinging to it tightly, and Manicamp on the ground with his foot advanced ready to set off. Goodevening, Manicamp, said the comte, I am glad to see you, my dear fellow; we missed you this evening, and a good many inquiries have been made about you. Mademoiselle de Montalais, your most obedient servant.
children.prevalue: In fact the fancied footsteps soon became a reality the foliage was pushed aside and SaintAignan appeared with a smile on his lips and his hand stretched out towards them taking every one by surprise that is to say Malicorne upon the tree with his head stretched out Montalais upon the round of the ladder and clinging to it tightly and Manicamp on the ground with his foot advanced ready to set off Goodevening Manicamp said the comte I am glad to see you my dear fellow we missed you this evening and a good many inquiries have been made about you Mademoiselle de Montalais your most obedient servant

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: Montalais blushed. Good heavens! she exclaimed, hiding her face in both her hands.
children.prevalue: Montalais blushed Good heavens she exclaimed hiding her face in both her hands

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: Pray reassure yourself; I know how perfectly innocent you are, and I shall give a good account of you. Manicamp, do you follow me: the hedge, the crosspaths, and labyrinth, I am well acquainted with them all; I will be your Ariadne. There now, your mythological name is found at last.
children.prevalue: Pray reassure yourself I know how perfectly innocent you are and I shall give a good account of you Manicamp do you follow me the hedge the crosspaths and labyrinth I am well acquainted with them all I will be your Ariadne There now your mythological name is found at last

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Perfectly true, comte.
children.prevalue: Perfectly true comte

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: And take M. Malicorne away with you at the same time, said Montalais.
children.prevalue: And take M Malicorne away with you at the same time said Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: No, indeed, said Malicorne; M. Manicamp has conversed with you as long as he liked, and now it is my turn, if you please; I have a multitude of things to tell you about our future prospects.
children.prevalue: No indeed said Malicorne M Manicamp has conversed with you as long as he liked and now it is my turn if you please I have a multitude of things to tell you about our future prospects

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: You hear, said the comte, laughing; stay with him, Mademoiselle Montalais. This is, indeed, a night for secrets. And, taking Manicamp's arm, the comte led him rapidly away in the direction of the road Montalais knew so well, and indicated so badly. Montalais followed them with her eyes as long as she could perceive them.
children.prevalue: You hear said the comte laughing stay with him Mademoiselle Montalais This is indeed a night for secrets And taking Manicamp s arm the comte led him rapidly away in the direction of the road Montalais knew so well and indicated so badly Montalais followed them with her eyes as long as she could perceive them

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: While Montalais was engaged in looking after the comte and Manicamp, Malicorne had taken advantage of the young girl's attention being drawn away to render his position somewhat more tolerable, and when she turned round, she immediately noticed the change which had taken place; for he had seated himself, like a monkey, upon the wall, the foliage of the wild vine and honeysuckle curled around his head like a faun, while the twisted ivy branches represented tolerably enough his cloven feet. Montalais required nothing to make her resemblance to a dryad as complete as possible. Well, she said, ascending another round of the ladder, are you resolved to render me unhappy? have you not persecuted me enough, tyrant that you are?
children.prevalue: While Montalais was engaged in looking after the comte and Manicamp Malicorne had taken advantage of the young girl s attention being drawn away to render his position somewhat more tolerable and when she turned round she immediately noticed the change which had taken place for he had seated himself like a monkey upon the wall the foliage of the wild vine and honeysuckle curled around his head like a faun while the twisted ivy branches represented tolerably enough his cloven feet Montalais required nothing to make her resemblance to a dryad as complete as possible Well she said ascending another round of the ladder are you resolved to render me unhappy have you not persecuted me enough tyrant that you are

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: I a tyrant? said Malicorne.
children.prevalue: I a tyrant said Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Yes, you are always compromising me, Monsieur Malicorne; you are a perfect monster of wickedness.
children.prevalue: Yes you are always compromising me Monsieur Malicorne you are a perfect monster of wickedness

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: I?
children.prevalue: I

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: What have you to do with Fontainebleau? Is not Orleans your place of residence?
children.prevalue: What have you to do with Fontainebleau Is not Orleans your place of residence

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Do you ask me what I have to do here? I wanted to see you.
children.prevalue: Do you ask me what I have to do here I wanted to see you

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Ah, great need of that.
children.prevalue: Ah great need of that

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Not as far as concerns yourself, perhaps, but as far as I am concerned, Mademoiselle Montalais, you know very well that I have left my home, and that, for the future, I have no other place of residence than that which you may happen to have. As you, therefore, are staying at Fontainebleau at the present moment, I have come to Fontainebleau.
children.prevalue: Not as far as concerns yourself perhaps but as far as I am concerned Mademoiselle Montalais you know very well that I have left my home and that for the future I have no other place of residence than that which you may happen to have As you therefore are staying at Fontainebleau at the present moment I have come to Fontainebleau

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Montalais shrugged her shoulders. You wished to see me, did you not? she said.
children.prevalue: Montalais shrugged her shoulders You wished to see me did you not she said

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Of course.
children.prevalue: Of course

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Very well, you have seen me,you are satisfied; so now go away.
children.prevalue: Very well you have seen me you are satisfied so now go away

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Oh, no, said Malicorne; I came to talk with you as well as to see you.
children.prevalue: Oh no said Malicorne I came to talk with you as well as to see you

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Very well, we will talk by and by, and in another place than this.
children.prevalue: Very well we will talk by and by and in another place than this

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: By and by! Heaven only knows if I shall meet you by and by in another place. We shall never find a more favorable one than this.
children.prevalue: By and by Heaven only knows if I shall meet you by and by in another place We shall never find a more favorable one than this

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: But I cannot this evening, nor at the present moment.
children.prevalue: But I cannot this evening nor at the present moment

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Why not?
children.prevalue: Why not

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Because a thousand things have happened tonight.
children.prevalue: Because a thousand things have happened tonight

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Well, then, my affair will make a thousand and one.
children.prevalue: Well then my affair will make a thousand and one

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: No, no; Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente is waiting for me in our room to communicate something of the very greatest importance.
children.prevalue: No no Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente is waiting for me in our room to communicate something of the very greatest importance

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: How long has she been waiting?
children.prevalue: How long has she been waiting

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: For an hour at least.
children.prevalue: For an hour at least

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: In that case, said Malicorne, tranquilly, she can wait a few minutes longer.
children.prevalue: In that case said Malicorne tranquilly she can wait a few minutes longer

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Monsieur Malicorne, said Montalais, you are forgetting yourself.
children.prevalue: Monsieur Malicorne said Montalais you are forgetting yourself

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: You should rather say that it is you who are forgetting me, and that I am getting impatient at the part you make me play here indeed! For the last week I have been prowling about among the company, and you have not once deigned to notice my presence.
children.prevalue: You should rather say that it is you who are forgetting me and that I am getting impatient at the part you make me play here indeed For the last week I have been prowling about among the company and you have not once deigned to notice my presence

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Have you been prowling about here for a week, M. Malicorne?
children.prevalue: Have you been prowling about here for a week M Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Like a wolf; sometimes I have been burnt by the fireworks, which have singed two of my wigs; at others, I have been completely drenched in the osiers by the evening damps, or the spray from the fountains,halffamished, fatigued to death, with the view of a wall always before me, and the prospect of having to scale it perhaps. Upon my word, this is not the sort of life for any one to lead who is neither a squirrel, a salamander, nor an otter; and since you drive your inhumanity so far as to wish to make me renounce my condition as a man, I declare it openly. A man I am, indeed, and a man I will remain, unless by superior orders.
children.prevalue: Like a wolf sometimes I have been burnt by the fireworks which have singed two of my wigs at others I have been completely drenched in the osiers by the evening damps or the spray from the fountains halffamished fatigued to death with the view of a wall always before me and the prospect of having to scale it perhaps Upon my word this is not the sort of life for any one to lead who is neither a squirrel a salamander nor an otter and since you drive your inhumanity so far as to wish to make me renounce my condition as a man I declare it openly A man I am indeed and a man I will remain unless by superior orders

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Well, then, tell me, what do you wish,what do you require,what do you insist upon? said Montalais, in a submissive tone.
children.prevalue: Well then tell me what do you wish what do you require what do you insist upon said Montalais in a submissive tone

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Do you mean to tell me that you did not know I was at Fontainebleau?
children.prevalue: Do you mean to tell me that you did not know I was at Fontainebleau

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: I?
children.prevalue: I

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Nay, be frank.
children.prevalue: Nay be frank

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: I suspected so.
children.prevalue: I suspected so

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Well, then, could you not have contrived during the last week to have seen me once a day, at least?
children.prevalue: Well then could you not have contrived during the last week to have seen me once a day at least

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I have always been prevented, M. Malicorne.
children.prevalue: I have always been prevented M Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Fiddlesticks!
children.prevalue: Fiddlesticks

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Ask my companion, if you do not believe me.
children.prevalue: Ask my companion if you do not believe me

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I shall ask no one to explain matters, I know better than any one.
children.prevalue: I shall ask no one to explain matters I know better than any one

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Compose yourself, M. Malicorne: things will change.
children.prevalue: Compose yourself M Malicorne things will change

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: They must indeed.
children.prevalue: They must indeed

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: You know that, whether I see you or not, I am thinking of you, said Montalais, in a coaxing tone of voice.
children.prevalue: You know that whether I see you or not I am thinking of you said Montalais in a coaxing tone of voice

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Oh, you are thinking of me, are you? well, and is there anything new?
children.prevalue: Oh you are thinking of me are you well and is there anything new

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: What about?
children.prevalue: What about

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: About my post in Monsieur's household.
children.prevalue: About my post in Monsieur s household

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Ah, my dear Malicorne, no one has ventured lately to approach his royal highness.
children.prevalue: Ah my dear Malicorne no one has ventured lately to approach his royal highness

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Well, but now?
children.prevalue: Well but now

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Now it is quite a different thing; since yesterday he has left off being jealous.
children.prevalue: Now it is quite a different thing since yesterday he has left off being jealous

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Bah! how has his jealousy subsided?
children.prevalue: Bah how has his jealousy subsided

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: It has been diverted into another channel.
children.prevalue: It has been diverted into another channel

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Tell me all about it.
children.prevalue: Tell me all about it

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: A report was spread that the king had fallen in love with some one else, and Monsieur was tranquillized immediately.
children.prevalue: A report was spread that the king had fallen in love with some one else and Monsieur was tranquillized immediately

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: And who spread the report?
children.prevalue: And who spread the report

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Montalais lowered her voice. Between ourselves, she said, I think that Madame and the king have come to a secret understanding about it.
children.prevalue: Montalais lowered her voice Between ourselves she said I think that Madame and the king have come to a secret understanding about it

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Ah! said Malicorne; that was the only way to manage it. But what about poor M. de Guiche?
children.prevalue: Ah said Malicorne that was the only way to manage it But what about poor M de Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Oh, as for him, he is completely turned off.
children.prevalue: Oh as for him he is completely turned off

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Have they been writing to each other?
children.prevalue: Have they been writing to each other

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: No, certainly not; I have not seen a pen in either of their hands for the last week.
children.prevalue: No certainly not I have not seen a pen in either of their hands for the last week

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: On what terms are you with Madame?
children.prevalue: On what terms are you with Madame

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: The very best.
children.prevalue: The very best

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: And with the king?
children.prevalue: And with the king

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: The king always smiles at me whenever I pass him.
children.prevalue: The king always smiles at me whenever I pass him

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Good. Now tell me whom have the two lovers selected to serve as their screen?
children.prevalue: Good Now tell me whom have the two lovers selected to serve as their screen

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: La Valliere.
children.prevalue: La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Oh, oh, poor girl! We must prevent that!
children.prevalue: Oh oh poor girl We must prevent that

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Why?
children.prevalue: Why

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Because, if M. Raoul Bragelonne were to suspect it, he would either kill her or kill himself.
children.prevalue: Because if M Raoul Bragelonne were to suspect it he would either kill her or kill himself

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Raoul, poor fellow! do you think so?
children.prevalue: Raoul poor fellow do you think so

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Women pretend to have a knowledge of the state of people's affections, said Malicorne, and they do not even know how to read the thoughts of their own minds and hearts. Well, I can tell you that M. de Bragelonne loves La Valliere to such a degree that, if she deceived him, he would, I repeat, either kill himself or kill her.
children.prevalue: Women pretend to have a knowledge of the state of people s affections said Malicorne and they do not even know how to read the thoughts of their own minds and hearts Well I can tell you that M de Bragelonne loves La Valliere to such a degree that if she deceived him he would I repeat either kill himself or kill her

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: But the king is there to defend her, said Montalais.
children.prevalue: But the king is there to defend her said Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: The king! exclaimed Malicorne; Raoul would kill the king as he would a common thief.
children.prevalue: The king exclaimed Malicorne Raoul would kill the king as he would a common thief

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Good heavens! said Montalais; you are mad, M. Malicorne.
children.prevalue: Good heavens said Montalais you are mad M Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Not in the least. Everything I have told you is, on the contrary, perfectly serious; and, for my own part, I know one thing.
children.prevalue: Not in the least Everything I have told you is on the contrary perfectly serious and for my own part I know one thing

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: What is that?
children.prevalue: What is that

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: That I shall quietly tell Raoul of the trick.
children.prevalue: That I shall quietly tell Raoul of the trick

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Hush! said Montalais, mounting another round of the ladder, so as to approach Malicorne more closely, do not open your lips to poor Raoul.
children.prevalue: Hush said Montalais mounting another round of the ladder so as to approach Malicorne more closely do not open your lips to poor Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Why not?
children.prevalue: Why not

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Because, as yet you know nothing at all.
children.prevalue: Because as yet you know nothing at all

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: What is the matter, then?
children.prevalue: What is the matter then

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Why, this eveningbut no one is listening, I hope?
children.prevalue: Why this eveningbut no one is listening I hope

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: This evening, then, beneath the royal oak, La Valliere said aloud, and innocently enough, 'I cannot conceive that when one has once seen the king, one can ever love another man.'
children.prevalue: This evening then beneath the royal oak La Valliere said aloud and innocently enough I cannot conceive that when one has once seen the king one can ever love another man

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Malicorne almost jumped off the wall. Unhappy girl! did she really say that?
children.prevalue: Malicorne almost jumped off the wall Unhappy girl did she really say that

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Word for word.
children.prevalue: Word for word

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: And she thinks so?
children.prevalue: And she thinks so

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: La Valliere always thinks what she says.
children.prevalue: La Valliere always thinks what she says

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: That positively cries aloud for vengeance. Why, women are the veriest serpents, said Malicorne.
children.prevalue: That positively cries aloud for vengeance Why women are the veriest serpents said Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Compose yourself, my dear Malicorne, compose yourself.
children.prevalue: Compose yourself my dear Malicorne compose yourself

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: No, no; let us take the evil in time, on the contrary. There is time enough yet to tell Raoul of it.
children.prevalue: No no let us take the evil in time on the contrary There is time enough yet to tell Raoul of it

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Blunderer, on the contrary, it is too late, replied Montalais.
children.prevalue: Blunderer on the contrary it is too late replied Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: How so?
children.prevalue: How so

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: La Valliere's remark, which was intended for the king, reached its destination.
children.prevalue: La Valliere s remark which was intended for the king reached its destination

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: The king knows it, then? The king was told of it, I suppose?
children.prevalue: The king knows it then The king was told of it I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: The king heard it.
children.prevalue: The king heard it

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Ahime! as the cardinal used to say.
children.prevalue: Ahime as the cardinal used to say

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: The king was hidden in the thicket close to the royal oak.
children.prevalue: The king was hidden in the thicket close to the royal oak

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: It follows, then, said Malicorne, that for the future, the plan which the king and Madame have arranged, will go as easily as if it were on wheels, and will pass over poor Bragelonne's body.
children.prevalue: It follows then said Malicorne that for the future the plan which the king and Madame have arranged will go as easily as if it were on wheels and will pass over poor Bragelonne s body

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Precisely so.
children.prevalue: Precisely so

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Well, said Malicorne, after a moment's reflection, do not let us interpose our poor selves between a large oaktree and a great king, for we should certainly be ground to pieces.
children.prevalue: Well said Malicorne after a moment s reflection do not let us interpose our poor selves between a large oaktree and a great king for we should certainly be ground to pieces

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: The very thing I was going to say to you.
children.prevalue: The very thing I was going to say to you

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Let us think of ourselves, then.
children.prevalue: Let us think of ourselves then

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: My own idea.
children.prevalue: My own idea

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Open your beautiful eyes, then.
children.prevalue: Open your beautiful eyes then

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: And you your large ears.
children.prevalue: And you your large ears

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Approach your little mouth for a kiss.
children.prevalue: Approach your little mouth for a kiss

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Here, said Montalais, who paid the debt immediately in ringing coin.
children.prevalue: Here said Montalais who paid the debt immediately in ringing coin

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Now let us consider. First, we have M. de Guiche, who is in love with Madame; then La Valliere, who is in love with the king; next, the king, who is in love both with Madame and La Valliere; lastly Monsieur, who loves no one but himself. Among all these loves, a noodle would make his fortune: a greater reason, therefore, for sensible people like ourselves to do so.

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: There you are with your dreams again.
children.prevalue: There you are with your dreams again

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Nay, rather with realities. Let me still lead you, darling. I do not think you have been very badly off hitherto?
children.prevalue: Nay rather with realities Let me still lead you darling I do not think you have been very badly off hitherto

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Well, the future is guaranteed by the past. Only, since all here think of themselves before anything else, let us do so too.
children.prevalue: Well the future is guaranteed by the past Only since all here think of themselves before anything else let us do so too

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Perfectly right.
children.prevalue: Perfectly right

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: But of ourselves only.
children.prevalue: But of ourselves only

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Be it so.
children.prevalue: Be it so

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: An offensive and defensive alliance.
children.prevalue: An offensive and defensive alliance

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: I am ready to swear it.
children.prevalue: I am ready to swear it

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Put out your hand, then, and say, 'All for Malicorne.'
children.prevalue: Put out your hand then and say All for Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: All for Malicorne.

children.value: And I, 'All for Montalais,' replied Malicorne, stretching out his hand in his turn.
children.prevalue: And I All for Montalais replied Malicorne stretching out his hand in his turn

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: And now, what is to be done?
children.prevalue: And now what is to be done

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Keep your eyes and ears constantly open; collect every means of attack which may be serviceable against others; never let anything lie about which can be used against ourselves.
children.prevalue: Keep your eyes and ears constantly open collect every means of attack which may be serviceable against others never let anything lie about which can be used against ourselves

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Agreed.
children.prevalue: Agreed

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Decided.
children.prevalue: Decided

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Sworn to. And now the agreement entered into, goodbye.
children.prevalue: Sworn to And now the agreement entered into goodbye

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: What do you mean by 'goodbye?'
children.prevalue: What do you mean by goodbye

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: Of course you can now return to your inn.
children.prevalue: Of course you can now return to your inn

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: To my inn?
children.prevalue: To my inn

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Yes; are you not lodging at the sign of the Beau Paon?
children.prevalue: Yes are you not lodging at the sign of the Beau Paon

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: Montalais, Montalais, you now betray that you were aware of my being at Fontainebleau.
children.prevalue: Montalais Montalais you now betray that you were aware of my being at Fontainebleau

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: Well; and what does that prove, except that I occupy myself about you more than you deserve?
children.prevalue: Well and what does that prove except that I occupy myself about you more than you deserve

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Hum!
children.prevalue: Hum

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: Go back, then, to the Beau Paon.
children.prevalue: Go back then to the Beau Paon

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: That is now quite out of the question.
children.prevalue: That is now quite out of the question

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: Have you not a room there?
children.prevalue: Have you not a room there

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: I had, but have it no longer.
children.prevalue: I had but have it no longer

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: Who has taken it from you, then?
children.prevalue: Who has taken it from you then

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: I will tell you. Some little time ago I was returning there, after I had been running about after you; and having reached my hotel quite out of breath, I perceived a litter, upon which four peasants were carrying a sick monk.
children.prevalue: I will tell you Some little time ago I was returning there after I had been running about after you and having reached my hotel quite out of breath I perceived a litter upon which four peasants were carrying a sick monk

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: A monk?
children.prevalue: A monk

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: Yes, an old graybearded Franciscan. As I was looking at the monk, they entered the hotel; and as they were carrying him up the staircase, I followed, and as I reached the top of the staircase I observed that they took him into my room.
children.prevalue: Yes an old graybearded Franciscan As I was looking at the monk they entered the hotel and as they were carrying him up the staircase I followed and as I reached the top of the staircase I observed that they took him into my room

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: Into your room?
children.prevalue: Into your room

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: Yes, into my own apartment. Supposing it to be a mistake, I summoned the landlord, who said that the room which had been let to me for the past eight days was let to the Franciscan for the ninth.
children.prevalue: Yes into my own apartment Supposing it to be a mistake I summoned the landlord who said that the room which had been let to me for the past eight days was let to the Franciscan for the ninth

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: Oh, oh!
children.prevalue: Oh oh

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: That was exactly what I said; nay, I did even more, for I was inclined to get out of temper. I went upstairs again. I spoke to the Franciscan himself, and wished to prove to him the impropriety of the step; when this monk, dying though he seemed to be, raised himself upon his arm, fixed a pair of blazing eyes upon me, and, in a voice which was admirably suited for commanding a charge of cavalry, said, 'Turn this fellow out of doors;' which was done, immediately by the landlord and the four porters, who made me descend the staircase somewhat faster than was agreeable. This is how it happens, dearest, that I have no lodging.

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: Who can this Franciscan be? said Montalais. Is he a general?
children.prevalue: Who can this Franciscan be said Montalais Is he a general

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: That is exactly the very title that one of the bearers of the litter gave him as he spoke to him in a low tone.
children.prevalue: That is exactly the very title that one of the bearers of the litter gave him as he spoke to him in a low tone

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: So that said Montalais.
children.prevalue: So that said Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: So that I have no room, no hotel, no lodging; and I am as determined as my friend Manicamp was just now, not to pass the night in the open air.
children.prevalue: So that I have no room no hotel no lodging and I am as determined as my friend Manicamp was just now not to pass the night in the open air

children.name: Paragraph_145
children.value: What is to be done, then? said Montalais.
children.prevalue: What is to be done then said Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_146
children.value: Nothing easier, said a third voice; whereupon Montalais and Malicorne uttered a simultaneous cry, and SaintAignan appeared. Dear Monsieur Malicorne, said SaintAignan, a very lucky accident has brought me back to extricate you from your embarrassment. Come, I can offer you a room in my own apartments, which, I can assure you, no Franciscan will deprive you of. As for you, my dear lady, rest easy. I already knew Mademoiselle de la Valliere's secret, and that of Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente; your own you have just been kind enough to confide to me; for which I thank you. I can keep three quite as well as one. Malicorne and Montalais looked at each other, like children detected in a theft; but as Malicorne saw a great advantage in the proposition which had been made to him, he gave Montalais a sign of assent, which she returned. Malicorne then descended the ladder, round by round, reflecting at every step on the means of obtaining piecemeal from M. de SaintAignan all he might possibly know about the famous secret. Montalais had already darted away like a deer, and neither crossroad nor labyrinth was able to lead her wrong. As for SaintAignan, he carried off Malicorne with him to his apartments, showing him a thousand attentions, enchanted to have so close at hand the very two men who, even supposing De Guiche were to remain silent, could give him the best information about the maids of honor.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: In the first place, let us supply our readers with a few details about the inn called Beau Paon. It owed its name to its sign, which represented a peacock spreading its tail. But, in imitation of certain painters who bestowed the face of a handsome young man on the serpent which tempted Eve, the limner of the sign had conferred upon the peacock the features of a woman. This famous inn, an architectural epigram against that half of the human race which renders existence delightful, was situated at Fontainebleau, in the first turning on the lefthand side, which divides the road from Paris, the large artery that constitutes in itself alone the entire town of Fontainebleau. The side street in question was then known as the Rue de Lyon, doubtless because, geographically, it led in the direction of the second capital of the kingdom. The street itself was composed of two houses occupied by persons of the class of tradespeople, the houses being separated by two large gardens bordered with hedges running round them. Apparently, however, there were three houses in the street. Let us explain, notwithstanding appearances, how there were in fact only two. The inn of the Beau Paon had its principal front towards the main street; but upon the Rue de Lyon there were two ranges of buildings divided by courtyards, which comprised sets of apartments for the reception of all classes of travelers, whether on foot or on horseback, or even with their own carriages; and in which could be supplied, not only board and lodging, but also accommodation for exercise, or opportunities of solitude for even the wealthiest courtiers, whenever, after having received some check at the court, they wished to shut themselves up to their own society, either to devour an affront, or to brood on revenge. From the windows of this part of the building travelers could perceive, in the first place, the street with the grass growing between the stones, which were being gradually loosened by it; next the beautiful hedges of elder and thorn, which embraced, as though within two green and flowery arms, the house of which we have spoken; and then, in the spaces between those houses, forming the groundwork of the picture, and appearing an almost impassable barrier, a line of thick trees, the advanced sentinels of the vast forest which extends in front of Fontainebleau. It was therefore easy, provided one secured an apartment at the angle of the building, to obtain, by the main street from Paris, a view of, as well as to hear, the passersby and the fetes; and, by the Rue de Lyon, to look upon and to enjoy the calm of the country. And this without reckoning that, in cases of urgent necessity, at the very moment people might be knocking at the principal door in the Rue de Paris, one could make one's escape by the little door in the Rue de Lyon, and, creeping along the gardens of the private houses, attain the outskirts of the forest. Malicorne, who, it will be remembered, was the first to speak about this inn, by way of deploring his being turned out of it, being then absorbed in his own affairs, had not told Montalais all that could be said about this curious inn; and we will try to repair the omission. With the exception of the few words he had said about the Franciscan friar, Malicorne had not given any particulars about the travelers who were staying in the inn. The manner in which they had arrived, the manner in which they had lived, the difficulty which existed for every one but certain privileged travelers, of entering the hotel without a password, or living there without certain preparatory precautions, must have struck Malicorne; and, we will venture to say, really did so. But Malicorne, as we have already said, had personal matters of his own to occupy his attention which prevented him from paying much attention to others. In fact, all the apartments of the hotel were engaged and retained by certain strangers, who never stirred out, who were incommunicative in their address, with countenances full of thoughtful preoccupation, and not one of whom was known to Malicorne. Every one of these travelers had reached the hotel after his own arrival there; each man had entered after having given a kind of password, which had at first attracted Malicorne's attention; but having inquired, in an indiscreet manner, about it, he had been informed that the host had given as a reason for this extreme vigilance, that, as the town was so full of wealthy noblemen, it must also be as full of clever and zealous pickpockets. The reputation of an honest inn like that of the Beau Paon was concerned in not allowing its visitors to be robbed. It occasionally happened that Malicorne asked himself, as he thought matters carefully over in his mind, and reflected upon his own position in the inn, how it was that they had allowed him to become an inmate of the hotel, when he had observed, since his residence there, admission refused to so many. He asked himself, too, how it was that Manicamp, who, in his opinion, must be a man to be looked upon with veneration by everybody, having wished to bait his horse at the Beau Paon, on arriving there, both horse and rider had been incontinently turned away with a nescio vos of the most positive character. All this for Malicorne, whose mind being fully occupied by his own love affair and personal ambition, was a problem he had not applied himself to solve. Had he wished to do so, we should hardly venture, notwithstanding the intelligence we have accorded as his due, to say he would have succeeded. A few words will prove to the reader that no one but Oedipus in person could have solved the enigma in question. During the week, seven travelers had taken up their abode in the inn, all of them having arrived there the day after the fortunate day on which Malicorne had fixed his choice on the Beau Paon. These seven persons, accompanied by a suitable retinue, were the following:

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: First of all, a brigadier in the German army, his secretary, physician, three servants, and seven horses. The brigadier's name was the Comte de Wostpur.A Spanish cardinal, with two nephews, two secretaries, an officer of his household, and twelve horses. The cardinal's name was Monseigneur Herrebia.A rich merchant of Bremen, with his manservant and two horses. This merchant's name was Meinheer Bonstett.A Venetian senator with his wife and daughter, both extremely beautiful. The senator's name was Signor Marini.A Scottish laird, with seven highlanders of his clan, all on foot. The laird's name was MacCumnor. An Austrian from Vienna without title or coat of arms, who had arrived in a carriage; a good deal of the priest, and something of the soldier. He was called the Councilor.And, finally, a Flemish lady, with a manservant, a lady's maid, and a female companion, a large retinue of servants, great display, and immense horses. She was called the Flemish lady.

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: All these travelers had arrived on the same day, and yet their arrival had occasioned no confusion in the inn, no stoppage in the street; their apartments had been fixed upon beforehand, by their couriers or secretaries, who had arrived the previous evening or that very morning. Malicorne, who had arrived the previous day, riding an illconditioned horse, with a slender valise, had announced himself at the hotel of the Beau Paon as the friend of a nobleman desirous of witnessing the fetes, and who would himself arrive almost immediately. The landlord, on hearing these words, had smiled as if he were perfectly well acquainted either with Malicorne or his friend the nobleman, and had said to him, Since you are the first arrival, monsieur, choose what apartment you please. And this was said with that obsequiousness of manners, so full of meaning with landlords, which means, Make yourself perfectly easy, monsieur: we know with whom we have to do, and you will be treated accordingly. These words, and their accompanying gesture, Malicorne had thought very friendly, but rather obscure. However, as he did not wish to be very extravagant in his expenses, and as he thought that if he were to ask for a small apartment he would doubtless have been refused, on account of his want of consequence, he hastened to close at once with the innkeeper's remark, and deceive him with a cunning equal to his own. So, smiling as a man would do for whom whatever might be done was but simply his due, he said, My dear host, I shall take the best and the gayest room in the house.
