children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: There is some mistake here, said Malicorne to himself; but until it is cleared up, I shall take advantage of it, which is the best thing I can possibly do. And he darted out of his room, like a huntingdog following a scent, in search of all the news and curiosities of the court, getting himself burnt in one place and drowned in another, as he had told Mademoiselle de Montalais. The day after he had been installed in his room, he had noticed the seven travelers arrive successively, who speedily filled the whole hotel. When he saw this perfect multitude of people, of carriages, and retinue, Malicorne rubbed his hands delightedly, thinking that, one day later, he should not have found a bed to lie upon after his return from his exploring expeditions. When all the travelers were lodged, the landlord entered Malicorne's room, and with his accustomed courteousness, said to him, You are aware, my dear monsieur, that the large room in the third detached building is still reserved for you?

'To the landlord of the Beau Paon Hotel,You will have been informed of the meeting arranged to take place in your inn between some people of importance; I shall be one of those who will meet with the others at Fontainebleau. Keep for me, then, a small room for a friend who will arrive either before or after me' and you are the friend, I suppose, said the landlord, interrupting his reading of the letter. Malicorne bowed modestly. The landlord continued:

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: So far so well. Adieu! And the landlord withdrew. Malicorne, left alone, reasoned with himself in the following manner: No one but De Guiche or Manicamp could have written to this fellow; De Guiche, because he wishes to secure a lodging for himself beyond the precincts of the court, in the event of his success or failure, as the case might be; Manicamp, because De Guiche must have intrusted him with his commission. And De Guiche or Manicamp will have argued in this manner. The large apartment would serve for the reception, in a befitting manner, of a lady thickly veiled, reserving to the lady in question a double means of exit, either in a street somewhat deserted, or closely adjoining the forest. The smaller room might either shelter Manicamp for a time, who is De Guiche's confidant, and would be the vigilant keeper of the door, or De Guiche himself, acting, for greater safety, the part of a master and confidant at the same time. Yet, he continued, how about this meeting which is to take place, and which has actually taken place, in this hotel? No doubt they are persons who are going to be presented to the king. And the 'poor devil,' for whom the smaller room is destined, is a trick, in order to better conceal De Guiche or Manicamp. If this be the case, as very likely it is, there is only half the mischief done, for there is simply the length of a purse string between Manicamp and Malicorne. After he had thus reasoned the matter out, Malicorne slept soundly, leaving the seven travelers to occupy, and in every sense of the word to walk up and down, their several lodgings in the hotel. Whenever there was nothing at court to put him out, when he had wearied himself with his excursions and investigations, tired of writing letters which he could never find an opportunity of delivering to the people they were intended for, he returned home to his comfortable little room, and leaning upon the balcony, which was filled with nasturtiums and white pinks, for whom Fontainebleau seemed to possess no attractions with all its illuminations, amusements, and fetes.

children.value: Things went on in this manner until the seventh day, a day of which we have given such full details, with its night also, in the preceding chapters. On that night Malicorne was enjoying the fresh air, seated at his window, toward one o'clock in the morning, when Manicamp appeared on horseback, with a thoughtful and listless air.

children.value: What does it matter whether I am or not, provided you are paid? said Malicorne, parodying the stranger's remark in a very majestic manner.
children.prevalue: What does it matter whether I am or not provided you are paid said Malicorne parodying the stranger s remark in a very majestic manner

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: It matters so far as this, said the landlord, who began to perceive that one person had been taken for another, that I beg you, monsieur, to leave the rooms, which had been engaged beforehand, and by some one else instead of you.
children.prevalue: It matters so far as this said the landlord who began to perceive that one person had been taken for another that I beg you monsieur to leave the rooms which had been engaged beforehand and by some one else instead of you

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Still, said Malicorne, this gentleman cannot require at the same time a room on the first floor and an apartment on the second. If this gentleman will take the room, I will take the apartment: if he prefers the apartment, I will be satisfied with the room.
children.prevalue: Still said Malicorne this gentleman cannot require at the same time a room on the first floor and an apartment on the second If this gentleman will take the room I will take the apartment if he prefers the apartment I will be satisfied with the room

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: I am exceedingly distressed, monsieur, said the traveler in his soft voice, but I need both the room and the apartment.
children.prevalue: I am exceedingly distressed monsieur said the traveler in his soft voice but I need both the room and the apartment

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: At least, tell me for whom? inquired Malicorne.
children.prevalue: At least tell me for whom inquired Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: The apartment I require for myself.
children.prevalue: The apartment I require for myself

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Very well; but the room?
children.prevalue: Very well but the room

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Look, said the traveler, pointing towards a sort of procession which was approaching.
children.prevalue: Look said the traveler pointing towards a sort of procession which was approaching

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Malicorne looked in the direction indicated, and observed borne upon a litter, the arrival of the Franciscan, whose installation in his apartment he had, with a few details of his own, related to Montalais, and whom he had so uselessly endeavored to convert to humbler views. The result of the arrival of the stranger, and of the sick Franciscan, was Malicorne's expulsion, without any consideration for his feelings, from the inn, by the landlord and the peasants who had carried the Franciscan. The details have already been given of what followed this expulsion; of Manicamp's conversation with Montalais; how Manicamp, with greater cleverness than Malicorne had shown, had succeeded in obtaining news of De Guiche, of the subsequent conversation of Montalais with Malicorne, and, finally, of the billets with which the Comte de SaintAignan had furnished Manicamp and Malicorne. It remains for us to inform our readers who was the traveler in the cloakthe principal tenant of the double apartment, of which Malicorne had only occupied a portionand the Franciscan, quite as mysterious a personage, whose arrival, together with that of the stranger, unfortunately upset the two friends' plans.
children.prevalue: Malicorne looked in the direction indicated and observed borne upon a litter the arrival of the Franciscan whose installation in his apartment he had with a few details of his own related to Montalais and whom he had so uselessly endeavored to convert to humbler views The result of the arrival of the stranger and of the sick Franciscan was Malicorne s expulsion without any consideration for his feelings from the inn by the landlord and the peasants who had carried the Franciscan The details have already been given of what followed this expulsion of Manicamp s conversation with Montalais how Manicamp with greater cleverness than Malicorne had shown had succeeded in obtaining news of De Guiche of the subsequent conversation of Montalais with Malicorne and finally of the billets with which the Comte de SaintAignan had furnished Manicamp and Malicorne It remains for us to inform our readers who was the traveler in the cloakthe principal tenant of the double apartment of which Malicorne had only occupied a portionand the Franciscan quite as mysterious a personage whose arrival together with that of the stranger unfortunately upset the two friends plans

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: In the first place, in order not to weary the reader's patience, we will hasten to answer the first question. The traveler with the cloak held over his face was Aramis, who, after he had left Fouquet, and taken from a portmanteau, which his servant had opened, a cavalier's complete costume, quitted the chateau, and went to the hotel of the Beau Paon, where, by letters, seven or eight days previously, he had, as the landlord had stated, directed a room and an apartment to be retained for him. Immediately after Malicorne and Manicamp had been turned out, Aramis approached the Franciscan, and asked him whether he would prefer the apartment or the room. The Franciscan inquired where they were both situated. He was told that the room was on the first, and the apartment on the second floor.
children.prevalue: In the first place in order not to weary the reader s patience we will hasten to answer the first question The traveler with the cloak held over his face was Aramis who after he had left Fouquet and taken from a portmanteau which his servant had opened a cavalier s complete costume quitted the chateau and went to the hotel of the Beau Paon where by letters seven or eight days previously he had as the landlord had stated directed a room and an apartment to be retained for him Immediately after Malicorne and Manicamp had been turned out Aramis approached the Franciscan and asked him whether he would prefer the apartment or the room The Franciscan inquired where they were both situated He was told that the room was on the first and the apartment on the second floor

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The room, then, he said.
children.prevalue: The room then he said

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Aramis did not contradict him, but, with great submissiveness, said to the landlord: The room. And bowing with respect he withdrew into the apartment, and the Franciscan was accordingly carried at once into the room. Now, is it not extraordinary that this respect should be shown by a prelate of the Church for a simple monk, for one, too, belonging to a mendicant order; to whom was given up, without a request for it even, a room which so many travelers were desirous of obtaining? How, too, can one explain the unexpected arrival of Aramis at the hotelhe who had entered the chateau with M. Fouquet, and could have remained at the chateau with M. Fouquet if he had liked? The Franciscan supported his removal up the staircase without uttering a complaint, although it was evident he suffered very much, and that every time the litter knocked against the wall or the railing of the staircase, he experienced a terrible shock throughout his frame. And finally, when he had arrived in the room, he said to those who carried him: Help me to place myself in that armchair. The bearers of the litter placed it on the ground, and lifting the sick man up as gently as possible, carried him to the chair he had indicated, which was situated at the head of the bed. Now, he added, with a marked benignity of gesture and tone, desire the landlord to come.
children.prevalue: Aramis did not contradict him but with great submissiveness said to the landlord The room And bowing with respect he withdrew into the apartment and the Franciscan was accordingly carried at once into the room Now is it not extraordinary that this respect should be shown by a prelate of the Church for a simple monk for one too belonging to a mendicant order to whom was given up without a request for it even a room which so many travelers were desirous of obtaining How too can one explain the unexpected arrival of Aramis at the hotelhe who had entered the chateau with M Fouquet and could have remained at the chateau with M Fouquet if he had liked The Franciscan supported his removal up the staircase without uttering a complaint although it was evident he suffered very much and that every time the litter knocked against the wall or the railing of the staircase he experienced a terrible shock throughout his frame And finally when he had arrived in the room he said to those who carried him Help me to place myself in that armchair The bearers of the litter placed it on the ground and lifting the sick man up as gently as possible carried him to the chair he had indicated which was situated at the head of the bed Now he added with a marked benignity of gesture and tone desire the landlord to come

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: They obeyed, and five minutes afterwards the landlord appeared at the door.
children.prevalue: They obeyed and five minutes afterwards the landlord appeared at the door

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Be kind enough, said the Franciscan to him, to send these excellent fellows away; they are vassals of the Vicomte de Melun. They found me when I had fainted on the road overcome by the heat, and without thinking of whether they would be paid for their trouble, they wished to carry me to their own home. But I know at what cost to themselves is the hospitality which the poor extend to a sick monk, and I preferred this hotel, where, moreover, I was expected.
children.prevalue: Be kind enough said the Franciscan to him to send these excellent fellows away they are vassals of the Vicomte de Melun They found me when I had fainted on the road overcome by the heat and without thinking of whether they would be paid for their trouble they wished to carry me to their own home But I know at what cost to themselves is the hospitality which the poor extend to a sick monk and I preferred this hotel where moreover I was expected

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The landlord looked at the Franciscan in amazement, but the latter, with his thumb, made the sign of the cross in a peculiar manner upon his breast. The host replied by making a similar sign on his left shoulder. Yes, indeed, he said, we did expect you, but we hoped that you would arrive in a better state of health. And as the peasants were looking at the innkeeper, usually so supercilious, and saw how respectful he had become in the presence of a poor monk, the Franciscan drew from a deep pocket three or four pieces of gold which he held out.
children.prevalue: The landlord looked at the Franciscan in amazement but the latter with his thumb made the sign of the cross in a peculiar manner upon his breast The host replied by making a similar sign on his left shoulder Yes indeed he said we did expect you but we hoped that you would arrive in a better state of health And as the peasants were looking at the innkeeper usually so supercilious and saw how respectful he had become in the presence of a poor monk the Franciscan drew from a deep pocket three or four pieces of gold which he held out

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: My friends, said he, here is something to repay you for the care you have taken of me. So make yourselves perfectly easy, and do not be afraid of leaving me here. The order to which I belong, and for which I am traveling, does not require me to beg; only, as the attention you have shown me deserves to be rewarded, take these two louis and depart in peace.
children.prevalue: My friends said he here is something to repay you for the care you have taken of me So make yourselves perfectly easy and do not be afraid of leaving me here The order to which I belong and for which I am traveling does not require me to beg only as the attention you have shown me deserves to be rewarded take these two louis and depart in peace

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The peasants did not dare to take them; the landlord took the two louis out of the monk's hand and placed them in that of one of the peasants, all four of whom withdrew, opening their eyes wider than ever. The door was then closed; and, while the innkeeper stood respectfully near it, the Franciscan collected himself for a moment. He then passed across his sallow face a hand which seemed dried up by fever, and rubbed his nervous and agitated fingers across his beard. His large eyes, hollowed by sickness and inquietude, seemed to peruse in the vague distance a mournful and fixed idea.
children.prevalue: The peasants did not dare to take them the landlord took the two louis out of the monk s hand and placed them in that of one of the peasants all four of whom withdrew opening their eyes wider than ever The door was then closed and while the innkeeper stood respectfully near it the Franciscan collected himself for a moment He then passed across his sallow face a hand which seemed dried up by fever and rubbed his nervous and agitated fingers across his beard His large eyes hollowed by sickness and inquietude seemed to peruse in the vague distance a mournful and fixed idea

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: What physicians have you at Fontainebleau? he inquired, after a long pause.
children.prevalue: What physicians have you at Fontainebleau he inquired after a long pause

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: We have three, holy father.
children.prevalue: We have three holy father

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: What are their names?
children.prevalue: What are their names

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Luiniguet first.
children.prevalue: Luiniguet first

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The next one?
children.prevalue: The next one

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: A brother of the Carmelite order, named Brother Hubert.
children.prevalue: A brother of the Carmelite order named Brother Hubert

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The next?
children.prevalue: The next

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: A secular member, named Grisart.
children.prevalue: A secular member named Grisart

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Ah! Grisart? murmured the monk, send for M. Grisart immediately.
children.prevalue: Ah Grisart murmured the monk send for M Grisart immediately

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: The landlord moved in prompt obedience to the direction.
children.prevalue: The landlord moved in prompt obedience to the direction

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Tell me what priests are there here?
children.prevalue: Tell me what priests are there here

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: What priests?
children.prevalue: What priests

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Yes; belonging to what orders?
children.prevalue: Yes belonging to what orders

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: There are Jesuits, Augustines, and Cordeliers; but the Jesuits are the closest at hand. Shall I send for a confessor belonging to the order of Jesuits?
children.prevalue: There are Jesuits Augustines and Cordeliers but the Jesuits are the closest at hand Shall I send for a confessor belonging to the order of Jesuits

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Yes, immediately.
children.prevalue: Yes immediately

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: It will be imagined that, at the sign of the cross which they had exchanged, the landlord and the invalid monk had recognized each other as two affiliated members of the wellknown Society of Jesus. Left to himself, the Franciscan drew from his pocket a bundle of papers, some of which he read over with the most careful attention. The violence of his disorder, however, overcame his courage; his eyes rolled in their sockets, a cold sweat poured down his face, and he nearly fainted, and lay with his head thrown backwards and his arms hanging down on both sides of his chair. For more than five minutes he remained without any movement, when the landlord returned, bringing with him the physician, whom he hardly allowed time to dress himself. The noise they made in entering the room, the current of air, which the opening of the door occasioned, restored the Franciscan to his senses. He hurriedly seized hold of the papers which were lying about, and with his long and bony hand concealed them under the cushions of the chair. The landlord went out of the room, leaving patient and physician together.
children.prevalue: It will be imagined that at the sign of the cross which they had exchanged the landlord and the invalid monk had recognized each other as two affiliated members of the wellknown Society of Jesus Left to himself the Franciscan drew from his pocket a bundle of papers some of which he read over with the most careful attention The violence of his disorder however overcame his courage his eyes rolled in their sockets a cold sweat poured down his face and he nearly fainted and lay with his head thrown backwards and his arms hanging down on both sides of his chair For more than five minutes he remained without any movement when the landlord returned bringing with him the physician whom he hardly allowed time to dress himself The noise they made in entering the room the current of air which the opening of the door occasioned restored the Franciscan to his senses He hurriedly seized hold of the papers which were lying about and with his long and bony hand concealed them under the cushions of the chair The landlord went out of the room leaving patient and physician together

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Come here, Monsieur Grisart, said the Franciscan to the doctor; approach closer, for there is no time to lose. Try, by touch and sound, and consider and pronounce your sentence.
children.prevalue: Come here Monsieur Grisart said the Franciscan to the doctor approach closer for there is no time to lose Try by touch and sound and consider and pronounce your sentence

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The landlord, replied the doctor, told me I had the honor of attending an affiliated brother.
children.prevalue: The landlord replied the doctor told me I had the honor of attending an affiliated brother

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Yes, replied the Franciscan, it is so. Tell me the truth, then; I feel very ill, and I think I am about to die.
children.prevalue: Yes replied the Franciscan it is so Tell me the truth then I feel very ill and I think I am about to die

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: The physician took the monk's hand, and felt his pulse. Oh, oh, he said, a dangerous fever.
children.prevalue: The physician took the monk s hand and felt his pulse Oh oh he said a dangerous fever

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: What do you call a dangerous fever? inquired the Franciscan, with an imperious look.
children.prevalue: What do you call a dangerous fever inquired the Franciscan with an imperious look

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: To an affiliated member of the first or second year, replied the physician, looking inquiringly at the monk, I should saya fever that may be cured.
children.prevalue: To an affiliated member of the first or second year replied the physician looking inquiringly at the monk I should saya fever that may be cured

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: But to me? said the Franciscan. The physician hesitated.
children.prevalue: But to me said the Franciscan The physician hesitated

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Look at my grey hair, and my forehead, full of anxious thought, he continued: look at the lines in my face, by which I reckon up the trials I have undergone; I am a Jesuit of the eleventh year, Monsieur Grisart. The physician started, for, in fact, a Jesuit of the eleventh year was one of those men who had been initiated in all the secrets of the order, one of those for whom science has no more secrets, the society no further barriers to presenttemporal obedience, no more trammels.
children.prevalue: Look at my grey hair and my forehead full of anxious thought he continued look at the lines in my face by which I reckon up the trials I have undergone I am a Jesuit of the eleventh year Monsieur Grisart The physician started for in fact a Jesuit of the eleventh year was one of those men who had been initiated in all the secrets of the order one of those for whom science has no more secrets the society no further barriers to presenttemporal obedience no more trammels

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: In that case, said Grisart, saluting him with respect, I am in the presence of a master?
children.prevalue: In that case said Grisart saluting him with respect I am in the presence of a master

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Yes; act, therefore, accordingly.
children.prevalue: Yes act therefore accordingly

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: And you wish to know?
children.prevalue: And you wish to know

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: My real state.
children.prevalue: My real state

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Well, said the physician, it is a brain fever, which has reached its highest degree of intensity.
children.prevalue: Well said the physician it is a brain fever which has reached its highest degree of intensity

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: There is no hope, then? inquired the Franciscan, in a quick tone of voice.
children.prevalue: There is no hope then inquired the Franciscan in a quick tone of voice

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: I do not say that, replied the doctor; yet, considering the disordered state of the brain, the hurried respiration, the rapidity of the pulse, and the burning nature of the fever which is devouring you
children.prevalue: I do not say that replied the doctor yet considering the disordered state of the brain the hurried respiration the rapidity of the pulse and the burning nature of the fever which is devouring you

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: And which has thrice prostrated me since this morning, said the monk.
children.prevalue: And which has thrice prostrated me since this morning said the monk

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: All things considered, I shall call it a terrible attack. But why did you not stop on your road?
children.prevalue: All things considered I shall call it a terrible attack But why did you not stop on your road

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: I was expected here, and I was obliged to come.
children.prevalue: I was expected here and I was obliged to come

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Even at the risk of your life?
children.prevalue: Even at the risk of your life

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Yes, at the risk of dying on the way.
children.prevalue: Yes at the risk of dying on the way

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Very well. Considering all the symptoms of your case, I must tell you that your condition is almost desperate.
children.prevalue: Very well Considering all the symptoms of your case I must tell you that your condition is almost desperate

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: The Franciscan smiled in a strange manner.
children.prevalue: The Franciscan smiled in a strange manner

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: What you have just told me is, perhaps, sufficient for what is due to an affiliated member, even of the eleventh year; but for what is due to me, Monsieur Grisart, it is too little, and I have a right to demand more. Come, then, let us be more candid still, and as frank as if you were making your own confession to Heaven. Besides, I have already sent for a confessor.
children.prevalue: What you have just told me is perhaps sufficient for what is due to an affiliated member even of the eleventh year but for what is due to me Monsieur Grisart it is too little and I have a right to demand more Come then let us be more candid still and as frank as if you were making your own confession to Heaven Besides I have already sent for a confessor

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Oh! I have hopes, however, murmured the doctor.
children.prevalue: Oh I have hopes however murmured the doctor

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Answer me, said the sick man, displaying with a dignified gesture a golden ring, the stone of which had until that moment been turned inside, and which bore engraved thereon the distinguishing mark of the Society of Jesus.
children.prevalue: Answer me said the sick man displaying with a dignified gesture a golden ring the stone of which had until that moment been turned inside and which bore engraved thereon the distinguishing mark of the Society of Jesus

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Grisart uttered loud exclamation. The general! he cried.
children.prevalue: Grisart uttered loud exclamation The general he cried

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Silence, said the Franciscan., you can now understand that the whole truth is all important.
children.prevalue: Silence said the Franciscan you can now understand that the whole truth is all important

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Monseigneur, monseigneur, murmured Grisart, send for the confessor, for in two hours, at the next seizure, you will be attacked by delirium, and will pass away in its course.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur monseigneur murmured Grisart send for the confessor for in two hours at the next seizure you will be attacked by delirium and will pass away in its course

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Very well, said the patient, for a moment contracting his eyebrows, I have still two hours to live then?
children.prevalue: Very well said the patient for a moment contracting his eyebrows I have still two hours to live then

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Yes; particularly if you take the potion I will send you presently.
children.prevalue: Yes particularly if you take the potion I will send you presently

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: And that will give me two hours of life?
children.prevalue: And that will give me two hours of life

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Two hours.
children.prevalue: Two hours

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: I would take it, were it poison, for those two hours are necessary not only for myself, but for the glory of the order.
children.prevalue: I would take it were it poison for those two hours are necessary not only for myself but for the glory of the order

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: What a loss, what a catastrophe for us all! murmured the physician.
children.prevalue: What a loss what a catastrophe for us all murmured the physician

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: It is the loss of one mannothing more, replied the Franciscan, for Heaven will enable the poor monk, who is about to leave you, to find a worthy successor. Adieu, Monsieur Grisart; already even, through the goodness of Heaven, I have met with you. A physician who had not been one of our holy order, would have left me in ignorance of my condition; and, confident that existence would be prolonged a few days further, I should not have taken the necessary precautions. You are a learned man, Monsieur Grisart, and that confers an honor upon us all; it would have been repugnant to my feelings to have found one of our order of little standing in his profession. Adieu, Monsieur Grisart; send me the cordial immediately.
children.prevalue: It is the loss of one mannothing more replied the Franciscan for Heaven will enable the poor monk who is about to leave you to find a worthy successor Adieu Monsieur Grisart already even through the goodness of Heaven I have met with you A physician who had not been one of our holy order would have left me in ignorance of my condition and confident that existence would be prolonged a few days further I should not have taken the necessary precautions You are a learned man Monsieur Grisart and that confers an honor upon us all it would have been repugnant to my feelings to have found one of our order of little standing in his profession Adieu Monsieur Grisart send me the cordial immediately

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Give me your blessing, at least, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Give me your blessing at least monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: In my mind, I do; go, go; in my mind, I do so, I tell youanimo, Maitre Grisart, viribus impossibile. And he again fell back on the armchair, in an almost senseless state. M. Grisart hesitated, whether he should give him immediate assistance, or should run to prepare the cordial he had promised. He decided in favor of the cordial, for he darted out of the room and disappeared down the staircase. [6]
children.prevalue: In my mind I do go go in my mind I do so I tell youanimo Maitre Grisart viribus impossibile And he again fell back on the armchair in an almost senseless state M Grisart hesitated whether he should give him immediate assistance or should run to prepare the cordial he had promised He decided in favor of the cordial for he darted out of the room and disappeared down the staircase 6

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: A few moments after the doctor's departure, the confessor arrived. He had hardly crossed the threshold of the door when the Franciscan fixed a penetrating look upon him, and, shaking his head, murmuredA weak mind, I see; may Heaven forgive me if I die without the help of this living piece of human infirmity. The confessor, on his side, regarded the dying man with astonishment, almost with terror. He had never beheld eyes so burningly bright at the very moment they were about to close, nor looks so terrible at the moment they were about to be quenched in death. The Franciscan made a rapid and imperious movement of his hand. Sit down, there, my father, he said, and listen to me. The Jesuit confessor, a good priest, a recently initiated member of the order, who had merely seen the beginning of its mysteries, yielded to the superiority assumed by the penitent.
children.prevalue: A few moments after the doctor s departure the confessor arrived He had hardly crossed the threshold of the door when the Franciscan fixed a penetrating look upon him and shaking his head murmuredA weak mind I see may Heaven forgive me if I die without the help of this living piece of human infirmity The confessor on his side regarded the dying man with astonishment almost with terror He had never beheld eyes so burningly bright at the very moment they were about to close nor looks so terrible at the moment they were about to be quenched in death The Franciscan made a rapid and imperious movement of his hand Sit down there my father he said and listen to me The Jesuit confessor a good priest a recently initiated member of the order who had merely seen the beginning of its mysteries yielded to the superiority assumed by the penitent

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: There are several persons staying in this hotel, continued the Franciscan.
children.prevalue: There are several persons staying in this hotel continued the Franciscan

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: But, inquired the Jesuit, I thought I had been summoned to listen to a confession. Is your remark, then, a confession?
children.prevalue: But inquired the Jesuit I thought I had been summoned to listen to a confession Is your remark then a confession

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Why do you ask?
children.prevalue: Why do you ask

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: In order to know whether I am to keep your words secret.
children.prevalue: In order to know whether I am to keep your words secret

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: My remarks are part of my confession; I confide them to you in your character of a confessor.
children.prevalue: My remarks are part of my confession I confide them to you in your character of a confessor

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Very well, said the priest, seating himself on the chair which the Franciscan had, with great difficulty, just left, to lie down on the bed.
children.prevalue: Very well said the priest seating himself on the chair which the Franciscan had with great difficulty just left to lie down on the bed

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The Franciscan continued,I repeat, there are several persons staying in this inn.
children.prevalue: The Franciscan continued I repeat there are several persons staying in this inn

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: So I have heard.
children.prevalue: So I have heard

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: They ought to be eight in number.
children.prevalue: They ought to be eight in number

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The Jesuit made a sign that he understood him. The first to whom I wish to speak, said the dying man, is a German from Vienna, whose name is Baron de Wostpur. Be kind enough to go to him, and tell him the person he expected has arrived. The confessor, astounded, looked at his penitent; the confession seemed a singular one.
children.prevalue: The Jesuit made a sign that he understood him The first to whom I wish to speak said the dying man is a German from Vienna whose name is Baron de Wostpur Be kind enough to go to him and tell him the person he expected has arrived The confessor astounded looked at his penitent the confession seemed a singular one

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Obey, said the Franciscan, in a tone of command impossible to resist. The good Jesuit, completely subdued, rose and left the room. As soon as he had gone, the Franciscan again took up the papers which a crisis of the fever had already, once before, obliged him to put aside.
children.prevalue: Obey said the Franciscan in a tone of command impossible to resist The good Jesuit completely subdued rose and left the room As soon as he had gone the Franciscan again took up the papers which a crisis of the fever had already once before obliged him to put aside

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The Baron de Wostpur? Good! he said; ambitious, a fool, and straitened in means.
children.prevalue: The Baron de Wostpur Good he said ambitious a fool and straitened in means

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: He folded up the papers, which he thrust under his pillow. Rapid footsteps were heard at the end of the corridor. The confessor returned, followed by the Baron de Wostpur, who walked along with his head raised, as if he were discussing with himself the possibility of touching the ceiling with the feather in his hat. Therefore, at the appearance of the Franciscan, at his melancholy look, and seeing the plainness of the room, he stopped, and inquired,Who has summoned me?
children.prevalue: He folded up the papers which he thrust under his pillow Rapid footsteps were heard at the end of the corridor The confessor returned followed by the Baron de Wostpur who walked along with his head raised as if he were discussing with himself the possibility of touching the ceiling with the feather in his hat Therefore at the appearance of the Franciscan at his melancholy look and seeing the plainness of the room he stopped and inquired Who has summoned me

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I, said the Franciscan, who turned towards the confessor, saying, My good father, leave us for a moment together; when this gentleman leaves, you will return here. The Jesuit left the room, and, doubtless, availed himself of this momentary exile from the presence of the dying man to ask the host for some explanation about this strange penitent, who treated his confessor no better than he would a man servant. The baron approached the bed, and wished to speak, but the hand of the Franciscan imposed silence upon him.
children.prevalue: I said the Franciscan who turned towards the confessor saying My good father leave us for a moment together when this gentleman leaves you will return here The Jesuit left the room and doubtless availed himself of this momentary exile from the presence of the dying man to ask the host for some explanation about this strange penitent who treated his confessor no better than he would a man servant The baron approached the bed and wished to speak but the hand of the Franciscan imposed silence upon him

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Every moment is precious, said the latter, hurriedly. You have come here for the competition, have you not?
children.prevalue: Every moment is precious said the latter hurriedly You have come here for the competition have you not

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Yes, my father.
children.prevalue: Yes my father

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: You hope to be elected general of the order?
children.prevalue: You hope to be elected general of the order

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: I hope so.
children.prevalue: I hope so

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: You know on what conditions only you can possibly attain this high position, which makes one man the master of monarchs, the equal of popes?
children.prevalue: You know on what conditions only you can possibly attain this high position which makes one man the master of monarchs the equal of popes

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Who are you, inquired the baron, to subject me to these interrogations?
children.prevalue: Who are you inquired the baron to subject me to these interrogations

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I am he whom you expected.
children.prevalue: I am he whom you expected

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: The electorgeneral?
children.prevalue: The electorgeneral

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: I am the elected.
children.prevalue: I am the elected

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: You are
children.prevalue: You are

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The Franciscan did not give him time to reply; he extended his shrunken hand, on which glittered the ring of the general of the order. The baron drew back in surprise; and then, immediately afterwards, bowing with the profoundest respect, he exclaimed,Is it possible that you are here, monseigneur; you, in this wretched room; you, upon this miserable bed; you, in search of and selecting the future general, that is, your own successor?
children.prevalue: The Franciscan did not give him time to reply he extended his shrunken hand on which glittered the ring of the general of the order The baron drew back in surprise and then immediately afterwards bowing with the profoundest respect he exclaimed Is it possible that you are here monseigneur you in this wretched room you upon this miserable bed you in search of and selecting the future general that is your own successor

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Do not distress yourself about that, monsieur, but fulfil immediately the principal condition, of furnishing the order with a secret of importance, of such importance that one of the greatest courts of Europe will, by your instrumentality, forever be subjected to the order. Well! do you possess the secret which you promised, in your request, addressed to the grand council?
children.prevalue: Do not distress yourself about that monsieur but fulfil immediately the principal condition of furnishing the order with a secret of importance of such importance that one of the greatest courts of Europe will by your instrumentality forever be subjected to the order Well do you possess the secret which you promised in your request addressed to the grand council

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Monseigneur
children.prevalue: Monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Let us proceed, however, in due order, said the monk. You are the Baron de Wostpur?
children.prevalue: Let us proceed however in due order said the monk You are the Baron de Wostpur

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Yes, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: And this letter is from you?
children.prevalue: And this letter is from you

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Yes, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: The general of the Jesuits drew a paper from his bundle, and presented it to the baron, who glanced at it, and made a sign in the affirmative, saying, Yes, monseigneur, this letter is mine.
children.prevalue: The general of the Jesuits drew a paper from his bundle and presented it to the baron who glanced at it and made a sign in the affirmative saying Yes monseigneur this letter is mine

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Can you show me the reply which the secretary of the grand council returned to you?
children.prevalue: Can you show me the reply which the secretary of the grand council returned to you

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Here it is, said the baron, holding towards the Franciscan a letter bearing simply the address, To his excellency the Baron de Wostpur, and containing only this phrase, From the 15th to the 22nd May, Fontainebleau, the hotel of the Beau Paon.A. M. D. G. [7]
children.prevalue: Here it is said the baron holding towards the Franciscan a letter bearing simply the address To his excellency the Baron de Wostpur and containing only this phrase From the 15th to the 22nd May Fontainebleau the hotel of the Beau Paon A M D G 7

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Right, said the Franciscan, and now speak.
children.prevalue: Right said the Franciscan and now speak

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I have a body of troops, composed of 50,000 men; all the officers are gained over. I am encamped on the Danube. In four days I can overthrow the emperor, who is, as you are aware, opposed to the progress of our order, and can replace him by whichever of the princes of his family the order may determine upon. The Franciscan listened, unmoved.
children.prevalue: I have a body of troops composed of 50 000 men all the officers are gained over I am encamped on the Danube In four days I can overthrow the emperor who is as you are aware opposed to the progress of our order and can replace him by whichever of the princes of his family the order may determine upon The Franciscan listened unmoved

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Is that all? he said.
children.prevalue: Is that all he said

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: A revolution throughout Europe is included in my plan, said the baron.
children.prevalue: A revolution throughout Europe is included in my plan said the baron

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Very well, Monsieur de Wostpur, you will receive a reply; return to your room, and leave Fontainebleau within a quarter of an hour. The baron withdrew backwards, as obsequiously as if he were taking leave of the emperor he was ready to betray.
children.prevalue: Very well Monsieur de Wostpur you will receive a reply return to your room and leave Fontainebleau within a quarter of an hour The baron withdrew backwards as obsequiously as if he were taking leave of the emperor he was ready to betray

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: There is no secret there, murmured the Franciscan, it is a plot. Besides, he added, after a moment's reflection, the future of Europe is no longer in the hands of the House of Austria.
children.prevalue: There is no secret there murmured the Franciscan it is a plot Besides he added after a moment s reflection the future of Europe is no longer in the hands of the House of Austria

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: And with a pencil he held in his hand, he struck the Baron de Wostpur's name from the list.
children.prevalue: And with a pencil he held in his hand he struck the Baron de Wostpur s name from the list

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Now for the cardinal, he said; we ought to get something more serious from the side of Spain.
children.prevalue: Now for the cardinal he said we ought to get something more serious from the side of Spain

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Raising his head, he perceived the confessor, who was awaiting his orders as respectfully as a schoolboy.
children.prevalue: Raising his head he perceived the confessor who was awaiting his orders as respectfully as a schoolboy

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Ah, ah! he said, noticing his submissive air, you have been talking with the landlord.
children.prevalue: Ah ah he said noticing his submissive air you have been talking with the landlord

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Yes, monseigneur; and to the physician.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur and to the physician

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: To Grisart?
children.prevalue: To Grisart

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: He is here, then?
children.prevalue: He is here then

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: He is waiting with the potion he promised.
children.prevalue: He is waiting with the potion he promised

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Very well; if I require him, I will call; you now understand the great importance of my confession, do you not?
children.prevalue: Very well if I require him I will call you now understand the great importance of my confession do you not

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Yes, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Then go and fetch me the Spanish Cardinal Herrebia. Make haste. Only, as you now understand the matter in hand, you will remain near me, for I begin to feel faint.
children.prevalue: Then go and fetch me the Spanish Cardinal Herrebia Make haste Only as you now understand the matter in hand you will remain near me for I begin to feel faint

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Shall I summon the physician?
children.prevalue: Shall I summon the physician

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Not yet, not yet... the Spanish cardinal, no one else. Fly.
children.prevalue: Not yet not yet the Spanish cardinal no one else Fly

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Five minutes afterwards, the cardinal, pale and disturbed, entered the little room.
children.prevalue: Five minutes afterwards the cardinal pale and disturbed entered the little room

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: I am informed, monseigneur, stammered the cardinal.
children.prevalue: I am informed monseigneur stammered the cardinal

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: To the point, said the Franciscan, in a faint voice, showing the cardinal a letter which he had written to the grand council. Is that your handwriting?
children.prevalue: To the point said the Franciscan in a faint voice showing the cardinal a letter which he had written to the grand council Is that your handwriting

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Yes, but
children.prevalue: Yes but

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: And your summons?
children.prevalue: And your summons

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: The cardinal hesitated to answer. His purple revolted against the mean garb of the poor Franciscan, who stretched out his hand and displayed the ring, which produced its effect, greater in proportion to the greatness of the person over whom the Franciscan exercised his influence.
children.prevalue: The cardinal hesitated to answer His purple revolted against the mean garb of the poor Franciscan who stretched out his hand and displayed the ring which produced its effect greater in proportion to the greatness of the person over whom the Franciscan exercised his influence

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Quick, the secret, the secret! said the dying man, leaning upon his confessor.
children.prevalue: Quick the secret the secret said the dying man leaning upon his confessor

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Coram isto? inquired the Spanish cardinal. [8]
children.prevalue: Coram isto inquired the Spanish cardinal 8

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Speak in Spanish, said the Franciscan, showing the liveliest attention.
children.prevalue: Speak in Spanish said the Franciscan showing the liveliest attention

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: You are aware, monseigneur, said the cardinal, continuing the conversation in Castilian, that the condition of the marriage of the Infanta with the king of France was the absolute renunciation of the rights of the said Infanta, as well as of King Louis XIV., to all claim to the crown of Spain. The Franciscan made a sign in the affirmative.
children.prevalue: You are aware monseigneur said the cardinal continuing the conversation in Castilian that the condition of the marriage of the Infanta with the king of France was the absolute renunciation of the rights of the said Infanta as well as of King Louis XIV to all claim to the crown of Spain The Franciscan made a sign in the affirmative

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: The consequence is, continued the cardinal, that the peace and alliance between the two kingdoms depend upon the observance of that clause of the contract. A similar sign from the Franciscan. Not only France and Spain, continued the cardinal, but the whole of Europe even, would be violently rent asunder by the faithlessness of either party. Another movement of the dying man's head.
children.prevalue: The consequence is continued the cardinal that the peace and alliance between the two kingdoms depend upon the observance of that clause of the contract A similar sign from the Franciscan Not only France and Spain continued the cardinal but the whole of Europe even would be violently rent asunder by the faithlessness of either party Another movement of the dying man s head

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: It further results, continued the speaker, that the man who might be able to foresee events, and to render certain that which is no more than a vague idea floating in the mind of man, that is to say, the idea of a future good or evil, would preserve the world from a great catastrophe; and the event, which has no fixed certainty even in the brain of him who originated it, could be turned to the advantage of our order.
children.prevalue: It further results continued the speaker that the man who might be able to foresee events and to render certain that which is no more than a vague idea floating in the mind of man that is to say the idea of a future good or evil would preserve the world from a great catastrophe and the event which has no fixed certainty even in the brain of him who originated it could be turned to the advantage of our order

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Pronto, pronto! murmured the Franciscan, in Spanish, who suddenly became paler, and leaned upon the priest. The cardinal approached the ear of the dying man, and said, Well, monseigneur, I know that the king of France has determined that, at the very first pretext, a death for instance, either that of the king of Spain, or that of a brother of the Infanta, France will, arms in hand, claim the inheritance, and I have in my possession, already prepared, the plan of policy agreed upon by Louis XIV. for this occasion.
children.prevalue: Pronto pronto murmured the Franciscan in Spanish who suddenly became paler and leaned upon the priest The cardinal approached the ear of the dying man and said Well monseigneur I know that the king of France has determined that at the very first pretext a death for instance either that of the king of Spain or that of a brother of the Infanta France will arms in hand claim the inheritance and I have in my possession already prepared the plan of policy agreed upon by Louis XIV for this occasion

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: And this plan? said the Franciscan.
children.prevalue: And this plan said the Franciscan

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Here it is, returned the cardinal.
children.prevalue: Here it is returned the cardinal

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: In whose handwriting is it?
children.prevalue: In whose handwriting is it

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: My own.
children.prevalue: My own

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Have you anything further to say to me?
children.prevalue: Have you anything further to say to me

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: I think I have said a good deal, my lord, replied the cardinal.
children.prevalue: I think I have said a good deal my lord replied the cardinal

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Yes, you have rendered the order a great service. But how did you procure the details, by the aid of which you have constructed your plan?
children.prevalue: Yes you have rendered the order a great service But how did you procure the details by the aid of which you have constructed your plan

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: I have the underservants of the king of France in my pay, and I obtain from them all the waste papers, which have been saved from being burnt.
children.prevalue: I have the underservants of the king of France in my pay and I obtain from them all the waste papers which have been saved from being burnt

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Very ingenious, murmured the Franciscan, endeavoring to smile; you will leave this hotel, cardinal, in a quarter of an hour, and a reply shall be sent you. The cardinal withdrew.
children.prevalue: Very ingenious murmured the Franciscan endeavoring to smile you will leave this hotel cardinal in a quarter of an hour and a reply shall be sent you The cardinal withdrew

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Call Grisart, and desire the Venetian Marini to come, said the sick man.
children.prevalue: Call Grisart and desire the Venetian Marini to come said the sick man

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: While the confessor obeyed, the Franciscan, instead of striking out the cardinal's name, as he had done the baron's, made a cross at the side of it. Then, exhausted by the effort, he fell back on his bed, murmuring the name of Dr. Grisart. When he returned to his senses, he had drunk about half of the potion, of which the remainder was left in the glass, and he found himself supported by the physician, while the Venetian and the confessor were standing close to the door. The Venetian submitted to the same formalities as his two predecessors, hesitated as they had done at the sight of the two strangers, but his confidence restored by the order of the general, he revealed that the pope, terrified at the power of the order, was weaving a plot for the general expulsion of the Jesuits, and was tampering with the different courts of Europe in order to obtain their assistance. He described the pontiff's auxiliaries, his means of action, and indicated the particular locality in the Archipelago where, by a sudden surprise, two cardinals, adepts of the eleventh year, and, consequently, high in authority, were to be transported, together with thirtytwo of the principal affiliated members of Rome. The Franciscan thanked the Signor Marini. It was by no means a slight service he had rendered the society by denouncing this pontifical project. The Venetian thereupon received directions to set off in a quarter of an hour, and left as radiant as if he already possessed the ring, the sign of the supreme authority of the society. As, however, he was departing, the Franciscan murmured to himself: All these men are either spies, or a sort of police, not one of them a general; they have all discovered a plot, but not one of them a secret. It is not by means of ruin, or war, or force, that the Society of Jesus is to be governed, but by that mysterious influence moral superiority alone confers. No, the man is not yet found, and to complete the misfortune, Heaven strikes me down, and I am dying. Oh! must the society indeed fall with me for want of a column to support it? Must death, which is waiting for me, swallow up with me the future of the order; that future which ten years more of my own life would have rendered eternal? for that future, with the reign of the new king, is opening radiant and full of splendor. These words, which had been halfreflected, halfpronounced aloud, were listened to by the Jesuit confessor with a terror similar to that with which one listens to the wanderings of a person attacked by fever, whilst Grisart, with a mind of higher order, devoured them as the revelations of an unknown world, in which his looks were plunged without ability to comprehend. Suddenly the Franciscan recovered himself.

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Let us finish this, he said; death is approaching. Oh! just now I was dying resignedly, for I hoped... while now I sink in despair, unless those who remain... Grisart, Grisart, give me to live a single hour longer.
children.prevalue: Let us finish this he said death is approaching Oh just now I was dying resignedly for I hoped while now I sink in despair unless those who remain Grisart Grisart give me to live a single hour longer

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Grisart approached the dying monk, and made him swallow a few drops, not of the potion which was still left in the glass, but of the contents of a small bottle he had upon his person.
children.prevalue: Grisart approached the dying monk and made him swallow a few drops not of the potion which was still left in the glass but of the contents of a small bottle he had upon his person

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Call the Scotchman! exclaimed the Franciscan; call the Bremen merchant. Call, call quickly. I am dying. I am suffocated.
children.prevalue: Call the Scotchman exclaimed the Franciscan call the Bremen merchant Call call quickly I am dying I am suffocated

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: The confessor darted forward to seek assistance, as if there had been any human strength which could hold back the hand of death, which was weighing down the sick man; but, at the threshold of the door, he found Aramis, who, with his finger on his lips, like the statue of Harpocrates, the god of silence, by a look motioned him back to the end of the apartment. The physician and the confessor, after having consulted each other by looks, made a movement as if to push Aramis aside, who, however, with two signs of the cross, each made in a different manner, transfixed them both in their places.
children.prevalue: The confessor darted forward to seek assistance as if there had been any human strength which could hold back the hand of death which was weighing down the sick man but at the threshold of the door he found Aramis who with his finger on his lips like the statue of Harpocrates the god of silence by a look motioned him back to the end of the apartment The physician and the confessor after having consulted each other by looks made a movement as if to push Aramis aside who however with two signs of the cross each made in a different manner transfixed them both in their places

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: A chief! they both murmured.
children.prevalue: A chief they both murmured

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Aramis slowly advanced into the room where the dying man was struggling against the first attack of the agony which had seized him. As for the Franciscan, whether owing to the effect of the elixir, or whether the appearance of Aramis had restored his strength, he made a movement, and his eyes glaring, his mouth half open, and his hair damp with sweat, sat up upon the bed. Aramis felt that the air of the room was stifling; the windows were closed; the fire was burning upon the hearth; a pair of candles of yellow wax were guttering down in the copper candlesticks, and still further increased, by their thick smoke, the temperature of the room. Aramis opened the window, and fixing upon the dying man a look full of intelligence and respect, said to him: Monseigneur, pray forgive my coming in this manner, before you summoned me, but your state alarms me, and I thought you might possibly die before you had seen me, for I am but the sixth upon your list.
children.prevalue: Aramis slowly advanced into the room where the dying man was struggling against the first attack of the agony which had seized him As for the Franciscan whether owing to the effect of the elixir or whether the appearance of Aramis had restored his strength he made a movement and his eyes glaring his mouth half open and his hair damp with sweat sat up upon the bed Aramis felt that the air of the room was stifling the windows were closed the fire was burning upon the hearth a pair of candles of yellow wax were guttering down in the copper candlesticks and still further increased by their thick smoke the temperature of the room Aramis opened the window and fixing upon the dying man a look full of intelligence and respect said to him Monseigneur pray forgive my coming in this manner before you summoned me but your state alarms me and I thought you might possibly die before you had seen me for I am but the sixth upon your list

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: The dying man started and looked at the list.
children.prevalue: The dying man started and looked at the list

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: You are, therefore, he who was formerly called Aramis, and since, the Chevalier d'Herblay? You are the bishop of Vannes?
children.prevalue: You are therefore he who was formerly called Aramis and since the Chevalier d Herblay You are the bishop of Vannes

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Yes, my lord.
children.prevalue: Yes my lord

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: I know you, I have seen you.
children.prevalue: I know you I have seen you

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: At the last jubilee, we were with the Holy Father together.
children.prevalue: At the last jubilee we were with the Holy Father together

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Yes, yes, I remember; and you place yourself on the list of candidates?
children.prevalue: Yes yes I remember and you place yourself on the list of candidates

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Monseigneur, I have heard it said that the order required to become possessed of a great state secret, and knowing that from modesty you had in anticipation resigned your functions in favor of the person who should be the depositary of such a secret, I wrote to say that I was ready to compete, possessing alone a secret I believe to be important.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur I have heard it said that the order required to become possessed of a great state secret and knowing that from modesty you had in anticipation resigned your functions in favor of the person who should be the depositary of such a secret I wrote to say that I was ready to compete possessing alone a secret I believe to be important

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Speak, said the Franciscan; I am ready to listen to you, and to judge the importance of the secret.
children.prevalue: Speak said the Franciscan I am ready to listen to you and to judge the importance of the secret

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: A secret of the value of that which I have the honor to confide to you cannot be communicated by word of mouth. Any idea which, when once expressed, has thereby lost its safeguard, and has become vulgarized by any manifestation or communication of it whatever, no longer is the property of him who gave it birth. My words may be overheard by some listener, or perhaps by an enemy; one ought not, therefore, to speak at random, for, in such a case, the secret would cease to be one.
children.prevalue: A secret of the value of that which I have the honor to confide to you cannot be communicated by word of mouth Any idea which when once expressed has thereby lost its safeguard and has become vulgarized by any manifestation or communication of it whatever no longer is the property of him who gave it birth My words may be overheard by some listener or perhaps by an enemy one ought not therefore to speak at random for in such a case the secret would cease to be one

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: How do you propose, then, to convey your secret? inquired the dying monk.
children.prevalue: How do you propose then to convey your secret inquired the dying monk

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: With one hand Aramis signed to the physician and the confessor to withdraw, and with the other he handed to the Franciscan a paper enclosed in a double envelope.
children.prevalue: With one hand Aramis signed to the physician and the confessor to withdraw and with the other he handed to the Franciscan a paper enclosed in a double envelope

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Is not writing more dangerous still than language?
children.prevalue: Is not writing more dangerous still than language

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: No, my lord, said Aramis, for you will find within this envelope characters which you and I alone can understand. The Franciscan looked at Aramis with an astonishment which momentarily increased.
children.prevalue: No my lord said Aramis for you will find within this envelope characters which you and I alone can understand The Franciscan looked at Aramis with an astonishment which momentarily increased

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: It is a cipher, continued the latter, which you used in 1655, and which your secretary, Juan Jujan, who is dead, could alone decipher, if he were restored to life.
children.prevalue: It is a cipher continued the latter which you used in 1655 and which your secretary Juan Jujan who is dead could alone decipher if he were restored to life

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: You knew this cipher, then?
children.prevalue: You knew this cipher then

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: It was I who taught it him, said Aramis, bowing with a gracefulness full of respect, and advancing towards the door as if to leave the room: but a gesture of the Franciscan accompanied by a cry for him to remain, restrained him.
children.prevalue: It was I who taught it him said Aramis bowing with a gracefulness full of respect and advancing towards the door as if to leave the room but a gesture of the Franciscan accompanied by a cry for him to remain restrained him

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Ecce homo! he exclaimed; then reading the paper a second time, he called out, Approach, approach quickly!
children.prevalue: Ecce homo he exclaimed then reading the paper a second time he called out Approach approach quickly

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Aramis returned to the side of the Franciscan, with the same calm countenance and the same respectful manner, unchanged. The Franciscan, extending his arm, burnt by the flame of the candle the paper which Aramis had handed him. Then, taking hold of Aramis's hand, he drew him towards him, and inquired: In what manner and by whose means could you possibly become acquainted with such a secret?
children.prevalue: Aramis returned to the side of the Franciscan with the same calm countenance and the same respectful manner unchanged The Franciscan extending his arm burnt by the flame of the candle the paper which Aramis had handed him Then taking hold of Aramis s hand he drew him towards him and inquired In what manner and by whose means could you possibly become acquainted with such a secret

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Through Madame de Chevreuse, the intimate friend and confidante of the queen.
children.prevalue: Through Madame de Chevreuse the intimate friend and confidante of the queen

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: And Madame de Chevreuse
children.prevalue: And Madame de Chevreuse

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Is dead.
children.prevalue: Is dead

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Did any others know it?
children.prevalue: Did any others know it

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: A man and a woman only, and they of the lower classes.
children.prevalue: A man and a woman only and they of the lower classes

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Who are they?
children.prevalue: Who are they

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Persons who had brought him up.
children.prevalue: Persons who had brought him up

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: What has become of them?
children.prevalue: What has become of them

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Dead also. This secret burns like vitriol.
children.prevalue: Dead also This secret burns like vitriol

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: But you survive?
children.prevalue: But you survive

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: No one is aware that I know it.
children.prevalue: No one is aware that I know it

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: And for what length of time have you possessed this secret?
children.prevalue: And for what length of time have you possessed this secret

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: For the last fifteen years.
children.prevalue: For the last fifteen years

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: And you have kept it?
children.prevalue: And you have kept it

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: I wished to live.
children.prevalue: I wished to live

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: And you give it to the order without ambition, without acknowledgement?
children.prevalue: And you give it to the order without ambition without acknowledgement

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: I give it to the order with ambition and with a hope of return, said Aramis; for if you live, my lord, you will make of me, now you know me, what I can and ought to be.
children.prevalue: I give it to the order with ambition and with a hope of return said Aramis for if you live my lord you will make of me now you know me what I can and ought to be

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: And as I am dying, exclaimed the Franciscan, I constitute you my successor... Thus. And drawing off the ring, he passed it on Aramis's finger. Then, turning towards the two spectators of this scene, he said: Be ye witnesses of this, and testify, if need be, that, sick in body, but sound in mind, I have freely and voluntarily bestowed this ring, the token of supreme authority, upon Monseigneur d'Herblay, bishop of Vannes, whom I nominate my successor, and before whom I, an humble sinner, about to appear before Heaven, prostrate myself, as an example for all to follow. And the Franciscan bowed lowly and submissively, whilst the physician and the Jesuit fell on their knees. Aramis, even while he became paler than the dying man himself, bent his looks successively upon all the actors of this scene. Profoundly gratified ambition flowed with lifeblood towards his heart.
children.prevalue: And as I am dying exclaimed the Franciscan I constitute you my successor Thus And drawing off the ring he passed it on Aramis s finger Then turning towards the two spectators of this scene he said Be ye witnesses of this and testify if need be that sick in body but sound in mind I have freely and voluntarily bestowed this ring the token of supreme authority upon Monseigneur d Herblay bishop of Vannes whom I nominate my successor and before whom I an humble sinner about to appear before Heaven prostrate myself as an example for all to follow And the Franciscan bowed lowly and submissively whilst the physician and the Jesuit fell on their knees Aramis even while he became paler than the dying man himself bent his looks successively upon all the actors of this scene Profoundly gratified ambition flowed with lifeblood towards his heart

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: We must lose no time, said the Franciscan; what I had still to do on earth was urgent. I shall never succeed in carrying it out.
children.prevalue: We must lose no time said the Franciscan what I had still to do on earth was urgent I shall never succeed in carrying it out

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: I will do it, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: I will do it said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: It is well, said the Franciscan, and then turning towards the Jesuit and the doctor, he added, Leave us alone, a direction they instantly obeyed.
children.prevalue: It is well said the Franciscan and then turning towards the Jesuit and the doctor he added Leave us alone a direction they instantly obeyed

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: With this sign, he said, you are the man needed to shake the world from one end to the other; with this sign you will overthrow; with this sign you will edify; in hoc signo vinces! [9]
children.prevalue: With this sign he said you are the man needed to shake the world from one end to the other with this sign you will overthrow with this sign you will edify in hoc signo vinces 9

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: Close the door, continued the Franciscan after a pause. Aramis shut and bolted the door, and returned to the side of the Franciscan.
children.prevalue: Close the door continued the Franciscan after a pause Aramis shut and bolted the door and returned to the side of the Franciscan

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: The pope is conspiring against the order, said the monk; the pope must die.
children.prevalue: The pope is conspiring against the order said the monk the pope must die

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: He shall die, said Aramis, quietly.
children.prevalue: He shall die said Aramis quietly

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: Seven hundred thousand livres are owing to a Bremen merchant of the name of Bonstett, who came here to get the guarantee of my signature.
children.prevalue: Seven hundred thousand livres are owing to a Bremen merchant of the name of Bonstett who came here to get the guarantee of my signature

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: He shall be paid, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: He shall be paid said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: Six knights of Malta, whose names are written here, have discovered, by the indiscretion of one of the affiliated of the eleventh year, the three mysteries; it must be ascertained what else these men have done with the secret, to get it back again and bury it.
children.prevalue: Six knights of Malta whose names are written here have discovered by the indiscretion of one of the affiliated of the eleventh year the three mysteries it must be ascertained what else these men have done with the secret to get it back again and bury it

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: It shall be done.
children.prevalue: It shall be done

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: Three dangerous affiliated members must be sent away into Tibet, there to perish; they stand condemned. Here are their names.
