children.prevalue: Three dangerous affiliated members must be sent away into Tibet there to perish they stand condemned Here are their names

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: I will see that the sentence be carried out.
children.prevalue: I will see that the sentence be carried out

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: Lastly, there is a lady at Anvers, grandniece of Ravaillac; she holds certain papers in her hands that compromise the order. There has been payable to the family during the last fiftyone years a pension of fifty thousand livres. The pension is a heavy one, and the order is not wealthy. Redeem the papers, for a sum of money paid down, or, in case of refusal, stop the pensionbut run no risk.
children.prevalue: Lastly there is a lady at Anvers grandniece of Ravaillac she holds certain papers in her hands that compromise the order There has been payable to the family during the last fiftyone years a pension of fifty thousand livres The pension is a heavy one and the order is not wealthy Redeem the papers for a sum of money paid down or in case of refusal stop the pensionbut run no risk

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: I will quickly decide what is best to be done, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: I will quickly decide what is best to be done said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: A vessel chartered from Lima entered the port of Lisbon last week; ostensibly it is laden with chocolate, in reality with gold. Every ingot is concealed by a coating of chocolate. The vessel belongs to the order; it is worth seventeen millions of livres; you will see that it is claimed; here are the bills of landing.
children.prevalue: A vessel chartered from Lima entered the port of Lisbon last week ostensibly it is laden with chocolate in reality with gold Every ingot is concealed by a coating of chocolate The vessel belongs to the order it is worth seventeen millions of livres you will see that it is claimed here are the bills of landing

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: To what port shall I direct it to be taken?
children.prevalue: To what port shall I direct it to be taken

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: To Bayonne.
children.prevalue: To Bayonne

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: Before three weeks are over it shall be there, wind and weather permitting. Is that all? The Franciscan made a sign in the affirmative, for he could no longer speak; the blood rushed to his throat and his head, and gushed from his mouth, his nostrils, and his eyes. The dying man had barely time to press Aramis's hand, when he fell in convulsions from his bed upon the floor. Aramis placed his hand upon the Franciscan's heart, but it had ceased to beat. As he stooped down, Aramis observed that a fragment of the paper he had given the Franciscan had escaped being burnt. He picked it up, and burnt it to the last atom. Then, summoning the confessor and the physician, he said to the former: Your penitent is in heaven; he needs nothing more than prayers and the burial bestowed upon the pious dead. Go and prepare what is necessary for a simple interment, such as a poor monk only would require. Go.
children.prevalue: Before three weeks are over it shall be there wind and weather permitting Is that all The Franciscan made a sign in the affirmative for he could no longer speak the blood rushed to his throat and his head and gushed from his mouth his nostrils and his eyes The dying man had barely time to press Aramis s hand when he fell in convulsions from his bed upon the floor Aramis placed his hand upon the Franciscan s heart but it had ceased to beat As he stooped down Aramis observed that a fragment of the paper he had given the Franciscan had escaped being burnt He picked it up and burnt it to the last atom Then summoning the confessor and the physician he said to the former Your penitent is in heaven he needs nothing more than prayers and the burial bestowed upon the pious dead Go and prepare what is necessary for a simple interment such as a poor monk only would require Go

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: The Jesuit left the room. Then, turning towards the physician, and observing his pale and anxious face, he said, in a low tone of voice: Monsieur Grisart, empty and clean this glass; there is too much left in it of what the grand council desired you to put in.
children.prevalue: The Jesuit left the room Then turning towards the physician and observing his pale and anxious face he said in a low tone of voice Monsieur Grisart empty and clean this glass there is too much left in it of what the grand council desired you to put in

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: Grisart, amazed, overcome, completely astounded, almost fell backwards in his extreme terror. Aramis shrugged his shoulders in sign of pity, took the glass, and poured out the contents among the ashes of the hearth. He then left the room, carrying the papers of the dead man with him.
children.prevalue: Grisart amazed overcome completely astounded almost fell backwards in his extreme terror Aramis shrugged his shoulders in sign of pity took the glass and poured out the contents among the ashes of the hearth He then left the room carrying the papers of the dead man with him

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The next day, or rather the same day (for the events we have just described were concluded only at three o'clock in the morning), before breakfast was served, and as the king was preparing to go to mass with the two queens; as Monsieur, with the Chevalier de Lorraine, and a few other intimate companions, was mounting his horse to set off for the river, to take one of those celebrated baths with which the ladies of the court were so infatuated, as, in fact, no one remained in the chateau, with the exception of Madame who, under the pretext of indisposition, would not leave her room; Montalais was seen, or rather not was not seen, to glide stealthily out of the room appropriated to the maids of honor, leading La Valliere after her, who tried to conceal herself as much as possible, and both of them, hurrying secretly through the gardens, succeeded, looking round them at every step they took, in reaching the thicket. The weather was cloudy, a warm breeze bowed the flowers and the shrubs, the burning dust, swept along in clouds by the wind, was whirled in eddies towards the trees. Montalais, who, during their progress, had discharged the functions of a clever scout, advanced a few steps further, and turning round again, to be quite sure that no one was either listening or approaching, said to her companion, Thank goodness, we are quite alone! Since yesterday every one spies on us here, and a circle seems to be drawn round us, as if we were plaguestricken. La Valliere bent down her head and sighed. It is positively unheard of, continued Montalais; from M. Malicorne to M. de SaintAignan, every one wishes to get hold of our secret. Come, Louise, let us take counsel, you and I, together, in order that I may know what to do.
children.prevalue: The next day or rather the same day for the events we have just described were concluded only at three o clock in the morning before breakfast was served and as the king was preparing to go to mass with the two queens as Monsieur with the Chevalier de Lorraine and a few other intimate companions was mounting his horse to set off for the river to take one of those celebrated baths with which the ladies of the court were so infatuated as in fact no one remained in the chateau with the exception of Madame who under the pretext of indisposition would not leave her room Montalais was seen or rather not was not seen to glide stealthily out of the room appropriated to the maids of honor leading La Valliere after her who tried to conceal herself as much as possible and both of them hurrying secretly through the gardens succeeded looking round them at every step they took in reaching the thicket The weather was cloudy a warm breeze bowed the flowers and the shrubs the burning dust swept along in clouds by the wind was whirled in eddies towards the trees Montalais who during their progress had discharged the functions of a clever scout advanced a few steps further and turning round again to be quite sure that no one was either listening or approaching said to her companion Thank goodness we are quite alone Since yesterday every one spies on us here and a circle seems to be drawn round us as if we were plaguestricken La Valliere bent down her head and sighed It is positively unheard of continued Montalais from M Malicorne to M de SaintAignan every one wishes to get hold of our secret Come Louise let us take counsel you and I together in order that I may know what to do

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: La Valliere lifted towards her companion her beautiful eyes, pure and deep as the azure of a spring sky, And I, she said, will ask you why we have been summoned to Madame's own room? Why have we slept close to her apartment, instead of sleeping as usual in our own? Why did you return so late, and whence are these measures of strict supervision which have been adopted since this morning, with respect to us both?
children.prevalue: La Valliere lifted towards her companion her beautiful eyes pure and deep as the azure of a spring sky And I she said will ask you why we have been summoned to Madame s own room Why have we slept close to her apartment instead of sleeping as usual in our own Why did you return so late and whence are these measures of strict supervision which have been adopted since this morning with respect to us both

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: My dear Louise, you answer my question by another, or rather, by ten others, which is not answering me at all. I will tell you all you want to know later, and as it is of secondary importance, you can wait. What I ask youfor everything will depend upon thatis, whether there is or is not any secret?
children.prevalue: My dear Louise you answer my question by another or rather by ten others which is not answering me at all I will tell you all you want to know later and as it is of secondary importance you can wait What I ask youfor everything will depend upon thatis whether there is or is not any secret

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: I do not know if there is any secret, said La Valliere; but I do know, for my part at least, that there has been great imprudence committed. Since the foolish remark I made, and my still more silly fainting yesterday, every one here is making remarks about us.
children.prevalue: I do not know if there is any secret said La Valliere but I do know for my part at least that there has been great imprudence committed Since the foolish remark I made and my still more silly fainting yesterday every one here is making remarks about us

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Speak for yourself, said Montalais, laughing, speak for yourself and for TonnayCharente; for both of you made your declarations of love to the skies, which unfortunately were intercepted.
children.prevalue: Speak for yourself said Montalais laughing speak for yourself and for TonnayCharente for both of you made your declarations of love to the skies which unfortunately were intercepted

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: La Valliere hung down her head. Really you overwhelm me, she said.
children.prevalue: La Valliere hung down her head Really you overwhelm me she said

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: I?
children.prevalue: I

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Yes, you torture me with your jests.
children.prevalue: Yes you torture me with your jests

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Listen to me, Louise. These are no jests, for nothing is more serious; on the contrary, I did not drag you out of the chateau; I did not miss attending mass; I did not pretend to have a cold, as Madame did, which she has no more than I have; and, lastly, I did not display ten times more diplomacy than M. Colbert inherited from M. de Mazarin, and makes use of with respect to M. Fouquet, in order to find means of confiding my perplexities to you, for the sole end and purpose that, when at last we were alone, with no one to listen to us, you should deal hypocritically with me. No, no; believe me, that when I ask you a question, it is not from curiosity alone, but really because the position is a critical one. What you said yesterday is now known,it is a text on which every one is discoursing. Every one embellishes it to the utmost, and according to his own fancy; you had the honor last night, and you have it still today, of occupying the whole court, my dear Louise; and the number of tender and witty remarks which have been ascribed to you, would make Mademoiselle de Scudery and her brother burst from very spite, if they were faithfully reported.
children.prevalue: Listen to me Louise These are no jests for nothing is more serious on the contrary I did not drag you out of the chateau I did not miss attending mass I did not pretend to have a cold as Madame did which she has no more than I have and lastly I did not display ten times more diplomacy than M Colbert inherited from M de Mazarin and makes use of with respect to M Fouquet in order to find means of confiding my perplexities to you for the sole end and purpose that when at last we were alone with no one to listen to us you should deal hypocritically with me No no believe me that when I ask you a question it is not from curiosity alone but really because the position is a critical one What you said yesterday is now known it is a text on which every one is discoursing Every one embellishes it to the utmost and according to his own fancy you had the honor last night and you have it still today of occupying the whole court my dear Louise and the number of tender and witty remarks which have been ascribed to you would make Mademoiselle de Scudery and her brother burst from very spite if they were faithfully reported

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: But, dearest Montalais, said the poor girl, you know better than any one exactly what I said, since you were present when I said it.
children.prevalue: But dearest Montalais said the poor girl you know better than any one exactly what I said since you were present when I said it

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Yes, I know. But that is not the question. I have not forgotten a single syllable you uttered, but did you think what you were saying?
children.prevalue: Yes I know But that is not the question I have not forgotten a single syllable you uttered but did you think what you were saying

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Louise became confused. What, she exclaimed, more questions still! Oh, heavens! when I would give the world to forget what I did say, how does it happen that every one does all he possibly can to remind me of it? Oh, this is indeed terrible!
children.prevalue: Louise became confused What she exclaimed more questions still Oh heavens when I would give the world to forget what I did say how does it happen that every one does all he possibly can to remind me of it Oh this is indeed terrible

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: What is?
children.prevalue: What is

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: To have a friend who ought to spare me, who might advise me and help me to save myself, and yet who is undoing meis killing me.
children.prevalue: To have a friend who ought to spare me who might advise me and help me to save myself and yet who is undoing meis killing me

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: There, there, that will do, said Montalais; after having said too little, you now say too much. No one thinks of killing you, nor even of robbing you, even of your secret; I wish to have it voluntarily, and in no other way; for the question does not concern your own affairs only, but ours also; and TonnayCharente would tell you as I do, if she were here. For, the fact is, that last evening she wished to have some private conversation in our room, and I was going there after the Manicamp and Malicorne colloquies terminated, when I learned, on my return, rather late, it is true, that Madame had sequestered her maids of honor, and that we were to sleep in her apartments, instead of our own. Moreover, Madame has shut up her maids of honor in order that they should not have the time to concert any measures together, and this morning she was closeted with TonnayCharente with the same object. Tell me, then, to what extent Athenais and I can rely upon you, as we will tell you in what way you can rely upon us?
children.prevalue: There there that will do said Montalais after having said too little you now say too much No one thinks of killing you nor even of robbing you even of your secret I wish to have it voluntarily and in no other way for the question does not concern your own affairs only but ours also and TonnayCharente would tell you as I do if she were here For the fact is that last evening she wished to have some private conversation in our room and I was going there after the Manicamp and Malicorne colloquies terminated when I learned on my return rather late it is true that Madame had sequestered her maids of honor and that we were to sleep in her apartments instead of our own Moreover Madame has shut up her maids of honor in order that they should not have the time to concert any measures together and this morning she was closeted with TonnayCharente with the same object Tell me then to what extent Athenais and I can rely upon you as we will tell you in what way you can rely upon us

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: I do not clearly understand the question you have put, said Louise, much agitated.
children.prevalue: I do not clearly understand the question you have put said Louise much agitated

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Hum! and yet, on the contrary, you seem to understand me very well. However, I will put my questions in a more precise manner, in order that you may not be able, in the slightest degree, to evade them. Listen to me: Do you love M. de Bragelonne? That is plain enough, is it not?
children.prevalue: Hum and yet on the contrary you seem to understand me very well However I will put my questions in a more precise manner in order that you may not be able in the slightest degree to evade them Listen to me Do you love M de Bragelonne That is plain enough is it not

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: At this question, which fell like the first bombshell of a besieging army into a doomed town, Louise started. You ask me, she exclaimed, if I love Raoul, the friend of my childhood,my brother almost?
children.prevalue: At this question which fell like the first bombshell of a besieging army into a doomed town Louise started You ask me she exclaimed if I love Raoul the friend of my childhood my brother almost

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: No, no, no! Again you evade me, or rather, you wish to escape me. I do not ask if you love Raoul, your childhood's friend,your brother; but I ask if you love the Vicomte de Bragelonne, your affianced husband?
children.prevalue: No no no Again you evade me or rather you wish to escape me I do not ask if you love Raoul your childhood s friend your brother but I ask if you love the Vicomte de Bragelonne your affianced husband

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Good heavens! dear Montalais, said Louise, how severe your tone is!
children.prevalue: Good heavens dear Montalais said Louise how severe your tone is

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: You deserve no indulgence,I am neither more nor less severe than usual. I put a question to you, so answer it.
children.prevalue: You deserve no indulgence I am neither more nor less severe than usual I put a question to you so answer it

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: You certainly do not, said Louise, in a choking voice, speak to me like a friend; but I will answer you as a true friend.
children.prevalue: You certainly do not said Louise in a choking voice speak to me like a friend but I will answer you as a true friend

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Well, do so.
children.prevalue: Well do so

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Very well; my heart is full of scruples and silly feelings of pride, with respect to everything that a woman ought to keep secret, and in this respect no one has ever read into the bottom of my soul.
children.prevalue: Very well my heart is full of scruples and silly feelings of pride with respect to everything that a woman ought to keep secret and in this respect no one has ever read into the bottom of my soul

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: That I know very well. If I had read it, I should not interrogate you as I have done; I should simply say,'My good Louise, you have the happiness of an acquaintance with M. de Bragelonne, who is an excellent young man, and an advantageous match for a girl without fortune. M. de la Fere will leave something like fifteen thousand livres a year to his son. At a future day, then, you, as this son's wife, will have fifteen thousand livres a year; which is not bad. Turn, then, neither to the right hand nor to the left, but go frankly to M. de Bragelonne; that is to say, to the altar to which he will lead you. Afterwards, why afterwards, according to his disposition, you will be emancipated or enslaved; in other words, you will have a right to commit any piece of folly people commit who have either too much liberty or too little.' That is, my dear Louise, what I should have told you at first, if I had been able to read your heart.
children.prevalue: That I know very well If I had read it I should not interrogate you as I have done I should simply say My good Louise you have the happiness of an acquaintance with M de Bragelonne who is an excellent young man and an advantageous match for a girl without fortune M de la Fere will leave something like fifteen thousand livres a year to his son At a future day then you as this son s wife will have fifteen thousand livres a year which is not bad Turn then neither to the right hand nor to the left but go frankly to M de Bragelonne that is to say to the altar to which he will lead you Afterwards why afterwards according to his disposition you will be emancipated or enslaved in other words you will have a right to commit any piece of folly people commit who have either too much liberty or too little That is my dear Louise what I should have told you at first if I had been able to read your heart

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: And I should have thanked you, stammered out Louise, although the advice does not appear to me to be altogether sound.
children.prevalue: And I should have thanked you stammered out Louise although the advice does not appear to me to be altogether sound

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Wait, wait. But immediately after having given you that advice, I should have added,'Louise, it is very dangerous to pass whole days with your head drooping, your hands unoccupied, your eyes restless and full of thought; it is dangerous to prefer the least frequented paths, and no longer be amused with such diversions as gladden young girls' hearts; it is dangerous, Louise, to scrawl with the point of your foot, as you do, upon the gravel, certain letters it is useless for you to efface, but which appear again under your heel, particularly when those letters rather resemble the letter L than the letter B; and, lastly, it is dangerous to allow the mind to dwell on a thousand wild fancies, the fruits of solitude and heartache; these fancies, while they sink into a young girl's mind, make her cheeks sink in also, so that it is not unusual, on such occasions, to find the most delightful persons in the world become the most disagreeable, and the wittiest to become the dullest.'
children.prevalue: Wait wait But immediately after having given you that advice I should have added Louise it is very dangerous to pass whole days with your head drooping your hands unoccupied your eyes restless and full of thought it is dangerous to prefer the least frequented paths and no longer be amused with such diversions as gladden young girls hearts it is dangerous Louise to scrawl with the point of your foot as you do upon the gravel certain letters it is useless for you to efface but which appear again under your heel particularly when those letters rather resemble the letter L than the letter B and lastly it is dangerous to allow the mind to dwell on a thousand wild fancies the fruits of solitude and heartache these fancies while they sink into a young girl s mind make her cheeks sink in also so that it is not unusual on such occasions to find the most delightful persons in the world become the most disagreeable and the wittiest to become the dullest

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I thank you, dearest Aure, replied La Valliere, gently; it is like you to speak to me in this manner, and I thank you for it.
children.prevalue: I thank you dearest Aure replied La Valliere gently it is like you to speak to me in this manner and I thank you for it

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: It was only for the benefit of wild dreamers, such as I have just described, that I spoke; do not take any of my words, then, to yourself, except such as you think you deserve. Stay, I hardly know what story recurs to my memory of some silly or melancholy girl, who was gradually pining away because she fancied that the prince, or the king, or the emperor, whoever it wasand it does not matter much whichhad fallen in love with her; while on the contrary, the prince, or the king, or the emperor, whichever you please, was plainly in love with some one else, anda singular circumstance, one, indeed, which she could not perceive, although every one around and about her perceived it clearly enough made use of her as a screen for his own love affair. You laugh as I do, at this poor silly girl, do you not, Louise?
children.prevalue: It was only for the benefit of wild dreamers such as I have just described that I spoke do not take any of my words then to yourself except such as you think you deserve Stay I hardly know what story recurs to my memory of some silly or melancholy girl who was gradually pining away because she fancied that the prince or the king or the emperor whoever it wasand it does not matter much whichhad fallen in love with her while on the contrary the prince or the king or the emperor whichever you please was plainly in love with some one else anda singular circumstance one indeed which she could not perceive although every one around and about her perceived it clearly enough made use of her as a screen for his own love affair You laugh as I do at this poor silly girl do you not Louise

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: I?oh! of course, stammered Louise, pale as death.
children.prevalue: I oh of course stammered Louise pale as death

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: And you are right, too, for the thing is amusing enough. The story, whether true or false, amused me, and so I remembered it and told it to you. Just imagine then, my good Louise, the mischief that such a melancholy would create in anybody's brain,a melancholy, I mean, of that kind. For my own part, I resolved to tell you the story; for if such a thing were to happen to either of us, it would be most essential to be assured of its truth; today it is a snare, tomorrow it would become a jest and mockery, the next day it would mean death itself. La Valliere started again, and became, if possible, still paler.
children.prevalue: And you are right too for the thing is amusing enough The story whether true or false amused me and so I remembered it and told it to you Just imagine then my good Louise the mischief that such a melancholy would create in anybody s brain a melancholy I mean of that kind For my own part I resolved to tell you the story for if such a thing were to happen to either of us it would be most essential to be assured of its truth today it is a snare tomorrow it would become a jest and mockery the next day it would mean death itself La Valliere started again and became if possible still paler

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Whenever a king takes notice of us, continued Montalais, he lets us see it easily enough, and, if we happen to be the object he covets, he knows very well how to gain his object. You see, then, Louise, that, in such circumstances, between young girls exposed to such a danger as the one in question, the most perfect confidence should exist, in order that those hearts which are not disposed towards melancholy may watch over those likely to become so.
children.prevalue: Whenever a king takes notice of us continued Montalais he lets us see it easily enough and if we happen to be the object he covets he knows very well how to gain his object You see then Louise that in such circumstances between young girls exposed to such a danger as the one in question the most perfect confidence should exist in order that those hearts which are not disposed towards melancholy may watch over those likely to become so

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Silence, silence! said La Valliere; some one approaches.
children.prevalue: Silence silence said La Valliere some one approaches

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Some one is approaching fast, in fact, said Montalais; but who can it possibly be? Everybody is away, either at mass with the king, or bathing with Monsieur.
children.prevalue: Some one is approaching fast in fact said Montalais but who can it possibly be Everybody is away either at mass with the king or bathing with Monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: At the end of the walk the young girls perceived almost immediately, beneath the arching trees, the graceful carriage and noble stature of a young man, who, with his sword under his arm and a cloak thrown across his shoulders, booted and spurred besides, saluted them from the distance with a gentle smile. Raoul! exclaimed Montalais.
children.prevalue: At the end of the walk the young girls perceived almost immediately beneath the arching trees the graceful carriage and noble stature of a young man who with his sword under his arm and a cloak thrown across his shoulders booted and spurred besides saluted them from the distance with a gentle smile Raoul exclaimed Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: M. de Bragelonne! murmured Louise.
children.prevalue: M de Bragelonne murmured Louise

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: A very proper judge to decide upon our difference of opinion, said Montalais.
children.prevalue: A very proper judge to decide upon our difference of opinion said Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Oh! Montalais, Montalais, for pity's sake, exclaimed La Valliere, after having been so cruel, show me a little mercy. These words, uttered with all the fervor of a prayer, effaced all trace of irony, if not from Montalais's heart, at least from her face.
children.prevalue: Oh Montalais Montalais for pity s sake exclaimed La Valliere after having been so cruel show me a little mercy These words uttered with all the fervor of a prayer effaced all trace of irony if not from Montalais s heart at least from her face

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Why, you are as handsome as Amadis, Monsieur de Bragelonne, she cried to Raoul, and armed and booted like him.
children.prevalue: Why you are as handsome as Amadis Monsieur de Bragelonne she cried to Raoul and armed and booted like him

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: A thousand compliments, young ladies, replied Raoul, bowing.
children.prevalue: A thousand compliments young ladies replied Raoul bowing

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: But why, I ask, are you booted in this manner? repeated Montalais, whilst La Valliere, although she looked at Raoul with a surprise equal to that of her companion, nevertheless uttered not a word.
children.prevalue: But why I ask are you booted in this manner repeated Montalais whilst La Valliere although she looked at Raoul with a surprise equal to that of her companion nevertheless uttered not a word

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Why? inquired Raoul.
children.prevalue: Why inquired Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Yes! ventured Louise.
children.prevalue: Yes ventured Louise

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Because I am about to set off, said Bragelonne, looking at Louise.
children.prevalue: Because I am about to set off said Bragelonne looking at Louise

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: The young girl seemed as though smitten by some superstitious feeling of terror, and tottered. You are going away, Raoul! she cried; and where are you going?
children.prevalue: The young girl seemed as though smitten by some superstitious feeling of terror and tottered You are going away Raoul she cried and where are you going

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Dearest Louise, he replied, with that quiet, composed manner which was natural to him, I am going to England.
children.prevalue: Dearest Louise he replied with that quiet composed manner which was natural to him I am going to England

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: What are you going to do in England?
children.prevalue: What are you going to do in England

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The king has sent me there.
children.prevalue: The king has sent me there

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: The king! exclaimed Louise and Aure together, involuntarily exchanging glances, the conversation which had just been interrupted recurring to them both. Raoul intercepted the glance, but could not understand its meaning, and, naturally enough, attributed it to the interest both the young girls took in him.
children.prevalue: The king exclaimed Louise and Aure together involuntarily exchanging glances the conversation which had just been interrupted recurring to them both Raoul intercepted the glance but could not understand its meaning and naturally enough attributed it to the interest both the young girls took in him

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: His majesty, he said, has been good enough to remember that the Comte de la Fere is high in favor with King Charles II. This morning, as he was on his way to attend mass, the king, seeing me as he passed, signed to me to approach, which I accordingly did. 'Monsieur de Bragelonne,' he said to me, 'you will call upon M. Fouquet, who has received from me letters for the king of Great Britain; you will be the bearer of them.' I bowed. 'Ah!' his majesty added, 'before you leave, you will be good enough to take any commissions which Madame may have for the king her brother.'
children.prevalue: His majesty he said has been good enough to remember that the Comte de la Fere is high in favor with King Charles II This morning as he was on his way to attend mass the king seeing me as he passed signed to me to approach which I accordingly did Monsieur de Bragelonne he said to me you will call upon M Fouquet who has received from me letters for the king of Great Britain you will be the bearer of them I bowed Ah his majesty added before you leave you will be good enough to take any commissions which Madame may have for the king her brother

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Gracious heaven! murmured Louise, much agitated, and yet full of thought at the same time.
children.prevalue: Gracious heaven murmured Louise much agitated and yet full of thought at the same time

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: So quickly! You are desired to set off in such haste! said Montalais, almost paralyzed by this unforeseen event.
children.prevalue: So quickly You are desired to set off in such haste said Montalais almost paralyzed by this unforeseen event

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Properly to obey those whom we respect, said Raoul, it is necessary to obey quickly. Within ten minutes after I had received the order, I was ready. Madame, already informed, is writing the letter which she is good enough to do me the honor of intrusting to me. In the meantime, learning from Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente that it was likely you would be in this direction, I came here, and am happy to find you both.
children.prevalue: Properly to obey those whom we respect said Raoul it is necessary to obey quickly Within ten minutes after I had received the order I was ready Madame already informed is writing the letter which she is good enough to do me the honor of intrusting to me In the meantime learning from Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente that it was likely you would be in this direction I came here and am happy to find you both

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: And both of us very sad, as you see, said Montalais, going to Louise's assistance, whose countenance was visibly altered.
children.prevalue: And both of us very sad as you see said Montalais going to Louise s assistance whose countenance was visibly altered

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Suffering? responded Raoul, pressing Louise's hand with a tender curiosity. Your hand is like ice.
children.prevalue: Suffering responded Raoul pressing Louise s hand with a tender curiosity Your hand is like ice

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: It is nothing.
children.prevalue: It is nothing

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: This coldness does not reach your heart, Louise, does it? inquired the young man, with a tender smile. Louise raised her head hastily, as if the question had been inspired by some suspicion, and had aroused a feeling of remorse.
children.prevalue: This coldness does not reach your heart Louise does it inquired the young man with a tender smile Louise raised her head hastily as if the question had been inspired by some suspicion and had aroused a feeling of remorse

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Oh! you know, she said, with an effort, that my heart will never be cold towards a friend like yourself, Monsieur de Bragelonne.
children.prevalue: Oh you know she said with an effort that my heart will never be cold towards a friend like yourself Monsieur de Bragelonne

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Thank you, Louise. I know both your heart and your mind; it is not by the touch of the hand that one can judge of an affection like yours. You know, Louise, how devotedly I love you, with what perfect and unreserved confidence I reserve my life for you; will you not forgive me, then, for speaking to you with something like the frankness of a child?
children.prevalue: Thank you Louise I know both your heart and your mind it is not by the touch of the hand that one can judge of an affection like yours You know Louise how devotedly I love you with what perfect and unreserved confidence I reserve my life for you will you not forgive me then for speaking to you with something like the frankness of a child

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Speak, Monsieur Raoul, said Louise, trembling painfully, I am listening.
children.prevalue: Speak Monsieur Raoul said Louise trembling painfully I am listening

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: I cannot part from you, carrying away with me a thought that tortures me; absurd I know it to be, and yet one which rends my very heart.
children.prevalue: I cannot part from you carrying away with me a thought that tortures me absurd I know it to be and yet one which rends my very heart

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Are you going away, then, for any length of time? inquired La Valliere, with faltering utterance, while Montalais turned her head aside.
children.prevalue: Are you going away then for any length of time inquired La Valliere with faltering utterance while Montalais turned her head aside

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: No; probably I shall not be absent more than a fortnight. La Valliere pressed her hand upon her heart, which felt as though it were breaking.
children.prevalue: No probably I shall not be absent more than a fortnight La Valliere pressed her hand upon her heart which felt as though it were breaking

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: It is strange, pursued Raoul, looking at the young girl with a melancholy expression; I have often left you when setting off on adventures fraught with danger. Then I started joyously enoughmy heart free, my mind intoxicated by thoughts of happiness in store for me, hopes of which the future was full; and yet I was about to face the Spanish cannon, or the halberds of the Walloons. Today, without the existence of any danger or uneasiness, and by the sunniest path in the world, I am going in search of a glorious recompense, which this mark of the king's favor seems to indicate, for I am, perhaps, going to win you, Louise. What other favor, more precious than yourself, could the king confer upon me? Yet, Louise, in very truth I know not how or why, but this happiness and this future seem to vanish before my very eyes like mistlike an idle dream; and I feel here, here at the very bottom of my heart, a deepseated grief, a dejection I cannot overcome something heavy, passionless, deathlike,resembling a corpse. Oh! Louise, too well do I know why; it is because I have never loved you so truly as now. God help me!
children.prevalue: It is strange pursued Raoul looking at the young girl with a melancholy expression I have often left you when setting off on adventures fraught with danger Then I started joyously enoughmy heart free my mind intoxicated by thoughts of happiness in store for me hopes of which the future was full and yet I was about to face the Spanish cannon or the halberds of the Walloons Today without the existence of any danger or uneasiness and by the sunniest path in the world I am going in search of a glorious recompense which this mark of the king s favor seems to indicate for I am perhaps going to win you Louise What other favor more precious than yourself could the king confer upon me Yet Louise in very truth I know not how or why but this happiness and this future seem to vanish before my very eyes like mistlike an idle dream and I feel here here at the very bottom of my heart a deepseated grief a dejection I cannot overcome something heavy passionless deathlike resembling a corpse Oh Louise too well do I know why it is because I have never loved you so truly as now God help me

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: At this last exclamation, which issued as it were from a broken heart, Louise burst into tears, and threw herself into Montalais's arms. The latter, although she was not easily moved, felt the tears rush to her eyes. Raoul noted only the tears Louise shed; his look, however, did not penetratenay, sought not to penetratebeyond those tears. He bent his knee before her, and tenderly kissed her hand; and it was evident that in that kiss he poured out his whole heart.
children.prevalue: At this last exclamation which issued as it were from a broken heart Louise burst into tears and threw herself into Montalais s arms The latter although she was not easily moved felt the tears rush to her eyes Raoul noted only the tears Louise shed his look however did not penetratenay sought not to penetratebeyond those tears He bent his knee before her and tenderly kissed her hand and it was evident that in that kiss he poured out his whole heart

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Rise, rise, said Montalais to him, ready to cry, for Athenais is coming.
children.prevalue: Rise rise said Montalais to him ready to cry for Athenais is coming

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Raoul rose, brushed his knee with the back of his hand, smiled again upon Louise, whose eyes were fixed on the ground, and, having pressed Montalais's hand gratefully, he turned round to salute Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, the sound of whose silken robe was already heard upon the gravel walk. Has Madame finished her letter? he inquired, when the young girl came within reach of his voice.
children.prevalue: Raoul rose brushed his knee with the back of his hand smiled again upon Louise whose eyes were fixed on the ground and having pressed Montalais s hand gratefully he turned round to salute Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente the sound of whose silken robe was already heard upon the gravel walk Has Madame finished her letter he inquired when the young girl came within reach of his voice

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Yes, the letter is finished, sealed, and her royal highness is ready to receive you.
children.prevalue: Yes the letter is finished sealed and her royal highness is ready to receive you

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Raoul, at this remark, hardly gave himself time to salute Athenais, cast one look at Louise, bowed to Montalais, and withdrew in the direction of the chateau. As he withdrew he again turned round, but at last, at the end of the grand walk, it was useless to do so again, as he could no longer see them. The three young girls, on their side, had, with widely different feelings, watched him disappear.
children.prevalue: Raoul at this remark hardly gave himself time to salute Athenais cast one look at Louise bowed to Montalais and withdrew in the direction of the chateau As he withdrew he again turned round but at last at the end of the grand walk it was useless to do so again as he could no longer see them The three young girls on their side had with widely different feelings watched him disappear

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: At last, said Athenais, the first to interrupt the silence, at last we are alone, free to talk of yesterday's great affair, and to come to an understanding upon the conduct it is advisable for us to pursue. Besides, if you will listen to me, she continued, looking round on all sides, I will explain to you, as briefly as possible, in the first place, our own duty, such as I imagine it to be, and, if you do not understand a hint, what is Madame's desire on the subject. And Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente pronounced these words in such a tone as to leave no doubt, in her companion's minds, upon the official character with which she was invested.
children.prevalue: At last said Athenais the first to interrupt the silence at last we are alone free to talk of yesterday s great affair and to come to an understanding upon the conduct it is advisable for us to pursue Besides if you will listen to me she continued looking round on all sides I will explain to you as briefly as possible in the first place our own duty such as I imagine it to be and if you do not understand a hint what is Madame s desire on the subject And Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente pronounced these words in such a tone as to leave no doubt in her companion s minds upon the official character with which she was invested

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Madame's desire! exclaimed Montalais and La Valliere together.
children.prevalue: Madame s desire exclaimed Montalais and La Valliere together

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Her ultimatum, replied Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, diplomatically.
children.prevalue: Her ultimatum replied Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente diplomatically

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: But, murmured La Valliere, does Madame know, then
children.prevalue: But murmured La Valliere does Madame know then

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Madame knows more about the matter than we said, even, said Athenais, in a formal, precise manner. Therefore let us come to a proper understanding.
children.prevalue: Madame knows more about the matter than we said even said Athenais in a formal precise manner Therefore let us come to a proper understanding

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Yes, indeed, said Montalais, and I am listening in breathless attention.
children.prevalue: Yes indeed said Montalais and I am listening in breathless attention

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Gracious heavens! murmured Louise, trembling, shall I ever survive this cruel evening?
children.prevalue: Gracious heavens murmured Louise trembling shall I ever survive this cruel evening

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Oh! do not frighten yourself in that manner, said Athenais; we have found a remedy. So, seating herself between her two companions, and taking each of them by the hand, which she held in her own, she began. The first words were hardly spoke, when they heard a horse galloping away over the stones of the public highroad, outside the gates of the chateau.
children.prevalue: Oh do not frighten yourself in that manner said Athenais we have found a remedy So seating herself between her two companions and taking each of them by the hand which she held in her own she began The first words were hardly spoke when they heard a horse galloping away over the stones of the public highroad outside the gates of the chateau

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: At the very moment he was about entering the chateau, Bragelonne met De Guiche. But before having been met by Raoul, De Guiche had met Manicamp, who had met Malicorne. How was it that Malicorne had met Manicamp? Nothing more simple, for he had awaited his return from mass, where he had accompanied M. de SaintAignan. When they met, they congratulated each other upon their good fortune, and Manicamp availed himself of the circumstance to ask his friend if he had not a few crowns still remaining at the bottom of his pocket. The latter, without expressing any surprise at the question, which he perhaps expected, answered that every pocket which is always being drawn upon without anything ever being put in it, resembles those wells which supply water during the winter, but which gardeners render useless by exhausting during the summer; that his, Malicorne's, pocket certainly was deep, and that there would be a pleasure in drawing on it in times of plenty, but that, unhappily, abuse had produced barrenness. To this remark, Manicamp, deep in thought, had replied, Quite true!
children.prevalue: At the very moment he was about entering the chateau Bragelonne met De Guiche But before having been met by Raoul De Guiche had met Manicamp who had met Malicorne How was it that Malicorne had met Manicamp Nothing more simple for he had awaited his return from mass where he had accompanied M de SaintAignan When they met they congratulated each other upon their good fortune and Manicamp availed himself of the circumstance to ask his friend if he had not a few crowns still remaining at the bottom of his pocket The latter without expressing any surprise at the question which he perhaps expected answered that every pocket which is always being drawn upon without anything ever being put in it resembles those wells which supply water during the winter but which gardeners render useless by exhausting during the summer that his Malicorne s pocket certainly was deep and that there would be a pleasure in drawing on it in times of plenty but that unhappily abuse had produced barrenness To this remark Manicamp deep in thought had replied Quite true

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The question, then, is how to fill it? Malicorne added.
children.prevalue: The question then is how to fill it Malicorne added

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Of course; but in what way?
children.prevalue: Of course but in what way

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Nothing easier, my dear Monsieur Manicamp.
children.prevalue: Nothing easier my dear Monsieur Manicamp

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: So much the better. How?
children.prevalue: So much the better How

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: A post in Monsieur's household, and the pocket is full again.
children.prevalue: A post in Monsieur s household and the pocket is full again

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: You have the post?
children.prevalue: You have the post

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: That is, I have the promise of being nominated.
children.prevalue: That is I have the promise of being nominated

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Well!
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Yes; but the promise of nomination, without the post itself, is like a purse with no money in it.
children.prevalue: Yes but the promise of nomination without the post itself is like a purse with no money in it

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Quite true, Manicamp replied a second time.
children.prevalue: Quite true Manicamp replied a second time

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Let us try for the post, then, the candidate had persisted.
children.prevalue: Let us try for the post then the candidate had persisted

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: My dear fellow, sighed Manicamp, an appointment in his royal highness's household is one of the gravest difficulties of our position.
children.prevalue: My dear fellow sighed Manicamp an appointment in his royal highness s household is one of the gravest difficulties of our position

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Oh! oh!
children.prevalue: Oh oh

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: There is no question that, at the present moment, we cannot ask Monsieur for anything.
children.prevalue: There is no question that at the present moment we cannot ask Monsieur for anything

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Why so? Because we are not on good terms with him.
children.prevalue: Why so Because we are not on good terms with him

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: A great absurdity, too, said Malicorne, promptly.
children.prevalue: A great absurdity too said Malicorne promptly

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Bah! and if we were to show Madame any attention, said Manicamp, frankly speaking, do you think we should please Monsieur?
children.prevalue: Bah and if we were to show Madame any attention said Manicamp frankly speaking do you think we should please Monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Precisely; if we show Madame any attention, and do it adroitly, Monsieur ought to adore us.
children.prevalue: Precisely if we show Madame any attention and do it adroitly Monsieur ought to adore us

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Hum!
children.prevalue: Hum

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Either that or we are great fools. Make haste, therefore, M. Manicamp, you who are so able a politician, and make M. de Guiche and his royal highness friendly again.
children.prevalue: Either that or we are great fools Make haste therefore M Manicamp you who are so able a politician and make M de Guiche and his royal highness friendly again

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Tell me, what did M. de SaintAignan tell you, Malicorne?
children.prevalue: Tell me what did M de SaintAignan tell you Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Tell me? nothing; he asked me several questions, and that was all.
children.prevalue: Tell me nothing he asked me several questions and that was all

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Well, was he less discreet, then, with me.
children.prevalue: Well was he less discreet then with me

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: What did he tell you?
children.prevalue: What did he tell you

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: That the king is passionately in love with Mademoiselle de la Valliere.
children.prevalue: That the king is passionately in love with Mademoiselle de la Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: We knew that already, replied Malicorne, ironically; and everybody talks about it loud enough for all to know it; but in the meantime, do what I advise you; speak to M. de Guiche, and endeavor to get him to make advances to Monsieur. Deuce take it! he owes his royal highness that, at least.
children.prevalue: We knew that already replied Malicorne ironically and everybody talks about it loud enough for all to know it but in the meantime do what I advise you speak to M de Guiche and endeavor to get him to make advances to Monsieur Deuce take it he owes his royal highness that at least

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: But we must see De Guiche, then?
children.prevalue: But we must see De Guiche then

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: There does not seem to be any great difficulty in that; try to see him in the same way I tried to see you; wait for him; you know that he is naturally very fond of walking.
children.prevalue: There does not seem to be any great difficulty in that try to see him in the same way I tried to see you wait for him you know that he is naturally very fond of walking

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Yes; but whereabouts does he walk?
children.prevalue: Yes but whereabouts does he walk

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: What a question to ask! Do you not know that he is in love with Madame?
children.prevalue: What a question to ask Do you not know that he is in love with Madame

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: So it is said.
children.prevalue: So it is said

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Very well; you will find him walking about on the side of the chateau where her apartments are.
children.prevalue: Very well you will find him walking about on the side of the chateau where her apartments are

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Stay, my dear Malicorne, you were not mistaken, for here he is coming.
children.prevalue: Stay my dear Malicorne you were not mistaken for here he is coming

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Why should I be mistaken? Have you ever noticed that I am in the habit of making a mistake? Come, we only need to understand each other. Are you in want of money?
children.prevalue: Why should I be mistaken Have you ever noticed that I am in the habit of making a mistake Come we only need to understand each other Are you in want of money

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Ah! exclaimed Manicamp, mournfully.
children.prevalue: Ah exclaimed Manicamp mournfully

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Well, I want my appointment. Let Malicorne have the appointment, and Manicamp shall have the money. There is no greater difficulty in the way than that.
children.prevalue: Well I want my appointment Let Malicorne have the appointment and Manicamp shall have the money There is no greater difficulty in the way than that

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Very well; in that case make yourself easy. I will do my best.
children.prevalue: Very well in that case make yourself easy I will do my best

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Do.
children.prevalue: Do

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: De Guiche approached, Malicorne stepped aside, and Manicamp caught hold of De Guiche, who was thoughtful and melancholy. Tell me, my dear comte, what rhyme you were trying to find, said Manicamp. I have an excellent one to match yours, particularly if yours ends in ame.
children.prevalue: De Guiche approached Malicorne stepped aside and Manicamp caught hold of De Guiche who was thoughtful and melancholy Tell me my dear comte what rhyme you were trying to find said Manicamp I have an excellent one to match yours particularly if yours ends in ame

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: De Guiche shook his head, and recognizing a friend, he took him by the arm. My dear Manicamp, he said, I am in search of something very different from a rhyme.
children.prevalue: De Guiche shook his head and recognizing a friend he took him by the arm My dear Manicamp he said I am in search of something very different from a rhyme

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: What is it you are looking for?
children.prevalue: What is it you are looking for

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: You will help me to find what I am in search of, continued the comte: you who are such an idle fellow, in other words, a man with a mind full of ingenious devices.
children.prevalue: You will help me to find what I am in search of continued the comte you who are such an idle fellow in other words a man with a mind full of ingenious devices

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: I am getting my ingenuity ready, then, my dear comte.
children.prevalue: I am getting my ingenuity ready then my dear comte

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: This is the state of the case, then: I wish to approach a particular house, where I have some business.
children.prevalue: This is the state of the case then I wish to approach a particular house where I have some business

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: You must get near the house, then, said Manicamp.
children.prevalue: You must get near the house then said Manicamp

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Very good; but in this house dwells a husband who happens to be jealous.
children.prevalue: Very good but in this house dwells a husband who happens to be jealous

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Is he more jealous than the dog Cerberus?
children.prevalue: Is he more jealous than the dog Cerberus

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Not more, but quite as much so.
children.prevalue: Not more but quite as much so

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Has he three mouths, as that obdurate guardian of the infernal regions had? Do not shrug your shoulders, my dear comte: I put the question to you with an excellent reason, since poets pretend that, in order to soften Monsieur Cerberus, the visitor must take something enticing with hima cake, for instance. Therefore, I, who view the matter in a prosaic light, that is to say in the light of reality, I say: one cake is very little for three mouths. If your jealous husband has three mouths, comte, get three cakes.
children.prevalue: Has he three mouths as that obdurate guardian of the infernal regions had Do not shrug your shoulders my dear comte I put the question to you with an excellent reason since poets pretend that in order to soften Monsieur Cerberus the visitor must take something enticing with hima cake for instance Therefore I who view the matter in a prosaic light that is to say in the light of reality I say one cake is very little for three mouths If your jealous husband has three mouths comte get three cakes

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Manicamp, I can get such advice as that from M. de Beautru.
children.prevalue: Manicamp I can get such advice as that from M de Beautru

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: In order to get better advice, said Manicamp, with a comical seriousness of expression, you will be obliged to adopt a more precise formula than you have used towards me.
children.prevalue: In order to get better advice said Manicamp with a comical seriousness of expression you will be obliged to adopt a more precise formula than you have used towards me

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: If Raoul were here, said De Guiche, he would be sure to understand me.
children.prevalue: If Raoul were here said De Guiche he would be sure to understand me

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: So I think, particularly if you said to him: 'I should very much like to see Madame a little nearer, but I fear Monsieur, because he is jealous.'
children.prevalue: So I think particularly if you said to him I should very much like to see Madame a little nearer but I fear Monsieur because he is jealous

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Manicamp! cried the comte, angrily, and endeavoring to overwhelm his tormentor by a look, who did not, however, appear to be in the slightest degree disturbed by it.
children.prevalue: Manicamp cried the comte angrily and endeavoring to overwhelm his tormentor by a look who did not however appear to be in the slightest degree disturbed by it

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: What is the matter now, my dear comte? inquired Manicamp.
children.prevalue: What is the matter now my dear comte inquired Manicamp

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: What! is it thus you blaspheme the most sacred of names?
children.prevalue: What is it thus you blaspheme the most sacred of names

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: What names?
children.prevalue: What names

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Monsieur! Madame! the highest names in the kingdom.
children.prevalue: Monsieur Madame the highest names in the kingdom

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: You are very strangely mistaken, my dear comte. I never mentioned the highest names in the kingdom. I merely answered you in reference to the subject of a jealous husband, whose name you did not tell me, and who, as a matter of course, has a wife. I therefore replied to you, in order to see Madame, you must get a little more intimate with Monsieur.
children.prevalue: You are very strangely mistaken my dear comte I never mentioned the highest names in the kingdom I merely answered you in reference to the subject of a jealous husband whose name you did not tell me and who as a matter of course has a wife I therefore replied to you in order to see Madame you must get a little more intimate with Monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Doubledealer that you are, said the comte, smiling; was that what you said?
children.prevalue: Doubledealer that you are said the comte smiling was that what you said

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Nothing else.
children.prevalue: Nothing else

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Very good; what then?
children.prevalue: Very good what then

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Now, added Manicamp, let the question be regarding the Duchessor the Duke; very well, I shall say: Let us get into the house in some way or other, for that is a tactic which cannot in any case be unfavorable to your love affair.
children.prevalue: Now added Manicamp let the question be regarding the Duchessor the Duke very well I shall say Let us get into the house in some way or other for that is a tactic which cannot in any case be unfavorable to your love affair

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Ah! Manicamp, if you could but find me a pretext, a good pretext.
children.prevalue: Ah Manicamp if you could but find me a pretext a good pretext

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: A pretext; I can find you a hundred, nay, a thousand. If Malicorne were here, he would have already hit upon a thousand excellent pretexts.
children.prevalue: A pretext I can find you a hundred nay a thousand If Malicorne were here he would have already hit upon a thousand excellent pretexts

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Who is Malicorne? replied De Guiche, halfshutting his eyes, like a person reflecting, I seem to know the name.
children.prevalue: Who is Malicorne replied De Guiche halfshutting his eyes like a person reflecting I seem to know the name

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Know him! I should think so: you owe his father thirty thousand crowns.
children.prevalue: Know him I should think so you owe his father thirty thousand crowns

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Ah, indeed! so it's that worthy fellow from Orleans.
children.prevalue: Ah indeed so it s that worthy fellow from Orleans

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Whom you promised an appointment in Monsieur's household; not the jealous husband, but the other.
children.prevalue: Whom you promised an appointment in Monsieur s household not the jealous husband but the other

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Well, then, since your friend Malicorne is such an inventive genius, let him find me a means of being adored by Monsieur, and a pretext to make my peace with him.
children.prevalue: Well then since your friend Malicorne is such an inventive genius let him find me a means of being adored by Monsieur and a pretext to make my peace with him

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Very good: I'll talk to him about it.
children.prevalue: Very good I ll talk to him about it

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: But who is that coming?
children.prevalue: But who is that coming

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: The Vicomte de Bragelonne.
children.prevalue: The Vicomte de Bragelonne

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Raoul! yes, it is he, said De Guiche, as he hastened forward to meet him. You here, Raoul? said De Guiche.
children.prevalue: Raoul yes it is he said De Guiche as he hastened forward to meet him You here Raoul said De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Yes: I was looking for you to say farewell, replied Raoul, warmly, pressing the comte's hand. How do you do, Monsieur Manicamp?
children.prevalue: Yes I was looking for you to say farewell replied Raoul warmly pressing the comte s hand How do you do Monsieur Manicamp

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: How is this, vicomte, you are leaving us?
children.prevalue: How is this vicomte you are leaving us

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Yes, a mission from the king.
children.prevalue: Yes a mission from the king

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Where are you going?
children.prevalue: Where are you going

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: To London. On leaving you, I am going to Madame; she has a letter to give me for his majesty, Charles II.
children.prevalue: To London On leaving you I am going to Madame she has a letter to give me for his majesty Charles II

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: You will find her alone, for Monsieur has gone out; gone to bathe, in fact.
children.prevalue: You will find her alone for Monsieur has gone out gone to bathe in fact

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: In that case, you, who are one of Monsieur's gentlemen in waiting, will undertake to make my excuses to him. I would have waited in order to receive any directions he might have to give me, if the desire for my immediate departure had not been intimated to me by M. Fouquet on behalf of his majesty.
children.prevalue: In that case you who are one of Monsieur s gentlemen in waiting will undertake to make my excuses to him I would have waited in order to receive any directions he might have to give me if the desire for my immediate departure had not been intimated to me by M Fouquet on behalf of his majesty

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Manicamp touched De Guiche's elbow, saying, There's a pretext for you.
children.prevalue: Manicamp touched De Guiche s elbow saying There s a pretext for you

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: What?
children.prevalue: What

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: M. de Bragelonne's excuses.
children.prevalue: M de Bragelonne s excuses

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: A weak pretext, said De Guiche.
children.prevalue: A weak pretext said De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: An excellent one, if Monsieur is not angry with you; but a paltry one if he bears you illwill.
children.prevalue: An excellent one if Monsieur is not angry with you but a paltry one if he bears you illwill

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: You are right, Manicamp; a pretext, however poor it may be, is all I require. And so, a pleasant journey to you, Raoul! And the two friends took a warm leave of each other.
children.prevalue: You are right Manicamp a pretext however poor it may be is all I require And so a pleasant journey to you Raoul And the two friends took a warm leave of each other

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Five minutes afterwards Raoul entered Madame's apartments, as Mademoiselle de Montalais had begged him to do. Madame was still seated at the table where she had written her letter. Before her was still burning the rosecolored taper she had used to seal it. Only in her deep reflection, for Madame seemed to be buried in thought, she had forgotten to extinguish the light. Bragelonne was a very model of elegance in every way; it was impossible to see him once without always remembering him; and not only had Madame seen him once, but it will not be forgotten he was one of the very first who had gone to meet her, and had accompanied her from Le Havre to Paris. Madame preserved therefore an excellent recollection of him.
children.prevalue: Five minutes afterwards Raoul entered Madame s apartments as Mademoiselle de Montalais had begged him to do Madame was still seated at the table where she had written her letter Before her was still burning the rosecolored taper she had used to seal it Only in her deep reflection for Madame seemed to be buried in thought she had forgotten to extinguish the light Bragelonne was a very model of elegance in every way it was impossible to see him once without always remembering him and not only had Madame seen him once but it will not be forgotten he was one of the very first who had gone to meet her and had accompanied her from Le Havre to Paris Madame preserved therefore an excellent recollection of him

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Ah! M. de Bragelonne, she said to him, you are going to see my brother, who will be delighted to pay to the son a portion of the debt of gratitude he contracted with the father.
children.prevalue: Ah M de Bragelonne she said to him you are going to see my brother who will be delighted to pay to the son a portion of the debt of gratitude he contracted with the father

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: The Comte de la Fere, Madame, has been abundantly recompensed for the little service he had the happiness to render the king, by the kindness manifested towards him, and it is I who will have to convey to his majesty the assurance of the respect, devotion, and gratitude of both father and son.
children.prevalue: The Comte de la Fere Madame has been abundantly recompensed for the little service he had the happiness to render the king by the kindness manifested towards him and it is I who will have to convey to his majesty the assurance of the respect devotion and gratitude of both father and son

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Do you know my brother?
children.prevalue: Do you know my brother

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: No, your highness; I shall have the honor of seeing his majesty for the first time.
children.prevalue: No your highness I shall have the honor of seeing his majesty for the first time

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: You require no recommendation to him. At all events, however, if you have any doubt about your personal merit, take me unhesitatingly for your surety.
children.prevalue: You require no recommendation to him At all events however if you have any doubt about your personal merit take me unhesitatingly for your surety

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Your royal highness overwhelms me with kindness.
children.prevalue: Your royal highness overwhelms me with kindness

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: No! M. de Bragelonne, I well remember that we were fellowtravelers once, and that I remarked your extreme prudence in the midst of the extravagant absurdities committed, on both sides, by two of the greatest simpletons in the world,M. de Guiche and the Duke of Buckingham. Let us not speak of them, however; but of yourself. Are you going to England to remain there permanently? Forgive my inquiry: it is not curiosity, but a desire to be of service to you in anything I can.
children.prevalue: No M de Bragelonne I well remember that we were fellowtravelers once and that I remarked your extreme prudence in the midst of the extravagant absurdities committed on both sides by two of the greatest simpletons in the world M de Guiche and the Duke of Buckingham Let us not speak of them however but of yourself Are you going to England to remain there permanently Forgive my inquiry it is not curiosity but a desire to be of service to you in anything I can

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: No, Madame; I am going to England to fulfil a mission which his majesty has been kind enough to confide to menothing more.
children.prevalue: No Madame I am going to England to fulfil a mission which his majesty has been kind enough to confide to menothing more

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: And you propose to return to France?
children.prevalue: And you propose to return to France

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: As soon as I have accomplished my mission; unless, indeed, his majesty, King Charles II., should have other orders for me.
children.prevalue: As soon as I have accomplished my mission unless indeed his majesty King Charles II should have other orders for me

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: He well beg you, at the very least, I am sure, to remain near him as long as possible.
children.prevalue: He well beg you at the very least I am sure to remain near him as long as possible

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: In that case, as I shall not know how to refuse, I will now beforehand entreat your royal highness to have the goodness to remind the king of France that one of his devoted servants is far away from him.
children.prevalue: In that case as I shall not know how to refuse I will now beforehand entreat your royal highness to have the goodness to remind the king of France that one of his devoted servants is far away from him

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Take care that when you are recalled, you do not consider his command an abuse of power.
children.prevalue: Take care that when you are recalled you do not consider his command an abuse of power

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: I do not understand you, Madame.
children.prevalue: I do not understand you Madame

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: The court of France is not easily matched, I am aware, but yet we have some pretty women at the court of England also.
children.prevalue: The court of France is not easily matched I am aware but yet we have some pretty women at the court of England also

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Raoul smiled.
children.prevalue: Raoul smiled

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Oh! said Madame, yours is a smile which portends no good to my countrywomen. It is as though you were telling them, Monsieur de Bragelonne: 'I visit you, but I leave my heart on the other side of the Channel.' Did not your smile indicate that?
children.prevalue: Oh said Madame yours is a smile which portends no good to my countrywomen It is as though you were telling them Monsieur de Bragelonne I visit you but I leave my heart on the other side of the Channel Did not your smile indicate that

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Your highness is gifted with the power of reading the inmost depths of the soul, and you will understand, therefore, why, at present, any prolonged residence at the court of England would be a matter of the deepest regret.
children.prevalue: Your highness is gifted with the power of reading the inmost depths of the soul and you will understand therefore why at present any prolonged residence at the court of England would be a matter of the deepest regret

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: And I need not inquire if so gallant a knight is recompensed in return?
