children.prevalue: And I need not inquire if so gallant a knight is recompensed in return

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: I have been brought up, Madame, with her whom I love, and I believe our affection is mutual.
children.prevalue: I have been brought up Madame with her whom I love and I believe our affection is mutual

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: In that case, do not delay your departure, Monsieur de Bragelonne, and delay not your return, for on your return we shall see two persons happy; for I hope no obstacle exists to your felicity.
children.prevalue: In that case do not delay your departure Monsieur de Bragelonne and delay not your return for on your return we shall see two persons happy for I hope no obstacle exists to your felicity

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: There is a great obstacle, Madame.
children.prevalue: There is a great obstacle Madame

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Indeed! what is it?
children.prevalue: Indeed what is it

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: The king's wishes on the subject.
children.prevalue: The king s wishes on the subject

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: The king opposes your marriage?
children.prevalue: The king opposes your marriage

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: He postpones it, at least. I solicited his majesty's consent through the Comte de la Fere, and, without absolutely refusing it, he positively said it must be deferred.
children.prevalue: He postpones it at least I solicited his majesty s consent through the Comte de la Fere and without absolutely refusing it he positively said it must be deferred

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Is the young lady whom you love unworthy of you, then?
children.prevalue: Is the young lady whom you love unworthy of you then

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: She is worthy of a king's affection, Madame.
children.prevalue: She is worthy of a king s affection Madame

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: I mean, she is not, perhaps, of birth equal to your own.
children.prevalue: I mean she is not perhaps of birth equal to your own

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Her family is excellent.
children.prevalue: Her family is excellent

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Is she young, beautiful?
children.prevalue: Is she young beautiful

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: She is seventeen, and, in my opinion, exceedingly beautiful.
children.prevalue: She is seventeen and in my opinion exceedingly beautiful

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: Is she in the country, or at Paris?
children.prevalue: Is she in the country or at Paris

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: She is here at Fontainebleau, Madame.
children.prevalue: She is here at Fontainebleau Madame

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: At the court?
children.prevalue: At the court

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: Do I know her?
children.prevalue: Do I know her

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: She has the honor to form one of your highness's household.
children.prevalue: She has the honor to form one of your highness s household

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Her name? inquired the princess, anxiously; if indeed, she added, hastily, her name is not a secret.
children.prevalue: Her name inquired the princess anxiously if indeed she added hastily her name is not a secret

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: No, Madame, my affection is too pure for me to make a secret of it to any one, and with still greater reason to your royal highness, whose kindness towards me has been so extreme. It is Mademoiselle Louise de la Valliere.
children.prevalue: No Madame my affection is too pure for me to make a secret of it to any one and with still greater reason to your royal highness whose kindness towards me has been so extreme It is Mademoiselle Louise de la Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: Madame could not restrain an exclamation, in which a feeling stronger than surprise might have been detected. Ah! she said, La Valliereshe who yesterday she paused, and then continued, she who was taken ill, I believe.
children.prevalue: Madame could not restrain an exclamation in which a feeling stronger than surprise might have been detected Ah she said La Valliereshe who yesterday she paused and then continued she who was taken ill I believe

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: Yes, Madame; it was only this morning that I heard of the accident that had befallen her.
children.prevalue: Yes Madame it was only this morning that I heard of the accident that had befallen her

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: Did you see her before you came to me?
children.prevalue: Did you see her before you came to me

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: I had the honor of taking leave of her.
children.prevalue: I had the honor of taking leave of her

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: And you say, resumed Madame, making a powerful effort over herself, that the king hasdeferred your marriage with this young girl.
children.prevalue: And you say resumed Madame making a powerful effort over herself that the king hasdeferred your marriage with this young girl

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: Yes, Madame, deferred it.
children.prevalue: Yes Madame deferred it

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: Did he assign any reason for this postponement?
children.prevalue: Did he assign any reason for this postponement

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: None.
children.prevalue: None

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: How long is it since the Comte de la Fere preferred his request to the king?
children.prevalue: How long is it since the Comte de la Fere preferred his request to the king

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: More than a month, Madame.
children.prevalue: More than a month Madame

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: It is very singular, said the princess, as something like a film clouded her eyes.
children.prevalue: It is very singular said the princess as something like a film clouded her eyes

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: A month? she repeated.
children.prevalue: A month she repeated

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: About a month.
children.prevalue: About a month

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: You are right, vicomte, said the princess, with a smile, in which De Bragelonne might have remarked a kind of restraint; my brother must not keep you too long in England; set off at once, and in the first letter I write to England, I will claim you in the king's name. And Madame rose to place her letter in Bragelonne's hands. Raoul understood that his audience was at an end; he took the letter, bowed lowly to the princess, and left the room.
children.prevalue: You are right vicomte said the princess with a smile in which De Bragelonne might have remarked a kind of restraint my brother must not keep you too long in England set off at once and in the first letter I write to England I will claim you in the king s name And Madame rose to place her letter in Bragelonne s hands Raoul understood that his audience was at an end he took the letter bowed lowly to the princess and left the room

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: A month! murmured the princess; could I have been blind, then, to so great an extent, and could he have loved her for this last month? And as Madame had nothing to do, she sat down to begin a letter to her brother, the postscript of which was a summons for Bragelonne to return.
children.prevalue: A month murmured the princess could I have been blind then to so great an extent and could he have loved her for this last month And as Madame had nothing to do she sat down to begin a letter to her brother the postscript of which was a summons for Bragelonne to return

children.name: Paragraph_145
children.value: The Comte de Guiche, as we have seen, had yielded to the pressing persuasions of Manicamp, and allowed himself to be led to the stables, where they desired their horses to be got ready for them; then, by one of the side paths, a description of which has already been given, they advanced to meet Monsieur, who, having just finished bathing, was returning towards the chateau, wearing a woman's veil to protect his face from getting burnt by the sun, which was shining very brightly. Monsieur was in one of those fits of good humor to which the admiration of his own good looks sometimes gave occasion. As he was bathing he had been able to compare the whiteness of his body with that of the courtiers, and, thanks to the care which his royal highness took of himself, no one, not even the Chevalier de Lorraine, was able to stand the comparison. Monsieur, moreover, had been tolerably successful in swimming, and his muscles having been exercised by the healthy immersion in the cool water, he was in a light and cheerful state of mind and body. So that, at the sight of Guiche, who advanced to meet him at a hand gallop, mounted upon a magnificent white horse, the prince could not restrain an exclamation of delight.
children.prevalue: The Comte de Guiche as we have seen had yielded to the pressing persuasions of Manicamp and allowed himself to be led to the stables where they desired their horses to be got ready for them then by one of the side paths a description of which has already been given they advanced to meet Monsieur who having just finished bathing was returning towards the chateau wearing a woman s veil to protect his face from getting burnt by the sun which was shining very brightly Monsieur was in one of those fits of good humor to which the admiration of his own good looks sometimes gave occasion As he was bathing he had been able to compare the whiteness of his body with that of the courtiers and thanks to the care which his royal highness took of himself no one not even the Chevalier de Lorraine was able to stand the comparison Monsieur moreover had been tolerably successful in swimming and his muscles having been exercised by the healthy immersion in the cool water he was in a light and cheerful state of mind and body So that at the sight of Guiche who advanced to meet him at a hand gallop mounted upon a magnificent white horse the prince could not restrain an exclamation of delight

children.name: Paragraph_146
children.value: I think matters look well, said Manicamp, who fancied he could read this friendly disposition upon his royal highness's countenance.
children.prevalue: I think matters look well said Manicamp who fancied he could read this friendly disposition upon his royal highness s countenance

children.name: Paragraph_147
children.value: Good day, De Guiche, good day, exclaimed the prince.
children.prevalue: Good day De Guiche good day exclaimed the prince

children.name: Paragraph_148
children.value: Long life to your royal highness! replied De Guiche, encouraged by the tone of Philip's voice; health, joy, happiness, and prosperity to your highness.
children.prevalue: Long life to your royal highness replied De Guiche encouraged by the tone of Philip s voice health joy happiness and prosperity to your highness

children.name: Paragraph_149
children.value: Welcome, De Guiche, come on my right side, but keep your horse in hand, for I wish to return at a walking pace under the cool shade of these trees.
children.prevalue: Welcome De Guiche come on my right side but keep your horse in hand for I wish to return at a walking pace under the cool shade of these trees

children.name: Paragraph_150
children.value: As you please, monseigneur, said De Guiche, taking his place on the prince's right as he had been invited to do.
children.prevalue: As you please monseigneur said De Guiche taking his place on the prince s right as he had been invited to do

children.name: Paragraph_151
children.value: Now, my dear De Guiche, said the prince, give me a little news of that De Guiche whom I used to know formerly, and who used to pay attentions to my wife.
children.prevalue: Now my dear De Guiche said the prince give me a little news of that De Guiche whom I used to know formerly and who used to pay attentions to my wife

children.name: Paragraph_152
children.value: Guiche blushed to the very whites of his eyes, while Monsieur burst out laughing, as though he had made the wittiest remark in the world. The few privileged courtiers who surrounded Monsieur thought it their duty to follow his example, although they had not heard the remark, and a noisy burst of laughter immediately followed, beginning with the first courtier, passing on through the whole company, and only terminating with the last. De Guiche, although blushing scarlet, put a good countenance on the matter; Manicamp looked at him.
children.prevalue: Guiche blushed to the very whites of his eyes while Monsieur burst out laughing as though he had made the wittiest remark in the world The few privileged courtiers who surrounded Monsieur thought it their duty to follow his example although they had not heard the remark and a noisy burst of laughter immediately followed beginning with the first courtier passing on through the whole company and only terminating with the last De Guiche although blushing scarlet put a good countenance on the matter Manicamp looked at him

children.name: Paragraph_153
children.value: Ah! monseigneur, replied De Guiche, show a little charity towards such a miserable fellow as I am: do not hold me up to the ridicule of the Chevalier de Lorraine.
children.prevalue: Ah monseigneur replied De Guiche show a little charity towards such a miserable fellow as I am do not hold me up to the ridicule of the Chevalier de Lorraine

children.name: Paragraph_154
children.value: How do you mean?
children.prevalue: How do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_155
children.value: If he hears you ridicule me, he will go beyond your highness, and will show no pity.
children.prevalue: If he hears you ridicule me he will go beyond your highness and will show no pity

children.name: Paragraph_156
children.value: About your passion and the princess, do you mean?
children.prevalue: About your passion and the princess do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_157
children.value: For mercy's sake, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: For mercy s sake monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_158
children.value: Come, come, De Guiche, confess that you did get a little sweet upon Madame.
children.prevalue: Come come De Guiche confess that you did get a little sweet upon Madame

children.name: Paragraph_159
children.value: I will never confess such a thing, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: I will never confess such a thing monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_160
children.value: Out of respect for me, I suppose; but I release you from your respect, De Guiche. Confess, as if it were simply a question about Mademoiselle de Chalais or Mademoiselle de la Valliere.
children.prevalue: Out of respect for me I suppose but I release you from your respect De Guiche Confess as if it were simply a question about Mademoiselle de Chalais or Mademoiselle de la Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_161
children.value: Then breaking off, he said, beginning to laugh again, Comte, that wasn't at all bad!a remark like a sword, which cuts two ways at once. I hit you and my brother at the same time, Chalais and La Valliere, your affianced bride and his future lady love.
children.prevalue: Then breaking off he said beginning to laugh again Comte that wasn t at all bad a remark like a sword which cuts two ways at once I hit you and my brother at the same time Chalais and La Valliere your affianced bride and his future lady love

children.name: Paragraph_162
children.value: Really, monseigneur, said the comte, you are in a most brilliant humor today.
children.prevalue: Really monseigneur said the comte you are in a most brilliant humor today

children.name: Paragraph_163
children.value: The fact is, I feel well, and then I am pleased to see you again. But you were angry with me, were you not?
children.prevalue: The fact is I feel well and then I am pleased to see you again But you were angry with me were you not

children.name: Paragraph_164
children.value: I, monseigneur? Why should I have been so?
children.prevalue: I monseigneur Why should I have been so

children.name: Paragraph_165
children.value: Because I interfered with your sarabands and your other Spanish amusements. Nay, do not deny it. On that day you left the princess's apartments with your eyes full of fury; that brought you illluck, for you danced in the ballet yesterday in a most wretched manner. Now don't get sulky, De Guiche, for it does you no good, but makes you look like a tame bear. If the princess did not look at you attentively yesterday, I am quite sure of one thing.
children.prevalue: Because I interfered with your sarabands and your other Spanish amusements Nay do not deny it On that day you left the princess s apartments with your eyes full of fury that brought you illluck for you danced in the ballet yesterday in a most wretched manner Now don t get sulky De Guiche for it does you no good but makes you look like a tame bear If the princess did not look at you attentively yesterday I am quite sure of one thing

children.name: Paragraph_166
children.value: What is that, monseigneur? Your highness alarms me.
children.prevalue: What is that monseigneur Your highness alarms me

children.name: Paragraph_167
children.value: She has quite forsworn you now, said the prince, with a burst of loud laughter.
children.prevalue: She has quite forsworn you now said the prince with a burst of loud laughter

children.name: Paragraph_168
children.value: Decidedly, thought Manicamp, rank has nothing to do with it, and all men are alike.
children.prevalue: Decidedly thought Manicamp rank has nothing to do with it and all men are alike

children.name: Paragraph_169
children.value: The prince continued: At all events, you have now returned, and it is to be hoped that the chevalier will become amiable again.
children.prevalue: The prince continued At all events you have now returned and it is to be hoped that the chevalier will become amiable again

children.name: Paragraph_170
children.value: How so, monseigneur: and by what miracle can I exercise such an influence over M. de Lorraine?
children.prevalue: How so monseigneur and by what miracle can I exercise such an influence over M de Lorraine

children.name: Paragraph_171
children.value: The matter is very simple, he is jealous of you.
children.prevalue: The matter is very simple he is jealous of you

children.name: Paragraph_172
children.value: Bah! it is not possible.
children.prevalue: Bah it is not possible

children.name: Paragraph_173
children.value: It is the case, though.
children.prevalue: It is the case though

children.name: Paragraph_174
children.value: He does me too much honor.
children.prevalue: He does me too much honor

children.name: Paragraph_175
children.value: The fact is, that when you are here, he is full of kindness and attention, but when you are gone he makes me suffer a perfect martyrdom. I am like a seesaw. Besides, you do not know the idea that has struck me?
children.prevalue: The fact is that when you are here he is full of kindness and attention but when you are gone he makes me suffer a perfect martyrdom I am like a seesaw Besides you do not know the idea that has struck me

children.name: Paragraph_176
children.value: I do not even suspect it.
children.prevalue: I do not even suspect it

children.name: Paragraph_177
children.value: Well, then; when you were in exilefor you really were exiled, my poor De Guiche
children.prevalue: Well then when you were in exilefor you really were exiled my poor De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_178
children.value: I should think so, indeed; but whose fault was it? said De Guiche, pretending to speak in an angry tone.
children.prevalue: I should think so indeed but whose fault was it said De Guiche pretending to speak in an angry tone

children.name: Paragraph_179
children.value: Not mine, certainly, my dear comte, replied his royal highness, upon my honor, I did not ask for the king to exile you
children.prevalue: Not mine certainly my dear comte replied his royal highness upon my honor I did not ask for the king to exile you

children.name: Paragraph_180
children.value: No, not you, monseigneur, I am well aware; but
children.prevalue: No not you monseigneur I am well aware but

children.name: Paragraph_181
children.value: But Madame; well, as far as that goes, I do not say it was not the case. Why, what the deuce did you do or say to Madame?
children.prevalue: But Madame well as far as that goes I do not say it was not the case Why what the deuce did you do or say to Madame

children.name: Paragraph_182
children.value: Really, monseigneur
children.prevalue: Really monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_183
children.value: Women, I know, have their grudges, and my wife is not free from caprices of that nature. But if she were the cause of your being exiled I bear you no illwill.
children.prevalue: Women I know have their grudges and my wife is not free from caprices of that nature But if she were the cause of your being exiled I bear you no illwill

children.name: Paragraph_184
children.value: In that case, monseigneur, said De Guiche. I am not altogether unhappy.
children.prevalue: In that case monseigneur said De Guiche I am not altogether unhappy

children.name: Paragraph_185
children.value: Manicamp, who was following closely behind De Guiche and who did not lose a word of what the prince was saying, bent down to his very shoulders over his horse's neck, in order to conceal the laughter he could not repress.
children.prevalue: Manicamp who was following closely behind De Guiche and who did not lose a word of what the prince was saying bent down to his very shoulders over his horse s neck in order to conceal the laughter he could not repress

children.name: Paragraph_186
children.value: Besides, your exile started a project in my head.
children.prevalue: Besides your exile started a project in my head

children.name: Paragraph_187
children.value: Good.
children.prevalue: Good

children.name: Paragraph_188
children.value: When the chevalierfinding you were no longer here, and sure of reigning undisturbedbegan to bully me, I, observing that my wife, in the most perfect contrast to him, was most kind and amiable towards me who had neglected her so much, the idea occurred to me of becoming a model husbanda rarity, a curiosity, at the court; and I had an idea of getting very fond of my wife.
children.prevalue: When the chevalierfinding you were no longer here and sure of reigning undisturbedbegan to bully me I observing that my wife in the most perfect contrast to him was most kind and amiable towards me who had neglected her so much the idea occurred to me of becoming a model husbanda rarity a curiosity at the court and I had an idea of getting very fond of my wife

children.name: Paragraph_189
children.value: De Guiche looked at the prince with a stupefied expression of countenance, which was not assumed.
children.prevalue: De Guiche looked at the prince with a stupefied expression of countenance which was not assumed

children.name: Paragraph_190
children.value: Oh! monseigneur, De Guiche stammered out; surely, that never seriously occurred to you.
children.prevalue: Oh monseigneur De Guiche stammered out surely that never seriously occurred to you

children.name: Paragraph_191
children.value: Indeed it did. I have some property that my brother gave me on my marriage; she has some money of her own, and not a little either, for she gets money from her brother and brotherinlaw of England and France at the same time. Well! we should have left the court. I should have retired to my chateau at VillersCotterets, situated in the middle of a forest, in which we should have led a most sentimental life in the very same spot where my grandfather, Henry IV., sojourned with La Belle Gabrielle. What do you think of that idea, De Guiche?
children.prevalue: Indeed it did I have some property that my brother gave me on my marriage she has some money of her own and not a little either for she gets money from her brother and brotherinlaw of England and France at the same time Well we should have left the court I should have retired to my chateau at VillersCotterets situated in the middle of a forest in which we should have led a most sentimental life in the very same spot where my grandfather Henry IV sojourned with La Belle Gabrielle What do you think of that idea De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_192
children.value: Why, it is enough to make one shiver, monseigneur, replied De Guiche, who shuddered in reality.
children.prevalue: Why it is enough to make one shiver monseigneur replied De Guiche who shuddered in reality

children.name: Paragraph_193
children.value: Ah! I see you would never be able to endure being exiled a second time.
children.prevalue: Ah I see you would never be able to endure being exiled a second time

children.name: Paragraph_194
children.value: I, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: I monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_195
children.value: I will not carry you off with us, as I had first intended.
children.prevalue: I will not carry you off with us as I had first intended

children.name: Paragraph_196
children.value: What, with you, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: What with you monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_197
children.value: Yes; if the idea should occur to me again of taking a dislike to the court.
children.prevalue: Yes if the idea should occur to me again of taking a dislike to the court

children.name: Paragraph_198
children.value: Oh! do not let that make any difference, monseigneur; I would follow your highness to the end of the world.
children.prevalue: Oh do not let that make any difference monseigneur I would follow your highness to the end of the world

children.name: Paragraph_199
children.value: Clumsy fellow that you are! said Manicamp, grumblingly, pushing his horse towards De Guiche, so as almost to unseat him, and then, as he passed close to him, as if he had lost command over the horse, he whispered, For goodness' sake, think what you are saying.
children.prevalue: Clumsy fellow that you are said Manicamp grumblingly pushing his horse towards De Guiche so as almost to unseat him and then as he passed close to him as if he had lost command over the horse he whispered For goodness sake think what you are saying

children.name: Paragraph_200
children.value: Well, it is agreed, then, said the prince; since you are so devoted to me, I shall take you with me.
children.prevalue: Well it is agreed then said the prince since you are so devoted to me I shall take you with me

children.name: Paragraph_201
children.value: Anywhere, monseigneur, replied De Guiche in a joyous tone, whenever you like, and at once, too. Are you ready?
children.prevalue: Anywhere monseigneur replied De Guiche in a joyous tone whenever you like and at once too Are you ready

children.name: Paragraph_202
children.value: And De Guiche, laughingly, gave his horse the rein, and galloped forward a few yards.
children.prevalue: And De Guiche laughingly gave his horse the rein and galloped forward a few yards

children.name: Paragraph_203
children.value: One moment, said the prince. Let us go to the chateau first.
children.prevalue: One moment said the prince Let us go to the chateau first

children.name: Paragraph_204
children.value: What for?
children.prevalue: What for

children.name: Paragraph_205
children.value: Why, to take my wife, of course.
children.prevalue: Why to take my wife of course

children.name: Paragraph_206
children.value: What for? asked De Guiche.
children.prevalue: What for asked De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_207
children.value: Why, since I tell you that it is a project of conjugal affection, it is necessary I should take my wife with me.
children.prevalue: Why since I tell you that it is a project of conjugal affection it is necessary I should take my wife with me

children.name: Paragraph_208
children.value: In that case, monseigneur, replied the comte, I am greatly concerned, but no De Guiche for you.
children.prevalue: In that case monseigneur replied the comte I am greatly concerned but no De Guiche for you

children.name: Paragraph_209
children.value: Bah!
children.prevalue: Bah

children.name: Paragraph_210
children.value: Yes.Why do you take Madame with you?
children.prevalue: Yes Why do you take Madame with you

children.name: Paragraph_211
children.value: Because I begin to fancy I love her, said the prince.
children.prevalue: Because I begin to fancy I love her said the prince

children.name: Paragraph_212
children.value: De Guiche turned slightly pale, but endeavored to preserve his seeming cheerfulness.
children.prevalue: De Guiche turned slightly pale but endeavored to preserve his seeming cheerfulness

children.name: Paragraph_213
children.value: If you love Madame, monseigneur, he said, that ought to be quite enough for you, and you have no further need of your friends.
children.prevalue: If you love Madame monseigneur he said that ought to be quite enough for you and you have no further need of your friends

children.name: Paragraph_214
children.value: Not bad, not bad, murmured Manicamp.
children.prevalue: Not bad not bad murmured Manicamp

children.name: Paragraph_215
children.value: There, your fear of Madame has begun again, replied the prince.
children.prevalue: There your fear of Madame has begun again replied the prince

children.name: Paragraph_216
children.value: Why, monseigneur, I have experienced that to my cost; a woman who was the cause of my being exiled!
children.prevalue: Why monseigneur I have experienced that to my cost a woman who was the cause of my being exiled

children.name: Paragraph_217
children.value: What a revengeful disposition you have, De Guiche, how virulently you bear malice.
children.prevalue: What a revengeful disposition you have De Guiche how virulently you bear malice

children.name: Paragraph_218
children.value: I should like the case to be your own, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: I should like the case to be your own monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_219
children.value: Decidedly, then, that was the reason why you danced so badly yesterday; you wished to revenge yourself, I suppose, by trying to make Madame make a mistake in her dancing; ah! that is very paltry, De Guiche, and I will tell Madame of it.
children.prevalue: Decidedly then that was the reason why you danced so badly yesterday you wished to revenge yourself I suppose by trying to make Madame make a mistake in her dancing ah that is very paltry De Guiche and I will tell Madame of it

children.name: Paragraph_220
children.value: You may tell her whatever you please, monseigneur, for her highness cannot hate me more than she does.
children.prevalue: You may tell her whatever you please monseigneur for her highness cannot hate me more than she does

children.name: Paragraph_221
children.value: Nonsense, you are exaggerating; and this because merely of the fortnight's sojourn in the country she imposed on you.
children.prevalue: Nonsense you are exaggerating and this because merely of the fortnight s sojourn in the country she imposed on you

children.name: Paragraph_222
children.value: Monseigneur, a fortnight is a fortnight; and when the time is passed in getting sick and tired of everything, a fortnight is an eternity.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur a fortnight is a fortnight and when the time is passed in getting sick and tired of everything a fortnight is an eternity

children.name: Paragraph_223
children.value: So that you will not forgive her?
children.prevalue: So that you will not forgive her

children.name: Paragraph_224
children.value: Never!
children.prevalue: Never

children.name: Paragraph_225
children.value: Come, come, De Guiche, be a better disposed fellow than that. I wish to make your peace with her; you will find, in conversing with her, that she has no malice or unkindness in her nature, and that she is very talented.
children.prevalue: Come come De Guiche be a better disposed fellow than that I wish to make your peace with her you will find in conversing with her that she has no malice or unkindness in her nature and that she is very talented

children.name: Paragraph_226
children.value: Monseigneur
children.prevalue: Monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_227
children.value: You will see that she can receive her friends like a princess, and laugh like a citizen's wife; you will see that, when she pleases, she can make the pleasant hours pass like minutes. Come, De Guiche, you must really make up your differences with my wife.
children.prevalue: You will see that she can receive her friends like a princess and laugh like a citizen s wife you will see that when she pleases she can make the pleasant hours pass like minutes Come De Guiche you must really make up your differences with my wife

children.name: Paragraph_228
children.value: Upon my word, said Manicamp to himself, the prince is a husband whose wife's name will bring him illluck, and King Candaules, of old, was a tiger beside his royal highness.
children.prevalue: Upon my word said Manicamp to himself the prince is a husband whose wife s name will bring him illluck and King Candaules of old was a tiger beside his royal highness

children.name: Paragraph_229
children.value: At all events, added the prince, I am sure you will make it up with my wife: I guarantee you will do so. Only, I must show you the way now. There is nothing commonplace about her: it is not every one who takes her fancy.
children.prevalue: At all events added the prince I am sure you will make it up with my wife I guarantee you will do so Only I must show you the way now There is nothing commonplace about her it is not every one who takes her fancy

children.name: Paragraph_230
children.value: Monseigneur
children.prevalue: Monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_231
children.value: No resistance, De Guiche, or I shall get out of temper, replied the prince.
children.prevalue: No resistance De Guiche or I shall get out of temper replied the prince

children.name: Paragraph_232
children.value: Well, since he will have it so, murmured Manicamp, in Guiche's ear, do as he wants you to do.
children.prevalue: Well since he will have it so murmured Manicamp in Guiche s ear do as he wants you to do

children.name: Paragraph_233
children.value: Well, monseigneur, said the comte, I obey.
children.prevalue: Well monseigneur said the comte I obey

children.name: Paragraph_234
children.value: And to begin, resumed the prince, there will be cards, this evening, in Madame's apartment; you will dine with me, and I will take you there with me.
children.prevalue: And to begin resumed the prince there will be cards this evening in Madame s apartment you will dine with me and I will take you there with me

children.name: Paragraph_235
children.value: Oh! as for that, monseigneur, objected De Guiche, you will allow me to object.
children.prevalue: Oh as for that monseigneur objected De Guiche you will allow me to object

children.name: Paragraph_236
children.value: What, again! this is positive rebellion.
children.prevalue: What again this is positive rebellion

children.name: Paragraph_237
children.value: Madame received me too indifferently, yesterday, before the whole court.
children.prevalue: Madame received me too indifferently yesterday before the whole court

children.name: Paragraph_238
children.value: Really! said the prince, laughing.
children.prevalue: Really said the prince laughing

children.name: Paragraph_239
children.value: Nay, so much so, indeed, that she did not even answer me when I addressed her; it may be a good thing to have no selfrespect at all, but to have too little is not enough, as the saying is.
children.prevalue: Nay so much so indeed that she did not even answer me when I addressed her it may be a good thing to have no selfrespect at all but to have too little is not enough as the saying is

children.name: Paragraph_240
children.value: Comte! after dinner, you will go to your own apartments and dress yourself, and then you will come to fetch me. I shall wait for you.
children.prevalue: Comte after dinner you will go to your own apartments and dress yourself and then you will come to fetch me I shall wait for you

children.name: Paragraph_241
children.value: Since your highness absolutely commands it.
children.prevalue: Since your highness absolutely commands it

children.name: Paragraph_242
children.value: Positively.
children.prevalue: Positively

children.name: Paragraph_243
children.value: He will not lose his hold, said Manicamp; these are the things to which husbands cling most obstinately. Ah! what a pity M. Moliere could not have heard this man; he would have turned him into verse if he had.
children.prevalue: He will not lose his hold said Manicamp these are the things to which husbands cling most obstinately Ah what a pity M Moliere could not have heard this man he would have turned him into verse if he had

children.name: Paragraph_244
children.value: The prince and his court, chatting in this manner, returned to the coolest apartments of the chateau.
children.prevalue: The prince and his court chatting in this manner returned to the coolest apartments of the chateau

children.name: Paragraph_245
children.value: By the by, said De Guiche, as they were standing by the door, I had a commission for your royal highness.
children.prevalue: By the by said De Guiche as they were standing by the door I had a commission for your royal highness

children.name: Paragraph_246
children.value: Execute it, then.
children.prevalue: Execute it then

children.name: Paragraph_247
children.value: M. de Bragelonne has, by the king's order, set off for London, and he charged me with his respects for you; monseigneur.
children.prevalue: M de Bragelonne has by the king s order set off for London and he charged me with his respects for you monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_248
children.value: A pleasant journey to the vicomte, whom I like very much. Go and dress yourself, De Guiche, and come back for me. If you don't come back
children.prevalue: A pleasant journey to the vicomte whom I like very much Go and dress yourself De Guiche and come back for me If you don t come back

children.name: Paragraph_249
children.value: What will happen, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: What will happen monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_250
children.value: I will have you sent to the Bastile.
children.prevalue: I will have you sent to the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_251
children.value: Well, said De Guiche, laughing, his royal highness, monseigneur, is decidedly the counterpart of her royal highness, Madame. Madame gets me sent into exile, because she does not care for me sufficiently; and monseigneur gets me imprisoned, because he cares for me too much. I thank monseigneur, and I thank Madame.
children.prevalue: Well said De Guiche laughing his royal highness monseigneur is decidedly the counterpart of her royal highness Madame Madame gets me sent into exile because she does not care for me sufficiently and monseigneur gets me imprisoned because he cares for me too much I thank monseigneur and I thank Madame

children.name: Paragraph_252
children.value: Come, come, said the prince, you are a delightful companion, and you know I cannot do without you. Return as soon as you can.
children.prevalue: Come come said the prince you are a delightful companion and you know I cannot do without you Return as soon as you can

children.name: Paragraph_253
children.value: Very well; but I am in the humor to prove myself difficult to be pleased, in my turn, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Very well but I am in the humor to prove myself difficult to be pleased in my turn monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_254
children.value: Bah!
children.prevalue: Bah

children.name: Paragraph_255
children.value: So, I will not return to your royal highness, except upon one condition.
children.prevalue: So I will not return to your royal highness except upon one condition

children.name: Paragraph_256
children.value: Name it.
children.prevalue: Name it

children.name: Paragraph_257
children.value: I want to oblige the friend of one of my friends.
children.prevalue: I want to oblige the friend of one of my friends

children.name: Paragraph_258
children.value: What's his name?
children.prevalue: What s his name

children.name: Paragraph_259
children.value: Malicorne.
children.prevalue: Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_260
children.value: An ugly name.
children.prevalue: An ugly name

children.name: Paragraph_261
children.value: But very well borne, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: But very well borne monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_262
children.value: That may be. Well?
children.prevalue: That may be Well

children.name: Paragraph_263
children.value: Well, I owe M. Malicorne a place in your household, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Well I owe M Malicorne a place in your household monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_264
children.value: What kind of a place?
children.prevalue: What kind of a place

children.name: Paragraph_265
children.value: Any kind of a place; a supervision of some sort or another, for instance.
children.prevalue: Any kind of a place a supervision of some sort or another for instance

children.name: Paragraph_266
children.value: That happens very fortunately, for yesterday I dismissed my chief usher of the apartments.
children.prevalue: That happens very fortunately for yesterday I dismissed my chief usher of the apartments

children.name: Paragraph_267
children.value: That will do admirably. What are his duties?
children.prevalue: That will do admirably What are his duties

children.name: Paragraph_268
children.value: Nothing, except to look about and make his report.
children.prevalue: Nothing except to look about and make his report

children.name: Paragraph_269
children.value: A sort of interior police?
children.prevalue: A sort of interior police

children.name: Paragraph_270
children.value: Exactly.
children.prevalue: Exactly

children.name: Paragraph_271
children.value: Ah, how excellently that will suit Malicorne, Manicamp ventured to say.
children.prevalue: Ah how excellently that will suit Malicorne Manicamp ventured to say

children.name: Paragraph_272
children.value: You know the person we are speaking of, M. Manicamp? inquired the prince.
children.prevalue: You know the person we are speaking of M Manicamp inquired the prince

children.name: Paragraph_273
children.value: Intimately, monseigneur. He is a friend of mine.
children.prevalue: Intimately monseigneur He is a friend of mine

children.name: Paragraph_274
children.value: And your opinion is?
children.prevalue: And your opinion is

children.name: Paragraph_275
children.value: That your highness could never get a better usher of the apartments than he will make.
children.prevalue: That your highness could never get a better usher of the apartments than he will make

children.name: Paragraph_276
children.value: How much does the appointment bring in? inquired the comte of the prince.
children.prevalue: How much does the appointment bring in inquired the comte of the prince

children.name: Paragraph_277
children.value: I don't know at all, only I have always been told that he could make as much as he pleased when he was thoroughly in earnest.
children.prevalue: I don t know at all only I have always been told that he could make as much as he pleased when he was thoroughly in earnest

children.name: Paragraph_278
children.value: What do you call being thoroughly in earnest, prince?
children.prevalue: What do you call being thoroughly in earnest prince

children.name: Paragraph_279
children.value: It means, of course, when the functionary in question is a man who has his wits about him.
children.prevalue: It means of course when the functionary in question is a man who has his wits about him

children.name: Paragraph_280
children.value: In that case I think your highness will be content, for Malicorne is as sharp as the devil himself.
children.prevalue: In that case I think your highness will be content for Malicorne is as sharp as the devil himself

children.name: Paragraph_281
children.value: Good! the appointment will be an expensive one for me, in that case, replied the prince, laughing. You are making me a positive present, comte.
children.prevalue: Good the appointment will be an expensive one for me in that case replied the prince laughing You are making me a positive present comte

children.name: Paragraph_282
children.value: I believe so, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: I believe so monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_283
children.value: Well, go and announce to your M. Melicorne
children.prevalue: Well go and announce to your M Melicorne

children.name: Paragraph_284
children.value: Malicorne, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Malicorne monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_285
children.value: I shall never get hold of that name.
children.prevalue: I shall never get hold of that name

children.name: Paragraph_286
children.value: You say Manicamp very well, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: You say Manicamp very well monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_287
children.value: Oh, I ought to say Malicorne very well, too. The alliteration will help me.
children.prevalue: Oh I ought to say Malicorne very well too The alliteration will help me

children.name: Paragraph_288
children.value: Say what you like, monseigneur, I can promise you your inspector of apartments will not be annoyed; he has the very happiest disposition that can be met with.
children.prevalue: Say what you like monseigneur I can promise you your inspector of apartments will not be annoyed he has the very happiest disposition that can be met with

children.name: Paragraph_289
children.value: Well, then, my dear De Guiche, inform him of his nomination. But, stay
children.prevalue: Well then my dear De Guiche inform him of his nomination But stay

children.name: Paragraph_290
children.value: What is it, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: What is it monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_291
children.value: I wish to see him beforehand; if he be as ugly as his name, I retract every word I have said.
children.prevalue: I wish to see him beforehand if he be as ugly as his name I retract every word I have said

children.name: Paragraph_292
children.value: Your highness knows him, for you have already seen him at the Palais Royal; nay, indeed, it was I who presented him to you.
children.prevalue: Your highness knows him for you have already seen him at the Palais Royal nay indeed it was I who presented him to you

children.name: Paragraph_293
children.value: Ah, I remember nownot a badlooking fellow.
children.prevalue: Ah I remember nownot a badlooking fellow

children.name: Paragraph_294
children.value: I know you must have noticed him, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: I know you must have noticed him monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_295
children.value: Yes, yes, yes. You see, De Guiche, I do not wish that either my wife or myself should have ugly faces before our eyes. My wife will have all her maids of honor pretty; I, all the gentlemen about me goodlooking. In this way, De Guiche, you see, that any children we may have will run a good chance of being pretty, if my wife and myself have handsome models before us.
children.prevalue: Yes yes yes You see De Guiche I do not wish that either my wife or myself should have ugly faces before our eyes My wife will have all her maids of honor pretty I all the gentlemen about me goodlooking In this way De Guiche you see that any children we may have will run a good chance of being pretty if my wife and myself have handsome models before us

children.name: Paragraph_296
children.value: Most magnificently argued, monseigneur, said Manicamp, showing his approval by look and voice at the same time.
children.prevalue: Most magnificently argued monseigneur said Manicamp showing his approval by look and voice at the same time

children.name: Paragraph_297
children.value: As for De Guiche, he very probably did not find the argument so convincing, for he merely signified his opinion by a gesture, which, moreover, exhibited in a marked manner some indecision of mind on the subject. Manicamp went off to inform Malicorne of the good news he had just learned. De Guiche seemed very unwilling to take his departure for the purpose of dressing himself. Monsieur, singing, laughing, and admiring himself, passed away the time until the dinnerhour, in a frame of mind that justified the proverb of Happy as a prince.
children.prevalue: As for De Guiche he very probably did not find the argument so convincing for he merely signified his opinion by a gesture which moreover exhibited in a marked manner some indecision of mind on the subject Manicamp went off to inform Malicorne of the good news he had just learned De Guiche seemed very unwilling to take his departure for the purpose of dressing himself Monsieur singing laughing and admiring himself passed away the time until the dinnerhour in a frame of mind that justified the proverb of Happy as a prince

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Every one had partaken of the banquet at the chateau, and afterwards assumed their full court dresses. The usual hour for the repast was five o'clock. If we say, then, that the repast occupied an hour, and the toilette two hours, everybody was ready about eight o'clock in the evening. Towards eight o'clock, then, the guests began to arrive at Madame's, for we have already intimated that it was Madame who received that evening. And at Madame's soirees no one failed to be present; for the evenings passed in her apartments always had that perfect charm about them which the queen, that pious and excellent princess, had not been able to confer upon her reunions. For, unfortunately, one of the advantages of goodness of disposition is that it is far less amusing than wit of an illnatured character. And yet, let us hasten to add, that such a style of wit could not be assigned to Madame, for her disposition of mind, naturally of the very highest order, comprised too much true generosity, too many noble impulses and highsouled thoughts, to warrant her being termed illnatured. But Madame was endowed with a spirit of resistancea gift frequently fatal to its possessor, for it breaks where another disposition would have bent; the result was that blows did not become deadened upon her as upon what might be termed the cottonwadded feelings of Maria Theresa. Her heart rebounded at each attack, and therefore, whenever she was attacked, even in a manner that almost stunned her, she returned blow for blow to any one imprudent enough to tilt against her.
children.prevalue: Every one had partaken of the banquet at the chateau and afterwards assumed their full court dresses The usual hour for the repast was five o clock If we say then that the repast occupied an hour and the toilette two hours everybody was ready about eight o clock in the evening Towards eight o clock then the guests began to arrive at Madame s for we have already intimated that it was Madame who received that evening And at Madame s soirees no one failed to be present for the evenings passed in her apartments always had that perfect charm about them which the queen that pious and excellent princess had not been able to confer upon her reunions For unfortunately one of the advantages of goodness of disposition is that it is far less amusing than wit of an illnatured character And yet let us hasten to add that such a style of wit could not be assigned to Madame for her disposition of mind naturally of the very highest order comprised too much true generosity too many noble impulses and highsouled thoughts to warrant her being termed illnatured But Madame was endowed with a spirit of resistancea gift frequently fatal to its possessor for it breaks where another disposition would have bent the result was that blows did not become deadened upon her as upon what might be termed the cottonwadded feelings of Maria Theresa Her heart rebounded at each attack and therefore whenever she was attacked even in a manner that almost stunned her she returned blow for blow to any one imprudent enough to tilt against her

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Was this really maliciousness of disposition or simply waywardness of character? We regard those rich and powerful natures as like the tree of knowledge, producing good and evil at the same time; a double branch, always blooming and fruitful, of which those who wish to eat know how to detect the good fruit, and from which the worthless and frivolous die who have eaten of ita circumstance which is by no means to be regarded as a great misfortune. Madame, therefore, who had a welldisguised plan in her mind of constituting herself the second, if not even the principal, queen of the court, rendered her receptions delightful to all, from the conversation, the opportunities of meeting, and the perfect liberty she allowed every one of making any remark he pleased, on the condition, however, that the remark was amusing or sensible. And it will hardly be believed, that, by that means, there was less talking among the society Madame assembled together than elsewhere. Madame hated people who talked much, and took a remarkably cruel revenge upon them, for she allowed them to talk. She disliked pretension, too, and never overlooked that defect, even in the king himself. It was more than a weakness of Monsieur, and the princess had undertaken the amazing task of curing him of it. As for the rest, poets, wits, beautiful women, all were received by her with the air of a mistress superior to her slaves. Sufficiently meditative in her liveliest humors to make even poets meditate; sufficiently pretty to dazzle by her attractions, even among the prettiest; sufficiently witty for the most distinguished persons who were present, to be listened to with pleasureit will easily be believed that the reunions held in Madame's apartments must naturally have proved very attractive. All who were young flocked there, and when the king himself happens to be young, everybody at court is so too. And so, the older ladies of the court, the strongminded women of the regency, or of the last reign, pouted and sulked at their ease; but others only laughed at the fits of sulkiness in which these venerable individuals indulged, who had carried the love of authority so far as even to take command of bodies of soldiers in the wars of the Fronde, in order, as Madame asserted, not to lose their influence over men altogether. As eight o'clock struck her royal highness entered the great drawingroom accompanied by her ladies in attendance, and found several gentlemen belonging to the court already there, having been waiting for some minutes. Among those who had arrived before the hour fixed for the reception she looked round for one who, she thought, ought to have been first in attendance, but he was not there. However, almost at the very moment she completed her investigation, Monsieur was announced. Monsieur looked splendid. All the precious stones and jewels of Cardinal Mazarin, which of course that minister could not do otherwise than leave; all the queenmother's jewels as well as a few belonging to his wifeMonsieur wore them all, and he was as dazzling as the rising sun. Behind him followed De Guiche, with hesitating steps and an air of contrition admirably assumed; De Guiche wore a costume of Frenchgray velvet, embroidered with silver, and trimmed with blue ribbons: he wore also Mechlin lace as rare and beautiful in its own way as the jewels of Monsieur in theirs. The plume in his hat was red. Madame, too, wore several colors, and preferred red for embroidery, gray for dress, and blue for flowers. M. de Guiche, dressed as we have described, looked so handsome that he excited every one's observation. An interesting pallor of complexion, a languid expression of the eyes, his white hands seen through the masses of lace that covered them, the melancholy expression of his mouthit was only necessary, indeed, to see M. de Guiche to admit that few men at the court of France could hope to equal him. The consequence was that Monsieur, who was pretentious enough to fancy he could eclipse a star even, if a star had adorned itself in a similar manner to himself, was, on the contrary, completely eclipsed in all imaginations, which are silent judges certainly, but very positive and firm in their convictions. Madame looked at De Guiche lightly, but light as her look had been, it brought a delightful color to his face. In fact, Madame found De Guiche so handsome and so admirably dressed, that she almost ceased regretting the royal conquest she felt she was on the point of escaping her. Her heart, therefore, sent the blood to her face. Monsieur approached her. He had not noticed the princess's blush, or if he had seen it, he was far from attributing it to its true cause.

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Madame, he said, kissing his wife's hand, there is some one present here, who has fallen into disgrace, an unhappy exile whom I venture to recommend to your kindness. Do not forget, I beg, that he is one of my best friends, and that a gentle reception of him will please me greatly.
children.prevalue: Madame he said kissing his wife s hand there is some one present here who has fallen into disgrace an unhappy exile whom I venture to recommend to your kindness Do not forget I beg that he is one of my best friends and that a gentle reception of him will please me greatly

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: What exile? what disgraced person are you speaking of? inquired Madame, looking all round, and not permitting her glance to rest more on the count than on the others.
children.prevalue: What exile what disgraced person are you speaking of inquired Madame looking all round and not permitting her glance to rest more on the count than on the others

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: This was the moment to present De Guiche, and the prince drew aside and let De Guiche pass him, who, with a tolerably wellassumed awkwardness of manner, approached Madame and made his reverence to her.
children.prevalue: This was the moment to present De Guiche and the prince drew aside and let De Guiche pass him who with a tolerably wellassumed awkwardness of manner approached Madame and made his reverence to her

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: What! exclaimed Madame, as if she were greatly surprised, is M. de Guiche the disgraced individual you speak of, the exile in question?
children.prevalue: What exclaimed Madame as if she were greatly surprised is M de Guiche the disgraced individual you speak of the exile in question

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Yes, certainly, returned the duke.
children.prevalue: Yes certainly returned the duke

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Indeed, said Madame, he seems almost the only person here!
children.prevalue: Indeed said Madame he seems almost the only person here

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: You are unjust, Madame, said the prince.
children.prevalue: You are unjust Madame said the prince

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I?
children.prevalue: I

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Certainly. Come, forgive the poor fellow.
children.prevalue: Certainly Come forgive the poor fellow

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Forgive him what? What have I to forgive M. de Guiche?
children.prevalue: Forgive him what What have I to forgive M de Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Come, explain yourself, De Guiche. What do you wish to be forgiven? inquired the prince.
children.prevalue: Come explain yourself De Guiche What do you wish to be forgiven inquired the prince

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Alas! her royal highness knows very well what it is, replied the latter, in a hypocritical tone.
children.prevalue: Alas her royal highness knows very well what it is replied the latter in a hypocritical tone

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Come, come, give him your hand, Madame, said Philip.
children.prevalue: Come come give him your hand Madame said Philip

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: If it will give you any pleasure, Monsieur, and, with a movement of her eyes and shoulders, which it would be impossible to describe, Madame extended towards the young man her beautiful and perfumed hand, upon which he pressed his lips. It was evident that he did so for some little time, and that Madame did not withdraw her hand too quickly, for the duke added:
children.prevalue: If it will give you any pleasure Monsieur and with a movement of her eyes and shoulders which it would be impossible to describe Madame extended towards the young man her beautiful and perfumed hand upon which he pressed his lips It was evident that he did so for some little time and that Madame did not withdraw her hand too quickly for the duke added

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: De Guiche is not wickedly disposed, Madame; so do not be afraid, he will not bite you.
children.prevalue: De Guiche is not wickedly disposed Madame so do not be afraid he will not bite you

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: A pretext was given in the gallery by the duke's remark, which was not, perhaps, very laughable, for every one to laugh excessively. The situation was odd enough, and some kindly disposed persons had observed it. Monsieur was still enjoying the effect of his remark, when the king was announced. The appearance of the room at that moment was as follows:in the center, before the fireplace, which was filled with flowers, Madame was standing up, with her maids of honor formed in two wings, on either side of her; around whom the butterflies of the court were fluttering. Several other groups were formed in the recesses of the windows, like soldiers stationed in their different towers who belong to the same garrison. From their respective places they could pick up the remarks which fell from the principal group. From one of these groups, the nearest to the fireplace, Malicorne, who had been at once raised to the dignity, through Manicamp and De Guiche, of the post of master of the apartments, and whose official costume had been ready for the last two months, was brilliant with gold lace, and shone upon Montalais, standing on Madame's extreme left, with all the fire of his eyes and splendor of his velvet. Madame was conversing with Mademoiselle de Chatillon and Mademoiselle de Crequy, who were next to her, and addressed a few words to Monsieur, who drew aside as soon as the king was announced. Mademoiselle de la Valliere, like Montalais, was on Madame's left hand, and the last but one on the line, Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente being on her right. She was stationed as certain bodies of troops are, whose weakness is suspected, and who are placed between two experienced regiments. Guarded in this manner by the companions who had shared her adventure, La Valliere, whether from regret at Raoul's departure, or still suffering from the emotion caused by recent events, which had begun to render her name familiar on the lips of the courtiers, La Valliere, we repeat, hid her eyes, red with weeping, behind her fan, and seemed to give the greatest attention to the remarks which Montalais and Athenais, alternately, whispered to her from time to time. As soon as the king's name was announced a general movement took place in the apartment. Madame, in her character as hostess, rose to receive the royal visitor; but as she rose, notwithstanding her preoccupation of mind, she glanced hastily towards her right; her glance, which the presumptuous De Guiche regarded as intended for himself, rested, as it swept over the whole circle, upon La Valliere, whose warm blush and restless emotion it instantly perceived.

Mademoiselle de la Valliere like Montalais was on Madame s left hand and the last but one on the line Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente being on her right She was stationed as certain bodies of troops are whose weakness is suspected and who are placed between two experienced regiments Guarded in this manner by the companions who had shared her adventure La Valliere whether from regret at Raoul s departure or still suffering from the emotion caused by recent events which had begun to render her name familiar on the lips of the courtiers La Valliere we repeat hid her eyes red with weeping behind her fan and seemed to give the greatest attention to the remarks which Montalais and Athenais alternately whispered to her from time to time As soon as the king s name was announced a general movement took place in the apartment Madame in her character as hostess rose to receive the royal visitor but as she rose notwithstanding her preoccupation of mind she glanced hastily towards her right her glance which the presumptuous De Guiche regarded as intended for himself rested as it swept over the whole circle upon La Valliere whose warm blush and restless emotion it instantly perceived

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The king advanced to the middle of the group, which had now become a general one, by a movement which took place from the circumference to the center. Every head bowed low before his majesty, the ladies bending like frail, magnificent lilies before King Aquilo. There was nothing very severe, we will even say, nothing very royal that evening about the king, except youth and good looks. He wore an air of animated joyousness and goodhumor which set all imaginations at work, and, thereupon, all present promised themselves a delightful evening, for no other reason than from having remarked the desire his majesty had to amuse himself in Madame's apartments. If there was any one in particular whose high spirits and goodhumor equalled the king's, it was M. de SaintAignan, who was dressed in a rosecolored costume, with face and ribbons of the same color, and, in addition, particularly rosecolored in his ideas, for that evening M. de SaintAignan was prolific in jests. The circumstance which had given a new expansion to the numerous ideas germinating in his fertile brain was, that he had just perceived that Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente was, like himself, dressed in rosecolor. We would not wish to say, however, that the wily courtier had not know beforehand that the beautiful Athenais was to wear that particular color; for he very well knew the art of unlocking the lips of a dressmaker or a lady's maid as to her mistress's intentions. He cast as many killing glances at Mademoiselle Athenais as he had bows of ribbons on his stockings and doublet; in other words he discharged a prodigious number. The king having paid Madame the customary compliments, and Madame having requested him to be seated, the circle was immediately formed. Louis inquired of Monsieur the particulars of the day's bathing; and stated, looking at the ladies present while he spoke, that certain poets were engaged turning into verse the enchanting diversion of the baths of Vulaines, and that one of them particularly, M. Loret, seemed to have been intrusted with the confidence of some waternymph, as he had in his verses recounted many circumstances that were actually trueat which remark more than one lady present felt herself bound to blush. The king at this moment took the opportunity of looking round him at more leisure; Montalais was the only one who did not blush sufficiently to prevent her looking at the king, and she saw him fix his eyes devouringly on Mademoiselle de la Valliere. This undaunted maid of honor, Mademoiselle de Montalais, be it understood, forced the king to lower his gaze, and so saved Louise de la Valliere from a sympathetic warmth of feeling this gaze might possibly have conveyed. Louis was appropriated by Madame, who overwhelmed him with inquiries, and no one in the world knew how to ask questions better than she did. He tried, however, to render the conversation general, and, with the view of effecting this, he redoubled his attention and devotion to her. Madame coveted complimentary remarks, and, determined to procure them at any cost, she addressed herself to the king, saying:
