children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Sire, your majesty, who is aware of everything which occurs in your kingdom, ought to know beforehand the verses confided to M. Loret by this nymph; will your majesty kindly communicate them to us?
children.prevalue: Sire your majesty who is aware of everything which occurs in your kingdom ought to know beforehand the verses confided to M Loret by this nymph will your majesty kindly communicate them to us

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Madame, replied the king, with perfect grace of manner, I dare notyou, personally, might be in no little degree confused at having to listen to certain detailsbut SaintAignan tells a story well, and has a perfect recollection of the verses. If he does not remember them, he will invent. I can certify he is almost a poet himself. SaintAignan, thus brought prominently forward, was compelled to introduce himself as advantageously as possible. Unfortunately, however, for Madame, he thought of his own personal affairs only; in other words, instead of paying Madame the compliments she so much desired and relished, his mind was fixed upon making as much display as possible of his own good fortune. Again glancing, therefore, for the hundredth time at the beautiful Athenais, who carried into practice her previous evening's theory of not even deigning to look at her adorer, he said:
children.prevalue: Madame replied the king with perfect grace of manner I dare notyou personally might be in no little degree confused at having to listen to certain detailsbut SaintAignan tells a story well and has a perfect recollection of the verses If he does not remember them he will invent I can certify he is almost a poet himself SaintAignan thus brought prominently forward was compelled to introduce himself as advantageously as possible Unfortunately however for Madame he thought of his own personal affairs only in other words instead of paying Madame the compliments she so much desired and relished his mind was fixed upon making as much display as possible of his own good fortune Again glancing therefore for the hundredth time at the beautiful Athenais who carried into practice her previous evening s theory of not even deigning to look at her adorer he said

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Your majesty will perhaps pardon me for having too indifferently remembered the verses which the nymph dictated to Loret; but if the king has not retained any recollection of them, how could I possibly remember?
children.prevalue: Your majesty will perhaps pardon me for having too indifferently remembered the verses which the nymph dictated to Loret but if the king has not retained any recollection of them how could I possibly remember

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Madame did not receive this shortcoming of the courtier very favorably.
children.prevalue: Madame did not receive this shortcoming of the courtier very favorably

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Ah! madame, added SaintAignan, at present it is no longer a question what the waternymphs have to say; and one would almost be tempted to believe that nothing of any interest now occurs in those liquid realms. It is upon earth, madame, important events happen. Ah! Madame, upon the earth, how many tales are there full of
children.prevalue: Ah madame added SaintAignan at present it is no longer a question what the waternymphs have to say and one would almost be tempted to believe that nothing of any interest now occurs in those liquid realms It is upon earth madame important events happen Ah Madame upon the earth how many tales are there full of

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Well, said Madame, and what is taking place upon the earth?
children.prevalue: Well said Madame and what is taking place upon the earth

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: That question must be asked of the Dryads, replied the comte; the Dryads inhabit the forest, as your royal highness is aware.
children.prevalue: That question must be asked of the Dryads replied the comte the Dryads inhabit the forest as your royal highness is aware

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: I am aware also, that they are naturally very talkative, Monsieur de SaintAignan.
children.prevalue: I am aware also that they are naturally very talkative Monsieur de SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Such is the case, Madame; but when they say such delightful things, it would be ungracious to accuse them of being too talkative.
children.prevalue: Such is the case Madame but when they say such delightful things it would be ungracious to accuse them of being too talkative

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Do they talk so delightfully, then? inquired the princess, indifferently. Really, Monsieur de SaintAignan, you excite my curiosity; and, if I were the king, I would require you immediately to tell us what the delightful things are these Dryads have been saying, since you alone seem to understand their language.
children.prevalue: Do they talk so delightfully then inquired the princess indifferently Really Monsieur de SaintAignan you excite my curiosity and if I were the king I would require you immediately to tell us what the delightful things are these Dryads have been saying since you alone seem to understand their language

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: I am at his majesty's orders, Madame, in that respect, replied the comte, quickly.
children.prevalue: I am at his majesty s orders Madame in that respect replied the comte quickly

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: What a fortunate fellow this SaintAignan is to understand the language of the Dryads, said Monsieur.
children.prevalue: What a fortunate fellow this SaintAignan is to understand the language of the Dryads said Monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: I understand it perfectly, monseigneur, as I do my own language.
children.prevalue: I understand it perfectly monseigneur as I do my own language

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Tell us all about them, then, said Madame.
children.prevalue: Tell us all about them then said Madame

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The king felt embarrassed, for his confidant was, in all probability, about to embark in a difficult matter. He felt that it would be so, from the general attention excited by SaintAignan's preamble, and aroused too by Madame's peculiar manner. The most reserved of those who were present seemed ready to devour every syllable the comte was about to pronounce. They coughed, drew closer together, looked curiously at some of the maids of honor, who, in order to support with greater propriety, or with more steadiness, the fixity of the inquisitorial looks bent upon them, adjusted their fans accordingly, and assumed the bearing of a duelist about to be exposed to his adversary's fire. At this epoch, the fashion of ingeniously constructed conversations, and hazardously dangerous recitals, so prevailed, that, where, in modern times, a whole company assembled in a drawingroom would begin to suspect some scandal, or disclosure, or tragic event, and would hurry away in dismay, Madame's guests quietly settled themselves in their places, in order not to lose a word or gesture of the comedy composed by Monsieur de SaintAignan for their benefit, and the termination of which, whatever the style and the plot might be, must, as a matter of course, be marked by the most perfect propriety. The comte as known as a man of extreme refinement, and an admirable narrator. He courageously began, then, amidst a profound silence, which would have been formidable to any one but himself:Madame, by the king's permission, I address myself, in the first place, to your royal highness, since you admit yourself to be the person present possessing the greatest curiosity. I have the honor, therefore, to inform your royal highness that the Dryad more particularly inhabits the hollows of oaks; and, as Dryads are mythological creatures of great beauty, they inhabit the most beautiful trees, in other words, the largest to be found.
children.prevalue: The king felt embarrassed for his confidant was in all probability about to embark in a difficult matter He felt that it would be so from the general attention excited by SaintAignan s preamble and aroused too by Madame s peculiar manner The most reserved of those who were present seemed ready to devour every syllable the comte was about to pronounce They coughed drew closer together looked curiously at some of the maids of honor who in order to support with greater propriety or with more steadiness the fixity of the inquisitorial looks bent upon them adjusted their fans accordingly and assumed the bearing of a duelist about to be exposed to his adversary s fire At this epoch the fashion of ingeniously constructed conversations and hazardously dangerous recitals so prevailed that where in modern times a whole company assembled in a drawingroom would begin to suspect some scandal or disclosure or tragic event and would hurry away in dismay Madame s guests quietly settled themselves in their places in order not to lose a word or gesture of the comedy composed by Monsieur de SaintAignan for their benefit and the termination of which whatever the style and the plot might be must as a matter of course be marked by the most perfect propriety The comte as known as a man of extreme refinement and an admirable narrator He courageously began then amidst a profound silence which would have been formidable to any one but himself Madame by the king s permission I address myself in the first place to your royal highness since you admit yourself to be the person present possessing the greatest curiosity I have the honor therefore to inform your royal highness that the Dryad more particularly inhabits the hollows of oaks and as Dryads are mythological creatures of great beauty they inhabit the most beautiful trees in other words the largest to be found

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: At this exordium, which recalled, under a transparent veil, the celebrated story of the royal oak, which had played so important a part in the last evening, so many hearts began to beat, both from joy and uneasiness, that, if SaintAignan had not had a good and sonorous voice, their throbbings might have been heard above the sound of his voice.
children.prevalue: At this exordium which recalled under a transparent veil the celebrated story of the royal oak which had played so important a part in the last evening so many hearts began to beat both from joy and uneasiness that if SaintAignan had not had a good and sonorous voice their throbbings might have been heard above the sound of his voice

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: There must surely be Dryads at Fontainebleau, then, said Madame, in a perfectly calm voice; for I have never, in all my life, seen finer oaks than in the royal park. And as she spoke, she directed towards De Guiche a look of which he had no reason to complain, as he had of the one that preceded it; which, as we have already mentioned, had reserved a certain amount of indefiniteness most painful for so loving a heart as his.
children.prevalue: There must surely be Dryads at Fontainebleau then said Madame in a perfectly calm voice for I have never in all my life seen finer oaks than in the royal park And as she spoke she directed towards De Guiche a look of which he had no reason to complain as he had of the one that preceded it which as we have already mentioned had reserved a certain amount of indefiniteness most painful for so loving a heart as his

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Precisely, Madame, it is of Fontainebleau I was about to speak to your royal highness, said SaintAignan; for the Dryad whose story is engaging our attention, lives in the park belonging to the chateau of his majesty.
children.prevalue: Precisely Madame it is of Fontainebleau I was about to speak to your royal highness said SaintAignan for the Dryad whose story is engaging our attention lives in the park belonging to the chateau of his majesty

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: The affair was fairly embarked on; the action was begun, and it was no longer possible for auditory or narrator to draw back.
children.prevalue: The affair was fairly embarked on the action was begun and it was no longer possible for auditory or narrator to draw back

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: It will be worth listening to, said Madame; for the story not only appears to me to have all the interest of a national incident, but still more, seems to be a circumstance of very recent occurrence.
children.prevalue: It will be worth listening to said Madame for the story not only appears to me to have all the interest of a national incident but still more seems to be a circumstance of very recent occurrence

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I ought to begin at the beginning, said the comte. In the first place, then, there lived at Fontainebleau, in a cottage of modest and unassuming appearance, two shepherds. The one was the shepherd Tyrcis, the owner of extensive domains transmitted to him from his parents, by right of inheritance. Tyrcis was young and handsome, and, from his many qualifications, he might be pronounced to be the first and foremost among the shepherds in the whole country; one might even boldly say he was the king of shepherds. A subdued murmur of approbation encouraged the narrator, who continued:His strength equals his courage; no one displays greater address in hunting wild beasts, nor greater wisdom in matters where judgment is required. Whenever he mounts and exercises his horse in the beautiful plains of his inheritance, or whenever he joins with the shepherds who owe him allegiance, in different games of skill and strength, one might say that it is the god Mars hurling his lance on the plains of Thrace, or, even better, that it was Apollo himself, the god of day, radiant upon earth, bearing his flaming darts in his hand. Every one understood that this allegorical portrait of the king was not the worst exordium the narrator could have chosen; and consequently it did not fail to produce its effect, either upon those who, from duty or inclination, applauded it to the very echo, or on the king himself, to whom flattery was very agreeable when delicately conveyed, and whom, indeed, it did not always displease, even when it was a little too broad. SaintAignan then continued:It is not in games of glory only, ladies, that the shepherd Tyrcis had acquired that reputation by which he was regarded as the king of the shepherds.
children.prevalue: I ought to begin at the beginning said the comte In the first place then there lived at Fontainebleau in a cottage of modest and unassuming appearance two shepherds The one was the shepherd Tyrcis the owner of extensive domains transmitted to him from his parents by right of inheritance Tyrcis was young and handsome and from his many qualifications he might be pronounced to be the first and foremost among the shepherds in the whole country one might even boldly say he was the king of shepherds A subdued murmur of approbation encouraged the narrator who continued His strength equals his courage no one displays greater address in hunting wild beasts nor greater wisdom in matters where judgment is required Whenever he mounts and exercises his horse in the beautiful plains of his inheritance or whenever he joins with the shepherds who owe him allegiance in different games of skill and strength one might say that it is the god Mars hurling his lance on the plains of Thrace or even better that it was Apollo himself the god of day radiant upon earth bearing his flaming darts in his hand Every one understood that this allegorical portrait of the king was not the worst exordium the narrator could have chosen and consequently it did not fail to produce its effect either upon those who from duty or inclination applauded it to the very echo or on the king himself to whom flattery was very agreeable when delicately conveyed and whom indeed it did not always displease even when it was a little too broad SaintAignan then continued It is not in games of glory only ladies that the shepherd Tyrcis had acquired that reputation by which he was regarded as the king of the shepherds

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Of the shepherds of Fontainebleau, said the king, smilingly, to Madame.
children.prevalue: Of the shepherds of Fontainebleau said the king smilingly to Madame

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Oh! exclaimed Madame, Fontainebleau is selected arbitrarily by the poet; but I should say, of the shepherds of the whole world. The king forgot his part of a passive auditor, and bowed.
children.prevalue: Oh exclaimed Madame Fontainebleau is selected arbitrarily by the poet but I should say of the shepherds of the whole world The king forgot his part of a passive auditor and bowed

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: It is, paused SaintAignan, amidst a flattering murmur of applause, it is with ladies fair especially that the qualities of this king of the shepherds are most prominently displayed. He is a shepherd with a mind as refined as his heart is pure; he can pay a compliment with a charm of manner whose fascination it is impossible to resist; and in his attachments he is so discreet, that beautiful and happy conquests may regard their lot as more than enviable. Never a syllable of disclosure, never a moment's forgetfulness. Whoever has seen and heard Tyrcis must love him; whoever loves and is beloved by him, has indeed found happiness. SaintAignan here paused; he was enjoying the pleasure of all these compliments; and the portrait he had drawn, however grotesquely inflated it might be, had found favor in certain ears, in which the perfections of the shepherd did not seem to have been exaggerated. Madame begged the orator to continue. Tyrcis, said the comte, had a faithful companion, or rather a devoted servant, whose name wasAmyntas.
children.prevalue: It is paused SaintAignan amidst a flattering murmur of applause it is with ladies fair especially that the qualities of this king of the shepherds are most prominently displayed He is a shepherd with a mind as refined as his heart is pure he can pay a compliment with a charm of manner whose fascination it is impossible to resist and in his attachments he is so discreet that beautiful and happy conquests may regard their lot as more than enviable Never a syllable of disclosure never a moment s forgetfulness Whoever has seen and heard Tyrcis must love him whoever loves and is beloved by him has indeed found happiness SaintAignan here paused he was enjoying the pleasure of all these compliments and the portrait he had drawn however grotesquely inflated it might be had found favor in certain ears in which the perfections of the shepherd did not seem to have been exaggerated Madame begged the orator to continue Tyrcis said the comte had a faithful companion or rather a devoted servant whose name wasAmyntas

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Ah! said Madame, archly, now for the portrait of Amyntas; you are such an excellent painter, Monsieur de SaintAignan.
children.prevalue: Ah said Madame archly now for the portrait of Amyntas you are such an excellent painter Monsieur de SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Madame
children.prevalue: Madame

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Oh! comte, do not, I entreat you, sacrifice poor Amyntas; I should never forgive you.
children.prevalue: Oh comte do not I entreat you sacrifice poor Amyntas I should never forgive you

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Madame, Amyntas is of too humble a position, particularly beside Tyrcis, for his person to be honored by a parallel. There are certain friends who resemble those followers of ancient times, who caused themselves to be buried alive at their masters' feet. Amyntas's place, too, is at the feet of Tyrcis; he cares for no other; and if, sometimes, the illustrious hero
children.prevalue: Madame Amyntas is of too humble a position particularly beside Tyrcis for his person to be honored by a parallel There are certain friends who resemble those followers of ancient times who caused themselves to be buried alive at their masters feet Amyntas s place too is at the feet of Tyrcis he cares for no other and if sometimes the illustrious hero

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Illustrious shepherd, you mean? said Madame, pretending to correct M. de SaintAignan.
children.prevalue: Illustrious shepherd you mean said Madame pretending to correct M de SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Your royal highness is right; I was mistaken, returned the courtier; if, I say, the shepherd Tyrcis deigns occasionally to call Amyntas his friend, and to open his heart to him, it is an unparalleled favor, which the latter regards as the most unbounded felicity.
children.prevalue: Your royal highness is right I was mistaken returned the courtier if I say the shepherd Tyrcis deigns occasionally to call Amyntas his friend and to open his heart to him it is an unparalleled favor which the latter regards as the most unbounded felicity

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: All that you say, interrupted Madame, establishes the extreme devotion of Amyntas to Tyrcis, but does not furnish us with the portrait of Amyntas. Comte, do not flatter him, if you like; but describe him to us. I will have Amyntas's portrait. SaintAignan obeyed, after having bowed profoundly to his majesty's sisterinlaw.
children.prevalue: All that you say interrupted Madame establishes the extreme devotion of Amyntas to Tyrcis but does not furnish us with the portrait of Amyntas Comte do not flatter him if you like but describe him to us I will have Amyntas s portrait SaintAignan obeyed after having bowed profoundly to his majesty s sisterinlaw

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Amyntas, he said, is somewhat older than Tyrcis; he is not an illfavored shepherd; it is even said that the muses condescended to smile upon him at his birth, even as Hebe smiled upon youth. He is not ambitious of display, but he is ambitious of being loved; and he might not, perhaps, be found unworthy of it, if he were only sufficiently wellknown.
children.prevalue: Amyntas he said is somewhat older than Tyrcis he is not an illfavored shepherd it is even said that the muses condescended to smile upon him at his birth even as Hebe smiled upon youth He is not ambitious of display but he is ambitious of being loved and he might not perhaps be found unworthy of it if he were only sufficiently wellknown

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: This latter paragraph, strengthened by a killing glance, was directed straight to Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, who received them both unmoved. But the modesty and tact of the allusion had produced a good effect; Amyntas reaped the benefit of it in the applause bestowed upon him: Tyrcis's head even gave the signal for it by a consenting bow, full of good feeling.
children.prevalue: This latter paragraph strengthened by a killing glance was directed straight to Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente who received them both unmoved But the modesty and tact of the allusion had produced a good effect Amyntas reaped the benefit of it in the applause bestowed upon him Tyrcis s head even gave the signal for it by a consenting bow full of good feeling

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: One evening, continued SaintAignan, Tyrcis and Amyntas were walking together in the forest, talking of their love disappointments. Do not forget, ladies, that the story of the Dryad is now beginning, otherwise it would be easy to tell you what Tyrcis and Amyntas, the two most discreet shepherds of the whole earth, were talking about. They reached the thickest part of the forest, for the purpose of being quite alone, and of confiding their troubles more freely to each other, when suddenly the sound of voices struck upon their ears.
children.prevalue: One evening continued SaintAignan Tyrcis and Amyntas were walking together in the forest talking of their love disappointments Do not forget ladies that the story of the Dryad is now beginning otherwise it would be easy to tell you what Tyrcis and Amyntas the two most discreet shepherds of the whole earth were talking about They reached the thickest part of the forest for the purpose of being quite alone and of confiding their troubles more freely to each other when suddenly the sound of voices struck upon their ears

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Ah, ah! said those who surrounded the narrator. Nothing can be more interesting.
children.prevalue: Ah ah said those who surrounded the narrator Nothing can be more interesting

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: At this point, Madame, like a vigilant general inspecting his army, glanced at Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, who could not help wincing as they drew themselves up.
children.prevalue: At this point Madame like a vigilant general inspecting his army glanced at Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente who could not help wincing as they drew themselves up

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: These harmonious voices, resumed SaintAignan, were those of certain shepherdesses, who had been likewise desirous of enjoying the coolness of the shade, and who, knowing the isolated and almost unapproachable situation of the place, had betaken themselves there to interchange their ideas upon A loud burst of laughter occasioned by this remark of SaintAignan, and an imperceptible smile of the king, as he looked at TonnayCharente, followed this sally.
children.prevalue: These harmonious voices resumed SaintAignan were those of certain shepherdesses who had been likewise desirous of enjoying the coolness of the shade and who knowing the isolated and almost unapproachable situation of the place had betaken themselves there to interchange their ideas upon A loud burst of laughter occasioned by this remark of SaintAignan and an imperceptible smile of the king as he looked at TonnayCharente followed this sally

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: The Dryad affirms positively, continued SaintAignan, that the shepherdesses were three in number, and that all three were young and beautiful.
children.prevalue: The Dryad affirms positively continued SaintAignan that the shepherdesses were three in number and that all three were young and beautiful

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: What were their names? said Madame, quickly.
children.prevalue: What were their names said Madame quickly

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Their names? said SaintAignan, who hesitated from fear of committing an indiscretion.
children.prevalue: Their names said SaintAignan who hesitated from fear of committing an indiscretion

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Of course; you call your shepherds Tyrcis and Amyntas; give your shepherdesses names in a similar manner.
children.prevalue: Of course you call your shepherds Tyrcis and Amyntas give your shepherdesses names in a similar manner

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Oh! Madame, I am not an inventor; I relate simply what took place as the Dryad related it to me.
children.prevalue: Oh Madame I am not an inventor I relate simply what took place as the Dryad related it to me

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: What did your Dryad, then, call these shepherdesses? You have a very treacherous memory, I fear. This Dryad must have fallen out with the goddess Mnemosyne.
children.prevalue: What did your Dryad then call these shepherdesses You have a very treacherous memory I fear This Dryad must have fallen out with the goddess Mnemosyne

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: These shepherdesses, Madame? Pray remember that it is a crime to betray a woman's name.
children.prevalue: These shepherdesses Madame Pray remember that it is a crime to betray a woman s name

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: From which a woman absolves you, comte, on the condition that you will reveal the names of the shepherdesses.
children.prevalue: From which a woman absolves you comte on the condition that you will reveal the names of the shepherdesses

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Their names were Phyllis, Amaryllis, and Galatea.
children.prevalue: Their names were Phyllis Amaryllis and Galatea

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Exceedingly well!they have not lost by the delay, said Madame, and now we have three charming names. But now for their portraits.
children.prevalue: Exceedingly well they have not lost by the delay said Madame and now we have three charming names But now for their portraits

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: SaintAignan again made a slight movement.
children.prevalue: SaintAignan again made a slight movement

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Nay, comte, let us proceed in due order, returned Madame. Ought we not, sire, to have the portraits of the shepherdesses?
children.prevalue: Nay comte let us proceed in due order returned Madame Ought we not sire to have the portraits of the shepherdesses

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: The king, who expected this determined perseverance, and who began to feel some uneasiness, did not think it safe to provoke so dangerous an interrogator. He thought, too, that SaintAignan, in drawing the portraits, would find a means of insinuating some flattering allusions which would be agreeable to the ears of one his majesty was interested in pleasing. It was with this hope and with this fear that Louis authorized SaintAignan to sketch the portraits of the shepherdesses, Phyllis, Amaryllis, and Galatea.
children.prevalue: The king who expected this determined perseverance and who began to feel some uneasiness did not think it safe to provoke so dangerous an interrogator He thought too that SaintAignan in drawing the portraits would find a means of insinuating some flattering allusions which would be agreeable to the ears of one his majesty was interested in pleasing It was with this hope and with this fear that Louis authorized SaintAignan to sketch the portraits of the shepherdesses Phyllis Amaryllis and Galatea

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Very well, then; be it so, said SaintAignan, like a man who has made up his mind, and he began.
children.prevalue: Very well then be it so said SaintAignan like a man who has made up his mind and he began

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Phyllis, said SaintAignan, with a glance of defiance at Montalais, such as a fencingmaster would give who invites an antagonist worthy of him to place himself on guard, Phyllis is neither fair nor dark, neither tall nor short, neither too grave nor too gay; though but a shepherdess, she is as witty as a princess, and as coquettish as the most finished flirt that ever lived. Nothing can equal her excellent vision. Her heart yearns for everything her gaze embraces. She is like a bird, which, always warbling, at one moment skims the ground, at the next rises fluttering in pursuit of a butterfly, then rests itself upon the topmost branch of a tree, where it defies the birdcatchers either to come and seize it or to entrap it in their nets. The portrait bore such a strong resemblance to Montalais, that all eyes were directed towards her; she, however, with her head raised, and with a steady, unmoved look, listened to SaintAignan, as if he were speaking of an utter stranger.
children.prevalue: Phyllis said SaintAignan with a glance of defiance at Montalais such as a fencingmaster would give who invites an antagonist worthy of him to place himself on guard Phyllis is neither fair nor dark neither tall nor short neither too grave nor too gay though but a shepherdess she is as witty as a princess and as coquettish as the most finished flirt that ever lived Nothing can equal her excellent vision Her heart yearns for everything her gaze embraces She is like a bird which always warbling at one moment skims the ground at the next rises fluttering in pursuit of a butterfly then rests itself upon the topmost branch of a tree where it defies the birdcatchers either to come and seize it or to entrap it in their nets The portrait bore such a strong resemblance to Montalais that all eyes were directed towards her she however with her head raised and with a steady unmoved look listened to SaintAignan as if he were speaking of an utter stranger

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Is that all, Monsieur de SaintAignan? inquired the princess.
children.prevalue: Is that all Monsieur de SaintAignan inquired the princess

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Oh! your royal highness, the portrait is but a mere sketch, and many more additions could be made, but I fear to weary your patience, or offend the modesty of the shepherdess, and I shall therefore pass on to her companion, Amaryllis.
children.prevalue: Oh your royal highness the portrait is but a mere sketch and many more additions could be made but I fear to weary your patience or offend the modesty of the shepherdess and I shall therefore pass on to her companion Amaryllis

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Very well, said Madame, pass on to Amaryllis, Monsieur de SaintAignan, we are all attention.
children.prevalue: Very well said Madame pass on to Amaryllis Monsieur de SaintAignan we are all attention

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Amaryllis is the eldest of the three, and yet, SaintAignan hastened to add, this advanced age does not reach twenty years.
children.prevalue: Amaryllis is the eldest of the three and yet SaintAignan hastened to add this advanced age does not reach twenty years

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, who had slightly knitted her brows at the commencement of the description, unbent them with a smile.
children.prevalue: Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente who had slightly knitted her brows at the commencement of the description unbent them with a smile

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: She is tall, with an astonishing abundance of beautiful hair, which she fastens in the manner of the Grecian statues; her walk is full of majesty, her attitude haughty; she has the air, therefore, rather of a goddess than a mere mortal, and among the goddesses, she most resembles Diana the huntress; with this sole difference, however, that the cruel shepherdess, having stolen the quiver of young love, while poor Cupid was sleeping in a thicket of roses, instead of directing her arrows against the inhabitants of the forest, discharges them pitilessly against all poor shepherds who pass within reach of her bow and of her eyes.
children.prevalue: She is tall with an astonishing abundance of beautiful hair which she fastens in the manner of the Grecian statues her walk is full of majesty her attitude haughty she has the air therefore rather of a goddess than a mere mortal and among the goddesses she most resembles Diana the huntress with this sole difference however that the cruel shepherdess having stolen the quiver of young love while poor Cupid was sleeping in a thicket of roses instead of directing her arrows against the inhabitants of the forest discharges them pitilessly against all poor shepherds who pass within reach of her bow and of her eyes

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Oh! what a wicked shepherdess! said Madame. She may some day wound herself with one of those arrows she discharges, as you say, so mercilessly on all sides.
children.prevalue: Oh what a wicked shepherdess said Madame She may some day wound herself with one of those arrows she discharges as you say so mercilessly on all sides

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: It is the hope of shepherds, one and all! said SaintAignan.
children.prevalue: It is the hope of shepherds one and all said SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: And that of the shepherd Amyntas in particular, I suppose? said Madame.
children.prevalue: And that of the shepherd Amyntas in particular I suppose said Madame

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The shepherd Amyntas is so timid, said SaintAignan, with the most modest air he could assume, that if he cherishes such a hope as that, no one has ever known anything about it, for he conceals it in the very depths of his heart. A flattering murmur of applause greeted this profession of faith on behalf of the shepherd.
children.prevalue: The shepherd Amyntas is so timid said SaintAignan with the most modest air he could assume that if he cherishes such a hope as that no one has ever known anything about it for he conceals it in the very depths of his heart A flattering murmur of applause greeted this profession of faith on behalf of the shepherd

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: And Galatea? inquired Madame. I am impatient to see a hand so skillful as yours continue the portrait where Virgil left it, and finish it before our eyes.
children.prevalue: And Galatea inquired Madame I am impatient to see a hand so skillful as yours continue the portrait where Virgil left it and finish it before our eyes

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Madame, said SaintAignan, I am indeed a poor dumb post beside the mighty Virgil. Still, encouraged by your desire, I will do my best.
children.prevalue: Madame said SaintAignan I am indeed a poor dumb post beside the mighty Virgil Still encouraged by your desire I will do my best

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: SaintAignan extended his foot and hand, and thus began:White as milk, she casts upon the breeze the perfume of her fair hair tinged with golden hues, as are the ears of corn. One is tempted to inquire if she is not the beautiful Europa, who inspired Jupiter with a tender passion as she played with her companions in the flowerspangled meadows. From her exquisite eyes, blue as azure heaven on the clearest summer day, emanates a tender light, which reverie nurtures, and love dispenses. When she frowns, or bends her looks towards the ground, the sun is veiled in token of mourning. When she smiles, on the contrary, nature resumes her jollity, and the birds, for a brief moment silenced, recommence their songs amid the leafy covert of the trees. Galatea, said SaintAignan, in conclusion, is worthy of the admiration of the whole world; and if she should ever bestow her heart upon another, happy will that man be to whom she consecrates her first affections.
children.prevalue: SaintAignan extended his foot and hand and thus began White as milk she casts upon the breeze the perfume of her fair hair tinged with golden hues as are the ears of corn One is tempted to inquire if she is not the beautiful Europa who inspired Jupiter with a tender passion as she played with her companions in the flowerspangled meadows From her exquisite eyes blue as azure heaven on the clearest summer day emanates a tender light which reverie nurtures and love dispenses When she frowns or bends her looks towards the ground the sun is veiled in token of mourning When she smiles on the contrary nature resumes her jollity and the birds for a brief moment silenced recommence their songs amid the leafy covert of the trees Galatea said SaintAignan in conclusion is worthy of the admiration of the whole world and if she should ever bestow her heart upon another happy will that man be to whom she consecrates her first affections

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Madame, who had attentively listened to the portrait SaintAignan had drawn, as, indeed, had all the others, contented herself with accentuating her approbation of the most poetic passage by occasional inclinations of her head; but it was impossible to say if these marks of assent were accorded to the ability of the narrator of the resemblance of the portrait. The consequence, therefore, was, that as Madame did not openly exhibit any approbation, no one felt authorized to applaud, not even Monsieur, who secretly thought that SaintAignan dwelt too much upon the portraits of the shepherdesses, and had somewhat slightingly passed over the portraits of the shepherds. The whole assembly seemed suddenly chilled. SaintAignan, who had exhausted his rhetorical skill and his palette of artistic tints in sketching the portrait of Galatea, and who, after the favor with which his other descriptions had been received, already imagined he could hear the loudest applause allotted to this last one, was himself more disappointed than the king and the rest of the company. A moment's silence followed, which was at last broken by Madame.
children.prevalue: Madame who had attentively listened to the portrait SaintAignan had drawn as indeed had all the others contented herself with accentuating her approbation of the most poetic passage by occasional inclinations of her head but it was impossible to say if these marks of assent were accorded to the ability of the narrator of the resemblance of the portrait The consequence therefore was that as Madame did not openly exhibit any approbation no one felt authorized to applaud not even Monsieur who secretly thought that SaintAignan dwelt too much upon the portraits of the shepherdesses and had somewhat slightingly passed over the portraits of the shepherds The whole assembly seemed suddenly chilled SaintAignan who had exhausted his rhetorical skill and his palette of artistic tints in sketching the portrait of Galatea and who after the favor with which his other descriptions had been received already imagined he could hear the loudest applause allotted to this last one was himself more disappointed than the king and the rest of the company A moment s silence followed which was at last broken by Madame

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Well, sir, she inquired, What is your majesty's opinion of these three portraits?
children.prevalue: Well sir she inquired What is your majesty s opinion of these three portraits

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: The king, who wished to relieve SaintAignan's embarrassment without compromising himself, replied, Why, Amaryllis, in my opinion, is beautiful.
children.prevalue: The king who wished to relieve SaintAignan s embarrassment without compromising himself replied Why Amaryllis in my opinion is beautiful

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: For my part, said Monsieur, I prefer Phyllis; she is a capital girl, or rather a goodsortoffellow of a nymph.
children.prevalue: For my part said Monsieur I prefer Phyllis she is a capital girl or rather a goodsortoffellow of a nymph

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: A gentle laugh followed, and this time the looks were so direct, that Montalais felt herself blushing almost scarlet.
children.prevalue: A gentle laugh followed and this time the looks were so direct that Montalais felt herself blushing almost scarlet

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Well, resumed Madame, what were those shepherdesses saying to each other?
children.prevalue: Well resumed Madame what were those shepherdesses saying to each other

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: SaintAignan, however, whose vanity had been wounded, did not feel himself in a position to sustain an attack of new and refreshed troops, and merely said, Madame, the shepherdesses were confiding to one another their little preferences.
children.prevalue: SaintAignan however whose vanity had been wounded did not feel himself in a position to sustain an attack of new and refreshed troops and merely said Madame the shepherdesses were confiding to one another their little preferences

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Nay, nay! Monsieur de SaintAignan, you are a perfect stream of pastoral poesy, said Madame, with an amiable smile, which somewhat comforted the narrator.
children.prevalue: Nay nay Monsieur de SaintAignan you are a perfect stream of pastoral poesy said Madame with an amiable smile which somewhat comforted the narrator

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: They confessed that love is a mighty peril, but that the absence of love is the heart's sentence of death.
children.prevalue: They confessed that love is a mighty peril but that the absence of love is the heart s sentence of death

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: What was the conclusion they came to? inquired Madame.
children.prevalue: What was the conclusion they came to inquired Madame

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: They came to the conclusion that love was necessary.
children.prevalue: They came to the conclusion that love was necessary

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Very good! Did they lay down any conditions?
children.prevalue: Very good Did they lay down any conditions

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: That of choice, simply, said SaintAignan. I ought even to add,remember it is the Dryad who is speaking,that one of the shepherdesses, Amaryllis, I believe, was completely opposed to the necessity of loving, and yet she did not positively deny that she had allowed the image of a certain shepherd to take refuge in her heart.
children.prevalue: That of choice simply said SaintAignan I ought even to add remember it is the Dryad who is speaking that one of the shepherdesses Amaryllis I believe was completely opposed to the necessity of loving and yet she did not positively deny that she had allowed the image of a certain shepherd to take refuge in her heart

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Was it Amyntas or Tyrcis?
children.prevalue: Was it Amyntas or Tyrcis

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Amyntas, Madame, said SaintAignan, modestly. But Galatea, the gentle and softeyed Galatea, immediately replied, that neither Amyntas, nor Alphesiboeus, nor Tityrus, nor indeed any of the handsomest shepherds of the country, were to be compared to Tyrcis; that Tyrcis was as superior to all other men, as the oak to all other trees, as the lily in its majesty to all other flowers. She drew even such a portrait of Tyrcis that Tyrcis himself, who was listening, must have felt truly flattered at it, notwithstanding his rank as a shepherd. Thus Tyrcis and Amyntas had been distinguished by Phyllis and Galatea; and thus had the secrets of two hearts revealed beneath the shades of evening, and amid the recesses of the woods. Such, Madame, is what the Dryad related to me; she who knows all that takes place in the hollows of oaks and grassy dells; she who knows the loves of the birds, and all they wish to convey by their songs; she who understands, in fact, the language of the wind among the branches, the humming of the insect with its gold and emerald wings in the corolla of the wildflowers; it was she who related the particulars to me, and I have repeated them.
children.prevalue: Amyntas Madame said SaintAignan modestly But Galatea the gentle and softeyed Galatea immediately replied that neither Amyntas nor Alphesiboeus nor Tityrus nor indeed any of the handsomest shepherds of the country were to be compared to Tyrcis that Tyrcis was as superior to all other men as the oak to all other trees as the lily in its majesty to all other flowers She drew even such a portrait of Tyrcis that Tyrcis himself who was listening must have felt truly flattered at it notwithstanding his rank as a shepherd Thus Tyrcis and Amyntas had been distinguished by Phyllis and Galatea and thus had the secrets of two hearts revealed beneath the shades of evening and amid the recesses of the woods Such Madame is what the Dryad related to me she who knows all that takes place in the hollows of oaks and grassy dells she who knows the loves of the birds and all they wish to convey by their songs she who understands in fact the language of the wind among the branches the humming of the insect with its gold and emerald wings in the corolla of the wildflowers it was she who related the particulars to me and I have repeated them

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: And now you have finished, Monsieur de SaintAignan, have you not? said Madame, with a smile that made the king tremble.
children.prevalue: And now you have finished Monsieur de SaintAignan have you not said Madame with a smile that made the king tremble

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Quite finished, replied SaintAignan, and but too happy if I have been able to amuse your royal highness for a few moments.
children.prevalue: Quite finished replied SaintAignan and but too happy if I have been able to amuse your royal highness for a few moments

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Moments which have been too brief, replied the princess; for you have related most admirably all you know; but, my dear Monsieur de SaintAignan, you have been unfortunate enough to obtain your information from one Dryad only, I believe?
children.prevalue: Moments which have been too brief replied the princess for you have related most admirably all you know but my dear Monsieur de SaintAignan you have been unfortunate enough to obtain your information from one Dryad only I believe

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Yes, Madame, only from one, I confess.
children.prevalue: Yes Madame only from one I confess

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The fact was, that you passed by a little Naiad, who pretended to know nothing at all, and yet knew a great deal more than your Dryad, my dear comte.
children.prevalue: The fact was that you passed by a little Naiad who pretended to know nothing at all and yet knew a great deal more than your Dryad my dear comte

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: A Naiad! repeated several voices, who began to suspect that the story had a continuation.
children.prevalue: A Naiad repeated several voices who began to suspect that the story had a continuation

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Of course close beside the oak you are speaking of, which, if I am not mistaken, is called the royal oakis it not so, Monsieur de SaintAignan?
children.prevalue: Of course close beside the oak you are speaking of which if I am not mistaken is called the royal oakis it not so Monsieur de SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: SaintAignan and the king exchanged glances.
children.prevalue: SaintAignan and the king exchanged glances

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Yes, Madame, the former replied.
children.prevalue: Yes Madame the former replied

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Well, close beside the oak there is a pretty little spring, which runs murmuringly over the pebbles, between banks of forgetmenots and daffodils.
children.prevalue: Well close beside the oak there is a pretty little spring which runs murmuringly over the pebbles between banks of forgetmenots and daffodils

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I believe you are correct, said the king, with some uneasiness, and listening with some anxiety to his sisterinlaw's narrative.
children.prevalue: I believe you are correct said the king with some uneasiness and listening with some anxiety to his sisterinlaw s narrative

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Oh! there is one, I can assure you, said Madame; and the proof of it is, that the Naiad who resides in that little stream stopped me as I was about to come.
children.prevalue: Oh there is one I can assure you said Madame and the proof of it is that the Naiad who resides in that little stream stopped me as I was about to come

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Ah? said SaintAignan.
children.prevalue: Ah said SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Yes, indeed, continued the princess, and she did so in order to communicate to me many particulars Monsieur de SaintAignan has omitted in his recital.
children.prevalue: Yes indeed continued the princess and she did so in order to communicate to me many particulars Monsieur de SaintAignan has omitted in his recital

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Pray relate them yourself, then, said Monsieur, you can relate stories in such a charming manner. The princess bowed at the conjugal compliment paid her.
children.prevalue: Pray relate them yourself then said Monsieur you can relate stories in such a charming manner The princess bowed at the conjugal compliment paid her

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: I do not possess the poetical powers of the comte, nor his ability to bring to light the smallest details.
children.prevalue: I do not possess the poetical powers of the comte nor his ability to bring to light the smallest details

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: You will not be listened to with less interest on that account, said the king, who already perceived that something hostile was intended in his sisterinlaw's story.
children.prevalue: You will not be listened to with less interest on that account said the king who already perceived that something hostile was intended in his sisterinlaw s story

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: I speak, too, continued Madame, in the name of that poor little Naiad, who is indeed the most charming creature I ever met. Moreover, she laughed so heartily while she was telling me her story, that, in pursuance of that medical axiom that laughter is the finest physic in the world, I ask permission to laugh a little myself when I recollect her words.
children.prevalue: I speak too continued Madame in the name of that poor little Naiad who is indeed the most charming creature I ever met Moreover she laughed so heartily while she was telling me her story that in pursuance of that medical axiom that laughter is the finest physic in the world I ask permission to laugh a little myself when I recollect her words

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The king and SaintAignan, who noticed spreading over many of the faces present a distant and prophetic ripple of the laughter Madame announced, finished by looking at each other, as if asking themselves whether there was not some little conspiracy concealed beneath these words. But Madame was determined to turn the knife in the wound over and over again; she therefore resumed with the air of the most perfect candor, in other words, with the most dangerous of all her airs: Well, then, I passed that way, she said, and as I found beneath my steps many fresh flowers newly blown, no doubt Phyllis, Amaryllis, Galatea, and all your shepherdesses had passed the same way before me.
children.prevalue: The king and SaintAignan who noticed spreading over many of the faces present a distant and prophetic ripple of the laughter Madame announced finished by looking at each other as if asking themselves whether there was not some little conspiracy concealed beneath these words But Madame was determined to turn the knife in the wound over and over again she therefore resumed with the air of the most perfect candor in other words with the most dangerous of all her airs Well then I passed that way she said and as I found beneath my steps many fresh flowers newly blown no doubt Phyllis Amaryllis Galatea and all your shepherdesses had passed the same way before me

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: The king bit his lips, for the recital was becoming more and more threatening. My little Naiad, continued Madame, was cooing over her quaint song in the bed of the rivulet; as I perceived that she accosted me by touching the hem of my dress, I could not think of receiving her advances ungraciously, and more particularly so, since, after all, a divinity, even though she be of a second grade, is always of greater importance than a mortal, though a princess. I thereupon accosted the Naiad, and bursting into laughter, this is what she said to me:
children.prevalue: The king bit his lips for the recital was becoming more and more threatening My little Naiad continued Madame was cooing over her quaint song in the bed of the rivulet as I perceived that she accosted me by touching the hem of my dress I could not think of receiving her advances ungraciously and more particularly so since after all a divinity even though she be of a second grade is always of greater importance than a mortal though a princess I thereupon accosted the Naiad and bursting into laughter this is what she said to me

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: 'Fancy, princess...' You understand, sire, it is the Naiad who is speaking?
children.prevalue: Fancy princess You understand sire it is the Naiad who is speaking

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: The king bowed assentingly; and Madame continued:'Fancy, princess, the banks of my little stream have just witnessed a most amusing scene. Two shepherds, full of curiosity, even indiscreetly so, have allowed themselves to be mystified in a most amusing manner by three nymphs, or three shepherdesses,'I beg your pardon, but I do not now remember if it was nymphs or shepherdesses she said; but it does not much matter, so we will continue.
children.prevalue: The king bowed assentingly and Madame continued Fancy princess the banks of my little stream have just witnessed a most amusing scene Two shepherds full of curiosity even indiscreetly so have allowed themselves to be mystified in a most amusing manner by three nymphs or three shepherdesses I beg your pardon but I do not now remember if it was nymphs or shepherdesses she said but it does not much matter so we will continue

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: The king, at this opening, colored visibly, and SaintAignan, completely losing countenance, began to open his eyes in the greatest possible anxiety.
children.prevalue: The king at this opening colored visibly and SaintAignan completely losing countenance began to open his eyes in the greatest possible anxiety

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: 'The two shepherds,' pursued my nymph, still laughing, 'followed in the wake of the three young ladies,'no, I mean, of the three nymphs; forgive me, I ought to say, of the three shepherdesses. It is not always wise to do that, for it may be awkward for those who are followed. I appeal to all the ladies present, and not one of them, I am sure, will contradict me.
children.prevalue: The two shepherds pursued my nymph still laughing followed in the wake of the three young ladies no I mean of the three nymphs forgive me I ought to say of the three shepherdesses It is not always wise to do that for it may be awkward for those who are followed I appeal to all the ladies present and not one of them I am sure will contradict me

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: The king, who was much disturbed by what he suspected was about to follow, signified his assent by a gesture.
children.prevalue: The king who was much disturbed by what he suspected was about to follow signified his assent by a gesture

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: 'But,' continued the Naiad, 'the shepherdesses had noticed Tyrcis and Amyntas gliding into the wood, and, by the light of the moon, they had recognized them through the grove of the trees.' Ah, you laugh! interrupted Madame; wait, wait, you are not yet at the end.
children.prevalue: But continued the Naiad the shepherdesses had noticed Tyrcis and Amyntas gliding into the wood and by the light of the moon they had recognized them through the grove of the trees Ah you laugh interrupted Madame wait wait you are not yet at the end

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: The king turned pale; SaintAignan wiped his forehead, now dewed with perspiration. Among the groups of ladies present could be heard smothered laughter and stealthy whispers.
children.prevalue: The king turned pale SaintAignan wiped his forehead now dewed with perspiration Among the groups of ladies present could be heard smothered laughter and stealthy whispers

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: 'The shepherdesses, I was saying, noticing how indiscreet the two shepherds were, proceeded to sit down at the foot of the royal oak; and, when they perceived that their overcurious listeners were sufficiently near, so that not a syllable of what they might say could be lost, they addressed towards them very innocently, in the most artless manner in the world indeed, a passionate declaration, which from the vanity natural to all men, and even to the most sentimental of shepherds, seemed to the two listeners as sweet as honey.'
children.prevalue: The shepherdesses I was saying noticing how indiscreet the two shepherds were proceeded to sit down at the foot of the royal oak and when they perceived that their overcurious listeners were sufficiently near so that not a syllable of what they might say could be lost they addressed towards them very innocently in the most artless manner in the world indeed a passionate declaration which from the vanity natural to all men and even to the most sentimental of shepherds seemed to the two listeners as sweet as honey

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: The king, at these words, which the assembly was unable to hear without laughing, could not restrain a flash of anger darting from his eyes. As for SaintAignan, he let his head fall upon his breast, and concealed, under a silly laugh, the extreme annoyance he felt.
children.prevalue: The king at these words which the assembly was unable to hear without laughing could not restrain a flash of anger darting from his eyes As for SaintAignan he let his head fall upon his breast and concealed under a silly laugh the extreme annoyance he felt

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Oh, said the king, drawing himself up to his full height, upon my word, that is a most amusing jest, certainly; but, really and truly, are you sure you quite understood the language of the Naiads?
children.prevalue: Oh said the king drawing himself up to his full height upon my word that is a most amusing jest certainly but really and truly are you sure you quite understood the language of the Naiads

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: The comte, sire, pretends to have perfectly understood that of the Dryads, retorted Madame, icily.
children.prevalue: The comte sire pretends to have perfectly understood that of the Dryads retorted Madame icily

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: No doubt, said the king; but you know the comte has the weakness to aspire to become a member of the Academy, so that, with this object in view, he has learnt all sorts of things of which very happily you are ignorant; and it might possibly happen that the language of the Nymph of the Waters might be among the number of things you have not studied.
children.prevalue: No doubt said the king but you know the comte has the weakness to aspire to become a member of the Academy so that with this object in view he has learnt all sorts of things of which very happily you are ignorant and it might possibly happen that the language of the Nymph of the Waters might be among the number of things you have not studied

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Of course, sire, replied Madame, for facts of that nature one does not altogether rely upon one's self alone; a woman's ear is not infallible, so says Saint Augustine; and I, therefore, wished to satisfy myself by other opinions beside my own, and as my Naiad, who, in her character of a goddess, is polyglot,is not that the expression, M. de SaintAignan?
children.prevalue: Of course sire replied Madame for facts of that nature one does not altogether rely upon one s self alone a woman s ear is not infallible so says Saint Augustine and I therefore wished to satisfy myself by other opinions beside my own and as my Naiad who in her character of a goddess is polyglot is not that the expression M de SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: I believe so, said the latter, quite out of countenance.
children.prevalue: I believe so said the latter quite out of countenance

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Well, continued the princess, as my Naiad, who, in her character of a goddess, had, at first spoken to me in English, I feared, as you suggest, that I might have misunderstood her, and I requested Mesdemoiselles de Montalais, de TonnayCharente, and de la Valliere, to come to me, begging my Naiad to repeat to me in the French language, the recital she had already communicated to me in English.
children.prevalue: Well continued the princess as my Naiad who in her character of a goddess had at first spoken to me in English I feared as you suggest that I might have misunderstood her and I requested Mesdemoiselles de Montalais de TonnayCharente and de la Valliere to come to me begging my Naiad to repeat to me in the French language the recital she had already communicated to me in English

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: And did she do so? inquired the king.
children.prevalue: And did she do so inquired the king

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Oh, she is the most polite divinity it is possible to imagine! Yes, sire, she did so; so that no doubt whatever remains on the subject. Is it not so, young ladies? said the princess, turning towards the left of her army; did not the Naiad say precisely what I have related, and have I, in any one particular, exceeded the truth, Phyllis? I beg your pardon, I mean Mademoiselle Aure de Montalais?
children.prevalue: Oh she is the most polite divinity it is possible to imagine Yes sire she did so so that no doubt whatever remains on the subject Is it not so young ladies said the princess turning towards the left of her army did not the Naiad say precisely what I have related and have I in any one particular exceeded the truth Phyllis I beg your pardon I mean Mademoiselle Aure de Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Precisely as you have stated, Madame, articulated Mademoiselle de Montalais, very distinctly.
children.prevalue: Precisely as you have stated Madame articulated Mademoiselle de Montalais very distinctly

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Is it true, Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente?
children.prevalue: Is it true Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: The perfect truth, replied Athenais, in a voice quite as firm, but not yet so distinct.
children.prevalue: The perfect truth replied Athenais in a voice quite as firm but not yet so distinct

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: And you, La Valliere? asked Madame.
children.prevalue: And you La Valliere asked Madame

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: The poor girl felt the king's ardent look fixed upon her,she dared not denyshe dared not tell a falsehood; she merely bowed her head; and everybody took it for a token of assent. Her head, however, was not raised again, chilled as she was by a coldness more bitter than that of death. This triple testimony overwhelmed the king. As for SaintAignan, he did not even attempt to dissemble his despair, and, hardly knowing what he said, he stammered out, An excellent jest! admirably played!
children.prevalue: The poor girl felt the king s ardent look fixed upon her she dared not denyshe dared not tell a falsehood she merely bowed her head and everybody took it for a token of assent Her head however was not raised again chilled as she was by a coldness more bitter than that of death This triple testimony overwhelmed the king As for SaintAignan he did not even attempt to dissemble his despair and hardly knowing what he said he stammered out An excellent jest admirably played

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: A just punishment for curiosity, said the king, in a hoarse voice. Oh! who would think, after the chastisement that Tyrcis and Amyntas had suffered, of endeavoring to surprise what is passing in the heart of shepherdesses? Assuredly I shall not, for one; and, you, gentlemen?
children.prevalue: A just punishment for curiosity said the king in a hoarse voice Oh who would think after the chastisement that Tyrcis and Amyntas had suffered of endeavoring to surprise what is passing in the heart of shepherdesses Assuredly I shall not for one and you gentlemen

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Nor I! nor I! repeated, in a chorus, the group of courtiers.
children.prevalue: Nor I nor I repeated in a chorus the group of courtiers

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Madame was filled with triumph at the king's annoyance; and was full of delight, thinking that her story had been, or was to be, the termination of the whole affair. As for Monsieur, who had laughed at the two stories without comprehending anything about them, he turned towards De Guiche, and said to him, Well, comte, you say nothing; can you not find something to say? Do you pity M. Tyrcis and M. Amyntas, for instance?
children.prevalue: Madame was filled with triumph at the king s annoyance and was full of delight thinking that her story had been or was to be the termination of the whole affair As for Monsieur who had laughed at the two stories without comprehending anything about them he turned towards De Guiche and said to him Well comte you say nothing can you not find something to say Do you pity M Tyrcis and M Amyntas for instance

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: I pity them with all my soul, replied De Guiche; for, in very truth, love is so sweet a fancy, that to lose it, fancy though it may be, is to lose more than life itself. If, therefore, these two shepherds thought themselves beloved,if they were happy in that idea, and if, instead of that happiness, they meet not only that empty void which resembles death, but jeers and jests at love itself, which is worse than a thousand deaths,in that case, I say that Tyrcis and Amyntas are the two most unhappy men I know.
children.prevalue: I pity them with all my soul replied De Guiche for in very truth love is so sweet a fancy that to lose it fancy though it may be is to lose more than life itself If therefore these two shepherds thought themselves beloved if they were happy in that idea and if instead of that happiness they meet not only that empty void which resembles death but jeers and jests at love itself which is worse than a thousand deaths in that case I say that Tyrcis and Amyntas are the two most unhappy men I know

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: And you are right, too, Monsieur de Guiche, said the king; for, in fact, the injury in question is a very hard return for a little harmless curiosity.
children.prevalue: And you are right too Monsieur de Guiche said the king for in fact the injury in question is a very hard return for a little harmless curiosity

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: That is as much to say, then, that the story of my Naiad has displeased the king? asked Madame, innocently.
children.prevalue: That is as much to say then that the story of my Naiad has displeased the king asked Madame innocently

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Nay, Madame, undeceive yourself, said Louis, taking the princess by the hand; your Naiad, on the contrary, has pleased me, and the more so, because she was so truthful, and because her tale, I ought to add, is confirmed by the testimony of unimpeachable witnesses.
children.prevalue: Nay Madame undeceive yourself said Louis taking the princess by the hand your Naiad on the contrary has pleased me and the more so because she was so truthful and because her tale I ought to add is confirmed by the testimony of unimpeachable witnesses

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: These words fell upon La Valliere, accompanied by a look that on one, from Socrates to Montaigne, could have exactly defined. The look and the king's remark succeeded in overpowering the unhappy girl, who, with her head upon Montalais's shoulder, seemed to have fainted away. The king rose, without remarking this circumstance, of which no one, moreover, took any notice, and, contrary to his usual custom, for generally he remained late in Madame's apartments, he took his leave, and retired to his own side of the palace. SaintAignan followed him, leaving the rooms in as much despair as he had entered them with delight. Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, less sensitive than La Valliere, was not much frightened, and did not faint. However, it may be that the last look of SaintAignan had hardly been so majestic as the king's.
