children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The king returned to his apartments with hurried steps. The reason he walked as fast as he did was probably to avoid tottering in his gait. He seemed to leave behind him as he went along a trace of a mysterious sorrow. That gayety of manner, which every one had remarked in him on his arrival, and which they had been delighted to perceive, had not perhaps been understood in its true sense: but his stormy departure, his disordered countenance, all knew, or at least thought they could tell the reason of. Madame's levity of manner, her somewhat bitter jests,bitter for persons of a sensitive disposition, and particularly for one of the king's character; the great resemblance which naturally existed between the king and an ordinary mortal, were among the reasons assigned for the precipitate and unexpected departure of his majesty. Madame, keensighted enough in other respects, did not, however, at first see anything extraordinary in it. It was quite sufficient for her to have inflicted some slight wound upon the vanity or selfesteem of one who, so soon forgetting the engagements he had contracted, seemed to have undertaken to disdain, without cause, the noblest and highest prize in France. It was not an unimportant matter for Madame, in the present position of affairs, to let the king perceive the difference which existed between the bestowal of his affections on one in a high station, and the running after each passing fancy, like a youth fresh from the provinces. With regard to those higher placed affections, recognizing their dignity and their illimitable influence, acknowledging in them a certain etiquette and displaya monarch not only did not act in a manner derogatory to his high position, but found even repose, security, mystery, and general respect therein. On the contrary, in the debasement of a common or humble attachment, he would encounter, even among his meanest subjects, carping and sarcastic remarks; he would forfeit his character of infallibility and inviolability. Having descended to the region of petty human miseries, he would be subjected to paltry contentions. In one word, to convert the royal divinity into a mere mortal by striking at his heart, or rather even at his face, like the meanest of his subjects, was to inflict a terrible blow upon the pride of that generous nature. Louis was more easily captivated by vanity than affection. Madame had wisely calculated her vengeance, and it has been seen, also, in what manner she carried it out. Let it not be supposed, however, that Madame possessed such terrible passions as the heroines of the middle ages, or that she regarded things from a pessimistic point of view; on the contrary, Madame, young, amiable, of cultivated intellect, coquettish, loving in her nature, but rather from fancy, or imagination, or ambition, than from her heartMadame, we say, on the contrary, inaugurated that epoch of light and fleeting amusements, which distinguished the hundred and twenty years that intervened between the middle of the seventeenth century, and the last quarter of the eighteenth. Madame saw, therefore, or rather fancied she saw, things under their true aspect; she knew that the king, her august brotherinlaw, had been the first to ridicule the humble La Valliere, and that, in accordance with his usual custom, it was hardly probable he would ever love the person who had excited his laughter, even had it been only for a moment. Moreover, was not her vanity ever present, that evil influence which plays so important a part in that comedy of dramatic incidents called the life of a woman? Did not her vanity tell her, aloud, in a subdued voice, in a whisper, in every variety of tone, that she could not, in reality, she a princess, young, beautiful, and rich, be compared to the poor La Valliere, as youthful as herself it is true, but far less pretty, certainly, and utterly without money, protectors, or position? And surprise need not be excited with respect to Madame; for it is known that the greatest characters are those who flatter themselves the most in the comparisons they draw between themselves and others, between others and themselves. It may perhaps be asked what was Madame's motive for an attack so skillfully conceived and executed. Why was there such a display of forces, if it were not seriously her intention to dislodge the king from a heart that had never been occupied before, in which he seemed disposed to take refuge? Was there any necessity, then, for Madame to attach so great an importance to La Valliere, if she did not fear her? Yet Madame did not fear La Valliere in that direction in which an historian, who knows everything, sees into the future, or rather, the past. Madame was neither a prophetess nor a sibyl; nor could she, any more than another, read what was written in that terrible and fatal book of the future, which records in its most secret pages the most serious events. No, Madame desired simply to punish the king for having availed himself of secret means altogether feminine in their nature; she wished to prove to him that if he made use of offensive weapons of that nature, she, a woman of ready wit and high descent, would assuredly discover in the arsenal of her imagination defensive weapons proof even against the thrusts of a monarch. Moreover, she wished him to learn that, in a war of that description, kings are held of no account, or, at all events, that kings who fight on their own behalf, like ordinary individuals, may witness the fall of their crown in the first encounter; and that, in fact, if he had expected to be adored by all the ladies of the court from the very first, from a confident reliance on his mere appearance, it was a pretension which was most preposterous and insulting even, for certain persons who filled a higher position than others, and that a lesson taught in season to this royal personage, who assumed too high and haughty a carriage, would be rendering him a great service. Such, indeed, were Madame's reflections with respect to the king. The sequel itself was not thought of. And in this manner, it will be seen that she had exercised all her influence over the minds of her maids of honor, and with all its accompanying details, had arranged the comedy which had just been acted. The king was completely bewildered by it; for the first time since he had escaped from the trammels of M. de Mazarin, he found himself treated as a man. Similar severity from any of his subjects would have been at once resisted by him. Strength comes with battle. But to match one's self with women, to be attacked by them, to have been imposed upon by mere girls from the country, who had come from Blois expressly for that purpose; it was the depth of dishonor for a young sovereign full of the pride his personal advantages and royal power inspired him with. There was nothing he could doneither reproaches, nor exilenor could he even show the annoyance he felt. To manifest vexation would have been to admit that he had been touched, like Hamlet, by a sword from which the button had been removedthe sword of ridicule. To show animosity against womenhumiliation! especially when the women in question have laughter on their side, as a means of vengeance. If, instead of leaving all the responsibility of the affair to these women, one of the courtiers had had anything to do with the intrigue, how delightedly would Louis have seized the opportunity of turning the Bastile to personal account. But there, again, the king's anger paused, checked by reason. To be the master of armies, of prisons, of an almost divine authority, and to exert such majesty and might in the service of a petty grudge, would be unworthy not only of a monarch, but even of a man. It was necessary, therefore, simply to swallow the affront in silence, and to wear his usual gentleness and graciousness of expression. It was essential to treat Madame as a friend. As a friend!Well, and why not? Either Madame had been the instigator of the affair, or the affair itself had found her passive. If she had been the instigator of it, it certainly was a bold measure on her part, but, at all events, it was but natural in her. Who was it that had sought her in the earliest moments of her married life to whisper words of love in her ear? Who was it that had dared to calculate the possibility of committing a crime against the marriage vowa crime, too, still more deplorable on account of the relationship between them? Who was it that, shielded behind his royal authority, had said to this young creature: be not afraid, love but the king of France, who is above all, and a movement of whose sceptered hand will protect you against all attacks, even from your own remorse? And she had listened to and obeyed the royal voice, had been influenced by his ensnaring tones; and when, morally speaking, she had sacrificed her honor in listening to him, she saw herself repaid for her sacrifice by an infidelity the more humiliating, since it was occasioned by a woman far beneath her in the world.

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Had Madame, therefore, been the instigator of the revenge, she would have been right. If, on the contrary, she had remained passive in the whole affair, what grounds had the king to be angry with her on that account? Was it for her to restrain, or rather could she restrain, the chattering of a few country girls? and was it for her, by an excess of zeal that might have been misinterpreted, to check, at the risk of increasing it, the impertinence of their conduct? All these various reasonings were like so many actual stings to the king's pride; but when he had carefully, in his own mind, gone over all the various causes of complaint, Louis was surprised, upon due reflectionin other words, after the wound has been dressedto find that there were other causes of suffering, secret, unendurable, and unrevealed. There was one circumstance he dared not confess, even to himself; namely, that the acute pain from which he was suffering had its seat in his heart. The fact is, he had permitted his heart to be gratified by La Valliere's innocent confusion. He had dreamed of a pure affectionof an affection for Louis the man, and not the sovereignof an affection free from all selfinterest; and his heart, simpler and more youthful than he had imagined it to be, had to meet that other heart that had revealed itself to him by its aspirations. The commonest thing in the complicated history of love, is the double inoculation of love to which any two hearts are subjected; the one loves nearly always before the other, in the same way that the latter finishes nearly always by loving after the other. In this way, the electric current is established, in proportion to the intensity of the passion which is first kindled. The more Mademoiselle de la Valliere showed her affection, the more the king's affection had increased. And it was precisely that which had annoyed his majesty. For it was now fairly demonstrated to him, that no sympathetic current had been the means of hurrying his heart away in its course, because there had been no confession of love in the casebecause the confession was, in fact, an insult towards the man and towards the sovereign; and finally, becauseand the word, too, burnt like a hot ironbecause, in fact, it was nothing but a mystification after all. This girl, therefore, who, in strictness, could not lay claim to beauty, or birth, or great intelligencewho had been selected by Madame herself, on account of her unpretending position, had not only aroused the king's regard, but had, moreover, treated him with disdainhe, the king, a man who, like an eastern potentate, had but to bestow a glance, to indicate with his finger, to throw his handkerchief. And, since the previous evening, his mind had been so absorbed with this girl that he could think and dream of nothing else. Since the previous evening his imagination had been occupied by clothing her image with charms to which she could not lay claim. In very truth, he whom such vast interests summoned, and whom so many women smiled upon invitingly, had, since the previous evening, consecrated every moment of his time, every throb of his heart, to this sole dream. It was, indeed, either too much, or not sufficient. The indignation of the king, making him forget everything, and, among others, that SaintAignan was present, was poured out in the most violent imprecations. True it is, that SaintAignan had taken refuge in a corner of the room; and from his corner, regarded the tempest passing over. His own personal disappointment seemed contemptible, in comparison with the anger of the king. He compared with his own petty vanity the prodigious pride of offended majesty; and, being well read in the hearts of kings in general, and in those of powerful kings in particular, he began to ask himself if this weight of anger, as yet held in suspense, would not soon terminate by falling upon his own head, for the very reason that others were guilty, and he innocent. In point of fact, the king, all at once, did arrest his hurried pace; and, fixing a look full of anger upon SaintAignan, suddenly cried out: And you, SaintAignan?
children.prevalue: Had Madame therefore been the instigator of the revenge she would have been right If on the contrary she had remained passive in the whole affair what grounds had the king to be angry with her on that account Was it for her to restrain or rather could she restrain the chattering of a few country girls and was it for her by an excess of zeal that might have been misinterpreted to check at the risk of increasing it the impertinence of their conduct All these various reasonings were like so many actual stings to the king s pride but when he had carefully in his own mind gone over all the various causes of complaint Louis was surprised upon due reflectionin other words after the wound has been dressedto find that there were other causes of suffering secret unendurable and unrevealed There was one circumstance he dared not confess even to himself namely that the acute pain from which he was suffering had its seat in his heart The fact is he had permitted his heart to be gratified by La Valliere s innocent confusion He had dreamed of a pure affectionof an affection for Louis the man and not the sovereignof an affection free from all selfinterest and his heart simpler and more youthful than he had imagined it to be had to meet that other heart that had revealed itself to him by its aspirations The commonest thing in the complicated history of love is the double inoculation of love to which any two hearts are subjected the one loves nearly always before the other in the same way that the latter finishes nearly always by loving after the other In this way the electric current is established in proportion to the intensity of the passion which is first kindled The more Mademoiselle de la Valliere showed her affection the more the king s affection had increased And it was precisely that which had annoyed his majesty For it was now fairly demonstrated to him that no sympathetic current had been the means of hurrying his heart away in its course because there had been no confession of love in the casebecause the confession was in fact an insult towards the man and towards the sovereign and finally becauseand the word too burnt like a hot ironbecause in fact it was nothing but a mystification after all This girl therefore who in strictness could not lay claim to beauty or birth or great intelligencewho had been selected by Madame herself on account of her unpretending position had not only aroused the king s regard but had moreover treated him with disdainhe the king a man who like an eastern potentate had but to bestow a glance to indicate with his finger to throw his handkerchief And since the previous evening his mind had been so absorbed with this girl that he could think and dream of nothing else Since the previous evening his imagination had been occupied by clothing her image with charms to which she could not lay claim In very truth he whom such vast interests summoned and whom so many women smiled upon invitingly had since the previous evening consecrated every moment of his time every throb of his heart to this sole dream It was indeed either too much or not sufficient The indignation of the king making him forget everything and among others that SaintAignan was present was poured out in the most violent imprecations True it is that SaintAignan had taken refuge in a corner of the room and from his corner regarded the tempest passing over His own personal disappointment seemed contemptible in comparison with the anger of the king He compared with his own petty vanity the prodigious pride of offended majesty and being well read in the hearts of kings in general and in those of powerful kings in particular he began to ask himself if this weight of anger as yet held in suspense would not soon terminate by falling upon his own head for the very reason that others were guilty and he innocent In point of fact the king all at once did arrest his hurried pace and fixing a look full of anger upon SaintAignan suddenly cried out And you SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: SaintAignan made a sign which was intended to signify, Well, sire?
children.prevalue: SaintAignan made a sign which was intended to signify Well sire

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Yes; you have been as silly as myself, I think.
children.prevalue: Yes you have been as silly as myself I think

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Sire, stammered out SaintAignan.
children.prevalue: Sire stammered out SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: You permitted us to be deceived by this shameless trick.
children.prevalue: You permitted us to be deceived by this shameless trick

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Sire, said SaintAignan, whose agitation was such as to make him tremble in every limb, let me entreat your majesty not to exasperate yourself. Women, you know, are characters full of imperfections, created for the misfortune of mankind: to expect anything good from them is to require them to perform impossibilities.
children.prevalue: Sire said SaintAignan whose agitation was such as to make him tremble in every limb let me entreat your majesty not to exasperate yourself Women you know are characters full of imperfections created for the misfortune of mankind to expect anything good from them is to require them to perform impossibilities

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The king, who had the greatest consideration for himself, and who had begun to acquire over his emotions that command which he preserved over them all his life, perceived that he was doing an outrage to his own dignity in displaying so much animosity about so trifling an object. No, he said, hastily; you are mistaken, SaintAignan; I am not angry; I can only wonder that we should have been turned into ridicule so cleverly and with such audacity by these young girls. I am particularly surprised that, although we might have informed ourselves accurately on the subject, we were silly enough to leave the matter for our own hearts to decide.
children.prevalue: The king who had the greatest consideration for himself and who had begun to acquire over his emotions that command which he preserved over them all his life perceived that he was doing an outrage to his own dignity in displaying so much animosity about so trifling an object No he said hastily you are mistaken SaintAignan I am not angry I can only wonder that we should have been turned into ridicule so cleverly and with such audacity by these young girls I am particularly surprised that although we might have informed ourselves accurately on the subject we were silly enough to leave the matter for our own hearts to decide

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The heart, sire, is an organ which requires positively to be reduced to its material functions, but which, for the sake of humanity's peace of mind, should be deprived of all its metaphysical inclinations. For my own part, I confess, when I saw that your majesty's heart was so taken up by this little
children.prevalue: The heart sire is an organ which requires positively to be reduced to its material functions but which for the sake of humanity s peace of mind should be deprived of all its metaphysical inclinations For my own part I confess when I saw that your majesty s heart was so taken up by this little

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: My heart taken up! I! My mind might, perhaps, have been so; but as for my heart, it was Louis again perceived that, in order to fill one gulf, he was about to dig another. Besides, he added, I have no fault to find with the girl. I was quite aware that she was in love with some one else.
children.prevalue: My heart taken up I My mind might perhaps have been so but as for my heart it was Louis again perceived that in order to fill one gulf he was about to dig another Besides he added I have no fault to find with the girl I was quite aware that she was in love with some one else

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The Vicomte de Bragelonne. I informed your majesty of the circumstance.
children.prevalue: The Vicomte de Bragelonne I informed your majesty of the circumstance

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: You did so: but you were not the first who told me. The Comte de la Fere had solicited from me Mademoiselle de la Valliere's hand for his son. And, on his return from England, the marriage shall be celebrated, since they love each other.
children.prevalue: You did so but you were not the first who told me The Comte de la Fere had solicited from me Mademoiselle de la Valliere s hand for his son And on his return from England the marriage shall be celebrated since they love each other

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I recognize your majesty's great generosity of disposition in that act.
children.prevalue: I recognize your majesty s great generosity of disposition in that act

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: So, SaintAignan, we will cease to occupy ourselves with these matters any longer, said Louis.
children.prevalue: So SaintAignan we will cease to occupy ourselves with these matters any longer said Louis

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Yes, we will digest the affront, sire, replied the courtier, with resignation.
children.prevalue: Yes we will digest the affront sire replied the courtier with resignation

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Besides, it will be an easy matter to do so, said the king, checking a sigh.
children.prevalue: Besides it will be an easy matter to do so said the king checking a sigh

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: And, by way of a beginning, I will set about the composition of an epigram upon all three of them. I will call it 'The Naiad and Dryad,' which will please Madame.
children.prevalue: And by way of a beginning I will set about the composition of an epigram upon all three of them I will call it The Naiad and Dryad which will please Madame

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Do so, SaintAignan, do so, said the king, indifferently. You shall read me your verses; they will amuse me. Ah! it does not signify, SaintAignan, added the king, like a man breathing with difficulty, the blow requires more than human strength to support in a dignified manner. As the king thus spoke, assuming an air of the most angelic patience, one of the servants in attendance knocked gently at the door. SaintAignan drew aside, out of respect.
children.prevalue: Do so SaintAignan do so said the king indifferently You shall read me your verses they will amuse me Ah it does not signify SaintAignan added the king like a man breathing with difficulty the blow requires more than human strength to support in a dignified manner As the king thus spoke assuming an air of the most angelic patience one of the servants in attendance knocked gently at the door SaintAignan drew aside out of respect

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Come in, said the king. The servant partially opened the door. What is it? inquired Louis.
children.prevalue: Come in said the king The servant partially opened the door What is it inquired Louis

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The servant held out a letter of a triangular shape. For your majesty, he said.
children.prevalue: The servant held out a letter of a triangular shape For your majesty he said

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: From whom?
children.prevalue: From whom

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I do not know. One of the officers on duty gave it to me.
children.prevalue: I do not know One of the officers on duty gave it to me

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: The valet, in obedience to a gesture of the king, handed him the letter. The king advanced towards the candles, opened the note, read the signature, and uttered a loud cry. SaintAignan was sufficiently respectful not to look on; but, without looking on, he saw and heard all, and ran towards the king, who with a gesture dismissed the servant. Oh, heavens! said the king, as he read the note.
children.prevalue: The valet in obedience to a gesture of the king handed him the letter The king advanced towards the candles opened the note read the signature and uttered a loud cry SaintAignan was sufficiently respectful not to look on but without looking on he saw and heard all and ran towards the king who with a gesture dismissed the servant Oh heavens said the king as he read the note

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Is your majesty unwell? inquired SaintAignan, stretching forward his arms.
children.prevalue: Is your majesty unwell inquired SaintAignan stretching forward his arms

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: No, no, SaintAignanread! and he handed him the note.
children.prevalue: No no SaintAignanread and he handed him the note

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: SaintAignan's eyes fell upon the signature. La Valliere! he exclaimed. Oh, sire!
children.prevalue: SaintAignan s eyes fell upon the signature La Valliere he exclaimed Oh sire

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Read, read!
children.prevalue: Read read

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: And SaintAignan read:
children.prevalue: And SaintAignan read

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Forgive my importunity, sire; and forgive, also, the absence of the formalities which may be wanting in this letter. A note seems to be more speedy and more urgent than a dispatch. I venture, therefore, to address this note to your majesty. I have retired to my own room, overcome with grief and fatigue, sire; and I implore your majesty to grant me the favor of an audience, which will enable me to confess the truth to my sovereign.
children.prevalue: Forgive my importunity sire and forgive also the absence of the formalities which may be wanting in this letter A note seems to be more speedy and more urgent than a dispatch I venture therefore to address this note to your majesty I have retired to my own room overcome with grief and fatigue sire and I implore your majesty to grant me the favor of an audience which will enable me to confess the truth to my sovereign

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: LOUISE de la VALLIERE.
children.prevalue: LOUISE de la VALLIERE

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Well? asked the king, taking the letter from SaintAignan's hands, who was completely bewildered by what he had just read.
children.prevalue: Well asked the king taking the letter from SaintAignan s hands who was completely bewildered by what he had just read

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Well! repeated SaintAignan.
children.prevalue: Well repeated SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: What do you think of it?
children.prevalue: What do you think of it

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: I hardly know.
children.prevalue: I hardly know

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Still, what is your opinion?
children.prevalue: Still what is your opinion

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Sire, the young lady must have heard the muttering of the thunder, and has got frightened.
children.prevalue: Sire the young lady must have heard the muttering of the thunder and has got frightened

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Frightened at what? asked Louis with dignity.
children.prevalue: Frightened at what asked Louis with dignity

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Why, your majesty has a thousand reasons to be angry with the author or authors of so hazardous a joke; and, if your majesty's memory were to be awakened in a disagreeable sense, it would be a perpetual menace hanging over the head of this imprudent girl.
children.prevalue: Why your majesty has a thousand reasons to be angry with the author or authors of so hazardous a joke and if your majesty s memory were to be awakened in a disagreeable sense it would be a perpetual menace hanging over the head of this imprudent girl

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: SaintAignan, I do not think as you do.
children.prevalue: SaintAignan I do not think as you do

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Your majesty doubtless sees more clearly than myself.
children.prevalue: Your majesty doubtless sees more clearly than myself

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Well! I see affliction and restraint in these lines; more particularly since I recall some of the details of the scene which took place this evening in Madame's apartments The king suddenly stopped, leaving his meaning unexpressed.
children.prevalue: Well I see affliction and restraint in these lines more particularly since I recall some of the details of the scene which took place this evening in Madame s apartments The king suddenly stopped leaving his meaning unexpressed

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: In fact, resumed SaintAignan, your majesty will grant an audience; nothing is clearer than that.
children.prevalue: In fact resumed SaintAignan your majesty will grant an audience nothing is clearer than that

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: I will do better, SaintAignan.
children.prevalue: I will do better SaintAignan

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: What is that, sire?
children.prevalue: What is that sire

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Put on your cloak.
children.prevalue: Put on your cloak

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: But, sire
children.prevalue: But sire

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: You know the suite of rooms where Madame's maids of honor are lodged?
children.prevalue: You know the suite of rooms where Madame s maids of honor are lodged

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: You know some means of obtaining an entrance there.
children.prevalue: You know some means of obtaining an entrance there

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: As far as that is concerned, I do not.
children.prevalue: As far as that is concerned I do not

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: At all events, you must be acquainted with some one there.
children.prevalue: At all events you must be acquainted with some one there

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Really, your majesty is the source of every good idea.
children.prevalue: Really your majesty is the source of every good idea

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: You do know some one, then. Who is it?
children.prevalue: You do know some one then Who is it

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: I know a certain gentleman, who is on very good terms with a certain young lady there.
children.prevalue: I know a certain gentleman who is on very good terms with a certain young lady there

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: One of the maids of honor?
children.prevalue: One of the maids of honor

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Yes, sire.
children.prevalue: Yes sire

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: With Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente, I suppose? said the king, laughing.
children.prevalue: With Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente I suppose said the king laughing

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Fortunately, no, sire; with Montalais.
children.prevalue: Fortunately no sire with Montalais

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: What is his name?
children.prevalue: What is his name

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Malicorne.
children.prevalue: Malicorne

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: And you can depend on him?
children.prevalue: And you can depend on him

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I believe so, sire. He ought to have a key of some sort in his possession; and if he should happen to have one, as I have done him a service, why, he will let us have it.
children.prevalue: I believe so sire He ought to have a key of some sort in his possession and if he should happen to have one as I have done him a service why he will let us have it

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Nothing could be better. Let us set off immediately.
children.prevalue: Nothing could be better Let us set off immediately

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: The king threw his cloak over SaintAignan's shoulders, asked him for his, and both went out into the vestibule.
children.prevalue: The king threw his cloak over SaintAignan s shoulders asked him for his and both went out into the vestibule

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: SaintAignan stopped at the foot of the staircase leading to the entresol, where the maids of honor were lodged, and to the first floor, where Madame's apartments were situated. Then, by means of one of the servants who was passing, he sent to apprise Malicorne, who was still with Monsieur. After having waited ten minutes, Malicorne arrived, full of selfimportance. The king drew back towards the darkest part of the vestibule. SaintAignan, on the contrary, advanced to meet him, but at the first words, indicating his wish, Malicorne drew back abruptly.
children.prevalue: SaintAignan stopped at the foot of the staircase leading to the entresol where the maids of honor were lodged and to the first floor where Madame s apartments were situated Then by means of one of the servants who was passing he sent to apprise Malicorne who was still with Monsieur After having waited ten minutes Malicorne arrived full of selfimportance The king drew back towards the darkest part of the vestibule SaintAignan on the contrary advanced to meet him but at the first words indicating his wish Malicorne drew back abruptly

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Oh, oh! he said, you want me to introduce you into the rooms of the maids of honor?
children.prevalue: Oh oh he said you want me to introduce you into the rooms of the maids of honor

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: You know very well that I cannot do anything of the kind, without being made acquainted with your object.
children.prevalue: You know very well that I cannot do anything of the kind without being made acquainted with your object

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Unfortunately, my dear Monsieur Malicorne, it is quite impossible for me to give you any explanation; you must therefore confide in me as in a friend who got you out of a great difficulty yesterday, and who now begs you to draw him out of one today.
children.prevalue: Unfortunately my dear Monsieur Malicorne it is quite impossible for me to give you any explanation you must therefore confide in me as in a friend who got you out of a great difficulty yesterday and who now begs you to draw him out of one today

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Yet I told you, monsieur, what my object was; which was, not to sleep out in the open air, and any man might express the same wish, whilst you, however, admit nothing.
children.prevalue: Yet I told you monsieur what my object was which was not to sleep out in the open air and any man might express the same wish whilst you however admit nothing

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Believe me, my dear Monsieur Malicorne, SaintAignan persisted, that if I were permitted to explain myself, I would do so.
children.prevalue: Believe me my dear Monsieur Malicorne SaintAignan persisted that if I were permitted to explain myself I would do so

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: In that case, my dear monsieur, it is impossible for me to allow you to enter Mademoiselle de Montalais's apartment.
children.prevalue: In that case my dear monsieur it is impossible for me to allow you to enter Mademoiselle de Montalais s apartment

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Why so?
children.prevalue: Why so

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: You know why, better than any one else, since you caught me on the wall paying my addresses to Mademoiselle de Montalais; it would, therefore, be an excess of kindness on my part, you will admit, since I am paying my attentions to her, to open the door of her room to you.
children.prevalue: You know why better than any one else since you caught me on the wall paying my addresses to Mademoiselle de Montalais it would therefore be an excess of kindness on my part you will admit since I am paying my attentions to her to open the door of her room to you

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: But who told you it was on her account I asked you for the key?
children.prevalue: But who told you it was on her account I asked you for the key

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: For whom, then?
children.prevalue: For whom then

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: She does not lodge there alone, I suppose?
children.prevalue: She does not lodge there alone I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: No, certainly; for Mademoiselle de la Valliere shares her rooms with her; but, really, you have nothing more to do with Mademoiselle de la Valliere than with Mademoiselle de Montalais, and there are only two men to whom I would give this key; to M. de Bragelonne, if he begged me to give it to him, and to the king, if he commanded me.
children.prevalue: No certainly for Mademoiselle de la Valliere shares her rooms with her but really you have nothing more to do with Mademoiselle de la Valliere than with Mademoiselle de Montalais and there are only two men to whom I would give this key to M de Bragelonne if he begged me to give it to him and to the king if he commanded me

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: In that case, give me the key, monsieur: I order you to do so, said the king, advancing from the obscurity, and partially opening his cloak. Mademoiselle de Montalais will step down to talk with you, while we go upstairs to Mademoiselle de la Valliere, for, in fact, it is she only whom we desire to see.
children.prevalue: In that case give me the key monsieur I order you to do so said the king advancing from the obscurity and partially opening his cloak Mademoiselle de Montalais will step down to talk with you while we go upstairs to Mademoiselle de la Valliere for in fact it is she only whom we desire to see

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: The king! exclaimed Malicorne, bowing to the very ground.
children.prevalue: The king exclaimed Malicorne bowing to the very ground

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Yes, the king, said Louis, smiling: the king, who is as pleased with your resistance as with your capitulation. Rise, monsieur, and render us the service we request of you.
children.prevalue: Yes the king said Louis smiling the king who is as pleased with your resistance as with your capitulation Rise monsieur and render us the service we request of you

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I obey, your majesty, said Malicorne, leading the way up the staircase.
children.prevalue: I obey your majesty said Malicorne leading the way up the staircase

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Get Mademoiselle de Montalais to come down, said the king, and do not breathe a word to her of my visit.
children.prevalue: Get Mademoiselle de Montalais to come down said the king and do not breathe a word to her of my visit

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Malicorne bowed in token of obedience, and proceeded up the staircase. But the king, after a hasty reflection, followed him, and that, too, with such rapidity, that, although Malicorne was already more than halfway up the staircase, the king reached the room at the same moment. He then observed, by the door which remained halfopened behind Malicorne, La Valliere, sitting in an armchair with her head thrown back, and in the opposite corner Montalais, who, in her dressinggown, was standing before a lookingglass, engaged in arranging her hair, and parleying the while with Malicorne. The king hurriedly opened the door and entered the room. Montalais called out at the noise made by the opening of the door, and, recognizing the king, made her escape. La Valliere rose from her seat, like a dead person galvanized, and then fell back in her armchair. The king advanced slowly towards her.
children.prevalue: Malicorne bowed in token of obedience and proceeded up the staircase But the king after a hasty reflection followed him and that too with such rapidity that although Malicorne was already more than halfway up the staircase the king reached the room at the same moment He then observed by the door which remained halfopened behind Malicorne La Valliere sitting in an armchair with her head thrown back and in the opposite corner Montalais who in her dressinggown was standing before a lookingglass engaged in arranging her hair and parleying the while with Malicorne The king hurriedly opened the door and entered the room Montalais called out at the noise made by the opening of the door and recognizing the king made her escape La Valliere rose from her seat like a dead person galvanized and then fell back in her armchair The king advanced slowly towards her

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: You wished for an audience, I believe, he said coldly. I am ready to hear you. Speak.
children.prevalue: You wished for an audience I believe he said coldly I am ready to hear you Speak

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: SaintAignan, faithful to his character of being deaf, blind, and dumb, had stationed himself in a corner of the door, upon a stool which by chance he found there. Concealed by the tapestry which covered the doorway, and leaning his back against the wall, he could thus listen without being seen; resigning himself to the post of a good watchdog, who patiently waits and watches without ever getting in his master's way.
children.prevalue: SaintAignan faithful to his character of being deaf blind and dumb had stationed himself in a corner of the door upon a stool which by chance he found there Concealed by the tapestry which covered the doorway and leaning his back against the wall he could thus listen without being seen resigning himself to the post of a good watchdog who patiently waits and watches without ever getting in his master s way

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: La Valliere, terrorstricken at the king's irritated aspect, rose a second time, and assuming a posture full of humility and entreaty, murmured, Forgive me, sire.
children.prevalue: La Valliere terrorstricken at the king s irritated aspect rose a second time and assuming a posture full of humility and entreaty murmured Forgive me sire

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: What need is there for my forgiveness? asked Louis.
children.prevalue: What need is there for my forgiveness asked Louis

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Sire, I have been guilty of a great fault; nay, more than a great fault, a great crime.
children.prevalue: Sire I have been guilty of a great fault nay more than a great fault a great crime

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: You?
children.prevalue: You

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Sire, I have offended your majesty.
children.prevalue: Sire I have offended your majesty

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Not in the slightest degree in the world, replied Louis XIV.
children.prevalue: Not in the slightest degree in the world replied Louis XIV

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: I implore you, sire, not to maintain towards me that terrible seriousness of manner which reveals your majesty's just anger. I feel I have offended you, sire; but I wish to explain to you how it was that I have not offended you of my own accord.
children.prevalue: I implore you sire not to maintain towards me that terrible seriousness of manner which reveals your majesty s just anger I feel I have offended you sire but I wish to explain to you how it was that I have not offended you of my own accord

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: In the first place, said the king, in what way can you possibly have offended me? I cannot perceive how. Surely not on account of a young girl's harmless and very innocent jest? You turned the credulity of a young man into ridiculeit was very natural to do so: any other woman in your place would have done the same.
children.prevalue: In the first place said the king in what way can you possibly have offended me I cannot perceive how Surely not on account of a young girl s harmless and very innocent jest You turned the credulity of a young man into ridiculeit was very natural to do so any other woman in your place would have done the same

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Oh! your majesty overwhelms me by your remark.
children.prevalue: Oh your majesty overwhelms me by your remark

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Why so?
children.prevalue: Why so

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Because, if I had been the author of the jest, it would not have been innocent.
children.prevalue: Because if I had been the author of the jest it would not have been innocent

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Well, is that all you had to say to me in soliciting an audience? said the king, as though about to turn away.
children.prevalue: Well is that all you had to say to me in soliciting an audience said the king as though about to turn away

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Thereupon La Valliere, in an abrupt and a broken voice, her eyes dried up by the fire of her tears, made a step towards the king, and said, Did your majesty hear everything?
children.prevalue: Thereupon La Valliere in an abrupt and a broken voice her eyes dried up by the fire of her tears made a step towards the king and said Did your majesty hear everything

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Everything, what?
children.prevalue: Everything what

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Everything I said beneath the royal oak.
children.prevalue: Everything I said beneath the royal oak

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: I did not lose a syllable.
children.prevalue: I did not lose a syllable

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: And now, after your majesty really heard all, are you able to think I abused your credibility?
children.prevalue: And now after your majesty really heard all are you able to think I abused your credibility

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Credulity; yes, indeed, you have selected the very word.
children.prevalue: Credulity yes indeed you have selected the very word

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: And your majesty did not suppose that a poor girl like myself might possibly be compelled to submit to the will of others?
children.prevalue: And your majesty did not suppose that a poor girl like myself might possibly be compelled to submit to the will of others

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Forgive me, returned the king; but I shall never be able to understand that she, who of her own free will could express herself so unreservedly beneath the royal oak, would allow herself to be influenced to such an extent by the direction of others.
children.prevalue: Forgive me returned the king but I shall never be able to understand that she who of her own free will could express herself so unreservedly beneath the royal oak would allow herself to be influenced to such an extent by the direction of others

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: But the threat held out against me, sire.
children.prevalue: But the threat held out against me sire

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Threat! who threatened youwho dared to threaten you?
children.prevalue: Threat who threatened youwho dared to threaten you

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Those who have the right to do so, sire.
children.prevalue: Those who have the right to do so sire

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: I do not recognize any one as possessing the right to threaten the humblest of my subjects.
children.prevalue: I do not recognize any one as possessing the right to threaten the humblest of my subjects

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Forgive me, sire, but near your majesty, even, there are persons sufficiently high in position to have, or to believe that they possess, the right of injuring a young girl, without fortune, and possessing only her reputation.
children.prevalue: Forgive me sire but near your majesty even there are persons sufficiently high in position to have or to believe that they possess the right of injuring a young girl without fortune and possessing only her reputation

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: In what way injure her?
children.prevalue: In what way injure her

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: In depriving her of her reputation, by disgracefully expelling her from the court.
children.prevalue: In depriving her of her reputation by disgracefully expelling her from the court

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Oh! Mademoiselle de la Valliere, said the king bitterly, I prefer those persons who exculpate themselves without incriminating others.
children.prevalue: Oh Mademoiselle de la Valliere said the king bitterly I prefer those persons who exculpate themselves without incriminating others

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Sire!
children.prevalue: Sire

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Yes; and I confess that I greatly regret to perceive, that an easy justification, as your own would have been, is now complicated in my presence by a tissue of reproaches and imputations against others.
children.prevalue: Yes and I confess that I greatly regret to perceive that an easy justification as your own would have been is now complicated in my presence by a tissue of reproaches and imputations against others

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: And which you do not believe? exclaimed La Valliere. The king remained silent.
children.prevalue: And which you do not believe exclaimed La Valliere The king remained silent

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Nay, but tell me! repeated La Valliere, vehemently.
children.prevalue: Nay but tell me repeated La Valliere vehemently

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: I regret to confess it, repeated the king, bowing coldly.
children.prevalue: I regret to confess it repeated the king bowing coldly

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: The young girl uttered a deep groan, striking her hands together in despair. You do not believe me, then, she said to the king, who still remained silent, while poor La Valliere's features became visibly changed at his continued silence. Therefore, you believe, she said, that I prearranged this ridiculous, this infamous plot, of trifling, in so shameless a manner, with your majesty.
children.prevalue: The young girl uttered a deep groan striking her hands together in despair You do not believe me then she said to the king who still remained silent while poor La Valliere s features became visibly changed at his continued silence Therefore you believe she said that I prearranged this ridiculous this infamous plot of trifling in so shameless a manner with your majesty

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Nay, said the king, it was neither ridiculous nor infamous; it was not even a plot; merely a jest, more or less amusing, and nothing more.
children.prevalue: Nay said the king it was neither ridiculous nor infamous it was not even a plot merely a jest more or less amusing and nothing more

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Oh! murmured the young girl, the king does not, and will not believe me, then?
children.prevalue: Oh murmured the young girl the king does not and will not believe me then

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: No, indeed, I will not believe you, said the king. Besides, in point of fact, what can be more natural? The king, you argue, follows me, listens to me, watches me; the king wishes perhaps to amuse himself at my expense, I will amuse myself at his, and as the king is very tenderhearted, I will take his heart by storm.
children.prevalue: No indeed I will not believe you said the king Besides in point of fact what can be more natural The king you argue follows me listens to me watches me the king wishes perhaps to amuse himself at my expense I will amuse myself at his and as the king is very tenderhearted I will take his heart by storm

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: La Valliere hid her face in her hands, as she stifled her sobs. The king continued pitilessly; he was revenging himself upon the poor victim before him for all he had himself suffered.
children.prevalue: La Valliere hid her face in her hands as she stifled her sobs The king continued pitilessly he was revenging himself upon the poor victim before him for all he had himself suffered

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Let us invent, then, this story of my loving him and preferring him to others. The king is so simple and so conceited that he will believe me; and then we can go and tell others how credulous the king is, and can enjoy a laugh at his expense.
children.prevalue: Let us invent then this story of my loving him and preferring him to others The king is so simple and so conceited that he will believe me and then we can go and tell others how credulous the king is and can enjoy a laugh at his expense

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Oh! exclaimed La Valliere, you think that, you believe that!it is frightful.
children.prevalue: Oh exclaimed La Valliere you think that you believe that it is frightful

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: And, pursued the king, that is not all; if this selfconceited prince take our jest seriously, if he should be imprudent enough to exhibit before others anything like delight at it, well, in that case, the king will be humiliated before the whole court; and what a delightful story it will be, too, for him to whom I am really attached, in fact part of my dowry for my husband, to have the adventure to relate of the monarch who was so amusingly deceived by a young girl.
children.prevalue: And pursued the king that is not all if this selfconceited prince take our jest seriously if he should be imprudent enough to exhibit before others anything like delight at it well in that case the king will be humiliated before the whole court and what a delightful story it will be too for him to whom I am really attached in fact part of my dowry for my husband to have the adventure to relate of the monarch who was so amusingly deceived by a young girl

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Sire! exclaimed La Valliere, her mind bewildered, almost wandering, indeed, not another word, I implore you; do you not see that you are killing me?
children.prevalue: Sire exclaimed La Valliere her mind bewildered almost wandering indeed not another word I implore you do you not see that you are killing me

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: A jest, nothing but a jest, murmured the king, who, however, began to be somewhat affected.
children.prevalue: A jest nothing but a jest murmured the king who however began to be somewhat affected

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: La Valliere fell upon her knees, and that so violently, that the sound could be heard upon the hard floor. Sire, she said, I prefer shame to disloyalty.
children.prevalue: La Valliere fell upon her knees and that so violently that the sound could be heard upon the hard floor Sire she said I prefer shame to disloyalty

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: What do you mean? inquired the king, without moving a step to raise the young girl from her knees.
children.prevalue: What do you mean inquired the king without moving a step to raise the young girl from her knees

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Sire, when I shall have sacrificed my honor and my reason both to you, you will perhaps believe in my loyalty. The tale which was related to you in Madame's apartments, and by Madame herself, is utterly false; and that which I said beneath the great oak
children.prevalue: Sire when I shall have sacrificed my honor and my reason both to you you will perhaps believe in my loyalty The tale which was related to you in Madame s apartments and by Madame herself is utterly false and that which I said beneath the great oak

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Well!
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: That is the only truth.
children.prevalue: That is the only truth

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: What! exclaimed the king.
children.prevalue: What exclaimed the king

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Sire, exclaimed La Valliere, hurried away by the violence of her emotions, were I to die of shame on the very spot where my knees are fixed, I would repeat it until my latest breath; I said that I loved you, and it is true; I do love you.
children.prevalue: Sire exclaimed La Valliere hurried away by the violence of her emotions were I to die of shame on the very spot where my knees are fixed I would repeat it until my latest breath I said that I loved you and it is true I do love you

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: You!
children.prevalue: You

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: I have loved you, sire, from the very first day I ever saw you; from the moment when at Blois, where I was pining away my existence, your royal looks, full of light and life, were first bent upon me. I love you still, sire; it is a crime of high treason, I know, that a poor girl like myself should love her sovereign, and should presume to tell him so. Punish me for my audacity, despise me for my shameless immodesty; but do not ever say, do not ever think, that I have jested with or deceived you. I belong to a family whose loyalty has been proved, sire, and I, too, love my king.
children.prevalue: I have loved you sire from the very first day I ever saw you from the moment when at Blois where I was pining away my existence your royal looks full of light and life were first bent upon me I love you still sire it is a crime of high treason I know that a poor girl like myself should love her sovereign and should presume to tell him so Punish me for my audacity despise me for my shameless immodesty but do not ever say do not ever think that I have jested with or deceived you I belong to a family whose loyalty has been proved sire and I too love my king

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Suddenly her strength, voice, and respiration ceased, and she fell forward, like the flower Virgil alludes to, which the scythe of the reaper severed in the midst of the grass. The king, at these words, at this vehement entreaty, no longer retained any illwill or doubt in his mind: his whole heart seemed to expand at the glowing breath of an affection which proclaimed itself in such noble and courageous language. When, therefore, he heard the passionate confession, his strength seemed to fail him, and he hid his face in his hands. But when he felt La Valliere's hands clinging to his own, when their warm pressure fired his blood, he bent forward, and passing his arm round La Valliere's waist, he raised her from the ground and pressed her against his heart. But she, her drooping head fallen forward on her bosom, seemed to have ceased to live. The king, terrified, called out for SaintAignan. SaintAignan, who had carried his discretion so far as to remain without stirring in his corner, pretending to wipe away a tear, ran forward at the king's summons. He then assisted Louis to seat the young girl upon a couch, slapped her hands, sprinkled some Hungary water over her face, calling out all the while, Come, come, it is all over; the king believes you, and forgives you. There, there now! take care, or you will agitate his majesty too much; his majesty is so sensitive, so tenderhearted. Now, really, Mademoiselle de la Valliere, you must pay attention, for the king is very pale.
children.prevalue: Suddenly her strength voice and respiration ceased and she fell forward like the flower Virgil alludes to which the scythe of the reaper severed in the midst of the grass The king at these words at this vehement entreaty no longer retained any illwill or doubt in his mind his whole heart seemed to expand at the glowing breath of an affection which proclaimed itself in such noble and courageous language When therefore he heard the passionate confession his strength seemed to fail him and he hid his face in his hands But when he felt La Valliere s hands clinging to his own when their warm pressure fired his blood he bent forward and passing his arm round La Valliere s waist he raised her from the ground and pressed her against his heart But she her drooping head fallen forward on her bosom seemed to have ceased to live The king terrified called out for SaintAignan SaintAignan who had carried his discretion so far as to remain without stirring in his corner pretending to wipe away a tear ran forward at the king s summons He then assisted Louis to seat the young girl upon a couch slapped her hands sprinkled some Hungary water over her face calling out all the while Come come it is all over the king believes you and forgives you There there now take care or you will agitate his majesty too much his majesty is so sensitive so tenderhearted Now really Mademoiselle de la Valliere you must pay attention for the king is very pale

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: The fact was, the king was visibly losing color. But La Valliere did not move.
children.prevalue: The fact was the king was visibly losing color But La Valliere did not move

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Do pray recover, continued SaintAignan. I beg, I implore you; it is really time you should; think only of one thing, that if the king should become unwell, I should be obliged to summon his physician. What a state of things that would be! So do pray rouse yourself; make an effort, pray do, and do so at once, my dear.
children.prevalue: Do pray recover continued SaintAignan I beg I implore you it is really time you should think only of one thing that if the king should become unwell I should be obliged to summon his physician What a state of things that would be So do pray rouse yourself make an effort pray do and do so at once my dear

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: It was difficult to display more persuasive eloquence than SaintAignan did, but something still more powerful, and of a more energetic nature than this eloquence, aroused La Valliere. The king, who was kneeling before her, covered the palms of her hands with those burning kisses which are to the hands what a kiss upon the lips is to the face. La Valliere's senses returned to her; she languidly opened her eyes and, with a dying look, murmured, Oh! sire, has your majesty pardoned me, then?
children.prevalue: It was difficult to display more persuasive eloquence than SaintAignan did but something still more powerful and of a more energetic nature than this eloquence aroused La Valliere The king who was kneeling before her covered the palms of her hands with those burning kisses which are to the hands what a kiss upon the lips is to the face La Valliere s senses returned to her she languidly opened her eyes and with a dying look murmured Oh sire has your majesty pardoned me then

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: The king did not reply, for he was still too much overcome. SaintAignan thought it was his duty again to retire, for he observed the passionate devotion which was displayed in the king's gaze. La Valliere rose.
children.prevalue: The king did not reply for he was still too much overcome SaintAignan thought it was his duty again to retire for he observed the passionate devotion which was displayed in the king s gaze La Valliere rose

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: And now, sire, that I have justified myself, at least I trust so, in your majesty's eyes, grant me leave to retire into a convent. I shall bless your majesty all my life, and I shall die thanking and loving Heaven for having granted me one hour of perfect happiness.
children.prevalue: And now sire that I have justified myself at least I trust so in your majesty s eyes grant me leave to retire into a convent I shall bless your majesty all my life and I shall die thanking and loving Heaven for having granted me one hour of perfect happiness

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: No, no, replied the king, you will live here blessing Heaven, on the contrary, but loving Louis, who will make your existence one of perfect felicityLouis who loves youLouis who swears it.
children.prevalue: No no replied the king you will live here blessing Heaven on the contrary but loving Louis who will make your existence one of perfect felicityLouis who loves youLouis who swears it

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Oh! sire, sire!
children.prevalue: Oh sire sire

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: And upon this doubt of La Valliere, the king's kisses became so warm that SaintAignan thought it was his duty to retire behind the tapestry. These kisses, however, which she had not the strength at first to resist, began to intimidate the young girl.
children.prevalue: And upon this doubt of La Valliere the king s kisses became so warm that SaintAignan thought it was his duty to retire behind the tapestry These kisses however which she had not the strength at first to resist began to intimidate the young girl

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Oh! sire, she exclaimed, do not make me repeat my loyalty, for this would show me that your majesty despises me still.
children.prevalue: Oh sire she exclaimed do not make me repeat my loyalty for this would show me that your majesty despises me still

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Mademoiselle de la Valliere, said the king, suddenly, drawing back with an air full of respect, there is nothing in the world that I love and honor more than yourself, and nothing in my court, I call Heaven to witness, shall be so highly regarded as you shall be henceforward. I entreat your forgiveness for my transport; it arose from an excess of affection, but I can prove to you that I love you more than ever by respecting you as much as you can possibly desire or deserve. Then, bending before her, and taking her by the hand, he said to her, Will you honor me by accepting the kiss I press upon your hand? And the king's lips were pressed respectfully and lightly upon the young girl's trembling hand. Henceforth, added Louis, rising and bending his glance upon La Valliere, henceforth you are under my safeguard. Do not speak to any one of the injury I have done you, forgive others that which they may have attempted. For the future, you shall be so far above all those, that, far from inspiring you with fear, they shall be even beneath your pity. And he bowed as reverently as though he were leaving a place of worship. Then calling to SaintAignan, who approached with great humility, he said, I hope, comte, that Mademoiselle de la Valliere will kindly confer a little of her friendship upon you, in return for that which I have vowed to her eternally.
children.prevalue: Mademoiselle de la Valliere said the king suddenly drawing back with an air full of respect there is nothing in the world that I love and honor more than yourself and nothing in my court I call Heaven to witness shall be so highly regarded as you shall be henceforward I entreat your forgiveness for my transport it arose from an excess of affection but I can prove to you that I love you more than ever by respecting you as much as you can possibly desire or deserve Then bending before her and taking her by the hand he said to her Will you honor me by accepting the kiss I press upon your hand And the king s lips were pressed respectfully and lightly upon the young girl s trembling hand Henceforth added Louis rising and bending his glance upon La Valliere henceforth you are under my safeguard Do not speak to any one of the injury I have done you forgive others that which they may have attempted For the future you shall be so far above all those that far from inspiring you with fear they shall be even beneath your pity And he bowed as reverently as though he were leaving a place of worship Then calling to SaintAignan who approached with great humility he said I hope comte that Mademoiselle de la Valliere will kindly confer a little of her friendship upon you in return for that which I have vowed to her eternally

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: SaintAignan bent his knee before La Valliere, saying, How happy, indeed, would such an honor make me!
children.prevalue: SaintAignan bent his knee before La Valliere saying How happy indeed would such an honor make me

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: I will send your companion back to you, said the king. Farewell! or, rather, adieu till we meet again; do not forget me in your prayers, I entreat.
children.prevalue: I will send your companion back to you said the king Farewell or rather adieu till we meet again do not forget me in your prayers I entreat

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Oh! cried La Valliere, be assured that you and Heaven are in my heart together.
children.prevalue: Oh cried La Valliere be assured that you and Heaven are in my heart together

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: These words of Louise elated the king, who, full of happiness, hurried SaintAignan down the stairs. Madame had not anticipated this denouement; and neither the Naiad nor the Dryad had breathed a word about it.
children.prevalue: These words of Louise elated the king who full of happiness hurried SaintAignan down the stairs Madame had not anticipated this denouement and neither the Naiad nor the Dryad had breathed a word about it

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: While La Valliere and the king were mingling, in their first confession of love, all the bitterness of the past, the happiness of the present, and hopes of the future, Fouquet had retired to the apartments which had been assigned to him in the chateau, and was conversing with Aramis precisely upon the very subjects which the king at that moment was forgetting.
children.prevalue: While La Valliere and the king were mingling in their first confession of love all the bitterness of the past the happiness of the present and hopes of the future Fouquet had retired to the apartments which had been assigned to him in the chateau and was conversing with Aramis precisely upon the very subjects which the king at that moment was forgetting

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Now tell me, said Fouquet, after having installed his guest in an armchair and seated himself by his side, tell me, Monsieur d'Herblay, what is our position with regard to the BelleIsle affair, and whether you have received any news about it.
children.prevalue: Now tell me said Fouquet after having installed his guest in an armchair and seated himself by his side tell me Monsieur d Herblay what is our position with regard to the BelleIsle affair and whether you have received any news about it

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Everything is going on in that direction as we wish, replied Aramis; the expenses have been paid, and nothing has transpired of our designs.
children.prevalue: Everything is going on in that direction as we wish replied Aramis the expenses have been paid and nothing has transpired of our designs

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: But what about the soldiers the king wished to send there?
children.prevalue: But what about the soldiers the king wished to send there

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: I have received news this morning they arrived there fifteen days ago.
children.prevalue: I have received news this morning they arrived there fifteen days ago

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: And how have they been treated?
children.prevalue: And how have they been treated

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: In the best manner possible.
children.prevalue: In the best manner possible

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: What has become of the former garrison?
children.prevalue: What has become of the former garrison

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The soldiers were landed at Sarzeau, and then transferred immediately to Quimper.
children.prevalue: The soldiers were landed at Sarzeau and then transferred immediately to Quimper

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: And the new garrison?
children.prevalue: And the new garrison

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Belongs to us from this very moment.
children.prevalue: Belongs to us from this very moment

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Are you sure of what you say, my dear Monsieur de Vannes?
children.prevalue: Are you sure of what you say my dear Monsieur de Vannes

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Quite sure, and, moreover, you will see by and by how matters have turned out.
children.prevalue: Quite sure and moreover you will see by and by how matters have turned out

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Still you are very well aware, that, of all the garrison towns, BelleIsle is precisely the very worst.
children.prevalue: Still you are very well aware that of all the garrison towns BelleIsle is precisely the very worst

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I know it, and have acted accordingly; no space to move about, no gayety, no cheerful society, no gambling permitted: well, it is a great pity, added Aramis, with one of those smiles so peculiar to him, to see how much young people at the present day seek amusement, and how much, consequently, they incline to the man who procures and pays for their favorite pastimes.
children.prevalue: I know it and have acted accordingly no space to move about no gayety no cheerful society no gambling permitted well it is a great pity added Aramis with one of those smiles so peculiar to him to see how much young people at the present day seek amusement and how much consequently they incline to the man who procures and pays for their favorite pastimes

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: But if they amuse themselves at BellIsle?
children.prevalue: But if they amuse themselves at BellIsle

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: If they amuse themselves through the king's means, they will attach themselves to the king; but if they get bored to death through the king's means, and amuse themselves through M. Fouquet, they will attach themselves to M. Fouquet.
children.prevalue: If they amuse themselves through the king s means they will attach themselves to the king but if they get bored to death through the king s means and amuse themselves through M Fouquet they will attach themselves to M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: And you informed my intendant, of course?so that immediately on their arrival
children.prevalue: And you informed my intendant of course so that immediately on their arrival

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: By no means; they were left alone a whole week, to weary themselves at their ease; but, at the end of the week, they cried out, saying that former officers amused themselves much better. Whereupon they were told that the old officers had been able to make a friend of M. Fouquet, and that M. Fouquet, knowing them to be friends of his, had from that moment done all he possibly could to prevent their getting wearied or bored upon his estates. Upon this they began to reflect. Immediately afterwards, however, the intendant added, that without anticipating M. Fouquet's orders, he knew his master sufficiently well to be aware that he took an interest in every gentleman in the king's service, and that, although he did not know the newcomers, he would do as much for them as he had done for the others.
children.prevalue: By no means they were left alone a whole week to weary themselves at their ease but at the end of the week they cried out saying that former officers amused themselves much better Whereupon they were told that the old officers had been able to make a friend of M Fouquet and that M Fouquet knowing them to be friends of his had from that moment done all he possibly could to prevent their getting wearied or bored upon his estates Upon this they began to reflect Immediately afterwards however the intendant added that without anticipating M Fouquet s orders he knew his master sufficiently well to be aware that he took an interest in every gentleman in the king s service and that although he did not know the newcomers he would do as much for them as he had done for the others

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Excellent! and I trust that the promises were followed up; I desire, as you know, that no promise should ever be made in my name without being kept.
children.prevalue: Excellent and I trust that the promises were followed up I desire as you know that no promise should ever be made in my name without being kept

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Without a moment's loss of time, our two privateers, and your own horses, were placed at the disposal of the officers; the keys of the principal mansion were handed over to them, so that they made up huntingparties, and walking excursions with such ladies as are to be found in BelleIsle; and such other as they are enabled to enlist from the neighborhood, who have no fear of seasickness.
children.prevalue: Without a moment s loss of time our two privateers and your own horses were placed at the disposal of the officers the keys of the principal mansion were handed over to them so that they made up huntingparties and walking excursions with such ladies as are to be found in BelleIsle and such other as they are enabled to enlist from the neighborhood who have no fear of seasickness

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: And there is a fair sprinkling to be met with at Sarzeau and Vannes, I believe, your eminence?
children.prevalue: And there is a fair sprinkling to be met with at Sarzeau and Vannes I believe your eminence

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Yes; in fact all along the coast, said Aramis, quietly.
children.prevalue: Yes in fact all along the coast said Aramis quietly

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: And now, how about the soldiers?
