children.prevalue: And now how about the soldiers

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Everything precisely the same, in a relative degree, you understand; the soldiers have plenty of wine, excellent provisions, and good pay.
children.prevalue: Everything precisely the same in a relative degree you understand the soldiers have plenty of wine excellent provisions and good pay

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Very good; so that
children.prevalue: Very good so that

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: So that this garrison can be depended upon, and it is a better one than the last.
children.prevalue: So that this garrison can be depended upon and it is a better one than the last

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Good.
children.prevalue: Good

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: The result is, if Fortune favors us, so that the garrisons are changed in this manner, only every two months, that, at the end of every three years, the whole army will, in its turn, have been there; and, therefore, instead of having one regiment in our favor, we shall have fifty thousand men.
children.prevalue: The result is if Fortune favors us so that the garrisons are changed in this manner only every two months that at the end of every three years the whole army will in its turn have been there and therefore instead of having one regiment in our favor we shall have fifty thousand men

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Yes, yes; I knew perfectly well, said Fouquet, that no friend could be more incomparable and invaluable than yourself, my dear Monsieur d'Herblay; but, he added, laughing, all this time we are forgetting our friend, Du Vallon; what has become of him? During the three days I spent at SaintMande, I confess I have forgotten him completely.
children.prevalue: Yes yes I knew perfectly well said Fouquet that no friend could be more incomparable and invaluable than yourself my dear Monsieur d Herblay but he added laughing all this time we are forgetting our friend Du Vallon what has become of him During the three days I spent at SaintMande I confess I have forgotten him completely

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: I do not forget him, however, returned Aramis. Porthos is at SaintMande; his joints are kept well greased, the greatest care is being taken care of him with regard to the food he eats, and the wines he drinks; I advise him to take daily airings in the small park, which you have kept for your own use, and he makes us of it accordingly. He begins to walk again, he exercises his muscular powers by bending down young elmtrees, or making the old oaks fly into splinters, as Milo of Crotona used to do; and, as there are no lions in the park, it is not unlikely we shall find him alive. Porthos is a brave fellow.
children.prevalue: I do not forget him however returned Aramis Porthos is at SaintMande his joints are kept well greased the greatest care is being taken care of him with regard to the food he eats and the wines he drinks I advise him to take daily airings in the small park which you have kept for your own use and he makes us of it accordingly He begins to walk again he exercises his muscular powers by bending down young elmtrees or making the old oaks fly into splinters as Milo of Crotona used to do and as there are no lions in the park it is not unlikely we shall find him alive Porthos is a brave fellow

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Yes, but in the mean time he will get bored to death.
children.prevalue: Yes but in the mean time he will get bored to death

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Oh, no; he never does that.
children.prevalue: Oh no he never does that

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: He will be asking questions?
children.prevalue: He will be asking questions

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: He sees no one.
children.prevalue: He sees no one

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: At all events, he is looking or hoping for something or another.
children.prevalue: At all events he is looking or hoping for something or another

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I have inspired in him a hope which we will realize some fine morning, and on that he subsists.
children.prevalue: I have inspired in him a hope which we will realize some fine morning and on that he subsists

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: What is it?
children.prevalue: What is it

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: That of being presented to the king.
children.prevalue: That of being presented to the king

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Oh! in what character?
children.prevalue: Oh in what character

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: As the engineer of BelleIsle, of course.
children.prevalue: As the engineer of BelleIsle of course

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Is it possible?
children.prevalue: Is it possible

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Quite true.
children.prevalue: Quite true

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Shall we not be obliged, then, to send him back to BelleIsle?
children.prevalue: Shall we not be obliged then to send him back to BelleIsle

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Most certainly; I am even thinking of sending him as soon as possible. Porthos is very fond of display; he is man whose weakness D'Artagnan, Athos, and myself are alone acquainted with; he never commits himself in any way; he is dignity himself; to the officers there, he would seem like a Paladin of the time of the Crusades. He would make the whole staff drunk, without getting tipsy in the least himself, and every one will regard him with admiration and sympathy; if, therefore, it should happen that we have any orders requiring to be carried out, Porthos is an incarnation of the order itself, and whatever he chose to do others would find themselves obliged to submit to.
children.prevalue: Most certainly I am even thinking of sending him as soon as possible Porthos is very fond of display he is man whose weakness D Artagnan Athos and myself are alone acquainted with he never commits himself in any way he is dignity himself to the officers there he would seem like a Paladin of the time of the Crusades He would make the whole staff drunk without getting tipsy in the least himself and every one will regard him with admiration and sympathy if therefore it should happen that we have any orders requiring to be carried out Porthos is an incarnation of the order itself and whatever he chose to do others would find themselves obliged to submit to

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Send him back, then.
children.prevalue: Send him back then

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: That is what I intend to do; but only in a few days; for I must not omit to tell you one thing.
children.prevalue: That is what I intend to do but only in a few days for I must not omit to tell you one thing

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: What is it?
children.prevalue: What is it

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: I begin to mistrust D'Artagnan. He is not at Fontainebleau, as you may have noticed, and D'Artagnan is never absent, or apparently idle, without some object in view. And now that my own affairs are settled, I am going to try and ascertain what the affairs are in which D'Artagnan is engaged.
children.prevalue: I begin to mistrust D Artagnan He is not at Fontainebleau as you may have noticed and D Artagnan is never absent or apparently idle without some object in view And now that my own affairs are settled I am going to try and ascertain what the affairs are in which D Artagnan is engaged

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Your own affairs are settled, you say?
children.prevalue: Your own affairs are settled you say

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: You are very fortunate in that case, then, and I should like to be able to say the same.
children.prevalue: You are very fortunate in that case then and I should like to be able to say the same

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: I hope you do not make yourself uneasy.
children.prevalue: I hope you do not make yourself uneasy

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Hum!
children.prevalue: Hum

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Nothing could be better than the king's reception of you.
children.prevalue: Nothing could be better than the king s reception of you

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: True.
children.prevalue: True

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: And Colbert leaves you in peace.
children.prevalue: And Colbert leaves you in peace

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Nearly so.
children.prevalue: Nearly so

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: In that case, said Aramis, with that connection of ideas which marked him, in that case, then, we can bestow a thought upon the young girl I was speaking to you about yesterday.
children.prevalue: In that case said Aramis with that connection of ideas which marked him in that case then we can bestow a thought upon the young girl I was speaking to you about yesterday

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Whom do you mean?
children.prevalue: Whom do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: What, have you forgotten already? I mean La Valliere.
children.prevalue: What have you forgotten already I mean La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Ah! of course, of course.
children.prevalue: Ah of course of course

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Do you object, then, to try and make a conquest of her?
children.prevalue: Do you object then to try and make a conquest of her

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: In one respect only; my heart is engaged in another direction, and I positively do not care about the girl in the least.
children.prevalue: In one respect only my heart is engaged in another direction and I positively do not care about the girl in the least

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Oh, oh! said Aramis, your heart is engaged, you say. The deuce! we must take care of that.
children.prevalue: Oh oh said Aramis your heart is engaged you say The deuce we must take care of that

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Why?
children.prevalue: Why

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Because it is terrible to have the heart occupied, when others, besides yourself, have so much need of the head.
children.prevalue: Because it is terrible to have the heart occupied when others besides yourself have so much need of the head

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: You are right. So you see, at your first summons, I left everything. But to return to this girl. What good do you see in my troubling myself about her?
children.prevalue: You are right So you see at your first summons I left everything But to return to this girl What good do you see in my troubling myself about her

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: This.The king, it is said, has taken a fancy to her; at least, so it is supposed.
children.prevalue: This The king it is said has taken a fancy to her at least so it is supposed

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: But you, who know everything, know very differently.
children.prevalue: But you who know everything know very differently

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: I know that the king is greatly and suddenly changed; that the day before yesterday he was crazy over Madame; that a few days ago, Monsieur complained of it, even to the queenmother; and that some conjugal misunderstandings and maternal scoldings were the consequence.
children.prevalue: I know that the king is greatly and suddenly changed that the day before yesterday he was crazy over Madame that a few days ago Monsieur complained of it even to the queenmother and that some conjugal misunderstandings and maternal scoldings were the consequence

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: How do you know all that?
children.prevalue: How do you know all that

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: I do know it; at all events, since these misunderstandings and scoldings, the king has not addressed a word, has not paid the slightest attention, to her royal highness.
children.prevalue: I do know it at all events since these misunderstandings and scoldings the king has not addressed a word has not paid the slightest attention to her royal highness

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Well, what next?
children.prevalue: Well what next

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Since then, he has been taken up with Mademoiselle de la Valliere. Now, Mademoiselle de la Valliere is one of Madame's maids of honor. You happen to know, I suppose, what is called a chaperon in matters of love. Well, then, Mademoiselle de la Valliere is Madame's chaperon. It is for you to take advantage of this state of things. You have no occasion for me to tell you that. But, at all events, wounded vanity will render the conquest an easier one; the girl will get hold of the king, and Madame's secret, and you can scarcely predict what a man of intelligence can do with a secret.
children.prevalue: Since then he has been taken up with Mademoiselle de la Valliere Now Mademoiselle de la Valliere is one of Madame s maids of honor You happen to know I suppose what is called a chaperon in matters of love Well then Mademoiselle de la Valliere is Madame s chaperon It is for you to take advantage of this state of things You have no occasion for me to tell you that But at all events wounded vanity will render the conquest an easier one the girl will get hold of the king and Madame s secret and you can scarcely predict what a man of intelligence can do with a secret

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: But how to get at her?
children.prevalue: But how to get at her

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Nay, you, of all men, to ask me such a question! said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Nay you of all men to ask me such a question said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Very true. I shall not have any time to take any notice of her.
children.prevalue: Very true I shall not have any time to take any notice of her

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: She is poor and unassuming, you will create a position for her, and whether she tames the king as his lady confessor, or his sweetheart, you will have enlisted a new and valuable ally.
children.prevalue: She is poor and unassuming you will create a position for her and whether she tames the king as his lady confessor or his sweetheart you will have enlisted a new and valuable ally

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Very good, said Fouquet. What is to be done, then, with regard to this girl?
children.prevalue: Very good said Fouquet What is to be done then with regard to this girl

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Whenever you have taken a fancy to any lady, Monsieur Fouquet, what course have you generally pursued?
children.prevalue: Whenever you have taken a fancy to any lady Monsieur Fouquet what course have you generally pursued

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: I have written to her, protesting my devotion to her. I have added, how happy I should be to render her any service in my power, and have signed 'Fouquet,' at the end of the letter.
children.prevalue: I have written to her protesting my devotion to her I have added how happy I should be to render her any service in my power and have signed Fouquet at the end of the letter

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: And has any one offered resistance?
children.prevalue: And has any one offered resistance

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: One person only, replied Fouquet. But, four days ago, she yielded, as the others had done.
children.prevalue: One person only replied Fouquet But four days ago she yielded as the others had done

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Will you take the trouble to write? said Aramis, holding a pen towards him, which Fouquet took, saying:
children.prevalue: Will you take the trouble to write said Aramis holding a pen towards him which Fouquet took saying

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: I will write at your dictation. My head is so taken up in another direction, that I should not be able to write a couple lines.
children.prevalue: I will write at your dictation My head is so taken up in another direction that I should not be able to write a couple lines

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Very well, said Aramis, write.
children.prevalue: Very well said Aramis write

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: And he dictated, as follows: MademoiselleI have seen youand you will not be surprised to learn, I think you very beautiful. But, for want of the position you merit at court, your presence there is a waste of time. The devotion of a man of honor, should ambition of any kind inspire you, might possibly serve as a means of display for your talent and beauty. I place my devotion at your feet; but, as an affection, however reserved and unpresuming it may be, might possibly compromise the object of its worship, it would ill become a person of your merit running the risk of being compromised, without her future being assured. If you would deign to accept, and reply to my affection, my affection shall prove its gratitude to you in making you free and independent forever.
children.prevalue: And he dictated as follows MademoiselleI have seen youand you will not be surprised to learn I think you very beautiful But for want of the position you merit at court your presence there is a waste of time The devotion of a man of honor should ambition of any kind inspire you might possibly serve as a means of display for your talent and beauty I place my devotion at your feet but as an affection however reserved and unpresuming it may be might possibly compromise the object of its worship it would ill become a person of your merit running the risk of being compromised without her future being assured If you would deign to accept and reply to my affection my affection shall prove its gratitude to you in making you free and independent forever

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Having finished writing, Fouquet looked at Aramis.
children.prevalue: Having finished writing Fouquet looked at Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Sign it, said the latter.
children.prevalue: Sign it said the latter

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Is it absolutely necessary?
children.prevalue: Is it absolutely necessary

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Your signature at the foot of that letter is worth a million; you forget that. Fouquet signed.
children.prevalue: Your signature at the foot of that letter is worth a million you forget that Fouquet signed

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Now, by whom do you intend to send this letter? asked Aramis.
children.prevalue: Now by whom do you intend to send this letter asked Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: By an excellent servant of mine.
children.prevalue: By an excellent servant of mine

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Can you rely on him?
children.prevalue: Can you rely on him

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: He is a man who has been with me all my life.
children.prevalue: He is a man who has been with me all my life

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Very well. Besides, in this case, we are not playing for very heavy stakes.
children.prevalue: Very well Besides in this case we are not playing for very heavy stakes

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: How so? For if what you say be true of the accommodating disposition of this girl for the king and Madame, the king will give her all the money she can ask for.
children.prevalue: How so For if what you say be true of the accommodating disposition of this girl for the king and Madame the king will give her all the money she can ask for

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: The king has money, then? asked Aramis.
children.prevalue: The king has money then asked Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: I suppose so, for he has not asked me for any more.
children.prevalue: I suppose so for he has not asked me for any more

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Be easy, he will ask for some, soon.
children.prevalue: Be easy he will ask for some soon

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Nay, more than that, I had thought he would have spoken to me about the fete at Vaux, but he never said a word about it.
children.prevalue: Nay more than that I had thought he would have spoken to me about the fete at Vaux but he never said a word about it

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: He will be sure to do so, though.
children.prevalue: He will be sure to do so though

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: You must think the king's disposition a very cruel one, Monsieur d'Herblay.
children.prevalue: You must think the king s disposition a very cruel one Monsieur d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: It is not he who is so.
children.prevalue: It is not he who is so

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: He is young, and therefore his disposition is a kind one.
children.prevalue: He is young and therefore his disposition is a kind one

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: He is young, and either he is weak, or his passions are strong; and Monsieur Colbert holds his weakness and his passions in his villainous grasp.
children.prevalue: He is young and either he is weak or his passions are strong and Monsieur Colbert holds his weakness and his passions in his villainous grasp

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: You admit that you fear him?
children.prevalue: You admit that you fear him

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: I do not deny it.
children.prevalue: I do not deny it

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: I that case I am lost.
children.prevalue: I that case I am lost

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Why so?
children.prevalue: Why so

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: My only influence with the king has been through the money I commanded, and now I am a ruined man.
children.prevalue: My only influence with the king has been through the money I commanded and now I am a ruined man

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Not so.
children.prevalue: Not so

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: What do you mean by 'not so?' Do you know my affairs better than myself?
children.prevalue: What do you mean by not so Do you know my affairs better than myself

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: That is not unlikely.
children.prevalue: That is not unlikely

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: If he were to request this fete to be given?
children.prevalue: If he were to request this fete to be given

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: You would give it, of course.
children.prevalue: You would give it of course

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: But where is the money to come from?
children.prevalue: But where is the money to come from

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Have you ever been in want of any?
children.prevalue: Have you ever been in want of any

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Oh! if you only knew at what a cost I procured the last supply.
children.prevalue: Oh if you only knew at what a cost I procured the last supply

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: The next shall cost you nothing.
children.prevalue: The next shall cost you nothing

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: But who will give it me?
children.prevalue: But who will give it me

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: I will.
children.prevalue: I will

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: What, give me six millions?
children.prevalue: What give me six millions

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Ten, if necessary.
children.prevalue: Ten if necessary

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: Upon my word, D'Herblay, said Fouquet, your confidence alarms me more than the king's displeasure. Who can you possibly be, after all?
children.prevalue: Upon my word D Herblay said Fouquet your confidence alarms me more than the king s displeasure Who can you possibly be after all

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: You know me well enough, I should think.
children.prevalue: You know me well enough I should think

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Of course; but what is it you are aiming at?
children.prevalue: Of course but what is it you are aiming at

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: I wish to see upon the throne of France a king devoted to Monsieur Fouquet, and I wish Monsieur Fouquet to be devoted to me.
children.prevalue: I wish to see upon the throne of France a king devoted to Monsieur Fouquet and I wish Monsieur Fouquet to be devoted to me

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: Oh! exclaimed Fouquet, pressing his hand,as for being devoted to you, I am yours, entirely; but believe me, my dear D'Herblay, you are deceiving yourself.
children.prevalue: Oh exclaimed Fouquet pressing his hand as for being devoted to you I am yours entirely but believe me my dear D Herblay you are deceiving yourself

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: In what respect?
children.prevalue: In what respect

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: The king will never become devoted to me.
children.prevalue: The king will never become devoted to me

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: I do not remember to have said that King Louis would ever become devoted to you.
children.prevalue: I do not remember to have said that King Louis would ever become devoted to you

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: Why, on the contrary, you have this moment said so.
children.prevalue: Why on the contrary you have this moment said so

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: I did not say the king; I said a king.
children.prevalue: I did not say the king I said a king

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: Is it not all the same?
children.prevalue: Is it not all the same

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: No, on the contrary, it is altogether different.
children.prevalue: No on the contrary it is altogether different

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: I do not understand you.
children.prevalue: I do not understand you

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: You will do so, shortly, then; suppose, for instance, the king in question were to be a very different person to Louis XIV.
children.prevalue: You will do so shortly then suppose for instance the king in question were to be a very different person to Louis XIV

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: Another person.
children.prevalue: Another person

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: Yes, who is indebted for everything to you.
children.prevalue: Yes who is indebted for everything to you

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: Impossible.
children.prevalue: Impossible

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: His very throne, even.
children.prevalue: His very throne even

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: You are mad, D'Herblay. There is no man living besides Louis XIV. who can sit on the throne of France. I know of none, not one.
children.prevalue: You are mad D Herblay There is no man living besides Louis XIV who can sit on the throne of France I know of none not one

children.name: Paragraph_145
children.value: But I know one.
children.prevalue: But I know one

children.name: Paragraph_146
children.value: Unless it be Monsieur, said Fouquet, looking at Aramis uneasily; yet Monsieur
children.prevalue: Unless it be Monsieur said Fouquet looking at Aramis uneasily yet Monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_147
children.value: It is not Monsieur.
children.prevalue: It is not Monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_148
children.value: But how can it be, that a prince not of the royal line, that a prince without any right
children.prevalue: But how can it be that a prince not of the royal line that a prince without any right

children.name: Paragraph_149
children.value: My king, or rather your king, will be everything that is necessary, be assured of that.
children.prevalue: My king or rather your king will be everything that is necessary be assured of that

children.name: Paragraph_150
children.value: Be careful, Monsieur d'Herblay, you make my blood run cold, and my head swim.
children.prevalue: Be careful Monsieur d Herblay you make my blood run cold and my head swim

children.name: Paragraph_151
children.value: Aramis smiled. There is but little occasion for that, he replied.
children.prevalue: Aramis smiled There is but little occasion for that he replied

children.name: Paragraph_152
children.value: Again, I repeat, you terrify me, said Fouquet. Aramis smiled.
children.prevalue: Again I repeat you terrify me said Fouquet Aramis smiled

children.name: Paragraph_153
children.value: You laugh, said Fouquet.
children.prevalue: You laugh said Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_154
children.value: The day will come when you will laugh too; only at the present moment I must laugh alone.
children.prevalue: The day will come when you will laugh too only at the present moment I must laugh alone

children.name: Paragraph_155
children.value: But explain yourself.
children.prevalue: But explain yourself

children.name: Paragraph_156
children.value: When the proper time comes, I will explain all. Fear nothing. Have faith in me, and doubt nothing.
children.prevalue: When the proper time comes I will explain all Fear nothing Have faith in me and doubt nothing

children.name: Paragraph_157
children.value: The fact is, I cannot but doubt, because I do not see clearly, or even at all.
children.prevalue: The fact is I cannot but doubt because I do not see clearly or even at all

children.name: Paragraph_158
children.value: That is because of your blindness; but a day will come when you will be enlightened.
children.prevalue: That is because of your blindness but a day will come when you will be enlightened

children.name: Paragraph_159
children.value: Oh! said Fouquet, how willingly would I believe.
children.prevalue: Oh said Fouquet how willingly would I believe

children.name: Paragraph_160
children.value: You, without belief! you, who, through my means, have ten times crossed the abyss yawning at your feet, and in which, had you been alone, you would have been irretrievably swallowed; you, without belief; you, who from procureurgeneral attained the rank of intendant, from the rank of intendant, that of the first minister of the crown, and who from the rank of first minister will pass to that of mayor of the palace. But no, he said, with the same unaltered smile, no, no, you cannot see, and consequently cannot believewhat I tell you. And Aramis rose to withdraw.
children.prevalue: You without belief you who through my means have ten times crossed the abyss yawning at your feet and in which had you been alone you would have been irretrievably swallowed you without belief you who from procureurgeneral attained the rank of intendant from the rank of intendant that of the first minister of the crown and who from the rank of first minister will pass to that of mayor of the palace But no he said with the same unaltered smile no no you cannot see and consequently cannot believewhat I tell you And Aramis rose to withdraw

children.name: Paragraph_161
children.value: One word more, said Fouquet; you have never yet spoken to me in this manner, you have never yet shown yourself so confident, I should rather say so daring.
children.prevalue: One word more said Fouquet you have never yet spoken to me in this manner you have never yet shown yourself so confident I should rather say so daring

children.name: Paragraph_162
children.value: Because it is necessary, in order to speak confidently, to have the lips unfettered.
children.prevalue: Because it is necessary in order to speak confidently to have the lips unfettered

children.name: Paragraph_163
children.value: And that is now your case?
children.prevalue: And that is now your case

children.name: Paragraph_164
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_165
children.value: Since a very short time, then?
children.prevalue: Since a very short time then

children.name: Paragraph_166
children.value: Since yesterday, only.
children.prevalue: Since yesterday only

children.name: Paragraph_167
children.value: Oh! Monsieur d'Herblay, take care, your confidence is becoming audacity.
children.prevalue: Oh Monsieur d Herblay take care your confidence is becoming audacity

children.name: Paragraph_168
children.value: One can well be audacious when one is powerful.
children.prevalue: One can well be audacious when one is powerful

children.name: Paragraph_169
children.value: And you are powerful?
children.prevalue: And you are powerful

children.name: Paragraph_170
children.value: I have already offered you ten millions; I repeat the offer.
children.prevalue: I have already offered you ten millions I repeat the offer

children.name: Paragraph_171
children.value: Fouquet rose, profoundly agitated.
children.prevalue: Fouquet rose profoundly agitated

children.name: Paragraph_172
children.value: Come, he said, come; you spoke of overthrowing kings and replacing them by others. If, indeed, I am not really out of my senses, is or is not that what you said just now?
children.prevalue: Come he said come you spoke of overthrowing kings and replacing them by others If indeed I am not really out of my senses is or is not that what you said just now

children.name: Paragraph_173
children.value: You are by no means out of your senses, for it is perfectly true I did say all that just now.
children.prevalue: You are by no means out of your senses for it is perfectly true I did say all that just now

children.name: Paragraph_174
children.value: And why did you say so?
children.prevalue: And why did you say so

children.name: Paragraph_175
children.value: Because it is easy to speak in this manner of thrones being cast down, and kings being raised up, when one is, one's self, far above all kings and thrones, of this world at least.
children.prevalue: Because it is easy to speak in this manner of thrones being cast down and kings being raised up when one is one s self far above all kings and thrones of this world at least

children.name: Paragraph_176
children.value: Your power is infinite, then? cried Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Your power is infinite then cried Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_177
children.value: I have told you so already, and I repeat it, replied Aramis, with glistening eyes and trembling lips.
children.prevalue: I have told you so already and I repeat it replied Aramis with glistening eyes and trembling lips

children.name: Paragraph_178
children.value: Fouquet threw himself back in his chair, and buried his face in his hands. Aramis looked at him for a moment, as the angel of human destinies might have looked upon a simple mortal.
children.prevalue: Fouquet threw himself back in his chair and buried his face in his hands Aramis looked at him for a moment as the angel of human destinies might have looked upon a simple mortal

children.name: Paragraph_179
children.value: Adieu, he said to him, sleep undisturbed, and send your letter to La Valliere. Tomorrow we shall see each other again.
children.prevalue: Adieu he said to him sleep undisturbed and send your letter to La Valliere Tomorrow we shall see each other again

children.name: Paragraph_180
children.value: Yes, tomorrow, said Fouquet, shaking his hands like a man returning to his senses. But where shall we see each other?
children.prevalue: Yes tomorrow said Fouquet shaking his hands like a man returning to his senses But where shall we see each other

children.name: Paragraph_181
children.value: At the king's promenade, if you like.
children.prevalue: At the king s promenade if you like

children.name: Paragraph_182
children.value: Agreed. And they separated.
children.prevalue: Agreed And they separated

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The dawn of the following day was dark and gloomy, and as every one knew that the promenade was down in the royal programme, every one's gaze, as his eyes were opened, was directed towards the sky. Just above the tops of the trees a thick, suffocating vapor seemed to remain suspended, with barely sufficient power to rise thirty feet above the ground under the influence of the sun's rays, which was scarcely visible as a faint spot of lesser darkness through the veil of heavy mist. No dew had fallen in the morning; the turf was dried up for want of moisture, the flowers withered. The birds sang less inspiringly than usual upon the boughs, which remained motionless as the limbs of corpses. The strange confused and animated murmurs, which seemed born and to exist in virtue of the sun, that respiration of nature which is unceasingly heard amidst all other sounds, could not be heard now, and never had the silence been so profound.
children.prevalue: The dawn of the following day was dark and gloomy and as every one knew that the promenade was down in the royal programme every one s gaze as his eyes were opened was directed towards the sky Just above the tops of the trees a thick suffocating vapor seemed to remain suspended with barely sufficient power to rise thirty feet above the ground under the influence of the sun s rays which was scarcely visible as a faint spot of lesser darkness through the veil of heavy mist No dew had fallen in the morning the turf was dried up for want of moisture the flowers withered The birds sang less inspiringly than usual upon the boughs which remained motionless as the limbs of corpses The strange confused and animated murmurs which seemed born and to exist in virtue of the sun that respiration of nature which is unceasingly heard amidst all other sounds could not be heard now and never had the silence been so profound

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The king had noticed the cheerless aspect of the heavens as he approached the window immediately upon rising. But as all the necessary directions had been given respecting the promenade, and every preparation had been made accordingly, and as, which was far more imperious than anything else, Louis relied upon this promenade to satisfy the cravings of his imagination, and we will even already say, the clamorous desires of his heartthe king unhesitatingly decided that the appearance of the heavens had nothing whatever to do with the matter; that the promenade was arranged, and that, whatever the state of the weather, the promenade should take place. Besides, there are certain terrestrial sovereigns who seem to have accorded them privileged existences, and there are certain times when it might almost be supposed that the expressed wish of an earthly monarch has its influence over the Divine will. It was Virgil who observed of Augustus: Nocte pluit tota redeunt spectacula mane. [10]
children.prevalue: The king had noticed the cheerless aspect of the heavens as he approached the window immediately upon rising But as all the necessary directions had been given respecting the promenade and every preparation had been made accordingly and as which was far more imperious than anything else Louis relied upon this promenade to satisfy the cravings of his imagination and we will even already say the clamorous desires of his heartthe king unhesitatingly decided that the appearance of the heavens had nothing whatever to do with the matter that the promenade was arranged and that whatever the state of the weather the promenade should take place Besides there are certain terrestrial sovereigns who seem to have accorded them privileged existences and there are certain times when it might almost be supposed that the expressed wish of an earthly monarch has its influence over the Divine will It was Virgil who observed of Augustus Nocte pluit tota redeunt spectacula mane 10

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Louis attended mass as usual, but it was evident that his attention was somewhat distracted from the presence of the Creator by the remembrance of the creature. His mind was occupied during the service in reckoning more than once the number of minutes, then of seconds, which separated him from the blissful moment when the promenade would begin, that is to say, the moment when Madame would set out with her maids of honor. Besides, as a matter of course, everybody at the chateau was ignorant of the interview which had taken place between La Valliere and the king. Montalais, perhaps, with her usual chattering propensity, might have been disposed to talk about it; but Montalais on this occasion was held in check by Malicorne, who had securely fastened on her pretty lips the golden padlock of mutual interest. As for Louis XIV., his happiness was so extreme that he had forgiven Madame, or nearly so, her little piece of malice of the previous evening. In fact, he had occasion to congratulate himself rather than to complain of it. Had it not been for her illnatured action, he would not have received the letter from La Valliere; had it not been for the letter, he would have had no interview; and had it not been for the interview he would have remained undecided. His heart was filled with too much happiness for any illfeeling to remain in it, at that moment at least. Instead, therefore, of knitting his brows into a frown when he perceived his sisterinlaw, Louis resolved to receive her in a more friendly and gracious manner than usual. But on one condition only, that she would be ready to set out early. Such was the nature of Louis's thoughts during mass; which made him, during the ceremony, forget matters which, in his character of Most Christian King and of the eldest son of the Church, ought to have occupied his attention. He returned to the chateau, and as the promenade was fixed for midday, and it was at present just ten o'clock, he set to work desperately with Colbert and Lyonne. But even while he worked Louis went from the table to the window, inasmuch as the window looked out upon Madame's pavilion: he could see M. Fouquet in the courtyard, to whom the courtiers, since the favor shown towards him on the previous evening, paid greater attention than ever. The king, instinctively, on noticing Fouquet, turned towards Colbert, who was smiling, and seemed full of benevolence and delight, a state of feeling which had arisen from the very moment one of his secretaries had entered and handed him a pocketbook, which he had put unopened into his pocket. But, as there was always something sinister at the bottom of any delight expressed by Colbert, Louis preferred, of the smiles of the two men, that of Fouquet. He beckoned to the superintendent to come up, and turning towards Lyonne and Colbert, he said:Finish this matter, place it on my desk, and I will read it at my leisure. And he left the room. At the sign the king had made to him, Fouquet had hastened up the staircase, while Aramis, who was with the superintendent, quietly retired among the group of courtiers and disappeared without having been even observed by the king. The king and Fouquet met at the top of the staircase.

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Sire, said Fouquet, remarking the gracious manner in which Louis was about to receive him, your majesty has overwhelmed me with kindness during the last few days. It is not a youthful monarch, but a being of higher order, who reigns over France, one whom pleasure, happiness, and love acknowledge as their master. The king colored. The compliment, although flattering, was not the less somewhat pointed. Louis conducted Fouquet to a small room that divided his study from his sleepingapartment.
children.prevalue: Sire said Fouquet remarking the gracious manner in which Louis was about to receive him your majesty has overwhelmed me with kindness during the last few days It is not a youthful monarch but a being of higher order who reigns over France one whom pleasure happiness and love acknowledge as their master The king colored The compliment although flattering was not the less somewhat pointed Louis conducted Fouquet to a small room that divided his study from his sleepingapartment

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Do you know why I summoned you? said the king as he seated himself upon the edge of the window, so as not to lose anything that might be passing in the gardens which fronted the opposite entrance to Madame's pavilion.
children.prevalue: Do you know why I summoned you said the king as he seated himself upon the edge of the window so as not to lose anything that might be passing in the gardens which fronted the opposite entrance to Madame s pavilion

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: No, sire, replied Fouquet, but I am sure for something agreeable, if I am to judge from your majesty's gracious smile.
children.prevalue: No sire replied Fouquet but I am sure for something agreeable if I am to judge from your majesty s gracious smile

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: You are mistaken, then.
children.prevalue: You are mistaken then

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: I, sire?
children.prevalue: I sire

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: For I summoned you, on the contrary, to pick a quarrel with you.
children.prevalue: For I summoned you on the contrary to pick a quarrel with you

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: With me, sire?
children.prevalue: With me sire

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Yes: and that a serious one.
children.prevalue: Yes and that a serious one

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Your majesty alarms meand yet I was most confident in your justice and goodness.
children.prevalue: Your majesty alarms meand yet I was most confident in your justice and goodness

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Do you know I am told, Monsieur Fouquet, that you are preparing a grand fete at Vaux.
children.prevalue: Do you know I am told Monsieur Fouquet that you are preparing a grand fete at Vaux

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Fouquet smiled, as a sick man would do at the first shiver of a fever which has left him but returns again.
children.prevalue: Fouquet smiled as a sick man would do at the first shiver of a fever which has left him but returns again

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: And that you have not invited me! continued the king.
children.prevalue: And that you have not invited me continued the king

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Sire, replied Fouquet, I have not even thought of the fete you speak of, and it was only yesterday evening that one of my friends, Fouquet laid a stress upon the word, was kind enough to make me think of it.
children.prevalue: Sire replied Fouquet I have not even thought of the fete you speak of and it was only yesterday evening that one of my friends Fouquet laid a stress upon the word was kind enough to make me think of it

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Yet I saw you yesterday evening, Monsieur Fouquet, and you said nothing to me about it.
children.prevalue: Yet I saw you yesterday evening Monsieur Fouquet and you said nothing to me about it

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: How dared I hope that your majesty would so greatly descend from your own exalted station as to honor my dwelling with your royal presence?
children.prevalue: How dared I hope that your majesty would so greatly descend from your own exalted station as to honor my dwelling with your royal presence

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Excuse me, Monsieur Fouquet, you did not speak to me about your fete.
children.prevalue: Excuse me Monsieur Fouquet you did not speak to me about your fete

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: I did not allude to the fete to your majesty, I repeat, in the first place, because nothing had been decided with regard to it, and, secondly, because I feared a refusal.
children.prevalue: I did not allude to the fete to your majesty I repeat in the first place because nothing had been decided with regard to it and secondly because I feared a refusal

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: And something made you fear a refusal, Monsieur Fouquet? You see I am determined to push you hard.
children.prevalue: And something made you fear a refusal Monsieur Fouquet You see I am determined to push you hard

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The profound wish I had that your majesty should accept my invitation
children.prevalue: The profound wish I had that your majesty should accept my invitation

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Well, Monsieur Fouquet, nothing is easier, I perceive, than our coming to an understanding. Your wish is to invite me to your fete, my own is to be present at it; invite me and I will go.
children.prevalue: Well Monsieur Fouquet nothing is easier I perceive than our coming to an understanding Your wish is to invite me to your fete my own is to be present at it invite me and I will go

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Is it possible that your majesty will deign to accept? murmured the superintendent.
children.prevalue: Is it possible that your majesty will deign to accept murmured the superintendent

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Why, really, monsieur, said the king, laughing, I think I do more than accept; I rather fancy I am inviting myself.
children.prevalue: Why really monsieur said the king laughing I think I do more than accept I rather fancy I am inviting myself

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Your majesty overwhelms me with honor and delight, exclaimed Fouquet, but I shall be obliged to repeat what M. Vieuville said to your ancestor, Henry IV., Domine non sum dignus. [11]
children.prevalue: Your majesty overwhelms me with honor and delight exclaimed Fouquet but I shall be obliged to repeat what M Vieuville said to your ancestor Henry IV Domine non sum dignus 11

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: To which I reply, Monsieur Fouquet, that if you give a fete, I will go, whether I am invited or not.
children.prevalue: To which I reply Monsieur Fouquet that if you give a fete I will go whether I am invited or not

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I thank your majesty deeply, said Fouquet, as he raised his head beneath this favor, which he was convinced would be his ruin.
children.prevalue: I thank your majesty deeply said Fouquet as he raised his head beneath this favor which he was convinced would be his ruin

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: But how could your majesty have been informed of it?
children.prevalue: But how could your majesty have been informed of it

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: By a public rumor, Monsieur Fouquet, which says such wonderful things of yourself and the marvels of your house. Would you become proud, Monsieur Fouquet, if the king were to be jealous of you?
children.prevalue: By a public rumor Monsieur Fouquet which says such wonderful things of yourself and the marvels of your house Would you become proud Monsieur Fouquet if the king were to be jealous of you

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: I should be the happiest man in the world, sire, since the very day on which your majesty were to be jealous of Vaux, I should possess something worthy of being offered to you.
children.prevalue: I should be the happiest man in the world sire since the very day on which your majesty were to be jealous of Vaux I should possess something worthy of being offered to you

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Very well, Monsieur Fouquet, prepare your fete, and open the door of your house as wide as possible.
children.prevalue: Very well Monsieur Fouquet prepare your fete and open the door of your house as wide as possible

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: It is for your majesty to fix the day.
children.prevalue: It is for your majesty to fix the day

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: This day month, then.
children.prevalue: This day month then

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Has your majesty any further commands?
children.prevalue: Has your majesty any further commands

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Nothing, Monsieur Fouquet, except from the present moment until then to have you near me as much as possible.
children.prevalue: Nothing Monsieur Fouquet except from the present moment until then to have you near me as much as possible

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I have the honor to form one of your majesty's party for the promenade.
children.prevalue: I have the honor to form one of your majesty s party for the promenade

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Very good; indeed, I am now setting out; for there are the ladies, I see, who are going to start.
children.prevalue: Very good indeed I am now setting out for there are the ladies I see who are going to start

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: With this remark, the king, with all the eagerness, not only of a young man, but of a young man in love, withdrew from the window, in order to take his gloves and cane, which his valet held ready for him. The neighing of the horses and the crunching of the wheels on the gravel of the courtyard could be distinctly heard. The king descended the stairs, and at the moment he appeared upon the flight of steps, every one stopped. The king walked straight up to the young queen. The queenmother, who was still suffering more than ever from the illness with which she was afflicted, did not wish to go out. Maria Theresa accompanied Madame in her carriage, and asked the king in what direction he wished the promenade to drive. The king, who had just seen La Valliere, still pale from the event of the previous evening, get into a carriage with three of her companions, told the queen that he had no preference, and wherever she would like to go, there would he be with her. The queen then desired that the outriders should proceed in the direction of Apremont. The outriders set off accordingly before the others. The king rode on horseback, and for a few minutes accompanied the carriage of the queen and Madame. The weather had cleared up a little, but a kind of veil of dust, like a thick gauze, was still spread over the surface of the heavens, and the sun made every atom glisten within the circuit of its rays. The heat was stifling; but, as the king did not seem to pay any attention to the appearance of the heavens, no one made himself uneasy about it, and the promenade, in obedience to the orders given by the queen, took its course in the direction of Apremont. The courtiers who followed were in the very highest spirits; it was evident that every one tried to forget, and to make others forget, the bitter discussions of the previous evening. Madame, particularly, was delightful. In fact, seeing the king at the door of her carriage, as she did not suppose he would be there for the queen's sake, she hoped that her prince had returned to her. Hardly, however, had they proceeded a quarter of a mile on the road, when the king, with a gracious smile, saluted them and drew up his horse, leaving the queen's carriage to pass on, then that of the principal ladies of honor, and then all the others in succession, who, seeing the king stop, wished in their turn to stop too; but the king made a sign to them to continue their progress. When La Valliere's carriage passed, the king approached it, saluted the ladies who were inside, and was preparing to accompany the carriage containing the maids of honor, in the same way he had followed that in which Madame was, when suddenly the whole file of carriages stopped. It was probable that Madame, uneasy at the king having left her, had just given directions for the performance of this maneuver, the direction in which the promenade was to take place having been left to her. The king, having sent to inquire what her object was in stopping the cavalcade, was informed in reply, that she wished to walk. She most likely hoped that the king, who was following the carriages of the maids of honor on horseback, would not venture to follow the maids of honor themselves on foot. They had arrived in the middle of the forest.

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: The promenade, in fact, was not illtimed, especially for those who were dreamers or lovers. From the little open space where the halt had taken place, three beautiful long walks, shady and undulating, stretched out before them. These walks were covered with moss or with leaves that formed a carpet from the loom of nature; and each walk had its horizon in the distance, consisting of about a handbreadth of sky, apparent through the interlacing of the branches of the trees. At the end of almost every walk, evidently in great tribulation and uneasiness, the startled deer were seen hurrying to and fro, first stopping for a moment in the middle of the path, and then raising their heads they fled with the speed of an arrow or bounded into the depths of the forest, where they disappeared from view; now and then a rabbit, of philosophical mien, might be noticed quietly sitting upright, rubbing his muzzle with his fore paws, and looking about inquiringly, as though wondering whether all these people, who were approaching in his direction, and who had just disturbed him in his meditations and his meal, were not followed by their dogs, or had not their guns under their arms. All alighted from their carriages as soon as they observed that the queen was doing so. Maria Theresa took the arm of one of her ladies of honor, and, with a side glance towards the king, who did not perceive that he was in the slightest degree the object of the queen's attention, entered the forest by the first path before her. Two of the outriders preceded her majesty with long poles, which they used for the purpose of putting the branches of the trees aside, or removing the bushes that might impede her progress. As soon as Madame alighted, she found the Comte de Guiche at her side, who bowed and placed himself at her disposal. Monsieur, delighted with his bath of the two previous days, had announced his preference for the river, and, having given De Guiche leave of absence, remained at the chateau with the Chevalier de Lorraine and Manicamp. He was not in the slightest degree jealous. He had been looked for to no purpose among those present; but as Monsieur was a man who thought a great deal of himself, and usually added very little to the general pleasure, his absence was rather a subject of satisfaction than regret. Every one had followed the example which the queen and Madame had set, doing just as they pleased, according as chance or fancy influenced them. The king, we have already observed, remained near La Valliere, and, throwing himself off his horse at the moment the door of her carriage was opened, he offered her his hand to alight. Montalais and TonnayCharente immediately drew back and kept at a distance; the former from calculated, the latter from natural motives. There was this difference, however, between the two, that the one had withdrawn from a wish to please the king, the other for a very opposite reason. During the last halfhour the weather also had undergone a change; the veil which had been spread over the sky, as if driven by a blast of heated air, had become massed together in the western part of the heavens; and afterwards, as if driven by a current of air from the opposite direction, was now advancing slowly and heavily towards them. The approach of the storm could be felt, but as the king did not perceive it, no one thought it proper to do so. The promenade was therefore continued; some of the company, with minds ill at ease on the subject, raised their eyes from time to time towards the sky; others, even more timid still, walked about without wandering too far from the carriages, where they relied upon taking shelter in case the storm burst. The greater number of these, however, observing that the king fearlessly entered the wood with La Valliere, followed his majesty. The king, noticing this, took La Valliere's hand, and led her to a lateral forestalley; where no one this time ventured to follow him.
