children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: At this moment, and in the same direction, too, that the king and La Valliere had taken, except that they were in the wood itself instead of following the path, two men were walking together, utterly indifferent to the appearance of the heavens. Their heads were bent down in the manner of people occupied with matters of great moment. They had not observed either De Guiche or Madame, the king or La Valliere. Suddenly something fell through the air like a colossal sheet of flame, followed by a loud but distant rumbling noise.
children.prevalue: At this moment and in the same direction too that the king and La Valliere had taken except that they were in the wood itself instead of following the path two men were walking together utterly indifferent to the appearance of the heavens Their heads were bent down in the manner of people occupied with matters of great moment They had not observed either De Guiche or Madame the king or La Valliere Suddenly something fell through the air like a colossal sheet of flame followed by a loud but distant rumbling noise

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Ah! said one of them, raising his head, here comes the storm. Let us reach our carriages, my dear D'Herblay.
children.prevalue: Ah said one of them raising his head here comes the storm Let us reach our carriages my dear D Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Aramis looked inquiringly at the heavens. There is no occasion to hurry yet, he said; and then resuming the conversation where it had doubtless been interrupted, he said, You were observing that the letter we wrote last evening must by this time have reached its destination?
children.prevalue: Aramis looked inquiringly at the heavens There is no occasion to hurry yet he said and then resuming the conversation where it had doubtless been interrupted he said You were observing that the letter we wrote last evening must by this time have reached its destination

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: I was saying that she certainly has it.
children.prevalue: I was saying that she certainly has it

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Whom did you send it by?
children.prevalue: Whom did you send it by

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: By my own servant, as I have already told you.
children.prevalue: By my own servant as I have already told you

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Did he bring back an answer?
children.prevalue: Did he bring back an answer

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: I have not seen him since; the young girl was probably in attendance on Madame, or was in her own room dressing, and he may have had to wait. Our time for leaving arrived, and we set off, of course; I cannot, therefore, know what is going on yonder.
children.prevalue: I have not seen him since the young girl was probably in attendance on Madame or was in her own room dressing and he may have had to wait Our time for leaving arrived and we set off of course I cannot therefore know what is going on yonder

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Did you see the king before leaving?
children.prevalue: Did you see the king before leaving

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: How did he seem?
children.prevalue: How did he seem

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Nothing could have passed off better, or worse; according as he be sincere or hypocritical.
children.prevalue: Nothing could have passed off better or worse according as he be sincere or hypocritical

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: And the fete?
children.prevalue: And the fete

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Will take place in a month.
children.prevalue: Will take place in a month

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: He invited himself, you say?
children.prevalue: He invited himself you say

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: With a pertinacity in which I detected Colbert's influence. But has not last night removed your illusions?
children.prevalue: With a pertinacity in which I detected Colbert s influence But has not last night removed your illusions

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: What illusions?
children.prevalue: What illusions

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: With respect to the assistance you may be able to give me under these circumstances.
children.prevalue: With respect to the assistance you may be able to give me under these circumstances

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: No; I have passed the night writing, and all my orders are given.
children.prevalue: No I have passed the night writing and all my orders are given

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Do not conceal it from yourself, D'Herblay, but the fete will cost some millions.
children.prevalue: Do not conceal it from yourself D Herblay but the fete will cost some millions

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I will supply six; do you on your side get two or three.
children.prevalue: I will supply six do you on your side get two or three

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: You are a wonderful man, my dear D'Herblay.
children.prevalue: You are a wonderful man my dear D Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Aramis smiled.
children.prevalue: Aramis smiled

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: But, inquired Fouquet, with some remaining uneasiness, how is it that while you are now squandering millions in this manner, a few days ago you did not pay the fifty thousand francs to Baisemeaux out of your own pocket?
children.prevalue: But inquired Fouquet with some remaining uneasiness how is it that while you are now squandering millions in this manner a few days ago you did not pay the fifty thousand francs to Baisemeaux out of your own pocket

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Because a few days ago I was as poor as Job.
children.prevalue: Because a few days ago I was as poor as Job

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: And today?
children.prevalue: And today

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Today I am wealthier than the king himself.
children.prevalue: Today I am wealthier than the king himself

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Very well, said Fouquet; I understand men pretty well; I know you are incapable of forfeiting your word; I do not wish to wrest your secret from you, and so let us talk no more about it.
children.prevalue: Very well said Fouquet I understand men pretty well I know you are incapable of forfeiting your word I do not wish to wrest your secret from you and so let us talk no more about it

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: At this moment a dull, heavy rumbling was heard, which suddenly developed into a violent clap of thunder.
children.prevalue: At this moment a dull heavy rumbling was heard which suddenly developed into a violent clap of thunder

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Oh, oh! said Fouquet, I was quite right in what I said.
children.prevalue: Oh oh said Fouquet I was quite right in what I said

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Come, said Aramis, let us rejoin the carriages.
children.prevalue: Come said Aramis let us rejoin the carriages

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: We shall not have time, said Fouquet, for here comes the rain.
children.prevalue: We shall not have time said Fouquet for here comes the rain

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: In fact, as he spoke, and as if the heavens were opened, a shower of large drops of rain was suddenly heard pattering on the leaves about them.
children.prevalue: In fact as he spoke and as if the heavens were opened a shower of large drops of rain was suddenly heard pattering on the leaves about them

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: We shall have time, said Aramis, to reach the carriages before the foliage becomes saturated.
children.prevalue: We shall have time said Aramis to reach the carriages before the foliage becomes saturated

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: It will be better, said Fouquet, to take shelter somewherein a grotto, for instance.
children.prevalue: It will be better said Fouquet to take shelter somewherein a grotto for instance

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Yes, but where are we to find a grotto? inquired Aramis.
children.prevalue: Yes but where are we to find a grotto inquired Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I know one, said Fouquet, smiling, not ten paces from here. Then looking round him, he added: Yes, we are quite right.
children.prevalue: I know one said Fouquet smiling not ten paces from here Then looking round him he added Yes we are quite right

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: You are very fortunate to have so good a memory, said Aramis, smiling in his turn, but are you not afraid that your coachman, finding we do not return, will suppose we have taken another road back, and that he will not follow the carriages belonging to the court?
children.prevalue: You are very fortunate to have so good a memory said Aramis smiling in his turn but are you not afraid that your coachman finding we do not return will suppose we have taken another road back and that he will not follow the carriages belonging to the court

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Oh, there is no fear of that, said Fouquet; whenever I place my coachman and my carriage in any particular spot, nothing but an express order from the king could stir them; and more than that, too, it seems that we are not the only ones who have come so far, for I hear footsteps and the sound of voices.
children.prevalue: Oh there is no fear of that said Fouquet whenever I place my coachman and my carriage in any particular spot nothing but an express order from the king could stir them and more than that too it seems that we are not the only ones who have come so far for I hear footsteps and the sound of voices

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: As he spoke, Fouquet turned round, and opened with his cane a mass of foliage which hid the path from his view. Aramis's glance as well as his own plunged at the same moment through the aperture he had made.
children.prevalue: As he spoke Fouquet turned round and opened with his cane a mass of foliage which hid the path from his view Aramis s glance as well as his own plunged at the same moment through the aperture he had made

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: A woman, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: A woman said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: And a man, said Fouquet.
children.prevalue: And a man said Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: It is La Valliere and the king, they both exclaimed together.
children.prevalue: It is La Valliere and the king they both exclaimed together

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Oh, oh! said Aramis, is his majesty aware of your cavern as well? I should not be astonished if he were, for he seems to be on very good terms with the dryads of Fontainebleau.
children.prevalue: Oh oh said Aramis is his majesty aware of your cavern as well I should not be astonished if he were for he seems to be on very good terms with the dryads of Fontainebleau

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Never mind, said Fouquet; let us get there. If he is not aware of it, we shall see what he will do if he should know it, as it has two entrances, so that whilst he enters by one, we can leave by the other.
children.prevalue: Never mind said Fouquet let us get there If he is not aware of it we shall see what he will do if he should know it as it has two entrances so that whilst he enters by one we can leave by the other

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Is it far? asked Aramis, for the rain is beginning to penetrate.
children.prevalue: Is it far asked Aramis for the rain is beginning to penetrate

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: We are there now, said Fouquet, as he pushed aside a few branches, and an excavation in the solid rock could be observed, hitherto concealed by heaths, ivy, and a thick covert of small shrubs.
children.prevalue: We are there now said Fouquet as he pushed aside a few branches and an excavation in the solid rock could be observed hitherto concealed by heaths ivy and a thick covert of small shrubs

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Fouquet led the way, followed by Aramis; but as the latter entered the grotto, he turned round, saying: Yes, they are entering the wood; and, see, they are bending their steps this way.
children.prevalue: Fouquet led the way followed by Aramis but as the latter entered the grotto he turned round saying Yes they are entering the wood and see they are bending their steps this way

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Very well; let us make room for them, said Fouquet, smiling and pulling Aramis by his cloak; but I do not think the king knows of my grotto.
children.prevalue: Very well let us make room for them said Fouquet smiling and pulling Aramis by his cloak but I do not think the king knows of my grotto

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Yes, said Aramis, they are looking about them, but it is only for a thicker tree.
children.prevalue: Yes said Aramis they are looking about them but it is only for a thicker tree

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Aramis was not mistaken, the king's looks were directed upward, and not around him. He held La Valliere's arm within his own, and held her hand in his. La Valliere's feet began to sleep on the damp grass. Louis again looked round him with greater attention than before, and perceiving an enormous oak with widespreading branches, he hurriedly drew La Valliere beneath its protecting shelter. The poor girl looked round her on all sides, and seemed half afraid, half desirous of being followed. The king made her lean back against the trunk of the tree, whose vast circumference, protected by the thickness of the foliage, was as dry as if at that moment the rain had not been falling in torrents. He himself remained standing before her with his head uncovered. After a few minutes, however, some drops of rain penetrated through the branches of the tree and fell on the king's forehead, who did not pay any attention to them.
children.prevalue: Aramis was not mistaken the king s looks were directed upward and not around him He held La Valliere s arm within his own and held her hand in his La Valliere s feet began to sleep on the damp grass Louis again looked round him with greater attention than before and perceiving an enormous oak with widespreading branches he hurriedly drew La Valliere beneath its protecting shelter The poor girl looked round her on all sides and seemed half afraid half desirous of being followed The king made her lean back against the trunk of the tree whose vast circumference protected by the thickness of the foliage was as dry as if at that moment the rain had not been falling in torrents He himself remained standing before her with his head uncovered After a few minutes however some drops of rain penetrated through the branches of the tree and fell on the king s forehead who did not pay any attention to them

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Oh, sire! murmured La Valliere, pushing the king's hat towards him. But the king simply bowed, and determinedly refused to cover his head.
children.prevalue: Oh sire murmured La Valliere pushing the king s hat towards him But the king simply bowed and determinedly refused to cover his head

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Now or never is the time to offer your place, said Fouquet in Aramis's ear.
children.prevalue: Now or never is the time to offer your place said Fouquet in Aramis s ear

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Now or never is the time to listen, and not lose a syllable of what they may have to say to each other, replied Aramis in Fouquet's ear.
children.prevalue: Now or never is the time to listen and not lose a syllable of what they may have to say to each other replied Aramis in Fouquet s ear

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: In fact they both remained perfectly silent, and the king's voice reached them where they were.
children.prevalue: In fact they both remained perfectly silent and the king s voice reached them where they were

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Believe me, said the king, I perceive, or rather I can imagine your uneasiness; believe me, I sincerely regret having isolated you from the rest of the company, and brought you, also, to a spot where you will be inconvenienced by the rain. You are wet already, and perhaps cold too?
children.prevalue: Believe me said the king I perceive or rather I can imagine your uneasiness believe me I sincerely regret having isolated you from the rest of the company and brought you also to a spot where you will be inconvenienced by the rain You are wet already and perhaps cold too

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: No, sire.
children.prevalue: No sire

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: And yet you tremble?
children.prevalue: And yet you tremble

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: I am afraid, sire, that my absence may be misinterpreted; at a moment, too, when all the others are reunited.
children.prevalue: I am afraid sire that my absence may be misinterpreted at a moment too when all the others are reunited

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: I would not hesitate to propose returning to the carriages, Mademoiselle de la Valliere, but pray look and listen, and tell me if it be possible to attempt to make the slightest progress at present?
children.prevalue: I would not hesitate to propose returning to the carriages Mademoiselle de la Valliere but pray look and listen and tell me if it be possible to attempt to make the slightest progress at present

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: In fact the thunder was still rolling, and the rain continued to fall in torrents.
children.prevalue: In fact the thunder was still rolling and the rain continued to fall in torrents

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Besides, continued the king, no possible interpretation can be made which would be to your discredit. Are you not with the king of France; in other words, with the first gentleman of the kingdom?
children.prevalue: Besides continued the king no possible interpretation can be made which would be to your discredit Are you not with the king of France in other words with the first gentleman of the kingdom

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Certainly, sire, replied La Valliere, and it is a very distinguished honor for me; it is not, therefore, for myself that I fear any interpretations that may be made.
children.prevalue: Certainly sire replied La Valliere and it is a very distinguished honor for me it is not therefore for myself that I fear any interpretations that may be made

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: For whom, then?
children.prevalue: For whom then

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: For you, sire.
children.prevalue: For you sire

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: For me? said the king, smiling, I do not understand you.
children.prevalue: For me said the king smiling I do not understand you

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Has your majesty already forgotten what took place yesterday evening in her royal highness's apartments?
children.prevalue: Has your majesty already forgotten what took place yesterday evening in her royal highness s apartments

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Oh! forget that, I beg, or allow me to remember it for no other purpose than to thank you once more for your letter, and
children.prevalue: Oh forget that I beg or allow me to remember it for no other purpose than to thank you once more for your letter and

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Sire, interrupted La Valliere, the rain is falling, and your majesty's head is uncovered.
children.prevalue: Sire interrupted La Valliere the rain is falling and your majesty s head is uncovered

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: I entreat you not to think of anything but yourself.
children.prevalue: I entreat you not to think of anything but yourself

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Oh! I, said La Valliere, smiling, I am a country girl, accustomed to roaming through the meadows of the Loire and the gardens of Blois, whatever the weather may be. And, as for my clothes, she added, looking at her simple muslin dress, your majesty sees there is but little room for injury.
children.prevalue: Oh I said La Valliere smiling I am a country girl accustomed to roaming through the meadows of the Loire and the gardens of Blois whatever the weather may be And as for my clothes she added looking at her simple muslin dress your majesty sees there is but little room for injury

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Indeed, I have already noticed, more than once, that you owed nearly everything to yourself and nothing to your toilette. Your freedom from coquetry is one of your greatest charms in my eyes.
children.prevalue: Indeed I have already noticed more than once that you owed nearly everything to yourself and nothing to your toilette Your freedom from coquetry is one of your greatest charms in my eyes

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Sire, do not make me out better than I am, and say merely, 'You cannot possibly be a coquette.'
children.prevalue: Sire do not make me out better than I am and say merely You cannot possibly be a coquette

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Why so?
children.prevalue: Why so

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Because, said La Valliere, smiling, I am not rich.
children.prevalue: Because said La Valliere smiling I am not rich

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: You admit, then, said the king, quickly, that you have a love for beautiful things?
children.prevalue: You admit then said the king quickly that you have a love for beautiful things

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Sire, I only regard those things as beautiful which are within my reach. Everything which is too highly placed for me
children.prevalue: Sire I only regard those things as beautiful which are within my reach Everything which is too highly placed for me

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: You are indifferent to?
children.prevalue: You are indifferent to

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Is foreign to me, as being prohibited.
children.prevalue: Is foreign to me as being prohibited

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: And I, said the king, do not find that you are at my court on the footing you should be. The services of your family have not been sufficiently brought under my notice. The advancement of your family was cruelly neglected by my uncle.
children.prevalue: And I said the king do not find that you are at my court on the footing you should be The services of your family have not been sufficiently brought under my notice The advancement of your family was cruelly neglected by my uncle

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: On the contrary, sire. His royal highness, the Duke of Orleans, was always exceedingly kind towards M. de SaintRemy, my stepfather. The services rendered were humble, and, properly speaking, our services have been adequately recognized. It is not every one who is happy enough to find opportunities of serving his sovereign with distinction. I have no doubt at all, that, if ever opportunities had been met with, my family's actions would have been as lofty as their loyalty was firm: but that happiness was never ours.
children.prevalue: On the contrary sire His royal highness the Duke of Orleans was always exceedingly kind towards M de SaintRemy my stepfather The services rendered were humble and properly speaking our services have been adequately recognized It is not every one who is happy enough to find opportunities of serving his sovereign with distinction I have no doubt at all that if ever opportunities had been met with my family s actions would have been as lofty as their loyalty was firm but that happiness was never ours

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: In that case, Mademoiselle de la Valliere, it belongs to kings to repair the want of opportunity, and most delightedly do I undertake to repair, in your instance, and with the least possible delay, the wrongs of fortune towards you.
children.prevalue: In that case Mademoiselle de la Valliere it belongs to kings to repair the want of opportunity and most delightedly do I undertake to repair in your instance and with the least possible delay the wrongs of fortune towards you

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Nay, sire, cried La Valliere, eagerly; leave things, I beg, as they are now.
children.prevalue: Nay sire cried La Valliere eagerly leave things I beg as they are now

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Is it possible! you refuse what I ought, and what I wish to do for you?
children.prevalue: Is it possible you refuse what I ought and what I wish to do for you

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: All I desired has been granted me, when the honor was conferred upon me of forming one of Madame's household.
children.prevalue: All I desired has been granted me when the honor was conferred upon me of forming one of Madame s household

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: But if you refuse for yourself, at least accept for your family.
children.prevalue: But if you refuse for yourself at least accept for your family

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Your generous intentions, sire, bewilder me and make me apprehensive, for, in doing for my family what your kindness urges you to do, your majesty will raise up enemies for us, and enemies for yourself, too. Leave me in the ranks of middle life, sire; of all the feelings and sentiments I experience, leave me to enjoy the pleasing instinct of disinterestedness.
children.prevalue: Your generous intentions sire bewilder me and make me apprehensive for in doing for my family what your kindness urges you to do your majesty will raise up enemies for us and enemies for yourself too Leave me in the ranks of middle life sire of all the feelings and sentiments I experience leave me to enjoy the pleasing instinct of disinterestedness

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: The sentiments you express, said the king, are indeed admirable.
children.prevalue: The sentiments you express said the king are indeed admirable

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Quite true, murmured Aramis in Fouquet's ear, and he cannot be accustomed to them.
children.prevalue: Quite true murmured Aramis in Fouquet s ear and he cannot be accustomed to them

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: But, replied Fouquet, suppose she were to make a similar reply to my letter.
children.prevalue: But replied Fouquet suppose she were to make a similar reply to my letter

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: True! said Aramis, let us not anticipate, but wait the conclusion.
children.prevalue: True said Aramis let us not anticipate but wait the conclusion

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: And then, dear Monsieur d'Herblay, added the superintendent, hardly able to appreciate the sentiments which La Valliere had just expressed, it is very often sound calculation to seem disinterested with monarchs.
children.prevalue: And then dear Monsieur d Herblay added the superintendent hardly able to appreciate the sentiments which La Valliere had just expressed it is very often sound calculation to seem disinterested with monarchs

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Exactly what I was thinking this very minute, said Aramis. Let us listen.
children.prevalue: Exactly what I was thinking this very minute said Aramis Let us listen

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: The king approached nearer to La Valliere, and as the rain dripped more and more through the foliage of the oak, he held his hat over the head of the young girl, who raised her beautiful blue eyes towards the royal hat which sheltered her, and shook her head, sighing deeply as she did so.
children.prevalue: The king approached nearer to La Valliere and as the rain dripped more and more through the foliage of the oak he held his hat over the head of the young girl who raised her beautiful blue eyes towards the royal hat which sheltered her and shook her head sighing deeply as she did so

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: What melancholy thought, said the king, can possibly reach your heart when I place mine as a rampart before it?
children.prevalue: What melancholy thought said the king can possibly reach your heart when I place mine as a rampart before it

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: I will tell you, sire. I had already once before broached this question, which is so difficult for a young girl of my age to discuss, but your majesty imposed silence on me. Your majesty belongs not to yourself alone: you are married; and every sentiment which would separate your majesty from the queen, in leading you to take notice of me, will be a source of profoundest sorrow for the queen. The king endeavored to interrupt the young girl, but she continued with a suppliant gesture. The Queen Maria, with an attachment which can be well understood, follows with her eyes every step of your majesty which separates you from her. Happy enough in having had her fate united to your own, she weepingly implores Heaven to preserve you to her, and is jealous of the faintest throb of your heart bestowed elsewhere. The king again seemed anxious to speak, but again did La Valliere venture to prevent him.Would it not, therefore, be a most blamable action, she continued, if your majesty, a witness of this anxious and disinterested affection, gave the queen any cause for jealousy? Forgive me, sire, for the expressions I have used. I well know it is impossible, or rather that it would be impossible, that the greatest queen of the whole world could be jealous of a poor girl like myself. But though a queen, she is still a woman, and her heart, like that of the rest of her sex, cannot close itself against the suspicions which such as are evilly disposed, insinuate. For Heaven's sake, sire, think no more of me; I am unworthy of your regard.
children.prevalue: I will tell you sire I had already once before broached this question which is so difficult for a young girl of my age to discuss but your majesty imposed silence on me Your majesty belongs not to yourself alone you are married and every sentiment which would separate your majesty from the queen in leading you to take notice of me will be a source of profoundest sorrow for the queen The king endeavored to interrupt the young girl but she continued with a suppliant gesture The Queen Maria with an attachment which can be well understood follows with her eyes every step of your majesty which separates you from her Happy enough in having had her fate united to your own she weepingly implores Heaven to preserve you to her and is jealous of the faintest throb of your heart bestowed elsewhere The king again seemed anxious to speak but again did La Valliere venture to prevent him Would it not therefore be a most blamable action she continued if your majesty a witness of this anxious and disinterested affection gave the queen any cause for jealousy Forgive me sire for the expressions I have used I well know it is impossible or rather that it would be impossible that the greatest queen of the whole world could be jealous of a poor girl like myself But though a queen she is still a woman and her heart like that of the rest of her sex cannot close itself against the suspicions which such as are evilly disposed insinuate For Heaven s sake sire think no more of me I am unworthy of your regard

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Do you not know that in speaking as you have done, you change my esteem for you into the profoundest admiration?
children.prevalue: Do you not know that in speaking as you have done you change my esteem for you into the profoundest admiration

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Sire, you assume my words to be contrary to the truth; you suppose me to be better than I really am, and attach a greater merit to me than God ever intended should be the case. Spare me, sire; for, did I not know that your majesty was the most generous man in your kingdom, I should believe you were jesting.
children.prevalue: Sire you assume my words to be contrary to the truth you suppose me to be better than I really am and attach a greater merit to me than God ever intended should be the case Spare me sire for did I not know that your majesty was the most generous man in your kingdom I should believe you were jesting

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: You do not, I know, fear such a thing; I am quite sure of that, exclaimed Louis.
children.prevalue: You do not I know fear such a thing I am quite sure of that exclaimed Louis

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: I shall be obliged to believe it, if your majesty continues to hold such language towards me.
children.prevalue: I shall be obliged to believe it if your majesty continues to hold such language towards me

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: I am most unhappy, then, said the king, in a tone of regret which was not assumed; I am the unhappiest prince in the Christian world, since I am powerless to induce belief in my words, in one whom I love the best in the wide world, and who almost breaks my heart by refusing to credit my regard for her.
children.prevalue: I am most unhappy then said the king in a tone of regret which was not assumed I am the unhappiest prince in the Christian world since I am powerless to induce belief in my words in one whom I love the best in the wide world and who almost breaks my heart by refusing to credit my regard for her

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Oh, sire! said La Valliere, gently putting the king aside, who had approached nearer to her, I think the storm has passed away now, and the rain has ceased. At the very moment, however, as the poor girl, fleeing as it were from her own heart, which doubtless throbbed but too well in unison with the king's, uttered these words, the storm undertook to contradict her. A deadwhite flash of lightning illumined the forest with a weird glare, and a peal of thunder, like a discharge of artillery, burst over their heads, as if the height of the oak that sheltered them had attracted the storm. The young girl could not repress a cry of terror. The king with one hand drew her towards his heart, and stretched the other above her head, as though to shield her from the lightning. A moment's silence ensued, as the group, delightful as everything young and loving is delightful, remained motionless, while Fouquet and Aramis contemplated it in attitudes as motionless as La Valliere and the king. Oh, sire! murmured La Valliere, do you hear? and her head fell upon his shoulder.
children.prevalue: Oh sire said La Valliere gently putting the king aside who had approached nearer to her I think the storm has passed away now and the rain has ceased At the very moment however as the poor girl fleeing as it were from her own heart which doubtless throbbed but too well in unison with the king s uttered these words the storm undertook to contradict her A deadwhite flash of lightning illumined the forest with a weird glare and a peal of thunder like a discharge of artillery burst over their heads as if the height of the oak that sheltered them had attracted the storm The young girl could not repress a cry of terror The king with one hand drew her towards his heart and stretched the other above her head as though to shield her from the lightning A moment s silence ensued as the group delightful as everything young and loving is delightful remained motionless while Fouquet and Aramis contemplated it in attitudes as motionless as La Valliere and the king Oh sire murmured La Valliere do you hear and her head fell upon his shoulder

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Yes, said the king. You see, the storm has not passed away.
children.prevalue: Yes said the king You see the storm has not passed away

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: It is a warning, sire. The king smiled. Sire, it is the voice of Heaven in anger.
children.prevalue: It is a warning sire The king smiled Sire it is the voice of Heaven in anger

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Be it so, said the king. I agree to accept that peal of thunder as a warning, and even as a menace, if, in five minutes from the present moment, it is renewed with equal violence; but if not, permit me to think that the storm is a storm simply, and nothing more. And the king, at the same moment, raised his head, as if to interrogate the heavens. But, as if the remark had been heard and accepted, during the five minutes which elapsed after the burst of thunder which had alarmed them, no renewed peal was heard; and, when the thunder was again heard, it was passing as plainly as if, during those same five minutes, the storm, put to flight, had traversed the heavens with the wings of the wind. Well, Louise, said the king, in a low tone of voice, do you still threaten me with the anger of Heaven? and, since you wished to regard the storm as a warning, do you still believe it bodes misfortune?
children.prevalue: Be it so said the king I agree to accept that peal of thunder as a warning and even as a menace if in five minutes from the present moment it is renewed with equal violence but if not permit me to think that the storm is a storm simply and nothing more And the king at the same moment raised his head as if to interrogate the heavens But as if the remark had been heard and accepted during the five minutes which elapsed after the burst of thunder which had alarmed them no renewed peal was heard and when the thunder was again heard it was passing as plainly as if during those same five minutes the storm put to flight had traversed the heavens with the wings of the wind Well Louise said the king in a low tone of voice do you still threaten me with the anger of Heaven and since you wished to regard the storm as a warning do you still believe it bodes misfortune

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: The young girl looked up, and saw that while they had been talking, the rain had penetrated the foliage above them, and was trickling down the king's face. Oh, sire, sire! she exclaimed, in accents of eager apprehensions, which greatly agitated the king. Is it for me, she murmured, that the king remains thus uncovered, and exposed to the rain? What am I, then?
children.prevalue: The young girl looked up and saw that while they had been talking the rain had penetrated the foliage above them and was trickling down the king s face Oh sire sire she exclaimed in accents of eager apprehensions which greatly agitated the king Is it for me she murmured that the king remains thus uncovered and exposed to the rain What am I then

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: You are, you perceive, said the king, the divinity who dissipates the storm, and brings back fine weather. In fact, even as the king spoke, a ray of sunlight streamed through the forest, and caused the raindrops which rested upon the leaves, or fell vertically among the openings in the branches of the trees, to glisten like diamonds.
children.prevalue: You are you perceive said the king the divinity who dissipates the storm and brings back fine weather In fact even as the king spoke a ray of sunlight streamed through the forest and caused the raindrops which rested upon the leaves or fell vertically among the openings in the branches of the trees to glisten like diamonds

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Sire, said La Valliere, almost overcome, but making a powerful effort over herself, think of the anxieties your majesty will have to submit to on my account. At this very moment, they are seeking you in every direction. The queen must be full of uneasiness; and Madameoh, Madame! the young girl exclaimed, with an expression almost resembling terror.
children.prevalue: Sire said La Valliere almost overcome but making a powerful effort over herself think of the anxieties your majesty will have to submit to on my account At this very moment they are seeking you in every direction The queen must be full of uneasiness and Madameoh Madame the young girl exclaimed with an expression almost resembling terror

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: This name had a certain effect upon the king. He started, and disengaged himself from La Valliere, whom he had, till that moment, held pressed against his heart. He then advanced towards the path, in order to look round, and returned, somewhat thoughtfully, to La Valliere. Madame, did you say? he remarked.
children.prevalue: This name had a certain effect upon the king He started and disengaged himself from La Valliere whom he had till that moment held pressed against his heart He then advanced towards the path in order to look round and returned somewhat thoughtfully to La Valliere Madame did you say he remarked

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Yes, Madame; she, too, is jealous, said La Valliere, with a marked tone of voice; and her eyes, so timorous in their expression, and so modestly fugitive in their glance, for a moment, ventured to look inquiringly into the king's.
children.prevalue: Yes Madame she too is jealous said La Valliere with a marked tone of voice and her eyes so timorous in their expression and so modestly fugitive in their glance for a moment ventured to look inquiringly into the king s

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Still, returned Louis, making an effort over himself, it seems to me that Madame has no reason, no right to be jealous of me.
children.prevalue: Still returned Louis making an effort over himself it seems to me that Madame has no reason no right to be jealous of me

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Alas! murmured La Valliere.
children.prevalue: Alas murmured La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Are you, too, said the king, almost in a tone of reproach, are you among those who think the sister has a right to be jealous of the brother?
children.prevalue: Are you too said the king almost in a tone of reproach are you among those who think the sister has a right to be jealous of the brother

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: It is not for me, sire, to seek to penetrate your majesty's secrets.
children.prevalue: It is not for me sire to seek to penetrate your majesty s secrets

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: You do believe it, then? exclaimed the king.
children.prevalue: You do believe it then exclaimed the king

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: I believe Madame is jealous, sire, La Valliere replied, firmly.
children.prevalue: I believe Madame is jealous sire La Valliere replied firmly

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Is it possible, said the king with some anxiety, that you have perceived it, then, from her conduct towards you? Have her manners in any way been such towards you that you can attribute them to the jealousy you speak of?
children.prevalue: Is it possible said the king with some anxiety that you have perceived it then from her conduct towards you Have her manners in any way been such towards you that you can attribute them to the jealousy you speak of

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Not at all, sire; I am of so little importance.
children.prevalue: Not at all sire I am of so little importance

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Oh! if it were really the case exclaimed Louis, violently.
children.prevalue: Oh if it were really the case exclaimed Louis violently

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Sire, interrupted the young girl, it has ceased raining; some one is coming, I think. And, forgetful of all etiquette, she had seized the king by the arm.
children.prevalue: Sire interrupted the young girl it has ceased raining some one is coming I think And forgetful of all etiquette she had seized the king by the arm

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Well, replied the king, let them come. Who is there who would venture to think I had done wrong in remaining alone with Mademoiselle de la Valliere?
children.prevalue: Well replied the king let them come Who is there who would venture to think I had done wrong in remaining alone with Mademoiselle de la Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: For pity's sake, sire! they will think it strange to see you wet through, in this manner, and that you should have run such risk for me.
children.prevalue: For pity s sake sire they will think it strange to see you wet through in this manner and that you should have run such risk for me

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: I have simply done my duty as a gentleman, said Louis; and woe to him who may fail in his, in criticising his sovereign's conduct. In fact, at this moment a few eager and curious faces were seen in the walk, as if engaged in a search. Catching glimpses at last of the king and La Valliere, they seemed to have found what they were seeking. They were some of the courtiers who had been sent by the queen and Madame, and uncovered themselves, in token of having perceived his majesty. But Louis, notwithstanding La Valliere's confusion, did not quit his respectful and tender attitude. Then, when all the courtiers were assembled in the walkwhen every one had been able to perceive the extraordinary mark of deference with which he had treated the young girl, by remaining standing and bareheaded during the stormhe offered her his arm, led her towards the group who were waiting, recognized by an inclination of the head the respectful salutations which were paid him on all sides; and, still holding his hat in his hand, he conducted her to her carriage. And, as a few sparse drops of rain continued to falla last adieu of the vanishing stormthe other ladies, whom respect had prevented from getting into their carriages before the king, remained altogether unprotected by hood or cloak, exposed to the rain from which the king was protecting, as well as he was able, the humblest among them. The queen and Madame must, like the others, have witnessed this exaggerated courtesy of the king. Madame was so disconcerted at it, that she touched the queen with her elbow, saying at the same time, Look there, look there.
children.prevalue: I have simply done my duty as a gentleman said Louis and woe to him who may fail in his in criticising his sovereign s conduct In fact at this moment a few eager and curious faces were seen in the walk as if engaged in a search Catching glimpses at last of the king and La Valliere they seemed to have found what they were seeking They were some of the courtiers who had been sent by the queen and Madame and uncovered themselves in token of having perceived his majesty But Louis notwithstanding La Valliere s confusion did not quit his respectful and tender attitude Then when all the courtiers were assembled in the walkwhen every one had been able to perceive the extraordinary mark of deference with which he had treated the young girl by remaining standing and bareheaded during the stormhe offered her his arm led her towards the group who were waiting recognized by an inclination of the head the respectful salutations which were paid him on all sides and still holding his hat in his hand he conducted her to her carriage And as a few sparse drops of rain continued to falla last adieu of the vanishing stormthe other ladies whom respect had prevented from getting into their carriages before the king remained altogether unprotected by hood or cloak exposed to the rain from which the king was protecting as well as he was able the humblest among them The queen and Madame must like the others have witnessed this exaggerated courtesy of the king Madame was so disconcerted at it that she touched the queen with her elbow saying at the same time Look there look there

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: The queen closed her eyes as if she had been suddenly seized with a faintingspell. She lifted her hands to her face and entered her carriage, Madame following her. The king again mounted his horse, and without showing a preference for any particular carriage door, he returned to Fontainebleau, the reins hanging over his horse's neck, absorbed in thought. As soon as the crowd had disappeared, and the sound of the horses and carriages grew fainter in the distance, and when they were certain, in fact, that no one could see them, Aramis and Fouquet came out of their grotto, and both of them in silence passed slowly on towards the walk. Aramis looked most narrowly not only at the whole extent of the open space stretching out before and behind him, but even into the very depth of the wood.
children.prevalue: The queen closed her eyes as if she had been suddenly seized with a faintingspell She lifted her hands to her face and entered her carriage Madame following her The king again mounted his horse and without showing a preference for any particular carriage door he returned to Fontainebleau the reins hanging over his horse s neck absorbed in thought As soon as the crowd had disappeared and the sound of the horses and carriages grew fainter in the distance and when they were certain in fact that no one could see them Aramis and Fouquet came out of their grotto and both of them in silence passed slowly on towards the walk Aramis looked most narrowly not only at the whole extent of the open space stretching out before and behind him but even into the very depth of the wood

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Monsieur Fouquet, he said, when he had quite satisfied himself that they were alone, we must get back, at any cost, that letter you wrote to La Valliere.
children.prevalue: Monsieur Fouquet he said when he had quite satisfied himself that they were alone we must get back at any cost that letter you wrote to La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: That will be easy enough, said Fouquet, if my servant has not given it to her.
children.prevalue: That will be easy enough said Fouquet if my servant has not given it to her

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: In any case it must be had, do you understand?
children.prevalue: In any case it must be had do you understand

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Yes. The king is in love with the girl, you mean?
children.prevalue: Yes The king is in love with the girl you mean

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: Deeply, and what is worse is, that on her side, the girl is passionately attached to him.
children.prevalue: Deeply and what is worse is that on her side the girl is passionately attached to him

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: As much as to say that we must change our tactics, I suppose?
children.prevalue: As much as to say that we must change our tactics I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: Not a doubt of it; you have no time to lose. You must see La Valliere, and, without thinking any more of becoming her lover, which is out of the question, must declare yourself her most devoted friend and her most humble servant.
children.prevalue: Not a doubt of it you have no time to lose You must see La Valliere and without thinking any more of becoming her lover which is out of the question must declare yourself her most devoted friend and her most humble servant

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: I will do so, replied Fouquet, and without the slightest feeling of disinclination, for she seems a goodhearted girl.
children.prevalue: I will do so replied Fouquet and without the slightest feeling of disinclination for she seems a goodhearted girl

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: Or a very clever one, said Aramis; but in that case, all the greater reason. Then he added, after a moment's pause, If I am not mistaken, that girl will become the strongest passion of the king's life. Let us return to our carriage, and, as fast as possible, to the chateau.
children.prevalue: Or a very clever one said Aramis but in that case all the greater reason Then he added after a moment s pause If I am not mistaken that girl will become the strongest passion of the king s life Let us return to our carriage and as fast as possible to the chateau

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Two hours after the superintendent's carriage had set off by Aramis's directions, conveying them both towards Fontainebleau with the fleetness of the clouds the last breath of the tempest was hurrying across the face of heaven, La Valliere was closeted in her own apartment, with a simple muslin wrapper round her, having just finished a slight repast, which was placed upon a marble table. Suddenly the door was opened, and a servant entered to announce M. Fouquet, who had called to request permission to pay his respects to her. She made him repeat the message twice over, for the poor girl only knew M. Fouquet by name, and could not conceive what business she could possibly have with a superintendent of finances. However, as he might represent the kingand, after the conversation we have recorded, it was very likelyshe glanced at her mirror, drew out still more the ringlets of her hair, and desired him to be admitted. La Valliere could not, however, refrain from a certain feeling of uneasiness. A visit from the superintendent was not an ordinary event in the life of any woman attached to the court. Fouquet, so notorious for his generosity, his gallantry, and his sensitive delicacy of feeling with regard to women generally, had received more invitations than he had requested audiences. In many houses, the presence of the superintendent had been significant of fortune; in many hearts, of love. Fouquet entered the apartment with a manner full of respect, presenting himself with that ease and gracefulness of manner which was the distinctive characteristic of the men of eminence of that period, and which at the present day seems no longer to be understood, even through the interpretation of the portraits of the period, in which the painter has endeavored to recall them to being. La Valliere acknowledged the ceremonious salutation which Fouquet addressed to her by a gentle inclination of the head, and motioned him to a seat. But Fouquet, with a bow, said, I will not sit down until you have pardoned me.
