have pardoned me

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: I? asked La Valliere, pardon what?
children.prevalue: I asked La Valliere pardon what

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Fouquet fixed a most piercing look upon the young girl, and fancied he could perceive in her face nothing but the most unaffected surprise. I observe, he said, that you have as much generosity as intelligence, and I read in your eyes the forgiveness I solicit. A pardon pronounced by your lips is insufficient for me, and I need the forgiveness of your heart and mind.
children.prevalue: Fouquet fixed a most piercing look upon the young girl and fancied he could perceive in her face nothing but the most unaffected surprise I observe he said that you have as much generosity as intelligence and I read in your eyes the forgiveness I solicit A pardon pronounced by your lips is insufficient for me and I need the forgiveness of your heart and mind

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Upon my honor, monsieur, said La Valliere, I assure you most positively I do not understand your meaning.
children.prevalue: Upon my honor monsieur said La Valliere I assure you most positively I do not understand your meaning

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Again, that is a delicacy on your part which charms me, replied Fouquet, and I see you do not wish me to blush before you.
children.prevalue: Again that is a delicacy on your part which charms me replied Fouquet and I see you do not wish me to blush before you

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Blush! blush before me! Why should you blush?
children.prevalue: Blush blush before me Why should you blush

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Can I have deceived myself, said Fouquet; and can I have been happy enough not to have offended you by my conduct towards you?
children.prevalue: Can I have deceived myself said Fouquet and can I have been happy enough not to have offended you by my conduct towards you

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Really, monsieur, said La Valliere, shrugging her shoulders, you speak in enigmas, and I suppose I am too ignorant to understand you.
children.prevalue: Really monsieur said La Valliere shrugging her shoulders you speak in enigmas and I suppose I am too ignorant to understand you

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Be it so, said Fouquet; I will not insist. Tell me, only, I entreat you, that I may rely upon your full and complete forgiveness.
children.prevalue: Be it so said Fouquet I will not insist Tell me only I entreat you that I may rely upon your full and complete forgiveness

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I have but one reply to make to you, monsieur, said La Valliere, somewhat impatiently, and I hope that will satisfy you. If I knew the wrong you have done me, I would forgive you, and I now do so with still greater reason since I am ignorant of the wrong you allude to.
children.prevalue: I have but one reply to make to you monsieur said La Valliere somewhat impatiently and I hope that will satisfy you If I knew the wrong you have done me I would forgive you and I now do so with still greater reason since I am ignorant of the wrong you allude to

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Fouquet bit his lips, as Aramis would have done. In that case, he said, I may hope, that, notwithstanding what has happened, our good understanding will remain undisturbed, and that you will kindly confer the favor upon me of believing in my respectful friendship.
children.prevalue: Fouquet bit his lips as Aramis would have done In that case he said I may hope that notwithstanding what has happened our good understanding will remain undisturbed and that you will kindly confer the favor upon me of believing in my respectful friendship

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: La Valliere fancied that she now began to understand, and said to herself, I should not have believed M. Fouquet so eager to seek the source of a favor so very recent, and then added aloud, Your friendship, monsieur! you offer me your friendship. The honor, on the contrary, is mine, and I feel overpowered by it.
children.prevalue: La Valliere fancied that she now began to understand and said to herself I should not have believed M Fouquet so eager to seek the source of a favor so very recent and then added aloud Your friendship monsieur you offer me your friendship The honor on the contrary is mine and I feel overpowered by it

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I am aware, replied Fouquet, that the friendship of the master may appear more brilliant and desirable than that of the servant; but I assure you the latter will be quite as devoted, quite as faithful, and altogether disinterested.
children.prevalue: I am aware replied Fouquet that the friendship of the master may appear more brilliant and desirable than that of the servant but I assure you the latter will be quite as devoted quite as faithful and altogether disinterested

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: La Valliere bowed, for, in fact, the voice of the superintendent seemed to convey both conviction and real devotion in its tone, and she held out her hand to him, saying, I believe you.
children.prevalue: La Valliere bowed for in fact the voice of the superintendent seemed to convey both conviction and real devotion in its tone and she held out her hand to him saying I believe you

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Fouquet eagerly took hold of the young girl's hand. You see no difficulty, therefore, he added, in restoring me that unhappy letter.
children.prevalue: Fouquet eagerly took hold of the young girl s hand You see no difficulty therefore he added in restoring me that unhappy letter

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: What letter? inquired La Valliere.
children.prevalue: What letter inquired La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Fouquet interrogated her with his most searching gaze, as he had already done before, but the same ingenious expressions, the same transparently candid look met his. I am obliged to confess, he said, after this denial, that your heart is the most delicate in the world, and I should not feel I was a man of honor and uprightness if I were to suspect anything from a woman so generous as yourself.
children.prevalue: Fouquet interrogated her with his most searching gaze as he had already done before but the same ingenious expressions the same transparently candid look met his I am obliged to confess he said after this denial that your heart is the most delicate in the world and I should not feel I was a man of honor and uprightness if I were to suspect anything from a woman so generous as yourself

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Really, Monsieur Fouquet, replied La Valliere, it is with profound regret I am obliged to repeat that I absolutely understand nothing of what you refer to.
children.prevalue: Really Monsieur Fouquet replied La Valliere it is with profound regret I am obliged to repeat that I absolutely understand nothing of what you refer to

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: In fact, then, upon your honor, mademoiselle, you have not received any letter from me?
children.prevalue: In fact then upon your honor mademoiselle you have not received any letter from me

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Upon my honor, none, replied La Valliere, firmly.
children.prevalue: Upon my honor none replied La Valliere firmly

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Very well, that is quite sufficient; permit me, then, to renew the assurance of my utmost esteem and respect, said Fouquet. Then, bowing, he left the room to seek Aramis, who was waiting for him in his own apartment, and leaving La Valliere to ask herself whether the superintendent had not lost his senses.
children.prevalue: Very well that is quite sufficient permit me then to renew the assurance of my utmost esteem and respect said Fouquet Then bowing he left the room to seek Aramis who was waiting for him in his own apartment and leaving La Valliere to ask herself whether the superintendent had not lost his senses

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Well! inquired Aramis, who was impatiently waiting Fouquet's return, are you satisfied with the favorite?
children.prevalue: Well inquired Aramis who was impatiently waiting Fouquet s return are you satisfied with the favorite

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Enchanted, replied Fouquet; she is a woman full of intelligence and fine feeling.
children.prevalue: Enchanted replied Fouquet she is a woman full of intelligence and fine feeling

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: She did not get angry, then?
children.prevalue: She did not get angry then

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Far from thatshe did not even seem to understand.
children.prevalue: Far from thatshe did not even seem to understand

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: To understand what?
children.prevalue: To understand what

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: To understand that I had written to her.
children.prevalue: To understand that I had written to her

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: She must, however, have understood you sufficiently to give the letter back to you, for I presume she returned it.
children.prevalue: She must however have understood you sufficiently to give the letter back to you for I presume she returned it

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Not at all.
children.prevalue: Not at all

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: At least, you satisfied yourself that she had burnt it.
children.prevalue: At least you satisfied yourself that she had burnt it

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: My dear Monsieur d'Herblay, I have been playing at crosspurposes for more than an hour, and, however amusing it may be, I begin to have had enough of this game. So understand me thoroughly: the girl pretended not to understand what I was saying to her; she denied having received any letter; therefore, having positively denied its receipt, she was unable either to return or burn it.
children.prevalue: My dear Monsieur d Herblay I have been playing at crosspurposes for more than an hour and however amusing it may be I begin to have had enough of this game So understand me thoroughly the girl pretended not to understand what I was saying to her she denied having received any letter therefore having positively denied its receipt she was unable either to return or burn it

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Oh, oh! said Aramis, with uneasiness, what is this you tell me?
children.prevalue: Oh oh said Aramis with uneasiness what is this you tell me

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I say that she swore most positively she had not received any letter.
children.prevalue: I say that she swore most positively she had not received any letter

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: That is too much. And did you not insist?
children.prevalue: That is too much And did you not insist

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: On the contrary, I did insist, almost impertinently even.
children.prevalue: On the contrary I did insist almost impertinently even

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: And she persisted in her denial?
children.prevalue: And she persisted in her denial

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Unhesitatingly.
children.prevalue: Unhesitatingly

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: And did she not contradict herself?
children.prevalue: And did she not contradict herself

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Not once.
children.prevalue: Not once

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: But, in that case, then, you have left our letter in her hands?
children.prevalue: But in that case then you have left our letter in her hands

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: How could I do otherwise?
children.prevalue: How could I do otherwise

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Oh! it was a great mistake.
children.prevalue: Oh it was a great mistake

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: What the deuce would you have done in my place?
children.prevalue: What the deuce would you have done in my place

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: One could not force her, certainly, but it is very embarrassing; such a letter ought not to remain in existence against us.
children.prevalue: One could not force her certainly but it is very embarrassing such a letter ought not to remain in existence against us

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Oh! the young girl's disposition is generosity itself; I looked at her eyes, and I can read eyes well.
children.prevalue: Oh the young girl s disposition is generosity itself I looked at her eyes and I can read eyes well

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: You think she can be relied upon?
children.prevalue: You think she can be relied upon

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: From my heart I do.
children.prevalue: From my heart I do

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Well, I think we are mistaken.
children.prevalue: Well I think we are mistaken

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: In what way?
children.prevalue: In what way

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: I think that, in point of fact, as she herself told you, she did not receive the letter.
children.prevalue: I think that in point of fact as she herself told you she did not receive the letter

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: What! do you suppose
children.prevalue: What do you suppose

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: I suppose that, from some motive, of which we know nothing, your man did not deliver the letter to her.
children.prevalue: I suppose that from some motive of which we know nothing your man did not deliver the letter to her

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Fouquet rang the bell. A servant appeared. Send Toby here, he said. A moment afterwards a man made his appearance, with an anxious, restless look, shrewd expression of the mouth, with short arms, and his back somewhat bent. Aramis fixed a penetrating look upon him.
children.prevalue: Fouquet rang the bell A servant appeared Send Toby here he said A moment afterwards a man made his appearance with an anxious restless look shrewd expression of the mouth with short arms and his back somewhat bent Aramis fixed a penetrating look upon him

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Will you allow me to interrogate him myself? inquired Aramis.
children.prevalue: Will you allow me to interrogate him myself inquired Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Do so, said Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Do so said Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Aramis was about to say something to the lackey, when he paused. No, he said; he would see that we attach too much importance to his answer; therefore question him yourself; I will pretend to be writing. Aramis accordingly placed himself at a table, his back turned towards the old attendant, whose every gesture and look he watched in a lookingglass opposite to him.
children.prevalue: Aramis was about to say something to the lackey when he paused No he said he would see that we attach too much importance to his answer therefore question him yourself I will pretend to be writing Aramis accordingly placed himself at a table his back turned towards the old attendant whose every gesture and look he watched in a lookingglass opposite to him

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Come here, Toby, said Fouquet to the valet, who approached with a tolerably firm step. How did you execute my commission? inquired Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Come here Toby said Fouquet to the valet who approached with a tolerably firm step How did you execute my commission inquired Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: In the usual way, monseigneur, replied the man.
children.prevalue: In the usual way monseigneur replied the man

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: But how, tell me?
children.prevalue: But how tell me

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: I succeeded in penetrating as far as Mademoiselle de la Valliere's apartment; but she was at mass, and so I placed the note on her toilettetable. Is not that what you told me to do?
children.prevalue: I succeeded in penetrating as far as Mademoiselle de la Valliere s apartment but she was at mass and so I placed the note on her toilettetable Is not that what you told me to do

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Precisely; and is that all?
children.prevalue: Precisely and is that all

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Absolutely all, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Absolutely all monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: No one was there?
children.prevalue: No one was there

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: No one.
children.prevalue: No one

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Did you conceal yourself as I told you?
children.prevalue: Did you conceal yourself as I told you

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: And she returned?
children.prevalue: And she returned

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Ten minutes afterwards.
children.prevalue: Ten minutes afterwards

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: And no one could have taken the letter?
children.prevalue: And no one could have taken the letter

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: No one; for no one had entered the room.
children.prevalue: No one for no one had entered the room

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: From the outside, but from the interior?
children.prevalue: From the outside but from the interior

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: From the place where I was secreted, I could see to the very end of the room.
children.prevalue: From the place where I was secreted I could see to the very end of the room

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Now listen to me, said Fouquet, looking fixedly at the lackey; if this letter did not reach its proper destination, confess it; for, if a mistake has been made, your head shall be the forfeit.
children.prevalue: Now listen to me said Fouquet looking fixedly at the lackey if this letter did not reach its proper destination confess it for if a mistake has been made your head shall be the forfeit

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Toby started, but immediately recovered himself. Monseigneur, he said, I placed the letter on the very place I told you: and I ask only half an hour to prove to you that the letter is in Mademoiselle de la Valliere's hand, or to bring you back the letter itself.
children.prevalue: Toby started but immediately recovered himself Monseigneur he said I placed the letter on the very place I told you and I ask only half an hour to prove to you that the letter is in Mademoiselle de la Valliere s hand or to bring you back the letter itself

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Aramis looked at the valet scrutinizingly. Fouquet was ready in placing confidence in people, and for twenty years this man had served him faithfully. Go, he said; but bring me the proof you speak of. The lackey quitted the room.
children.prevalue: Aramis looked at the valet scrutinizingly Fouquet was ready in placing confidence in people and for twenty years this man had served him faithfully Go he said but bring me the proof you speak of The lackey quitted the room

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Well, what do you think of it? inquired Fouquet of Aramis.
children.prevalue: Well what do you think of it inquired Fouquet of Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: I think that you must, by some means or another, assure yourself of the truth, either that the letter has, or has not, reached La Valliere; that, in the first case, La Valliere must return it to you, or satisfy you by burning it in your presence; that, in the second, you must have the letter back again, even were it to cost you a million. Come, is not that your opinion?
children.prevalue: I think that you must by some means or another assure yourself of the truth either that the letter has or has not reached La Valliere that in the first case La Valliere must return it to you or satisfy you by burning it in your presence that in the second you must have the letter back again even were it to cost you a million Come is not that your opinion

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Yes; but still, my dear bishop, I believe you are exaggerating the importance of the affair.
children.prevalue: Yes but still my dear bishop I believe you are exaggerating the importance of the affair

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Blind, how blind you are! murmured Aramis.
children.prevalue: Blind how blind you are murmured Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: La Valliere, returned Fouquet, whom we assume to be a schemer of the first ability, is simply nothing more than a coquette, who hopes that I shall pay my court to her, because I have already done so, and who, now that she has received a confirmation of the king's regard, hopes to keep me in leading strings with the letter. It is natural enough.
children.prevalue: La Valliere returned Fouquet whom we assume to be a schemer of the first ability is simply nothing more than a coquette who hopes that I shall pay my court to her because I have already done so and who now that she has received a confirmation of the king s regard hopes to keep me in leading strings with the letter It is natural enough

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Aramis shook his head.
children.prevalue: Aramis shook his head

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Is not that your opinion? said Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Is not that your opinion said Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: She is not a coquette, he replied.
children.prevalue: She is not a coquette he replied

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Allow me to tell you
children.prevalue: Allow me to tell you

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Oh! I am well enough acquainted with women who are coquettes, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Oh I am well enough acquainted with women who are coquettes said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: My dear friend!
children.prevalue: My dear friend

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: It is a long time ago since I finished my education, you mean. But women are the same, throughout the centuries.
children.prevalue: It is a long time ago since I finished my education you mean But women are the same throughout the centuries

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: True; but men change, and you at the present day are far more suspicious than you formerly were. And then, beginning to laugh, he added, Come, if La Valliere is willing to love me only to the extent of a third, and the king twothirds, do you think the condition acceptable?
children.prevalue: True but men change and you at the present day are far more suspicious than you formerly were And then beginning to laugh he added Come if La Valliere is willing to love me only to the extent of a third and the king twothirds do you think the condition acceptable

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Aramis rose impatiently. La Valliere, he said, has never loved, and never will love, any one but the king.
children.prevalue: Aramis rose impatiently La Valliere he said has never loved and never will love any one but the king

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: At all events, said Fouquet, what would you do?
children.prevalue: At all events said Fouquet what would you do

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Ask me rather what I would have done?
children.prevalue: Ask me rather what I would have done

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Well! what would you have done?
children.prevalue: Well what would you have done

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: In the first place, I should not have allowed that man to depart.
children.prevalue: In the first place I should not have allowed that man to depart

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Toby?
children.prevalue: Toby

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Yes; Toby is a traitor. Nay, I am sure of it, and I would not have let him go until he had told me the truth.
children.prevalue: Yes Toby is a traitor Nay I am sure of it and I would not have let him go until he had told me the truth

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: There is still time. I will recall him, and do you question him in your turn.
children.prevalue: There is still time I will recall him and do you question him in your turn

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Agreed.
children.prevalue: Agreed

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: But I assure you it is useless. He has been with me for twenty years, and has never made the slightest mistake, and yet, added Fouquet, laughing, it would have been easy enough for him to have done so.
children.prevalue: But I assure you it is useless He has been with me for twenty years and has never made the slightest mistake and yet added Fouquet laughing it would have been easy enough for him to have done so

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Still, call him back. This morning I fancy I saw that face, in earnest conversation with one of M. Colbert's men.
children.prevalue: Still call him back This morning I fancy I saw that face in earnest conversation with one of M Colbert s men

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Where was that?
children.prevalue: Where was that

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Opposite the stables.
children.prevalue: Opposite the stables

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Bah! all my people are at daggers drawn with that fellow.
children.prevalue: Bah all my people are at daggers drawn with that fellow

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: I saw him, I tell you, and his face, which should have been unknown to me when he entered just now, struck me as disagreeably familiar.
children.prevalue: I saw him I tell you and his face which should have been unknown to me when he entered just now struck me as disagreeably familiar

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Why did you not say something, then, while he was here?
children.prevalue: Why did you not say something then while he was here

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Because it is only at this very minute that my memory is clear upon the subject.
children.prevalue: Because it is only at this very minute that my memory is clear upon the subject

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Really, said Fouquet, you alarm me. And he again rang the bell.
children.prevalue: Really said Fouquet you alarm me And he again rang the bell

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Provided that it is not already too late, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Provided that it is not already too late said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Fouquet once more rang impatiently. The valet usually in attendance appeared. Toby! said Fouquet, send Toby. The valet again shut the door.
children.prevalue: Fouquet once more rang impatiently The valet usually in attendance appeared Toby said Fouquet send Toby The valet again shut the door

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: You leave me at perfect liberty, I suppose?
children.prevalue: You leave me at perfect liberty I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Entirely so.
children.prevalue: Entirely so

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: I may employ all means, then, to ascertain the truth.
children.prevalue: I may employ all means then to ascertain the truth

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: All.
children.prevalue: All

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Intimidation, even?
children.prevalue: Intimidation even

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: I constitute you public prosecutor in my place.
children.prevalue: I constitute you public prosecutor in my place

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: They waited ten minutes longer, but uselessly, and Fouquet, thoroughly out of patience, again rang loudly.
children.prevalue: They waited ten minutes longer but uselessly and Fouquet thoroughly out of patience again rang loudly

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Toby! he exclaimed.
children.prevalue: Toby he exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Monseigneur, said the valet, they are looking for him.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur said the valet they are looking for him

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: He cannot be far distant, I have not given him any commission to execute.
children.prevalue: He cannot be far distant I have not given him any commission to execute

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: I will go and see, monseigneur, replied the valet, as he closed the door. Aramis, during the interview, walked impatiently, but without a syllable, up and down the cabinet. They waited a further ten minutes. Fouquet rang in a manner to alarm the very dead. The valet again presented himself, trembling in a way to induce a belief that he was the bearer of bad news.
children.prevalue: I will go and see monseigneur replied the valet as he closed the door Aramis during the interview walked impatiently but without a syllable up and down the cabinet They waited a further ten minutes Fouquet rang in a manner to alarm the very dead The valet again presented himself trembling in a way to induce a belief that he was the bearer of bad news

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Monseigneur is mistaken, he said, before even Fouquet could interrogate him, you must have given Toby some commission, for he has been to the stables and taken your lordship's swiftest horse, and saddled it himself.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur is mistaken he said before even Fouquet could interrogate him you must have given Toby some commission for he has been to the stables and taken your lordship s swiftest horse and saddled it himself

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: And he has gone off.
children.prevalue: And he has gone off

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: Gone! exclaimed Fouquet. Let him be pursued, let him be captured.
children.prevalue: Gone exclaimed Fouquet Let him be pursued let him be captured

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: Nay, nay, whispered Aramis, taking him by the hand, be calm, the evil is done.
children.prevalue: Nay nay whispered Aramis taking him by the hand be calm the evil is done

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: The valet quietly went out.
children.prevalue: The valet quietly went out

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: The evil is done, you say?
children.prevalue: The evil is done you say

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: No doubt; I was sure of it. And now, let us give no cause for suspicion; we must calculate the result of the blow, and ward it off, if possible.
children.prevalue: No doubt I was sure of it And now let us give no cause for suspicion we must calculate the result of the blow and ward it off if possible

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: After all, said Fouquet, the evil is not great.
children.prevalue: After all said Fouquet the evil is not great

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: You think so? said Aramis.
children.prevalue: You think so said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: Of course. Surely a man is allowed to write a loveletter to a woman.
children.prevalue: Of course Surely a man is allowed to write a loveletter to a woman

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: A man, certainly; a subject, no; especially, too, when the woman in question is one with whom the king is in love.
children.prevalue: A man certainly a subject no especially too when the woman in question is one with whom the king is in love

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: But the king was not in love with La Valliere a week ago! he was not in love with her yesterday, and the letter is dated yesterday; I could not guess the king was in love, when the king's affection was not even yet in existence.
children.prevalue: But the king was not in love with La Valliere a week ago he was not in love with her yesterday and the letter is dated yesterday I could not guess the king was in love when the king s affection was not even yet in existence

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: As you please, replied Aramis; but unfortunately the letter is not dated, and it is that circumstance particularly which annoys me. If it had only been dated yesterday, I should not have the slightest shadow of uneasiness on your account.
children.prevalue: As you please replied Aramis but unfortunately the letter is not dated and it is that circumstance particularly which annoys me If it had only been dated yesterday I should not have the slightest shadow of uneasiness on your account

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: Fouquet shrugged his shoulders.
children.prevalue: Fouquet shrugged his shoulders

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: Am I not my own master, he said, and is the king, then, king of my brain and of my flesh?
children.prevalue: Am I not my own master he said and is the king then king of my brain and of my flesh

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: You are right, replied Aramis, do not let us attach greater importance to matters than is necessary; and besides... Well! if we are menaced, we have means of defense.
children.prevalue: You are right replied Aramis do not let us attach greater importance to matters than is necessary and besides Well if we are menaced we have means of defense

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: Oh! menaced! said Fouquet, you do not place this gnat bite, as it were, among the number of menaces which may compromise my fortune and my life, do you?
children.prevalue: Oh menaced said Fouquet you do not place this gnat bite as it were among the number of menaces which may compromise my fortune and my life do you

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: Do not forget, Monsieur Fouquet, that the bit of an insect can kill a giant, if the insect be venomous.
children.prevalue: Do not forget Monsieur Fouquet that the bit of an insect can kill a giant if the insect be venomous

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: But has this sovereign power you were speaking of, already vanished?
children.prevalue: But has this sovereign power you were speaking of already vanished

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: I am allpowerful, it is true, but I am not immortal.
children.prevalue: I am allpowerful it is true but I am not immortal

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: Come, then, the most pressing matter is to find Toby again, I suppose. Is not that your opinion?
children.prevalue: Come then the most pressing matter is to find Toby again I suppose Is not that your opinion

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: Oh! as for that, you will not find him again, said Aramis, and if he were of any great value to you, you must give him up for lost.
children.prevalue: Oh as for that you will not find him again said Aramis and if he were of any great value to you you must give him up for lost

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: At all events he is somewhere or another in the world, said Fouquet.
children.prevalue: At all events he is somewhere or another in the world said Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: You're right, let me act, replied Aramis.
children.prevalue: You re right let me act replied Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Anne of Austria had begged the young queen to pay her a visit. For some time past suffering most acutely, and losing both her youth and beauty with that rapidity which signalizes the decline of women for whom life has been one long contest, Anne of Austria had, in addition to her physical sufferings, to experience the bitterness of being no longer held in any esteem, except as a surviving remembrance of the past, amidst the youthful beauties, wits, and influential forces of her court. Her physician's opinions, her mirror also, grieved her far less than the inexorable warnings which the society of the courtiers afforded, who, like rats in a ship, abandon the hold into which on the very next voyage the water will infallibly penetrate, owing to the ravages of decay. Anne of Austria did not feel satisfied with the time her eldest son devoted to her. The king, a good son, more from affectation than from affection, had at first been in the habit of passing an hour in the morning and one in the evening with his mother; but, since he had himself undertaken the conduct of state affairs, the duration of the morning and evening's visit had been reduced by one half; and then, by degrees, the morning visit had been suppressed altogether. They met at mass; the evening visit was replaced by a meeting, either at the king's assembly or at Madame's, which the queen attended obligingly enough, out of regard to her two sons.
children.prevalue: Anne of Austria had begged the young queen to pay her a visit For some time past suffering most acutely and losing both her youth and beauty with that rapidity which signalizes the decline of women for whom life has been one long contest Anne of Austria had in addition to her physical sufferings to experience the bitterness of being no longer held in any esteem except as a surviving remembrance of the past amidst the youthful beauties wits and influential forces of her court Her physician s opinions her mirror also grieved her far less than the inexorable warnings which the society of the courtiers afforded who like rats in a ship abandon the hold into which on the very next voyage the water will infallibly penetrate owing to the ravages of decay Anne of Austria did not feel satisfied with the time her eldest son devoted to her The king a good son more from affectation than from affection had at first been in the habit of passing an hour in the morning and one in the evening with his mother but since he had himself undertaken the conduct of state affairs the duration of the morning and evening s visit had been reduced by one half and then by degrees the morning visit had been suppressed altogether They met at mass the evening visit was replaced by a meeting either at the king s assembly or at Madame s which the queen attended obligingly enough out of regard to her two sons

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The result of this was, that Madame gradually acquired an immense influence over the court, which made her apartments the true royal place of meeting. This, Anne of Austria perceived; knowing herself to be very ill, and condemned by her sufferings to frequent retirement, she was distressed at the idea that the greater part of her future days and evenings would pass away solitary, useless, and in despondency. She recalled with terror the isolation in which Cardinal Richelieu had formerly left her, those dreaded and insupportable evenings, during which, however, she had both youth and beauty, which are ever accompanied by hope, to console her. She next formed the project of transporting the court to her own apartments, and of attracting Madame, with her brilliant escort, to her gloomy and already sorrowful abode, where the widow of a king of France, and the mother of a king of France, was reduced to console, in her artificial widowhood, the weeping wife of a king of France.
children.prevalue: The result of this was that Madame gradually acquired an immense influence over the court which made her apartments the true royal place of meeting This Anne of Austria perceived knowing herself to be very ill and condemned by her sufferings to frequent retirement she was distressed at the idea that the greater part of her future days and evenings would pass away solitary useless and in despondency She recalled with terror the isolation in which Cardinal Richelieu had formerly left her those dreaded and insupportable evenings during which however she had both youth and beauty which are ever accompanied by hope to console her She next formed the project of transporting the court to her own apartments and of attracting Madame with her brilliant escort to her gloomy and already sorrowful abode where the widow of a king of France and the mother of a king of France was reduced to console in her artificial widowhood the weeping wife of a king of France

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Anne began to reflect. She had intrigued a good deal in her life. In the good times past, when her youthful mind nursed projects that were, ultimately, invariably successful, she had by her side, to stimulate her ambition and her love, a friend of her own sex, more eager, more ambitious than herself,a friend who had loved her, a rare circumstance at courts, and whom some petty considerations had removed from her forever. But for many years pastexcept Madame de Motteville, and La Molena, her Spanish nurse, a confidante in her character of countrywoman and woman toowho could boast of having given good advice to the queen? Who, too, among all the youthful heads there, could recall the past for her,that past in which alone she lived? Anne of Austria remembered Madame de Chevreuse, in the first place exiled rather by her wish than the king's, and then dying in exile, the wife of a gentleman of obscure birth and position. She asked herself what Madame de Chevreuse would have advised her to do in similar circumstances, in their mutual difficulties arising from their intrigues; and after serious reflection, it seemed as if the clever, subtle mind of her friend, full of experience and sound judgment, answered her in the wellremembered ironical tones: All the insignificant young people are poor and greedy of gain. They require gold and incomes to supply means of amusement; it is by interest you must gain them over. And Anne of Austria adopted this plan. Her purse was well filled, and she had at her disposal a considerable sum of money, which had been amassed by Mazarin for her, and lodged in a place of safety. She possessed the most magnificent jewels in France, and especially pearls of a size so large that they made the king sigh every time he saw them, because the pearls of his crown were like millet seed compared to them. Anne of Austria had neither beauty nor charms any longer at her disposal. She gave out, therefore, that her wealth was great, and as an inducement for others to visit her apartments she let it be known that there were good gold crowns to be won at play, or that handsome presents were likely to be made on days when all went well with her; or windfalls, in the shape of annuities which she had wrung from the king by entreaty, and thus she determined to maintain her credit. In the first place, she tried these means upon Madame; because to gain her consent was of more importance than anything else. Madame, notwithstanding the bold confidence which her wit and beauty inspired her, blindly ran head foremost into the net thus stretched out to catch her. Enriched by degrees by these presents and transfers of property, she took a fancy to inheritances by anticipation. Anne of Austria adopted the same means towards Monsieur, and even towards the king himself. She instituted lotteries in her apartments. The day on which the present chapter opens, invitations had been issued for a late supper in the queenmother's apartments, as she intended that two beautiful diamond bracelets of exquisite workmanship should be put into a lottery. The medallions were antique cameos of the greatest value; the diamonds, in point of intrinsic value, did not represent a very considerable amount, but the originality and rarity of the workmanship were such, that every one at court not only wished to possess the bracelets, but even to see the queen herself wear them; for, on the days she wore them, it was considered as a favor to be admitted to admire them in kissing her hands. The courtiers had, even with regard to this subject, adopted various expressions of gallantry to establish the aphorism, that the bracelets would have been priceless in value if they had not been unfortunate enough to be placed in contact with arms as beautiful as the queen's. This compliment had been honored by a translation into all the languages of Europe, and numerous verses in Latin and French had been circulated on the subject. The day that Anne of Austria had selected for the lottery was a decisive moment; the king had not been near his mother for a couple of days; Madame, after the great scene of the Dryads and Naiads, was sulking by herself. It is true, the king's fit of resentment was over, but his mind was absorbingly occupied by a circumstance that raised him above the stormy disputes and giddy pleasures of the court.

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Anne of Austria effected a diversion by the announcement of the famous lottery to take place in her apartments on the following evening. With this object in view, she saw the young queen, whom, as we have already seen, she had invited to pay her a visit in the morning. I have good news to tell you, she said to her; the king has been saying the most tender things about you. He is young, you know, and easily drawn away; but so long as you keep near me, he will not venture to keep away from you, to whom, besides, he is most warmly and affectionately attached. I intend to have a lottery this evening and shall expect to see you.
children.prevalue: Anne of Austria effected a diversion by the announcement of the famous lottery to take place in her apartments on the following evening With this object in view she saw the young queen whom as we have already seen she had invited to pay her a visit in the morning I have good news to tell you she said to her the king has been saying the most tender things about you He is young you know and easily drawn away but so long as you keep near me he will not venture to keep away from you to whom besides he is most warmly and affectionately attached I intend to have a lottery this evening and shall expect to see you

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: I have heard, said the young queen, with a sort of timid reproach, that your majesty intends to put in the lottery those lovely bracelets whose rarity is so great that we ought not to allow them to pass out of the custody of the crown, even were there no other reason than that they had once belonged to you.
children.prevalue: I have heard said the young queen with a sort of timid reproach that your majesty intends to put in the lottery those lovely bracelets whose rarity is so great that we ought not to allow them to pass out of the custody of the crown even were there no other reason than that they had once belonged to you

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: My daughter, said Anne of Austria, who read the young queen's thoughts, and wished to console her for not having received the bracelets as a present, it is positively necessary that I should induce Madame to pass her time in my apartments.
children.prevalue: My daughter said Anne of Austria who read the young queen s thoughts and wished to console her for not having received the bracelets as a present it is positively necessary that I should induce Madame to pass her time in my apartments

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Madame! said the young queen, blushing.
children.prevalue: Madame said the young queen blushing

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Of course: would you not prefer to have a rival near you, whom you could watch and influence, to knowing the king is with her, always as ready to flirt as to be flirted with by her? The lottery I have proposed is my means of attraction for that purpose; do you blame me?
children.prevalue: Of course would you not prefer to have a rival near you whom you could watch and influence to knowing the king is with her always as ready to flirt as to be flirted with by her The lottery I have proposed is my means of attraction for that purpose do you blame me

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Oh, no! returned Maria Theresa, clapping her hands with a childlike expression of delight.
children.prevalue: Oh no returned Maria Theresa clapping her hands with a childlike expression of delight

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: And you no longer regret, then, that I did not give you these bracelets, as I at first intended to do?
children.prevalue: And you no longer regret then that I did not give you these bracelets as I at first intended to do

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Oh, no, no!
children.prevalue: Oh no no

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Very well; make yourself look as beautiful as possible that our supper may be very brilliant; the gayer you seem, the more charming you appear, and you will eclipse all the ladies present as much by your brilliancy as by your rank.
children.prevalue: Very well make yourself look as beautiful as possible that our supper may be very brilliant the gayer you seem the more charming you appear and you will eclipse all the ladies present as much by your brilliancy as by your rank

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Maria Theresa left full of delight. An hour afterwards, Anne of Austria received a visit from Madame, whom she covered with caresses, saying, Excellent news! the king is charmed with my lottery.
children.prevalue: Maria Theresa left full of delight An hour afterwards Anne of Austria received a visit from Madame whom she covered with caresses saying Excellent news the king is charmed with my lottery

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: But I, replied Madame, am not so greatly charmed: to see such beautiful bracelets on any one's arms but yours or mine, is what I cannot reconcile myself to.
children.prevalue: But I replied Madame am not so greatly charmed to see such beautiful bracelets on any one s arms but yours or mine is what I cannot reconcile myself to

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Well, well, said Anne of Austria, concealing by a smile a violent pang she had just experienced, do not look at things in the worst light immediately.
children.prevalue: Well well said Anne of Austria concealing by a smile a violent pang she had just experienced do not look at things in the worst light immediately

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Ah, Madame, Fortune is blind, and I am told there are two hundred tickets.
children.prevalue: Ah Madame Fortune is blind and I am told there are two hundred tickets

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Quite as many as that; but you cannot surely forget that there can only be one winner.
children.prevalue: Quite as many as that but you cannot surely forget that there can only be one winner

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: No doubt. But who will that be? Can you tell? said Madame, in despair.
children.prevalue: No doubt But who will that be Can you tell said Madame in despair

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: You remind me that I had a dream last night; my dreams are always good,I sleep so little.
children.prevalue: You remind me that I had a dream last night my dreams are always good I sleep so little

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: What was your dream?but are you suffering?
children.prevalue: What was your dream but are you suffering

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: No, said the queen, stifling with wonderful command the torture of a renewed attack of shooting pains in her bosom; I dreamed that the king won the bracelets.
children.prevalue: No said the queen stifling with wonderful command the torture of a renewed attack of shooting pains in her bosom I dreamed that the king won the bracelets

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The king!
children.prevalue: The king

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: You are going to ask me, I think, what the king could possibly do with the bracelets?
children.prevalue: You are going to ask me I think what the king could possibly do with the bracelets

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: And you would not add, perhaps, that it would be very fortunate if the king were really to win, for he would be obliged to give the bracelets to some one else.
children.prevalue: And you would not add perhaps that it would be very fortunate if the king were really to win for he would be obliged to give the bracelets to some one else

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: To restore them to you, for instance.
children.prevalue: To restore them to you for instance

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: In which case I should immediately give them away; for you do not think, I suppose, said the queen, laughing, that I have put these bracelets up to a lottery from necessity. My object was to give them without arousing any one's jealousy; but if Fortune will not get me out of my difficultywell, I will teach Fortune a lessonand I know very well to whom I intend to offer the bracelets. These words were accompanied by so expressive a smile, that Madame could not resist paying her by a grateful kiss.
children.prevalue: In which case I should immediately give them away for you do not think I suppose said the queen laughing that I have put these bracelets up to a lottery from necessity My object was to give them without arousing any one s jealousy but if Fortune will not get me out of my difficultywell I will teach Fortune a lessonand I know very well to whom I intend to offer the bracelets These words were accompanied by so expressive a smile that Madame could not resist paying her by a grateful kiss

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: But, added Anne of Austria, do you not know, as well as I do, that if the king were to win the bracelets, he would not restore them to me?
children.prevalue: But added Anne of Austria do you not know as well as I do that if the king were to win the bracelets he would not restore them to me

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: You mean he would give them to the queen?
children.prevalue: You mean he would give them to the queen

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: No; and for the very same reason that he would not give them back again to me; since, if I had wished to make the queen a present of them, I had no need of him for that purpose.
children.prevalue: No and for the very same reason that he would not give them back again to me since if I had wished to make the queen a present of them I had no need of him for that purpose

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Madame cast a side glance upon the bracelets, which, in their casket, were dazzlingly exposed to view upon a table close beside her.
children.prevalue: Madame cast a side glance upon the bracelets which in their casket were dazzlingly exposed to view upon a table close beside her

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: How beautiful they are, she said, sighing. But stay, Madame continued, we are quite forgetting that your majesty's dream was nothing but a dream.
children.prevalue: How beautiful they are she said sighing But stay Madame continued we are quite forgetting that your majesty s dream was nothing but a dream

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I should be very much surprised, returned Anne of Austria, if my dream were to deceive me; that has happened to me very seldom.
children.prevalue: I should be very much surprised returned Anne of Austria if my dream were to deceive me that has happened to me very seldom

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: We may look upon you as a prophetess, then.
children.prevalue: We may look upon you as a prophetess then

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: I have already said, that I dream but very rarely; but the coincidence of my dream about this matter, with my own ideas, is extraordinary! it agrees so wonderfully with my own views and arrangements.
children.prevalue: I have already said that I dream but very rarely but the coincidence of my dream about this matter with my own ideas is extraordinary it agrees so wonderfully with my own views and arrangements

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: What arrangements do you allude to?
children.prevalue: What arrangements do you allude to

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: That you will get the bracelets, for instance.
children.prevalue: That you will get the bracelets for instance

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: In that case, it will not be the king.
children.prevalue: In that case it will not be the king

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Oh! said Anne of Austria, there is not such a very great distance between his majesty's heart and your own; for, are you not his sister, for whom he has a great regard? There is not, I repeat, so very wide a distance, that my dream can be pronounced false on that account. Come, let us reckon up the chances in its favor.
children.prevalue: Oh said Anne of Austria there is not such a very great distance between his majesty s heart and your own for are you not his sister for whom he has a great regard There is not I repeat so very wide a distance that my dream can be pronounced false on that account Come let us reckon up the chances in its favor

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I will count them.
children.prevalue: I will count them

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: In the first place, we will begin with the dream. If the king wins, he is sure to give you the bracelets.
children.prevalue: In the first place we will begin with the dream If the king wins he is sure to give you the bracelets

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: I admit that is one.
children.prevalue: I admit that is one

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: If you win them, they are yours.
children.prevalue: If you win them they are yours

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Naturally; that may be admitted also.
children.prevalue: Naturally that may be admitted also

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Lastly;if Monsieur were to win them!
children.prevalue: Lastly if Monsieur were to win them

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Oh! said Madame, laughing heartily, he would give them to the Chevalier de Lorraine.
children.prevalue: Oh said Madame laughing heartily he would give them to the Chevalier de Lorraine

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Anne of Austria laughed as heartily as her daughterinlaw; so much so, indeed, that her sufferings again returned, and made her turn suddenly pale in the very midst of her enjoyment.
children.prevalue: Anne of Austria laughed as heartily as her daughterinlaw so much so indeed that her sufferings again returned and made her turn suddenly pale in the very midst of her enjoyment

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: What is the matter? inquired Madame, terrified.
children.prevalue: What is the matter inquired Madame terrified

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Nothing, nothing; a pain in my side. I have been laughing too much. We were at the fourth chance, I think.
children.prevalue: Nothing nothing a pain in my side I have been laughing too much We were at the fourth chance I think

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: I cannot see a fourth.
children.prevalue: I cannot see a fourth

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: I beg your pardon; I am not excluded from the chance of winning, and if I be the winner, you are sure of me.
children.prevalue: I beg your pardon I am not excluded from the chance of winning and if I be the winner you are sure of me

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Oh! thank you, thank you! exclaimed Madame.
children.prevalue: Oh thank you thank you exclaimed Madame

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: I hope that you look upon yourself as one whose chances are good, and that my dream now begins to assure the solid outlines of reality.
children.prevalue: I hope that you look upon yourself as one whose chances are good and that my dream now begins to assure the solid outlines of reality

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Yes, indeed: you give me both hope and confidence, said Madame, and the bracelets, won in this manner, will be a hundred times more precious to me.
children.prevalue: Yes indeed you give me both hope and confidence said Madame and the bracelets won in this manner will be a hundred times more precious to me

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Well! then, goodbye, until this evening. And the two princesses separated. Anne of Austria, after her daughterinlaw had left her, said to herself, as she examined the bracelets, They are, indeed, precious; since, by their means, this evening, I shall have won over a heart to my side, at the same time, fathomed an important secret.
children.prevalue: Well then goodbye until this evening And the two princesses separated Anne of Austria after her daughterinlaw had left her said to herself as she examined the bracelets They are indeed precious since by their means this evening I shall have won over a heart to my side at the same time fathomed an important secret

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Then turning towards the deserted recess in her room, she said, addressing vacancy,Is it not thus that you would have acted, my poor Chevreuse? Yes, yes; I know it is.
children.prevalue: Then turning towards the deserted recess in her room she said addressing vacancy Is it not thus that you would have acted my poor Chevreuse Yes yes I know it is

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: And, like a perfume of other, fairer days, her youth, her imagination, and her happiness seemed to be wafted towards the echo of this invocation.
children.prevalue: And like a perfume of other fairer days her youth her imagination and her happiness seemed to be wafted towards the echo of this invocation

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: By eight o'clock in the evening, every one had assembled in the queenmother's apartments. Anne of Austria, in full dress, beautiful still, from former loveliness, and from all the resources coquetry can command at the hands of clever assistants, concealed, or rather pretended to conceal, from the crowd of courtiers who surrounded her, and who still admired her, thanks to the combination of circumstances which we have indicated in the preceding chapter, the ravages, which were already visible, of the acute suffering to which she finally yielded a few years later. Madame, almost as great a coquette as Anne of Austria, and the queen, simple and natural as usual, were seated beside her, each contending for her good graces. The ladies of honor, united in a body, in order to resist with greater effect, and consequently with more success, the witty and lively conversations which the young men held about them, were enabled, like a battalion formed in a square, to offer each other the means of attack and defense which were thus at their command. Montalais, learned in that species of warfare which consists of sustained skirmishing, protected the whole line by a sort of rolling fire she directed against the enemy. SaintAignan, in utter despair at the rigor, which became almost insulting from the very fact of her persisting in it, Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente displayed, tried to turn his back upon her; but, overcome by the irresistible brilliancy of her eyes, he, every moment, returned to consecrate his defeat by new submissions, to which Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente did not fail to reply by fresh acts of impertinence. SaintAignan did not know which way to turn. La Valliere had about her, not exactly a court, but sprinklings of courtiers. SaintAignan, hoping by this maneuver to attract Athenais's attention towards him, approached the young girl, and saluted her with a respect that induced some to believe that he wished to balance Athenais by Louise. But these were persons who had neither been witnesses of the scene during the shower, nor had heard it spoken of. As the majority was already informed, and well informed, too, on the matter, the acknowledged favor with which she was regarded had attracted to her side some of the most astute, as well as the least sensible, members of the court. The former, because they said with Montaigne, How do I know? and the latter, who said with Rabelais, Perhaps. The greatest number had followed in the wake of the latter, just as in hunting five or six of the best hounds alone follow the scent of the animal hunted, whilst the remainder of the pack follow only the scent of the hounds. The two queens and Madame examined with particular attention the toilettes of their ladies and maids of honor; and they condescended to forget they were queens in recollecting that they were women. In other words, they pitilessly picked to pieces every person present who wore a petticoat. The looks of both princesses simultaneously fell upon La Valliere, who, as we have just said, was completely surrounded at that moment. Madame knew not what pity was, and said to the queenmother, as she turned towards her, If Fortune were just, she would favor that poor La Valliere.
children.prevalue: By eight o clock in the evening every one had assembled in the queenmother s apartments Anne of Austria in full dress beautiful still from former loveliness and from all the resources coquetry can command at the hands of clever assistants concealed or rather pretended to conceal from the crowd of courtiers who surrounded her and who still admired her thanks to the combination of circumstances which we have indicated in the preceding chapter the ravages which were already visible of the acute suffering to which she finally yielded a few years later Madame almost as great a coquette as Anne of Austria and the queen simple and natural as usual were seated beside her each contending for her good graces The ladies of honor united in a body in order to resist with greater effect and consequently with more success the witty and lively conversations which the young men held about them were enabled like a battalion formed in a square to offer each other the means of attack and defense which were thus at their command Montalais learned in that species of warfare which consists of sustained skirmishing protected the whole line by a sort of rolling fire she directed against the enemy SaintAignan in utter despair at the rigor which became almost insulting from the very fact of her persisting in it Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente displayed tried to turn his back upon her but overcome by the irresistible brilliancy of her eyes he every moment returned to consecrate his defeat by new submissions to which Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente did not fail to reply by fresh acts of impertinence SaintAignan did not know which way to turn La Valliere had about her not exactly a court but sprinklings of courtiers SaintAignan hoping by this maneuver to attract Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: That is not possible, said the queenmother, smiling.
children.prevalue: That is not possible said the queenmother smiling

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Why not?
children.prevalue: Why not

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: There are only two hundred tickets, so that it was not possible to inscribe every one's name on the list.
children.prevalue: There are only two hundred tickets so that it was not possible to inscribe every one s name on the list

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: And hers is not there, then?
children.prevalue: And hers is not there then

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: No!
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: What a pity! she might have won them, and then sold them.
children.prevalue: What a pity she might have won them and then sold them

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Sold them! exclaimed the queen.
children.prevalue: Sold them exclaimed the queen

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Yes; it would have been a dowry for her, and she would not have been obliged to marry without her trousseau, as will probably be the case.
children.prevalue: Yes it would have been a dowry for her and she would not have been obliged to marry without her trousseau as will probably be the case

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Really, answered the queenmother, poor little thing: has she no dresses, then?
children.prevalue: Really answered the queenmother poor little thing has she no dresses then

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: And she pronounced these words like a woman who has never been able to understand the inconveniences of a slenderly filled purse.
children.prevalue: And she pronounced these words like a woman who has never been able to understand the inconveniences of a slenderly filled purse

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Stay, look at her. Heaven forgive me, if she is not wearing the very same petticoat this evening that she had on this morning during the promenade, and which she managed to keep clean, thanks to the care the king took of her, in sheltering her from the rain.
children.prevalue: Stay look at her Heaven forgive me if she is not wearing the very same petticoat this evening that she had on this morning during the promenade and which she managed to keep clean thanks to the care the king took of her in sheltering her from the rain

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: At the very moment Madame uttered these words the king entered the room. The two queens would not perhaps have observed his arrival, so completely were they occupied in their illnatured remarks, had not Madame noticed that, all at once, La Valliere, who was standing up facing the gallery, exhibited certain signs of confusion, and then said a few words to the courtiers who surrounded her, who immediately dispersed. This movement induced Madame to look towards the door, and at that moment, the captain of the guards announced the king. At this moment La Valliere, who had hitherto kept her eyes fixed upon the gallery, suddenly cast them down as the king entered. His majesty was dressed magnificently and in the most perfect taste; he was conversing with Monsieur and the Duc de Roquelaure, Monsieur on his right, and the Duc de Roquelaure on his left. The king advanced, in the first place, towards the queens, to whom he bowed with an air full of graceful respect. He took his mother's hand and kissed it, addressed a few compliments to Madame upon the beauty of her toilette, and then began to make the round of the assembly. La Valliere was saluted in the same manner as the others, but with neither more nor less attention. His majesty then returned to his mother and his wife. When the courtiers noticed that the king had only addressed some ordinary remark to the young girl who had been so particularly noticed in the morning, they immediately drew their own conclusion to account for this coldness of manner; this conclusion being, that although the king may have taken a sudden fancy to her, that fancy had already disappeared. One thing, however, must be remarked, that close beside La Valliere, among the number of the courtiers, M. Fouquet was to be seen; and his respectfully attentive manner served to sustain the young girl in the midst of the varied emotions that visibly agitated her.

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: M. Fouquet was just on the point, moreover, of speaking in a more friendly manner with Mademoiselle de la Valliere, when M. Colbert approached, and after having bowed to Fouquet with all the formality of respectful politeness, he seemed to take up a post beside La Valliere, for the purpose of entering into conversation with her. Fouquet immediately quitted his place. These proceedings were eagerly devoured by the eyes of Montalais and Malicorne, who mutually exchanged their observations on the subject. De Guiche, standing within the embrasure of one of the windows, saw no one but Madame. But as Madame, on her side, frequently glanced at La Valliere, De Guiche's eyes, following Madame's, were from time to time cast upon the young girl. La Valliere instinctively felt herself sinking beneath the weight of all these different looks, inspired, some by interest, others by envy. She had nothing to compensate her for her sufferings, not a kind word from her companions, nor a look of affection from the king. No one could possibly express the misery the poor girl was suffering. The queenmother next directed the small table to be brought forward, on which the lotterytickets were placed, two hundred in number, and begged Madame de Motteville to read the list of the names. It was a matter of course that this list had been drawn out in strict accordance with the laws of etiquette. The king's name was first on the list, next the queenmother, then the queen, Monsieur, Madame, and so on. All hearts throbbed anxiously as the list was read out; more than three hundred persons had been invited, and each of them was anxious to learn whether his or her name was to be found in the number of privileged names. The king listened with as much attention as the others, and when the last name had been pronounced, he noticed that La Valliere had been omitted from the list. Every one, of course, remarked this omission. The king flushed as if much annoyed; but La Valliere, gentle and resigned, as usual, exhibited nothing of the sort. While the list was being read, the king had not taken his eyes off the young girl, who seemed to expand, as it were, beneath the happy influence she felt was shed around her, and who was delighted and too pure in spirit for any other thought than that of love to find an entrance either to her mind or her heart. Acknowledging this touching selfdenial by the fixity of his attention, the king showed La Valliere how much he appreciated its delicacy. When the list was finished, the different faces of those who had been omitted or forgotten fully expressed their disappointment. Malicorne was also left out from amongst the men; and the grimace he made plainly said to Montalais, who was also forgotten, Cannot we contrive to arrange matters with Fortune in such a manner that she shall not forget us? to which a smile full of intelligence from Mademoiselle Aure, replied: Certainly we can.

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The tickets were distributed to each according to the number listed. The king received his first, next the queenmother, then Monsieur, then the queen and Madame, and so on. After this, Anne of Austria opened a small Spanish leather bag, containing two hundred numbers engraved upon small balls of motherofpearl, and presented the open sack to the youngest of her maids of honor, for the purpose of taking one of the balls out of it. The eager expectation of the throng, amidst all the tediously slow preparations, was rather that of cupidity than curiosity. SaintAignan bent towards Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente to whisper to her, Since we have each a number, let us unite our two chances. The bracelet shall be yours if I win, and if you are successful, deign to give me but one look of your beautiful eyes.

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: No, said Athenais, if you win the bracelet, keep it, every one for himself.
children.prevalue: No said Athenais if you win the bracelet keep it every one for himself

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: You are without any pity, said SaintAignan, and I will punish you by a quatrain:
children.prevalue: You are without any pity said SaintAignan and I will punish you by a quatrain

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Beautiful Iris, to my vows You are too opposed
children.prevalue: Beautiful Iris to my vows You are too opposed

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Silence, said Athenais, you will prevent me hearing the winning number.
children.prevalue: Silence said Athenais you will prevent me hearing the winning number

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Number one, said the young girl who had drawn the motherofpearl from the Spanish leather bag.
children.prevalue: Number one said the young girl who had drawn the motherofpearl from the Spanish leather bag

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: The king! exclaimed the queenmother.
children.prevalue: The king exclaimed the queenmother

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The king has won, repeated the queen, delightedly.
children.prevalue: The king has won repeated the queen delightedly

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Oh! the king! your dream! said Madame, joyously, in the ear of Anne of Austria.
children.prevalue: Oh the king your dream said Madame joyously in the ear of Anne of Austria

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The king was the only one who did not exhibit any satisfaction. He merely thanked Fortune for what she had done for him, in addressing a slight salutation to the young girl who had been chosen as her proxy. Then receiving from the hands of Anne of Austria, amid the eager desire of the whole assembly, the casket inclosing the bracelets, he said, Are these bracelets really beautiful, then?
children.prevalue: The king was the only one who did not exhibit any satisfaction He merely thanked Fortune for what she had done for him in addressing a slight salutation to the young girl who had been chosen as her proxy Then receiving from the hands of Anne of Austria amid the eager desire of the whole assembly the casket inclosing the bracelets he said Are these bracelets really beautiful then

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Look at them, said Anne of Austria, and judge for yourself.
children.prevalue: Look at them said Anne of Austria and judge for yourself

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The king looked at them, and said, Yes, indeed, an admirable medallion. What perfect finish!
children.prevalue: The king looked at them and said Yes indeed an admirable medallion What perfect finish

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Queen Maria Theresa easily saw, and that, too at the very first glance, that the king would not offer the bracelets to her; but, as he did not seem the least degree in the world disposed to offer them to Madame, she felt almost satisfied, or nearly so. The king sat down. The most intimate among the courtiers approached, one by one, for the purpose of admiring more closely the beautiful piece of workmanship, which soon, with the king's permission, was handed about from person to person. Immediately, every one, connoisseurs or not, uttered various exclamations of surprise, and overwhelmed the king with congratulations. There was, in fact, something for everybody to admirethe brilliance for some, and the cutting for others. The ladies present visibly displayed their impatience to see such a treasure monopolized by the gentlemen.
