children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Gentlemen, gentlemen, said the king, whom nothing escaped, one would almost think that you wore bracelets as the Sabines used to do; hand them round for a while for the inspection of the ladies, who seem to have, and with far greater right, an excuse for understanding such matters!
children.prevalue: Gentlemen gentlemen said the king whom nothing escaped one would almost think that you wore bracelets as the Sabines used to do hand them round for a while for the inspection of the ladies who seem to have and with far greater right an excuse for understanding such matters

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: These words appeared to Madame the commencement of a decision she expected. She gathered, besides, this happy belief from the glances of the queenmother. The courtier who held them at the moment the king made this remark, amidst the general agitation, hastened to place the bracelets in the hands of the queen, Maria Theresa, who, knowing too well, poor woman, that they were not designed for her, hardly looked at them, and almost immediately passed them on to Madame. The latter, and even more minutely, Monsieur, gave the bracelets a long look of anxious and almost covetous desire. She then handed the jewels to those ladies who were near her, pronouncing this single word, but with an accent which was worth a long phrase, Magnificent!
children.prevalue: These words appeared to Madame the commencement of a decision she expected She gathered besides this happy belief from the glances of the queenmother The courtier who held them at the moment the king made this remark amidst the general agitation hastened to place the bracelets in the hands of the queen Maria Theresa who knowing too well poor woman that they were not designed for her hardly looked at them and almost immediately passed them on to Madame The latter and even more minutely Monsieur gave the bracelets a long look of anxious and almost covetous desire She then handed the jewels to those ladies who were near her pronouncing this single word but with an accent which was worth a long phrase Magnificent

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: The ladies who had received the bracelets from Madame's hands looked at them as long as they chose to examine them, and then made them circulate by passing them on towards the right. During this time the king was tranquilly conversing with De Guiche and Fouquet, rather passively letting them talk than himself listening. Accustomed to the set form of ordinary phrases, his ear, like that of all men who exercise an incontestable superiority over others, merely selected from the conversations held in various directions the indispensable word which requires reply. His attention, however, was now elsewhere, for it wandered as his eyes did.
children.prevalue: The ladies who had received the bracelets from Madame s hands looked at them as long as they chose to examine them and then made them circulate by passing them on towards the right During this time the king was tranquilly conversing with De Guiche and Fouquet rather passively letting them talk than himself listening Accustomed to the set form of ordinary phrases his ear like that of all men who exercise an incontestable superiority over others merely selected from the conversations held in various directions the indispensable word which requires reply His attention however was now elsewhere for it wandered as his eyes did

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente was the last of the ladies inscribed for tickets; and, as if she had ranked according to her name upon the list, she had only Montalais and La Valliere near her. When the bracelets reached these two latter, no one appeared to take any further notice of them. The humble hands which for a moment touched these jewels, deprived them, for the time, of their importancea circumstance which did not, however, prevent Montalais from starting with joy, envy, and covetous desire, at the sight of the beautiful stones still more than at their magnificent workmanship. It is evident that if she were compelled to decide between the pecuniary value and the artistic beauty, Montalais would unhesitatingly have preferred diamonds to cameos, and her disinclination, therefore, to pass them on to her companion, La Valliere, was very great. La Valliere fixed a look almost of indifference upon the jewels.

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Oh, how beautiful, how magnificent these bracelets are! exclaimed Montalais; and yet you do not go into ecstasies about them, Louise! You are no true woman, I am sure.
children.prevalue: Oh how beautiful how magnificent these bracelets are exclaimed Montalais and yet you do not go into ecstasies about them Louise You are no true woman I am sure

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Yes, I am, indeed, replied the young girl, with an accent of the most charming melancholy; but why desire that which can never, by any possibility, be ours?
children.prevalue: Yes I am indeed replied the young girl with an accent of the most charming melancholy but why desire that which can never by any possibility be ours

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The king, his head bent forward, was listening to what Louise was saying. Hardly had the vibration of her voice reached his ear than he rose, radiant with delight, and passing across the whole assembly, from the place where he stood, to La Valliere, You are mistaken, mademoiselle, he said, you are a woman, and every woman has a right to wear jewels, which are a woman's appurtenance.
children.prevalue: The king his head bent forward was listening to what Louise was saying Hardly had the vibration of her voice reached his ear than he rose radiant with delight and passing across the whole assembly from the place where he stood to La Valliere You are mistaken mademoiselle he said you are a woman and every woman has a right to wear jewels which are a woman s appurtenance

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Oh, sire! said La Valliere, your majesty will not absolutely believe in my modesty?
children.prevalue: Oh sire said La Valliere your majesty will not absolutely believe in my modesty

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I believe you possess every virtue, mademoiselle; frankness as well as every other; I entreat you, therefore, to say frankly what you think of these bracelets?
children.prevalue: I believe you possess every virtue mademoiselle frankness as well as every other I entreat you therefore to say frankly what you think of these bracelets

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: That they are beautiful, sire, and cannot be offered to any other than a queen.
children.prevalue: That they are beautiful sire and cannot be offered to any other than a queen

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: I am delighted that such is your opinion, mademoiselle; the bracelets are yours, and the king begs your acceptance of them.
children.prevalue: I am delighted that such is your opinion mademoiselle the bracelets are yours and the king begs your acceptance of them

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: And as, with a movement almost resembling terror, La Valliere eagerly held out the casket to the king, the king gently pushed back her trembling hand.
children.prevalue: And as with a movement almost resembling terror La Valliere eagerly held out the casket to the king the king gently pushed back her trembling hand

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: A silence of astonishment, more profound than that of death, reigned in the assembly.
children.prevalue: A silence of astonishment more profound than that of death reigned in the assembly

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: And yet, from the side where the queens were, no one had heard what he had said, nor understood what he had done. A charitable friend, however, took upon herself to spread the news; it was TonnayCharente, to whom Madame had made a sign to approach.
children.prevalue: And yet from the side where the queens were no one had heard what he had said nor understood what he had done A charitable friend however took upon herself to spread the news it was TonnayCharente to whom Madame had made a sign to approach

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Good heavens! explained TonnayCharente, how happy that La Valliere is! the king has just given her the bracelets.
children.prevalue: Good heavens explained TonnayCharente how happy that La Valliere is the king has just given her the bracelets

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Madame bit her lips to such a degree that the blood appeared upon the surface of the skin. The young queen looked first at La Valliere and then at Madame, and began to laugh. Anne of Austria rested her chin upon her beautiful white hand, and remained for a long time absorbed by a presentiment that disturbed her mind, and by a terrible pang which stung her heart. De Guiche, observing Madame turn pale, and guessing the cause of her change of color, abruptly quitted the assembly and disappeared. Malicorne was then able to approach Montalais very quietly, and under cover of the general din of conversation, said to her:

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Aure, your fortune and our future are standing at your elbow.
children.prevalue: Aure your fortune and our future are standing at your elbow

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Yes, was her reply, as she tenderly embraced La Valliere, whom, inwardly, she was tempted to strangle.
children.prevalue: Yes was her reply as she tenderly embraced La Valliere whom inwardly she was tempted to strangle
